Response: From the very beginning I had a love for math and science. I loved how the numbers just made sense in my mind and loathed the feeling of solving a complicated problem. I found myself asking my parents and teachers questions I had about the way the world worked and the inter-workings of different simple machines I encountered. When I got to high school I searched for every opportunity to immerse myself in the science and math community. The notion that I could select the things I wanted to learn about really enthused me. My first interaction with rudimentary physics was when I had the opportunity to take AP Physics 1 and 2. I looked forward to going to those classes everyday and loved how it allowed me to explain the curiosities I came across. This is also one of the first times I realized the lack of women in physics programs. I was one of two women in my physics 2 class and this angered me in a way. But"," it also allowed me to be confidence in my own abilities and urged me to want to pursue a career in physics.

I first took a physics class in my junior year of high school. My dad is a physics professor"," so I`d been exposed to it beforehand when he told us about his research and took us to the department. That sparked some interest in me"," but my high school teacher definitely set the ball rolling - he engaged with students and didn`t mind taking extra time to reexplain concepts in new ways"," which made the subject accessible and fascinating. I felt like I left class each day with a warped and new view of the world.Last year I took a second physics class and found it interesting enough to try adding as a major in college. Being first and foremost an art student"," I feel like my second major sometimes pull me apart from the other art students"," which can be discouraging. Other young girls studying science and math in opposition of the large gender gap"," however"," inspire me - I also want to help fight for its closure. I don`t have a job in mind that I`d like to pursue after graduation"," but I do have a large desire to keep learning about this subject and see where it takes me.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: I first considered physics as a major when I took my first physics class in junior year of high school. Originally I did not see myself liking physics"," but I ended up finding myself enjoying it a lot and putting a lot of extra effort into the class. I owe a lot of that to the teacher I had at the time because he knew that I really liked it and he would always answer my extra questions even though they were beyond the scope of the class. When I expressed interest in pursuing physics further"," I kind of expected to be told that I wasn`t really cut out for it (not because of things other people said but because of my own perceptions of myself)"," but I talked to that teacher about it and he encouraged me a lot and told me he thought it was a great choice for me. That meant a lot to me and I don`t think I would be where I am if I had not had that mentorship. Then"," when I got to college I wasn`t sure if I would be able to "handle it." But"," I ended up doing pretty well in my initial classes and really enjoying the challenge of them. I also found other people in the same/similar majors and had an older student as a mentor who encouraged me. And so I continued on because I liked it and I had no reason not to.

Ever since I was a freshman in high school"," I knew whatever I was interested in at the moment would never overcome my interest in science. My dad is a physicist"," and I grew up with him doing science experiments with my sister and I. I was always so interested in how and why everything worked so even though I had never taken a physics class"," I would be interested in it. Throughout high school I questioned everything. I tried learning for the knowledge"," not just the grade"," like several of my peers. Even now"," I do the same. Some might think I am honorable by doing things the hard way"," but that is how I learn. With every mistake comes new understanding"," and I now know that is why I have chosen the Physics way of life.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: I had always wanted to become an astronaut as a child. When I realized how dangerous it was"," I decided I wanted to study space from the ground. In Junior High I found astrophysics and since then I have been striving to become an astrophysicist.

I fell in love with physics while watching NOVA documentaries in middle school. I started read a lot of math and physics books targeted at a more general audience and found it fascinating.Unfortunately I`m very shy by nature. I`ve been plagued with extreme issues of self-doubt. Once upon a time I was the typical straight-A hardworking high school student. However"," since halfway through highschool I`ve been treated for severe depression and been through a number of confusing medication changes. Eventually I was tested and diagnosed with mild to moderate OCD and ADHD"," but to this day it has been the depression that has been the hardest issue for me to shake. I still love physics. I`m just not sure if someone "like me--prone to extreme self-criticism and simultaneously manages to be too perfectionistic and yet astoundingly disorganized--will be able to last in field like physics and STEM. My doubts are as to whether I`ll ever be able to have the discipline and mindset to get what needs to be done during periods when my moods tend to sink.Research and having an advisor/mentor has been an amazing experience. My interactions with a recent past internship really forced me to communicate and engage in ways that I (all too often) shy away from with direct communication with professors"
Codes: Media Triggered, Cost (Outside Effort), Cost (Emotional), Event Triggered, Social Persuasion

Response: When I started taking physics in 7th grade"," I was amazed by theexplanatory and predictive power of physics.Although I wanted to major in physics at that time"," I feltthat it was too late for me to major in the natural sciences. Back at home"," studentswho made up their minds to go into the sciences went to ha-gwons or weretutored to prepare for science magnet high schools as early as in 4th grade.Because I had not been receiving a structured science education outside ofschool"," I felt that physics was not an option for me. I ended up going to amagnet school for the social sciences"," where I met a handful of students whowere planning on going into the natural sciences. I realized that it was notlate to pursue a career in physics"," and have considered myself a to-bephysicist since then.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Outside Effort), Vicarious Experience

Response: My middle school teacher influenced me to pursue a career in science.Then I became interested in astronomy and physics on my own.Since starting college"," my interests changed to applied physics"," and now I an considering going to a Business school.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: I enjoyed physics in high school. My teacher was very good. Most of what we did in high school was easy for me. I thought I would be good at it.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: As a kid"," I was very interested in the stars and astrophysics related content. I pursued physics inside and outside of school in order to feed this interest. As I got older"," I realized that I really liked physics as a field"," but that astrophysics was not what interested me. Currently I am looking into climate related studies. I don`t know exactly what I want to do"," but I do know that I want to do something that gives back. I want my work to benefit people around me.
I loved physics in high school because I had an amazing teacher. I continued in college because I like it and was good at it"," I also had a women professor who was very inspiring.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience

Response: I initially came into undergrad intending to major in marine biology"," but I quickly realized that what I most enjoyed in high school was physics. I took both Honors and AP Physics courses in high school and loved the problem-solving aspect of the field.

Ever since I was a kid"," I have been very curious about the universe and how everything works. I always loved going to the Planetarium"," watching science television shows"," and reading books about science. My dad has always made sure to encourage my love for science and in particular astronomy. I have always wanted to be a physicist"," but once I entered high school and discovered how much I loved mathematics and physics and excelled at AP Physics"," I knew that was the job for me.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience

Response: I became a physics major because of my excellent HS teacher and because upon entering college I was unsure what I wanted to do but I had learned that physics was a major that you could apply to almost anything. Later in college I participated in a program to explore teaching and also was an assistant in a teaching lab which has led me to pursue a career as a physics teacher.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Utility Value, Event Triggered

Response: I became very interested in astronomy when I was in high school. Though never taken a physics class prior to attending Purdue University"," I read several books on the string theory"," the Big Bang"," and elementary particles that are constituents of the universe. From that point onward"," I did research on black holes and their characteristics and many other celestial objects. From that"," I became even more intrigued which motivated me to explore the physics behind them and become a physics major.

The first time I considered physics was when I found out that my late grandfather had been an engineer for the US Navy. I was 15 at the time"," and I thought it was really interesting. Back then I wanted to be more like him"," but I knew I didn`t want to go into engineering specifically"," so I began looking around and found physics. When I was a senior in high school"," I took my school`s only physics class and absolutely fell in love. I loved the difficulty of solving a problem"," and the satisfaction of finally figuring it out. My physics teacher picked up early on that I was interested"," and he always encouraged me to pursue it further. He never made me feel strange as a woman interested in the subject. When it came time for college applications"," he made sure that I sat down with him to talk about being a physics major. His encouragement and my own interest are what led me to MTSU. Here"," I have found professors who are even more encouraging than my high school teacher"," and their passion for teaching has helped me rediscover my own passion for the subject again and again.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion

Response: I had a very passionate high school physics teacher. I already liked to know how things worked"," and she showed me that by studying physics you can a large amount of the natural phenomenon in the world at the fundamental level. She also lent me a book about the discovery of the Higgs boson that illustrated the amazing working being done if physics right now.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Vicarious Experience

Response: I never considered physics or anything science related as a profession or major until junior year of high school. I was good at math and science but only stayed in them to prove that I could do that as well as humanities geared subjects. I feel in love with Chemistry and experimentation. Someone told me it was hard but I saw beauty in it. I loved how it described everything around me with such precision on a more fundamental that inspired me where classic mechanics didn`t. I ended up entering college going into Engineering and have worked with physics demos and seen that there is so much I don`t know that I NEED to know. I`ve been influenced greatly by my professors and teachers"," but it has been their ability to show physics in an involving way that has pulled me in.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: Since I am majoring in computer science"," my thought was that I want to do research"," but I am not sure in what discipline. I have always been fascinated by how things work both mechanically and biologically"," so when I had the opportunity to take an astronomy course"," I took it. When talking to my professor"," my interest in doing research came up and I learned that they do physics research and were in need of a computer scientist. I couldn`t believe my ears"," it was exactly the kind of experience I was looking for. After working in the lab on a particle physics project"," I decided to take on a minor in physics. Because of my interest in physics"," I had already taken all of the general physics and math courses necessary to complete the minor; I only had 3 upper division courses to take"," so I was excited to get started. In conclusion"," I kind of fell into my role as a physics lab assistant and minor"," but I honestly believe I found these opportunities mainly because I was looking for them.

I took AP physics in high school since I didn`t want to take any of the other science courses"," and i really enjoyed it. I had a great teacher and by the end of the course I had decided I might want to go into physics in college.I thought I was going to be a computer science major"," but I was still really interested in physics since special relativity was a really fascinating course"," in my first semester at Mudd. However"," I didn`t really like mechanics"," but it was still cool what I could do with physics.I also took a humanities course spring of freshman year about Nothing"," and wrote my final essay on nothing from a physics perspective"," looking at quantum mechanics. It was really interesting"," and when I took Electromagnetism this fall"," I realized how interesting physics can be.So"," I decided to be a physics major.
Read pop sci books about quantum mechanics after hearing about the Higgs Boson discovery and wanted to be able to understand more.

I am currently a physics/biology major. Initially I was a biology major"," but after presenting my research at an emerging researchers national scientists conference in Washington"," D.C."," a physics professor at my university"," Dr. Mostafa Dokhanian"," became interested in my educational pursuits. I was the recipient of the presidential scholarship at my university at that time. I was later selected for a physics internship and did biophysics research. Following that I was selected for a internship at Harvard University where I was introduced to and participated in cutting edge biology research. Because of the need for diversity of knowledge that crosses scientific disciplines that has arisen in the world of science today"," I am firmly convinced that now it is more important than ever to combine forces across the sciences to address problems that are posed to society today. This summer I was selected for an internship where I participated in physics and material science engineering. I received a travel award and presented two posters at The Botanical Society of America Conference in July"," where I was also teamed there with my Harvard mentor. I presented one in physics/material science and one in biology. My colleagues and supporters were intrigued and very supportive of my desire to cross and integrate science disciplines. I am very interested in biophysics"," biomedical engineering and see the necessity of applying all of these sciences in today???s world. In January of last year"," by physics mentor and friend"," Dr. Mostafa Dokhanian died at his desk while working on grant proposals to help students. Although I miss him and his encouragement greatly"," I still seek his vision. He instilled within me the vision to cross science disciplines"," combining their strengths in order to achieve the ability to help humanity at its greatest needs"," whatever they could be. I am now on a physics scholarship which will enable me to complete the physics requirements and obtain both degrees simultaneously in May"," 2016 after which time I intend to go to graduate school and enroll in a doctoral program.
Codes: Event Triggered, Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Biophysics), Utility Value

Response: I took an independent study course on calculus based physics in high school because I really liked physics and math but I never considered it a viable career option (I didn`t have much interest in teaching).It took me until my 4th year of undergrad to consider it an option and even that was pure chance. I had been diagnosed with a learning disability (I prefer the term difference vs. disability) and also found out I had a remarkably high IQ that had been masked by my uncontrolled symptoms. I realized that I wasn`t bad at my major"," I was bored and uninterested. I knew I needed a change from the major and to get away from large class sizes so I started looking at transferring to a private university. When I took a tour of my current university"," I thought I wanted to pursue Mechanical or Electrical Engineering but mentioned offhandedly that I was curious about the physics program. His friend was an Engineering Physics major and was able to drop by to talk to me for a few minutes. I also was lucky that the Head of the Physics Department was available to speak with me about it as well and show me the labs. Good thing I ran into them"," I was immediately hooked and it`s continued to be a great fit ever since.I wouldn`t say it has been the easiest decision but it definitely is the right one. When I first transferred"," I remember seeing shocked looks on my peers` faces (sometimes my professors` too) when I would get one of the top scores in the class on a big assignment or exam. I don`t know if this is because I am a female"," that I was new"," or that I may not come across as very confident. I also feel compelled to downplay my abilities when amongst my peers"," possibly due to instinctive reaction to fit in or that I don`t want to hurt anyone`s feelings.My professors have definitely been the most motivating/inspiring and supportive for me. They took the time to get to know me and to be patient with my questions"," both course and career related. They believe in me in a way no one ever really has and it makes me feel confident in my decision"," like I belong in physics. Several of my physics professors are also women - it has been very nice to have role models that are somewhat like me. Now"," the biggest question is grad school. I have the talent to go but I`m worried about the amount of interest that would accumulate on my undergraduate loans and my personal life. Industry has its appeal but the difficult part is finding a position challenging and complex enough to keep me interested long term.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Outside Effort), Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience

Response: I had an amazing physics teacher in high school. I took my first physics class during my sophomore year of high school and that`s when I first became interested in physics and science overall. During my senior year I took another physics class to see if physics was something that I was really interested in pursuing. With the support of my high school physics teacher and my peaked interestin physics I decided that I would major in physics once I was accepted into Ohio State. Although physics has been difficult at times during my time at Ohio State"," I know that this is something that I want to continue working toward especially since there is such a small amount of African American Women in the field.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Cost (Task Effort)

Response: It has been very pleasant. The physics department at Cal Poly Pomona is very friendly and helpful.

My grandpa was a civil engineer who I always looked up to. I always enjoyed math and I knew I wanted to be an engineer"," but I didn`t feel prepared for engineering school. I took a liberal arts approach instead"," focusing on math and physics. Next year"," I hope to transfer into a civil engineering program and hopefully obtain a BA in physics"," as well. I should also note that I have not completed courses in Classical Mechanics and Electromagnetism I"," but I am taking them currently.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I`ve always known that I wanted to pursue physics"," but the ACE program at UCSC inspired me to apply for research positions and taught me to have faith in myself. Until I attended ACE I really didn`t think I could do it.
The inherent coolness of physics and the inspiring and helpful people (teachers"," professors"," classmates"," grad students) I meet along the way

When compared to most"," I am a relative new-comer to Physics.I very recently (the summer before my junior year of my undergraduate studies) switched my major of study from Mechanical Engineering to Physics. There were many contributing factors"," the most prominent of which was a feeling of satisfaction that only comes when doing something that you love absolutely. I knew that I wanted to do physics after taking the first installment of my lower division physics course"," I spent the next two quarters and summer convincing myself that it was a practical choice. This hesitation was due to misconceptions I had about job prospects after graduation and what career path I wanted to pursue. I eventually decided my love of physics was too strong"," and outweighed the struggles I may or may not face after obtaining my degree. Later I learned that my worries were essentially for nothing"," and that there is a wide array of jobs awaiting physics graduates. Every aspect"," even the trying ones"," that I???ve experienced in physics has consistently reaffirmed that my decision to switch was an excellent choice.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Intrinsic Value

Response: Throughout middle school and most of high school I had the intention of going to college and majoring in journalism"," until I began to develop a deep interest in space and space travel. In my high school Calculus class we watched "Hidden Figures""," and it introduced me to the idea of working at NASA in any capacity. I decided to take AP Physics 1 my senior year of high school"," and I ended up really liking it and being good at it. My mom played a large part in me deciding to major in physics because she encouraged me to enter a field where women are underrepresented"," and where the subject matter was interesting to me. I chose to major in physics and minor in astronomy with the intention of getting my Ph.D. in astrophysics. My goal is to work at NASA as an astronaut studying dark matter.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience, Utility Value, Social Persuasion

Response: I took a physical science class in the eighth grade and from that class on I knew I wanted to learn more about physics. I remember learning about acceleration and deceleration and how it affects motion. That was the first time I began to notice those concepts in the real world like when I was in a car I could actually feel the car accelerate and change motion. I decided to take physics both junior year and senior year of high school"," and that was one of the best decisions I have made because my physics teacher is one of my best friends and the biggest supporter of my education in physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: - I wanted to be a pilot; however"," my eyesight was unacceptable- Since I couldn`t be a pilot"," I wanted to work on space shuttles.- Thought about going into aerospace engineering - The college I wanted to attend didn`t have that.- So"," I decided to go into

Physics has always been a challenge for me"," a big challenge. I feel like that is why I chose it to be my major"," why I wanted to study it.I took physics in high school and it was the best and worse thing I`ve ever done. It was such challenge"," the only challenging class I took in high school.My high school physics teacher always said "Physics is everything. That saying has stuck with me since then.Understanding physics and seeing how it`s happening all around us

After spending time in the professional world"," I decided to return to school to something challenging and physics was always something that I was interested in. I wanted to understand how the world worked.

My chemistry and physics high school teachers instilled in me a love and passion for science. My curiosity about then world around me drove me to pursue a degree in science at Allegheny College. I originally planned to major in chemistry"," but after taking introductory physics courses at Allegheny"," I quickly realized my true interests lie in the fundamental concepts physics so elegantly describe using mathematics. After talking with my professor and some older students in the department"," I decided to switch my major and am thankful for that decision everyday. Pursuing physics has allowed me to learn and grow more than I ever thought I could.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: I had to take a physics course to fulfill a science graduation requirement in high school and then with the persuasion of the entire math and science department at my high school"," took Calculus based Physics my senior year.  Over the course of the year"," realized it made a lot of sense and that I wanted to know more about it.  I then had to decide on my college majors and knew I wanted to teach math and one of a handful of other subjects.  I ended up deciding on Physics as my second subject to get licensed in because it fascinated me my last year and there were so many paths to take in college.  Since then"," I have taken courses that will support me in being a high school physics teacher and have pursued research in high-energy particle physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Event Triggered

Response: My mother is a physicist"," so it`s always been an option I`ve considered. It wasn`t until my really excellent high school physics teacher that I realized I for sure wanted to study/do physics.

Well"," I was a graphic designer and didn`t love it anymore while I took a required class called `Visions of the Universe` that blew my mind. It was an astro class and I immediately did research on how to become an astrophysics major"," shortly after that I changed my major and have loved it ever since.

I initially never intended to become a physics major. I had always loved math and wanted to pursue a career that involved using this skill. Physics finally entered my thoughts of a major my sophomore year when I realized that a major in this would greatly help me in my goals of working in engineering. One of my main influences during the way would have to be my mentors in a program we have here at my college called MapCores. This group is for girls going into fields such as Math"," Computer Science"," Physics and Engineering. After being around girls with many of the same interests I found out that this is the type of field that I feel like I belong and will thrive in.
Codes: Utility Value, Event Triggered, Viarious Experience, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: Attending a science camp in Barcelona Spain helped expose me to the scientific community"," whilst presenting the information to my classmates made me realize how this could become a career.

I attended another university for four years and obtained a degree in Justice Studies. Three-quarters of the way through the program"," I realized it was not my passion and began looking for other options. Physics"," specifically astrophysics and astronomy has always appealed to me even without any physics background. I needed a change in my environment"," so I began researching astrophysics-related majors and came across the Space Physics program at Embry-Riddle. After learning about the program and the university itself"," I knew I needed to take a chance and follow my passion.

The physics department at my college has an amazing sense of community and a commitment to collaborative learning. The biggest reason I have stuck it out so long is the consistent support and understanding we receive from our Professors and the strength I derive from struggling through the hard classes with my peers.

I was 26"," working as a bartender/server at a country club and realized it might actually be possible for me to go back to school. I`ve always known I wanted more for myself"," but I was uncertain of what that was exactly. I`ve always been good in math and also drawn to the sciences"," and one day it just clicked. Physics was what I wanted to do. I made an appointment to speak to a community college since I`d been out of school so long"," and started my journey. Now"," I`m at a four year institution and am a junior. I`m studying physics with an emphasis in astronomy and I couldn`t be happier! I finally found my calling.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Attainment Value

Response: I`ve originally wanted to become an astronomer when I was a young girl. I would gather different types of booksconcerning anything about astronomy. I remember I would my constellation book everyday to my high school. When I entered my first year in college"," I was determined to become more engage in what I`m most passionate of. The first step I`ve done was to major into physics and then joined the physics and astronomy club in my college. So far"," I have already volunteered two conferences that wereheld in Utah Valley University. The first event I volunteered was called the Four Corners Section of the APS","held on October 7th-8th"," 2014. The second event I volunteered at was called `Empowering Your Tomorrow Boy`s Conference`"," held on November 8th"," 2014. Up until now"," I`ve felt satisfied with the accomplishments I have done up to this point and I plan on graduating with a degree in physics.

I was first exposed to physics in high school and was intrigued by learning about the world around me in such a different way. I graduated with a continued curiosity for how things work and why things are the way that they are"," and the first college course I wanted to take was Introduction to the Universe. This course sparked an even deeper passion and wonder for physics and studying the processes and happenings in the multiverse.
I had always been interested in physics since I was young"," and once I started taking physics courses it only solidified that it was something I wanted to pursue.

I took physics my junior year of high school because I didn`t think I`d do well in anatomy. I happened to have a wonderful teacher","who really made the material feel real to me"," and although the subject matter was harder than most of my other classes at the time"," I really felt that I connected to the material. However"," I have a much older passion for Religious Studies"," and didn`t think of physics as my primary major until I got to college and realized how much more work it is than most majors.
I entered college as an astronomy major"," and decided several weeks into the semester to declare a second major in physics in order to be seen as more legitimate after graduation.

While I was dual-enrolled at UWG"," I had to take one more science to get my high school diploma"," so I took astronomy. I loved coming home every day and telling my mom what I had learned because it was so exciting. From that point on I decided to pursue a physics b.s and continue to graduate school for astrophysics.

I took an honours physics course in 10th grade of High school. The teacher was very mean and made the class an unpleasant experience. However I just really loved the subject despite that and that I wanted to take another Physics course again"," which I was unable to do in High School. So I decided to take an intro level Physics course in college and decided I wanted to major in it"," and the physics faculty at my school have been very helpful and supportive of me so far.

Ive always had an interest in space/cosmology"," and wanted to understand on a grand scale how things came to be as they are. I believe people in prominent media such as Neil Degrasse Tyson and Bill Nye were easily accessible to me so they jump-started my passion to purse this field. Along the way"," reading books and watching sci fi shows (so again largely media) influenced by decision to pursue this path. The motivation my teachers gave me also largely helped push me towards picking physics as well.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Social Persuasion

Response: I have always been curious about outer space and the formation of planets and other extra terrestrial bodies. I began taking prerequisites for a b.s. in geology and realized in a chemistry class that I want to understand more about physics so I found a planetary science program that will allow me to explore both topics further.

When I was in 7th grade and was competing in the science olympiad"," my event was simple machines"," and hardly a soul in my middle school knew enough about them to teach me or provide any advice. Through perseverance and hard work"," I won 6th place in the event despite competing alone. Fast forward to 9th and 10th grade"," I was warned by friends (they were male"," and I remember two in particular) that physics was difficult and I might not like it. I replied that it seemed like something I might like"," based on the experiences I had in middle school. I was right"," eventually???I really did enjoy it! I took both AP Physics B and C in high school; one of the students who warned me about physics was a year older than I"," and he eventually dropped Physics C because it was too difficult. The other was two years my senior"," and his warnings to me were about the difficulty of the class. He was working very hard"," but the subject itself was just very hard"," he said. I just remember finding my classes very enjoyable. They were at times difficult"," but never impossibly difficult. I was one of two girls in the class"," which represented a 100% increase from the previous year. It did make me uncomfortable that the class was so male"," because many of them had very immature senses of humor"," and the class was very relaxed"," so many of them felt comfortable expressing themselves. There were also two people in the class that stood out as high performers; one had ranked internationally in Physics Bowl during his first year of ever taking physics"," and the other was a year younger than most people in the class but was one of those people that just understood things instantaneously and thus excelled. I always enjoyed physics as a subject"," but I never thought of myself as particularly talented at physics until I came to college. I discovered"," to my surprise"," that there were fewer prodigies than had existed in my high school classroom"," and I found that most people actually struggled. Many of the engineers in introductory physics courses expressed that they really did not like the subject. I found this surprising. It was a very different shift in dynamics. I eventually involved myself in research with a professor in the ECE department. Her lab explores the synthesis of quantum dot thin film solar cells"," and I don`t claim to understand most of it"," but I am fascinated"," and I am learning.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Event Triggered, Physiological/Emotional, Cost (Emotional)

Response: 1. Keen interest in the history and development of sciences"," especially in the 19th and 20th century.2. Excellent high school physics teachers3. Wonderful physics department in college

I enjoyed basic introductions to physics in 8th grade"," but never as much as chemistry. I hated physics in 12th grade because I didn`t like my teacher and felt very uncomfortable in the class (I was one of three girls and there was borderline sexual harassment taking place). In College"," I started studying math"," and almost everyone who studied math also studied physics. I really liked the culture of the Math-Physics department at my College-the professors were accessible"," most students were very intelligent"," driven"," and friendly"," and half or more than half of the students were girls. I`m thinking of becoming a teacher"," and my school requires two teaching fields"," so I chose to major in Math-Physics so I could become qualified to teach both Math and Physics.

I initially entered college as an engineer. Because of a sequence of events that are funny looking back but were not funny then"," I didn`t get into the college of engineering. My hs physics teacher recommended that I start in physics and transfer into engineering when I could get into the college. After the first semester"," I ended up loving physics. I had an amazing mechanics professor (Dr. Tatiana Eurikhomova) who was very inspiring and motivating to me. Physics was my favorite class. And after freshman year"," I decided to definitely stay in physics. Since then"," I`ve made great friends and enjoyed my classes. After I get my bachelor`s degree I`m going to grad school"," and hopefully someday I will be doing research in particle physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Particle), Utility Value

Response: My father was a physics major"," and is heaviliy involved in the sciences in his field of work. I grew up with an above average knowledge of physics"," but my interests at that time lay in the liberal arts. During my first year of college"," where I was intending to major in psychology"," I took an introductory astronomy course. This was initially to fill a environmental science requirement"," but I was fascinated by how the topics my father had been talking about since I was a child combined with such fantastical concepts. I changed my major to astrophysics"," and have been enjoying the field ever since.
I took an AWESOME physics class in high school! before that"," I planned on being a math major. The class was fun and exciting"," and I like to read up on current events involving science.

When I was in elementary school I really liked science and math and watched a lot of shows like Cosmos on television. I later started reading popular science books by people like Stephen Hawking and Brian Greene and thought it was really cool and I wanted to do stuff like that.

I was first exposed to physics in my senior year of high school. I took a physics course along with an astronomy course. I found the overlap of these two courses very interesting. At the time"," I was also reading Carl Sagan`s "Cosmos"," and became fascinated with physics and cosmology. My teacher was very encouraging and would entertain all of my questions. He was sure that with hard work I could learn anything. I took this mindset along with me to college and despite some set backs have been fairly successful in my academics. Along the way
Codes: Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: When I took physics for the first time in my junior year of high school"," everything made total sense. I applied for a Research in Physics program at my school and got in--and realized that I loved it. I have since interned at CERN and NASA"," published my first paper as first author"," attended multiple conferences"," and won various research awards and scholarships. I plan to go to graduate school and continue working towards my dream of being a physics researcher at a national or international institute.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience, Utility Value

Response: In my high school Earth Science class"," the astronomy unit explained how physicists experimented until they could find equations and formulas that could explain how the universe functioned. I loved the aspect of science where you could use math to predict events"," but what I most liked about physics is that is was easy for me to see it in the world and apply it in everyday life. My science teacher encouraged me to enroll in the Idaho Science and Aerospace Scholars. This program was available to high school juniors"," and we would be sorted into different teams who would all work together to design a mission to Mars and present it at Boise State University. That was an amazing experience"," as I got to meet the man who currently held my dream job: being the head researcher on NASA`s SOFIA program. After enrolling at BSU"," I joined their Physics and Astronomy Club"," and became the vice president. The president at the time was a good friend of mine who took me under his wing and encouraged me to pursue my dream of researching physics.  His passion kept rubbing off on me"," and has helped motivate me during times where I feel I`ve bit off more than I can chew. I met the previous president who was a huge inspiration for me. She knew what she wanted"," and she was confident in herself and her abilities.Currently I`m a sophomore at BSU"," and I`m the president of the Physics and Astronomy Club. This semester"," my physics professor has been working closely with the club to find outreach opportunities that can help us become more successful and recognized in the community. The club has showed me what the physics community is truly about: sharing passion and supporting others. I love physics. It`s a practical science that melds well with the way I think"," and can explain anything in the universe. I love the physics community. It`s open"," supportive"," and generous. Powerful women have inspired me to continue on my path to success"," and I can`t wait for my next move.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: My mom is a physics teacher so I was exposed to science at a young age. In high school"," I took all the AP sciences that I could and I found that I liked AP Physics the best. After taking the first year of physics courses"," I knew I wanted to be a physics major. After doing a summer of research"," I knew I wanted to have a career in research.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: I`ve always had a head for numbers"," and in my senior year of high school"," I did very well in AP Physics. I pride myself on my achievements and talent"," so I decided to take more physics classes in college. The professors were wonderful. I enjoyed learning the material and seeing how different concepts came together. I made friends in the physics department"," and I joined the Society of Physics Students"," which made me feel like I was part of a community.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I started college as a biochemistry major and took physics as a requirement for that major sophomore year. I had taken physics in high school and was a mediocre student"," but had quite a knack for college physics. After a few weeks the professor noticed this and asked if I was interested in physics or had a background in physics. My chemistry adviser heard I was good at physics (I attend a very small school) and said I should consider adding a physics major. I initially thought she was insane"," but then decided to add the major. I have now changed my biochem major to chem because it ties in with physics more neatly.

A poster of the solar system that was posted by my parents on the wall of our bedroom. I was around 4 by then but I remember that special kind of feeling when I was looking into that poster. I felt like I was a part of universe though I had absolutely no idea what physics is.When I was in the 5th and 6th grade"," the school started to offer a course called "nature that covers the basic science (mostly physics). The teacher who was teaching that class "warned" us it would be a very hard course and it would be almost impossible to get perfect score. I felt challenged and surprisingly found the material appealing. I loved how that course guided me to think logically

Well"," I was given an assignment in middle school to do a presentation on anything science related. I decided to do that presentation on black holes. From there"," I immersed myself in astronomy and physics concepts because I found it interesting. I also loved how people could predict behavior of things in space.

I first became interested in physics when I saw a headlineabout the Higgs boson observation on a Scientific Americancover that my father had lying around. It made me realizethat physics is still full of puzzles and we need to applyourselves as humans (not as men or women) to complete thesepuzzles. The pursuit of understanding our universe is pureand vital"," and much like art"," not necessarily motivated byeconomic gain. These same ideas still motivate me today.

I`ve always been good at math in high school. I took an honorsphysics class my senior year and really enjoyed the material.I took intro level physics freshman year of college anddecided it was the major for me. I like studying a widevariety of subjects and physics is the perfect outlet for my liberal studies. It is a subject that is influential in all areas of learning"," it is challenging"," and it providesskills that are considered valuable in the job market.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Utility Value

Response: It started with my first physics teaching in my junior year of high school. He loved what he taught and focused on us truly understanding the material and not just passing exams. I continued on to take AP physics and then pursue a bachelor`s degree in physics because the passion he taught with really peaked my interest.  I loved that physics explained things I saw in the world around me and really made me think because I previously school had been really easy for me and I liked the challenge of physics. And then when I got to college it was the advisors in the physics professors who really cared about me and the community (small but mightly) of physics students around me who supported and encouraged one another that got me to being only 6 months away from a BS in physics.  Without the support and collaboration between my physics peers"," I would not have made it through the degree.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I originally thought I wanted to be a physics teacher"," but then learned I liked research when I got to college.

I became interested in physics when I found a study partner who was struggling in Physics course like me. We would meet twice a weekto study Physics. Challenged each other to understand the material more.Together we found our passion for physics and from there we both starteddoing better in the courses. Also being a Chemistry major I found thatunderstanding Physics helped me better understand the concept I was learning in Physical Chemistry.
I went to the observatory and attended a talk about stars and galaxies"," and fell in love with the idea of the physics of the universe.

I had not considered going into any field of science"," let alone physics until I took my high school physics course. My teacher was a female who had worked for NASA and just explained everything so wonderfully. She inspired me and I wanted to know what she knew. After her classes I would go home and search up as much as i could over the topic of astrophysics. and that`s how i knew I wanted to do Physics. Along my undergraduate career so far I`ve met other female professors and male professors who were just as inspiring and helpful. Also the graduate students at the college were very helpful and supportive to many undergraduate students. Ultimately"," I think the curiosity of what could be out there and how the world worked and why was what caught my attention in physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: I originally started my college education when I was sixteen and planned on going into nursing. After taking chemistry courses"," I found a love for science and research. I have been exploring various fields and career options since then. I will be graduating with my associate`s degree in biology in the spring of 2019 and then plan on transferring to a four year institution. Because I graduated high school early"," this year taking College Physics at BCC is my first experience really learning about physics. I find it very interesting and it is a field of study that I would like to explore more.
I took a physics class in high school. I was both very engaged and challenged in class"," which made me think of physics as my major.

My high school did not have any astronomy classes or anything similar"," so all I knew about the stars is what I learned from my dad. Once I got to college"," I was majoring in mathematics and I needed one elective class. They tried to stick me in geology"," but I did not want to and chose basic astronomy instead. Soon"," I fell in love with the class and decided to change my major to astrophysics.

My Physics teacher in High School was the most amazing woman. She explained things in such a way that made everything understandable and fun. I love science and math"," and found that physics had the best of both. I love solving problems.

I took AP Physics 1 Algebra-based senior year of high school (although we covered much of the material from Physics 2 and conceptually went over some modern physics after the AP test)"," and this class is what made me think that I wanted to pursue physics. It was a very engaging course taught by a professor who was clearly excited about the material"," and one of the main takeaways I had was that physics is amazing because it explains why the world around us functions how it does. When I came up to college"," I was accepted into a freshman research program at NMU and have been working on solid-state semiconductor research since with my mentor and another (older) student for the past year and a half. I have attended two different experiments and am an active member of our research group. This has been a really positive experience for me"," confirming that this (active physics research) is what I wish to pursue. I am learning about advanced topics in solid-state physics in a cutting-edge research setting"," in a community of caring and passionate people. I am currently enrolled in Physics 2 and Mathematical Methods in Physics (concurrently)"," and have been enjoying learning more about the framework upon which the research I am currently involved in is built. Additionally"," it has been neat to be sitting in the physics student office when another"," older major comes in and is excited about something they just learned"," and shares.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered

Response: I really enjoyed high school physics. In high school I got to participate in a class where you pick a profession and mentor for the year"," and I picked Medical Physics. And after doing that it made me want to even more do a degree in physics.

My interest in Physics started when I attended a Physics camp at Tougaloo. I had a general idea of Physics"," and wanted to explore further.I performed very well at the camp and kept a good relationship with the professors.The department exposed me to different experiences and varieties with Physics like astronomy and simple machine machanics.I took the AP Physics course my senior year and grew to love Physics further.Physics is a challenge that never ends but I like every second of it.
Codes: Event Triggered, Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: I grew up loving astronomy"," and as I progressed through my high school education I realized the best way to achieve my goals would be through majoring in both physics and astronomy. As college progressed"," I tacked on a minor in math.I never really considered studying any other fields outside of the sciences"," though have changed my mind between (choosing engineering"," just astronomy"," both physics and astronomy"," etc)

I was originally planning to major in chemistry"," and I was strong in neither physics nor mathematics.I planned to start from organic chemistry in my first year"," but I ended up taking physical chemistry as a freshman because (1) organic chemistry class was more than full (2) my faculty adviser specializes in laser spectroscopy (3) I had organic chemistry grades from high school.Taking physical chemistry required me to build a sufficient physics background as quickly as possible"," so I started taking physics major courses along with physical chemistry in my first two semesters.It turned out that I am highly interested in physics major courses"," and by the end of the sophomore year"," I declared chemistry/physics double major.
Codes: Utility Value, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: I first became interested in physics during my freshman year of high school"," the first time that I took a physicsclass. My teacher encouraged me to continue with physicsbecause I was skilled at it. I took AP Physics C my junior year of high school"," and did well on the AP tests.I applied for colleges that have strong physics programs","and chose to attend UC Santa Barbara. In college I initially had doubts about continuing in physics"," butby changing the pace of my classes I decided to con- tinue studying physics. I am now in my junior year of my undergraduate and in spite of occasional lapses in self-confidence"," I have decided to stick with physics for good.

During my first year in college I knew I wanted to study medicine"," but I knew I also liked physics"," so I was kind of at a stand still on what I wanted to pursue. One day at church I met a retired medical physicist and after she explained what her work consisted of I was hooked on the idea. I decided to volunteer in the Radiology department of the local hospital"," which also helped in my decision to pursue medical physics. She also recommended I tour UCI since that is where she went for undergrad"," and this how I discovered UCI and ultimately decided to transfer there for the research opportunities.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Medical), Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: In my very first physics class in high school"," we discussed Newton`s Laws.  While so mundane and elementary"," this lesson was so mind-blowing to me"," allowing me to look at the way things happen in the world from a whole new perspective.  While most of what I claimed to like usually stems from what naturally comes easy for me (math for example) physics was never easy.  It is a constant struggle to grasp and apply physics concepts.  But it is one of the few things that I have learned to love even though it is not easy and something I am naturally good at"," because when I finally get it"," it becomes all the more rewarding"," making certain aspects of my daily life so much more understandable on a deeper level.  I first considered becoming a physics major that first day of physics class in high school and"," while poor test grades and frustrating labs sometimes wavered that decision briefly"," I always came back to the fact that it is the one subject that I truly loved to learn about ultimately making me realize that it would be a major I would enjoy.

Since I was little I wanted to be an astrononaut"," I remember that when I was in middle school I took a class of Terrestrial and Space Sciences and I totally fell in love with science and more specifically with Astronomy. The curiosity of knowing and understanding how the universe works has always been intriguing to me. Having the opportunity to study more deeply the universe has encouraged me to want to pursue a career in that field. Since in my country there is not any degree on that field and I know that Astronomy/Astrophysics involves a lot of Physics"," I decided to pursue that carreer for my undergraduate degree. However"," I did not start my college degree in Physcs because my high school physics class was not the best and I got scared from people`s comments about the field. I entered as a Geology student to try it out but after one year"," I decided to switch to Physics which was what I wanted initially. After my general courses of Physics"," I knew that I made the right choice.

I first thought about becoming a physics major after taking my first physics course my junior year of high school. I loved the material that was being presented and my teacher was very supportive. Unfortunately"," I could not take AP physics my senior year. Instead"," I was a teaching assistant for juniors in regular physics and loved it. When I first arrived as a physics major"," everything seemed different and wonderful. I have conducted research in materials science"," nuclear physics"," and biomechanics. I have been published in a journal and am ready to move onto graduate studies in either biomedical engineering or nuclear engineering.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Physiological/Emotional

Response: I first started considering physics freshman year of college. I was also considering a major in international relations. I realized I enjoyed my work for my physics classes more than any other. I confirmed I wanted to do research and go to Graduate School during my REU experience at Georgetown.

Throughout my three years at Bridgewater State University I have bounced from major to major trying to figure out what I wanted to study. I started off as an accounting major"," and then I took a math course and really enjoyed the class. I eventually changed my major to math. In my journey of exploring the world of math I had to take chemistry. I liked the science aspect"," but did not have enough mathematics involved. Then I spoke to someone in the physics department"," Dr. Thomas Kling who is now my advisor"," and we decided that trying an introductory physics class was a science field to try. I never had the opportunity to study this subject in high school and only ever heard bad things about how confusing and difficult the subject was. I quickly realized that they may have been right"," but I did not realize how much I enjoyed the balance of science in math within the physics subject area. The end of my sophomore year I declared physics as my major with a math minor. My journey to physics took some time"," but finally narrowing down the area of what I like is a huge relief off my shoulders. Due to the time it took my schedule of classes is different than a typically physics student. I am still finishing the physics degree within 4 years"," but the opportunities to do further research or any other academia opportunity has been difficult to achieve.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Cost (Emotional), Physiological/Emotional, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: I became interested in Physics through a community organized Astronomical Society in Highschool. This peaked my interest and it was thanks to the individuals there and my highschool physics teacher that I had the confidence to pursue physics. Now that I am in college doing research and being involved in the department leads me to continue to be inspired in physics and learn things hands on.

I don`t honestly remember when the switch happened. I wanted to be an artist for most of my childhood but at some point"," maybe due to science fiction I was getting into"," I fell in love with the concept of physics and science. I was always good at math so I wasn`t put off by the idea of spending my life doing math when people brought it up. The idea that I could describe the universe without flowery language or pretense fascinated me early on. I just fell in love with understanding the unimaginable sizes of the universe and how interactions happened. There was no big influencing person or experience. I`ve just wanted to learn how the world works in the best language (math) and help us (people) to describe it more and more accurately.
Codes: Media Triggered, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: An astronaut came to my school"," and I loved her career path

I became a physics major because physics was my favorite class in high school. A lot of it was because i really liked the teacher and he made it super fun. And in college i have been interested and succeeding in my classes which has kept me in my path as a physics major.
My major is in engineering"," however"," I feel like engineers and physicists need one other to succeed in there jobs.

I found physics and math interesting and challenging in high school. As such"," I decided to pursue the physics degree in college"," since it was one of the few topics in high school that actually challenged me mentally. It helped that both my physics teachers in high school were women and encouraged me to pursue physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: I`ve always been proficient in math"," but found the subject itself dry. I decided to pursue physics because it`s an

My love for mathematics and science started when I was in elementary school. I remembered the fun I had when I was able to solve difficult problems. My dream was to be a mathematician or a scientist. However"," my math teacher in Vietnam"," whom I held in high regard"," told me that I should choose a more appropriate career for women. At that time"," I was one of few females in his honors class"," so hearing that was infuriating and hurtful. I had lost all hopes in my dream"," but Calculus class reignited the passion that was lost long ago. I can see math???s beauty in other fields such as physics. That was when I decided to become a scientist and mathematician.

I started taking classes at The Evergreen State College not knowing my exact path in my education other than"," science and mathematics"," in general. While completing programs involving pre-calculus"," biology"," astronomy"," cosmology"," environmental geology"," and physical geology"," I read through our schoolÕs academic catalog to find my next program in the sciences. I found the program description for a year long Matter and Motion program (physics (I"," II)"," chemistry"," and calculus (I"," II"," III)) to be the most intriguing and most giving in future opportunities. I decided to meet with the main physics professor and instantly knew I wanted him as my mentor. Having his mentorship was more important than the programs I was taking. Through his mentorship"," I found myself drawn to physics more and more. I have continued with another year long upper division physics and mathematics program with him as my professor and mentor this school year.Through becoming a coordinator for the Evergreen Astronomical Society (a school club)"," I was able to bridge the communication of science and mathematics with our surrounding communities. Currently"," I have joined three of the clubs coordinators in accomplishing a binary star research project.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social), Vicarious Experience

Response: I was always very interested in physics and physics research.  At Kenyon I felt very excited about the major and supported in the physics department so I declared a major.
My physics professor suggested engineering and I looked into it and found that I liked it.

Physics was one of my favorite class in high school. I have always enjoyed math a lot"," though it was harder to see mathematical applications to things in the real world. My father was an engineering major for the first two years of college"," so he has always helped me with engineering and physics related things. My freshman year in college I took a variety of classes"," my major being completely undecided"," and my physics class was my favorite. I declared my major pre-engineering (this is a 3/2 program- Rollins College doesn`t have an engineering program) with a concentration in physics. At this point I was not fully sure if I would stick with it"," but after taking more classes in the subject I am convinced that I made the right decision.

I have always loved science and math in school and in my junior hear of high school I took my first physics class. I quickly grew to love it.I always have wanted to teach as well but never knew what. Having always been good at math and science"," a close friend suggested teaching one of those subjects. I decided to teach physics because I want to inspire young minds and share my love and hopefully ignite that same flame in my students.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Social Persuasion

Response: I started college off as a chemistry major"," but a physics course was required. I ended up really enjoying the class and decided to take more. I decided to get a physics minor the fall semester of my sophomore year. By the end of my sophomore year I had realized that I was enjoying my physics courses significantly more than the chemistry courses I was taking"," so I decided to change my major to physics

I have always held a certain aptitude for math and science"," mostly due to my parents both being math teachers in secondary and post secondary levels. My high school physics teacher also opened up my possibility towards a physics related career.. I have also always liked the laboratory study. Forensics sciences in the government require chemistry and physics skills prior to employment. Thus"," I am a chemistry and physics major.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience, Utility Value, Physiological/Emotional

Response: My first physics professor did an amazing job at inspiring me to want to learn more about physics. The main difference between that teacher and others was his teaching style. As a student"," I got to discover equations on my own through collecting data. This made the material more meaningful and sparked my curiosity.

I was attempting to get into CS and engineering majors at the UW and was having no success. I visited the physics dept advising office to inquire about getting a physics tutor"," and the graduate advisor ended up speaking with me and looking at my transcript. She gave me great guidance and support--the only friendliness I`d encountered from any advisor at the UW. Feeling like I could belong in the physics dept"," along with an interest in physics and generally STEM"," is what led me to declare physics.

The first time I took a physics course was in junior year of high school and I found it extremely interesting and easy compared to many other students in my class. My high school physics teacher was amazing and he showed me how amazing it truly is. How physics is all around us and before his class I wasn`t able to see that. That was the same year I was applying to college and it was my favorite subject in school so I decided to see if I wanted it to be my major in college.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience

Response: I have always been fascinated with physics"," but I think my trips to Fermilab really did it for me. It was just an amazing facility with a positive"," exciting atmosphere and people who were passionate about their work. There wasn`t really any single event that made me decide to be a physics major. I feel like I have always loved science!
Codes: Event Triggered, Attainment Value, Intrinsic Value

Response: In high school"," my sophomore year"," I took two science classes: physics and chemistry. I had a terrible chemistry teacher and never wanted to take another chem course again. I had an amazing physics teacher and shortly into the term decided to go to college for physics.

Took 2 years of physics in high school (Honors Physics and AP Physics C) with an awesome teacher and really enjoyed it. Second semester freshman year (at Williams)"," took a tutorial on quantum systems that was cool but really challenging. I was taking Abstract Algebra at the same time and that`s what got me interested in the area of math with applications in theoretical physics. I ended up deciding to major in math rather than physics because while I really enjoyed physics from a conceptual standpoint"," I didn`t like doing long problem sets and not understanding everything completely. I`m not sure how many physics courses I will take throughout the rest of my college years but I will definitely enjoy learning and doing more physics on my own.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Task Effort)

Response: In high school"," I was on the honors student track"," and Honors Physics was just the next level of science to take. Wow! Physics had the answers to the ???Why does this do that??? questions! I loved the class"," but it did not come naturally to me. I look back at that time"," remember the late nights of frustration and agony over kinematics and circuits"," and thank God for providing an incredibly patient and encouraging teacher"," Eric Curry. He taught me how to formulate questions"," how to think problems through instead of chugging numbers into memorized equations"," and how to replace my obsession for good grades with a love of learning. He also convinced me to take the position as electrical team captain on the school???s FIRST robotics team (Go 1208!); that hands-on experience made sense of all the lectures and homework problems! In college"," I started out planning to major in electrical engineering. But when I had completed College Physics 1 and 2"," I still had so many questions for the physics world: questions about light"," optics"," relativity"," and atomic level stuff. So"," I switched to a physics major! Studying physics lets me explore dozens of topics. Each semester"," some questions are answered"," and ten more are formulated. It???s a wonderful cycle of endless curiosity.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered

Response: Sci-fi movies and books"," Brief History of Time

I started out as a chemistry major because I liked chemistry but did not know what to do with it. As I researched research opportunities"," I realized what I wanted to do was more physics-related than chemistry-related. I also completed my chemistry courses relatively quickly and realized there was never enough math or problem-solving in chemistry as I hoped"," so I declared a chemistry and physics double major.

My high school physics teacher pushed me to apply as a physics major. I was unsure at the time"," so I just applied and figured I could change my major if I wanted. Along the way I was supported and encouraged by the professors in my department"," and I felt like there was a good sencse of community in the physics department. I enjoyed learning at a deep"," conceptual level"," and really started to enjoy my classes. When I heard about applied fields I really fell in love the subject. I loved the fact that I could apply my extensive knowledge of physics to broad topics in any field.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social), Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value

Response: I`m not sure when I first considered physics as an option"," maybe high school"," but I didn`t think about it seriously until after getting my first degree (English) and realizing English wasn`t what I really wanted to do. I had a very difficult freshman year as a physics major because the learning curve was so steep. Eight years lapsed between my freshman and sophmore years as a physics major. It wasn`t until I came back"," in my mid-30s"," that I was ready to entertain the idea that I might be able to earn a PhD in physics. I`ve struggled to build my self-confidence in this way.

I first got the idea because my uncle has his PhD in astrophysics and my brother is majoring in physics. They would talk about physics and I found it so interesting. From there"," I took my first physics class in high school and I was hooked since. Once I started attending university"," I joined WIMSE(Women in Math"," Science"," and Engineering) and met so many girls like me in STEM and I met my mentor and friend Dr. Susan Blessing. WIMSE gave me the opportunity to visit physics labs and I was exposed to even more. Right now I am working in a physical chemistry lab and the professor who I am working with has his PhD in physics.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social), Intrinsic Value

Response: I was not raised religious"," but I was very interested in spirituality and the reasons I was here on Earth. I used alot of Chrisitan beliefs to help myself understand these ideas. When I was 15"," I took my first physics class in high school and all of the sudden everything I was giving "god credit for could be explained by science. I really liked that

A really amazing high school physics teacher lead the way for me to pursue a degree in physics. Nothing deterred me past that point in time and with an amazing college and it`s physics department I am still going strong.

Growing up"," my dad always told me about the science behind everyday life at every opportunity"," and my grandmotherloved to give me math and logic puzzles when we were waiting for food at restaurants. Throughout elementary and high school"," I showed a lot of aptitude for math andscience and never considered a career outside of STEM.I didn`t specifically want to be a physicist though untilmy dad gave me a copy of Surely You`re Joking"," Mr. Feynman.Feynman`s attitude toward physics and the world in generalis so inspiring and from there I was drawn into books byBrian Greene and Michio Kaku"," driven to figure out whyand how the world works. When I came to college"," I did notknow whether I wanted to major in physics or engineeringbut after a few classes in each discipline"," physics emergedas the victor.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Media Triggered

Response: When I took my first physics class in high school"," everything just made sense. The only way that I can put it is that physics think and my thinking were very similar. That`s when I decided to pursue physics. It`s more than just an aptitude: I like knowing how the world works"," and physics is a great way to do that.

When I was a child I was curious about nature and loved astronomy and pattern. When I was in my sophomore year of high school I took a geometry class. I would teach myself geometry and it made me have an interest in mathematics and changed my view on reality. I always thought philosophically so I wanted to learn how to apply logic to reality and how reality works. I took a chemistry class that had a chapter that briefly explained some concepts in quantum mechanics and I would use the internet to read about physics. During this time as a teenager I had many ideas about the universe particularly in quantum mechanics and cosmology that I wrote down in a notebook. That is when I realized I wanted to do theoretical physics so I decided to become a physics major when I graduated from high school. Even though there is no guarantee that I will be successful the benefits of a physics education for me is tremendous to aiding my ideas and creativity. This is what I thought later in the time I was at a community college.

Ever since high school"," I was fascinated by how physics uses the language of math to describe natural phenomena; the idea that we can model physical phenomena from first principles was especially appealing. Though I considered other majors (like engineering)"," the basic science aspect of physics is what drew me to it.

I actually originally became interested in astrophysics in my junior year of high school when I realized that I was consistently fascinated by many space-related science fiction novels and TV shows. I started out watching tutorials and explanations on YouTube (like Crash Course Astronomy) to learn basic astrophysics concepts"," and I also completed a few online EdX courses related to astronomy. In the summer after my junior year"," I participated in an astrophysics research internship"," which made me realize that while I really enjoyed learning about astrophysics"," I preferred physics as an academic (career?) path for its ability to be applied to more real-world problems. I started taking more physics classes in my senior year of high school and enjoyed them"," and I haven`t looked back since!
Codes: Event Triggered, Media Triggered, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: In school I was always distantly enamored with astrophysics and I performed well in math and science classes as well as logic tests"," so I felt physics would be a major that could hold my interest. I felt pressured to go into engineering"," but chose physics instead.

I became an astrophysics major due to a science summer camp I attended as a child. Since then I`ve been interested in astronomy and have stuck to it ever since. For a while I considered engineering or particle physics"," but I didn`t like the experiments as much"," and culture in astronomy seemed to be better than the other two fields I was considering"," so I stayed in astronomy.

I have always been interested in a science field and realized physics was a good fit after taking calculus/physics in high school.  Physics gave a purpose to math and gave a language to understanding the way things work in a way that other fields of education do not.  I was encouraged by my high school teachers to pursue an education in some STEM field.

My older cousin earned his Bachelor`s degree in Physics and went on to get a Masters and a Doctorate in Mechanical Engineering. Knowing that I have always been interested in math"," he encouraged me to job-shadow him. At the time"," he was working for a company who is hired by other companies to fix their issues. The job title he gave himself was a "research scientist". His job is to find the best"," most efficient way to solve the client`s problem. From this day on I started seriously considering pursuing a degree in physics. I loved what he did"," and it was something I could see myself doing as a career. Now"," here I am"," attending the University of Mount Union planning to double major in Physics and Applied Mathematics.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I took my first physics class in ninth grade and really enjoyed it"," so I started reading easily-accessible physics articles and books. The biggest factor that has influenced my decision to be a physics major so far is my positive experience with supportive teachers in high school physics classes.

I have always been fascinated in learning more about the universe and questions concerning astronomy and physics. This all started in my third grade year when I had join the astonomy club after school; I still remember the time when several of the NASA group members came in to the classroom and had talk to the entire class about the moon and visually showing us small pieces of the moon rocks that they had brought with them and I thought that was pretty cool so then through out the years I joined in more science clubs.
