This made me realize and gave me the courage to major in physics for my BS and persue my masters or doctoral degree in Astrophysics but I believe that even before my third grade relization"," I have always had a passion for studying space itself because at the age of six"," I would always go outside to lay down on the grass"," watch the sky"," and feel the Earth spin. This made me curious and in fact I am still curious about the universe because perhaps there might not be an answer to solving the puzzle of the universe but I want to be part of that group who is in search for answers.

I had no intentions in majoring in physics until I met a professor who showed me that physics is something I could do and is beyond weekly problem sets. I was invited to her research team and I have been in it since then. I have really bad imposter syndrome"," and still I don`t identify as a physicist but I find so much comfort in my research team.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic (Social), Event Triggered

Response: I thoroughly enjoyed space science in 8th grade and my friend mentioned they wanted to be an astrophysicist so I googled it and it sounded interesting. I continued in physics and math classes in high school and I found it interesting to learn about how the world works. I still enjoy learning more about how everything works even though it takes me a good while to get the concepts and math down and understand everything completely.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: It all started when I was in High School. I had two great physics teachers that made physics fun and exciting. Therefore"," as the end of my High School career came to be"," I had to determine what major I wanted to be. I decided on physics because it was the most interesting. It was the one subject in High School that challenged me and made me think.
It just made sense to me. Also"," I have had positive influences from all my professors that have guided me towards this.

I first began my interest in physics when I was a junior in high school"," beginning to embark on my first ever calculus class. For the first time"," I was really excited to go to a math class. I worked hard outside of class to master the material not because I had to"," but because I wanted to. I found immense beauty in calculus in a way I had never encountered in school. That same semester I took my first physics class. My physics teacher would often say that the things we did in class were much cooler when calculus was involved"," which was great for me"," since I already thought the algebra-based physics we were doing was really neat. I later enrolled in college with the intention of being a physics major"," expecting the worst.My first calculus-based physics class in undergrad was what really cemented physics as the major for me. I expected the other physics majors to be cut-throat know-it-alls who didn`t care about anyone but themselves and their success. I was surprisingly met by some of the most amazing and well-rounded people I`ve ever met.The same time that I fell in love with physics as an undergrad"," I had a similar experience in my general chemistry class. My first term professor"," a biochemist by trade"," showed me a side of chemistry that I had never seen. Like physics"," chemistry was fun and exciting"," particularly when framed by a biochemist. I find the mechanisms behind life`s many processes immensely fascinating from a chemical perspective. Thus"," I was torn between my long-held love of physics and my newfound infatuation with biochemistry. After talking with a lot of faculty members"," as well as a good bit of soul searching"," I realized that I didn`t have to decide. I`m now on track to complete a physics and a biochemistry major"," with the intention of going on to med school upon my graduation from Augustana. Using my love of physics and biochem to help patients is the perfect culmination of everything I love about both subjects.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social), Vicarious Experience

Response: I have loved mathematics since I was in elementary school. My love of physics began during my first years of college when I was attempting to double major in chemistry and physics. There came a time when I decided that I wanted to simply focus on one major. After"," talking with a few graduate students and professors"," it became clear to me that physics was the major I wanted to focus on. One conversation with a graduate student in particular really helped me narrow my focus. I recall that he asked me what my favorite chemistry subjects were. I answered"," "Molecular orbital theory"," the Bohr model"," and thermodynamics"," to which he exclaimed

I also found science interesting. I loved everything about it"," but I always thought I wasn`t smart enough to be a scientist. After high school"," I started to take a few courses at a local community college. I adored the physics class"," and I did really well"," and my professor said she thought I would do really well. Because of her I decided that I wanted to actually further my education in physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: I always enjoyed physics in high school so when I began thinking about what I wanted to go to college for physics was in the back of my mind. I began talking to my high school physics teacher about what it was like to go to school for physics. He told me about his experience and it instantly got me very interested in pursuing a degree in physics. I began doing more more research on what getting a physics degree would allow me to do. I saw that there were many different paths I could take in the job field with a physics degree. I didn`t exactly know what I wanted to do so the wide variety of options appealed to me. This is when I decided I was going to school for physics.
I grew to love physics from my high school physics teacher in the AP class and want to pass that joy on to oothers
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: The first thing that ever got me interested in physics was a science project I did in the 5th grade on black holes. Up until that point I don`t think I even know what physics was. I knew that Albert Einstein was a famous physicist and he was supposedly really smart. Once I started researching for this project though I was hooked. It was my introduction to special relativity and time dilation. I learned about the Hubble telescope and its contributions to astronomy. I was completely fascinated by all of these abstract concepts that really went against my 10 year intuition that I had built up as a child taking in the world around me. I`ve also always had really good science teachers that encouraged my interest in science class"," whether it be biology or chemistry or physics"," and many of my favorite teachers were women who showed me that being a women in science was entirely possible. Another thing that really solidified my decision to major in physics was a book my Aunt gave me for Christmas"," "The Elegant Universe by Brian Greene. Reading that book and
Codes: Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Media Triggered

Response: In high school I found physics interesting to me.

Wanted to keep as many options available to me open as long as possible as I was not drawn to a particular field in high school but wanted to do something in STEM. I enjoyed my high school physics class and felt that it would give me a lot of options if I pursued a degree in it. After beginning my college degree I could not see myself in any other major so I have stuck with physics.

I began to like physics in high school when I took AP physics. It was a challenging course for me and I wanted to be able to learn more on the subject. Through this"," I found a love for engineering and I knew a physics background would give me good opportunities to become an engineering of my choice. Currently"," physics has been able to open many doors for me to connect with fellow research scientists and share my love for engineering.

In highschool"," I would get amazing grades in every subject but one. And that one subject"," of course"," was physics. Therefore"," in college"," I decided to major in the one thing that I didn`t succeed with in highschool. There have been times I get defeated in college"," but I wouldn`t change this discipline for anything else out there.

I`ve always been interested in the health field and mathematics. Originally"," I was just going to be a biomedical engineer or a mathematics major that was also premed"," but when I realized that there was such a thing as biomedical physics"," I thought I would give it a try. The physics view of medicine is very often not discussed or seen by a lot of premedical students"," and I thought it was one of the most interesting things. As I`m learning the physics concepts"," I also have the opportunity to take all of the math classes and premedical classes I need/want. Right now"," it`s a win/win situation to be a physics major.

When I took my first physics class in college"," my sophomore year. I got an A in physics in High School. In college I got a B in my first physics class. I enjoyed physics and the challenge it provided. I have always had an easy time in school. Physics academically challenged me in a way that the other sciences and liberal classes didn`t. I started to attend SPS meetings after changing to a Physics Major my junior year. I have taken many more Physics classes and willgraduate next year in May with a BS in physics. I did summerreseach this year and presented my project at the SPS Texas Sectional Meeting. My summer research was in Space Physics and I also attended a Plamsa Physics Conference this year. Iplan to go to graduate school.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic (Social), Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: I loved physics in high school"," but was concerned about matching career opportunities to my ethical values and deprioritized physics as a result. I took an integrated sciences intro course my first year of college and fell in love with statistical mechanics as an approach to understanding the world. I also very much enjoyed Calc III and DiffEq so I chose to do a biophysics major and a philosophy of science minor. Doing a biomaterials internship the summer after my sophomore year (as a result of CuWiP networking"," actually) solidified my interest in laboratory work and graduate school.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Biophysics)

Response: I became interested in High School"," and entered Cornell thinking that a major in Physics (concentrating in astrophysics) was a possibility. I felt extremely welcomed and supported by the physics faculty and peers from the beginning. My coursework in physics during my Freshman and Sophomore years confirmed this interest - also participated in research in biophysics which was a wonderful experience"," although I found I was more interested in cosmological issues rather than biological ones. The significance and impact of the research questions in cosmology are really what has motivated me to pursue a career as an academic physicist.
Codes: Intrinsic (Social), Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Cosmology), Utility Value

Response: I switched to physics from a pre-medical degree track after taking Physics I at my university. I was very interested in the concepts and I enjoyed the associated labs"," there was something incredibly appealing about designing an experiment and changing variables just to see how the system would react. Although the physics major itself has been very challenging and not what I expected"," I am so excited to continue what I do and try to better the field from the inside.
I took intro physics sophomore year and really loved it. I`ve had a lot of encouragement from friends and professors"," which has been very important.
Read a important book.

I didn???t get turned to physics until my senior year of high school"," previously"," and for most of my life"," I had wanted to be a pastry chef. I had a brilliant high school teacher who really instilled a love for physics in me and"," when he found out that he had done that"," gave me applications for internships and opportunities. He really encouraged me into the world of physics"," and I actually spent that summer in the QuarkNet program where he really helped me out.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: Concepts of physics just seemed interesting enough for me to want to pursue a career in physics.

I had always been interested in astrophysics and astronomy growing up and in high school"," but I never felt like I would be able to be a physics major because I felt I wasn`t smart enough. Once at CMU"," I listened to a talk by the Dean of the College of Science (who is an amazing lady) and she said she always sees students choosing to study things that they`re passionate about and not necessarily the things they`re comfortable with or good at. After listening to her speech I decided to take the leap and switched my major from chemistry to physics and I haven`t looked back.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Cost (Emotional), Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience

Response: My high school teacher introduced me to physics and at first"," I could not see myself as a physicist even though I loved the subject. However"," I overcame my fears and followed my dreams. I am so glad that I did.

I really liked physics when I had it in high school and my teachers and family encouraged me to pursue it further. Fellow physics students helped me pursue my desire to understand the universe and my research was very good in applying what I learn to the world.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I was interested in studying science in college"," because I felt it was a challenge. I loved math as a kid"," because it didn`t come easily and I had to work for it. I thought that because I didn`t possess many `natural` talents in science"," that maybe this would give me the same thrill"," and justify paying so much money to have someone teach it to me. I took a few survey courses in various disciplines"," but it was an inspiring lecture on the first day of Dr. Walsh`s "Energy and the Environment course at the UofM-TC that made me feel like I had found my place. It really was an instant knowing. I decided that I would be happy working at a coffee shop for the rest of my life as long as I could be qualified to sit at the same table with people like that professor

I have never taking physics or calculus before due to my school not offering it. I wanted to experience something new. I wanted to go to Gordon College even though I wanted to be an architect. I decided to take on engineering so I can soon master what I love.

I have been interested in astronomy from a young age. My parents bought me a telescope when I was five and facilitated my curiosity as I grew older by taking me to visit observatories around the country. Once I entered high school and took my first physics course I realized I had a second passion. After doing well in my senior physics course I chose to combine my curiosity about physics and astronomy.That is why I decided to be an astrophysics major.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: I have been interested in the intersection of math and art for a long time and how this connection has dated back through history. For a while this manifested itself in architecture and city planning"," however"," I became more interested in alternative energy and this morphed into a curiosity about how these techniques worked physically and chemically. I enjoy studying physics because I can understand these processes in depth and I want to become an engineer so I can apply these concepts in the real world to help people. I`m currently really enjoying studying Quantum Mechanics because it is excitably not intuitive and unlike intro physics I`ve become so accustomed to.

The first time I considered pursuing physics was in my high school AP Chemistry class. In chemistry"," we were discussing the double slit experiment"," and I remember having so many questions and being completely fascinated by this seemingly impossible phenomenon. I began talking to the physics teachers at my school"," and I found myself really enjoying discussions on physics - especially astrophysics. The following year"," I enrolled in AP physics and advanced astronomy. Those two classes completely changed the career path I found myself following. I went from an intended medical researching career to an intended astrophysics/aerospace engineering career. I now feel like I have really found my passion in life. Since then"," the University of Pittsburgh Department of Physics and Astronomy has given me so many opportunities to do research"," attend conferences"," and network in physics. I know that taking that leap my senior year of high school to switch intended majors was the best decision I have ever made.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered

Response: I really enjoy the hands on experience working in laboratories offer. I choose physics because of this and its high integration of math"," since I also enjoy math.

I first became interested in physics when my dad and I would use his telescope to look at the stars. We also used to watch a lot of documentaries on space. When I finally took a physics class in my senior year of high school"," I loved it! I also took the other physics class available in my school. I had a very positive experience with my teacher and I have had very good interactions with my professors at Siena college as well. These relationships have encouraged me to pursue physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: IÕve always been a scientist. From a young age I questioned everything and wasnÕt satisfied until a proper answer explained all observations. The moment I read books on the universe i fell in love. I wanted to know why the universe works the way it does. From the subatomic to the expansion of space itself. Trying to understand this excites me in a profound way"," and thatÕs how I know doing physics is where I belong.
Codes: Attainment Value, Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Physiological/Emotional

Response: To be honest"," I`m still considering. I took an intro to physics course this semester not because I wanted to major in Physics but because it`s just fun. I`ve done some Physics in high school. Though my teacher wasn`t great"," I enjoyed the subject. And Pomona`s Physics department is so helpful and welcoming that I`m considering majoring in Physics now. The courses are very interesting to start with (we start with modern Physics in the intro sequence so that it`s new for everyone"," and I think it`s a really good approach to show people more possibilities in the field while building our confidence at the same time).

My father is an engineer"," so from a young age I was taught to not just accept the things that went on around me"," but to also understand why and how they worked. Throughout school"," math and science were my strongest subjects and naturally made sense. With these two factors"," I knew I would most likely explore a career in science. It wasn`t until high school when I took my first physics course that I actually considered physics as a major. I had a wonderful physics teacher that taught me for both physics and AP physics. Going into college"," I looked at a few other options for majors"," but after researching careers in physics and the program at my university"," I decided signing as a physics major would be the best option for myself.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Utility Value

Response: I took class in high school and in college I saw many signs that said Physics on it which helped keep it in my mind. Then I noticed the way my mind thought and the questions I often asked myself were physics based.

I was fortunate in that my high school had a planetarium. I took two of the three offered planetarium classes"," and I have known since then that I wantedto study astrophysics. During the summer before my senior year of high school"," I pursued the subject further by taking an astronomy course at my localcommunity college. After enrolling at Williams College"," I took the intro-level physics and astronomy courses. Not only enjoying the material but also makingnew friends who shared my passion for physics and astronomy solidified my desire to major in astrophysics.

I was a chemistry major"," but I found myself more engrossed with the physics courses and the physics research posters than with my own major"," so I switched to physics. I liked the challenge my physics courses have presented even if I have not gotten the best grades. I grew up creating codes and solving them so I`m very happy that I get to solve problems for a living...when I find a job.

I took a physics class in high school and had fun"," though it was not what I wanted to do with my life. When I got to college"," I wanted to go into politics. I quickly found out that politics was not the field for me"," so I went back to physics.
My parents and what they exposed me to"," both at home and at work.

As soon as I decided to pursue a career in a STEM field"," I decided to take the calculus-based physic course.  While taken the course"," I found myself absolutely fascinated by everything we were studying and I couldn`t imagine not finding some way to continue with physics in my career.  With the encouragement of a friend who is a physics major and my physics professor"," I started exploring options that could combine my love of biology with my passion for physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: In high school I took an interest to the subject matter in physics. I had always been good at math so physics was interesting to me. My high school physics teacher was not very good"," however. He made me cry in front of the whole class for something completely unrelated to physics. Also"," he failed to mention the due date for an assignment and the day of a test. After this I was reluctant to go into the physics field"," but for some reason I decided to try a physics class in college. I figured I could always switch if I did not enjoy it. My physics professors at school have been wonderful. The material can be very difficult and the tests are by no means easy. However"," I feel as if I have learned a lot about the world. I enjoy it.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Cost (Emotional), Vicarious Experience, Cost (Task Effort), Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional

Response: When I was in elementary school"," there was a teacher that conducted an annual activity called `star lab`. Star Lab was a large inflatable dome (it fit inside a classroom)"," and stars were projected onto the interior of the dome. She told my class about the constellations"," and stars of particular interest. I thought it was the coolest"," and looked forward to it every year.From a young age"," math was my best subject. It wasn`t until I was in high school that I actually considered studying physics in college. There was a tv show called The Universe"," that was of special interest to me. I watched every episode"," and took notice of the passion that the scientists featured had for Astronomy. I thoughtthat they had the most exciting and inspiring jobs. I had a teacher/mentor that really encouraged me to pursuestudying Astrophysics because she knew how much it meant to me.After high school"," I attended a community college for fouryears. I completed my Associate of Science in Mathematicsin May 2014. I transferred to the University of CaliforniaSanta Cruz in Fall 2014. I
Codes: Event Triggered, Mastery Experience, Media Triggered, Social Persuasion

Response: I think"," since middle school"," my favorite class has always been physics. So it is natural for me to take physics class in college and i feel passionate when i`m studying physics

I was initially a business major when I first started my undergraduate courses and only switched to physics my junior year. I have always been interested in space and astronomy"," but I never really considered that as a career-- it was always more of a hobby. I realized that I would rather spend my life doing something that I was actually interested in rather than something that would just provide me a job. I was terrified switching to physics"," but my university has such an awesome collection of professors and students that I never felt like I couldn`t ask for help. I am much happier now that I am studying something that I am actually interested in"," and I can`t wait to hopefully continue learning in graduate school.

I`ve always been very interested in STEM"," starting with my realization as a toddler that science is basically like understanding all the magic in the world. I was not deterred by the lack of women in physics or chemistry"," but I`ve never been the sort of person to be told I cannot do something for reasons as arbitrary as being assigned female. I`m still new to many of the concepts I`m studying in physics now"," and I`m not as strong with it as I am with chemistry"," but I know that if I want to study physical chemistry"," I need to master physics. Moreover"," I need the strong mathematical foundation that a physics degree demands.I am not unfamiliar with the way men unthinkingly condescend to women who have better grades and work harder than them in the classroom"," but I am still undeterred.
I decided to pursue Mechanical Engineering because I wanted to pursue something that would make a change in the world. Engineering does just that.

I had always been interested in science. When in elementary school I had a teacher tell me I would make a very good scientist. From there I considered that an option. Coming into high school I knew I wanted to focus on physics. While in high school physics classes one of my teachers was very enthusiastic which convinced me to study physics further so I could potentially share that enthusiasm with others.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Exprerience

Response: Through most of my life"," I was very indecisive about what I wanted to do. It started when I was young and wanted to be a cook"," which was a short lived dream"," followed by an interest in writing. Sadly"," after discovering my lack of ability to write well"," I moved on to science and math. My love affair for math started my first year in high school when I had a spunky math teacher that was able to get me excited about geometry. All I wanted to do was math and solve problems. I knew then that I wanted to solve problems for the rest of my life"," but I didn???t know what field I would end up in. At first I thought about chemistry. I thought of maybe going into the medical field. Though after suffering through a year of AP chemistry"," I couldn???t take it anymore. Luckily"," my dad convinced me to give physics a try. I was very opposed to the idea at first because I was so set on chemistry at the time"," but I thought why not. It turned out to be the best decision of my life. My teacher had a great passion for the subject and always added enthusiasm to the class and tried to get us more interested in the field. She was the one to suggest going to UW River Falls for my undergrad because she got her Masters in physics there. UW River Falls has given more opportunities than I could have ever dreamed of. I???ve learned so much through the year and a half that I have been here. I have been able to help overs with physics and math by becoming a tutor and learning assistant. I also have worked on the IceCube project where I learned just how nerdy I was. All I did for the summer was physics and hang out with people that had the same passions as me. My life has changed so much but I ???m more than glad for the direction that physics is taking me and I can???t wait to where I end up.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: When I first took AP Physics in high school","  I was completely blown away by its connection to mathematical concepts and I was utterly intrigued by its ability to predict and solve problems. I wasn`t good at it at all...but I loved it. I am also not the kind of person who easily turns away from a challenge. I have never been very confident in my abilities"," but I do not like to lose. Physics seemed like something I would really enjoy"," but my lack of confidence made me question my capability to pursue a degree in it. In fact"," it wasn`t until talking with my mom that I decided I would! She saw the way my eyes lit up when I would come home from school and tell her what I learned"," and she wasn`t going to let that flame die. In fact"," I owe much of my success to my mom and my dad. Without their support"," I don`t think I would be where I am today; just months away from getting my bachelors degree in physics! It has been anything but an easy ride (as anticipated)"," but the friends I made along the way have made it much smoother and for them I am extremely grateful. Physics is hard. And being a woman in physics is even harder (I can`t even imagine how difficult it is for Black/Latina women). I think we need to focus more on encouraging others"," like my family and friends have done for me. You don`t have to be a genius to get your degree in physics"," you just have to believe that you are capable.
I`ve always been good at math"," and in High school I developed special interest in Physics due to it`s many application.

I wanted to be an engineer until the latter half of my senior year of high school. After having toured several college campuses"," I found that I clicked more with the physics department than I did with the colleges of engineering. I knew that for my career"," I wanted to attempt to discover -- previously"," I had hoped to attempt to do so through making machines which would then"," in turn"," make discoveries. I had grand hopes of building space probes or rockets. It didn`t occur to me that I could instead pursue science until I began to interact with people within the field of physics"," both students and professors alike. I found myself drawn both to the subject as a whole"," the hope of discovery"," and the people whom I could work alongside.

As early as middle school"," I found that there were many more boys than girls in my math and science classes. In my AP physics class in high school"," I was one of two girls"," out of about twenty-five students. This trend has continued throughout my studies in physics. Currently I am one of two female physics majors out of seventeen in my year. Although this can be discouraging"," I have found that having a female role model can have a profoundly positive effect on a student`s decision to continue in physics. My high school physics teacher`s passion for physics and role as my mentor inspired me to think seriously about a career in physics. Moreover"," she taught me to never give up and to recognize that if I was stuck on a problem"," it was because the problem was hard"," not because I was inherently bad at physics.

My journey as a physics student has been rocky. Especially considering I do not have much family"," advisors"," except a few friends supporting me in my decision. I am not officially in the major yet"," but I refuse to stop trying and working towards my goal. Many family"," personal"," and medical issues have arose to put me behind these past two years"," so many people"," out of realness"," told me to stop perusing physics and do something else. But I have refused"," and kept persevering anyways. I persevere because it makes me happy"," it is a flame that has lit in me since I was 6. Also because I seem to inspire one of my older brothers"," to have a want to go back to school so he can continue his dream of being an optometrist as he sees me struggling to achieve my goal.

I took my first physics class my sophomore year in high school and then I was hooked. I took AP Physics the following year"," and my senior year in high school I was my old physics teacher`s teaching assistant. I first considered physics as a major because it was one of the few things I enjoyed in school. I always liked science"," and physics wasalways the most fun"," the most interesting choice. So"," when I was applying for colleges"," I startedto discover all of the possibilities that physics offers"," and I decided it would be a good fit for me.I loved the subject"," it interested me"," and it was fun. I`m not sure what I want to do in the field yet"," but it is very fun trying new things and figuring it out.

I started considering physics in tenth grade"," when I first took introductory physics"," and I really enjoyed it. Specifically I really enjoyed the way it made me think about problems in different ways and from different perspectives. I took AP Physics 1 in my junior year and really disliked the class itself but I enjoyed the problems and the content. At that point I was considering both physics and history"," but I was repeatedly advised to study physics because it had greater job prospects and financial opportunity. That summer I took an internship in a mechanical engineering lab"," and decided that while I liked the physics aspect more than the engineering aspect"," I really liked the research atmosphere and mindset and wanted to return to it in the future - this is when I decided I definitely wanted to go to grad school. The next year I took AP Physics C and loved it"," and applied to college for physics. The classes in university so far have been very difficult because my background is relatively poor"," but I`ve been enjoying it despite the difficulty"," which definitely made me certain I want to continue majoring in physics.
I decided to become a physicist because of my passion for space science and aeronautics.

I am a physics/astronomy major. Originally"," I chose it because as a child I used to watch meteor showers with my grandmother. It has always been one of my best memories of her"," and I wanted to better understand what we were looking at. In high school I came to realize how interconnected physics and astronomy are"," so I started looking for degrees in both. After coming to college I realized that I liked my choice of major"," and joined the local physics club to make me feel more involved.

I went to a science summer camp after my sophomore year of high school. I got to take classes up at UNT and learned that science was fun! Once I got to take physics in high school"," I loved it"," so physics was a great choice for me.

I originally started out as an animal science major with the intention of becoming a vet. I decided that that wasn`t for me and wanted to do something that involved more math. I found physics to be particularly interesting and wanted to do more with it.

I had wanted to be a journalist for quite some time","writing in some sort of a science field"," but it wasn`t until senior year that I determined that science field would be physics. My high school physics teacher was actually a college-level professor who took the high school job when she moved with her husband for his work. She was impressed with my abilities and urged me to go into physics in college"," unlike my classmates who felt I wasn`t smart enough to doso. I love doing physics so I followed my teacher`s adviceand looked for a college with a good physics and writing program"," thus I came to be at Coe. The two years I`ve beenhere I`ve felt supported by faculty but at times I stilldon`t feel my classmates see my worth"," but I will continueforward regardless.
Codes: Utility Value, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I became initially interested in majoring in physics after taking physics in high school. I absolutely loved the class"," and the material seemed to work well with how I thought. After taking the class"," I also realized that many of the shows"," books"," and documentaries I saw were physics related. Through my introductory physics class in college"," becoming friends with my fellow physics majors"," and attending colloquiums"," I became to think of myself as a physicist.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Attainment Value, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I am planning on eventually going into astrophysics research. I`ve been interested in physics ever since fifth grade"," when I found one of my mom`s old physics textbooks and was fascinated by what I read. My mom was herself a physics major"," but she never got to finish her degree as she had to support my dad as he went through grad school. In middle school I discovered Star Trek"," which is what first fostered my interest in space and interstellar travel. During high school I participated in a large number of astronomy related activities. I even started my own astronomy club at my high school. My mom has always been a huge supporter of my interest in astronomy and astrophysics"," and her encouragement has really helped me along the way to getting my physics degree.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Utility Value

Response: My dad is an electrical engineer and encouraged me to take physics in high school. While in high school"," I greatly enjoyed my physics courses"," which led to the pursuit of a degree in physics.

I never thought that I would consider physics in my career because I was afraid that I would just be a failure. However"," when I got accepted into a research program during the summer"," I started to think that I could actually pursue a related career to physics. My research was in the Biophysics and Physiology department and it concentrated on the pathways of neurotransmission of nociceptors. Every day"," I always came early in the morning and left late in the evening because I enjoyed observing all of the experiments that my lab members were performing.

I`ve always wanted to work in astrophysics"," but for a time I thought it wasn`t feasible for me to get a job in such a small field. Then"," after exploring other subjects"," I visited the physics department at Michigan Tech"," and after seeing the cool research being done"," I knew that was what I wanted to do.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Utility Value

Response: In high school physical science class was when I first considered being a physics major. My friends and family influenced me to continue the major

I have been interested in physics since high school"," although my high school physics teacher did not foster an environment in the classroom that encouraged a lot of interest. Upon arriving at Lafayette College with the intention of studying math"," I enrolled in a special relativity course and found that physics was a topic I would like to pursue further"," which resulted in me working towards a dual degree in math and physics. During the summer between my second and third years of college"," I also participated in dark-matter research with a faculty member"," which further enhanced my interest.

I took many AP science classes my Junior year of HS in Texas"," and joined clubssuch as Robotics and Academic UIL (competition) as well as volunteer tutoring AP Calculus"," Chemistry"," Algebra"," and physics students after school.My senior year of high school I moved to WA and did Running Start at ColumbiaBasin College"," which is where you go to college for high school credit. I took an astronomy class at the end of the year and absolutely loved it. I enjoyed working with telescopes and equations so much"," and I even enjoyed the physics part enough to write my final paper on the Higgs Boson.When it came to registering for classes for my first year of college"," I just realizedthat I had to be a physics major"," so I declared on my first day on campus.
I have very little experience in physics or physics-related topics but I have always enjoyed the sciences and am looking forward to learning more.

I was originally a biology major"," but when I took anatomy and physiology classes I realized that medicine wasn`t for me and I needed to switch majors. I took some CS courses"," math"," engineering and physics. I had the most success in physics"," and I also enjoyed it the most. So"," I changed my major to physics.

When I was in high school"," I remember sitting in Physics II and watching my professor conduct this experiment of putting currents through water (not enough to harm people) but then have students feel the effects when they put two fingers next to each other in the water and then move them apart from each other. I remember being very amazed and knew that I fell in love with the sciences.

I always thought that physics was an interesting field"," but thought that I wasn`t smart enough to do well in it (I still think this"," but I`m trying). I distinctly remember sitting in my bed as a sophomore in high school looking at a picture of the Hubble Deep Field. The description said that every point of light in the image was a galaxy"," and that absolutely blew my mind. I immediately started looking into physics"," astrophysics"," everything I could get my hands on. I fell in love with the field and was so excited to take my first physics courses in high school. It was very difficult for me; since I usually have to take more time and study harder for concepts to stick I sometimes fell behind in my classes. In college"," I`ve gotten better at learning fast (because I didn`t have another option) but I still struggled and sometimes did poorly on exams. Occasionally I would consider changing to another major because I thought I wasn`t smart enough to do well in physics"," but then I couldn`t think of any other subject that made me as excited as physics does. It`s hard"," but I`m trying my best to succeed.
Codes: Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Cost (Task Effort), Physiological/Emotional

Response: My freshmen year in college was the first time I took physics. At first"," it was difficult to understand"," but after a month studying"," it started to fascinate me. As an engineer"," I was required to only take the two general physics classes"," but instead of stopping there"," I decided to enroll in more. When I asked the head of department which courses he would recommend me to take"," he suggested double majoring in physics instead of taking classes as a hobby. During my modern physics class"," as I was learning about Einstein`s relativity theory and radioactive decay schemes"," I finally realized what nuclear really is. After that semester"," I started working on a nuclear energy minor as well. After I graduate from my undergraduate studies"," I want to continue my nuclear engineering education and become a researcher at a national lab.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: I had a great high school physics teacher"," who got me interested in physics. When I decided that I want to major in physics in college"," my parents didn`t object (which I know happened to some of my classmates). Then in college"," I`ve been doing great in my course work which gave me confidence. I like talking to people who are knowledgeable about physics as well"," so being in the physics department made me comfortable. Physics gradually becomes something that I am good at as well as interested in.
I work in a live theatre"," primarily as a sound designer"," and the physics behind how waves travel started from working in the theatre. This is how I became interested in physic.

Even though both of my parents are physicists"," I had no interest in physicsuntil I took my first physics class in college. Even though I did well in physics classesin high school"," it was not interesting to me until I came to college.The professors at Wellesley College made physics really interesting and that`s why I decided to be a physics major. Some of the courses were verystress-inducing and frustrating"," but once I got over the initial hump"," it made things easier. I know there are many more challenges coming my wayin the future"," but I feel like I could tackle them because I`ve really come to enjoy doing physics.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Cost (Emotional), Physiological/Emotional

Response: My senior of high school"," I had to choose between taking physics and biotechnology"," my two prospective careers. I chose physics because I had just taken an astronomy course and loved it. I also knew I liked physics because of the display of special relativity I saw at New York`s Natural History museum"," where I bought a book that changed my life. The book is called "Empire of the Stars by Arthur I. Miller
Codes: Utility Value, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered, Media Triggered

Response: I thought the proton was awesome once I learned it wasnÕt just one particle and IÕve always been curious

After being accepted to Colby College"," I knew that I would need to explore new opportunities considering that previous degree programs I had considered were not offered. I had some interest in mathematics but no background in physics. I started reading different books by physicists"," mostly those concerning astrophysics"," and became very passionate about taking physics classes in college. Once I began taking a class"," I quickly realized how much interest I had in the subject"," and how much excitement my professors helped me develop over the concepts. I have since become more confident in my decision to declare the major by next fall.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience

Response: IÕve always thought I would be an artist"," everyone around me thought I was going to be an artist. In 7th grade I learned the word astrophysicist and I thought it was cool but even as a sophomore high school student I complained about not being in an art school. I donÕt exactly know when exactly I decided IÕd be a physics major"," but I did physics honors courses in high school and declared my physics major october of freshmen year at college. I think one of the largest contributors that lead me to where I am now (IÕm a senior applying to physics/astronomy grad schools and not applying to a single job"," since I am sure I want to pursue a Phd) is the mentors I have had. I have been very"," very"," priviledged to have teachers"," tutors"," professors"," and advisors who know what they teach"," are 100% supportive of everything I do and show that they really do care about me as a person. Last semester I suffered from serious depression"," anxiety"," and imposter syndrome. Knowing the facts about misogyny"," homophobia and racism that will worsen as I move through this career doesnÕt help. No matter what I do right now when I send in my grad school apps some people will look at my name"," others my gender"," and yet others my sexuality and make biased conclusions without even knowing it. This is the society we all have been taught to live in"," and none of us are free from the bias. Yet there are people I love and respect and look up to in this field and sharing my ideas"," my research with them"," or conducting research with them"," or learning from them all make it worth staying"," because with their support and guidance I know I will make it through no matter how uncertain I am right now"," and my self esteem will grow as I grow (and take antidepressants and continue counseling"," all of which I have found very effective.)
Codes: Social Persuasion, Cost (Emotional), Vicarious Experience, Utility Value

Response: After beginning physics classes as a junior in high school"," I immediately fell in love with the subject. My high school physics teacher was very knowledgeable on the topic and was a great female role model. She helped me persevere in the class and inspired me to continue studying physics in college. My interest in astrophysics derives from an astronomy class I took while attending the Virginia Governor`s School for Math"," Science"," and Technology. I plan on pursuing both of my passions in college as I intend to major in physics and minor in astronomy at the University of Virginia.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: My interest in Physics started as an interest in maththat I remember having ever since elementary school.When I first learned how to multiply large numbers"," I wanted to do it all the time. I remember sitting ina restaurant making my mom write out pairs of numberson napkins so I could multiply them using my newly learnedskills. Throughout middle school and early in high school","I had a talent for math and I enjoyed it"," but I wanted towork in the publishing industry because I love to read.However"," I didn`t enjoy my English classes as much as mymath classes"," so I wasn`t sure I wanted to major in Englishin college. I didn`t know what I wanted to study in collegeuntil I took an advanced calculus class my senior year ofhigh school. I took an advanced physics class the same year","but I thought physics was difficult and I didn`t enjoy it.I asked my calculus teacher how I could turn my interestin his class into a career. He told me to become anengineer. So I came to college to study electricalengineering"," which requires physics classes and allowedme to discover an interest and a talent for physicsas well.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Cost (Task Effort), Utility Value

Response: I think it was just the way I was brought up. My grandfather had a huge influence on me as a kid in the science field and I always knew I was interested in math and truly enjoyed it. I knew that I wanted to do something in STEM so I just found my way through by trying different things. I eventually found a great interest in astronomy and wanted to learn more. However"," as I started entering college I knew that being an astronomer wasn`t enough if  I really wanted a job where I could apply my love for math so due to that I decided to double major in physics and astronomy since they go so hand in hand. Honestly"," as of right now"," I feel that I am really struggling in this field and see myself as a not-so-great student who feels constantly confused with the topics and concepts. I really do want to do well but I feel like I`m losing the feeling of happiness in this field of study due to how lowly I am doing in terms of academics. I don`t want to give up though and so my goal this year is to truly find out what I am passionate about in this broad field.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Cost (Task Effort), Cost (Emotional)

Response: I decided to pursue physics and engineering based on a gut feeling and because of my aptitude for math"," love for building/machinery"," and blind ambition. I Decided to challenge myself as much as possible to achieve what I believe will be the most fulfilling career I could pursue. I would be the third engineer in my family history"," the first female"," and I hope to spend my life finding ways to save the planet from human destruction. The culmination of these factors lead me to where I am today"," a year from my undergraduate physics degree and a few years from my professional engineer`s certification.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Utility Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: I always loved math in elementary/middle and high school"," but when I gotto apply math to physics"," it was a completely different experience"," and Ienjoyed it so much more.

I was interested in general science courses when graduating high school. I decided to major in chemistry and physics in order to explore multiple areas of science. I enjoyed when the two subjects overlapped in class"," and that encouraged me to continue with both majors. My physics professors also heavily encouraged me to continue with the physics major since I was the only female student in the physics program.

I ascertained my interest in physics fairly late in my academic career. I first became interested in astrophysics as a freshman in college. I was inspired by the material in my astronomy elective course. The faculty members in my school`s astronomy department were incredibly admirable and inspiring - especially the female professors. It was a community I desired to be a part of. I discovered a new curiosity for astronomy and physics"," so switched into the major from psychology.

My first experience with physics was a class before in the summer before 7th grade on it. It was obviously very basic physics but I was very interested. However in high school"," after having a bad experience with a physics course"," I was turned off. I originally started college as a molecular biology major. A intro physics course professor encouraged me to go into physics after taking his class that I ended up enjoying much more than any previous classes I took. A year and three physics courses later"," I have never been more confident in my decision.
Codes: Event Triggered, Cost (Emotional), Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional

Response: I was a pre-med major and I found physics fascination and switched tracks.
Physics was my toughest class in High school"," but it was also the class I enjoyed the most and my teacher was very challenging and supportive.

I took both astronomy and physics courses my junior year of high school. I had fallen in love with astronomy"," but was on the fence about physics.My senior year I took AP physics surprisingly enough just so that I could have a class with my boyfriend.It was by far the hardest class I had ever taken"," and I struggled throughout the entire year.However"," it was the first class to ever challenge me.When it came to picking a major for college"," it became an easy choice.I loved astronomy"," and loved the challenge of physics.I chose astrophysics and have been very happy with my decision ever since!

I had little confidence in my physics abilities in high school and initially only decided to take physics in college after doing well on the Advanced Placement physics exams. I really enjoyed my first semester of Modern Physics and excelled"," eventually deciding to continue with physics.

I always liked science and math"," but I didn`t start considering physics until high school. I participated in an engineering program"," and I enjoyed the physics behind it"," so I decided physics would be a good major for me.

I chose physics because my physics professor at the junior college was an exceptional educator that made physics interesting. I have always had an interest in particle accelerators and collisions"," specifically when considering nuclear fusion. The ITER project and LLNL elemental discoveries is what has lead me to physics.

My interest in physics sprung from my passion for engineering. A large portion of engineering is knowledge about physics"," both basic and complex. As soon as I began the University Physics courses"," I knew that I would not only enjoy"," but excel in the physics field. Also"," the support of the faculty"," other students"," and my family greatly influenced my passion for physics and engineering.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: I first considered physics from a high school course. My physics teacher was very active in QuarkNet and worked hard to inspire at least a few of us. We learned modernphysics concepts"," although we did not have the math background"," as well as attending a particle physics Masterclass two years in a row at the College of William and Mary. My teacher was invested in my development as a person and my success as a student"," and never pressured me to pursue a physics degree. I took two years of highschool physics and asked tons of physics questions. I considered many degree options"," but none were as fascinatingas physics"," so that is what I chose to major in. When I came to college"," my first year of introductory courses wascrushing my desire to continue in physics. I got involvedin a research lab at my college and that revived my interest.I cannot see myself studying anything else; physics just seemed to "click. I love my research job and enjoy learning new physics concepts. "
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Emotional)

Response: I had always had an interest in science. When I started high school"," I realized how much I was interested in astronomy. After talking to my uncle"," who is an astronomy professor at UCLA"," he told me that astronomy is essentially the physics of the universe. That was when I started learning more physics and I found that thoroughly enjoyed it. Towards my senior year"," I was conflicted between becoming an astronomy/physics double major or a chemistry major. I put chemistry on all of my college applications"," but as soon as I came to orientation"," realized that chemistry was not where my true interests were. I changed my major to astronomy/physics and have had no regrets since.
I enjoyed high school physics

The first time I remember hearing anythign related to physics was in middle school when i heard the high school physics teacher talking about how we can never really be in physical contact with anything because of EM. Later in middle school I saw the powers of ten video. Both of these experiences showed me how little we know about the world and how things I initially took to be obvious were actually incorrect. When I learned in high school that studying physics is the way to study these interesting phenomena"," I decided I wanted to study that.
I started out as an engineering major"," then switched to physics when I realized I had a passion for fundamental science and math.

I was initially interested in outer space and human space travel as a child. I never thought I was "smart enough" to do physics for my career. This changed in high school"," when I really enjoyed my physics classes and was fairly successful. I was also encouraged when I received a 5 on the AP physics test. I enjoyed my first undergraduate introductory physics course enough to take a second course in the department. This was atomic and nuclear physics"," taught by a female prof that I absolutely love"," and I was fascinated by the course material. This course convinced me to be a physics major.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience

Response: By taking high school AP Physics  solidified my love of physics beyond the introductory high school courses"," however it was my first year of being an mechanical engineering major that made me realize that physics was a the correct major for me as engineering did not captivate me the way that physics does.
My father would always point out physics phenomena to me as a kid"," and then in high school my favorite teacher was my physics teacher. She was an incredible role model and a great mentor.
Math and physics are the only things I understand and I`m interested in engineering. Humanities and Business wasn`t something I was interested in.

I attended a pre-university science intensive camp in high school which made me realize the love that I had for physics. I always loved problem-solving and the concept of building things which led me to want a career in engineering. Since"," my school does not offer engineering"," I felt that physics would be suitable as a major for my career path.
Codes: Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I first thought about becoming a physicist in 5th grade"," because I liked science and math. Everyone told me that I would be very good at it"," and I believed them. Then"," I discovered how awesome and real research was. I fell in love with research.

I chose my major because of my high school physics teacher.  In high school"," it seemed that my teachers were just teaching because it was there job"," expect for my physics teacher. He was so enthusiastic about his job and physics.  His ability to teach and passion for physics took away the "negative beliefs" about physics being a tough and impossible class.

I decided to go into college as a physics major because my high school physics teacher was a huge inspiration to me. He sparked my interest in the subject matter and encouraged me to continue my studies in college. As a sophomore in college"," I still love learning about physics
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: I was pursuing my second degree as a biology major and took Physics II for non-physics majors with an amazing professor.  From the moment I learned that the speed of light popped out of Maxwell`s equations"," I was hooked. Relativity and Quantum Mechanics became my obsession and I truly couldn`t stop thinking about it; while driving"," in the shower"," walking the dog"," at the gym"," I was sorting out how the double-slit experiment was possible"," how light could have a constant speed"," and how relativistic length contraction worked. How can the result of an experiment depend on whether or not it is observed?  My mind was blown. The "impossible" was objectively real and verifiable. To say I fell in love with physics is a gross understatement"," and it is impossible to describe without resorting to poetic metaphors. I saw the world in a completely new way and was enthralled by the harmony of it all. Somehow"," the mathematical logic made it more "magical" than any supernatural explanation ever had. I changed my major to physics (I still have a minor in biology) and I have never looked back. Unfortunately"," after I started my physics courses I had to take a few semesters off due to the discovery of a brain tumor that was affecting my memory and causing neurological issues and to take care of my dog who had cancer. Life throws you curveballs"," sometimes. As a retired Army veteran"," I had/have the option to withdraw from school and never finish my degree or start a career"," but I can`t imagine doing that"," regardless of the medical hurdles. I spent my time off learning how to "learn" again with my unreliable memory"," brushing up on trigonometry and calculus (that I had not rigorously focused on as a biology major)"," and reading physics books. I`m thrilled to be continuing my degree today.  I look forward to moving on to my PhD and I hope to change the world both in my career and by sharing my passion for what I believe is often an unappreciated field.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Outside Effort)

Response: I took my first physics class in 9th grade and found both the concepts and the way of thinking fascinating. It was interesting"," I was good at it"," and none of my other classes felt nearly as compelling. In college"," I found a fantastic physics community which confirmed my desire to continue with physics. Problem solving and learning and understanding physics continues to be satisfying and I hope to carry that with me to whatever comes next.

I struggled with calculus when I was in high school and it pushed me to want to work to improve"," which was something new as I had never really been challenged before.  It intrigued me"," and I really loved how physics is working to push humanity`s understanding of the universe around us"," so I decided to major in it. I also love how flexible it is and how many paths are available after getting a bachelor`s in physics.  The community at UCLA is amazing"," and I joined the board of our SPS group within the first year here and built a strong"," close-knit group of physics majors around myself for support.  I also joined a lab in thermoelectrics and really enjoy doing that.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic (Social), Utility Value, Physiological/Emotional

Response: Leading up to graduation"," I attended a college fair where I stumbled upon Dillard University. The representative told me about their physics program"," which is when I decided to make it my major. I was currently enrolled in an AP Physics class at the time and I loved it. Initially"," I was unsure about keeping physics as my major"," but after I took my first physics course"," I knew that I was in the right major.
High School Teacher was encouragingCommunity College Professor exposed me to the different applications of physicsUniversity Department of Physics faculty are very supportive and are true mentors

I first considered physics as a trajectory when I was around 8 years old. I realized that time did not exist"," and decided to become a physicist in order to prove it! A year or two later there was a young scientist on the cover of Time magazine who was trying to do exactly that"," and I gave up on the idea of being a ground-breaking theoretician. Years later"," when I was in high school"," I took a physics course with a teacher who`s classes were considered the most difficult in the whole school. I remember talking with him at length about the function of reference frames at constant velocity"," and at the end of the conversation he gave me a theoretical physics textbook to keep.  I went on to Willamette University and declared in the physics major"," but I was discouraged by the realization (I had wanted to go into engineering) that there was no great discovery in engineering necessary to create a more sustainable world"," the infrastructure is just arranged poorly - with profit above healthy function. I left Willamette University due to a death in my family and two years later entered University of Washington"," intending to become a librarian. I took a history of physics/astronomy course in the winter of my first year here and was hooked again"," theoretical physics and its historical context is my calling. I am now playing catch-up in my physics credits in order to graduate with an Astronomy degree"," a History and Philosophy of Science degree"," and a minor in Mathematical Physics.

I have always enjoyed and understand sciences so when I had an amazing high school physics teacher"," he helped push me into physics. Physics makes sense to me and helps explain our world and I enjoy being able to explain that to others.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Attainment Value

Response: I didn`t enjoy physics classes in high school but modern physics discoveries interested me and I started reading about particle physics and quantum physics and thought maybe I could do that with my life.  It solidified itself when I took relativity in my sophomore year and I thoroughly enjoyed that class and wanted to continue learning physics"," the following summer I started doing research work and that was also something I really enjoyed so now I think that physics is something I want to professionally consider.

I originally went to college and graduated with a legal studies degree. However"," that was not my dream. I wanted to do something with science"," but my parents wanted me to be a lawyer. After graduation"," I didn`t apply to law school. I was missing science too much. I realized I wanted to do physics the day I passed my college algebra class ( a class I was struggling with for a long time). I always have deep theoretical questions about outerspace and the future of our universe. I began to take a few courses and was in love. I want to continue onwards to a Ph.D in Astrophysics.
Codes: Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Utility Value

Response: I first considered physics as an option when I took Honors Physics my junior year of high school. I excelled and enjoyed the course thoroughly"," as well as the teacher`s methods of pedagogy. His encouragement inspired me to pursue physics"," but I was also a talented writer and was lauded my whole life for my writing skills (by my parents and teachers) so I continued on a college-prep English track"," taking AP English courses rather than AP Science courses. When the time came to choose my college major and I thought about what I would like to do for the rest of my life"," I realized I was more interested in physics and science in general than the humanities and found it more compelling than anything else. I figured I had been making decisions based on the influence of others and decided to go my own way.
I took my first physics class my senior year of high school. I had an amazing teacher.

I attended an arts high school so Physics was not offered as a class because it was not required by the state curriculum. When I started college"," I actually failed my first physics class. At the time"," I was a Chemistry major and Physics was not even on my radar as a viable option for my future career. Because Physics was a requirement for the Chemistry major"," I retook Physics 1 with a different professor and the content started to make sense. I switched majors from Chemistry to Chemical Engineering"," then to Mechanical Engineering"," and finally to a double in Physics and Math. I think it is a surprise to myself that I am majoring in Physics and Math"," because in my first year of college"," those were my worst courses. But through dedication and hard work"," I have grown to love Physics and tolerate Math. I am a student parent and I was struggling to keep up with my classes while I worked 30+ hours/week to support my family. The Physics department at my school offered me a paid research position and I was able to have a flexible schedule and support my son without quitting school. I am now the lead for our research team and have published papers. So many opportunities have been given to me through physics. If I did not give Physics a second try"," I might not have even finished college. This spring I am graduating and planning to continue my education in graduate school.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic (Social), Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: I never considered being a physics major in high school. I excelled in physics and chemistry"," but it wasn`t until my senior year that I attended a workshop at my university`s physics department. I fell in love with the demonstrations"," the faculty"," and all of the classes. I haven`t looked back since. I feel a great need to spread the knowledge of physics and help other students and future students to understand the importance of the science behind it all.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Event Triggered, Utility Value, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I began having experience with physics as a child as my father is a HS physics teacher. Watching the way the world works as well as my AP physics class encouraged me to look at majoring in physics. The different things I enjoy doing outside of class and homework have all involved the physics of motion and particles which has encouraged me to continue pursuing this major even if I do not go into a typical physics-related field.

I remember taking physics in my freshman year of high school and hating it because I didn`t have the proper background to fully understand the concepts according to the way my teacher was teaching. Taking physics courses in college made a lot more sense to me"," and my electromagnetism professor actually invited me to join his student research group. This greatly influenced my decision to become an engineer major because I found that I actually did have the ability to succeed in this career.
Codes: Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Social Persuasion

Response: I have always felt like mathematics was the most powerful and elegant language. It was then natural for me to be intrigued by the field of physic; it intend to answer universal questions with fundamental concepts throughout this precise language"," brilliant isn`t it ?I started my bachelor degree in physics and mathematics not planning to pursue as a future career. However my different experiences of research"," popularization and conferences made me realise thatworking as a scientist would allow me to fulfill my curiosity"," creativity and desire to communicate with others.

In high school"," I just had a really great instructor who made the topic extremely comprehension  and fun. I loved that I was learning about all the thing around me. Then I discovered medical physics and thought the career was extremely innovative and amazing.

I have always wanted to be a engineer and coming to Appalachian State University made that hard since it is not an engineering school. I decided to stay and be a physics major because of my intro to physics professor that never gave up on me. I failed my very first physics test and she helped me with anything I needed instead of giving up on me. That`s why I am a physics major because of the people around me helping me instead of putting me down.

I didn`t consider any STEM related field until I entered college.I started off as an English major"," my plan was to get a doctorates and teach English in universities around the would. But my husband at the time told me it wouldn`t be affordable for him to get his medications outside of the US so I needed to change majors since they`re aren`t many opportunities in English. I took general physics to fulfill my science requirement and realized that it was the only class I was enthused about going to. I switched to physics and began taking all of my math requirements (I had to start at pre-cal because I had no math background).I initially just had the plan of being an educator but as I got further in my studies and realized the opportunities available to be I now am devoting myself to research endeavors.

I took a physics class in high school and it was the first science course I had genuienly enjoyed. I started touring different Universities and realized that I was much more interested in the physics and research being done rather than the engineering side. I decided to go to Embry-Riddle because of their Astronomy and Astrophysics program. My classmates"," professors"," and a love for science that I never realized I had kept me on my physics path.

I loved taking physics in high school. My dad is a research physical chemist so the world of physics surrounded me growing up in the form of books and Carl Sagan`s Cosmos. I did research in materials science before college and found it enjoyable. I keep studying physics today because the problems are interesting and challenging"," and the community is close knit. I also love math (I`m a double major)"," and I am thinking about doing applied math in my future because it can involve both physics and math.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Media Triggered, Intrinsic (Social), Event Triggered

Response: My interest in physics comes from having amazing professors that took the time to invest in my education and help develop my curiosity.

It has been my dream to "," work on investigations and research specifically in the astronomy area. I have been influenced by my family and friends and I found a great interest in this since I was very young.
The research program at my university and my father`s work in high energy physics influenced me to pursue a physics career.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: I was really interested in how things worked"," and my teachers encouraged me to pursue that interest which led me to the field of physics"," and the more I looked into it the more excited I became. I got involved in physics research and realized that I really liked it and then decided to major in it.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I have always been fascinated by space. When exploring space in high school"," I realized that studying physics was the path I should take to be able to understand the cosmos.

I first considered a physics degree when I was in high school. I knew I wanted to go into a science relatedfield"," and I had taken biology and chemistry and wanted totry physics. I enjoyed the regular physics class"," and enrolled in AP Physics. AP Physics was a very interesting class and my teacher was compelling and knowledgeable. Hehad gone into the Navy"," and when he was out"," chose physicsbecause it was the most difficult major and ended up enjoying it. One of my best friends was also an intendedphysics major"," and I`m sure that also influenced my decision. I was accepted into the Honors program at my university and was enrolled in Honors introductory physics.It was an interesting class in which we learned more than we had in AP Physics"," including some Lagrangian and specialrelativity. As I continued on in college"," I started to doubt my abilities as a physics major"," since many of my grades were in the "B range. However

I first considered physics when I was 11 years old. I found myself intrigued with teleportation in videogames; this remained my main motivation to study physics until I entered high school and took my first physics class. I passed the International Baccalaureate`s higher level physics class"," and moved on to study music composition in university"," one of my passions at the time. After a sour experience in the music department"," I realized that I had been badly missing physics. I transferred to the University of North Florida and switched my major to physics"," ready to begin the next chapter in my life.

Science has always been something I was very passionate about and from a young age I wanted to be a scientist and when I took physics in high school I knew that it was what I wanted to do. When I entered college I felt overwhelmed and almost quit physics but through the support of the other women in physics I decided to stick with it and I am very glad I did.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Emotional), Social Persuasion, Attainment Value

Response: I have always been interested in how the world around me works since I was a kid. I decided to study physics in college because it was interesting to me"," and I had likes the concepts I had seen in my HS physics class. In college I found that I really loved astrophysics in particular through an introductory class I took. I have continued with this into my research project this summer"," which has had a big impact on where I want to go with my future.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered

Response: My family has science background. I was always fascinated by it. I decided to pursue physics in high school as it seemed most logical and basic of the sciences.
I want to be an engineer and Physics is the key.
8th grade science teacher- had previously been an engineer before switching to teaching"," really pushed me to go into the sciences8th grade math teacher- pushed me to consider math as a major

I was always interested in math and science growing up"," and excelled in all my classes"," but particularly math.Once coming to high school"," I started taking AP math and science classes and doing well in them"," knowing I would end up in a math or science field.I took physics for the first time my junior year of high school and loved it. It was a challenge at first. I appreciated the challenge. For most other classes"," it took very little effort to get an A. With physics I had to work for it.My dad is also a physicist. He got his PhD in physics from MIT"," and I inherited his brain in a way.Applying for colleges I was deciding between a physics and mathematics for my major.
