In my mind"," physics was the perfect combination of math and science and the beautiful universe that I had falling in love with"," and so I chose physics and added a minor in math for fun.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience

Response: I have loved astronomy since the 7th grade. Every chance I got I would be reading library books about astronomy. I read my way through books about all of the planets and then I worked my way up to stars"," galaxies"," and cosmology. Once I got to high school and I took the introductory physical sciences class I realized that astronomy was not possible without physics. At that point I decided to be an astrophysicist"," it helped that the physics section of that course was very easy for me. I continued on to take the highest level physics course offered by my high school and passed that easily"," confirming for me that pursuing a physics major as well as an astronomy major would be a great choice. When starting college I was unsure of whether physics would be the right choice for me"," so I took the core engineering classes just in case"," but once I had taken the introductory astronomy courses I was sold"," I declared both astronomy and physics as majors and have been working on them since.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Utility Value, Mastery Experience

Response: In high school"," I took AP physics course 1 and 2. I did not so well in physics 1 but decided to stick it out for physics 2 because I did enjoy the course it was just challenging for me. In Physics 2"," I had an amazing professor who saw my potential in physics and really pushed me to do well and try my hardest and I ended up getting a really great grade and did well on my AP test. Then I discovered the physics and engineering program and decided I would give physics a try. Now I am currently attending UAlbany and have switched my major to just physics and plan to get my Masters in Chemical Engineering.

I considered being a physics major my junior year of high school when I took a regular physics class and seemed to do very well in it. To ensure that I liked the topic my senior year I took the AP Physics class and found that it was very difficult but it was the only class that stimulated me in away that made sense. Since I still had a love for physics I decided to go through college as a physics major and it has been one of the best decisions of my life. My professors and mentors have been positivelyinfluential in my career as I`ve learned applicable skillsand learned about various internship and conferenceopportunities.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I started to study physics since I came to United States. The subject itself was very hard for me to understand but still it was the most enjoyable education I have had. The joy of learning was the most pleasant when learning physics. Even though it is challenging"," I believe it was worth learning and I am still continuing to learn.

I was exposed to math and science at a young age"," partially because my parents are both math and science teachers. In addition"," I had the opportunity to take physics extensively in middle and high school - I took physical science"," physics"," and AP-level physics. Although in middle and high school I was more interested in math (particularly competition math) than physics"," in my senior year of high school I decided to try majoring in physics since it is more applied than math and I anticipated that I would not enjoy pure"," theoretical mathematics.In college"," I initially planned to double major in physics and mathematics"," but debated between those majors and mechanical engineering or computer science. I declared my major to be mechanical engineering at the end of my freshman year"," but then switched to a physics major midway through my sophomore fall. My reasons for switching included: I enjoyed my mechanical engineering classes but realized that I would probably not like the hands-on work of engineering as much as I anticipated; I did a fabrication-based research project in mechanical engineering and did not enjoy it; I was taking a relativity class for fun"," which turned out to be a fantastic class and helped me to realize how much I love physics. Since switching"," I have been very happy with my major.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered

Response: I have always been good with computers and the internal systems and how they worked. so i wanted to become a computer engineer"," then i took my first physics class and i was immediately caught on to the idea of physics. now i want to become a aerospace engineer.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value

Response: When I was a child"," I told my father that I wanted to be a scientists.  He asked me what I mean to study.  I was determined to learn everything that I could"," so I told him "everything".  He told me that I should be a physicist"," because they learn the science behind how everything works.  I always considered physics to be an option in college for me"," and my growing interest in the area and the amount that I enjoyed the physics class I had in high school cemented this as a serious goal of mine.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Attainment Value

Response: In high school I did well in Advanced Physics as well as math classes and enjoyed taking an Introduction to Engineering course. This led me to be interested in Engineering.Then"," I was accepted into the MapCores program for women majoring in Physics"," Computer Science"," Mathematics and Pre-Engineering. Although the college physics courses were challenging"," I also found them verygratifying and interesting so I declared my major in Applied Physics.
High school Physics teacher influenced me to major in physics.

I have been interested in physics and particularly its applications to astronomy from a young age. I did not get much exposure to the subjects before arriving at university other than watching documentaries and reading a few books"," but I selected Astronomy-Physics as my intended major and enjoyed it enough to stay.
I enjoyed physics in high school"," so I continued in college"," but I have found the course material difficult"," so I opted to do an astronomy minor with a double humanities major.
I took AP Physics in high school and liked it a lot"," and then I did not like biology and chemistry but still wanted to be in science so it lead me towards physics.

I have always been interested in the mysteries of the universe"," but my love for physics started in high school. I had a wonderful physics teacher who explained topics with excitement and passion"," and who let me ask as many questions as I needed to in order to succeed. In addition"," it was in this class that I experienced my fist science fair"," and that was the first time that I ever felt the confidence to pursue a career as a physicist.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered, Attainment Value

Response: I went to a college fair the year after taking my first high school physics course"," got a bit overwhelmed and realized what id like to be doing for the rest of my life is something I enjoy and that challenges me mentally"," and that physics fits all that criteria.
Well"," I always liked science and math since I was a child. However"," the trip to the Kennedy Space Center is what got me interested in Space related sciences. Now I settled on Astrophysics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: I was always interested and talented in Mathematics. For most of my life I dreamed of becoming a Mathematician but then Sophomore year of high school I realized I would be taking Physics and started looking more and more into the field. I still remember when my dad convinced me that I would probably enjoy Physics the next year because it was so heavily based in mathematics. When I took the Honors Physics course my junior year"," I instantly fell in love. I excelled in the subject and found the knowledge to be beautiful. When I had free time I would watch videos about Astrophysics and read articles about the hot topics in Physics. I became fascinated by black holes and the idea of discovering such things. I went on to take AP Physics C (Mech) my senior year and it simply solidified my decision that Physics was the career I wanted to pursue (specifically Astrophysics). I had an internship with HDR to test out Engineering"," but I figured out that my real passion was pure Physics. People encouraged me to follow my dreams and become a Physicist. Now"," I`ve declared my major and I couldn`t be happier with my decision.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Event Triggered

Response: I want to achieve a PhD in bioengineering and physics is the stepping stone to make this possible. I love science and I believe I can help people with the knowledge I will be acquiring during my academic preparation. Colombia is my home country and I have seen what the guerrilla situation has done to soldiers. Amputations are a common problem due to mines and I would like to participate in the research and creation of ambulation devices. I want to contribute to the reestablishing of human functionality with the help of robotics.
I didn`t think that I would be able to do physics"," it seemed too difficult. However"," my physics one class at Colorado School of Mines had a "Meet A Physicist day

I have always been interested in the way the world works and what makes everything tick and physics teaches you everything about it. I have also had a strong interest in astronomy and it goes hand in hand with physics.

I would say it started when I was on Active Duty in the Navy as a nuclear trained electricians mate and dealing with Electricity on a regular basis. I liked it`s sources and how it worked but knew I wasn`t interested in being an electrical engineer so I thought a better option would be to study physics specifically. When I was laid off from my job and had the opportunity to go to college on the GI Bill I chose Physics as my major and eventually added Applied Mathematics as a second major.

When I was a child I was fascinated about space and the night sky. I asked my dad so many questions and shared my curiosity with him in science and math. As I went through school as a child I also spent countless hours at the kitchen table doing math homework with my dad. When I entered college I took an Intro to Astronomy course and decided that Astrophysics was what I wanted to major in.

I enjoyed the challenge physics presented in highschoolÑ I had grown somewhat bored with science classes and physics brought back the excitement that had been lacking in the high school level biology and chemistry. In the summer before college"," I took part in a research project working on laser spectroscopy of lithium and that was ultimately what inspired my enthusiasm for physics research.

I liked astronomy since I was young for reasons that most kids do (space is cool as heck).  In high school"," I was placed into an astronomy class by accident"," and I liked it a lot.  My teacher was very supportive of me and encouraged me to apply for NASA programs and continue with a degree in physics or astrophysics if that was what I liked.  In college"," I decided to study astrophysics"," and have been continuously supported by a community of diversity-minded STEM folks.  My high school astronomy teacher and my first physics professor were both confident STEM women that pushed me to seek opportunity and were chief influencers in my decision to start and continue with astrophysics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social), Vicarious Experience

Response: My high school chemistry teacher was the first reason I became interested in science. It wasn`t until college I becameinterested in physics because of the introduction to physics courses.

My mom is an engineer"," and she`s always encouraged me academically. I didn`t consider majoring in physics until I found out I did very well on major physics and calculus tests"," and"," when I looked through the degree course requirements"," they all sounded enjoyable and interesting. My high school physics teacher was absolutely the best teacher I`ve ever had"," and through his class I gained a deep appreciation for physics and science.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: I used to read random papers and joke i would be a physicist some day. then i went to college and studied biology and chemistry and took a random physics course. Between that and the amazing physics adviser i got to know"," i realized nothing else would do!

I`ve always been interested in STEM and I`ve never been influenced to think I don`t belong in STEM because I`m a girl. I think that has to do with how my sisters and I were raised and the fact that I went to an all-girl high school. I loved physics in high school"," and I was an undeclared engineering major my freshman year of college. After a year I knew I liked physics more so I switched. It`s very broad and is a great base for any work in STEM or further studies in graduate school.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: I was more interested in science and mathematics in school. By the end of high school I was sure I liked to work on physics and mathematics. But was not able to make up my mind between science and engineering. I studied engineering and got a job. Due to various reasons"," I had a long break with academics and work. When I thought of returning to academics"," I was motivated by series of lectures by Dr Walter Lewis from MIT"," and I decided to pursue a career in physics.
i loved physics in high school and have pursued it ever since

I went into civil engineering at McGill University from high school.After my first year of university"," I was very interested in pursuing a program with a bigger emphasis on Math and Physics.I transferred into the joint Honours Math and Physics program at McGill"," but also found out about UBC`s Engineering Physics program that also matched my interests well.I ended up coming to UBC and the program has been an excellent fit for me.The math department at McGill was very hesitant to encourage students to enter the Math and Physics program as it had a reputation of being very difficult. I found the admission process at UBC to be more welcoming and encouraging despite Engineering Physics being an equally demanding program.

I first considered becoming a physics major after I watched a video on quantum mechanics and became fascinated by the counter-intuitive nature of particles at those size scales. In high school"," I had a brilliant physics teacher who urged me to think about the explanations for daily phenomena. He taught physics in engaging and creative ways"," using several demonstrations"," as well as provided us with many resources to further study physics. My curiosity to learn about why our universe functions the way it does largely fueled my decision to become a physics and astronomy major. I also attended a 2 week"," day scholar summer program called Summer Physics for Girls at University of Maryland"," and I gained basic exposure to several topics in modern physics"," as well as listened to lectures given by a number of female physics professors and researchers in the department. That furthered my love for physics and passion to learn more about it. Attending both my physics and my astronomy class"," as well as lectures given by University of Maryland physics professors and researchers during college has only reinforced my motivation to learn more about physics and space to ultimately get a better understanding of the universe.
Codes: Media Triggered, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value

Response: I always scored good grades in physics and math. I was interested in the subject of astronomy which led me to participate in a Space Competition when I was in eighth grade.This helped me to decide that I wanted to do a career in astronomy.However during my sophomore year in college I changed my major to engineering in physics since I discovered my interest in engineering courses.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Mastery Experience, Event Triggered, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: I first considered physics when I took it in 8th grade and it was the first class I had to work for. I loved it so I took AP Physics 1 my junior year of high school"," and took AP Physics 2 as an independent study my senior year. My high school physics and calculus teachers always encouraged me and allowed me to explore my thought processes even when tests weren`t my strong suit. I came into college knowing I wanted to major in physics. I had to work through pre-calculus before I could take intro physics courses which meant I couldn`t start the major until my second year.

I`ve always loved science. First I wanted to be a paleontologist or maybe a marine biologist"," but in 4th or 5th grade"," I read a book about basic astronomy and decided that was what I wanted to learn about. When I got to college"," I decided"," somewhat impulsively"," that physics would be the best major to help me with that dream.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered

Response: I found my God and Mathematics combined in physics and that led me to persue it on the first place and once I started I was thoroughly amazed by every moment of it and the best part is there is there is always more to it and that drives me towards studying physics.
I`ve always wanted to study physics and as I get older I understand even more that I want to do research in biophysics to some capacity.

After I first expressed interest in pursuing physics"," my mother really started pushing for me to keep going on thatpath. My family as a whole has been very excited andsupportive of it.My first time visiting college after that my host was a jointphysics and studio art major--she had me convinced that myfuture college`s physics program was the best choice for me.Since then"," whenever I`ve gotten discouraged"," she`s been theone to remind me of why I started and why I`m doing what I`mdoing and why I shouldn`t give up.I found that as I progressed my final year of high schoolthat there was a lot that I didn`t know about the physicsside of the world that I wished I knew. I consoledmyself with the thoughts that I would find out"," I woulddiscover these things through my schooling"," and because ofthat I started to research things on my own.Also--probably the greatest influencing factor--was thepossibility of being able to make ground-breaking discoveries--finally find a planet capable of supporting life"," finding a wayto achieve space travel and exploration on the large scale--and quasars.Quasars have fascinated me since I discovered them. Themystery behind them made me wonder"," made me curious.I became enthralled with sci-fy during this period--as myother half of my degree is creative writing"," I dove headfirst into this world of sciences and natural wonder.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered

Response: I was originally taking physics as my general education lab course"," and ended up loving the class and the concepts within it. So I switched my major and began my journey as a physics student.

Prior to attending the South Carolina Governor`s School for Science and Mathematics"," I had believed I would go on to do computer science. My junior year I took a physics course under an exemplary professor"," Dr. Whitbeck"," and decided to pursue physics instead"," graduating with a concentration in physics from GSSM. From there I have continued to pursue physics"," and did research at Christian-Albrechts University in Kiel"," Germany over the summer to help solidify and confirm that that was the path I wanted to take.

I considered studying Physics for the first time in Grades 4-5"," because I was fascinated by the Physics experiments we did at school"," and I liked how Physics explained how things work. During middle school and high school I did independent study in Math"," and enjoyed viewing the topics I was studying from the perspective of Physics during my free time (e.g. the physical interpretation of the Poincar conjecture). Some of my teachers encouraged me to participate in National Physics Competitions"," and be a member of the Physics club"," which strengthened my interest for Physics. I started viewing Physics problems as challenging"," thought provoking problems which I enjoyed solving in my free time (and not only when I studied for school).My visit to CERN in Grade 11 strengthened my interest in Physics"," because I saw that scientists from all over the world collaborated with a common goal in mind; yet"," everyoneÕs background was different. I visited CERN with my high school in recognition of being one of the top students in Physics.Additionally"," I started windsurfing (sailing) during high school"," and I was intrigued by the fact that I could improve my technique and racing strategy by analyzing the Physics behind windsurfing. I really liked seeing applications of Physics in sailing and the prediction of weather conditions.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered, Mastery Experience

Response: I was initially interested in space but didn`t know what field I liked best (astronomy/astrophysics"," planetary science"," etc.). I spoke to several scientistsat the Jet Propulsion Lab"," and all of them said that having a background in physics is a great starting point for any of these fields"," as well as many others. Idecided before entering college that I would study physics"," and upon startingcollege"," I never considered changing majors an option. I know other subjectsare much easier for me and often more enjoyable"," but I`m determined to finish the physics degree - both to know that I`ve accomplished somethingparticularly challenging for me"," and also to better understand the fundamentalprinciples that make up the world around us.
I`ve been set on becoming a physics major since I was young because I have always had an interest in Astronomy.

summer research in high school as a Simons Research Fellow at Stony Brook (condensed matter)confidence from doing well in the F=ma exam of the Physics Olympiadsuper encouraging physics teacher in high schoolespecially enjoyed the atomic chemistry parts of AP chemistryengaging and difficult intro physics sequence
Codes: Event Triggered, Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: When I was a child"," my dad used to take my sister and I "storm chasing" in Nevada where we would watch lightning storms. It was then"," when I began to love exploring the natural world and wondering how the natural world worked. I loved building things"," taking things apart"," and I really wanted to know the answers to the universe. Although medical school calls me"," I hope I`ll be able to use physics in research in medicine.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Medical)

Response: Coming out of high school"," I knew college was a one time opportunity to study anything I wanted -- turns out I wanted to study the biggest thing I could: the universe. So I guess that`s how I ended up in physics.

I enjoyed my introductory physics course"," so I considered majoring in it. I attended CUWiP for the first time and decided to be a physics major. My first research project was in nuclear physics and I really liked it. I won an award at my school for being an outstanding physics student. I did more nuclear physics research"," but experimental nuclear research this time. I became a Society for Physics Students officer at my school. I am currently applying to graduate school and intend to go into experimental nuclear physics.
I was very interested in space exploration and thus theoretical physics is very interesting to me.

I chose physics because I wanted to learn more about the universe and have a better general understanding of the world. I worked with a condensed matter professor for my first two years of undergrad"," but graduallty I realized that this wasn`t the field that I wanted to go into. My third year of college I switched to a cosmology lab studying cosmic microwave background"," and now I know that this is the field I would love to stay in. I hope to go on to grad school and continue my studies after completing my undergrad degree.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Cosmology), Utility Value

Response: I had never taken physics in HS and opted to take anatomy in it`s place. I took my first ever physics class in college and fell in love. I currently work at the Center for Electron Microscopy and Nanofabrication and my love for physics has grown with the work I do here.

I have been interested in space since a very young age. I took my first physics class in high school"," which I didnt succeed in (mostly due to lack of math knowledge at the time). In my post high school travels"," a long time I had focused myself on matters that were much smaller than space"," thinking that both math and physics were far above my abilities. Eventually"," I found my way back to studying math"," which (surprise) I was not bad at. Eventually I wanted more meaning to the math I was studying and took my first physics course. Never looked back.

I grew up in a very philosophically and spiritually mindful home. My grandfather was a prominent eastern philosopher and he raised my mother with radical ideas and an overflowing curiosity. This curiosity transferred to me and for a large part of my life"," I looked towards philosophical texts to answer my curiosities about the universe. This led to be unfruitful because I would only be left with more questions. I turned to science"," specifically physics"," around high school"," and all of the sudden"," abstract concepts started taking on finite mathematical definitions"," and the universe started making more sense. It is in this pursuit of knowledge and a more complete understanding of our universe"," that I hope to be a student of physics for the rest of my life. As I am now about to complete my bachelors degree and go on to pursue a Ph.D"," I have discovered that my idyllic ambitions for a life in physics come with a lot of struggle. Being at a constant disadvantage for something as rudimentary as my female gender is disheartening but it reminds me that along with my scientific aspirations"," a future in physics will also be my battlefield for social justice.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Emotional), Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: I am a Mechanical engineer major which is heavily reliant on physics in terms of electricity and statics.
The LA (learning assistant) program definitely influence my interest in teaching physics"," especially in high school.

I really loved my physics class in high school because it made a lot of sense about the world and I was good at it. In college"," I began doing research in astrophysics and the support and success I have had in my research has really encouraged me to stick with it.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I have always loved physics and was good at it in high school. However"," I focused more on chemistry and math and was determined to pursue a Chemical Engineering degree until I was introduced to the quantum model of the atom. As I took a low grade in my very first quiz of Intensive Chemistry that was on the wave equation and the double-slit experiment"," I started studying harder on the topic and reading more from different sources. Seeing the beauty of quantum physics"," I slowly started changing my mind about my major until I finally took the leap of faith to change my major. Now I work at a lab at Columbia"," learning about the research that Z-Lab does on ultra-cold molecules cooled with lasers.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered

Response: Astrophotography that I saw on Pinterest got me really interested in stars and their creation and therefore astronomy. Eventually I found myself looking for information about different physics topics like the cmb"," Big Bang"," quantum physics which showed me that physics as a research is a viable option and that was something I really wanted to do. My parents were skeptical but mostly encouraging and USC gave me the platform I needed to learn more and expand my knowledge and love for physics.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion

Response: I was always interested in mathematics; however"," I didn`t know how I could apply it. Upon learning of physics"," I was instantly hooked. Near the end of my freshman year in college"," I began conducting computational materials science research.  This experience provided the perfect way for me to apply my physics and mathematics background to solve real-world problems. Materials play a paramount role in modern society"," and being able to use concepts from physics to predict and analyze interesting phenomena is akin to having a superpower!

When filling up applications for college"," I found myself in struggle to decide for my future.As a past experience"," in high school"," I used to work as a volunteer for a Nature Reserve Program in Puerto Rico where I learned a lot of biology.When going to college I thought to myself that I`ve already learned what I wanted from this field"," and by that same time I lived without electricity for three months. As a hobby"," during the nights"," I climbed to the roof to watch the sky"," at that time I fell in love with the stars"," and started reading astronomy and meteorology books.Another day"," I went to a tv station"," were Ada Monzon used to give the weather forecast. She showed me the process of getting information from the sky"," calculations and programs she used.
Codes: Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Intrinsic Value (Meteorology), Media Triggered

Response: My father is a physics professor"," and my older brother is a physics and math major at Tarleton State University. Since I have always had a gift with mathematics"," I decided to take my first APB Physics course last year in high school"," and I fell in love. This year as a freshman in college I have taken my first calculus based physics course"," and I know that I want to pursue a career in physics because it comes natural to me. I want to understand the world I live in"," and the best way to accomplish that is through physics.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I took IB physics in high school and loved it. I had an amazing teacher who pushed me to learn things beyond what was taught in class that I was interested in. I came into college wanting to major in physics"," but I took a computer science class because I thought it would be a good skill to have and ended up loving it. I thought about double majoring"," but I would`ve had to stay in school for 5-6 years. I ultimately chose to major in computer science and minor in physics because I could more easily see the practical application of computer science (including how I could apply it to physics) than I could physics. Computer science seemed to give a larger variety of post-graduation options than physics. Also"," the professors"," advisors"," and staff in the computer science department were often more accepting. I often had to fight to get the disability accommodations I needed with physics professors"," but the computer science faculty were very open and willing to work with me to make the class accessible to my needs. My computer science classes also had way more diversity (gender"," race"," ability"," etc) than my physics classes (kind of ironic given the CS stereotypes)"," so I felt like I could better fit into the community there. I appreciated the group projects in computer science which forced people to interact with each other and build a community. The computer science department also had a lot of diversity related events and conversations"," ad had a lot of initiatives to try to improve the diversity within the program. The commitment from the people high up in the department on these issues created a more welcoming atmosphere for all students then I felt in the physics department. For these reasons"," I chose to dedicate the majority of my undergrad to studying computer science while still minoring in physics.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Cost (Emotional)

Response: In 6th grade"," I developed a strong love for math for thefirst time. Math just made sense to me on some fundamentallevel like nothing else did. Once I got into high school andstarted taking science classes"," I found that I loved physicsthe most purely because of the math. When it came time to apply to college and declare a major"," I was leaning towards math but felt that physics offered a greater variety of future opportunities. To be honest"," I wasn`t exactly surethat physics was the right path for me at the time"," and therewere very few resources at my school to help me make the decision. It wasn`t until my second year in college that I truly fell in love with physics and felt I had made the rightchoice. I now love the subject as well as the community of people.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Intrinsic (Social), Cost (Outside Effort)

Response: as a young girl"," I was fascinated by the way things worked"," especially on a cosmological scale. It began when I picked up a physics book"," and has not ceased to amaze me since.  I became a physics major because I love being at the forefront of discovery everyday"," I learn something I didn`t know before on a daily basis"," and that is very valuable to me.

I hadn`t considered physics as an option for me until I realized that psychology wasn`t challenging me. I wanted more concrete answers and methods than those used in psychology"," and I remembered that my dad`s very good friend taught physics at a university. I ended up attending this university and now enjoy taking classes with this particular professor.

I started reading about current physics research based on radio shows and Ted Talks and found them incredibly interesting. It led me to wanting to learn more"," and realized physics was an attainable field of study.

My high school physics teacher showed me the many potential paths I could pursue with a physics degree. My uncle"," a chemist"," also shared with me a convincing story about how he looks up to physicists. Both of these people are individuals I respect greatly"," and I valued their opinions.

In high school I had a very good physics teacher who was always available to help us. I became very interested in the motion of objects and the forces felt by and exerted by particles and larger objects. I wanted to be a nutrition major in college"," but I went to La Verne for the track team and they didn`t have a nutrition major. I was interested in physics"," so I decided to try that and really enjoyed it. The more I learned"," the more interested I became and decided that I wanted to go into energy issues.

I took a class in high school and learned what physics was. I had an idea of what kind of science I wanted to pursue"," but because  I grew up in a low-income community"," I lacked the resources to know what physics was called until I was a senior in high school.

I was intimidated by the idea of completing higher level physics because the concepts are barely well explained. When I decided to pursue chemistry and biology instead of chemistry and physics despite my high school physics teacher urging me to take physics. I decided that I might want to become an engineer so I enrolled at Juniata as an engineering physics major. After taking University physics"," I was certain that I want to have a mix of chemistry and physics in my major as I can have better understanding of the science field. After my first semester of college I attended the CUWiP conference at Penn State and the astounding support that the women in physics community has established made me want to continue to be a part of this.
Codes: Cost (Emotional), Social Persuasion, Utility Value, Event Triggered, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I became interested in physics through astronomy in high school. Physics was the first class which ever challenged me as a student in high school"," which drove me to pursue it further. For several years I was too afraid to tell classmates/parents/etc that I wanted to pursue physics because I didn`t think I was smart or naturally talented enough. Eventually I did decide to major in physics and announce it"," and since then have been fairly successful.

I have liked space and astronomy for as long as I can remember"," but in high school"," I was very unhappy with my life and let my school performance suffer. Because of this"," I decided to pursue the arts and moved to New York. However"," I always watched youtube videos about physics and astronomy (like Vsauce and PBS Spacetime) and as my interest continued to grow"," I started signing up for free online courses through EdX and Coursera. After that"," I found World Science U and the World Science Festival and felt strongly that I wanted a community to share these things with. When LIGO announced the first detection of GW in 2015"," I finally decided I couldn`t bear to be on the sidelines any longer and applied to community college"," eventually transferring to Columbia.
My physics faculty is an astrophysicist which is something which is what I always wanted to be but did not think it was obtainable. She showed me that it was and I was convinced to chase my dreams.

I always had an interest in the stars and how the universe worked growing up"," so when I got to high school and found that I really enjoyed and performed well in my physics class I knew I had to try it out. I was encouraged by a couple of teachers and my Mom to look deeper into what studying physics meant as well as signing up for science-related activities/events leading up to college. In my first couple of years in college"," I felt like an imposter doing physics (I was not fully physics driven like the rest of the students--I also participated in music and a faith community) but while being involved in the National Council for SPS"," I was further encouraged by the other undergraduate women to not give up on a subject I loved. If none of the encouragement was placed in my life to pursue this passion"," I might have given up on physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic (Social)

Response: My dad spent many years tutoring kids in physics as I was growing up"," and would talk to me about things like friction from an early age. I had a lot of opportunities to take physics in high school"," and really enjoyed it all three times I took it. I declared it as my major when I began university at UW when I was 18"," but the combination of severe depression and 200-person lecture prompted an almost immediate drop-out. I returned to school to study politics"," another area I had always loved and excelled in"," and a field of study where I felt I fit in better. Many years later"," holding a B.A. in European Studies and a few years of experience in the workforce"," I realized I was falling deeply in love with the geology and earth sciences section of the local library. I decided to return to school to pursue a Master`s in Marine Geology"," and was delighted to discover that preparing for such a goal meant getting really solid in physics and chemistry"," which I could do at the small school near my house. Evergreen is known for giving lots of opportunities"," resources"," and attention to its STEM students. At Evergreen I also found much more socially diverse classes than I had seen at UW"," which made it an easier environment in which to find my voice. I have been very grateful for the strength of my high school physics education"," because now combining physics with calculus feels like I have moved from a screwdriver to a power drill"," and I am delighted.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Cost (Outside Effort)

Response: I was an English major in a community college"," and I happened to take an astronomy course.I had far too many questions for one astronomy course to handle"," and so I took non-calculus based physics"," and fell in love with it.I decided sometime later to switch my major and pursue a Masters Degree in Astrophysics.
Encouragement from peers in high school and from high school physics teachers.

I have always been curious about how and why things work.Every time I was able to answer some of my own questions it was rewarding. So I applied to college as an undeclared major because I didnot know what i wanted to study. I tested out a bunch of classes to see which one I felt passionateabout and learned the most from and that class ended up being a physics class for non-physics majors. The "non-physics major just meant that there wasn`t anydifficult math which is funny because I found myself thinking that that class wouldhave been perfect if there was a little more math. So I took a calculus based physics courseand that made me declare a major in physics."

I became interested in physics after taking physical science in eighth grade. I realized I enjoy math and I attended a summer program (COSMOS) in 2016 on the "Big Bang and the Subatomic World" where I did a research project on dark matter in the Andromeda. I decided to pursue physics in college mostly because of COSMOS and my interest in astrophysics.

In high school"," when first introduced to physics"," it was my nightmare. Over time"," kinematics became my favourite portion"," and in grade 11"," I decidedto take up physics as one of my options on the way to getting into engineering.Once in engineering"," I wanted to become interdisciplinary and engineeringphysics seemed like the way to go to gain a solid understanding of how thingswork"," so that I could build things myself.
Because I am interested in explosive field and I desire to serve in the U.S military.

I started my career in Physics"," because my first option of studies (Astronomy) was not being offered in any of the Universities at Puerto Rico. However"," I thought that a bachelors in physics would prepare me more (with science and mathematics background) and then to specialize in Astronomy or Astrophysics. Surprisingly"," I`ve been very intrigued by many topics in Physics"," like particle physics"," and I am even considering other specializations besides Astronomy.

I was inspired by my dad to go into engineering"," and I loved Xavier so much"," but the only program with engineering is engineering physics. I was inspired by the women that presented their research at the poster session during the last CUWiP Conference. About a month of thinking about it"," I changed my major to physics. I did research with one of the professors at Xavier this past summer. Not only did I gain an amazing research experience and a new sense of confidence in myself"," it also validated the idea of me being a physicist and going into research.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Attainment Value, Event Triggered

Response: My grandfather is a physicist and I grew up in Hawaii surrounded by a ton of research in astronomy.

As a teenager I thought physics was cool and read a bunch of Neil deGrasse Tyson books"," and then I didn`t really know what I wanted to study in college but I knew I had to go to college so I thought"," "hey! why not physics?"

I didn`t know anything about physics until I took it my third year of high school. I liked the class so I wanted to do something related to physics in college. I was going back and forth on majoring in physics or engineering in college. I didn`t like the engineering course that I took"," but it seemed like a more practical major with a clear career path. Ultimately"," I decided to major in physics because I enjoyed the topic more.
I was initially and engineer and found my physics and hard science classes to be more interesting.

I thought I was going to study English or Political Science"," but decided to take a physics class after watching some cool videos about cosmology and string theory in my high school physics class. I really loved the more mathematically rigorous approach to physics in college"," as well as the extraordinary phenomena physics could teach you about and provide you tools with for you to explore yourself.

Physics was the only class in high school that I really enjoyed and was excited to attend every day. I have come to love the community at the Physics department at SUNY Geneseo and it has become a second home for me.

I plan on studying astrophysics in graduate school and itÕs been a goal of mine for a long time"," but it took me too long into college to get the confidence to switch from finance to the more challenging but also more rewarding world of physics.

In high school I wanted to major in chemistry. As I was taking adavanced chemistry classes I realized that I didn`t like chemistry enough to want that as my major. At the same time I took my first physics class and I fell in love with it.

My high school science classes were always my favorite and I thought chemistry was my favorite topic until I started physics when I was 17. It had never occurred to me that physics was an option for an undergraduate major though (I naively assumed if you were interested in physics"," you had to go into an engineering field)! I declared my major as soon as possible and I was heavily encouraged by my high school teacher to do so.

I first considered physics as an option when I took Honors Physics in High School. I really enjoyed the topic"," but I had a really bad experience with the teacher. Since coming to college"," I`ve realized that the really good physicists go on to graduate school"," but high schools have a pretty horrible physics program. Coming to college"," I was interested in engineering"," so I took a physics class. I ended up really liking the concepts and teacher and so I just kept taking more physics classes! Right now"," I`m deciding between majoring in physics and engineering because I really enjoy applied math.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: I attended a physics and astronomy research experience over the summer in my junior year of highschool. This is the first time I ever saw grad students"," and realized that people do research for a living. I loved astronomy and naturally gravitated to Physics because of it.
Codes: Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: I first learned about physics during high school"," it really fascinated me with how applicable it was and how much could be described from some simple equations. My high school physics teacher was very inspiring; she was very encouraging and supportive of my decision to major in physics. I was seriously considering studying nuclear physics or particle physics"," but was kind of discouraged when I came to university. I took a class that was an introduction to particle physics during my sophomore year"," and I basically hated it. I hated how it was presented. It was only until winter 2018"," when I felt inspired again by one of my professors. His lectures were one of the main reasons"," along with attending the 2018 Reines lecture"," that made me fall in love with astrophysics. I`ve felt more support in some other professors here at UCI"," which has been a big factor in helping me along these past few weeks.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Cost (Emotional), Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience

Response: I was first inspired to do physics in high school"," because I found my physics class to be hard but rewarding. I had always wanted to teach"," so when I got teaching experience in my first few years as an undergrad"," it really helped me see that I wanted to do physics education.
My high school physics teacher was very influential andbecame the advisor for a senior project in physics. He was very passionate about physics and very encouraging.

Always had a curious mind about the world around me. Originally considered doing engineering due to a strong background in math but wanted more diverse academic opportunities"," so I chose a liberal arts institution"," which resulted in me considering physics. Toured Davidson and met the physics department chair and found the research and classes offered by the physics department interesting. My first semester at Davidson I took Introduction to Physics and loved the practical applications of math and the broad range of opportunities that physics presented.
Generally felt more confident in math classes in High School but had a natural curiosity as to how the world works.
I always like physics in high school and I was good at it. I didn`t declare my major until the middle of freshman year and that mainly due to encouragement from other physics majors and professors

I took physics for the first time my junior year in high school. I really liked it"," we just learned about the basic materials like projectile motion"," forces"," and energy. I have always really enjoyed math"," since I was in elementary school. I noticed that physics includes a lot of math"," but it just applies it to the real world"," which I like a lot.

I used to love space as a young kid. As I grew up it stayed and I felt that pursuing physics would help me to feel like I have a comprehensive understanding of science. I took classes and attended events in other fields but felt that the challenge of physics made me feel more engaged and rewarded for my work.
One name: Stephen HawkingOne book: A Brief History of Time

Interest in astronomy stemming from a visit to NRAO`s Greenbank Observatorywhen I was around ten years old.Declared physics major coming into college as a freshman"," but after the application/acceptance.Enjoyed freshman physics/math/astronomy courses"," and decided to stay with the major.

When I was young and asked all of the questions children ask"," ???What are rainbows????"," ???Why is the sky blue????"," ???How does snow form????"," my parents told me that all of these questions are answered in physics. I knew I wanted to study physics before I knew what physics was because physics told me how the world works. My story is really that simple. I am still trying to find out how the world works.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Attainment Value

Response: I did well in Physics in high school and I found the topics very interesting. It was fascinating learning how nature works.

Was an English major previously"," then I took my first calculus class and fell in love with physics and astronomy. I didn`t perform well on standardized exams for math"," but did for writing and reading"," so I never thought I could pursue science. But I absolutely loved calculus and from there am now planning on spending my life studying astrophysics.

I took my first physics course in high school and loved it.  While everyone else was complaining about how they couldn`t understand it"," I enjoyed being challenged and loved the satisfaction I got when I finally figured a concept out.  My senior year of high school I took AP Physics"," hearing from everyone else that that class would convince me not to continue with physics.  It did the opposite.  Because of that class"," I decided to make physics my major.  I loved the concepts I learned in class"," the math problems that I solved"," and the never-ending connection between those two.

I first considered physics while taking a physics course in high school. I have been studying physics since I entered college. I had not considered physics grad school until I participated in research at DESY.

I was active duty military"," working with munitions and I decided I wanted a fundamental understanding of the things I handled on a daily basis. I failed physics in high school"," because I was not a dedicated student. My high school chemistry teacher noted my aptitude for physical sciences nearly ten years ago"," but college was not something I could afford at the time.  Now I am a mother and striving to be a person my daughter can look up to. I am pursuing a bachelors in physics and then graduate school for engineering.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Cost (Outside Effort)

Response: When attending Xavier University for the summer"," every Friday we would go on a field trip and it was something different every time. We`ve visited ExxonMobil"," BP"," and many more. It was an experience I`ll never forget because it was very educational. I had the opportunity to talk to different engineers and see why they like their job so much and what makes it unique.
I went to grade school and loved all the school subjects. As time went on"," I couldn`t focus solely on one subject. I think the need to study everything led me to physics.

I attended an astrophysics summer camp in North Carolina while I was in high school. I decided to go into astronomy"," but I wanted to see more of the science behind it and decided a physics degree would suit me better. I hope to work in planetariums someday.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: Unlike many of my classmates in physics and mathematics"," I discovered my passion for the subjects only after starting university; through most of high school"," I had a serious intention of becoming an architect. The turning point was my very first calculus course. I still clearly remember sitting in a sea of sullenly resigned first-years and being utterly delighted by this new and exciting world that I had never suspected existed. On the surface"," physics and architecture seem like only superficially related disciplines"," beyond the obvious connection at the level of structural engineering. However"," there is a certain deep resonance between them: a concern with form"," pattern"," and structure"," subject to complex"," densely interrelated constraints that must be analyzed to determine what is or is not possible.  I have enthusiastically pursued research opportunities in theoretical physics"," and have had the good fortune to have been involved with five different research groups"," each with distinct areas of specialty. The experience has been richly rewarding; each of these groups utilizes small working groups of only three to four people"," which has given me the opportunity to make significant contributions to our published results. I have co-authorship on three published papers"," with two more in review and planned for publication this fall. Conducting research with Prof. Linda Reichl has been one of the most rewarding and meaningful experiences of my undergraduate career. Prof. ReichlÕs enthusiasm for her specialties of quantum chaos"," classical-quantum correspondence"," and nonlinear dynamics is infectious. As a female hard-science major"," having the opportunity to work with Prof. Reichl has been particularly inspiring for me"," since there are too few women in science"," even fewer in physics"," and fewer still specializing in theoretical physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered

Response: My interest first began when I took general physics in high school. I felt pretty good at it and eventually took AP physics the following year. This course was the first one to really challenge me"," and while I struggled at points"," the whole thing was satisfying. While there are other degree options I wouldÕve excelled in"," I was strongly encouraged by my dad to study physics in college.

I originally started college as a math education major because I loved math. I actually was also put in a random intro to physics class ( only physics major class  also) my freshman year and I fell in love with the course. I enjoyed the idea of applying math and taking my understanding to the next level. So I got to know my physics professor and he convinced me to become a physics major!

I was always fascinated by the concepts and ideas of Physics ever since my freshman year in High School. The concepts interested me so much that I took AP Physics in my senior year. My AP Physics teacher`s enthusiasm and thought-provoking questions encouraged me to seek answers through mathematical analyses and reasoning. The challenges I faced in this class did not discourage me"," but instead motivated me to work even harder with the help of my teacher and my peers. After overcoming the challenges"," I not only felt rewarded but also passionate to learn more. That is why I knew I wanted to continue learning physics in college. The supportive environment that my professors and classmates create made me realize how important teamwork is when learning physics. Throughout college I had always known I wanted to become a physics major because of my ability to problem solve and collaborate with my peers.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic (Social), Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience

Response: I became interested in physics in highschool when I started looking at current events and research happening within the field. I had never taken a physics course before coming to Cal Poly"," but I knew it was something I had to be a part of.

I was set on being a pre-med student and majoring in mathematics. The biology course I would have to take as a pre-med student was not available during my first semester"," so I had no other option but to register in physics. This was my first time taking a physics course. The course was the most challenging during my freshman year because I had no background in the material. However"," I found the material to be so intriguing. I also attended an APS meeting with the Physics department at Hofstra. As I was presenting myself I told them I was a Mathematics major and although physics was tough I enjoyed it. Many students encouraged me to pursue a degree in physics"," a few of them were double majors in math and physics. When entering college I promised to challenge myself and get the most of my undergraduate experience. This meeting influenced me to become a physics major.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Task Effort), Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I have always been interested in science and became interested in physics in high school.

I first considered teaching physics as a career option in highschool. However"," because of the teaching methods and competition based judging and pressure on students"," I lost interest and began college undecided. In college"," I started enjoying physics again"," and discovered I enjoy research.

When I was very young"," I knew I wanted to be a scientist. I was curious about the world and always wanted to know more about it. So as I got older"," I started exploring specific scientific fields"," and discovered that I didn`t particularly like any of them except astronomy. However"," it is very hard to get an industry job with an astronomy degree"," so I decided that physics was close enough to astronomy to chose as a major. Being at an all-girls high school"," all of my science teachers heavily encouraged me to chose physics as a major as well.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Attainment Value

Response: I`ve always been interested in astronomy. From the time we were little we would go out and watch the Perseid meteor shower. One year for Christmas my parents got us a 12" Dobsonian telescope that we used to watch the eclipse last year. I first wanted to study Astronomy & Astrophysics after watching Star Trek in 6th grade. I came to school as an Aerospace Engineer but switched during the first semester because it wasn`t interesting.

Read a lot about Physics online. Thought a lot about what I wouldn`t mind doing for the rest of my life. Decided I love learning"," and physics is the most important science to research"," in my opinion. Did really well in Physics classes while others were dropping out of the major left and right. Participated in research groups and experiments.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I grew up being very confused about what I wanted to do with my life. I had always had a talent for imagination so I excelled in classes like literature. Upon reaching college"," I decided I did not want to be any sort of english major simply because I enjoyed it too much. It was already too intrinsically valuable to me to create an extrinsic enjoyment through my work. I needed something challenging"," but most of all"," I needed something that provided substantial imaginative properties. Physics"," to me"," means figuring out incredible"," unthinkable questions that I could never conjure up on my own. My dad had always been an advocate for space exploration and what-not"," and I figure that influenced me to major in physics in order to eventually make my way into the world of astrophysics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: I decided to pursue a major in physics during my first high school course in physics. I was surprised at how much I liked it and how much the material made sense to me. Fortunately"," having a teacher for a mother gave me a solid foundation in math"," and I think that really helped me succeed in introductory physics courses. I took a break between high school and college to work and save money"," but my goal never changed. I couldn`t have had a better physics faculty to learn from when I chose to return to school. A lot of who I am as a student today is the result of having great professors. I transferred from a two-year community college to a four-year university"," and now I have a fantastic support system of fellow physics students and professors to look to for guidance. I also began tutoring math and physics"," which has only deepened my appreciation for education. Physics isn`t always easy for me"," but I love the challenge and the dedication it requires to continue.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: My interest in physics originated from science fiction movies and tv shows about time travel. In school"," I enjoyed physics and math classes more than any others. One of the main reasons I am fascinated by physics today is that many of the concepts are counterintuitive.

I enjoyed physics as a subject of study in high school and"," wanting to fundamentally understand the things I was studying and the work I would do"," it appealed to me as a major in undergrad. Since becoming a physics major"," I have come to appreciate the uniqueness of the physics community"," the skill set I have gained"," and the range of possibilities available to me. It was my first CUWiP that helped me truly identify as a physicist after my first semester.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic (Social), Event Triggered

Response: My high school physics teacher had a huge influence on me deciding to be a physics major.

I have had an aptitude for math since I was very young"," andwhen I took AP Physics I and II my senior year of high school"," it seemed to come very naturally to me. My motherhad majored in physics and encouraged me to do the same"," butafter consideration of my other interests (namely"," theperforming arts) I chose to major in musical theater. Atthat time"," I couldn`t envision myself as an educator orresearch scientist"," and really had no idea what those careerpaths entailed. A decade later"," I had fallen into teachingjobs and my passion for the wonder of the universe had neverleft me"," so I finally decided my mother was right all along","and now I am pursuing my physics degree with an eye toward graduate school. I might have made the decision earlier if Ihad only known the range of careers available to physicsmajors beyond being a high school teacher!
Codes: Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Utility Value, Attainment Value

Response: I think my original interest in physics (specifically astrophysics) began when I read the book "A Short History of Nearly Everything by Bill Bryson when I was about twelve or thirteen years old. While it answered many questions about the universe for me
When I really understood something it felt like waking up for the first time.

It was not until high school that I seriously considered what field I would pursue as a career. Always having loved math"," and excelled in it"," my parents both saw me as a future engineer"," but I did not see that future for myself in high school. Because of my many other interests"," I saw myself pursuing a career as a chef"," a business manager"," or an athletic trainer. This continued to be true even when I took my first physics class in high school during my junior year. It was definitely my favorite class"," and I strong in it"," but I saw a disconnect between my love for physics in that class and the study of physics as a career. During my college search as a senior in high school"," I found the field of dietetics and thought it would be a great path for my future. I never considered in the slightest any field in math or a physical science. However"," upon completing my first semester of college courses with no math"," or physics"," I found myself feeling incomplete"," and not intellectually stimulated. I did however enjoy my general chemistry class"," whose lab was in the physical science building. It is solely the location of this lab that is responsible for my current path in academia. In the basement of the physical science building is the ???Science Discovery Center","??? which I visited after a chemistry lab one day. Several of the displays and apparatus brought me back to my high school physics class"," remembering how much I loved physics. Two current physics undergraduates were working in the Discovery Center at the time"," and talking with them may have been the most pivotal conversation I have ever had. One student encouraged me to talk to the chair of our physics department because it was clear that I loved physics"," and I remember him saying that if I am good at physics and like it"," then there is no reason I should not pursue it further"," because few people"," especially women"," can relate. Following this pivotal conversation was the next one I had with my current professor"," Dr. Faux. He signed me into the department soon after our talk. At this point"," I was a physics and dietetics dual major"," and I had an amazing second semester in my physics classes"," while my nutrition classes were interesting at points"," but seemed to drag. This semester was when I attended my first physics conference with some students from our physics department. Loving the experience of engaging with other intellectuals much above my own intellect was inspiring"," and I couldn???t wait to attend more conferences. The following summer of 2014"," I attended two more conferences on my own"," where I threw myself into atmospheres like none I had ever experienced. Both of these conferences were research specific conference"," where I was the only undergraduate"," let alone the only one who was not an expert in the particular fields"," namely neutron stars and parity violations in particle physics. Although much of the content was over my head"," I enjoyed listening to the talks and I made connections with a lot of physicists from around the world. After having attended those conferences I could see myself doing nothing other than physics as a career"," whether experimental of theoretical. Continuing into my first sophomore semester at college"," I realized that I would gain little pursuing dietetics"," when I could be focusing my studies elsewhere. I then decided to change my dual major to physics and mathematics. Because of the chemistry classes I had previously taken as coursework towards my dietetics degree"," I found that I could also minor in chemistry by planning to take physical chemistry classes in the future. By choosing this combination of coursework"," I hope to develop my mathematical skills so that I can be prepared to pursue theoretical physics in graduate school. I am also hoping to develop my knowledge of chemistry if I decide to instead pursue experimental physics where this knowledge may be applicable.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: My junior year of high school I took a physics course and really enjoyed the class and I was interested in learning more about the material. My father is also a big advocate for science and he also motivated me to pursue a science degree. From there on I decided to focus on physics and astronomy since it was something I was very interested in and relatively good at.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience

Response: My high school intro to physics class and The North Star Project (program for incoming freshman at University of Oregon).

I didn`t really know what I wanted to study"," only that I really loved math and science because it challenged me the most. I liked my physics classes in high school"," so I applied as a physics major. To be honest"," though"," when I went to school I was positive I would change my major. However"," I was involved in a program called Sundial that was geared towards diversity and being inclusive in the sciences. I fell in love with the program and with physics"," and have been in it ever since.

I really never thought I would get into physics at all. I was always just into civil engineering"," then when I was in high school"," I absolutely loved my physics class and always found myself staying after to try to get extra stuff to do from my teacher. Then"," my teacher suggested that I consider majoring in physics when I got to college and explained to me that it has a lot to do with civil engineering and other engineering fields in general. So that was when I knew that physics and civil engineering was what I wanted to do.

Good physics background in HS: AP Physics C"," Engineering courses in Project Lead the Way (PLTW)Experience in conferences: SkillsUSA (drafting"," engineering design); Architecture competition (College of DuPage)Presentation with Women in STEM in HS: presentation with ComEd paired with MotorolaUS Naval ROTC - applied for Tier 1: engineeringHopeful for career in aviation/astronaut corps.
Family traveled to Lowell Observatory"," saw youtube video by physicist Jacob Barnett"," personal physics exploration
Codes: Event Triggered, Media Triggered, Vicarious Experience

Response: My seventh-grade natural science class taught me more about how our world works. Ever since then"," I have been fascinated with learning about how our world works. I also have always been into observing and learning about the stars and our universe. Then when I took a physics class in high school"," my passion for physics grew drastically.

I always liked math as far back as I can remember. My freshman year in high school I took geometry and my teacher"," Mrs. Agnew"," was really encouraging of girls in STEM and she actually sponsored a club for girls in STEM that I was president of for a year"," until she moved away. I first considered a career in physics when I took a physics class my junior year in high school"," my teacher Mr. Wuellner was really supportive of the girls in the class and made sure everyone was treated as equally as he could control. He created a really safe environment for me to be curious and ask questions without being self-conscious. I took the next level physics class my senior year"," with the same teacher. I didn`t actually decide on a physics major until the second half of my senior year"," after I toured the physics department at FSU.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social), Attainment Value

Response: Graduating high school early"," I decided to go to a technical college for Laser/Electro-Optics. After graduating with my Associates of Applied Science"," I decided I wanted to learn more about light/matter interaction. This led me to UTA"," where I am now dual majoring in physics and math while researching in an optics laboratory.

When I took Physics in High School"," I was one out of only a handful of girls in my class. Initially"," my desire to succeed in Physics just came from the fact that all the boys (including my brothers) said it was impossible for a girl to do well in this subject"," and I wanted to prove them wrong. When I won the end-of-the-year physics award for that class"," I began to consider Physics as a subject that I could succeed in when very few of my peers could"," and maybe it could be something worth pursuing. After I replicated my performance in my freshman year physics courses and began to realize that physics was re-shaping the way I viewed the world - informing me on more efficient ways of doing things"," and affecting how I viewed something as simple as a falling leaf - I realized I enjoyed learning it"," and wanted to learn as much more as possible. Presently"," I am constantly amazed by news about SpaceX"," the race to Mars"," dark matter hurricanes"," quantum computers"," and many other happenings in the world of physics that I can`t wait to be a part of. My father and physics professors have been phenomenal at encouraging me to pursue a career in physics"," and though I am one of four female physics majors in the department"," the other male majors respect me even if I am excluded from their study groups and discussions.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Cost (Emotional), Physiological/Emotional

Response: When I was about 5 or 6"," I was asking questions about the stars to my dad"," who answered as he could with what he remembered from high school science classes.He nevertheless managed to tell me about some fascinating concepts of relativity","which impressed me a lot (even if I did not understand very much...)My stepmother gave me Stephen Hawking`s book A Brief History of Time at Christmas when I was about 12-13. It took me more than a year to read itin between school and other books"," but it was one of the most rewarding thingI did. I though that the way he explained physics was elegant and logical"," and I realized physics was the most fundamental science. It also introduced me to quantum physics"," which is still today the field of physics that I find the mostexciting. Since then"," I considered studying in animation (drawings)"," architecture or even ancient history"," but nothing stimulated me as much as physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional

Response: I first took a physics class my junior year of high school and it was my favorite class. I loved math and science"," and I especially liked how much physics relied on math.Once I learned about special relativity"," I thought physics was the most interesting field out there.It attempts to explain everything fundamental to the universe that we still don`t understand.I also loved physics even more when I learned it with calculus my senior year of high school and in college.When paired with calculus"," mechanics is elegant and beautiful.
I always liked science and had a great high school physics teacher.
My dad was very encouraging for me to get interested in the sciences. I first became interested in physics through astronomy and have loved it ever since!

I have always wanted to be a physicist. My dad was a theoretical physicist and I came into college wanting to do physics. I considered dropping out Freshman fall but my honors mechanics teacher inspired me to stick with it and I have worked in her lab ever since.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: When I first started at Hendrix"," I was a chemical physics major because I wanted to be a chemical engineer. I liked chemistry all throughout high school and I thought I would just continue on in college. Sadly"," that did not happen. I found myself incredibly bored in my chemistry classes and challenged in my physics ones. By the second semester"," I found myself signing up for more physics classes and less chemistry which eventually led me to change my major in my second semester of sophomore year. I enjoy how I never really understand what is going on in my physics class but when it finally makes sense"," it`s an "aha" moment where everything clicks into place. I love that feeling. I guess at the end of the day"," I like solving puzzles and that is how I see physics.

Seeing a special on the mysterious "God Particle" back in the early 2000s got me interested in physics"," then reading books by Michio Kaku"," Stephen Hawking"," and Carl Sagan sealed it for me. Unfortunately"," undiagnosed disabilities and a chronic illness made me drop after my freshman year in 2008 and I found jobs in the tech industry. It wasn`t until LSST came to my hometown of Bremerton for community conferences (late 2015) that I decided to pursue college again. I started at a community college"," finally got my associates"," and moved up to a four year institution. CUWip and other conferences kept my fire (and confidence) going and this time I know I`ll be getting that physics degree.
Codes: Media Triggered, Cost (Outside Effort), Event Triggered

Response: I have been interested in physics since I was a child"," without even realizing. From a young age the mysteries of the universe always intrigued me"," and the thought of working for NASA seemed fascinating. However"," I did not decide to major in physics until my last year of High School. I was unsure because I knew the subject was hard but there was nothing else that I found more interesting. Since then many people have influenced me to continue my journey"," even with all the difficulties that come along with majoring in Physics. One significant person that I came across always sticks out. He was my Physics 2 professor. The passion he had for physics and his enthusiasm"," encouraged me to be a better student and reminded me why I wanted to be a part of the physics field.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Task Effort), Vicarious Experience

Response: I considered engineering while I was a senior in high school because I like solving problems and I want to build things and work with my hands. I realized my sophomore year in college that engineering wasn`t for me and what I actually wanted was time in a research lab. I had had previous lab experience and I knew I really liked the atmosphere and the work. I chose physics because I could work in a lab and solve problems but also have the opportunity to work with my hands. I always loved science so it wasn`t difficult to decide that physics was what I was really interested in.

I really liked physics in high school"," and wanted a challenge"," so I decided to try it in college.
