It continued to be a challenge"," and despite at times being demoralized and feeling inadequate"," I had support from people around me"," in SWIP"," and also from home that enabled me to continue with my passion. Seeing interesting problems also continued to inspire me.

Before college"," I had decided I wanted to do engineering because I was good at problem solving and mathematics. The school I ended up choosing for financial reasons did not have an engineering program however. As a result"," I made the plan to transfer after my first academic year"," but in order to do this I would have to take introductory physics or chemistry my first year. Given that I disliked chemistry at the time"," I took the introductory physics course and the experience made me decide to stay at the university to major in physics. Several factors caused this"," my professors were amazing"," my peers challenged me and inspired me to rise to their level"," and the course itself required dedication to get through.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I`ve loved astronomy ever since I was a kid and my parents bought me a telescope for my birthday"," and when I got to high school I learned that if you want to study astronomy you`re really better off studying astrophysics"," so here I am! Pretty simple"," really

I first started considering physics as a career optionduring my Junior year of high school when I was exposedto electron entanglement. It fascinated me so much that Istarted to read Brian Greene and Michio Kaku in my sparetime. My high school physics teacher noticed my interestand had me design a course encompassing particle physicsfor my senior year. Now I am attending South Dakota school of Mines and Technology"," pursuing my bachelors degree in physics. Last summer I participated in theDavis Bahcall program where I took an intensive twoweek course in particle physics before touring severalmajor physics labs around the world including FermiLab","Argonne"," NoVA"," Minos"," CDMS"," Frascati"," and Gran Sasso. I plan on continuing on in my education until I obtain my Ph.D in theoretical particle physics. With this degree I plan on becoming a research scientist in eitherthe strong force or neutrino physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: I`m interested in developing physics engines for alternative realities with alternative physics laws.
I have a desire for meteorology and physics is a huge base for that.

I have always loved science and math. Physics seemed to combine my two interests. However"," the biggest influence in my desire to be/ to stay a physics major was my first year physics professor. The Physics faculty at my college genuinely cared about me and how I did in the course. Their constant support and kindness made me glad of my decision to be a physics major.

As an adult"," I read a sci-fi book that talked about relativity - it was so insane"," I had to learn more. The more I learned"," the more I realized I didn`t know. So I learned some math. Then a bit more. Eventually"," I just decided to jump in with both feet and go to school to learn as much as I possibly could. I`m only a junior"," and each day"," I learn more and more about how little I know!! It`s glorious.

I love math and so when I found out I could have a job that really used math I was excited. I heard a speaker in high school talk about the physics of renewable energy and then I realized that I could use science to make the world a better place. As I learned more calculus I fell more in love with math and kept wanting to do science that used a lot of math. Then I learned about quantum mechanics and there was no going back.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Event Triggered

Response: I felt highly out of place in engineering"," and I found myself excelling more in physics classes. Also"," the physics faculty at my school are wonderful"," and they helped me feel like I could succeed in physics.

I was initially interested in space and Astrophysics as a kid because of popular science fiction shows like Star Trek or by watching Cosmos. In high school"," I took my first physics class and fell in love with the subject. I loved how physics allows us to study the laws that govern the universe. Taking that class switched my focus purely on discovering physics and the myriad of interesting topics in the field.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Intrinsic Value

Response: I am very interested in the areas of science and mathematics"," because despite being I like very much the most interesting ones for me. As the years go by (specifically in intermediation). Because it is a subject that covers many subtopics. When I saw how my teacher gave her class and the happiness with which she taught"," I wanted to be like her"," a great researcher. It was because of her that she gave me that push to the sciences and thanks to her I was able to participate in research competitions. That over the years I get to win several times in the area of __renewable and electric energy.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I have been very passionate about mathematics"," particles"," and astronomy for a long time. I also always did very well in math and science courses in school. My interests combined with my academic success led me to choose to pursue a degree in physics. My interest in physics has continued"," especially as my knowledge becomes more advanced. Research opportunities and chances to attend conferences have helped to enhance my interest in becoming a physicist.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I am a physicist. I solve mathematical problems to navigate through the physical concepts that define our world. I work to understand the smallest building blocks and the widest expanses of our universe. But I am not just a physicist. I am a female physicist. This drastically changes how I approach physics"," and how others approach me as a physics major. There isn???t a great track record for women having an equal opportunity to succeed in physics. In my freshman introductory physics class at college"," I was one of about ten women in a seventy-student class. Professors dissuaded me from taking harder math courses"," though I ignored their advice. I didn???t have a female professor for a technical class until this semester"," my fifth at Brown"," already halfway through my degree. At first"," I didn???t seek out conversations about this disparity because I felt that acknowledging it would validate the fact that I was different. But the issue is unavoidable. I am constantly aware of the gendered language used by professors"," and the biases"," unconscious or conscious"," that exist in program admissions and even grant distribution. I want to get more involved in the conversation so that awareness of the issues of representation in physics can reach spaces where it currently goes untouched"," and I hope that attending the Conference for Undergraduate Women in Physics will help me achieve this goal.I am pursuing a Bachelor of Science in physics at Brown"," and am taking a host of rigorous math"," physics and computer science classes. I have participated in physics REU programs the past two summers"," in the Molecular Physics Lab at SRI International and the Physics and Astronomy department at UNC Chapel Hill. I had strong female mentors in both of these programs with whom I discussed issues of gender in physics"," and they encouraged me in my goal of attending graduate school.I intend to pursue a Ph.D. and ultimately a job in academia in cosmology or a related field"," the part of physics that I am most passionate about. Ratios and biases"," while deterring"," won???t stop me from pursuing a career in the subject that I love and have so much to contribute to. Attending the CUWiP conference would push me towards this goal"," and allow me to take a step towards making becoming a physicist more achievable for other women as well.
Codes: Attainment Value, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Emotional), Event Triggered, Utility Value, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: I have always been interested in the way things work and have always been very science oriented. I have known I wanted to be in STEM from a young age but did not decide on physics until my junior year of high school. I took AP physics my junior year and my teacher presented the material in new and interesting ways"," which made it a very appealing subject to me.

I picked physics because it was the hardest subject I couldn`t grasp the first time through in high school.I liked the challenge but it`s also very interesting. My grandfather was a physicist and a chemist inRussia where I was also born. Physicists are very well-respected in Russia even if they don`t get paid alot. I thought that studying physics and going into a physics-related field would give me a sense offulfillment and let me understand the world a little better. Another factor was my boyfriend. He`s veryinterested in science and how things work and we`ve had many discussions about physics"," that`s how I gotexposed to it on a more personal level"," outside of the classroom. It made me see that physics is not ashard as it makes itself to be"," and that there are people who are willing to teach you. It`s been great tosee that other physics students at my school are just as interested in physics as I am"," and offer helpwhen you need it. Physics has a really welcoming community.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I was inspired when I took two physics courses in high school. The concepts were very interesting to me and easy to grasp initially. My teacher didn`t seem to have any prejudices against students and simply supported and celebrated students that did well. I felt very strong and accepted in the courses and felt that peers recognized my talent and asked for help which reaffirmed that I understood the material and boosted my confidence in the subject. As I transitioned into college"," it was extremely refreshing to meet others with the same passion and interest in the field. I felt like I belonged as I found a diverse group of people that all were truly invested and inspired by physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I initially began college as a Civil Engineering major. I chose this major because I knew I liked physics"," and this degree seemed to encompass physics. Half-way through my second semester as a Civil"," I realized the only thing I really liked about my major was that it involved physics. I then considered changing my major to Physics. I talked with professors and older students"," and I joined a research group that was studying solar flares and coronal mass ejections. This led me to realize that physics itself could be a career!I was so excited that I changed my major right away. I am so glad I made the jump to physics! It never ceases to fascinate and challenge me. I am so excited to get to study it for the rest of my life.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Utility Value, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered

Response: I originally planned to be a physics and math double major. Then a college scholarship group reached out to me and said I would be a good candidate to be a high school math teacher. I then started as a math and secondary education major. I was not enjoying the classes (sec. ed) and decided to take an Astro 101 class. That led me to wanting to be a physics minor. My junior year I decided to switch to an astronomy major. My senior year (first round"," last year) I switched to a physics major.

I first considered psychiatry"," engineering"," and physics"," but math has also been a strong suit for me"," and I had no clue what type of engineering I would want to do"," so I went with a physics major. I started my physics education in high school with AP Physics I and II. I went on to community college for financial reasons"," and got my associates degree in physics. Now I am at Virginia Tech as a Physics major"," and I am considering going on to graduate school for engineering if I do well during my time at Virginia Tech.

Both my parents pursued higher education in physics"," and would always tell me about cool physics facts when I was younger. I decided to study a subject that would help me learn about how the world works around me"," and physics seemed like the best place to start. To this day"," I`m really glad I made that decision.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: My father"," cousin and uncle as physics majors was a first step. My high school physics teacher encouraged my passion in physics

I`ve always been interested in science"," but chemistry is difficult and biology is too mechanical (memorize and regurgitate) and I hated studying dead things. Astrophysics and the study of the universe originally interested me in science as I read a lot as a young person about astronomy and the way things work. My father is an engineer so I`ve been exposed to physics many times in my childhood despite high school teachers discouraging my interest in physics and mathematics. I am glad I pursued physics and had the opportunity to study in a department that valued me as a young black woman. No"," people don`t treat me the same and it makes a difference.
Always had an interest in physics/space from a very young age"," started attending Splash events at MIT and really fell in love.

I really enjoyed my high school physics class and from there took a gap year where I was able to do some research in physical fields. Since then"," I have only found myself to like physics more and more"," and find it more applicable to things I might be working on in the future.

I was influenced to become a physics major at the university I started college at because of the Learning Assistant program run by Dr. Close at Texas State University. I was exposed to people who have a passion for physics and for helping others learn physics and that was what most garnered my attention. I officially decided to change my major when I realized the difference between what physicist do for the world and what engineers do. I decided I wanted to be the one that was learning and discovering things about the universe so that others can create things that benefit the world.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I have wanted to pursue an astronomy and a astronomy-related career ever since I was a child. Growing up"," I participated and graduated in Spring 2015 from the Arecibo Observatory Space Academy"," 12-week pre-college research program in which students did a research project in astronomy-related subject"," and later on I had the opportunity to be a Teacher Assistant in the program. The program first introduced me to physics"," and later on in high school"," by counseling from my teachers"," I decided to study physics"," with a minor on astronomy and astrophysics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered, Social Persuasion

Response: I was put in a physics class as a freshman and wanted to continue taking physics classes afterwards.

I always liked math and science as a kid"," and my dad also majored in physics and went to grad school with work in lasers and condensed matter"," so we often talked about science as just a regular part of life and something really cool to use to learn about the world. My fifth grade teacher was really the one who introduced me to the idea that "Astrophysicist" was a career"," not just science fiction! Once in high school"," I continued to get more interested in physics and math and took it my junior and senior years. I loved it! Being able to explain and model the world around me and the interactions between things with math and theoretical models is very satisfying.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: Originally I started off in a major in art. However in high school"," that is where I realized that I loved physics. The class was challenging"," but my professor made the class fun. Throughout the years"," I realized that things that are easy to me are not fun. When I was deciding to change my major"," I chose physics because it was challenging to me and caused me to thing in new ways. I enjoyed/enjoy my physics classes because they are challenging and cause me to think in new ways.

I have always been very interested in math. I was especially drawn to physics because of its use of mathematics. In middle school I had a very good physics teacher. I also very much enjoyed reading A Brief History of Time by Stephen Hawking in High School.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Media Triggered

Response: I first became interested in physics when I was in 8th grade when I began reading about the potential of life on other planets. From there"," I started reading about space"," which eventually lead to me reading about physics in my spare time and falling in love with it. By the time I was in 10th  grade"," I knew for sure that I wanted to major in physics when I got to college. I took all of the physics classes at my high school and did a small research project at a nearby university. Once I got to Yale"," I declared my major in physics. The summer after freshman year"," I did research at Fermilab"," which confirmed for me that I was in the right major. This year and this coming summer"," I will continue research at Fermiab (remotely from Yale during the school year and on-site in the summer). Then"," in my junior year and the following summer"," I will remotely do ATLAS research from Yale during the school year and will travel to CERN for the summer. Although it can be hard to succeed in physics classes and it is easy to acquire a serious case of impostor syndrome"," I know that at the end of the day"," I can`t picture myself doing anything else"," and I know I am in the right place pursuing the right things.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Event Triggered, Cost (Emotional)

Response: I never thought that I could study physics. I took a physics course for physicsmajors by accident my freshman fall of college. It was really difficult for meand I had a really hard time finding people to work with"," but by the endI realized I really loved physics. I was very encouraged by getting a good grade in my introductory course"," even though I felt like I didn`t deserve it.I didn`t feel like I would belong in the physics community unless I was very successful. I think physics has very little tolerance for women who arenot at the top of their class.

I have always loved science. Physics and Mathematics being the two fundamental building blocks to the universe"," the answer behind every why and how"," have excited me throughout my life. I think in numbers and pictures"," conceptualizing and devouring knowledge. Physics"," thus"," has always appealed to me immensely.

I started college as an accounting major. Mostly because my parents wanted me to do so. My parents didn`t have faith in me to do much more and I had always been convinced Math was hard. I met an instructor who changed the world for me. After a conversation about how I didn`t belong in such a low level class he asked me: "What do you think is the hardest thing in the world to do? to which my response was

Initially I remember first thinking about space as a kid and just being amazed at how crazy of an idea it was but also at how beautiful things looked in the night sky or through a telescope. I fell in love with astronomy and space and it helped that my dad"," who studied microbiology in college"," was always interested in cool science topics. My mom also is an industrial engineer so her interest in physics and understanding how physical systems worked was something I had as well. I can remember being good at math and science my entire life all the way through high school"," and I loved all of it. It wasnÕt really until college when I felt challenged trying to learn calculus"," but now that IÕve taken over two years of it"," I see the beauty and the way the puzzle pieces fit together in a sense. IÕve also always been interested in crazy logical/science concepts; I can remember my momÕs Dad asking me math riddles and little logic puzzles as a young kid"," and loving the challenge of finding the answer and seeing the full picture. IÕve always loved these topics and concepts"," and continued to throughout high school"," until that time when you start to think about what to study in college. Even before that though I can remember dreaming of being a professor (I dreamed of being a lot of different things though...)"," but even though planned to study physics in college"," I didnÕt really think that being a professor was really possible for me. IÕm not sure what it was that made me doubt myself like that"," but all I really knew was that it takes a lot of time to get a PhD and become a professor"," and I didnÕt know if I could actually DO it. But now IÕm a junior"," IÕm in my first ÒrealÓ quarter of physics"," and IÕm working the hardest I ever have"," I tutor"," AND grad school actually seems plausible now.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: I really like physics and I enjoy thinking about questions of our universe. I was encouraged by my teachers and professors to go on be a physics major if I want to.

I have always had the desire to become a teacher"," but I haven`t always been exactly sure what I wanted to teach.During my senior year of High school I took physics"," and I was drawn into the subject due to my teacher`s enthusiasm for the content. It was then that I decided I would teach Physics. Although Physics is difficult for me to grasp at times"," I receive extreme enjoyment when I finally understand a concept"," or reach the correct solution for a problem. The enjoyment I receive from these experiences is so extreme that I want to share it with future students"," whether they are interest in science as a career or not. It is because of my struggles that I feel I can relate to students. Throughout my education I have tried to foster a growth mindset"," and this is one characteristics I would like to pass on to my future students.

In high school I knew I was interested in science and I did well in my physics classes in both my junior and senior year. I took AP Physics C and got a 4 on E&M and 5 on Kinematics"," so when I got into college I was able to advance quickly into higher level classes. I found that physics was the science that Iunderstood the least and didn`t know the most in"," so I wantedto pursue it and learn how the world works. My brother is alsostudying to be an engineer which has had influence on me because he thought physics was interesting"," so I started paying attention to it more and now I think so too. The biggest factor may be because my best friend in high school`s older sister was a physics major at Wellesley College and I thought"," if she can do it I can do it too!
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience

Response: I have always being interested in learning about space and science overall. Once I became a senior in high school"," I knew that studying physics could teach me more about space. I would like to work for an aerospace company in the future so I believe getting a degree in physics can help me achieve so. Another reason why I went into the physics field is to inspire more women to join too.

I became interested in physics by taking physics classes in my junior and senior years of high school. I thought solving the problems was fun. In one class"," we read Feynman`s QED"," which really sparked my interest in physics as a field (rather than just a source of fun problems). When I came to college"," I found that the physics department at my college was very warm and welcoming"," which made me want to be a physics major even more.

When I first started high school"," I didn`t really realize that majoring in physics/astronomy was an option that I can actually pursue"," but I always had an interest in physics topics. When I found out that majoring in physics was an option for me"," I decided to study physics in college. I read more about it on my own and realized that I wanted to learn more.

Growing up"," I never believed I was smart enough to become a science major. But I had always loved science and was envious of those to whom math came easily. Long story short"," I lost someone very close to me in high school which made me realize that life is too short to not take risks and do something you love. So I decided to study physics upon entering college. It took some convincing for my parents"," but they have always supported me. I may not be a genius"," but I am willing to work hard in the pursuit of what I enjoy doing. Although there are days I wonder if another major would have been easier"," I have never regretted the decision of studying physics. I love it"," and although it is hard"," it is worth it. Now I am a junior doing my capstone projectmodeling and building a laser for a mission with a team at NASA. I would call that","for where I am in my career"," success and am looking forward to being part of the physics community for a long time to come.

I was first inspired to pursue physics under my high school physics teacher. His love for the subject was infectious"," and I soon began to consider if I myself would be able to become a physics educator in the future. Furthermore"," his skill and passion for teaching were revolutionary for me"," and led me to wish to pursue a career as a physics educator.Though I originally wanted to be a college professor"," over time"," that dream morphed into following in my old teacher`s footsteps"," and becoming a high school teacher like him. Currently"," that is the goal I am striving towards.

It was not until sophomore year of college that I started to enjoy physics. My professor made the class very interesting and the math used in this level of physics made things appear simpler. As I got further into my major"," I was very interested in how physics played into the role of chemistry. The math got more complicated and that made it more interesting to me.

September 6"," 2018 - "The LHC era: Protons and New Physics" Dep. of Physics colloquium talk by Dr. Marco Guzzi"," @KSUSeptember 11"," 2018 Ð ÒKSU Money Wise Series: Budgeting 101Ó session"," @KSUSeptember 14"," 2018 - " The Puzzling Nanoscale Piezoelectric WorldÓ talk by Dr. Yuri Barnakov"," @KSUSeptember 15"," 2018 - ÒWomen in Physics SocialÓ hosted by Kennesaw Ladies in Physics"," @KSUOctober 3"," 2018 Ð ÒCyber Security DayÓ session"," @KSU

I just really enjoyed physics and the different type of thinking that went into problem solving. I had an Physics teacher in high school that encouraged me to take AP my senior year. This is when I truly fell in love with physics and decided to pursue it as a major in college. At college everyone was super supportive of my passion and even though I might not be great at it sometimes"," there is always help available.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social), Cost (Task Effort), Physiological/Emotional

Response: It all started with me enrolling into high school physics on a whim of curiosity. I noticed that I was more interested and curious about physics than my peers. The AP physics teacher at my high school saw me teaching tension to another student and recommended that I take her class. The next  year"," I did and despite all of the hard work I had to do to understand concepts and do labs"," I enjoyed every minute of the challenges; something I had never witnessed in any other subject. I cannot leave out how the movie Hidden Figures helped me realize that physics as a career option for me as an African American woman was more than attainable.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Physiological/Emotional

Response: I was first introduced to physics in high school"," where I had the opportunity to be involved in the Physics/Astronomy related clubs. I was also able to work/volunteer in a planetarium where the planetarium director and astronomy teacher both encouraged me to pursue a career in the sciences. It was my high school physics teacher"," who was the first female science teacher I had had"," that made me realize that I could be a physicist and then guided me towards the physics major I am pursuing in college now. In college"," I am constantly being reminded that the physics department is the place for me. From running experiments in the lab"," to building a sense of community with my fellow physics students (and professors)"," I am always experiencing moments that make me think that I could do this for the rest of my life.
Codes: Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: My initial interest in Physics was triggered by "pop-science". In my experience this response is rather common. However"," I personally ended up sticking with my Physics major because I really enjoyed the challenge that it offered. Additionally"," I was unsure what I wanted to do post-graduation and I felt Physics would be one of the more flexible degrees as it teaches a wide variety of skillsets.
I had great middle school and high school teachers that encouraged me to ask questions and pursue physics.

My parents have always allowed my sister and I the opportunities to explore"," ask questions"," and be creative. This"," along with being influenced by media such as Carl Sagan"," the "Walking With..." BBC series"," and Animal Planet"," fostered a curiosity of the natural world. Then"," I realized I loved physics while being in the course my junior year of high school. Senior year I was in AP Biology"," which gave way to my interest in biophysics and astrobiology.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value

Response: I have many academic interests and have changed my major several times. I first became interested in physics when taking engineering courses. However"," due to family opinions I did not choose it at that time. I choose to study art and psychology but continued to read and learn about new physics topics in my free time. After coming out as LGBTQ to my family I realized that I needed to follow an educational path that I was interested in"," not one that they had chosen for me. Due to taking unrelated classes I am now behind where a typical third year student would be and may have to spend extra time completing courses. I enjoy physics because it is challenging and there are so many opportunities for new discovery.

I generally like to learn challenging topics"," and took an interest to physics when I took it my junior year of high school. I began to read more about the subject"," which only increased my interest"," so I decided to major it it.

I have always been good at math and enjoy doing math. When I got to college I couldn`t decide between math or physics as a major. I eventually decided to do physics because it is more applied mathematics and I enjoy learning about how the world works.

During my early years I was implicitly discouraged from pursuing a STEM path academically. As a post baccalaureate student"," I have returned to academics and discovered a love for mathematics and how it is applied in STEM fields"," specifically Image Processing as it relates to Computer Science"," number theory as it relates to Gaming"," Linear Algebra as it relates to Computer Science"," Electrical Engineering and Physics. I decided to take University Physics instead of College Physics although my experience in High School with the subject  matter had not been  a great one. I fell in  love with the subject; especially Physics II. I am very interested in Optics"," conducted research and attended a SPIE Conference"," having the opportunity to present my work. Optics ties all the aspects that I love about the previously mentioned subject matter. I hope I will have the opportunity to research"," teach and write about this very interesting are of academics in the future.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Optics), Event Triggered

Response: IÕm a geology major with a physics minor. IÕve been involved with a lot of club activities and met some cool students in the physics department and took a few intro level physics classes for the geology major. I also took some interesting geophysics classes"," but our school doesnÕt offer a geophysics specialization so I signed up for the physics minor.

Initially"," I had planned on studying Mechanical Engineering"," but after becoming an AVID tutor for my old high school I learned that I really enjoy teaching and talking about physics. I also noticed how much of an issue creating an inclusive environment for women and minorities are"," especially in low-socioeconomical neighborhoods. This is my main motivation to become a physics teacher. I want to help change that.

I started my love for physics by trying to teach it to myself between my sophomore and junior year of high school. I had an amazing physics teacher my junior year who encouraged me to pursue engineering. I went back and forth between electrical engineering and physics until I got near the end of my senior year of high school. I talked to some engineers and decided I was more interested in research than industrial applications of physics. I have since been very passionate about physics. I entered college unsure of which area of physics I was interested in"," but I have since participated in condensed matter research. I am most interested in soft matter and condensed matter physics for graduate school.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered

Response: At the age of 30 my friend asked me to relearn calculus to help him with an interesting physics question. That process was utterly enjoyable. I started taking physics classes and am now redoing my bachelors in physics. my previous degree was in child psychology.

I`ve always been curious about how things work and I asked many questions as a child. I`ve loved math since elementary school"," but I enjoyed my high school physics class even more. It was only an honors course so I knew I didn`t want to decide about pursuing physics until I had taken more challenging classes. I didn`t enjoy my first physics professor very much"," but I thought the material was interesting and I wanted to delve into it further. However"," I`ve talked to many other professors in my physics department"," and they have been very helpful when I asked them questions about the field. Additionally"," the professor I am currently doing research with has been very encouraging. Now that I have been exposed to more physics"," I can`t picture myself choosing another path. I`m excited about going to my classes each day"," and I love the challenging coursework.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Attainment Value, Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion

Response: My high school astronomy course was what really made me realize that I wanted to pursue astrophysics
My grandfather and uncle are physicists.

Initially"," I was a communications major but was becoming more interested in mathematics throughout my schooling. I spoke to one of my closest teachers"," and he advised me to go and meet with the physics professors"," because of my personality and interests. Rather than send me on my way to pursue a math degree like I thought he would"," instead I realized that he knew what would be good for me personally and academically so I went to talk to one of the physics professors. He made sure I was really thinking about this decision all the way through and asked me to go to an introductory course for a few weeks and really feel it out.I loved it"," although I knew very little about the topic. Since starting physics"," I have learned so many different things and even if I`m still a bit behind everyone else in my classes"," I am really trying and putting forth my best effort because I truly want to succeed and progress.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Task Effort)

Response: I watched a show on the History Channel called "The Universe with my father. It got me interested in physics for the first time

Other than the fact that physics seems to be in my blood as my grandfather was a professor of physics"," I found this path trying to figure out my major. I knew that I wanted to do something related to the empirical sciences"," but after narrowing the options I found that physics alone was left. After pondering it"," I realized that it was my interest all along"," specifically astrophysics. I have always had a sort of awe and curiosity about the sky and I see Astrophysics as a path to explore the possibilities of the beyond as well as why it functions the way it does. I have since found an interest in theoretical physics as well. I believe I am still in an exploratory phase"," so I haven`t ruled anything out"," but I do certainly see certain topics rising to the top. As I continue"," I hope to find the topic or course that truly fuels my passion.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Intrinsic Value

Response: In high school I was interested in bio until I took the AP course and didn`t like it at all. I took my first physics class the next year. I didn`t do well at first"," but after one marking period I was at the top of the class. I applied to colleges as a computer science major"," but by the end of high school I knew I wanted to be a physics major.

My high school did not offer any physics courses"," and I started college in an unrelated major. After taking an astronomy class and a physics class (and loving them and the teacher)"," I transferred schools to one with a better physics program and changed my major to physics. I disliked and was average at math and science in high school (and like I mentioned"," my school did not have a lot of either)"," but good experiences with these classes early in college made physics and math options for my major/future career.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Cost (Task Effort), Utility Value

Response: Throughout high school"," I was always very good at math and I really understood numbers. I knew I wanted a career that used math but in a more interesting way. My Junior year of high school"," I took my first physics class and found it to be very interesting. I have also always been fascinated by the mysteries of space so I decided to use physics to combine math and astronomy. Physics is a perfect major for me because it allows me to use calculations and analysis to study astronomical events.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Intrinsic Value

Response: I watched physics youtube videos in high school like veritasium"," minutephysics"," and physics girl. and their videos were interesting and I decided I wanted to do physics. My high school chemistry"," physics"," and calculus teachers were a significant inspiration to me as well to choose physics. I spent a lot of time in high school learning physics stuff on the internet too.

I have always been very interested in math and science"," so in high school"," physics seemed to be a logical class to take. I took AP Physics 1&2 my junior year"," and loved my teacher"," and the subject so I took AP Physics C E&M and Mechanics my senior year. During this course I decided that I wanted to pursue physics in college. I went into college knowing that I wanted to do physics and/or engineering"," and have followed both paths thus far.

Throughout high school I hated physics"," well the theoritical part of it bacause I just wouldn`t get it. I always seem to love the practical part of physics"," I always loved to construct or repair things"," to make different models or just to make things work"," most of the times through try and error. Then one day"," three years ago"," I came accross a lecture of Walter Lewin on Youtube and I fell in love with physics. That was it"," I decided that physics is what I want to do for the rest of my life!

I`ve always enjoyed and done well in physics courses but have never seen myself as a physicist.  When I got to college"," I took physics on a whim but assumed I`d drop it soon since I wouldn`t be good enough.  My second year"," I did quite well in (and sort of perversely enjoyed) an introductory math methods for physics course accidentally taught at a near-graduate level.  This gave me the confidence I needed to declare the major.

I began college with the endeavor to be a chemical engineer and transfer to another university. I quickly found out that engineering wasn`t for me. After coming to this realization I decided to study chemistry which I also eventually found was not my cup of tea. I then thought about pursuing an English degree"," but I couldn`t imagine myself in a career that wasn`t in science.I ended up taking a semester off afterwards and signed up for this Women in Physics conference from a friend"," who had just decided to pursue her degree in Physics"," and absolutely enjoyed the experience. I have always been in love with astrophysics and chemistry (which i eventually realized what quantum mechanics) but I had never thought of physics as a real option as a career. I had an extremely dull and mind numbing experience in my high school physics class which did not help my attitude toward the study of physics. It was actually my Chemistry professor and his AP class that established a true love for science; he taught hybridization very well and his passion for his life study of chemistry was infectious. His class demonstrated how accessible and riveting science was. It was this chemistry class that actually deepened my passion for physics So"," with this revelation of what I was actually wanted to do with my college career (and future career) I set off to pursue Physics. I will now be graduating in the summer of 2015 and"," after taking a year off"," plan on going after a graduate degree (most likely a PhD). I would eventually like to work for NASA.
Codes: Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Cost (Emotional), Utility Value

Response: I have always been interested in physics - ever since I was in grade school. My mother got me a lecture cd from Harvard University on quantum mechanics and the discovery of muons and other related modern physics topics. I was hooked on the idea of studying physics ever since. Throughout high school and the beginning of college I strayed from actively following physics and pursued different topics. I struggled a great deal throughout my first few years of college trying to find some direction and was overall unhappy with the courses I was taking. I decided to switch to a physics major since it was a topic I had always been interested in. I had a lot of catching up to do but I`m glad I made the change and I certainly feel more comfortable as a physics major than a biology major but it`s been a rather circuitous route to get here.

I have always been interested in physics, in how the world works. I wanted to find out why things happen and why things exist the way they do from a very young age. I used to watch NOVA and just marvel about everything. Honestly, I never thought physics wasn`t an option. By the time that I realized that physics as a career had everything I wanted, I was set. I did move around a bit on what type of physics I wanted to go into (I wanted to be a string theorist for a while, but now I`m set on astrophysics), but never actually wavered on the physics part. I took high school physics, and I loved it. There weren`t really any other options for me -- I love physics, and that`s all there is to it.

The urge to know and understand how nature works, why things happen a certain way, and a love for learning and passion for physics and astronomy led me to choose Astrophysics as my major. My parents developed and encouraged a love for reading in me from a very young age. They gave me the freedom to explore any and all fields that I found interesting. I was barely three when my father demonstrated the occurrences of eclipses to me using a candle and rubber balls. I was fascinated right there and then. In school, I discoveredmy interest and aptitude for physics, problem-solving, astronomy and my eagerness to explore unanswered questions in these fields. I watched a lot of scientific documentaries and attended lectures by scientists, each of which strengthened my passion for science, and astrophysics in particular. I joined an amateur astronomy club in my city-the oldest in India-and was instantly a member of a group of astronomy-enthusiasts who shared the same level of passion for science and astronomy and physics as I.There, I truly realized that this was what I wanted to do for the rest of my life. On coming to college, I began assisting a professor in research, basically just downloading images and processing them, but that too, strengthened my passion for astrophysics. I feel at home in the astronomy-lab, with all the books, the periodicals, the others conducting their own research, the atmosphere is filled with science, physics and astrophysics and that increases my enthusiasm for the subject.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered, intrinsic (Social)

Response: I started volunteering at an observatory after becoming interested in physics and fell in love with it since then.

For many years, I struggled to establish my cultural identity. Having lived in Russia for thirteen years as an American kid, I learned to embrace a new culture as if it were my own. Not long after returning to the United States, I was off to college with little knowledge of how American society functioned on a social level. However, one topic I found that I could always discuss without any queer or confused looks fromothers was science. Math and physics seem to cross the language and cultural barrier with little to no change. Immersing myself in academics, I realized that physics was the best way I could make a contribution in society. My dream of working with scientists all over the globe slowly became a reality as I step foot on campus. Prior to arriving as a freshman at Georgia College and State University, I received acceptance into the Honors Program and joined Eta Sigma Alpha Honor Society to take advantage of all the extracurricular and study abroad opportunities that I knew were to come. On the first day of college classes, I walked up to my first physics professor Dr. Ralph France to introduce myself and was thrilled to find he was in charge of the nuclear astrophysics sector of the department. In the spring semester of 2013, I received a Physics Scholar Award as his new research student. I still hold a leadership position on his research team as we construct a portable electrostatic ion accelerator.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I always loved school and I was placed into a fast-paced math track starting in elementary school because I found it very easy and fun. Growing up, my family always watched NOVA shows as well as Cosmos. I still watch shows like that on the Discovery Channel to this day. I believe the shows are what caused my initial interest in science and how things work. In terms of school, though, I was mainly interested in math with a vague interest in science in general until sophomore year when I took the required physics course. I found it pretty interesting, and I was ahead in school because of being on the fast-paced track, so I was able to take an AP science class my Junior year. I chose AP Physics (Mechanics and E&M). I found it pretty fun and interesting and I had an amazing teacher (he runs a program teaching other high school teachers how to teach science). However, the thing that sealed the deal for me in terms of wanting to become an astrophysicist was one lecture first semester during Mechanics. We had already found equations for centripetal motion, and my teacher used those equations to tell us about Kepler`s Laws. I was interested in space before this, but I hadn`t specifically known Kepler`s Laws. This lecture blew my mind, that you could use just a few simple equations in physics to explain the motion of our solar system. That was the day I decided I would become an astrophysicist.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered

Response: Have always been interested in Physics since young and had an amazing high school physics experience. I would love to learn more about how the world works.

Public education was inadequate, and my academic placement as a senior in high school was purely accidental-- AP Physics was the only science course open. Despite the poor planning by part of my counselors at that time, it allowed me to immerse myself in a subject I would otherwise never have been exposed to. My sparked interest in Physics allowed me to delve into Mathematics, which complimented eachother. Since then, my pursuit in Physics and Mathematics has opened up opportunities and has expanded my intellectual horizons. Our only limit is poor access to education and resources.

For a long time in high school i wanted to go to school for physical therapy, however my junior year of high school that changed. I took physics, the only one offered at my school, and I guess one couold say fell in love with it. I just really enjoyed how it applies to everyday life.In high school, and still today I am a very visual learner, and in physics a lot of times you can draw out exactly what is happening, and that really helps me understandthe material and how to interpret it. How I chose to become a Physics Astronomy major is more blurry for me however, I am not sure when i clearly decided that. But I know thatfor me space and the universe has always been an interest. So I just decided, why not put two subjects I love together and make a career out of it.

I started college as an undergraduate who was undeclared. I knew I had a passion for science and math and everything in between, but I knew I did not want to pursue a science like biology or chemistry. I`ve been ecstatic about astronomy since I was in high school and fell for physics when I saw my math skills being used for science, discovery, and critical thinking.

I`ve been interested in physics since I was a young girl, since my mom was a physics major and introduced me to a lot of books and television programs about physics. In high school, my interest in math and physics solidified. Once I came to Harvey Mudd, I found that I enjoyed my physics classes the most, and so I made the decision to be a physics major.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered

Response: In high school, I was not given the opportunity to study physics in depth (only a 3 week summer course). Growing up I was always interested in space and being an astronaut and I knew I liked the sciences (specifically chemistry and math) so I just thought I would also like physics and decided to double major in it in college to help me on my path to being an astrophysicist. Shows like the Big Bang Theory fantasized these ideas, but coming to college I realized physics is extremely difficult and I`m not sure if I can see a future in it/ if I can get into and make it into graduate school.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Cost (Task Effort), Intrinsic Value

Response: It was in a geology class I took 5 years ago that I grasped the concept of just how incredibly vast is the universe. Realizing that our solar system is merely one of umpteen possible solar systems really opened my eyes and reeled me in to learn more about the physics of the universe in which we live. I wanted to learn all I could about the way things work - I always have, and I always will. I`ll never stop asking "Why? and demanding an answer

I have wanted to learn more about astronomy since I was a little kid, when my dad took my brothers and I out to the backyard with an old telescope and pointed it at the planets. As I went through school, I figured out that math came naturally to me, and eventually even learned to like it. A terrible illness surfaced in high school and kept me from going to class for long periods, and I had to work closely with teachers to graduate. In this time, I was able to work one on one with my calculus and physics teachers, and go more in depth into the things that interested me.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Cost (Outside Effort)

Response: I have always been fascinated by astronomy so it has always been me trying to figure out the best way to pursue that. I had tried engineering for a time, before I was able to take physics in high school, but even though my engineering classes were fun I quickly learned that was not for me. I was then able to take physics and discovered that most astronomers started out with a physics or math degree so I stuck on that path and it has worked really well for me thus far.

I took two STEM classes in high school and I attended a Women`s in Engineering Day at the Westinghouse in Pennsylvania. My aunt is a civil engineer and she has had a big influence in me choosing a career in the engineering/physics field.

The first encounter I had with physics came from a book named the elegant universe by Brian Greene. This book contained all of the major contributions made in physics in the last few centuries. What stuck with me was the information provided on EinsteinÕs work. Both special and general relativity just baffled me. Shortly after reading the book I found myself gravitating towards researching new concepts in physics. After a few months of doing so, I ultimately made the decision to study physics with the hopes of one day receiving a noble prize.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I have always been interested in riddles and mystery, and space is a place of great mystery. As a very inquisitive person, I am drawn to the cosmos and want to study it. I am a very science and math inclined person and majoring in physics just made sense.
I have always been interested in pursuing astronomy, especially as my father is an aerospace engineer. I knew that my university had a very good astronomy program which involves many physics classes.

I have always been interested in how things work and why the world is the way it is. Before declaring my major, I had never taken a physics class. (My high school didn`t offer it.) I wanted to learn why things happen and i wanted to spend my life making meaningful discoveries so i decided to major in physics so i could answer all of my own questions about the universe.

Growing up as a kid I always had a specific affinity to mathematics, and a specific aversion to all subjects where I had to memorize. Being introduced to physics as a field of study in high school allowed me to use mathematics to study my surroundings. I found myself learning more and more without having to memorize any passages or definitions; the science was self-sufficient, intelligent. During that time in high school, one of my physics teachers told me this: "You are now barely learning A, B, C in your physics alphabet", and I hold that with me everyday. There is always more to learn in physics - which is why I participate in research today, and why I want to work in academia and research in the future.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Event Triggered, Social Persuasion, Attainment Value

Response: My sixth-grade math teacher, before teaching she had been an engineer. My first memories of enjoying math were in her class. I remember thinking "If I had a career in the future with math, I would love it." My teacher at the time definitely changed my perspective on math and made it into something I love. Now my freshman year in high school I took my very first physics class. Again the teacher I had made physics a fascinating and easy to understand topic. Not to mention it had math involved. Probably one of the most memorable classes I took in High School. I really felt like the teachers I had that were passionate about what they did help me grow my passion and fascination for math and science. I have learned that I am someone that loves solving puzzles and that how I see math and science. It`s about solving issues. I want to become an engineer in hopes to help my community in solving real-life "puzzles".
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: I was organically was a Chemistry major, physics wasa require course to take. Once I took intro to physics 4AI was hook.

I originally was a math major and considering a physics minor but everyone in the physics department was so friendly and they had a welcome back barbecue which showed what a tight-knit community the department is at Loyola.

I was required to take honors physics in high school, and from there I was able to take AP Physics 1, AP Physics C, and a college level waves and modern physics course. My physics teachers were encouraging and enthusiastic about my interest in physics, and prompted me to look into summer programs and schools with promising physics programs. After starting at WPI, I`ve been lucky enough to work with amazing faculty members that inspire me to pursue undergrad research opportunities and challenge myself in my coursework.

I always enjoyed the sciences growing up, and in high school, I had a great physics teacher. She really brought enjoyment for the subject into the class. Just before entering my senior year, I thought about the applications of physics and the universe through a conversation with my family about the universe. I knew I wanted to get involved in something that had a big field of opportunity to discover more. I came into this major wanting to be a part of that, and be at the forefront of making these big new discoveries, to help others understand and learn.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I decided to become a physics major when I saw how perfectly an experiment in high school physics worked out. Since then, my interest has been fueled by the constant excitement about leaning how things work and why things are certain ways.

I started community college intending on majoring inpsychology. I was disinterested in every class I took until I enrolled in an astronomy course to satisfythe iGETC physical science requirement. Although, I wasnot a great/focused student at the time, the class really intrigued me. It was when I started buyingastronomy books and reading articles on my own, outsideof class, that I realized that this is what I wanted to continue to study and learn about for the rest of mylife. After that at Santa Barbara City College I took my first physics course with Dr. Young and loved thecourse just as much as astronomy. It was Dr. Young who suggested to me to major in astrophysics. I had alwaysbeen ahead of my peers in math, even in high school. It seemed that physics just fit in naturally with my constant questioning of how anything/everything worksand my math skills.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience

Response: Initially I believed I wanted to do engineering, so I took a physics course in high school. I really enjoyed it and began to question whether I wanted to do engineering or physics. Even though I really enjoyed physics, I quickly realized that I wasn`t doing as well as my peers. I started to dedicate more time to my assignments and studying and I eventually began to see better progress. It was still very discouraging because I was putting in 2 or 3 times the work for the same grade as my peers. I decided to stick with it when I applied to college. There is an introductory course offered at my institution so I was then going to gauge how I felt about the major. I realized that this was exactly what I wanted to do and that no other career/ major seemed right for me. The biggest influences in my choices were my high school physics teacher, with whom I became very close with, the introductory course, and the professor who taught the introductory course.
HAd to choose a topic to write about for English1010 paper. Chose Aliens. Decided i want to be able to discover the probability of their being intelligent life within our universe

I didn`t really consider myself a scientist until late high school, but I was always one of the best in my class in math, and was interested in it. My physics classes showed a new perspective that felt more true and interesting than any previous science classes. I did not initially feel comfortable or able to understand the material well in my high school physics classes, and did poorly at first, but I got extra help and quickly became one of the best in the class. Then I started considering physics more seriously. I particularly liked the physics community, especially the women in it, and it was sad that there weren`t many. In undergrad, it was hard to connect to the physics department, but events like attending my first CUWiP sophomore year and attending an REU with majority women helped me gain a lot of confidence both socially and in my ability to do research and be competitive. Since then I`ve become a leader in the physics department of my home institution, and feel very fulfilled by this. I am applying to physics grad school and look forward to a lifetime engaging with hard physics problems with the physics community.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic (Social), Event Triggered, Physiological/Emotional

Response: I came into my undergraduate program unsure of what I wanted to do so I decided to study physics and art. I enjoyed my honors physics course in high school so decided to continue my studies at New College. I didn`t really know what I wanted to do with physics but I often found myself reading articles on astrophysics-related discoveries. And one night, while I was out watching the stars, my future hit me. I asked a friend of mine what he thought of astrophysics and he discouraged me from pursuing it. But as my first year of college came to an end, I watched my physics I lab TA defend her thesis on machine learning used to identify type ia supernova and subsequently calculate the acceleration of the expansion of the universe. That baccalaureate exam showed me that woman are much more capable than I had been led to believe growing up. I continued to delve deeper and deeper into my readings on astrophysics and astronomy, and discovered that it was more enjoyable to me than anything else I had ever studied.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered

Response: I always liked science and engineering since childhood. I liked buildings things when I was little and science was always my favorite subject. I really became interested in physics in high school when I took my first physics class. I really like my physics teacher and the subject itself. I took a second physics class in high school that was much more hands-on. I like the engineering aspect of it and had considered studying engineering in college. However, when I reached college, I wasn???t sure what type of engineering I liked or if I wanted to even commit to engineer. I decided on physics to keep my options open.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Utility Value

Response: I have always been interested in science (though I wasn`t aware if it; really, I should have seen physics coming) and my father always encouraged me. When I took physics in high school, I loved it so much I took it again at the AP level the next year. After that, I knew I would major in physics. I have been taking classes for years, and though I have always been sure of physics, I have never been very sure of myself or my future career. Currently I want to be a middle school science teacher.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: being fascinated by space since I was a child

I`ve been good at physics ever since I started learning it. I feel that physics is a really powerful tool to understand the world. I feel enlightened every time I learn a new concept, and I like to be challenged as I gain a more holistic and profound understanding of the universe. I choose to be a physics major as I`m sure that I will regret it if I don`t pursue physics.
Rebecca Welch helped me in seeing the beauty of physics by telling me about her glass research

I debated between computer science, mathematics, and physics when declaring a major while enrolling in university. I didn`t have a particular interest in anything (still don`t, really). Physics is the least boring of the three (which is a lie; I am much more competent at computer science, and I don`t know why I`m in physics in the first place).I decided to stick with physics since it`s a lot less popular. It`s also more impressive to say that you`re a physics major. I`m also not too terrible at it. I`m not the best but that`s what school is for.It`s pretty vain.
Codes: Utility Value, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: An introductory physics course integrated with chemistry and biology showed me that there are varying types of physics outside of purely classical mechanics. The community from that class encouraged me to move forward in other varying physics classes.

I feel in love with physics my senior year in high school. I had such an amazing teacher that truly believed in me and shared his love of the field with me. After a month of that class I knew physics was the field for me.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: I always felt that working in this field is a beautiful way to spend a life. When I was little my parents let me stay up late to watch NOVA, and I loved the ones on physics (it was great to realize how much we still donÕt know).I hadnÕt believed that it was an option for me to peruse it as a career until relatively recently. IÕm actually still not sure if I am capable of it intellectually.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Cost (Task Effort), Physiological/Emotional

Response: I enjoyed mathematics and science-related courses in high school, and I knew I wanted to be a secondary education teacher.  However, I needed to pick a subject for my focus, and after taking physics in high school, I realized that it was something I genuinely enjoyed.  One day, after class, my physics professor spoke to me and told me I should consider going to TCNJ and applying for the Noyce scholarship, because he felt that physics came naturally to me and that I was genuinely interested in the subject.  So, I applied to TCNJ and decided to major in physics, and I was very pleased with my decision after being welcomed into the department.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I decided to be a physics major because when i was considering different majors the physics classes were the ones I was most interested in.

Sitting in my third grade classroom being presented to the solar system was the biggest factor that pushed me into becoming a physics major. My interest in science has always been prevalent compared to other courses. However, space exploration has always been number one in my book.

The first time I was exposed to physics was the summer after my freshman year of college. I took a summer course in basic physics and the concurrent lab. I really enjoyed the class and wanted to pursue it further. I have been taking physics classes ever since. What influenced me the most was the fact that it was unlike any subject I had seen before. The way it explains the world is similar to the way I view the world. Math has always been one of my favorite subjects but I had never considered pursuing anything math related because I was encouraged to do more "female related things. Once I found physics I realized that I could be a part of that field despite the fact that I had never been encouraged to do so. Once I decided this I spoke to the professor that taught my summer physics class and he was very happy to hear that I was interested in pursuing a physics degree. Since then I have met a lot of people who also enjoy physics and help encourage me to go further in this field."
Codes: Event Triggered, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Emotional), Social Persuasion

Response: I took physics in high school and was always fascinated with the subject. During an independent study in high school, I looked to combine physics and music (as I play the violin) and wanted to pursue both, so I am now pursuing a degree in both Physics as well as Music.

loved space and the idea of learning about the inner workings of our universe. hated math for the longest time and so never saw myself as a physicist until a few years ago when i decided i could deal with math if it meant learning about the universe. now i love math and want to be an astrophysics prof.

It was shortly after my first group project on microbial fuel cells that I realized I wanted to be a physics major. I`ve always wanted to work in sustainability to some extent but I didn`t really realize that renewable energy was my path until that project.

I was fascinated by a Chinese legend about the creation of the world (that it evolved from a person- his eyes became the sun and the moon, his hair became the trees etc) as a kid (before grade school).Both of my parents have PhD degrees in STEM and I have always been encouraged to pursue my interests in physics (since before grade school).In middle school, I read an article on the Scientific American about the LHC. It also talked about the standard model and I was sooooooo amazed- there are people working to understand the fundamental elements of the universe!! In high school, I was "the physics gal in my year (in a positive manner- I was one of the cool kids)During my first 2 years in college
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Attainment Value

Response: I`ve been interested in science for as long as I can remember, but freshman physics in high school was the first time when I became truly interested in physics. Calc-based physics senior year furthered that. I`ve loved every physics course in college thus far, and I really enjoy doing the problem sets (particularly for modern physics). I enjoy learning the material and actually understanding the concepts.
I took the class in highshool and it was very interesting, I did more research and it was just th best. I love physics!

I first wanted to become a physics major in high school when one of my friends had a project about the end of the world (I know that seems silly). Her part of the project was to take the scientific approach, and she ended up researching about collapsing wave functions. At the time neither of us really understood the idea of collapsing wave functions, but I found the idea enthralling. I proceeded to look into physics and I bought lots of physics books and lectures. In college I already had a plan to major in physics, and my first physics professor corroborated this plan because he was an amazing, brilliant man. I wanted to understand the world in the way he did, so I continued with my major.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered

Response: I really enjoyed the astronomy aspects of my high school physics classes, so I decided to major in astronomy. I also would watch SciShow Space videos on YouTube, Neil DeGrasse Tyson`s Cosmos, and read Stephen Hawking`s "A Brief History of Time." I knew physics and astronomy went hand in hand and that I would need a strong background in physics, so I decided to double major. I haven`t had the best experience in Physics, but the uWiP group at my university has been very supportive.
Codes: Media Triggered, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic (Social), Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy

Response: We used to live by a planetarium when I was little and we would go to the shows every weekend. Since then, I have always wanted to pursue astronomy/astrophysics

My grandfather was a physicist/mathematician who developed the panel method, a way to design in three dimensions. My parents both graduated from California colleges with science-related degrees(psychology and biology). In grade school, I always saw mathematics as my strongest subject, although my focus was directed more towardsmusic and photography. The more educated I became in music, the more I becamefamiliar with the way in which physics and music are related.From then on, physics was a personal interest of mine.

I realized that I wanted to study either engineering and or physics when I witness the destruction of the space shuttle challenger. This tragic event made realized how brave those astronaut were and I felt inspired how passionate they were for science even facing the odds against. As I progressed further in school I noticed that I want to study the theory behind engineering and had an interest in telescope so I grew an passion for astronomy and decided to study physics to understand engineering and astronomy concepts.

Prior to physics, I was a film student with aspirations of being a director. In fact, I never took physics in high school. Fast forward a few years after graduating from high school, I took a general physics class at my community college and it instantly stirred my curiosity about our world and led to a deep interest to study the subject. The professor I had in this course had a great impact on me. I would always stay after class and ask questions, and he was so patient in answering my questions. It made a subject matter that I thought was intimidating, to a subject matter that was approachable. After that general physics course, I realized that physics was what I wanted to study. The next quarter, I took mechanics and within a year, I finished the four physics courses needed to transfer to a 4-year institution. During that year, my professors were my greatest mentors. Even though they were incredibly busy individuals, my physics and mathematics professors really cared for their students and were invested in their success. Their doors were always open if we as students ever needed to ask questions or just to talk about different ideas in the field. I remember a math professor I had who gave me insightful advice on choosing a graduate program and applying to graduate school. This same professor allowed me to take an independent study course with him where we explored topology, a mathematics concept not usually taught at a community college. My other professors in physics allowed me to audit their courses and attend their office hours, where I was able to ask questions and also sit and learn from questions other students asked. This open dialogue, reciprocity, and encouragement that I experienced during my time at community college is the reason that I am in physics today. They were a great influence and driving factor to me seriously pursuing physics and not getting discouraged so early on in my career.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: My Physics professor in high school encouraged me initially and then I was accepted into the North Star Program my first year at UO and have received continuous encouragement and support from my physics graduate student mentor and the professor in charge of it. I completed at REU at UT Austin in Astronomy over the summer and want to go to graduate school for either Astronomy or Astrophysics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: First time i had a physics class what freshman year of highschool and I loved it. Jr year I had an intro to engineering class with my sister`s old high school physics teacher and come senior year I chose to take physics 2. I love it so much that going into college I knew I wanted to study both Physics and Engineering, so here I am.
My mother and sister are both in physics fields. I enjoyed the physics class I took in high school.

I applied to many schools with different majors and I applied to my school for physics on a whim following on of my many childhood dreams. A lot of it has to come from my obsession with outerspace and my quest to know things about the universe.
I met an engineer in the space industry and was infatuated with the work they are a part of.

My high school physics and calculus teachers encouraged me to pursue physics/engineering in college since I had a particular interest and aptitude for it. When I began taking physics and engineering courses in college I really enjoyed learning about physics, especially the problem solving aspects of the courses.

I had initially wanted to go into animation; it was suggested that I take a physics course so that I could get a better understanding on how the real world worked and how to translate that into animation. I`d never taken a physics course before since it wasn`t offered at my school. Since I had already taken calculus, I decided to go into the physics course that was designed for physics and engineering majors. The more I did in that class and my math classes, the more I started to feel that I wanted to go into physics instead of animation. I took some higher level math and hard science classes and decided that I was more interested in pursuing something in the physics field rather than something in the animation field. I decided to go into astrophysics because I`ve always had a love for stars specifically and being a physics major gave me an excellent opportunity to study them more in depth and possibly choose them as a career choice. Making good and close friends in the physics department and getting to know the faculty has solidified my decision to remain in the physics field.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I had a great professor in my intro physics class who inspired me to learn physics more.I`m interested in applications and the mechanisms behind those.
I always loved physics concepts in high school more so than any other subject so I started the physic major path for undergad.

When in high school I realized I had an interest in both math and science. Physics became an option because I realized it was applied math. I also love astronomy and realized I would eventually need physics to study the stars.

I was always curious about why and how things work. But the Tohoku earthquake in 2011 had the most impact on my life. It made me think of the future of nuclear energy, alternative energy generators and sustainable clean energy in general. It made me want to come back to school to learn about them from scratch so I could be part of that community to bridge the industry and the general public. I feel there are not enough people who can explain and communicate to the general community about the environmental risks associated with each type of power plants.
Codes: Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value
