Response: I had a really enthusiastic teacher freshman year in college when I took it on a whim. The community at my small liberal arts school is in general very supportive and pushes me.

My high school required physics for all students. I was very intimidated by it and worked very hard to understand it for fear of being lost. I realized I very much enjoyed learning the material, working on the problems, and helping my peers do well as well. When I went to college, I originally had a psychology major, because I thought a physics major would be too difficult for me. I reluctantly changed my major to physics before registering for classes freshman year and kept with the major ever since.

I never had an interest in physics (or even knew what it was) until I was 16 and had to take a physics class. I wasn`t expecting much from it, but I ended up falling in love with it and decided to go into engineering, thinking that it involved a lot more physics than it really does. I went to school as an engineering major, and in my second semester, I realized that I loved the theory and application of physics more than the designing and building of engineering. I specifically remember having a question about why gravity exists and having the burning desire to answer that question. That was when I knew that I wanted to do physics more than anything else. I have a passion for discovering why the universe works in the way that it does.

I have always been interested in physics, since I enjoy reading, and often science-fiction isn`t very far off from the truth. As I got older, I began to read more fiction, especially regarding physics as it applies to space and the world around us. I soon found that I simply didn`t have enough education to solve the problems I wanted to, and decided it was time to continue my education. At that time, I was interested in obtaining a bachelors degree, and going into the field of theoretical physics, since I often watch scientific documentaries, and have always been fascinated with unsolved phenomena. I have a desire to further our understanding of the universe as a whole, and one day make an important contribution to the scientific community. I have always dreamed of solving conundrums related to dark matter and energy, and solving a true theory of everything. I began taking beginning physics courses(non-calculus) because I just wanted to jump right in, even though I did not yet have the math skills to take advanced physics courses. Since then, I have completed almost every math course I need to continue a serious physics education, and along the way encountered computer science(in particular Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning). I am currently a Junior, and will graduate by June 2020(although I am projected to finish early at this time). I have altered my educational goals slightly to include in-depth knowledge of computer science as well, because I think AI will be a very effective tool to help further scientific research and discovery in the realm of physics. I am currently learning how to do research, as I have just been accepted into the PSU University Research Mentorship Program, and will soon conduct a research project of my own. I intend to focus on artificial intelligence and machine learning, so that when I complete my bachelors program, I can start doing research right away using the knowledge I`ve obtained through a physics grad program.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Utility Value

Response: My family has always encouraged me to follow a career in science as they saw how important it was to have more women in STEM, and that I had taken a special interest in it. I pursued science and mathematics courses throughout my childhood. I joined Academic Decathlon in high school for three years and became the captain of the team. The most fun I have had in STEM outside of school`s standardized curriculum was studying the unique science category in Academic Decathlon that changed every year based upon an overarching theme.

I enjoyed taking general Physics in high school and decided to try out the advanced placement. Though it was a lot more difficult, it just opened my eyes to the world of physics that we live in and being able to point it out in our everyday lives is wonderful. I decided from there that I wanted to pursue physics and I want to find a way to help people with it. Through an intro to science course, I found my interest in more Biomedical physics and that`s where I am headed toward right now.

After spending several years studying Fashion Design, I came to an epiphany. Even though I was relatively successful in my fashion classes, I felt a tremendous lack of satisfaction. At the moment of this realization, I was certain I would not go on with this major. My search for a field with more meaning and value started as a fire ignited within me. I began opening my mind to the world and then the possibilities, and my inspiration grew exponentially. The input that fuels the function of my consciousness shifted dramatically and I found myself in a quadrant of infinite passion where my rate of change of potential was increasing. My recollection of love for math, curiosity for outer space, and knack for doing puzzles, led me to choose a more suitable major. Watching documentaries that address the biggest questions about the universe initially caught my attention. Then doing further research on the related topics such as the theories of everything and candidates for dark matter, convinced me that I should be doing Astrophysics. It is at the frontier of human understanding and unexplained puzzles of nature where I will dedicate myself in contribution to the sciences. In a library full of tools, we find mathematics, physical observations, astronomical charts, and much more, left for our advantage by others who did this before. I believe the more we collectively understand about the universe we are inherently a part of, the easier we can adapt within it and the more fulfillment we can get out of existence.

I had a really great physics teacher in high school who encouraged me to pursue physics in college. I have always loved science and math and before coming to college I thought that I wanted to go to medical school. However, shortly after my time here at HWS, in my second semester, I was taking organic chemistry and intro level mechanics. I loved what I was learning in the courses, and I found out that I wanted to continue learning chemistry and physics beyond college and medical school was not going to get me there. I then decided to pursue chemical and biomedical engineering as a potential career.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: Growing up, I always loved to watch scientific shows with my dad, specifically about space. I would read the titles of the people who would speak on this show, and I remember reading "theoretical astrophysicist" and thinking to myself "wow, what in the world is that?" When I googled a little bit about what astrophysicists do, I felt this little spark, like it was what I wanted to do. I`d always been fascinated by space and really complex questions, such as the origin of the universe, existence, and etcetera, so it seemed like a perfect fit, especially because it combined my desire to be challenged and use my mind. So this is the path I have chosen.
My physics teacher in high school noticed that I had an innate ability for science and encouraged me to seek out a science degree.
I enjoyed physics in high school, and my lab classes as a first year in college.

I`ve always enjoyed mathematics, but I loved applying it to the world around me. Then I took physics junior year of high school. It really made you think about everything. I know I want to make a positive difference in the world and I think learning about physics could help me do that.

I did some science fair projects in high school that exposed me to physics and the scientific processes involved in physics. I enjoyed the process of working with scientific concepts combined with mathematics, and the concept that many of physics concepts are derivable from other laws and concepts. Apart from that, I`ve read books and have spoken with my parents about physics, which opened my eyes to the variety of exciting opportunities within the field.
Codes: Event Triggered, Physiological/Emotional, Media Triggered, Social Persuasion

Response: I have always loved astronomy and motion since I was little. After my AP Physics course in high school, I decided to pursue it as a career.

While in my first year of college, I really missed taking math classes and doing math. I wasn`t sure I wanted to stay in my major, which was biology. When I met Linda McDonald, the physics professor at North Park, she convinced me that physics was the way to go. Ever since then, I have beenstuck on physics and have been supported by my professors the whole way.I currently have no idea what I would like to do with my degree and that iswhy I want to go to this conference for some guidance and support.
Codes: Social Persusion, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: I took a career education course where I learned about Astrophysics.

My father received his Bachelor`s Degree in Geophysics, and he really encouraged my interest in math and science. When I took Physics in high school, my teacher really impressed me, and after we took a field trip to a university physics department, I decided I wanted to study physics.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: My interest on physics basically comes from my experiences of watching allkinds of science-fiction movies and specially a TV show named "With MorganFreeman Through The Wormhole. That TV show inspired my a lot and introducedsome basic physics ideas to me

I was really interested in space and what goes on in our universe and I wanted to learn more about the factors out there than here on earth because other degrees don`t really have meaning when looking at a large scale like space.

I read "A Brief History of Time" in high school and it opened up my eyes completely to the subject of physics even before I took the classes. I really enjoyed the way physics makes you think. It alters the way you approach problems and view the world. This passion led me to study and pursue physics in college with aspirations of becoming a physicist. As I move farther along with my physics studies and do research with my university, I have started to consider other routes physics has to offer. I am in the middle if trying to figure out the career path I want to take with my physics degree. I believe that no matter what I end up pursuing as a career, physics will be very useful beneficial.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Physiological/Emotional

Response: I took physics in high school, knowing that I wanted to do something in STEM and with an open mind. I had an exceptional teacher who made the class enjoyable, so I decided to select it as a tentative major while I took classes in college to figure out if I wanted to switch. However, once I began interacting with the physics department and my university, I fell in love with the community and inclusiveness among students and faculty. With the encouragement of my professors, I decided to keep my physics major.
A physics major is required for the kind of job that I would like to have in the future (researcher). I`ve always been passionate, since I was younger, to one day be an astrophysicist.

I toyed along with a lot of mostly fine arts options before settling on physics, because the fine arts, poetry and culinary, are things I can more easily learn on my own time, while physics requires real, good professors, experimentation and explanation. But once I got more into the physical sciences, I realized how much I love them, how beautiful they are, and how much more they are than watching a ball roll down an inclined plane. After working in research and hearing all about careers in physics, I`m happy where I am, and believe that the beauty of physics may even inspire some poems.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: Since I was a little girl I was interested in numbers, I asked questions related to how fast things moved, what happened to the Universe and so on. Despite the limitations that education in my town put me on the road, I always continued to be interested and researching by my own about physics and mathematics. Years later when I graduated from high school in Costa Rica, I had the opportunity to volunteer in a satellite project in Costa Rica (Projecto Irazð). I could observe how the scientists worked and that made me totally fall in love with what they were doing, also I convinced that I`m interested in studying physics and engineering. Two years later when I graduated from United World Colleges I decided to apply to The College of Idaho. I was accepted and now I am a freshman year studying a major in math-physics and I am really proud and happy to be part of this great community, and open to experience my career in physics.

(1) High school kinematics: math was suddenly a language for describing the real world, and I thought that was very exciting.(2) I knew I wanted to be a teacher. I chose to become a Physics teacher because I loved the subject.(3) My college advisor tried to dissuade me, saying that I would be better respected and paid as a Physics professor and researcher.(4) I had a summer research internship, and I was very grateful for the opportunity, but I was miserable working indoors with instruments.(5) I affirmed my choice to be a high school Physics teacher, and I am now heading into the final steps of certification.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Event Triggered

Response: I think I was always very interested in physics, I just never knew exactly what the subject was that had begun to peak my interest at an early age. Those specifics of what I wanted to study for the rest of my life, in fact, did not come until my senior year of high school. The way the sciences were taught to me in middle and high school first started with biology and then went to chemistry before finally tackling physics junior and senior year. This meant that when I started looking at colleges and thinking about potential career options, I had not taken any physics and thus did not consider it an option. I did however, very much like chemistry, but I was unsatisfied with something about it as I was drawn more towards the coulombic forces between particles and the driving mechanisms behind chemistry than chemistry itself. Senior year, I took AP Physics with my amazing high school teacher Mr. Levik whose enthusiasm about the subject exponentially increased my inherent enthusiasm and really pushed me to consider studying it in college. I had been interested in Physics prior to that class, but Mr. Levik fostered that into a love for the subject that I think I will have for the rest of my life. Indeed, since then my professors I have had at BC and the people I have met in the field and all of their work and insight has only made me more excited to one day enter the field myself.

I always enjoyed physics in high school but never considered it as a major until college when one of my physics professors that taught Modern Physics talked me into it. After that, I was hooked. My physics major allowed me the chance to do research at an undergraduate level which stimulated an interest in pursuing a Ph.D. in graduate school since I enjoyed doing research.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: Read books about contribution of Einstein and Madame Curie, and wanted to be a scientist as great as rhem.Participated in some compatition in high school, and got sense of satisfaction when involving in it.

I was somehow naturally drawn to physics from a very young age. Maybe it was because I grew up without siblings, but I had a lot of alone time to think about all the things that made me curious. I guess I soon saw the pattern in how all the exciting phenomena always lead to physics, and decided that physics was the path for me.

I first considered physics because it was the only topic I didn`t find extremely easy in school. I needed to choose a major soon because I had been undecided for a while and I didn`t want to take the easy route with a major that would be easy for me but would also very boring to be in. I chose physics because it challenged me and the concepts interested me. Since the topics did not come naturally to me, I enjoyed working hard and being challenged. Now, I am a physics major because I enjoy understanding how the intricacies of our world work and I still enjoy a challenge. Every day I feel like I am working towards something.

In high school, going into junior year, our school allowed us for the first time to pick which science course we would like to take instead of simply placing us in a chemistry or biology course required for graduation. I had heard only a little bit about physics, so I decided to visit the physics teacher at my high school during our school`s open house. His room was so crowded with parents that I couldn`t even talk to him. His reputation as a teacher invested in students and physics became apparent and definitely helped me to decide to take AP Physics I with him. The first month of class was incredibly difficult for me. I had never been challenged to think in the ways his class had me think, and felt utterly out of place. I cried after class for the first week because I felt I was in over my head and had no idea what to do. I followed the study tips our teacher gave us, but still felt like I was in a class meant for engineers and yes, men. After our first test, my teacher personally told me that I had gotten a perfect score and I nearly cried with happiness. Just that little moment of him reaching out to me and showing he was invested in me reassured me so much about all the work I was doing and that I was in a class I could succeed at. yes, the work was hard and new, but it was hard for the rest of the class too, but our teacher was there to help us. I took two years of physics with him in high school, and have continued ever since. I really like how physics challenges one to ditch their intuition and really think through how things are interrelated. It`s a field so few people seem to want to enter that taking on that extra challenge and showing others that it`s not nearly as intimidating as it can appear to be feels really rewarding. I hope that by succeeding in physics as a woman I can help show other women and minorities that in a field previously dominated by white men, there is still plenty of room for us to join and succeed in the field.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value, Utility Vaue

Response: I first began to pursue physics due to my love of the subject in high school.  In high school, I took two physics courses with an amazing teacher who encouraged me to be successful in the subject manner.  When deciding where to attend school, I knew I wanted to pursue physics due to the love of physics my teacher had shown me.  At the time, I also wanted to have the same impact my high school teacher had on me to other high schoolers. I started off at John Carroll wanting to pursue education and physics.  After more searching, I discovered that there are so many more opportunities other than becoming a high school physicists teacher for me.  As the courses have been getting more difficult, I embrace the challenges I am faced with every day in the classroom and I am lucky to be taught by some of the most amazing professors.  Even though I am not sure what type of career I want to pursue with my physics degree, I know physics is the right fit for me.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: I have always loved science, my Junior year of High school my physics teacher taught me about his degree in astrophysics. I took the time to research and learn about the topic and fell in love with it. Since then I set a goal to get a Ph.D. in astrophysics and learn as much as I can so to become one of the best of my profession.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Utility Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: I had a wonderful professor at my community college whose influence led me to study physics for my bachelor`s degree. Before his influence, I was planning on studying mathematics.

I had an inspiring teacher in high school that motivated his students to questionhow things work. I always felt a similar curious nature so I wanted to enter afield that would satisfy my natural curiosity. Out of all the majors I could havepossibly chosen, physics made the most sense because it gives you access to research that you would not otherwise be able to participate in. For example, I wouldn`t need to be an art student to paint a portrait but I do need to be a physics students to handle periodic elements.
Initially in math, but did not find research interesting. Did undergraduate research in experimental physics, found it very interesting and more fulfilling.

The first time considered becoming a physicist was my senior year in high school when I took my first physics class. Until that year I had no previous experience in physics. Since then IÕve switched my major twice and ended up back as a physics major. I realized my fascination has no limit and IÕm always curious to learn more. Physics the the subject where questions never end and answers are always seeked. My only influence on my decision to choose this pathway is my own education. None of my family has continued education later than high school let alone have any background in the sciences. My main source of support has come from only peers and have nothing but positive experiences with my classmates which has driven me to continue on the pathway of physics.
I took AP Physics in my senior year of high school and really enjoyed it so I took more courses my first year in college applied to the physics major the same year.

I began taking an interest in physics topics at a very young age when I watched movies that had to do with the curving and bending of spacetime. Though this is a bit of a cliche in my opinion, I am very interested in the "abnormal and mind-bending aspects of physics

I always enjoyed science and in high school I was required to take a physics class to graduate. I immediately loved the focus on understanding instead of memorizing. I have since applied the same logic to many different fields and considered unrelated careers, but I always find myself drawn back to physics.

I was fascinated by stars and the concept of outer space when I was a child. I hated math, but I knew it was key to increasing my understanding of the world around me. The more I understand, the more empathetic and aware I can be. As such, I worked on math until physics came- another challenging subject that I needed to overcome. I love increasing my understanding and physics is another avenue to do so.
I was originally a pre-nursing major but then I switched to Physics because I like solving challenging problems

IÕve always liked challenges and knowledge. With physics can be challenging and thatÕs why I love it. Also information just keeps going so I feel like IÕm learning forever. Physics is a perfect fit for me
My high school AP Physics teacher was my favorite teacher in high school and he made me fall in love with the subject.

I fell love with physics at the first time I learned her in my mid school. She is so mysterious and attractive. Physics offer a new way to see the world we are live in and show all the amazing things about our universe. I wasn???t a physics major when I was in the first year of my college. The reason why I didn???t choose physics is because of my parents don???t agree me to be a physics major. They thought that being physicist isn???t a good option, especially for girls. I followed their suggestions and chose other major. I spent three years in that major, but I realized that is not what I want. I can???t enjoy studying anymore. Going school made me feel very painful. I spent too much time in the dark side, then I made the best decision in my life. I changed my major in my junior year. I knew that means I may need two or three more years to finish my undergraduate studying, but I can enjoy my life. It is really hard to explain how happy to do what you like. My life is colorful now. By the experience I had, I realized that physics is not the only option in my life but it is the only option to make my life be meaningful.

I dont really know, by the time I graduated high school, I was very interested in becoming a physician. I met a guy at a scholarship competition at the university I ended up attending who was a pre-med physics major, and it inspired me to follow suit, however I never really followed through with the medical side. I became totally caught up in the physics side and learned to love it. I also found that I loved the students and faculty and spaces available to me at this university as a physics student. What keeps me going is a love for learning these topics and being able to apply them in a computational manner, computational physics being my main focus.

My dad is an engineer in applied physics with PhD in fluid dynamics, so the physics major seemed achievable and something valuable to pursuit. The only physics class offered in highschool was basic kinematics, which I took my senior year. I was taking AP compsci, AP stats, and physics. I knew I always liked STEM, but wasn`t interested in bio or chem. I got A`s in compsci and stats, but a B in physics. However, it seemed like something I had the rest of my life to explore without getting bored of, so I just kind of went for it. There were some moments in my life that I almost wanted to do something with art or music. However, I think choosing physics was the best decision of my life.
I first became interested in physics when watching Wonders of the Universe with Brian Cox, and from there I intended to major in physics

I`ve always loved astronomy and ever since I was little knew I wanted to work at a place like NASA or Space X. When I was in fourth grade I read a book called Atlas of the Universe which sparked said interest in astronomy. In high school I realized I had some real skills in math and physics when I was solving problems other struggled greatly with and helping other study in math and physics. My high school math teacher had a lot of influence on me when he told me that I was his most tenacious student and that he thought I was going to end up at NASA. He constantly emailed me with helpful resources and I would spend a lot of time after school discussing astronomy and mathematics with him. Because of his influence on my I knew I wanted to go to college and major in math and physics. However, money is a big factor for me. I can`t stay in school for long and as such have opted for a math major and physics minor rather than a double major in math and physics. This hasn`t discouraged my interest in physics though and I still try and take ever opportunity I have to learn more.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Cost (Outside Effort)

Response: I first considered physics as an option in about 5th grade, when I was really interested in space. My dad took me to various Astronomy/Physics related things such as going to the observatory outside of town when I was in middle school. In high school, I attended several Nebraska Citizens for Science meetings, where they had interesting discussions about various physics concepts. As a sophomore in high school, I job shadowed a physics professor at the University of Nebraska. When it came time to choose a major, there weren`t really any other options that appealed to me.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience

Response: Physics was the most interesting and challenging class in high school, so I wanted to pursue it at college. The college courses I took were challenging as well, but the problem-solving nature of the classes was satisfying. Cosmology especially attracted my attention with the massive scale of the topics and how physics shapes everything we experience on all scales. No other classes were as exciting to me.

I really enjoy mathematics. I am not very good at numbers and hated math all through high school. Then when I took calculus my senior year, I realized I was really good at math. I went into physics because I enjoyed applying calculus to problems. I was also not very good at introductory physics. I tried really hard but everyone else in my classes seemed to get the material while I understood what was going on in the problem to the point that I could teach the material when I was in study groups however I could not do it for myself. However, now thatI am in the upper level classes I am in the top of my class. I enjoy physics now that I can do the problems for myself.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Task Effort)

Response: This is my second degree. I was working in a boring desk job for three years after my first degree, listening to podcasts about space and astronomy.  At some point, I was wishing I could be an astrophysicist instead of my boring job, and then I realized I could do exactly that.  So I started taking evening classes and then I quit my job to take classes full time, on track to earn a physics degree in 3 semesters.

I became interested in physics when a high school friends of mine recommended a book to me - "The Elegant Universe by Brian Greene. The book described string theory and all the physics that led up to it. I thought it was beautiful

The cultivation of my interest in physics stems from a mixture of my own curiosity and the teachers I`ve had along the way.I knew I wanted to be an astrophysicist when I was 8 years old. It all started for me in elementary school when I picked up my first book on outer space and our solar system ( specifically my favorite book on Saturn!). I wrote to NASA several times during those young years and they always sent me back large envelopes stuffed with new research and fun things to read. I still to this day cherish those memories of getting those envelopes, the fact that they cared so much for such a young child is very special to me. In high school my father bought me my first telescope and I joined the local astronomical society. I started to really fall in love with the night sky at this point. not one night went by that i wasn`t out looking for a new constellation or crater on the moon. I had an amazing teacher at that time, Mr. Fisk, that paid extra special attention to my questions and really made me fall more in love with our universe and all its mystery. Now in college, I find myself staying awake at night with all of the fresh new concepts I`m learning about in my Physics class and my ideas about how and why these physical phenomena happen. I am fortunate enough to have an outstanding Professor, Dr. Lysak, that is inspiring beyond words. This Professor is without a doubt exactly what I wish to become for my students one day. This ability to spark interest and passion is so desperately needed in this field and I want to be someone who helps in turning on that natural curiosity and wonder. Whether it be children or young adults. Not only do I wish to be a Professor in my career, I also want to do research and have an opportunity to advance our knowledge of our known universe, and maybe even be able to take a crack at the unknown.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Utility Value

Response: When I was very young, I became interested in the way things worked, and from that, I became interested in the ways that everything in the world worked. My parents provided information on what they could, and I quizzed them relentlessly about how atoms worked and what they were made up of. I simply could not find anything that was as interesting as physics, and specifically, particle physics. I thought for a short time during high school that topology could be as interesting as physics, but I have not been able to find anything at all that contains the same search for the true underpinnings of the universe as physics does.No other field delves into exactly why the world is the way it is, what makes it that way, and how we can play with it.

I was always curious. A science teacher in middle school always answered all of my curious questions and I found that his answers usually led to physics. I found the subject fascinating from early on and it only grew as I worked my way through my academic career.

I liked physics in high school, but didn`t think there were many job opportunities in it, so I decided to major in mechanical engineering. It was my sophomore year in college that I realized that I liked physics so much that I would try to major in both engineering and physics. There are two other students at my university doing the same thing and we all help each other out. I`m glad I made the decision to pursue both majors.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Social Persuasion

Response: Having a good high school physics teacher inspired me to want to take an interest in physics. Also, other family members influence me to be interested in physics.
Curiosity and an overall fascination with things I don`t already know or understand.

Ever since I was little, I had a love for Astronomy. When I was older, I realized that I could pursue it as a career. After doing some research, I realized that Astronomy was not a typical undergraduate degree and most professional astronomers studied a related field for their undergrad and then went to grad school for astronomy or astrophysics. I figured that Physics would give me a good foundation. In high school, I was ahead in math and I also loved learning about the sciences. In addition, I knew that a Physics degree would be very versatile and help me develop the skills that are necessary in a lot of successful careers.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Mastery Experience, Utility Value

Response: Shortly before graduating from high school, I was named a scholar by Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico. As a part of my scholarship, I was also offered a research intern position at the labs throughout my undergraduate studies. I accepted, and proceeded to work there the summer following my high school graduation and continue to work at the labs today. By chance, I had been placed into an optical physics research laboratory in their nanotechnology department. Previously, my research experiences and interest had purely been in pure life science research. During my school semesters, I work in a biomedical research laboratory at my university. Through the experiences I continuously have in these two labs, my interest in physics has come about from realizing the impact and connections that physics concepts have to offer to my original interest in biomedical research. I used to see physics as a field that was completely unnecessary and irrelevant to someone like myself, but have grown to realize the utility it offers throughout my college experience.
I really liked physics in High School, and have been interested in astronomy for as long as I can remember. Combining the two seemed like the best thing to me.

Before I even took a physics class, I knew I liked science and math, and physics was the most math-y of the sciences. I am interested in quantum mechanics but unfortunately, I am not far enough in my program to get to interesting topics like that.
I`ve had the goal of becoming an aerospace engineer since third grade. Throughout all of my public schooling, I`ve been the "math and science girl. I found all topics interesting
Codes: Utility Value, Attainment Value, Intrinsic Value

Response: In high school, my physics teacher likes me a lot even though I sucked at physics in the first year. He insisted that I take physics Olympics.So I gave it a try for three months` studying, but without any expectationto get any prize. Then it turned out that I got the first prize. I think it`s thenI started to have confidence in physics.However, physics olympics was not the type of physics I would enjoyingdoing for 4 years in college. It was just playing around the tricks. But comingto US without very good English left me no choice but physics, sinceit was something I was at least good at and doesn`t require a high levelof English. What changed my view on physics was my advisor, Dr. David Lee.He challenged me in thinking about this world in a whole different way. I started reading books about quantum mechanics and generalrelativity, which amazed me. I then realized that physics is not onlyjust about solving a problem. It`s about how you look at this whole universe. It`s about exploring our limit and even simply being amazed byhow little we know and how tiny we are.Anyway, I have no idea for what I want to do with physics. I justsimply enjoy it so much that I would like to do anything with it. To be quite frankly, I would love to just study physics and explore all the fields I possiblycould for my life. If someone could offer me a job for doing so, that would the coolest thing I would ever ask for.In a word, physics is soooo cool!
Codes: Cost (Task Effort), Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered, Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value

Response: Being a physics major didn`t cross my mind until my junior year of high school after having taken a physics class the previous year. I also enjoyed astronomy, all of my science fair projects were physics-related, and math is one of my strengths. After taking my physics class, it just sort of all came together and made sense that physics is a good fit for me.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: In high school, I struggled with my physics class at first. But then I worked really hard for the rest of the year and ended up enjoying it, learning a lot, and doing well. I would go into office hours to talk to my professor about physics things unrelated to class that I was just interested in. At the end of the semester, my teacher gave me the physics award for the year. It was an empowering experience and made me excited about physics. Then, taking physics in college, they were always my favorite classes where I felt like I was using my brain to understand and solve more and more interesting problems. Then, this summer, I did physics research in a lab at NYU. I enjoyed this lab experience a lot and discovered that I like physics lab work as much as I like learning physics in a classroom. Having personal relationships with many of the professors in the physics department at my school has certainly contributed to my enjoyment of physics as well.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered

Response: After the first day of Physics 1 at my high school junior year, I came home and told my mother that I had found what I had wanted to do with my life. Since then I have pursued physics in my academics, finding the subject interesting, thought provoking, and intellectually stimulating.

On a whim, I took an entry level physics honor class my last year of high school. While we did not learn much of the mathematics of physics in the class, we did watch many documentaries on recent discoveries and biologies of Einstein`s life. I always found what they had to say very compelling and it prompted me to think of what I wanted to study when I got to college. Though being in my senior year of high school I had no clue what I wanted to major in. I knew that I did not want to spend the whole of college writing essays for english classes or doing any other liberal studies course. At that moment, I decided I wanted to physics; just like that I decided fairly quickly. Also interested in the elusive narrative about "dark matter" I decided I wanted to major specifically in astrophysics. My experience is probably more unconventional from those who knew they wanted to do physics early on, but I can confidently say that since I started at university, I have not regretted choosing this major. The things we learn, in my opinion, are so much more impactful and mind opening than anything else.

I attended a nuclear astrophysics camp in high school after being introduced to the field by my first physics teacher in high school. It was a really positive experience both because of the content and because of the incredible physicists I met. From there, I pursued a research project in high school, where I got to do a lot of programming, which was a skill I was interested in acquiring. In college, the physics community here seems nice and tight, and I recently joined a research group with applications that interest me.
Codes: Event Triggered, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I took AP Physics C in high school, and because I loved the class so much I decided I would major in physics in college. I want to be a doctor, but physics, especially biophysics and medical physics, have always interested me more than basic biology and chemistry classes.

I have always been interested in science, but I started considering physics more seriously as a career in high school, when I participated in physics events of Science Olympiad competitions. I found them interesting and fun, and decided that I wanted to study physics more in the future. I declared physics and geology as my two majors when starting college, and it`s only gotten better from there. I started working in a condensed matter physics lab the summer before my freshman year of college. Getting into research strengthened my interest and intentions in physics. I continue working toward a research career in geophysics today, with an internship in seismology at MIT in summer 2014, and many applications for internships and graduate programs on the way over the next few years.
Codes: Event Triggered, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value (Geophysics)

Response: I originally decided to be a physics major when I heard of the medical careers available, and then I decided I wanted to do something more engineering related, and physics was still applicable. Now I am just finishing my first semester as a physics major.
I enjoyed physics class in high school and the topic in general.

Mainly my decision to peruse a career in physics came from discovering my love of math and using it to explain the physical world, mainly in high school. I wanted to use my passion for solving problems with physical and mathematical reasoning to understand more fully how living things work at the molecular level. My mom helped me come up with the idea as hopefully a way I could combine my love of biology and physics. College has been a bit of a blow to my passion and I haven`t really felt like the physics concepts I`ve been learning here have been taught in such a way that I can internalize them. I might change my major if I continue to feel like I can`t understand or connect to the material, but I think the problem might be the way it`s taught, not my ability to understand. I wish I had more resources and ways to think about what I`m learning.

I`ve always been interested in science and really loved my physics class in high school so I decided to become a physics major when I went to college. In my second semester of freshman year, I started doing research in the physics department, which cemented my desire to study physics. It`s now my junior year, and I have no regrets; after college, I want to go on to grad school in physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Event Triggered

Response: A lot of my motivation came from a really amazing high school physics teacher. She inspired curiosity and wonder for this subject in me. She also was very pragmatic and allowed no talk of the type of girls can`t do physics.
I fell in love with astrophysics when I was a junior in high school and decided I wanted to go to grad school for physics in order to conduct research in the field of astrophysics.

I have wanted to be an engineer for a few years now. I was heavily involved in the STEM program in high school, but disliked my high school physics class due to the teacher and the boring topics covered in the class. As I was looking at different colleges to attend, I found a college with a dual-degree engineering program. I chose to attend this college, and quickly learned that the physics and engineering programs are closely intertwined. My academic advisor suggested majoring in applied physics alongside my engineering major since it was just two additional classes. I agreed and continued to fall in love with physics through my introductory physics courses. These courses provided an excellent foundation of physics and made physics fun and applicable to my life. Now, I enjoy learning about physics both in my advanced physics courses and outside of my classes. I am very eager to use my physics training in my engineering studies in the near future.
Codes: Cost (Emotional), Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I loved how the ideas in physics were presented to me. They were described in such an interesting way that I wanted to learn more and continue learning about the topics in class. I thought it was great that I could actually visualize a significant amount of what I was being taught and it wasn`t something I had to imagine.

In high school, physics was not a required part of the science curriculum, but I decided to take it in order to round myself out. If I recall correctly, I believed that it would improve my college prospects as it showed that I was willing to challenge myself. It ended up being the most challenging course I had ever taken. The challenge was really refreshing in contrast to my other courses which I felt were fairly easy. By the end of high school, I had taken three years of physics courses at the AP and IB level.Coming into college, I felt inclined to major in physics, but was really unsure about my abilities in it, so I took the intro courses at my school my first year. By the end of my first year, I had convinced myself that I was good enough at physics to commit myself to the major. The community within my school`s physics department also made me feel at home, and made the decision easier as well. It is also worth mentioning that I attend a women`s college and I feel like I have received a lot of support and encouragement from my physics classmates that have helped affirm my decision to major in physics. In high school I was one of two woman in my class, and was frequently the target of sexist comments and behavior, which did not make me feel confident about my place in the physics classroom.

I have always loved science, especially physical science, but had pretty much made up my mind to pursue Biology because that was more of a "women`s science or because women were more successful in that field. I didn`t really have the opportunity to see many women in the role of a physicist and even though I was good at physics I didn`t want to pursue it because of this. However

I started thinking about studying physics only after I started college. Initially, I was pretty certain that I wanted to pursue a life sciences related field. My interactions with the physics professors at my college, and hearing about their research changed my path to becoming a physics student.

I really didn`t think I was going to study physics until my sophomore year at Yale. Before that, I was mostly leaning towards the biological sciences, and I signed up to take physics because it was required for biology majors. I ended up really loving physics and realizing that the quantitative nature was more akin to my learning style than the memorization-based style of biology, so I switched majors last year and could not be happier!

Originally I wanted to be a chemistry major, but decided I did not like it after taking AP Chemistry in high school and switched my interest to astronomy. While I was applying to colleges, I came across Angelo State University and saw they had a great physics program. I expressed interest in the program to their department chair, Dr. David Bixler, who later called me to come to ASU for my undergraduate. This outreach of kindness was a big deal to me and I chose ASU. I`m glad I picked this school because the learning environment here is amazing everyone want you to succeed.
Planetarium near home;Brief History of Time by Stephan Hawking;Classmates and friends in Junior High and HIgh School

When I was growing up my mother always made it known that I could be anything and do anything I wanted to do. She stressed the fact that women could do well in math and science classes and pushed me to try my hardest in these classes. My mom would always talk about science related topics with me and keep me up to date with what was going on in the science field. Also when I was younger I was enrolled in space camps during the summer months. Math and science courses were always my best classes so going into the math and science field was something I knew I was going to do. I had a lot of very influential teachers in my math and sciences courses as well. In 7th grade I had a female math teacher who I became very close with and she always pushed me to do my hardest and made sure I continued in this field. Once in high school I took more astronomy and physics classes and knew that this was the field I wanted to be a part of. Know in college I know that I have made the right decision and I can???t were to see where this all takes me in life.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Event Triggered, Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience

Response: I had my first physics class at my high school. The professor was amazing and made everything seem fun and interesting. I`ve always had a knack for science and math and physics seems to be the perfect mix for me. I did well in the class and decided to change my mind on which major I was considering to physics. Since I have been a physics major at App State, I have been able to do research with different professors. My freshman year, I helped put on demo shows for young students. My sophomore year, I was able to learn how to use a scanning electron microscope. I have also helped out at a computer club at a local school. I love understanding certain topics in physics and being able to help others learn about them. Because of that, I have been considering a career as a college professor.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: In high school I took my first actual physics class and I scored well, and everything made sense, but beyond that, everything was fun and exciting to learn about, such that I wanted to pursue it further. Upon arriving to college, I wanted to take an introductory physics course to see if I really did like the subject, and with the course of Mechanics, I loved it. Thermodynamics and Electromagnetism were tough, but I still got such a joy from understanding the material and getting to successfully work through the problems and experiments that I considered physics even further. And now I`m here, intending on majoring in physics.

I love problem solving! I also have honestly been a bit influenced by wanting to prove myself if challenging courses and show myself that I can succeed in physics.Also, Whitman doesn`t have a WiP group, but along with a few peers, I founded a Women in STEM club which addresses some similar issues.

I have always had a strong fascination with space and the laws that govern our universe, and was encouraged throughout my childhood to employ scientific methods in order to gain answers to the questions I posed.Learning about famous scientists such as Brian Cox and Neil deGrasse Tyson inspired and motivated me to follow their example by studying hard so that I could some day be able to understand the complexities of our world.During my high school career, I began to search for career paths with the potential to allow me the freedom of scientific exploration and discovery I desired, leading me to consider a Physics Major in college.

In the seventh grade I had taken a field trip to the NASA Space Exploration Museum through aclub called MESA from my school. I consider this trip one of the most eye-opening and life-changingevents of my life. The museum introduced me to new possibilities and horizons in the science field that I never before knew existed. I learned about spaceships, missions, and the physics at work behind it all. I was especially determined to work in the physics and engineering field when I was given a book called "Cool Careers for Girls in Air and Space. I aspire to be half asinspiring and impacting as all the women in this book. Their stories inspire me every day and are a reminder that it is possible to reach my dreams of working for NASA
Codes: Event Triggered, Media Triggered, Vicarious Experience

Response: I came into my undergrad as undeclared but I knew I wanted to go into a science so I took the first physics class meant for engineers. I loved the class because it was the first one that I had taken that applied calculus to understanding physical situations. I had a very good calculus education in high school and so physics appealed to me because it was involved some that I was already good at, and used calculus to explain the physical world (satisfying my own personal curiosity). I didn`t take any physics classes before college, and I honestly only knew what physics was by watching the Big Bang Theory. Most of the adults I tell I`m studying physics, do not know what it is.I continue in my studies in physics because of my fellow students and the strong friendships I have made. We are each others best resource for studying and getting help, and I wouldn`t have performed as well as I have without the help of fellow undergrads. My mental health has stayed healthy enough because of the friendships I have made.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic (Social), Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience

Response: In my senior year of high school, I was a declared biology major, but I realized that biology wasn`t really my main interest even though I was doing well with the subject, so I switched to chemistry. I was going to attend college away from home as a chemistry major, but I still needed around $3600 for the year even with scholarships, meaning that I couldn`t afford to continue an education at that point in time, so I took a year off after graduating high school. During this year, I realized that I`m way more interested in physics and the wide expanse of knowledge it covers. I switched my major to physics, and I`m now attending a college in my city, so that I can stay with my family and actually afford an education. I chose physics because there`s still so much to explore in the subject and it`s applicable to every area of life. There are around 15 (+/- 5) physics students on my campus, so the physics professors know me and my experience in physics is more personal. The physics faculty have thus far been really nice and inclusive, so that environment has been very encouraging for me to continue pursuing physics.

Despite loving physics, I hadn`t considered it as a major until my second semester as a mechanical engineering major. I went into engineering because I feared that as a physicist, my skills wouldn`t be as practical or applicable and my career options would be more limited than as an engineer, but after my experience in my engineering courses, I figured that an engineering career wasn`t for me. The only thing I really enjoyed about my major were the physics classes I had to take. I love learning about the world around me and why and how things work and physics isn`t just about learning about what is already known, it`s about discovery and about challenging the things we think we know, unlike engineering. So I spoke to a physics professor at my college and they put my fears of finding a career to rest. That was all the reassurance I needed to change my major and 3 semesters later I am still thrilled to go to class.
Codes: Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: At the beginning of my freshman year, I was a nursing major who became nervous to enter the program because of all the hard work professors kept telling me I would have to put into my education. Then I thought, I should not feel as though I am working hard because I should be doing something I love to do for the rest of my life. One day during freshman week, Ms. Dillard University, at that time, inspired me to have the same passion as she did for physics.Throughout the week, she would always mention how great Dillard???s Physics department was and that their students were always presented with many opportunities. I was thinking, man, I need to reconsider my current path and take this high road. After all, Physics was one of my best subjects in high school so I went for it.I had a long conversation with Ms. Dillard and she was thrilled that a female freshman wanted to change majors to physics since the number of women in physics was very low. She took me straight to my current advisors office and as of that day, history was made.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience

Response: When I was a child, my mom would take me outside to look at the constellations. They fascinated me and I wanted to learn more so I took the physics class and the astronomy class that my high school taught. I was not as interested in physics, but astronomy caught my attention so I decided to continue with astrophysics in college. Many of my physics classes made me reconsider my major choice, but I had several good astronomy professors who convinced me to stay. I enjoy doing astronomy related research and I enjoy my astronomy classes, for the most part, so that is why I am now graduating soon with my astrophysics degree. I feel that I have also learned many transferable skills that I could use if I would like to find a job in a different field, like computer programming, public speaking, research, and math.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Utility Value

Response: The chronology: I was a very curious kid, I started reading pop culture science books, I used Edx to teach myself to an AP Physics 1 exam, I became involved in robotics, I attended University of Maryland Girls Advanced Physics summer outreach program, I became involved in a mechanical engineering summer program. More info: I love solving problems, creating things, and learning about the world around me
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Event Triggered

Response: Mentorship

I have a family member that worked as an electrical engineer for NASA and I have always been interested in his work, but did not have a good experience with high school physics. My first degree was in Applied Health Sciences and I was required to take physics courses for that, but unfortunately waited until my last year to take them. I enjoyed them thoroughly but had already accepted a position to get my Doctorate in Physical Therapy. I found myself dreading everything I was doing with this degree and missing math and logic and met with a friend of mine who was a physics student. I started hanging around physics labs and working on my own ideas having to do with physics while juggling my doctoral work. Eventually I quit my doctorate on Friday, and the Monday after dove straight into physics and have not regretted it once.

My AP physics teacher in high school was an amazing professor, a doctor who was overqualified for the job but wanted to inspire young students. He was very good at presenting the material in an interesting way and it became my favorite class in high school. He would encourage us to use our brains to come up with the fundamental physics formulas and apply them to calculate how the world around us works. I was not sure what I wanted to study in college, but since that was the only class that really interested me I decided to continue studying that in college. I stuck with it because there is no other subject I`ve come across that gets me as excited as physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience

Response: I was first interested in math during middle and high school which led me to become interested in astronomy. I knew I couldn`t go far in astronomy without a good knowledge of physics, so learning more about physics helped me realize the possibilities in the field beyond astronomy. Learning about higher dimensions in middle school is what initially drove me to pursue an interest in STEM and bizarre things like that have helped motivate me to continue to study physics and related fields.

I absolutely fell in love with physics in high school and simply could not give it up, leading me to enter college as a physics major and not change my major once throughout. After continuing physics in college I came to the conclusion that I wanted to be a high school physics teacher and am excited for my future in this field.

The time in high school when working out unification of the electromagnetic force with vector space feel the delight and pleasure of having some understood about the world and its beauty in such a fundamental level, and all the hard work are worth it.

I love space and astrophysics. I wanted to pursue this career path because I thought it would be very fun. I also thought it would make my parents proud and it would impress others. I initially thought about obtaining a physics degree in high school when I took a difficult physics class and astronomy. I thought that astrophysics was super cool and wanted to learn more about it. I did deeply wonder if I was smart or driven enough for a career path in physics. I was not a science oriented person all throughout my life until late in high school. I thought that people wouldnÕt think that I could do it. I am a very hard worker, so I knew that I could make it through just my brute force, but I didnÕt want to struggle. I didnÕt know if I was smart enough. Eventually I applied to several colleges that offered Physics. I knew that I could always change my major if it didnÕt work out, but so far I am absolutely loving the major even though I am the only female in all of my upper level physics classes.

I first really considered physics after I took a regular course and then a CIS course through the University of Minnesota at my school. During the CIS course, I had a real passion for the subject but I felt like I did not have the representation necessary in terms of being a woman in order to put my talents to the complete test. I decided to take a freshman level physics course at my undergraduate institution and I knew after a semester that it was the subject that I needed to pursue. It was the one subject that I found every little thing we talked about to be very fascinating and my professors were so helpful in terms of making sure I was to the level of my peers and pushed me even further. One thing that also really helped with this decision was the fact that I had a couple of other women in the class who were just as passionate as I was about the coursework and we would study together all the time and I knew that it was just the right thing for me.

I took the upper-level physics courses because of the influence of my high school physics teacher. He was an amazing person and educator and helped me to develop as a student in physics and other topics.
i love to be a physics major because i did physics olympiad in high school and i did research in wind tunnel aerospace in high school

I dealt with my teen angst by viewing everything logically. That was while I was taking a Physics class and I felt like Physics was the most reasonable possible approach to life. I then home schooled myself so I could take classes at the local community college and complete my Associate`s degree.

I have always been very interested in sustainable energy. Before I entered college, I took a physics course in high school and found that I love how physics allows you to solve problems and understand things. A major in physics seemed like a really interesting way to contribute to science and technology for sustainable energy. I took a physics course my first semester of college and found the community in my class and department to be really welcoming. I attended peer-led tutoring sessions and had a wonderful time. Although I found the material challenging, it was very rewarding to learn. I have enjoyed every physics class I have taken and I feel much more confident as a student in courses in the Math Department. I started research related to sustainable energy during my first year of college and I found that research made me feel more confident as a physicist. It is not only interesting and fun, but plays to some of my abilities which don`t come out in my physics courses. For research, you need to be organized, detail-oriented, and communicate clearly. I am currently very involved in my Physics department. I have had a very positive experience pursuing physics so I want to share my experience with other people and help other people to see themselves as scientists, find opportunities, and participate in the community.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Energy), Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Intrinsic (Social), Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered

Response: I originally came to university to study elementary education. Found myself bored and really wanting more science and math. When I looked at what I could do instead, I choose Astrophysics because it was the closest thing to Astronomy that the university offered.

The first time I took physics was my sophomore year of college as I was taking it to fulfill a requirement for the Biology major. I realized the connection between math and physics--how math is used to help explain our world. And I began doing more research on my own about astronomy and astrophysics and I was completely awestruck. I didn`t know physics and math would ever be this fun and interesting and mysterious. And I never knew I could do it.

I first took physics in HS. I had the option to take physics or chemistry, and I decided to take physics because I had read Richard FeynmanÕs autobiography and thought he seemed like a cool person so I figured I would try physics. One I was in HS physics I realized I really liked it. I had an amazing teacher (female) and I realized I was really good at physics and that it was a lot of fun. So when I got to college I had to choose a major and nothing else really seemed interesting to me. But I loved physics I decided to go for it.
I decided to major in physics because of the physics teacher that I had in high school. She was always excited to teach the subject and made the subject interesting.

I was taking a developmental math course at Austin Community College and my professor (who had a Ph.D. in Physics) said to me, "You have the mind of a physicist...you should major in physics! I changed my major that day."

I originally started college intending to major in Marine science. At the time, physics was not a possible major for me, as I believed it wasn`t my strongest subject. My freshmen year I took Fundamental physics with a professor who was the head of the physics department. I started to consider physics as a major after talking with this professor, and became more passionate about physics. Towards the end of my freshmen year, I began reflecting over which courses I liked and which ones I didn`t, and realized I enjoyed my physics courses more than I thought. I also took a course in 3d-printing and engineering, and decided that I wanted to do something more involved with physics and engineering as a result of that course. I decided to pursue a physics and engineering major as a result of the influence that my physics professor, who is now my mentor, as she encouraged me to pursue physics and helped me find courses and other opportunities to explore this field.

I was very undecided as a freshman in college, but I knew I enjoyed science, I`d always had a passion for astronomy, and I had a really excellent high school physics teacher, so I decided to try it and have been a physics major since then.

I knew I wanted to be an Engineer since 5th grade. I had participated in a future cities competition that gave me the insight into my future. I loved how I could use my creative skills with the education to make something new. I loved that I was able to apply my skills. Although at times it has been a challenge, it is the feeling of accomplishment once the challenge is surpassed.

My background in the field of physics begins with my high school physics teacher. Of all courses I was enrolled in, he made the most effortless sense, everything he lectured simply made sense. I started to see the physics in my every environment, and it has not left me since. When coming to University, I have carried multiple majors while fulfilling prerequisite courses and when it came to choosing a physics major, I have not doubted myself once. Now that I am beginning my major specific coursework, I feel that I have truly felt a home amongst the professors, the material, the research, and my academic peers.

IÕm an older student, and in the time that IÕve been in and out of college, IÕve taken a lot of classes and changed my major a few times. I always found a subject interesting until about halfway through the class and then became disenchanted with it. I took an introductory astronomy course and was fascinated all the way through it, enjoying even the parts that most people wouldnÕt (mainly the math). I decided to take my first physics class and another astronomy class after that and enjoyed learning about how and why things move the way they do and more in depth about astronomy. This led me to discussions outside of the classroom with professors about various topics in physics and began buying books about these topics for leisure reading (dark matter, string theory, quantum mechanics, quantum gravity, etc). I had never had an interest in anything like this before, so this is when I knew that I wanted to major in physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Social Persuasion

Response: I`ve wanted to do astrophysics since I was 9 years old. My parents, although not STEM majors, always taught me to embrace my curiosity.

I started feeling belong to physics because I simply do well in it in my middle and high school, then I feel that among my circle of friends, someone does well in humanity or sports and I am the one do best in physics. After attending university I feel more this way that I enjoy the way physicists communicate with each other and I have the general interest to attend physics panel and learn about new research and progression in physics. These things give me a sense of direction of what I want to work with in the future.

When I was very little I really wanted to become an astronaut - I was fascinated by the whole prospect of outer space and how we really didn`t know anything about it. However, when I started looking into actually becoming an astronaut, I came across many interesting things about physics and astrophysics that an astronaut could not take part in. I realized that instead of physically going into space, I wanted to research about space. After deciding I wanted to research in the field of astrophysics, I decided to become a physics and astrophysics major.

Though I lived with my mom & grew up much closer to my mom, I can`t help but consider the influence of my dad, who was a math major and physics minor. Whenever my dad and I did speak, it was about astronomy or math. In high school, I initially wanted to be a marine biologist, but as I neared college applications, I started to recognize the intellectual and monetary prestige that surrounded engineering. I started to draw lines between physics, engineering, astronomy, and math...I wanted a marketable, challenging, yet enjoyable degree. After eliminating marine biology, I planned to double major in physics and astronomy (physics for practical reasons, astronomy for the fun). However, I arrived at college and found disappointment in astronomy research. At the same time, my (male) calculus professor noticed my abilities in math and suggested that I major in it. Thus, I switched my astronomy degree to a math degree, making myself a double major in physics and math (sound familiar?). I`ve focused much more on my physics degree, treating my math degree as a foundation for physics. I work in an experimental physics lab, though I find it very boring. I still wonder about life as a marine biologist. I`m proud to be doing well as a physics major, but I question whether or not it`s the right degree for me.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Utility Value, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Mastery Experience

Response: Although I have always been interested and had a passion for physical sciences, I was not driven to study physics when I was in high school in a male dominated classroom. In fall 2017, I enrolled in a course at Thomas Nelson Community College with Dr. Elena Kuchina. Dr. Kuchina introduced me to the correlation between chemistry and physics and their interconnected dynamics. Introducing me to the real-world application and providing me an environment that encouraged questions and understanding of the topic, allowed me to develop my physics skills. This encouragement also gave me the confidence to lead a study group and lab group solely consisting of men. While developing my appreciation for the course in the second semester, when Dr. Kuchina was no longer my laboratory and lecture professor, she provided me with physics theory and additional confidence in my abilities to study, research, and share that information with my male counterparts, and I was able to lead my group again as well as assist other groups in the lab. I also took it upon myself to be the only member of my group to familiarize myself with the physics graphing program RStudio and learn the coding required to accurately represent data. I also discovered my ability to share this information with my peers and explain its usefulness in the physics classroom. For these reasons and experiences, Dr. Kuchina has be an instrumental advisor in my decision to expand my knowledge of chemistry to a more physical application, such as the knowledge required to be a physical or inorganic chemist.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I fell in love with physics my junior year of high school, so much so that I took AP mechanics and AP E&M my senior year of high school. Everyone thought I`d go into art, but physics fascinated and excited me. It was finally explaining everything I`d always been so interested in growing up. Once I entered the major, I loved my professors and quickly grew relationships with the fellow students. Through those relationships, I have managed to advance more than I would`ve been able to otherwise - we really all support each other and it`s a great atmosphere.
I decided to become after a physics major after having an amazing physics teacher in high school who is an electrical engineer. S

After becoming very interested in physics, math, and engineering in high school, I took into physics my freshman year of college. Upon taking these courses, I realized that I enjoyed it a lot and easily made connections with my professors. Because of my experience in the class in college, I decided to declare it as my major.

I enjoyed science in high school, but planned to major in biology. During my senior year of high school, I received a Physics Departmental Scholarship at an institution I did not end up attending. This gave me the confidence to try physics, and I found astrophysics appealing.
My father is a physicist so I have been exposed to it all my life. I knew I was going to major in physics at 8 years old.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Attainment Value, Social Persuasion

Response: I have always been intrigued by the way in which things/the world works and my love for outer space and desire to figure out things unknown and unearthly drove me to choose astrophysics.

During my junior year of high school, I had a teacher that first sparked my love for Physics. I wanted to do the same for other students, which is why I decided to become a high school physics teacher. My parents encouraged me to do so.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Utility Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: My physics teacher at Cape Cod Community College was the first person ever who understood the way I think. That was when I decided to pursue a career in physics.
I really enjoyed high school physics. My parents said I should go for it.

I enjoyed physics a lot in high school. I had a hard time coming to terms with what I was going to study in college because I enjoyed so many different topics and I wasn`t sure what I was going to want to do for four solid years. I chose physics because it felt economical, really. I was good at math, and I enjoyed high school physics, and my father wanted me to be successful. I wanted to prove myself as being smart enough, so I committed to physics.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Utility Value, Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: I have always enjoyed mathematics and knowing how to use mathematics to explain why things work the way they do. I competed in several different mathematics and engineering competitions when I was in high school. When I took physics and engineering in high school, I felt comfortable and truly enjoyed working and solving problems. When I began college I was an engineering physics major. I took several math classes and an engineering class. During those classes I learned a lot of the math used in physics, and I learned briefly how the math could be applied. When I began to work physics problems in my classes, I felt a connection and knew I wanted to study physics. I am currently double majoring in physics and mathematics in order to develop a good mathematics background to help me in my physics courses.

I was very interested the material in my high school class, but the teacher was not a physics major nor had she taught physics prior to teaching my AP class. I always loved math and especially calculus. I specifically enjoyed learning about topics that I felt were applicable to the real world. Coming into UCSB, I planned on declaring my major as physics (I came in as undeclared), but after my first quarter I felt intimidated by the culture and didn`t think I could be successful. I declared chemistry as my major during my freshman year and thought that was what I was going to do. At the start of my sophomore year, though, I had become more confident as a student and as a person, and I was still enjoying my lower division physics classes far more than my chemistry courses. I started to rethink my decision and ultimately switched into the physics major at the end of my second year. This time, I knew what the classroom dynamic was like and I knew I could succeed if I was confident and asserted myself. I am now well-established with my physics peers and part of several study groups, which is helping me to be successful in my classes.
