Often times I am the only girl in the room, but I have learned that I am just as capable as my male classmates and I need to confident in my abilities if I want them to listen to what I have to contribute.

I took product development during high school which is based on physics and engineering. We had to do so many projects based on physics and I loved how physics worked behind all the experiments so far now. Currently I am majoring in mechanical engineering and interesting how we need physics in everything we do.

I started college as an arts major with intention to go into a career creating music for film. However, arts lacked the subtlety that I had always enjoyed in math and science classes. So I eventually switched to an Electrical Engineering major, in the sophomore year of that major I took an Intro Physics class and was encouraged by my professor to change to a physics degree. Since then I have done research under various faculty members of the department further narrowing my interests into Astrophysics, particularly dark matter and radio astronomy. Despite my choice of major I still have a great passion for creative writing, music, and art.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered

Response: I have always had an interest in science, but in my first year of high school I attended a lecture on physics at a local science museum. It was the most interesting thing I had ever seen and I have wanted to work with physics ever since.

I love science and could not decide which STEM field to go into. I took the first year calculus based physics series and fell in love with physics, realizing that I really got a taste of all the STEM fields in physics.

Talking with my dad is really what got me interested in physics. We like to discuss some of the stranger aspects of physics like particle and quantum physics. When I came to college I was initially pre med but I hated the introductory biology courses. It was all memorization which is not my strongestarea. This lead me to physics. I really enjoy the kind of thought that goes intosolving a physics problem. It leaves me feeling more accomplished than just spewing back a bunch of memorized information. For a while I consideredteaching high school physics. It bothers me that so may people get turned off from physics by the introductory courses and I would like to change that. That my plan at least until I talked with a couple of women in graduate school. They both sounded so excited about their research that it made me consider doingboth teaching and research. Since this was a recent decision, I now plan ontaking next year off to get some research experience in a lab and take the physics GRE before applying to graduate school.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value

Response: Mostly an engineering teacher I had in high school is who really influenced me to become a part of the physics community.
I first took physics in my junior year of high school and fell in love with the subject. I had an excellent teacher that year and haven`t stopped taking physics classes since.

I was on a team for the Chinese Physics Olympia in highschool and we learned a lot of physics and went to lecturesgiven by college professors. I did pretty well in physicsthen and topics like relativity caught my interest so Idecided to pursue a physics degree in college.
Codes: Event Triggered, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: It was sort of by chance I became a physics major and I did have a mid-college life crisis about if I should switch to CS the first semester of my sophomore year. I realized though that year that I did enjoy doing and learning physics and I didn`t have to become a CS major to do programming. Computational Physics helped me realize that this is the direction I wanted to head because I get the best of both worlds. Right now I`m working on my Scientific and Engineering Computing minor so that I can use programming as an even more effective tool in my research.

When I was younger, my mother liked learning about space. She would rent videos/movies from the library of Carl Sagan and that`s when I first became interested in space. I started posing questions in physics as a teenager and wanted to figure out answers to it, so I decided that I would study it and major in it for college. It`s been difficult because I am the only woman graduating in the spring of 2020, so I am surrounded by men but I have been working on overcoming it.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Media Triggered, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic Value

Response: I came in as a Math major and decided I liked Applied mathematics moreso than a lot of the theoretical stuff. I decided Physics was a great option to explore and a great option for careers after college.

I attended Maths and Science High School back in Bulgaria, and up until my senior year I was actively involved in my math and physics courses, and astronomy. Then for one reason or another, we got new teachers in those subjects, and a knowledgeable as they were in their subjects, they didn`t grab me. Simultaneously my philosophy teacher was incredibly influential and pulled me closer towards the metaphysical sciences. Thus I went to pursue a bachelor`s degree in Book Publishing at the journalistic faculty at Sofia University after I graduated high school and left my interest in math and science on the back burner. Fast forward three years, I had moved to the US, and relocated to Oregon from Montana with the intent to enroll in a community college. While it was only plausible that I would sign up for a communications/journalism/PR degree, in unison with my previous education, I kept thinking that if I could go back and do it all over again, I would pursue higher education in the field of math and physics. And then it clicked - that`s exactly what I was doing, starting over, starting fresh. I could do anything I wanted to do, and to get involved in math and physics was it.

When I was in high school I had the opportunity to take a class called "science research"; it was a 3 year program where students could work with a professional mentor and complete scientific research. Through that class I was introduced to physics (before taking high school physics) and got involved in physics research, and from there I knew I wanted to keep doing physics research.

I was the Vice President of the Science National Honor Society in high school , I always did well in physics and it was the most interesting science to me. I really was not a fan of chemistry and I really hated biology but physics really clicked with me. My high school trigonometry teacher used to be a chemical engineer and she really encouraged me to pursue the STEM fields. She also encouraged me to look into engineering and to not be afraid to challenge myself. Nowadays, I thoroughly enjoy my courses and I love physics, I am in the 3-2 engineering program for engineering and I am truly excited to go through the journey of becoming an engineer. I have friends at RPI that tell me about their coursework and it really is interesting to me.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional

Response: Physics has the ability to explain phenomenon that occur all around us, from simple actions to complex theories. I find physics very interesting, especially astrophysics.
I had an excellent high school physics teacher, which is when I considered physics as an option.I`ve continued as I`ve gotten to know the other majors better, as well as started a research project.

I have always wanted to study astronomy, but as a kid I also wanted to study several other things. So, what made my decision be astronomy happened in the summer of my Senior year of high school, when I got into a summer program at Yale. I decided to take an astronomy course and I found out that I liked it a lot. After that, the decision to get into physics seemed easy, since in that way I could get to learn about other physics branches and also get my astronomy knowledge.

The problem solving aspect of physics and connection to math interested me most at first. I think now it`s more about learning about how the world works and noticing patterns that occur naturally. The drive to gain as much knowledge about the world we live in and more importantly the universe as a whole inspires me to study physics. A lot of people assume that we know everything about nature and science but we are far from satisfied with the knowledge we have gained.
I love math, but I wanted something more challenging than mathematics so I looked into physics and saw that it has a lot of mathematics and decided to major in physics and minor in math.

Throughout most of my lower education I wanted to be an architect quite badly. However, by my sophomore year of high school I had decided that I enjoyed the math side more than design, so I decided I would pursue civil engineering.I had always enjoyed physics, though at that point I had never taken a full physics course. When I learned of the3-2 program my college offered, it seemed very suited to me. By my senior year, after having taken an actual physicscourse, I decided I very much would love to start with a physics degree. The theory interested me and I felt itwas an extremely good choice for a background going into civil engineering. The longer I stay, the more confident I am in my choice.

A very long time ago, I wanted to learn about the stars. Once I finally made it back to college, I puttered around various science majors, trying to find one where I felt I could make a difference, until I settled back to Physics - I may not have thought I could make a difference, but at least I might enjoy the work, right? After a while, I decided that I wasn`t terribly interested in spending my nights wake, out in the middle of nowhere for months at a time - but I was really enjoying the Physics major. I am steering towards Engineering, as it appears that I may be one of those dreaded experimentalists....
My fascination of the fact that it encompasses the world around us, large and small. My curiosity and desire to understand things in general is consilient with my passion to pursue physics.

I was undeclared in college and I thought about majoring in French but I didn`t see it as lucrative. I didn`t want to be an engineer but I wanted to challenge myself. I volunteered in high school at the Discovery Center and science appealed to me as fun.

I first considered mechanical engineering as a major in college because I like to build things and was good at math and science. I switched to physics because I took two similar physics and engineering class concurrently and enjoyed the physics class more. I then switched my major to math because I decided I liked math better than physics. I later took a pre-diagnostic exam in an introductory physics class and getting a very high grade. I talked to the teacher, and he said he would allow me to test out of his class if the teacher of the next class up would take me in his class without having taken the prerequisite course. The teacher of this next class took me, and taught in a way that made me excited about physics. He taught using math to explain the concepts, and this not only solidified my understanding of the topics but made me realized that I wanted to apply my math degree to physics. So I changed my major, and I take extra math classes on the side, which I think has really helped me understand physics better.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: I decided to major in Physics because of my mother. My mother already had a bachelor`s degree in Journalism, but she decided to go back to school to study physics, at the age of 32. Before going back to school in Physics, my mother worked for LIGO, in the educational outreach program, and before that, she was a middle and high school teacher. When I graduated from high school, I knew I was going to college, but I didn`t know what I would major in. My mother suggested that I major in Physics because she thought that it would open up my mind.But that wasn`t enough to convince me. Then I thought back on when I was thirteen and she brought me to San Francisco with her for two weeks while she was going through job training for LIGO, at the Exploratorium. During the last week, we traveled to Pasadena and stayed on Cal-Tech`s campus. During that trip, I met so many interesting people and I learned so many things. It was because of that experience and my mother being an excellent role model that I decided to major in physics.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I have always enjoyed and been really good at math, so as a young kid my teachers would all say I would go into something having to do with math. I was undecided in my major when I started applying for college, and was leaning more towards teaching so when I decided that I would like to pursue engineering, none of my schools actually offered it as a major. I came into college planning on doing a 3-2 engineering program focused on physics but after I began working with the physics department I found that I wanted to just continue on in physics. The key factors in this were speaking to my highschool physics teachers, becoming so close with the other physics majors in not not my class but the two classes above me, and the connexion I had with all of my physics professors.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: Ever since I was a little girl, I have always loved stars and I loved everything that had to do with stars. I started noticing every little aspect in life and would start to question why the world is the way it is and that is what strikes me as a student and I love it. It can be quite intimidating and hard to grasp the ideas but once I was able to utilize the ideas to help me understand the world better it has helped driven my passion of physic and astronomy to another level.

I visited the University of Uppsala in Sweden. The museum sections dedicated to physics and the achievements that historical physicists were able to accomplish with relatively primitive tools were remarkable and humbling. We have access to all of their knowledge and more raw computational power than any of them could ever hope for, and these resources were built on their work. I realized that if we want our children to learn the nature of the universe, we must lay the foundation for it ourselves, in this moment.

I almost failed most of my AP Physics tests and cried throughout most of them. But I was fascinated by the subject and my professors in physics have always been extremely passionate about physics and are excited to help me understand it; they never gave up on me. I think there is a tough mentality that physicists have, a certain stubbornness that I was attracted to. I didn`t take physics again until my sophomore year of college and I just liked the way it made math relevant to the world and everything is physics, so why not study physics?
Codes: Cost (Task Effort), Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: I was really interested in astronomy as a kid (and still am) so I really was interested in physics once I got to high school and realized physics was the main component behind astronomy. Also, I participated in a science research program at my high school that got me involved with physics at a hands on level. My mentor, who was a woman, really inspired me to continue with physics and astronomy.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: When I was in high school I became very interested in astronomy and astrophysics specifically, so I started doing research on my own and learning more about some of those topics. I ended up really enjoying it, so I attended a two-week summer program at UMass-Amherst for astronomy, and then I took AP Physics my senior year of high school and really enjoyed it. I also surrounded myself with lots of friends who also enjoyed physics, and I joined an observatory and attended presentations, even giving a few of my own. I`ve found that I really love the type of people who work in physics; they`re all brilliant, funny, and laid-back. Overall, I really enjoy the topic and the community as a whole.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: My freshman year of high school, I was in a science fair class taught by one of the physics teachers at my school. She was an amazing teacher and always supported me and pushed me to be better. Both her and her brother graduated from Rollins as physics majors and her brother was currently working on his PhD in geophysics, the same degree I wanted to pursue. Both of them helped me a lot with my project and showed me how awesome science is. I continued on with this class all through high school and my teacher was one of my biggest supporters. She helped me develop scientific research, writing, and communication skills and I am forever grateful. Through the class we were also able to go on field trips to research labs which allowed me to see a lot of different career options. Then when I had her for physics my junior year, it reinforced that I wanted to major in physics at the same college as her and her brother. When I eventually got to Rollins, I knew I wanted to work with the same physics professor that they both did doing musical acoustics research. He has been extremely influential in teaching me research and presentation skills as well as introducing me to the acoustics community and helping me network. Furthermore, the physics department as my school is one of the most welcoming and personalized environments I have ever experienced. The professors all take a very hands on and personalized approach to teaching and care about us as individuals outside of the classroom. I have never been in such a supportive environment and they constantly remind me of my strengths and help me plan my future. The special part is that we have 4 female professors and 2 male professors so there is a lot of positive representation. I have also remained very close with my high school teacher and she continues to be a treasured mentor in my life.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I enjoyed my high school physics course, so when I got to college and had to choose a science general education class, I took University Physics with Calculus because I liked seeing the applications of the math classes I felt successful in. I was originally undecided, but after that course, I declared my major in Physics and have continued on that path since.
I was originally an engineering major. However, Smith only offers a general engineering degree. I liked the physics based concepts of engineering which prompted me to switch my major to physics.

I took the Physics class that was offered at my high school and liked it. So, when it came to deciding upon something to go into, I already knew that I wanted to go into a STEM field, but wasnt sure which one. So I selected Physics on my college application, about a year into the field I actually switched to an education degree, but that was still physics and science heavy. But decided to come back to physics afterdetermining that teaching at the high school/middle school level wasntfor me.

At college I fell in love with my chemistry courses and soon became a major. I also really enjoy doing math, though, so when I reached physical chemistry(Thermodynamics and Kinetics, but especially Quantum Chemistry) I was hooked.I really love the physical and mathematical aspects of chemistry and would love to become an astrochemist.

I didn`t think that I could actually become a physics major in high school because I had a very discouraging teacher who made me feel really incompetent in the major without encouraging self-efficacy of any sort. I started college in mechanical engineering but after two semesters of the courses I realized how incredibly bored I was with how empirical the physics was and when I took an intro astronomy course for extra curricular credit I realized there was no other class that made me feel the way I did learning astronomy and applying physics in large schemes and impossible approximations. I had been introduced to astronomy from a young age by my dad`s interests but I had never considered it as an option until my sophomore year of university when I realized that I was not entirely incompetent and able to pursue a difficult career if it was something I was passionate about.

-Embarrassing to admit, but I feel that my parents` obsession with star trek really got me to love the idea of space travel and other galaxies growing up.-My AP physics teacher in high school, Mr. Luna, was an amazing person. His first year as a teacher a
I decided I wanted to pursue the physics major my junior year of high school when I was taking Advanced Placement Physics. I found that it was the perfect mix of mathematical reasoning and science.

I took chemistry and AP Biology in high school. I found myself wanting to delve further into why certain things were happening. How did electrons act the way they did in chemical reactions? How is the sun able to provide all the energy to support the world? I was not satisfied with the answers biology and chemistry could provide. Then I took a physics class and the laws and sound mathematical proof and support fascinated me. I knew physics was where the answers were and that`s why I wanted to take this course. I also knew that as I did the calculations in physics and math, I couldn`t just work with numbers. I always had to know what the numbers were representing. I am not a physics major because it`s easy, but because I believe it is fundamental to understanding how our world functions.

When I was middle school student, my curiosity in science and physics developed into a passion that persists to this day. However, when I was a high school student who was tasked with figuring out what to do for the rest of my life, I did not believe that physics was the right path for me. I felt as though I was not capable enough, intelligence enough, or came from the right background to study physics. I was a first generation immigrant who did not have the grades nor the influence from others that allowed me to believe that I had what it took to become a physicist. I went with another path, nursing, which proved to be the wrong path for me. I dropped out of my nursing program in college. When it was time for me to return to college, I decided to say "why the heck not" and pursued science. Since then, I have been a devoted member of the science community at my community college. I was eventually accepted into UW physics and had the opportunity to reach out to a professor whose research I have been interested in for a while. At the present, I am a research assistant for the Axion Dark Matter Experiment at UW who contributes to the collaboration as a soft developer and a data analyst.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Task Effort), Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I have always loved science and took a physics class for the first time my senior year of high school. I found that not only did I really enjoy it, I was also really good at it.

I had a very smart high school physics teacher who is a woman and encouraged the women in the class a lot. A couple close friends that I had who went through intro physics courses with me helped improve my confidence and that helped me stick with it.

This current degree will be my second bachelors in a STEM field. I was at Auburn University for Biomedical Sciences with the intention of going to medical school. I was required to take physics 1 and physics 2 with that degree. I fell in love with the field and discussed switching my major. However, I was already a junior and decided to finish the degree I was in. After graduating from Auburn, I decided to go back to school (UAH) to pursue a degree in physics. This decision was encouraged by my mother. My maternal grandfather worked at NASA during the Apollo missions. I`ve always had a fascination with space but never knew how to get there, how to be in a field that studied space. I finally landed on physics being the best link to get to that point and I`ve enjoyed every quirk, every "that`s funny" moment physics has had to offer.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: Ever since I was real young I enjoyed astronomy. My uncle was my biggest supporter until High School. There my chemistry and physics teacher found out not only did I do well in both physics and chemistry but I enjoy astronomy. It was then he introduced the idea of astrophysics to me. After that I knew I wanted to become an astrophysicist I just did not now how I would get there. It wasn`t until I began my education at Lawrence Tech that I began forming ideas of what exactly I would like to do with my life (both education and career goals). Lawrence Tech and my first CUWiP have influenced my career choices greatly.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I had a great high school physics teacher who saw my potential and made the subject very interesting and easy to understand. It seemed like the perfect fit for my technologically-inclined mind.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: I took my first physics course my junior year of high school.  I understood it really well, scored high, and enjoyed it. Following this, I took every physics course and AP test offered at my high school, and really enjoyed them.  However, I always thought I would end up becoming a mechanical engineer, especially because my senior year capstone project was an engineering project.  However, about a month before I arrived at college, I found a majors-only physics class that I really wanted to take, so I "temporarily" was going to switch my major.  As soon as I had done this, I received emails from recruiting physics research groups.  I found one that really grabbed my interest, and even related to my previous engineering project.  I applied, and against all odds, was accepted to this research group as a freshman.  I am really enjoying the work so far, and I figure that if I keep finding myself being drawn to physics, I would enjoy a career in physics.  Following this, I switched my major to physics, where I now intend to keep it.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I enjoyed high school physics and thought it was a good practical major to pursue in college. It was the first "serious" academic thing I really enjoyed besides art/theater and I knew it was much more stable than either of those career options, so I picked and pursued Physics.

I began to like physics when my brother took it in high school. I have always loved science and when I got to high school, during my junior year, I was finally able to take a physics course. I thoroughly enjoyed the course and took the next level course my senior year. These classes really were the inspiration for me to become a physics major. I am currently taking a physics course and have learned so much. I am still loving physics and want to continue it in the future.

I took a keen interest in space science my freshman year of college. It wasn`t until I took a physics course during my sophomore year of college and found a lot of interesting topics that had to do with how our world "works". I found it fascinating that it was all explained by many fields in physics. Afterward, I switched my major from aerospace engineering to astrophysics in hopes to thoroughly and deeply understand the underlying reality that we experience.

My degree is in Engineering Physics. I am interested more in the applications and uses of physics in every day life. I have a background in Aircraft Maintenance and I can recall working on a component whose location made no sense as it often required replacement but was extremely difficult to access. I want to bring the perspective of someone who will eventually be working on my components and I have a desire to understand how and why dynamic components work the way they do. So I chose a degree pathway that would be able to merge the theoretical and the applications.

A perpetually curious child, science was always my favourite subject. However, my high school did not have a very strong science program. I became rather discouraged and looked into pursuing a different degree in college. I signed up for an introductory physics class only because it was a common prerequisite. My father, a physicist himself, encouraged me but I had no intention of studying the subject further. That first proved to be the absolute worst class I had ever been in. I was not used to challenging material. My late exposure to physics left me feeling at a disadvantage. I expected to do poorly which inspired me to not try to succeed. I only signed up for the second introductory physics course because it was also required for many interesting majors, dreading it. A few weeks into the course I was hooked. I would go to office hours and chat with the professor about how the concepts we were learning applied to space travel and lightening and superheroes and everything in between. In his office is where I learned that physics really is the study of everything. I hungered to explore the universe and physics promised me a fascinating, never-ending journey.
Codes: Attainment Value, Cost (Outside Effort), Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic Value

Response: When I was young, I stayed up late one night watching a Nova episode about the race to the moon. I was so fascinated by all the cool things we could achieve with science. I thought for the remainder of elementary school that I wanted to be a rocket scientist. Eventually, that changed to me wanting to be a physicist. I`m not really sure why that stuck with me for so long. Sometimes I wonder whether I would have chosen physics if I hadn`t picked it at such an early age. When I was in high school, I was in a 3 year long science research program. We each picked a topic in any field of science and researched and presented our topics over the course of three years. I hadn`t had any physics background when I started, so I chose a topic in chemistry. However, the skills I gained from that class (reading journal articles, writing scientific papers, working in a research lab, giving presentations about my research, etc.) were very valuable to me. I did really well in that program, and it confirmed that I wanted to study science in college. I`ve struggled with my classes a bit since coming to college. I`ve ended up doing fine each semester, but I often question whether I`m in the right major because it`s so hard. However, the research I`m doing at my university has really motivated me to keep going. I really like what I do, and I know that one day I`ll be done with classes and will be able to focus on the aspects of physics that are truly important to me.
Codes: Media Triggered, Event Triggered, Cost (Task Effort)

Response: I`ve always enjoyed looking at the moon and stars so my mother eventually got me an astronomy book when I was young and bought me a telescope. I really wanted to be a scientist because I wanted to be like the forensic scientists that I saw on crime shows. I looked up to them a lot, in particular, Abby from NCIS. My family watched that a lot. When I did start doing science in high school, I did well but I eventually did not want anything to do with biology and I liked chemistry more. However the best part of chemistry I found to be things that dealt with the atom and subatomic particles. So I switched my interest back to physics as this part of chemistry was based more on physics. In addition I could rejoin my love of astronomy. I also watched Angels and Demons while I was young, which lead me to read the book and I then read more about particle physics as it fascinated me. My mother always encouraged me by buying random books she saw in bookstores on topics I had voiced my interest in. That`s how I came to pursue physics at university.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Social Persuasion

Response: Although I have enough credits to be considered a senior, this is my third year at Bowling Green State University and I???m a sophomore in the Physics program. However, this is the fourth college I have attended and the second degree that I have attempted. My first degree is a B. A. in Film and Television Production from the Columbia College Hollywood in Tarzana, CA. For most of my life ??? because of movies like the ???Back to the Future??? and ???Star Trek??? franchises ??? I wanted a career in the entertainment industry. But after obtaining a degree and working on several projects, my interests turned more and more towards the subject of a class I had taken my senior year called ???Space Sciences: Orbital Mechanics and Rocket Science.??? It was in this class that I first discovered what gravity was and after that, I read every book I could understand about cosmology, relativity and quantum physics. Finally, I was forced to return to school in order to satisfy my intense desire to know everything about the Universe. My interests in physics varies from exploring the nature of time and relativity (which could lead to breakthroughs in ???faster-than-light??? travel) to observed gravitational distortions like black holes to contributing to the search for exo-planets and the long term goal of the human race becoming a truly space-faring species. More recently, I???ve gained a new interest in radio astronomy from my research experience at SETI; light in its various forms is too bizarre and compelling to not be explored from every perspective! In addition to my own curiosity about the nature of everything, I believe that science encourages critical thinking which leads to a more enlightened society, making science communication invaluable. My unique background in the entertainment industry combined with my breadth of coursework and life experience can allow me to help make science more approachable. I also believe that this past experience, my planned undergraduate curriculum of courses and my intense passion for physics will prepare me for a doctoral program focused on particle astrophysics and a career in theoretical research. After graduating with a B.S. in Physics and minors in Astronomy, Math and Computer Science, I plan to attend a doctoral program in theoretical astrophysics. Following grad school, I would like to apply to do post-doctoral research and perhaps one day be able to head my own research team a university or laboratory.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: I wanted to become a physics major once I had taken physics in high school junior year. At that level, it`s the first science class you take where math has a very large role, which I enjoyed. I still really enjoy physics in college, as well as the math courses that go along with it. I was not particularly influenced by anyone in my personal life to become a physics major, but had a series of wonderful and encouraging teachers who recognized I had an aptitude for math and science, and were always happy to answer my questions.

I`ve always been interested in the sciences -- I have loved math since I was taught to count, tried to build my own computers out of paper when our family computer was in use, played with dinosaur figurines as frequently as I played with dolls, and voluntarily lost myself in the depths of the universe via any and every book I could get my hands on. I thought I might very much like to be a "scientist when I grew up but didn`t really know what the field of "physics" was or anything about it until high school

My uncle had a degree in environmental engineering and Itook an interest in the environment as a result of him.I soon realized that one of the best ways to help theenvironment (alternative energy research, in my opinion)involved physics heavily, so I have gone into it as aresult.
My college doesnÕt have a WiP, but I have been nothing but entirely astounded by the inclusiveness by my department. I think the inclusiveness in my department is something to truly aspire too.

I was initially afraid of taking high school physics because I heard that boys tend to do better than girls in that class. However, I ended up loving physics because my high school teacher was a brilliant teacher and physics enthusiast. I did a great number of labs in that class. In fact, I did so many cool labs (photoelectric effect, measuring the speed of light, predicting where a ball falling down a ramp would land, muon detection, centripetal force on a big spinning merry-go-around) that my college intro physics lab was almost all repeats.Coming into college, I was thinking of engineering, but I fell in love with the physics department. The professors knew my name and would have meals with me and other students. They really cared about each individual student. I think I started considering a physics major at that point.My interest in renewable energy led me to organic photovoltaics research with one of my college`s physics faculty over the summer. That research inspired me to take more physics and chemistry classes. Now, I am off the engineering track, and well into the physics/chemistry/material science subjects.
Codes: Cost (Emotional), Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic (Social), Event Triggered

Response: I spent the first two years of college completely undecided, but seemed to be taking more math and science courses than any other subjects. I took a contemporary physics seminar. My interest was peaked and I had a million questions. I really enjoyed the topics presented, and thought maybe physics would a good fit for me since its a broad field. Shortly after a physics professor gave me a lab tour, then offered me a chance to do undergraduate research. I gladly accepted, and soon after declared myself a physics major.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered, Social Persuasion

Response: I was studying abroad in Japan and realized that the courses and major I was studying under (psychology and Japanese) were no longer for me. After some introspection, I realized I had always looked up at the sky and loved astronomy. I then researched job outlooks and course curricula for astronomy/astrophysics and decided that it would be worth it to me to pursue a career in a field of physics.

I always enjoyed the math and sciences. I first becameinterested in Physics in high school thanks to myphysics teacher. He made learning about physics fun andenjoyable. I also enjoyed physics because it was finallya science that was completely math based especially to thedegree of calculus. As I was able to participate invarious physics labs my interest in physics grew. Istarted off as a Math major, then I added a physics major,but now I am working towards a physics major with a mathminor. My various co-ops have also continued my interestin physics and more specifically in the field ofacoustics.

I was a chemistry major that slowly became disinterested in the subject and I dropping out of college was a frequent thought. I was the Physics Club treasurer at the time so I was familiar with the physics faculty. Our electronics professor got me into the lab. I was introduced to the raspberry pi and coding. All I did was make an LED blink but I was immediately hooked. I changed my major and haven`t looked back. Our department has almost a 50/50 ratio of males to females. We form a supportive environment and all work together to be successful. Without those connections and the personal relationships with each professor, I would not be graduating in May with a BS in Physics.

My mom took me to astronomy lectures given at our local university when I was a kid. The professor will lead us to the school`s telescope afterwards to observe. I knew then that I loved physics and astronomy.
Codes: Social Persusion, Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: My interest in physics and astrophysics began when I was 15 and starting looking at astrophotography. Before then, I wasn`t really the best at math or science, but the more I learned about astronomy and the universe, I started diving further into the field.

My dad spent a lot of time with me as a child and young adult discussing physical phenomena, and I read some of Richard Feynman`s lectures which interested me greatly. Also my mom proved to me that any woman can be successful in male-dominated professions, since she`s had success in finance at a high level.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Vicarious Experience

Response: In high school, my physics teacher was your stereotypical old man who liked to blow stuff up, and that caught my initial attention.I was really into math at the time, I was on the math team and spent all of my free hours doing calculus. I was fascinatedby the way my teacher could explain real-life properties using math. The example that really blew my mind was when he would telltall tales of how he won state track championships coaching the long jump because he supposedly calculated the best angles for eachathlete to take off at. Whether he actually did it or not was another story. I was pretty good at other subjects in school,especially English, but it did not hold my interest the way physics did. I chose to pursue an education in physics because I knew there was so much left for me to learn, and it was exciting. The difficulty of the coursework was intimidating, but did not scare meoff because I figured the only things worth doing in life get difficult. Now I am studying at Central Methodistunder a professor who really invests himself into making sure the physics students are learning, which is great.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Task Effort), Physiological/Emotional

Response: In 8th grade, I read A Briefer History of Time by Stephen Hawking, after which I began to consider physics as a field to consider pursuing academically. During the summer before my senior year in high school, I attended the International Summer School for Young Physicists at the Perimeter Institute in Waterloo, Canada. This was a 2 week program in which participants had daily lectures on advanced theories, such as special and general relativity. It was an incredible experience, and I was sure at that point that I wanted to become a physicist. In those 2 weeks, we also had the opportunity to visit the Sudbury Neutrino Observatory Lab, where I witnessed the nature of experimental physics. I do not have a strong high school background in physics since calculus was never introduced in my physics classes, so I do lack self confidence as a physics student; however, I am certain that this is the field I want to take part in because I absolutely enjoy it.
Codes: Media Triggered, Event Triggered, Cost (Emotional), Physiological/Emotional

Response: Originally I wanted to be a biology major, because I love being outside with plants an animals. Then I felt overwhelmed by large chemistry classes. When I came back to school, I wanted to be an environmental science major, because I wanted to help communities like my home town in California deal with drought. After taking a lot of chemistry, biology and math, I decided that being an engineer was a better way to help communities dealing with drought, and also a better way to help myself be successful in what I do. Now I am on a civil (water resources) engineering transfer track.
I love Physics

I fell in love with physics in high school and knew I wanted to pursue the field in college along with my biochemistry degree. Since taking my first collegiate physics course though, I found an even deeper love for the material and its ability to explain the world. I began my senior thesis this past summer at an focused ultrasound lab and this only heightened what I already felt towards physics along with my passion for research. Now, I partake in every job possible within my physics department including that of learning and teaching assistant, tutor, and homework grader. Each of these have not only pushed me to pursue my PhD in physics but to one day become a professor.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Event Triggered

Response: When I realized that I didn`t enjoy Chemistry, and also when the first episode of Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey came onto Television.When I got my first telescope and saw the craters on the moon, as well as the 4 largest moons of Jupiter.When I took Honors Physics in high school and enjoyed it, and also took AP Chemistry and detested it.

I took AP Physics in high school. I went in thinking I would hate it but I came to really love it and over time, it easily became what I wanted to do permanently. I got to Furman University and really found a community in the physics department that only strengthened my love of the science. The professors and other students are encouraging, involved, and do lots of research, including research along the lines of my current physics goal: astrophysics.
None I have always loved science

For most of my life, I had no idea what I wanted to be and enjoyed just about anything new. I decided I wanted to do something in the hard sciences after taking AP Chemistry. Due to timing and my study abroad experience, Physics was the only science class I didn`t take. In high school, I took biology, chemistry, and Earth science so at Lawrence I decided to take Physics. I decided to become a Physics major after taking Modern Physics, my third term of the Physics sequence and fell in love with it.

I had the opportunity to be a founding member of a FIRST robotics team my senior year of high school and I fell in love with robotics and physics. This inspired me to pursue physics in my undergraduate studies and has allowed me to become a mentor for the team I helped found. My love for space and learning about our universe has also continued to push me towards physics and understanding the world and universe around me.
Performing summer research under my physics professor. I also am interested in starting a WiP group at m University.

My parents encouraged STEM sense I was about 5 years old. In Middle school I meet some engineers who created my interest in engineering fields to sky-rocket. Then in high school I took my schools IB physics course which I had a tun of fun in and was the only reason I wanted to go to school my senior year of high school.

I had dreamed of being an astronaut after seeing a lunar eclipse when I was 6. From there I delved into books and shows to learn all about space I could, eventually learning of the profession astrophysics. Once I made that discovery it was only a matter of waiting until I could take high school physics courses and then apply to university as an astrophysics major.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Event Triggered

Response: I have always been more orientated towards math and science and knew that I would major in a related topic. Engineering was much too hands on for my taste and Pure and Applied Mathematics were not practical enough. I took physics in High School and liked it, but did not do amazing so I wrote off physics as a potential option for me. In university, I had to re-take physics as I had not taken it calculus based as part of a potential computer science major. I did much better than I had in high school and suddenly I thought of it as an option for myself again. Over the summer between my Freshman and Sophomore year, I found a youtube channel of someone completing their Ph.D in Physics and I was really intrigued and decided that I wanted to pursue physics. In the years since, I have loved most of my classes and have been constantly fascinated with what physical phenomena we can describe with physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Task Effort), Mastery Experience, Media Triggered

Response: I have always been incredibly interested in meteorology. However, I never considered it as a career until my introduction to meteorology course I took the first semester of my freshman year. Since I didn`t want to transfer colleges, and our school doesn`t have a meteorology program, I decided that a major in physics was what I should do. My decision to pursue graduate studies in atmospheric electricity stemmed from interesting discussions in my Electricity and Magnetism/Modern Physics courses.

I was originally interested in aviation which is was originally drew me into physics. I then fell in love with all the math that was related to the topics we discussed and decided to still pursue the degree even after deciding not to pursue aviation.

It all started with my first Physics class in High School, my teacher started to talk about space and black holes,it all was so fascinating. I gave allot of efficiencies to this class, we built a roller coaster out of legos (from scratch) and a rocket made out of recycled materials. It was fun and all so very interesting. When the time came to apply for college I didn`t know whether to apply for Biology or Physics. I went to an open house at the University of Puerto Rico in Humacao (my institute), got lost in the natural science building and stumbled upon one the Physics class room, where there were giving a conference about what did the department offer and the benefits. It made everything all so clear, it was destiny if you ask me. Once I started and took my first Physics course with Prof. Juan Cersocimo, doors started to opened. He directed me to Prof. Idalia Ramos (my mentor) to begin my first research investigation. I started working at the PREM program (Partnership for Research and Education in Materials) preparing Chitosan nanofibers and GaN nanoparticles. During the year 2014 I participated in PREM`s Spring Symposium, PREM`s summer camp (Experiment with PREM) as an assistant to the faculty, and the 11th Annual Meeting the past November 21st, which I presented a poster titled ???Preparation and Characterization and GaN/Chitosan nanofibers???. In the future I plan to proceed my investigation, enhancing the GaN nanoparticles`s optical properties and apply for Graduate School.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered, Social Persuasion

Response: A few months after starting learning Physics my friend invited me to join him to a talk by Kip Thorn in Barcelona, which I gladly enjoyed. For the first time I felt like part of something big, something outside of high-school. A little later my Physics teacher connected me with a professor at the local university, who let me do some fun experiments in their lab in Marseille. It was a very calming experience, as opposed to the usual time pressure of group labs. I chose all of my schools based on what I thought would be a good place to study Physics, and, shortly after receiving my Carleton College application approval letter, I graduated as the best Physical Sciences student of my school.The initial reason, or rather a kick, for why I started doing Physics, was that I had nothing to say in my friends` discussions. They were into STEM and I felt terribly isolated. I had some interest, so I put all of my free time into science. In the end I lost one of these friends to envy for my progress, but I found out science is something I actually want to do in my life, and it became one of my most important independent life choices.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Event Triggered, Mastery Experience, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Intrinsic Value

Response: For the longest time I refused to consider Physics as an option because my father is an Astrophysicist. However, that all changed when I took AP Physics C in high school and found the problem sets more fun than the biochem research I was doing. Upon entering UChicago, I took Honors Intro Physics and from then on I`ve been hooked. It is hard to maintain that initial level of enthusiasm; I had attended a girls` school for all of my life, so the shift to a male-dominated atmosphere was difficult to handle. It still is at times, and it has been weighing on me as I consider my options for post-BA work.

I didn`t consider physics at all until I ended up doing research in it my senior year of high school. My mechanics class was interesting, but I thought I was meant to be a doctor. I really enjoyed the experience I got in the lab, even if I had no idea what I was doing some of the time. I wanted to be in a biology lab, but ended up in chemical physics and it was such a great misplacement. The grad students that I worked with opened my eyes to the physics, and the professor was always very supportive.

I decided to be an astrophysics major during freshman orientation. I had previously had interest in space, but throughout high school I was considering biochemistry. The summer after high school I realized that I didn`t really know what biochemists would actually do for a career, and I remembered that I had an interest in space, so I decided to major in astrophysics. It was difficult adjusting at first because I never took a physics class before, but I`ve really enjoyed it.

My high school physics teacher was very encouraging of exploring physics. When I first took physics I started to read popular science books and look up interesting articles on the internet. I`ve always loved math and science and I appreciate both the abstraction and the realism of physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value

Response: I spent the previous two years in college as an Asian studies major, and had not been enjoying my classes, so I began to search for other areas I may be interested in. I have always had an interest in astronomy, and had enjoyed an astronomy class in my first year, but there is no astronomy major at my school, so I took a physics major instead with a minor in astronomy.

I was always strong in sciences and math in HS. I had a great AP Physics teacher in HS who really turned me on to physics. I continued to fall in love with physics my freshman year in the intro courses. After I declared my major, the classes became much more involved and difficult, but that just added to the excitement. I got involved in research my sophomore year, and am now working on a second completely different project.
most interesting subject I`ve ever come across

I chose to pursue physics as a junior in high school as I was taking a physics related class called math and mechanics. From there I applied to FSU under the assumption that I would be pursuing a degree in physics. I have been very happy in my physics classes since then, and started doing research in high energy physics which I love. I loved the challenging nature of physics, and the fact that it forces one to think analytically about a problem. It is not memorizing information, and it applies in so many different fields.

I am influenced by discovery channel from a young age. At age 7, my uncle gave me a entire set of encyclopedia and that opens the door of science to me. And I am engrossed in astronomy and solar system planets in middle school. Gradually, studying the space becomes something that I aspired to do for my career.
Curiosity as a child, reading books.
I considered physics degree in high school while taking AP physics. During that class we did experiments and such that peaked my interest and I also found that I was fairly good at it.

At a young age, I had a calling to be a high school teacher, which only continued my junior year in high school as I developed a passion for learning physics. My passion developed because of my high school physics teacher. He introduced interesting topics throughout my junior year of high school. This lead me to continue my education in physics, my senior year of high school. From there, I decided to declare physics and secondary education my official major. Today, I am excited to have to opportunity to open new doors that combines these passions.
Codes: Utility Value, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: I have always known that science was the direction I wanted to go in. There was always something about making discoveries and finding out answers to questions that lit the fire. I took AP Physics, along with AP biology my senior year in high school and fell in love with both. Of course, it was confusing and challenging and I really did struggle at first. But I started watching physics videos outside of school. I joined the astronomy club. I would spend the little free time I had during school hours, talking with my physics teacher and trying to make sense or find out more about what we were learning. By the time winter of my senior year came around, I realized that I enjoyed putting in the effort to make sense of the world around me. Physics challenged me in a way no other class could, and once I realized that I loved putting in hard work and effort into physics, I knew that physics was the direction I wanted to go. There was something about physics (especially within the astronomy realm) that pushed me. I decided that I have too many questions about this world to continue asking my high school teacher, I wanted to figure out the answers myself. And that`s what I plan to do.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional

Response: From the beginning stages of learning with block letters and children`s books up to the second semester of my freshman year in high school, I was lucky enough to be homeschooled by my mother and father. I have been taught to ask questions, surpass the average, and not to allow others to put a boundary on my potential. My grandfather worked as an electrical engineer at Lockheed Martin throughout the 60s and 70s sending multiple satellite missions into space. His accounts of daily work, launches, and over all pride in his work inculcated in me curiosity about the world, space, and physics. Since hearing of my grandfather???s work when I was but a young child, I have had my attention drawn to as many sources of physics, space, and explorative engineering news that I could find. I made the decision to major in physics before I finished high school and hit the ground running at my current institution, Seattle University. The faculty at SeattleU has further opened my eyes to different branches of physics, the possibilities that this major can present to me, and also they have acted as reliable and inspiring advisers. Furthermore, my classmates as well as those one and two years above me have acted as role models with study habits, dedication to the subject, and always providing new challenges to accomplish as a team. Overall this major has instilled in me a great sense of pride not only in myself but in the physics community I am now a part of worldwide.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic (Social), Physiological/Emotional

Response: Brian Greene inspired me to pursue the philosophical knowledge that comes with physics
I fell in love with my high school physics class and before I knew it I was only looking forward to do my physics homework.

Since my father was a High School Physics teacher, he alwaysliked to challenge me with word problems, or easy physics problems. When I realized that I had a knack for solving these problems when I was in middle school, I thought I should give physics a try. After looking through a couplephysics books, I fell in love with the subject and have never looked back.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Media Triggered

Response: Liked physical oceanography. My college didn`t have an oceanography program so I did physics. Have done research in environmental science including physical oceanography.

i have always been really excited about science and physics in general. From the first time I took physics in high school all the way though college I always thought that physics was super fun and that I would excel in the subject. I also didn`t see many females getting excited about physics and science like Ii was and I would very much like to work on changing that.

IÕm not a physics major. I am a physics minor and largely due to my physics teacher. She makes the topics interesting and relatable. She never gives up on trying to make sure that we learn and understand concepts. Due to this as well as other characteristics she makes learning accessible and non intimidating.

The biggest factor in my decision to major in physics was my high school physics teacher. He saw that I had a talent for physics and he was the first person to make me seriously consider it as a career. He presented me with an opportunity to attend a summer astrophysics program before my senior year in high school. He also took extra time to teach me and a few other students a physics course that was not offered in the school curriculum. If it were not for him I would not be doing what I am doing today. I am still good friends with him to this day because of all that he has done to help me.

I knew I wanted to be in STEM, I took bio, chem, and physics in highschool but physics was the most interesting to me. I feel like it embodies most other subjects and does so practically. So I chose to be a physics major and do not regret it!

I became a physics major after spending two years in university studying literature and political science with a plan to go to law school. This took place 2015. I was interested in the factual evidence supplied by physics and wanted to understand the world around me in a more scientific way.

I`ve always known that I had an interest in science. It wasn`t until my high school physics class where I realized how much I enjoyed physics. Seeing my teacher have fun with interactive demonstrations and have an overall positive and encouraging attitude towards the subject made me think "I want to learn more about this!". My guidance counselor come time for college applications wasn`t as encouraging about what I said I wanted to study in college. In any case, she handed me a list of mostly ivy league reach schools that I knew I wouldn`t get in to or could afford. My parents had me go to my local community college first. I applied as a potential "business" major but on registration day switched to chemistry. I was just feeling lost and misguided, and had quite honesty forgotten my feelings for physics. I spent a year doing the general required classes. Once I got into the upper-level chemistry classes I floundered a bit, and switched my major again to "general science". I then took general biology courses and then noticed I was just a few classes shy of the associates in physics. So, along with having completed an associates in general science, I went forward and really started my college career in physics. That was a decision I do not regret. After completing my associate`s in physics, I transferred my credits to Rutgers, and found that I really enjoy nuclear science and biophysics.

My highschool at one point had a phenomenally wealthy donor give the funds to build a decent sized observatory. Those of us in the astronomy and physics class got to learn to use it, and go to nights where we`d stargaze. I also had a great physics and astronomy teacher in higschool.My friend`s dad was also in the process of a astrophysics postdoc.

The beginning moment is like most others in high school, my physics teacher was in a rock band and a lumberjack... this made class openly creative. The last two months of classes we had an independent project, so I built a 6ft Dobsonian telescope. From the moment of building a telescope, I knew I had wanted to be a telescope technician/ invent new forms of optics. However to be an adequate astronomer/engineer I must be knowledgable in the realm physics, thus, I am an undergraduate physics student wanting to pursue an astronomy Ph.D..
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: Since I was little I always had an interest in Astronomy from watching documentaries and specials on Astronomy related topics. As I grew up I became more interested in science and then to physics, since in most schools Astronomy and Physics are taught together. By the time I was in High School and was taking much more advanced science courses I started to rule out the sciences that I did not have interest in and eventually narrowed it down to Chemistry or Physics. After taking a Physics course in High School and enjoying the material I decided to major in Physics since that is the science I had the most interest in (plus Astronomy is with Physics therefore made much more appealing). Even though my parents did not get much education and don`t really know what Physics was I was always interested to know more since it can apply to everything around us and there is still a lot more things that need explanations and proofs in the Physics field.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional

Response: I`ve honestly always been interested in the way things worked but was always slightly intimidated by physics growing up. It wasn`t until I took Mechanics and became a physics learning assistant that I considered changing my major. The deciding factor was actually two of my professors telling me they wished I was a physics major because I thought like a physicists. Shortly after that I changed my major and its been love ever since!
Codes: Cost (Task Effort), Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: I had always been interested in physics and astronomy as a child, but in high school, I got more interested in programming and robotics. I was planning to major in mechatronics engineering, but I sat in on an upper-division physics class taught by the professor who is now my thesis advisor and thought "I have to take this class." To put it simply, I liked the department at my school, and I liked that class. I didn`t make the wrong choice.

As a child, I have always been interested in the way things work, and constructing things. In high school, my physics teacher was incredibly inspiring. The amount that he knew and how he managed to tie it all together was amazing, everything seemed to make sense. It was for this same reason I chose to take physics for a natural science sequence as a general education requirement in college. My professors were incredibly supportive and I have always loved that physics seems to tie together all the sciences, as well as math. There is so much to be learned and physics is the subject area that has it all. There are also so many different aspects to physics and areas to research and I love that there are so many opportunities to learn and discover.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion

Response: I started off as a pre-med student wanting to major in chemistry. I had to take two physics courses as a requirement for the major. While taking these courses.....I fell in love. I found physics to be interesting, attention grabbing and really cool that by understanding the concepts and learning the math I could describe the world around me and how it worked. At least at a very basic level. So I wanted to learn more. I decided to minor since I didn`t discover physics until my sophomore year. But after talking to my advisers and checking my schedule I found out Junior year that I could actually major in physics. So I took my chance on the major that I actually loved. And here I am today.

My interest in physics stemmed from my interest in astronomy. I took an astronomy course in high school, and my teacher took special interest in me because I was the youngest in the class and obviously loved the subject. He suggested I take AP physics with him. I took the class and loved it, so he suggested I take AP physics 2 and AP physics C the next year, which I did. The subject was so perfect for me because there is no memorization, its all problem solving. Understand the concepts, and it`s easy to apply what you`re learning to multiple situations.

The first time I took physics was in high school, and at that point, it seemed like the most inaccessible subject. I failed a lot of quizzes and tests, and that demotivated me. However, I figured I was learning it wrong. So I took it upon myself to teach it to myself, and that`s when I started appreciating the subject and eventually falling in love with it. I also met a great teacher who taught me how to learn physics, so I owe it to him!
Codes: Cost (Task Effort), Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: I`ve always been interested in Astronomy and I tried doing some research and decided that`s what I wanted to do. There were definitely plenty of doubts along the way.

All my life, my parents encouraged me to do well in math (I come from a low-income family and am a first generation American and college student, so they wanted me to do well financially). It wasn`t a problem, as I seemed to be good in math and actually liked it. I also had a fascination with space, and made it a point to tell everyone and everything that I was going to be an astronaut.   In the country my parents came from, women were well respected in those fields (enginnering). I later transferred to a specialized math and science boarding high school in Maine, just to get away from it all and see if I really wanted to pursue a career in math and science. This is where things really started to get bad. Being a generally shy/sensitive person, I was thrown into classes where I ended up being one of two or three girls in a room packed with guys(I`m thinking mostly of my CS/Robotics classes) - it wouldn`t have been such a problem if they didn`t all have this superiority complex. It really got to me, and it seemed like they were way ahead of me academically and much more knowledgeable than me, that I felt that there was no way I could go into math/science. I felt sooo out of place. Then I happened to take my first astronomy class. I was lucky enough to have the teacher I did - If it wasn`t for him, I don`t think I would ever have thought to declare a physics major here at Mount Holyoke. he reminded me of my love for astronomy/physics - he would to get me to work harder, to not give up in not just his class but in my other math/physics classes as well. He made sure to remind me nearly everyday that I am capable of doing anything, no matter my gender and what field I want to pursue. Me, who thought very little of myself, honestly really needed to hear this. Because of this experience, I am now going to be an astrophysicist - I plan to major in physics (with an astronomy concentration), and minor in CS. I couldn`t be happier :)
Codes: Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Cost (Emotional)

Response: Most of the motivation to initially pursue physics came from my aptitude in math and science courses in high school and my dad encouraging me to pursue it. Going into my sophomore year of college, I was doubting whether I wanted to be a physics major or not. I didn`t have a close relationship with any of the professors nor did I have any guidance for the questions I had (and still do) about what I wanted to do with a physics major. My first semester of sophomore year, I started building relationships with some of my classmates (I am the only female student) and one of the professors in the department. These relationships helped me feel more comfortable in the major. Second semester of my sophomore year we were introduced to quantum mechanics and nuclear physics. This was the first time I was intensely fascinated with what I was learning and that feeling has only increased since then. I spent my summer after sophomore year working for the professor I had formed a relationship with designing experiments in nuclear physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Matery Experience, Intrinsic (Social), Intrinsic Value

Response: My father encouraged I study science because I had outstanding understanding of it from a young age. He took me star gazing, had be read Stephen Hawking books and Scientific Americans, and took me to any science festivals that were going on in the Triangle area.When I graduated high school, it was only natural that I go into physics and continue that path my father had started for me.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Event Triggered

Response: On the first day of AP Physics in high school, my teacher sent us in groups to lab tables covered in random equipment and said "Okay, now figure out the spring constant of this spring." He did not give any equations, instructions, or direction, and I think the experimental curiosity and critical thinking that this problem solving activity demanded really drew me into scientific inquiry, particularly in Physics. I have always been interested in Mathematics, and after taking a few Physics classes at the college level I fell in love with how the natural world can be explained numerically. In terms of my research interest in the field of Education, I have always loved learning and the academic environment.

The first time I knew I was going to major in physics was not until senior year of high school. I grew up with a grandfather in love with astrophysics, I also loved it, but I did not know that it was considered physics.  I always heard how people hate physics, how awful it was.  I did not know until first hand that physics was actually, amazing. My high school teacher saw that I had a natural talent with physics and told me if I liked it, I should pursue it.  I have never second guessed myself, physics was a great choice for me.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Mastery Experience

Response: My father was a physics major and got his Masters in Nuclear Physics. So, growing up he would tell me all about it and would talk about how amazing physics was, and so when I got to college I decided that a good knowledge about physics would be both interesting and a good way to get a good knowledge about the world and how it works.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion

Response: When I was I kid I was always fascinated by space, the stars, how the world worked, I even remember telling my dad that I`d understand all of it one day, even string theory and quantum mechanics. For a while I became intimidated by physics and science due to how much work it would take, I did not believe I was smart enough or that I would realistically be able to do so much schooling, so I fell back on the option of striving to become a nurse like my older sister and many other female members of my family. In high school I took a physics class and fell in love, but still I was intimidated by calculus. I took a risk and set my major as Physics anyway, at that point I had at least realized that I didn`t want to be a nurse. I wasn`t absolutely certain that Physics is what I wanted to do until the first month of college when I realized how much I would be missing out on by ever leaving physics, how strong fighting through all of the fear and intimidation would make me. Now I am certain that I will keep with the physics major until the very end.

I love to challenge myself and, as a high school student, saw that women were not seen or represented very often in the Physics community. I had the good fortune of having a female research scientist teach my AP physics classes. It is because of her that I became so interested in Physics. Well, that and the fact that I wanted to make a name for myself as the only female student interested in Physics in my high school.At my university, a liberal arts institution, I am currently one of five women in undergraduate Physics. It has been hard being the gender-minority in a classroom (to the point where I would be the only one in a class of six), and often I would find myself comparing my intelligence with my classmates and wondering if I was less intelligent. Thankfully, due to support from my professors and my stubborn inability to back down from a challenge, I`ve stayed with the Physics department and am now doing research for my astrophysics professor.I wouldn`t have it any other way. I love physics.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Cost (Emotional), Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I did not have a specific source of inspiration. I have always loved science, specifically astronomy. My dad, who has a degree in physics, always encouraged by to pursue the interest. However, I didn`t consider an actual career in physics until I was applying to college, just because I was not really aware it was a path I could realistically pursue, outside of a more applied field like engineering.My high school calculus teacher also played a part in showing me that higher math, or math in general could be enjoyable, and giving examples of careers that existed in math and science.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: I first took physics in my sophomore year of high school and fell in love with the subject. I didn`t do very well the first time I took it (partly because of my teachers method which was to give us practice problems and then a test with no lecturing or reviewing of problems) but I knew that I wanted to understand more. I`ve taken physics every year since and knew by my senior year of high school that it was the subject for me.

In 7th grade I became very interested in astronomy, and wanted to become an astronomer after watching Carl Sagan`s `Cosmos`. Then, I realized that studying astronomy would require a lot of physics knowledge, so I made the effort to take as many physics courses in high school as possible. Towards the end of high school I realized that physics as a whole is very interesting to me so I decided to keep going with it and made it my major for college.
I developed a strong interest in the universe and knew since 5th grade that was the only thing I wanted to spend my time pursuing. My high school math teacher encouraged to pursue Astrophysics.

When I came to college as a first year, I was afraid to tell people that I was a physics major since it wasn`t the subject I scored the highest in my high school. I was very much dissuaded by my teachers. However, on coming to college, I got involved with the physics department and the several activities and opportunities they provided. The fellow upperclassmen encouraged me and helped me a lot to feel confident about my ability to do math and comprehend physics concepts.

I had female professors and I took special relativity as my first college physics course. I really enjoyed it and from then on considered to be a physics major. I was afraid to become a physics major because of the difficulty, since I had more experience in computer science. However, I always enjoyed my physics courses more than my computer science courses so that was the time I decided to do physics.

I took physics in high school and found I really enjoyed it because it explained how things you see everyday happens the way they do. My physics teacher in high school was very supportive and patient with answering all my questions when I didn`t understand how to do a problem.
