I took a physics class in high school and really liked it. I started liking the topics it covered a lot earlier in high school. When I got to college I came in as a theatre major but needed a minor, and physics would be something i was interested in, and so I just made it another major.

I have always liked math and science. I have enjoyed working with numbers and solving equations especially when in high school. It wasn`t until this semester when my physics professor told me that I should attend this conference to expand and explore possible career options.He believes that I am a good and intelligent student.Since I really like math and science, and I don`t know where to go with them I am hoping that by going to this conference it can help me decide what I want to do.
I have always enjoyed physics and I decided that it is something I can see myself doing for a long long time.

I am a non-traditional student (i.e. I am returning to school to complete my first bachelor`s degree at 39 years of age). As I was rasing my children and working in the healthcare field, I read every book I could get my hands on about physics; from cosmology to particle physics, I was enthralled.  What I found I was lacking was a deeper understanding of the mathmatical concepts and I longed to make a contribution to understanding the world around me- and inside me.  I decided to pursue a formal education in the field and beleive to my core that I can make significant contributions to our understanding of the natural world.

I began considering physics as a career when I became instrested in quantum physics. I never took physics in Highschool the school I attended had very poor education level but I became very interested in the subject and read as much as i could about it in my own. I think that having a strong background in mathematics had a great influence in my decision to choose physics as it was much easier to make sense of.
Both my parents are college professors
Having a great physics teacher in high school encouraged me to pursue a degree in physics education.

I participated in high school robotics, and enjoyed programming and engineering. I liked the math component a lot, and enjoyed applying it. It took some time to get over engineering as a "gross male job but I am interested in it now. "

Since my family never saw the value in me furthering my education, my inspiration came from fellow members of a hacker space. Together, they showed me that I did have the capacity to learn which turned into a great love of education and nothing was more interesting than the laws the govern our physical world.

I think most of my interest in physics comes from high school. I`ve also read a lot about physics in the news and find it really fascinating. It`s just something I`ve naturally been drawn to. I`m excited to continue studying it and attend conferences to learn more about physics.
I`ve always liked the riguer in physics. It`s what makes it challenging.

When I started undergrad, I figured I should take physics classes because I was pretty good at it. I was really intimidated by my first-year advisor`s other advisees, and I told my advisor that I didn`t think I was smart enough to be a physics student. He told me about impostor syndrome and suggested that I have lunch with the woman of color in the department. She shared a lot of her experiences and advice. I did well at first, despite not really finding a place in any study groups. I then did very poorly in second semester (E&M). I didn`t feel comfortable around the professor and I felt isolated from my classmates, who were very close with one another. That semester, I also took a first-year seminar in astrophysics, taught by my advisor, which I enjoyed but struggled through. The next year, I enrolled in sophomore-level physics and sophomore-level astrophysics. I struggled a lot for the first month and a half for the same reasons. I had to take a medical leave for unrelated reasons and did not finish the semester. The next summer, I ended up deciding that I wasn`t smart enough for physics and that I should become a computer science major. That fall, I took intro CS and sophomore-level astrophysics. I found the astro classes really tough but I liked them a lot. I particularly liked my astronomy professor from the spring, Andrea Lommen. When the time came for the department to hire summer research fellows, I figured I wasn`t good enough to conduct research since I hadn`t done really well in a physics/astro class since freshman fall. Andrea reached out to me to invite me to apply, so I did and I got a placement in her lab! That summer I learned so much from doing research. In conversations with Andrea, my colleagues, and a postdoc that I met at the conference Andrea took us to, I realized how much I enjoyed doing research and that I wanted to keep doing so. I just declared my Astro major at the start of my Junior year!
Codes: Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Cost (Emotional), Cost (Outside Effort), Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered

Response: I began by reading scientific american in high school and finding the physics/astronomy the most interesting.I had the opportunity to help out in a physics lab later in high school, so I was exposed to research in person and discovered I really enjoyed it. I also worked on my own circuitry project at the lab and learned more about independent work and science innovation through that.Throughout college so far I have found all the courses in physics that I`ve taken to be fascinating. Additionally, my professors have been supportive and encouraging.
Codes: Media Triggered, Event Triggered, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: The summer going into my senior year of high school, I had attempted suicide. When I had survived and recovered, I felt incredibly lost as to what I was going to do after high school. At the time, I really wanted to go into medical school, but did not do so hot in AP Biology my junior year so majoring in Biology was out of the question.I then sat down and really thought about what subjects I loved and did well in. And then I thought about who inspired me, and it was my AP Physics B & C teacher. She was half Filipino (I`m full Filipino) and had a physics degree and a job. I was hesitant at first because of the difficulty and rigor of a physics degree, but then I had stumbled across an article called "You want a physicist to speak at your funeral". I was completely moved and inspired after reading it, and that was what solidified my choice to major in physics.When I had told my high school physics teacher about my revelation and what I wanted to do post-high school, she had told me that I was making a big mistake. She told me to go into engineering or premed, but not into physics. To this day, she refuses to speak to me.Despite her strong opposition, I continued on with my physics degree. Admittedly, I did struggle, I still do. However, the support of my women professors, women physics graduate students, and fellow lady physics undergrads, is what keeps me inspired and keeps me going.As of the present day, I am an undergraduate research assistant in the "extreme environments" lab at my school. I am 2 semesters away from graduating with my BA in Physics and my teacher certification for 7-12 secondary sciences. I couldn`t have gotten here without a lot of support.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Media Triggered, Cost (Emotional), Cost (Task Effort), Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: My introductory physics course at Wellesley inspired me to be a Physics major

I grew up near the Kennedy Space Center in Titusville, Fl and many family members of mine have worked with or for NASA. Because of the experiences I have had living so close to the space program, I have had an interest in physical sciences and astronomy since a young age. In addition, my high school physics teacher taught me how wonderful and interesting the world of physics is. Upon finishing my high school physics course, I knew that it was what I wanted to do for the rest of my life.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: I first became interested in physics my junior year of high school, when I took first first intro level class. After becoming increasingly interested with the concepts and theories, I signed up to take AP physics 1 my senior year. Both of these classes gave me a solid foundation in physics, and inspired me to take a physics class my first semester of college. I currently take Introductory Physics II at Bowdoin College. While taking these classes and becoming more and more interested in physics, I began to read books on astronomy and the universe to answer some of my burning questions. One in particular, "The Cosmic Connection" by Carl Sagan inspired me to think more deeply about the importance of physics and space exploration in society. All of these experiences have led me to consider a possible physics major.

When I was a junior in high school I attended the New Jersey Governor`s School in the Sciences, where I was introduced to physics topics like rocketry and special relativity.  These courses allowed me to look beyond high school physics and into the realm of some really interesting topics in more advanced physics, which convinced me to put "physics" down as my major when I went to college.I had a hard time adjusting to the pace of college physics classes and had an even harder time adjusting to the attitudes of my peers, which nearly drove me out of the physics department, until I spoke to a professor in the department and she convinced me to do a research project with her to get out of the undergraduate courses and into real physics research.  After completing this project, I was dedicated to staying in the major despite the climate-related issues.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Emotional), Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I met an astronaut that told me that great minds do not stand still, they look up and around to do bigger and better things to help the community. Astrophysics is where I found my place.

I have always been interested in space as a child, specifically how much is still unknown about the universe. In high school, I decided to apply for summer programs related to astronomy and see if this could be a potential career path for me. During my time at the Yale Young Global Scholars program, I was able to attend specialized seminars about space, tour the astronomy facilities on campus, and even present a capstone project about the future of space exploration at the end of the program. This experience inspired me to take my first astrophysics class the following summer at Stanford, which solidified my love for physics and astronomy, which ultimately led me to majoring in both areas at UC Berkeley.

I have always loved science and math, and they come relatively easy to me.I`m pursuing my bachelor`s degree as a chemistry major mathematics minor.Physics I & II were required classes for graduation.I choose to take the calculus based courses due to my love and understanding of mathematics.The first physics class I had ever taken was in my junior year of college.I really enjoy physics and feel it is unfortunate that I didn`t get introduced to physics until fairly recently.I didn`t have high school physics, so the coursework is new and exciting while challenging. None the less, I have learned more from my two physics classes than I knew was possible.I`m truly excited to get involved in the physics community as I would like to study material science or perhaps engineering.Physics is my favorite branch of science because it is all encompassing and explains the phenomena of the universe by incorporating concepts and mathematical models.I feel like I belong in a physics related career.I think that in physics my creativity, math and problem solving skills all come together.Furthermore, the physics department at my school has been the most embracing to me as a student.I also would love to pursue art, but with physics I feel I can use my artistic talents as well, vice verse.Nature brings together science and art, and I know there has to be a place for me somewhere in the science world.

In high school I took a good physics course and a very good calculus course. My calculus teacher had a background in science.A classmate of mine was very good at math and physics. She went to Caltech for her undergrad and she was something of a role model to me.My father has always been interested in science and engineering. My uncle works in an observatory. My mother is a teacher and was very encouraging when I was applying for college.

I didn`t consider it an option seriously until after I had been in engineering for a while. I hated engineering, but I loved the math and physics, so I just decided that instead of doing engineering because I like physics, why not just do physics. That was it. Simple as that, and I never switched again.

As a child, I enjoyed breaking my toys and putting them back together. Growing up, I realized that engineering was the path I wanted to take but I first wanted to get my undergrad in physics so I could fully understand how physics came into play in the engineering field.

The second week of college, I asked a professor if I could audit her intro physics major course and she said, "Nope, majors only, do you want to double major?"  I decided in under ten seconds I wanted to try to double major because I really wanted to learn more physics, but I had no experience except I took AP physics in senior year of high school.  I`m very grateful that I got the opportunity because I can`t imagine who I would be today if I hadn`t dived into physics.

The first time I took physics was at the calculus based university level. At the time, I was encountering general chemistry and calculus all at the same time for a full year. I decided that since previously of that year, I loved marine science, I could pursue an education in physical oceanography. Going further into upper division physics has led me to a furious passion for geophysics. Nothing gets me more excited than this subject. In high school I had hated math and was told that I could not be successful. But now all I do is math and physics! I think that geophysics could use more of a female population and I am excited about making headway in that direction
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Geophysics), Utility Value, Cost (Emotional), Physiological/Emotional

Response: I was hired to be apart of QuarkNet Note Dame and worked in dark matter research at IUSB. I enjoyed it very much and knew I wanted to follow that path.

I originally started by thinking I wanted to go into theater. I loved stage craft but I didn`t only love the theater part, I also loved the science of what I was doing with lights and sounds. I recognized my passion for science and how excited I would get when I would talk about physics. The math and ideas made sense to me and I wanted to know more. The further I dove, the more I got excited about recognizing science in the real world. I would point it out to the people I was around and only other people who get as excited as I would were physics people. All the signs were there and I just listened to my own intuition. In addition, I had an older sister who got her physics degree and she really opened up my eyes to what physics could be and is beyond introduction courses.
My high school physics teacher was very supportive and encouraging. Physics and calculus were my favorite classes in high school, and I wanted to keep studying physics in college.

I got very interested in High school because I loved my teacher and how she taught the class as lab-based.  Then once I realized how versatile the major was I jumped in, very excited for future opportunities. I realized I could go into engineering, enviromental science, finance, forensic science, and research. I loved the freedom it gave me and I can not wait for more.  I love the support I get from my professors and they really keep me in my major.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Utility Value, Intrinsic (Social), Vicarious Experience

Response: As a child I always wanted to build a time machine. I was fascinated with the concepts of time and space, and as I got older I learned that I could study those concepts through physics. I was encouraged by my parents and did a lot of reading on physics, but the first time I actually took a physics class was junior year of high school. I did not actually do as well in this class as I normally did in school, but I enjoyed the challenge and how I was forced to think differently. When I applied for college I was not sure if I wanted to study medicine or physics, but I realized that while physics is hard, I am most content studying it, which is my I want to get my undergraduate degree in physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Media Triggered

Response: Meeting a woman physicist at the hospital I volunteered at motivated me to become a physicist.
I enjoyed math and science but realized I didn`t like biology or chemistry. I loved space and turned to astronomy before deciding on physics.

I have always been interested in sicence and understanding how things work at a fundamental level. I weighed several options when applying to college, but I decided on physics and astrophysics mostly because it was what I kept gravitating to every time I would consider something different. There was also an element of wanting to prove people wrong present in my decision. I was told several times by high school teachers that I wasn`t good enough at math or smart enough to be a physicist, and I wanted to show them that I was.

For my AP Physics class in senior year of high school (2005-6), my favorite teacher, the now deceased Dennis Whitehead, ignited my interest in physics. He was able to lecture with limited use of his notes or other materials because he understood the topic so well, and was also proficient at explaining non-calculus-based physics. I remember my mom commenting during that period how she didn`t understand that I could excitedly explain concepts that I had just learned in physics class that day, but struggle to retain information from classes that required rote memorization. I was diagnosed with ADD that year, but was never properly medicated for it (until very recently). I spent a long time not knowing what I wanted during the following decade, but I amassed valuable skills in the workforce along the way. The decision to return to school occurred almost instantaneously when my dad was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in 2015, and the realization that physics and astronomy had always interested me suddenly seemed obvious. I came back to school part-time in fall 2016 as a physics major. I still don`t know exactly what I want to do with my degree, but I am confident that, as my knowledge expands, the answer will present itself.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Outside Effort), Vicarious Experience

Response: I read a book about cosmology when I was twelve, and it sparked my interest in physics. I`d always loved science and math, and I liked that physics gave a very rational, mathematical framework for describing and finding out how the world worked. I read a lot of books about physics and astronomy through high school, and my first formal contact with it was physics class my senior year of high school. It was hard, but I still enjoyed the class, which reinforced for me that I truly liked physics.

I had always been interested in physical phenomenon as a child. In 4th-8th grade I had an exemplary science teacher who introduced us to many topics, physics being one of them. I won a build-a-rollercoaster contest demonstrating Newton`s laws in her class and felt very confident in my ability to do well in physics. Similarly in high school, I did extremely well in my physics and physics-related courses, however, I was prevented from taking an AP physics course by administration for trivial reasons and my physics teacher was slightly sexist. This did not prevent me from persuing physics but it did slow me down. I was unsure of picking just physics as my major because I didn`t know what jobs physicists did besides being a professor or teacher, so I decided to pursue an engineering-physics joint-degree program. Making good friends/study group in college gave me more confidence in my ability. Becoming involved in research and physics club leadership further solidified my confidence. Losing my study group because they transfered or left physics or graduated made it difficult to balance classwork and other professional development, which has caused me to struggle to keep my grades as high as they used to be. I have also struggled with mental health issues such as depression and anxiety in this time, which combined with imposter syndrome causes me to doubt my accomplishments that have led me to this day.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Cost (Emotional), Cost (Task Effort), Event Triggered, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: visitng CERN was the most important experience, seeing all the different and exciting jobs and discoveries that occur there. Seeing the international aspect of physics in such an institution definitely sparked my interest.
In high school I had a great astronomy teacher, who initially got me interested in astronomy. Later I studied about physics and astronomy more, and fell in love with the field.

I was interested in being a math major, so I took physics to fulfill my science requirement. I did extremely well in introphysics and I would it to be very interesting. At the end of theyear, my professor asked if I was continuing on in physicsand was shocked when I said no. He said that I was a physicsand I needed to take physics the next year, so I did. At the of my sophomore year, I had really enjoyed all of my physicsclasses and was enjoying my math classes less, so I decidedto switch to physics.

My eighth grade science teacher loved astronomy and I picked that up from him (I am a physics and astronomy major). I took Honors Physics in 11th grade and liked it, took AP in 12th grade and liked it, came to undergrad undecided but deciding between Biology, Physics, and Math. I eventually decided that I liked applying numbers and having things make sense, so I went with physics.

There were no events or experiences that led me to becoming a physics major. I had always been fascinated by science and math. However I never truly considered it as a life or career path until college, and even in myfreshmen year I still did not consider physics out of allthe sciences till the end of my freshmen year. I had completedtwo chemistry courses and realized that, though I enjoyed them, the science was not fundamental enough. I always hadin the back of my mind a love of physics, and in high schooland into college I would buy books on physics to read forpleasure. And yet it wasn`t a field I thought I could getinto due to some implanted idea in my head that it wouldbe too difficult and that I wasn`t smart enough for it.However, the end of my freshmen year came and I decided to throw the idea of "not being smart enough out the windowand enroll for physics classes in the fall. And I`ve stuckwith it ever since."
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Cost (Task Effort)

Response: I initially wanted to become an engineer, since I enjoyed math and science in high school. However, when I met with a family friend that was a professor of engineering, I realized that I was more drawn to the theory and physics behind it. By my senior year of high school I knew that physics is what I wanted to study. My parents tried to dissuade me (it was "too difficult" of a major) but this only added fuel to the fire. I`m nearing the end of my first semester and I know that I made the right choice.
I decided to become a physics student because from a young age I enjoyed watching physics and astronomy documentary and loved my high school physics class.
My high school physics teacher was essential in getting me into physics. In high school I was not sure about what I wanted to do and he made me want to know more about the field.
As a Biology and Physics double-major, I was well into mythird year as a Bio major before I considered a degree inPhysics. I took two "Applications of Physics to Bio/Medicine courses

I became interested in physics in high school. I thought the applied math was very interesting. I didn`t think I was capable of pursuing successfully such a major until years after graduating high school. After I decided that I was perfectly capable of doing anything I wanted to I went back to school. Reading Richard Feynman biography made me realize that my personality wouldn`t keep me from learning as much as possible.

The fact that I am interested in science and have the courage to go for a degree in one of the least diverse fields out there is probably largely due to the fact that my parents have always stressed the importance of education in science. From before I knew what physics was, my parents had both my brother and I watch Bill Nye the science guy on a fairly regular basis and made it so that it was not unusual to talk about science or math at the dinner table. As a matter of fact, it was generally strange if we didn???t. However, my brother always did more in the sciences when we were young, as I was in remedial math (and reading) classes throughout elementary school and always felt that I just wasn???t good at science or math. My brother was smart; I was cute. Even so, during middle school this mindset changed once I noticed that I did have potential where not I nor anyone else thought I did.The first time I considered becoming a physics major was a while ago, when I was still in middle school. Somehow, between fifth and sixth grade, I suddenly jumped between being in remedial classes to being in all honors classes, which opened up opportunities for me to delve into science. In my seventh grade honors science class, it was required that each student complete a science fair project and enter it into the fair. I conducted a project in physics (signal processing regarding how the waveforms of violinists differ) and managed to win awards all the way up to the state level, which is as far as you can go in the state of Texas at that age. This positive experience with science led me into telling people I wanted to be a physicist, and it gave me the confidence to more seriously think about the field. Throughout the end of middle school and into high school--when I attended a sub-par public school in rural Oklahoma--, I read physics books and magazines in my spare time, and being interested in the field became normal to me. I then applied and was accepted to the Oklahoma School of Science and Mathematics, where I was able to take seven physics classes and math through multivariable calculus during my junior and senior years of high school. I declared physics as my major almost immediately after starting my time at Stanford University, and have stuck with it, even though I???m not entirely sure of the details of what I want to do after college. I am able to stand by my decision, because I believe that having a degree in physics is a good foundation for any job, as it teaches you how to think critically at a fundamental level.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Cost (Emotional), Mastery Experience, Event Triggered, Cost (Outside Effort), Utility Value

Response: I realized that I enjoy physics because math has always been a subject I enjoyed, and I thought that physics takes math and makes it applicable to the real world. In addition, the subject of Biophysics has interested me for years and I can see myself being a biophysicist.

I was very interested in astronomy when I was in elementary school.My father asked people how I should accomplish that goal, and people said I would need a degree in physics. I continued to pursue my love for science by taking the physics option in high school (choosing over chemistry II or biology II). My physics teacher in high school was not very supportive of my decision to pursue physics in college; he would say I was not talented enough to pursue physics.Naturally I began college as a physics major and have stuck with it ever since, even adding an astronomy major. I have attended a few REUs and seem to be doing decently well as an undergraduate.

I live with my boyfriend who is pursuing a degree in mechanical engineering. After getting an associates degree in Art, I took a year off from school to work and figure out what I wanted to do with my degree. My boyfriend took a series of Physics courses at school and I often found myself watching him as he did his homework each night. I was amazed with the formulas and equations that he wrote up on our whiteboard every day, and their real life applications to everyday items around us.Now I am back in school, pursuing a degree in Computer Science. I amwhere he was a full year ago, taking my series of Physics courses to delve deeper into my new major. Although Computer Science and Physics aren`t inherently similar, they do require one to have the same problem solving skills. I am excited to explore Physics further as I complete my education, and possiblytie it into my degree as well.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: My first two years in college, I was declared as a Theatre Arts major. I truly love theatre, however, the time I spent developing that major felt incomplete; as if I could do more. I felt as though there were not many opportunities to continue learning in Theatre and began searching for something else.In my Introductory Astronomy Lab a year ago, the grad student instructor and I spoke about the possibility of me changing to a physics major, and since then I have been diving head first into the topic.Finding the Astrophysics major was a perfect fit for me. I found something I was passionate about and that was ever-changing. The idea that science always presents an opportunity to learn something new really appealed to me, and I couldn`t pass it up. I am hoping this conference will be an inspiring opportunity for me to learn about physics, as well as the other women in the major who may be struggling with the same topics as I am.

I came to college unsure of what I wanted to major in, but because I was interested in a little bit of everything I decided to major in physics. There have definitely been some bumps in the road, but for the most part I am happy with my choice to be a physics major. Probably the most important moment of my undergraduate program was the day when my Intermediate Mechanics professor stopped his lecture and talked to the entire class about impostor syndrome. I was planning to change my major to mechanical engineering, but his talk that day kept me in physics. It was the first time that anyone had told us we were all good enough if we were willing to put in the effort.
My high school physics teacher told me that he believed I could do physics when I told him I wasn`t enjoying chemistry and didn`t know what to major in.

I was the only girl (of 2000 students) to take physics I and II in high school, and I enjoyed it so much! I had a great teacher who was constantly supporting my love for all science and helping me any time I needed it.

I started on a pre-engineering track at a school without an engineering major. Moved to a physics/ chemistry double major and thoroughly enjoy my department. The physics majors and professors are all actively involved both inside and out of the classroom.

Physics was my hardest class in high school, so it was the most rewarding when I did well. My dad and I have always had discussions about science, often watching the Science and Discovery Channels together.Increasingly, I want to pursue science writing, policy, and outreach to help spread interest and understanding of science.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Utility Value, Social Persuasion, Media Triggered

Response: My senior year of high school, I went in after school oneday and asked to my physics teacher about how energy could be converted into mass. This started a semester-long conversation about fission and fusion that made merealize that physics beyond the first year kinematics isvery interesting. I had always liked math, and decidedthat physics was the place I should be.

When I was in middle school, I decided that I wanted to be an aerospace engineer. Someone came to talk to my math class, and I was completely captivated by their work. I decided that I too wanted to spend my day working with rockets and space. As I got older, however, I realized that engineering isn`t what truly interested me; it was just space itself. Eventually, I abandoned my ideas to become an engineer in favor of learning the true scientific ideas that I was interested in. That is why I decided to pursue astrophysics.
Codes: Utility Value, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience

Response: In high school, I thoroughly enjoyed my honors physics course, and so I took AP Physics the next year, and it was the most enjoyable class I had ever had. I decided to pursue physics as a major when I caught my self sitting in choir (which had been my favorite class for years), counting down until I could leave for physics. I considered engineering for a long time, simply for its practicality, but at the last minute, I realized I did not want to be an engineer; I had just listened to much to others advice.

First I did really well in high school physics classes. My high school physics teacher was supportive. He encouraged me to read Feynmann`s Lectures on Physics and to start an independent research. Then I did my research and wrote a formal report.The physics intro sequence is fantastic at my college and the department is close and supportive. My major advisor also offered a lot of help.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I originally came to Towson University as an aspiring dance major. I quickly learned that I wanted to keep dance as purely a way to express my creativity rather than as a career. I began looking around other departments, and felt most welcomed by the physics department. I met with one of the department`s oldest faculty members, Tom Krause, and he told me it would be a tough road ahead if I were to switch to physics at the end of my freshman year. But, he believed I could do it and succeed. So I took Calculus I and Physics I over the summer, passing both courses with flying colors, and planned my physics degree to fit into three years. I am now a Junior physics major, right on schedule with the other majors in my year and an internship at Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Lab during the summer of 2014. I first fell in love with the people and community of Physics, then the science itself. I found my voice and my home.

I declared my major to be electrical engineering when I graduated high school, but I cameto be undecided between a biology major andelectrical engineering. As a freshman in college, I took physics and I decided I was interested in the laws of nature. The professor I had increased mycuriosity in physics. He encouraged people to ask questionsand provided exciting videos. When I asked his assistance forhelp on some homework problems I would receive satisfyinganswers. I had a difficulty concentrating on my physics course because of the personal problems I had at that time. I retook the class and successfully earned an A. I realized how much potential I had and decided to continue to the next physics course. Currently, I`ve been searching for guidance that will helpme focus on taking science courses like physics besidesGeneral Education courses that have wasted much of mytime. I will shoot for the stars and look forward toexciting academic pursues in a physics-related major! Thank you so much for your encouragement!
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Cost (Outside Effort), Mastery Experience

Response: I first started loving physics in high school, when I took AP physics taught by my favorite and best teacher. I liked the subject so much that I chose to do any independent study course, AP physics C, during my senior year. This course and my teacher inspired me to keep with physics into college, where I took general physics in my first year. Although I did not have great professors that year, I enjoyed the labs and the problem-solving aspects of the class and was really interested in the kinematics and mechanics part of the course. Second year I got into some tougher courses and really enjoyed the lab work and learning about electronics and relativity. Last summer, I worked with Professor Mark Beck at Whitman College on a quantum research experiment in which we created desired light states using single photons and a double interferometer. It was very interesting to work in a lab and get a feel for what a career in research might hold. Overall, I have been influenced greatly by my hands on experiences in physics as well by as my teachers and professors.
The fact that I am so facinated with the weather and am always wanting to learn more about it, caused me to become a physics major.
The last CuWiP conference, where I met and befriended a number of female physics majors, really negated any residue doubt I had about my important and sense of belonging as a physics major.
Codes: Intrinsic (Social), Intrinsic Value (Event Triggered), Event Triggered

Response: I had a really great high school teacher. She really motivated me to be the best that I could be.

I`ve always liked science. In high school, I knew that I was going to take AP physics and AP chemistry--two more science courses than required to graduate, and all I couldfit in my schedule. I liked my algebra-based physics classenough that I applied to the Tennessee Governor`s School for Computational Physics, and attending that was what really made me seriously consider studying physics. Then, my senior year in high school, I took AP physics and AP calculus, and loved them both; that was probably what solidified the desire. I won`t pretend that I haven`t hadmoments of uncertainty; I still do. I made a D in IntroPhysics II, and that was a blow. I`m retaking it, and stillstruggling. I frequently wonder if I`m not just sticking with it out of inertia, or a desire not to seem foolish, but I honestly can`t imagine doing anything else. I may not have a talent for it, but physics is what I love.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Physiological/Emotional, Cost (Task Effort)

Response: I grew up in a village and my elementary school did not have that much equipment for physics class. But I still remember my first experiment for high pressure. we peeled a             cooled, hard-boiled egg. Simultaneously light three matches and drop them into           an empty glass bottle. Quickly, we covered the opening with the egg. After the              matches extinguish, I widely opened my eye when I saw the egg got sucked into               the bottle. My whole class was roaring and thought all the happening was magic.              Until my teacher explained the heat from the matches causes the air sealed in              the bottle to expand. After the air cools and contracts. The pressure inside the              bottle becomes lower than the pressure outside the bottle. As the pressure            equalizes, the egg squeezes into the bottle. It was really interesting experiment            which inspired me when I was young.

The main factor that led to my interest in physics was visiting Albert Einstein`s apartment in Switzerland during a family vacation a few years ago and getting to see where he lived while he was developing his famous theories. This inspired me to begin studying mathematics and physics at home more seriously, which resulted in my taking the AP Calculus AB exam during May of my 8th grade year. The outstanding math and physics faculty at my current university really solidified my desire to focus on these areas as my college course of study.

During my junior year of high school, I was enrolled in physics and Calculus 1 simultaneously. Through those courses, I began to see the way that physics described everything I interacted with in the world. I specifically remember analyzing the way that I would feel pushed to one side as my car drove around a bend and completing a project that analyzed the forces applied to a softball as I threw it to my 1st baseman. During that year, I was also introduced to the world of medical physics as one of my dear friends was being treated with low-intensity laser therapy. I was fascinated as I continued to study how physics is being utilized in the medical field, from radiation therapy to new diagnostic imaging devices. My senior year, I discovered that one of the schools I had applied to offered a major in Biomedical physics. I spoke with the department chair and he agreed to work with me to complete the major and all of my pre-med courses. In this degree, I have taken classes that specifically deal with the application of modern physics technology to the medical field and biology research. Following my junior year, I joined a research team studying the magnetic field signature of the small intestine and its application for diagnosing functional gastric disorders. Personally, I have been developing a program that analytically solves for the magnetic field of the ileum, at the skin`s surface, while taking into account the conductivity of the layers of the stomach wall. Through these experiences, I have developed a passion for research and specifically the application of the physics principles I have learned in my undergraduate degree to the medical field I am about to enter.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Medical), Event Triggered

Response: I am an astrophysics major. I knew that I wanted to study astronomy when I was eight years old. I don`t really remember why, I just knew I had to. In middle/high school, I realized that I could use physics and math to study the stars and the universe. Since then, I have never really considered anything else.

A high school physics teacher told me that it was something I was good at. I have always been very interested in astronomy which led me to read books about physics and fostered a curiosity for the way the universe works.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Mastery Experience

Response: I`ve always had an interest in astronomy and wanted to become an astronomer when I was seven or eight. From then on, I tried to learn what I could about space: reading books, looking at NASA`s website, going to camps, etc. When I got to high school, I started taking physics classes, and I loved it. To me, physics and astronomy go well hand in hand, and I loved learning how the world works. My interest only grew. In college, I was excited to take more astronomy and physics classes to learn more. I had a knack for understanding the concepts pretty quickly and did well. My junior year, I started doing some research with my adviser, who does research on star formation. All of this confirmed that I really want to learn more in this field.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Event Triggered, Mastery Experience

Response: My interest in physics began in the 7th grade in my gifted program where we had a unit on astronomy and the astrophysicists Carl Sagan and Stephen Hawking. Since that unit, I wanted to learn more about astrophysics and I would spend many nights researching blackholes and supernova remnants. In highschool, I was accepted into MIT`s Online Science Technology and Engineering Community for the summer of 2013. In this program, I took a course in astrophysics and this further confirmed that I would major in astrophysics. I was able to learn how to use a deep space telescope, Chandra, to gather data about various supernova remnants and learn more about this research from a professor at MIT. These events helped shape my interest for astrophysics.

I took physics in High School and it made the world make sense. I liked what I was learning and wanted to learn more. I wasn`t sure what I wanted to do as a career but I decided to study what I loved.

I came into college not knowing what I wanted to do, other than work toward a math or science career. I intended on transferring to engineering after my freshman year but I felt called to physics instead. I loved the small classes and the focus physics places on how the laws work, not just the applications, like engineering. Into my sophomore year, I discovered my passion for learning about gravitational waves and decided to pursue a career in research in cosmology and gravitation.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Cosmology), Utility Value

Response: In high school, I did a research project at our local observatory. That kick started my interest in physics and the research process. I decided I would study physics. In college I have enjoyed it, and have found the courses challenging. I really enjoy research. That is what I am excited to do.

I initially wanted to be a chemical engineer but I didn`t get into the school of engineering, so from the options I had I decided physics seemed like the most relevant. My plan was to transfer to engineering but once I started taking physics classes I realized I actually really enjoyed the classes and the research and decided not to transfer.

I have always loved astronomy and math. When applying for college, I realized physics was the best combination of these interests. For a while, I was also interested in being a high school physics teacher because I knew that part of my struggles in high school physics came from the fact I didn`t learn well from my high school teacher. Now I am in physics to learn how the world works and to solve interesting problems. I am now interested in applying coding to physics research.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Cost (Task Effort), Intrinsic Value

Response: I always liked science as a whole and then took a physics class and an astronomy class in high school and loved them both. I was considering either majoring in english or physics in college and ultimately decided on physics because I felt more drawn to it and that I could contribute more - not only in terms of research but socially as well by helping to balance a predominantly male field.

I didn`t consider physics as something to pursue for a long time. I somehow convinced myself that I wasn`t good at math (despite completing precalculus as a sophomore in high school). I thought I should go into the "soft" sciences and avoid pursuing math, physics, or engineering because I didn`t fit my own ideas of what a scientist or engineer is. Outside of school, I frequently read about current physics and read and watched things explaining physical concepts directed at a very general audience. I was always interested in physics, but what really grabbed my interest was taking an introductory course in Physics at my university. Getting to experience a small taste of what doing physics was like started a real and lengthy evaluation of myself and my goals. With the guidance of one of the physics professors at my university, I started to research and explore the idea of taking my path towards physics. I really wish I had been exposed to physics and more role models when I was younger so that I could have seen that pursuing physics was a real option for me.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion

Response: I took my first physics class as a senior in high school because it was required to graduate. The class and my teacher intimidated me at first, but I was determined to do well, so I attended many after-class tutorials for help with my homework. I remember at one of those tutorials, my teacher pulled me aside into the hallway and asked me why I was so afraid of physics. She told me that I was doing very well in her class so far and I had the potential to be very good at physics if I wanted to. Over the next few months, she and I developed a very close relationship, and I began to realize that I did enjoy physics. At the same time, I realized that my classmates would come to me to ask questions about homework or concepts, which further reinforced my confidence. During the third trimester of my senior year of high school, this same teacher was teaching an introductory Modern Physics class. Although my schedule was already full, she invited me to audit it during one of my free periods. I did- I went to nearly every class, did all of the homework problems, and even took the midterm. I loved the introduction to the concepts. By the time I got to college, I had already decided that I wanted to pursue a physics major. At college, I took advantage of every opportunity to get involved in the department. I joined our chapter of SPS (and later the executive board) and participated in various department events. I have found that the department has been welcoming and my professors genuinely want to see me succeed.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I first got interested in physics when I heard about the effects of relativity and the existence of spacetime. I decided to take a scientific path in high school, and I realized I enjoyed the math and the thought process involved in physics problems. I talked to my teachers and did online research about the opportunities for me in the field. Once I started my major, I knew I had made the right choice.

I have an older brother. I always wanted to be like him and get good grades like him. I took Physics in high school just like him and I fell in love with it. It helped me discover that I wanted to be a high school physics teacher. Taking physics classes in college have just increased my drive for physics. Having met the people involved in physics, including some of the girls joining me at this conference, I am so thankful I chose Physics so I got to enjoy their company and minds.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I have always been interested in science since I was a child. I especially was obsessed with space. I closely followed the space program, had my own telescope, and made comics about spaceships going on adventures in the galactic center,narrowly escaping the supermassive black hole. Unfortunately, for the longest time, I did not know that astronomy and cosmology were considered part of physics. Physics was either pulleys and levers (which I learned from my grade school teachers) or the science of weapons and atomic bombs (which I learned from over-enthusiastic boys at school...the only people into physics were boys). I considered the former to be mind-numbingly boring, and the latter reprehensible and an insult to the purpose of science. As such I`d always assume I would grow up to be a biologist, or geologist, or meteorologist....any kind of scientist but a physicist!It wasn`t until middle school that things changed after I saw a documentary about black holes....something I hadn`t watched since I was in kindergarten. It was then that I learned that black holes were themselves an outcome of general relativity, a theory of physics. Surprised, I decided to read into this subject. I was shocked to discover that physics was being used to unravel the mysteries of the cosmos. It was around that time that I realized that I wanted to become an astrophysicist.

We don`t have WiP at Humboldt State, but we do have a club called SWIMS (Society for Women in Math and Science). Through this club, I`ve been able to share previous CUWiP experiences and have encouraged other students to join the club. We have also held a "You Belong Workshop" to let other students know that they are not alone and teach people how to cope with isolation within their majors. The workshop had a faculty and student panel in which people talked about REUs, grad school, and imposter syndrome.

My physical chemistry course initially got me interested in physics. My work in a physical chemistry lab that specializes in SPM and photovoltaics inspired me to major in physics. I thought that knowledge of physics would allow me to understand microscopy and photovoltaics better, and I was right.

My interest in physics began when I was young, through long conversations with my father. Though he is not a scientist or engineer, he studied physics as a hobby and encouraged me to do so as well. I demonstrated an aptitude for math and science throughout high school and my early college years. However, though I had considered pursuing a degree in science upon beginning college, I thought it would be too difficult to raise a family and work as a research professor. I also felt incompetent and unqualified, since the male scientists I was surrounded by always seemed so confident. So initially, my major was high school science education. However, my professors encouraged me to change majors, since they believed I would make a wonderful scientists. At the urging of my professors, I chose to change my major and pursue a degree in my favorite of the sciences, physics. My fascination with light then drove me to study optics and lasers in particular.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic Value (Optics)

Response: I began questioning things like what makes up protons and neutrons, and started learning about the fundamental particle. I knew that if i wanted to know more I had to pursue a degree in physics.

I knew early on I had an aptitude for engineering because of my creativity and mathematical skills. While in high school, chemistry was my supposed niche and I had a strong feeling my path pointed towards becoming a chemistry teacher. Taking all aspects into account, including household income, I applied to Truman in hopes of pursuing my desired career. After days of pondering through restless nights, I received a letter notifying me of my acceptance to Truman`s science program. Furthermore, when I was accepted to Truman I was also given the opportunity of joining a summer program called SPECTRA that would allow me to take summer classes preceding my freshman year at no cost, however this operated on the condition that I would attend Truman for one year. On top of SPECTRA, I also saw potential in being able to continue my participation in track and field. Taking that into account, I knew Truman had the right program for me. I made the  decision to attend for two years and then transfer to an engineering school. Sophomore year I looked into potential transfer schools as well as summer research opportunities. After studying physics for a period of time, I came to the realization that engineering school didn`t have the appealing factor that summer research opportunities promised. I was accepted into a research experience at the University of Arkansas which allowed for an in depth look at biophysics. After just one summers worth of participation, I knew this field was my future.  Not only did I enjoy the people I worked with, but I enjoyed my research. That summer at Arkansas helped me realize my love of biophysics as well as a desire to learn more about it.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Event Triggered, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value (Biophysics)

Response: As a high school student, I was introduced to physics and was intrigued by the idea of using math to describe and predict phenomena (up until then, math had been very dry, boring, and abstract to me). My family members did not think I was capable of doing well in physics, so they discouraged me from pursuing physics, but I chose physics as my major anyway, because I was interested and willing to spend more time solving physics problems than other classwork. I also had a very encouraging high school physics teacher, and some upperclassmen to look up to.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Emotional), Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: I think physics is interesting and I liked my physics course in high school. I enjoy solving problem and learning about how the world works.

I found my high school physics class interesting, but didn`t feel like I knew enough about physics to major in it, so I took a physics class in college for fun. I loved it, and mentioned to the professor that I was thinking about adding a physics major. He met with me and discussed my options, then helped me fill out the paperwork and introduced me to the other physics professors. His willingness to help me was a huge part of my final decision to major in physics.

I was mainly influenced by my AP Physics class in high school. Until then, I had taken Chemistry and enjoyed it so I thought I would do chemistry. But then I realized that I actually really enjoyed physics more instead.

I loved Physics in high school and in my first year of college and it`s a useful career field. I also had a very good experience with a Physics professor simultaneously with a very bad experience with a Behavioral Science professor (BSci was the other major I had considered.)
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Utility Value

Response: I first considered my interest in physics when I took introductory science classes in middle school and was intrigued by the subject matter. In high school, my knowledge, as well as my fascination, grew. Now that I am in college, I wish to learn and explore even more physics.

A high school chemistry teacher told me I couldn`t do physics, which is what first made me want to be a physics major. My parents and my father, in particular, have always been very encouraging. I also started doing research in first geophysics, and now nuclear physics, which cemented my desire to be a physicist.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Nuclear), Event Triggered

Response: I was interested in planets, the solar system, space, etc and the universe at large from when I was very young and that grew into wanting to take classes in physics!

The physics department at Kenyon College is very focussed on community, and that attracted me to becoming a physics major. My the summer after my sophomore year, I began cosmology research with Professor Tom Giblin, and that research is what motivated me to continue my physics education in graduate school. In my research with Prof. Giblin, I have collaborated directly with some of his collaborators, and that made me feel like a part of the cosmology community instead of just an undergraduate student.
Codes: Intrinsic (Social), Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Cosmology), Event Triggered

Response: After taking an environmental science course in high school I realized I was interested in working in fields relating to climate change mitigation and other environmental issues. After exploring different ways to get into an environmental field that had more of an emphasis on research I decided to go into physics. I hope to work in atmospheric physics or something related in the future.

I was always really interested in physics as a subject, and I discovered I was very good at it at the college level. My friends and family also really supported me changing into a physics major from my previous major choice.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: My high school physics teacher made every topic fun and hands on, and it really inspired me to pursue the field.  Since entering college, I have become more and more interested in the various topics that fall within the physics field, and I want to pass on my love for understanding the world around us through physics.

In my very first physics class I struggled tragically because I was thinking of physics the wrong way and when I began to realize how visually one must think about physics I became very intrigued by it. It was fascinating learning how the world works and I wanted to learn more.

From the time I was little I have always loves the stars, and when ever I got older, I wanted to go into astronomy. Knowing that physics included astronomy I took it in high school to see if I liked it and I did.That the summer of my junior year I went to MSU to see their astronomy program and do some research.Because of my time there I locked in on being a physics major and decided to go to college for physics.

I was choosing between chemistry and physics. After my first semester of physics, I started doing research in the physics department in my second year. My mentor has really supported me and taught me a lot of things. As I continued doing research in his lab, I became more and more interested in physics.

When I was in high school, I had a physics class given by a teacher who thought that the moon was a planet and was not able to explain to the student what was a negative speed. After this year, I decided that I didn`t want to do science anymore. Because of some events in my life, I ended up starting science classes in college. Everyone was expecting me to become a physician, but at the last moment I changed my plans. I went to multiple events where the physics studies seemed the more interesting to me. So I started a Bachelor in physics and I founded out that physics was a real passion to me and that I really liked to understand the world around me. I also did an internship before starting my bachelor`s studies. I understood that I could understand complex systems starting with basic physics law.

I have always known that I would like a career in science, but it took me awhile to figure out what exactly I wanted to do. I have been interested in various topics. I have always looked through a microscope, examined rocks, study equations and always looked up at the stars. I used to lock myself in the bathroom for hours and shine a flashlight through paper cups that had constellations poked in the bottom. Whenever lunar eclipses happened I would stay out all night looking at the sky. In 2009 I believe it was, the moon had the largest corona ever in history I believe and I stayed outside all night long staring in amazement at the sheer size and beauty of the corona. Many times I would find myself looking at images on NASA`s picture of the day and trying to understand all in the images. Always I have asked questions about space. In high school it became clear that any topic that dealt with space kept my attention better than any other topic we may have discussed. It wasn`t until my junior year in high school that I decided for sure that I wanted to study Astrophysics. That is when I knew I needed to have a Bachelor`s degree in Physics.
I have always loved Astronomy, and an undergraduate Physics degree is the path to take to be an Astronomer.

From a young age I have always loved space and have been fascinated with the difficult questions of ???what???s out there???? and ???how did we come to be????. Ultimately, this has lead me to physics. I???ve always loved asking deep questions and have always found myself yearning for more meaningful and quantitative answers. I originally planned to major in astronomy coming into undergrad but with time realized my questions didn???t stop with astronomy, they ranged from the macro to the microscopic scales. As I began studying physics I realized how many fields existed and that I loved every one of them. I wanted to see the real world applications of what I was learning in class so during sophomore year of undergrad I began my first semester of research. Since then my research has ranged from dark matter to reconstructing bosons and from categorizing SEP events to building MicroMegas detectors. My goal is to continue to broaden my knowledge in physics and to explore many of the career possibilities that exist.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: My high school physics teacher helped me see the beauty of physics and how cool women in STEM are. Also, before I came to college, I toured my current school and a male professor of physics was talking to me about how I would be a great addition to women making a difference in Physics.

I wasn`t very interested in math or science until I took Calc I and physics concurrently my junior year of high school. I had phenomenal teachers who made the subject matter very interesting and took time to help me understand it. It was during that year that I realized I wanted to pursue physics further, and while applying to colleges I took the time to look for schools with good physics programs. My school, Bard College, has an amazing and small program, and I entered college knowing I wanted to be a physics major. I have been a physics major since the first day and have participated research for many years as well.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I became interested in Physics when I started researching the string theory. I then found a passion for particle physics and the possibility of combining gravity with quantum mechanics in an equation. I originally started as a Chemical Engineering major but I found that my true passion is in physics.

Last year, I was feeling a little hesitant about continuing with Physics and I was considering changing majors. After one of my professors encouraged me to go to CUWiP first I met a bunch of other girls in the Physics department and generally just got to know the department better. Now I can`t imagine being anywhere else!
Codes: Social Persuasion, Event Triggered, Intrinsic (Social), Cost (Emotional)

Response: I always loved astronomy, and I really enjoyed learning about physical science in middle school, and honestly the short version is that when I saw the movie Interstellar, I decided that`s what I wanted to do. I`ve stuck with it ever since, and now that I`m in college physics courses, I can say I`m more sure than ever it was for me.

I loved physics in high school but struggled to master the material. I college I aced my first intro physics course, and realized that I wanted to study physics. I lost a lot of confidence during my second intro physics course because I again found myself struggling to master the material. Over time I came to understand that this is a normal experience for physics students. It wasn`t until after I declared my major that I felt I was part of the physics community and qualified to be in that community.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Cost (Task Effort), Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I took a high-school AP Physics 1 class and my teacher was phenomenal. He introduced me to the world of physics and how physics explains our world. I realized when I didn`t take AP Physics 2 and regretted not taking it, despite the difficulty, I wanted to study physics. My high school physics teacher cultivated my love for physics and was always willing to talk about it with me. I am also on a AFROTC tech scholarship so Physics is my first tech choice. Moreover, I have always loved flying and I think physics could help me appreciate the ability to fly (in a plane) even more as I pursue a career as a pilot in the USAF.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: Having been exposed to physics from a young age through my grandfather, now a retired physics professor, I have been interested in physics since high school. I participated in various math and physics competitions I while in high school, and doing well in them made me feel that physics might be one of the things I could pursue in college.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience

Response: I was initially interested in physics after reading a nonfiction book on how mathematical fractals were applied to astrophysics. I was then more attracted to physics after taking AP Chemistry in high school because my favorite topics were more along the lines of atomic physics. I had intended initially to join the field of particle physics but after taking a seminar on gravitational lensing taught by a professor at my university, I was again very interested in astrophysics and observational research. Since then I`ve worked under that professor on a grav. lensing research project and I`ve done an REU at another university and plan to finish two majors in physics and astrophysics. Eventually I plan to attend grad school in astronomy.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: I took my first physics course in high school. My dad, who received his bachelor`s degree and Ph.D. in physics, helped me on my physics homework during that time and was super influential. Because I think a lot like my dad, I began to think physics might be a good option for me. I liked environmental engineering, but the fact that physics was more encompassing and would open more doors made it more appealing. Starting a physics study group during freshman year intro physics was hugely influential in keeping me in this major. Now, my small physics cohort is a family that I can`t imagine leaving!
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Utility Value, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I always knew I loved science. First I was a biology major, but a few classes in that made me change my mind. Then I became chemistry major and I couldn`t deal with the symbols, finally I found physics and I just fit it. I was able to understand what was going on in front of me and understood how things work! Now I do my research in a lab and am surrounded my lasers. I couldn`t be happier with what I do!
I am very curious about the nature of the universe and I can`t imagine a field other than Physics would be fulfilling to me.

I knew when I started high school that math came easy to me and I had really enjoyed my previous physics classes as well as having an interest in how things around me worked so I chose physics and I love it. Although it had been a few years since my last physics class before starting up in physics again two years ago, it is still the same as I remember it and I love it.

Growing up I always had a vague idea of what physics was, but I didnÕt properly do any physics until senior year of high school. Everyone always told me IÕd be good at it because I was good at math, and I liked the idea of becoming an astronaut someday. Once I tried my first physics class, I was sold. I knew the math behind everything, so I thought it would be a good idea to jump straight into AP Physics C as my first ever physics course, and even though it was difficult I loved it. I just wanted to keep learning more.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value

Response: I first started as an English major, once exploring my love for botany and ecology... I was amazed by science. I then took a calculus course and my first Astronomy course. Astronomy introduced me to physics and I fell in love right then. I became close with my Astronomy professor and am now planning trips with him for asteroid occultations and other astro-physics events. I became amazed by the resounding feeling of being so small in the world and being an observer and uncovering the amazing dynamics of our universe and other universes! I recognize the privilege I have to observe and study the universe to make it a better place and more expansive and open-minded place for the truth.The truth is the ultimate goal for any scientist. Or at least, an ethical scientist.
I hadn`t considered until I took intro physics in college and loved both the class and felt welcome in the department.

My first high school physics class (AP Physics B) was the first class in high school that challenged me. I enjoy math and puzzles. I knew I wanted to do science, but was unsure of which field. I liked biology, but with my sister already going into that field I didn`t want to compete with her. So I found I preferred physics to chemistry and so I chose physics as a major.

I was originally intending on going the biology route and becoming a doctor. It wasn`t until my senior year of high school when I took the physics course that I realized I wanted to study physics. Before I even started college, I changed majors and have yet to regret that decision.

I was always interested in math and science, and I knew that I wanted to major in a STEM field when I applied to college. After taking an intro astronomy course my freshman year, I immediately decided to major in physics and astronomy. My sister was also a big influence in my decision to study astrophysics because she studied physics as an undergrad and is now pursuing her PhD in nuclear astrophysics at Michigan State.

I initially started college as an Aerospace Engineering major, but due to my interest in space and physics I switched to Engineering Physics. Throughout my career I have followed opportunities and interests and moved farther from the engineering aspect to being almost completely physics-focused.

The first physics course I took was a semester long introductory course my freshmen year of high school. I don`t particularly remember enjoying the subject, but I absolutely loved my teacher, Ms. Ortman, who made the class exciting. Due to this, I took physics my junior year in the hopes of having her as a teacher again, which I did. During a lab, in which the class had to calculate when to launch a projectile in order to hit a moving object with a constant velocity, I decided that this was what I wanted to do with my life. I loved how seemingly simple calculations translated into real life motion and events. Due to this, I proceeded to take AP Physics my senior year of high school, which only confirmed my desire to major in this field, as I excelled in the class. However, the weekend before the AP Test, I contracted a horrible sinus infection, but took the test anyways, and received a 4 on both the Physics C Mechanics and Electricity and Magnetism tests. Honestly I was a little disappointed, but I felt that if I could do that well when sick, then I certainly could go further with physics. The following summer, at my orientation at MSU, I was set on continuing on to the next physics class, but the lack of math credits kept me from taking the nest course. So, I decided to retake the Mechanics and E&M 1 my freshmen year in order to maintain a strong base in physics. Currently in my freshmen year, I am maintaining a high grade in my physics course, and helping my sister(who is a junior in college) with the concepts in her introductory physics course. I also attend the meetings for the Society of Physics Students and the Astronomy Club; both which help me to further my physics knowledge through guest speakers and presentations. In the future, I wish to continue learning all that I can about physics throughout my undergrad and possible grad schooling.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I started my college career as an engineering major because everyone said that I was good at math and that`s all you can do with that. I then learned that engineering is not what I wanted to do, so I switched to a mathematics education major, because, again, that`s all I knew that I could do with a love for math. I finally took physics as a math cognate class and found that I loved it. I then looked in to it and found that I could do this as a career, and immediately switched my major.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I was originally a mircobiology major and considered going into psychology or film, but they were impacted at my school. In the first semester of college I was taking Chemistry, Pre-Calc, and GE`s. I was discouraged from taking Calculus and Astronomy my first semester by college mentors, which ticked me off a bit because those were the classes that I really wanted to take but these college mentors, who were biology students, kind of influenced me with an iron fist to take the classes that they thought were best, and I had to go along with it and I had no way to change my schedule. So, half-way along through the semester I learned that they were having an EYH, Expanding Your Horizon`s, women`s conference that I could teach at. I ended up teaching a program about astrophysics and cosmology, because I knew a lot about it and it was fun. The program didn`t have any other program besides biology or chemistry related programs, so I decided to do with astrophysics one. After teaching at that conference, I decided that I did not want to go into microbiology because it was not challenging enough for me and it wasn`t what I wanted to do. So I decided to switch my major to physics, and I signed up for the appropriate classes for the following semester, and I also decided to volunteer at the ASP and at our local observatory. I never figured that I would go into physics because in high school I did so poorly on the AP test. But doing AP and IB I always loved the astrophysics part of it, but I teacher purposefully never taught it to us, even though that was half of the test. So because I did poorly on the AP and IB physics test I was discouraged from it. But, that obviously changed.
Codes: Cost (Emotional), Event Triggered, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: My high school didn`t offer calculus based physics so I dropped out of high school to take physics at the UO. I liked it and enjoyed it even though it was hard, so I decided to major in it. I`ve wanted to be a scientist since I was like four, though, when i saw the worm on sesame street go to the moon. When I was six i decided i had outgrown my toy microscope, so i asked for a real one for Christmas (and my family got me one)! Having a mother who has always assumed I`d go to graduate school has had a huge impact.
Learning about Hawaiian Navigation and how they utilized the stars and used astronomy to expertly navigate the Pacific Ocean is what got me interested in astronomy, physics, and science in general.
Working in a physics lab

My middle school science teacher introduced physics concepts to us and doing well in understanding those concepts plus the encouragement of my teacher made me want to look into it more as a subject to look into once I got older. I took AP Physics in high school and while my teacher probably didn`t care whether or not we liked physics or encouraged us to go into physics as a career, I kept a fascination to it as I got to applying for schools. While I started at my university as a physics major, I didn`t truly see myself doing this more permanently until I stepped foot in a lab.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered

Response: I did well in my high school physics class and I really enjoyed the material. On top of that, my teacher in Physics in high school was amazing and he really inspired me to continue in the field. I am honestly still a little unsure of my major since I haven`t taken a college physics class yet but I love science and think it could be a great path for me

I first considered physics as an option last year. I was taking pre-engineeringclasses and I found myself frustrated at the lack of explanation of why we wereusing the expressions to the solve problems that we were. At that same time I wastaking my first astronomy course at the university, and was completely fascinated.This realization that I had found something that I loved, and also something that I didn`t, led me to physics.
