I am very interested in the physical phenomena thatinfluence the engineering strategies I was being taught (I loved my E&M class, but notso much my intro electrical engineering class), and as my dream occupationis a research scientist/professor, I came to the conclusion that physics and astronomywould be the most rewarding path for me to take.

I watched a bunch of science channel physics documentaries in middle school and thought it`d be fun. I didn`t enjoy high school physics, but I liked the subject itself so I kept on. I did an astronomy reu the summer after my freshman year of college and I liked the reading i did so i asked my supervisor whether there were any people he`d recommend doing research with near my university, I reached out to one of the people he listed and I`ve been working with her since. Anyway I`m also super depressed and have adhd so that`s pretty much been wrecking my academic life from the jump, hence my self-reported low aptitude for physics and any careers thereof
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Social Persuasion, Cost (Outside Effort)

Response: I first was rejected from Chemical Engineering so I was looking for a major that is related to Chemical Engineering but is also related to pharmaceuticals, which lead me to Biophysics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Biophysics), Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: I went to the best high school in Shanghai and it is famous for its Mathematics and Physics concentrations. So my experience there definitely made me find my interests in natural sciences and my ability to do science as a career.

I did not take any physics courses in high school, so my first experience with the subject was in a required physical science course my freshmen year of college. I enjoyed the challenge of the subject andadded physics as a second major the following year. At the time therewere only 3 other physics majors, 2 of them upperclassmen,and the school could only offer one upper-level physics class everyyear or 2. In order to graduate on time I had to take a few classes out of order, which led to some very difficult semesters in whichI had to take physics classes which required math I didn`t have.When I first started of the four physics majors 2 of us were female. We now have 15 or 16 physics majors, but only one of the new majors is a girl.

I am a non-traditional, transfer student to my university. I knew I loved science but did not have a lot of direction in where I wanted to go. I had just taken my first physics courses through the community college I was at, and had been tutoring chemistry for a couple of years. Through an internship program, I began research with Dr. Eric Toberer in the physics department at Colorado School of Mines. My graduate mentor was a prior physics major who had graduated from Mines a few years prior and encouraged me to follow that path, as physics had greatly benefitted him in materials, and could be applied to many fields. As I have continued my research past my internship, now well into my second year of research with this advisor, I have truly found a love of materials; and as my mentor told me it had for him, all of the things I love in physics help me comprehend and have a better understanding of the way materials work. I love physics, and the base in physics will help me pursue my passion in a PhD program in materials science.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience

Response: The thing that got me initially interested in physics was the movie Interstellar, and seeing how time was distorted because of gravity really intrigued me. Ever since, I knew that was the direction I wanted to go in for my career and goal of life. Learning about how physics-related things worked clicked well in my brain and I knew I wanted to go into physics. At my current university, the physics staff is really amazing and makes me want to succeed and prove to myself that I can do it.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion

Response: I`ve always been interested in science and thought that I was going to be a chemistry major. When I realized while taking a physics course that all my favorite parts of chemistry were actually the physics of it, that was when I realized I wanted to become a physics major.

In high school, I took two years of physics. In doing so, I slowly saw the world around me open up and change. I enjoyed connected memories and real-life situations to equations. From opening doors to seeing rainbows, I realized these relationships were a source of pride that others did not feel the same way towards. Now, as a freshman in college, I feel even more sure that I belong in this field for the people around me who feel the same way towards the incredible and shocking discoveries in modern physics to their own perspective towards the work they do. On the first day of classes, my professor said this: "Physicists are humble. It is not because they know more than many people in the world, it is because the knowledge they acquire gives them a more accurate estimate of how much they do not know."
I`ve always been interested in astronomy and math. I read one of Stephen Hawking`s books when I was a junior in high school and realized that is what I want to spend my life doing.

I have always had a deep interest in math and science, specifically astronomy, and that led me to pursue physics. I initially pursued engineering, but at a young age had a bad experience with a professor and decided engineering would not be a good fit.

I first became interested in physics because of my older brother.  I saw him struggle with it, and I wanted to do better.  I was good at math in high school, so physics came a lot easier.  I did really well in my high school physics classes, and I learned how I could apply a physics degree to many different industries after graduation, so I decided to go with it.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Utility Value

Response: Having the opportunity to take an astronomy class in high school, that material and some material about the Bohr model in chemistry piqued my interest in particles and atoms and the way they relate. I so enjoyed my astronomy course that I decided to consider applying to astrophysics programs around the country, though I ended up applying for anthropology programs when the time came to apply to college. In college, I felt something missing without the same education in science and mathematics, and I knew that I needed to enroll in physics. The major factors that influenced me included genuine interest and a concern that a degree in social science would not give me the career I want. Now the influences that keep me studying include the relationships I have developed with my peers, the challenges provided by the material, and my own fascination and deep interest in the topics discussed.
I took physics in high school as I was told that the class was really fun. It genuinely was, and became one of my favorite classes. I love astronomy as well, so combining the two was natural.

I wanted to do something that I enjoyed and that would also lead me to a successful career. I`m interested in working in something to do with spacecraft. I`m going to be honest; that interest was influenced by things like Star Trek.
From the beginning, I liked the way it gave me power to look at the world in a powerful way. In college the courses seemed to fit the way that I think.My professors had faith in me.

I was working at a science museum selling tickets while taking classes at community college, and I slowly became more interested in science in general. I was able to get a job working in the galleries, and then the planetarium. I developed a real passion for astronomy and astrophysics, and ended up doing an REU at the Department of Astrophysics at the American Museum of Natural History. I fell in love with astrophysics research at that point, and my mentor really made me feel like I belonged and that this was a viable professional option for me. Now I`ve transferred to a four-year school to earn my BS, and I want to get a good background in physics to prepare for applying to grad school for Astronomy.

I started college as an art major, in time I realized that in art I wasn`t very happy, as I don`t believe that I could see myself competitively creating art, it`s not something you can just do for a check. It has to be something you sort of create with no deadline. I`ve always had an interest in astrophysics and astronomy, but I never had much of a math background, nor did I ever take physics in high school. While sitting in an astronomy lecture at the College of Charleston I found an interest in mathematics and physics that I wish to know more about, so I decided to change my majors to something I will thoroughly enjoy as an adult, as well as something that would challenge me. I am now a triple major in Computer Science, Physics, and Astrophysics, hoping to one day become a Computational Astrophysicist that may work for NASA or other space exploration careers.

Science Channel shows about black holes, cosmology, and atomic theory always interested me while growing up. When applying to college, I was originally going to study engineering, but I could not decide on a specific branch of engineering. Rather than choose a subfield that I may later regret, I realized that I could study physics, the basis of all other sciences. It also captured my fascination of the very big and the incredibly small. I wanted to study the ways of nature. My father played a key role in helping me find my path and understand my interests. Even though he is a jack-of-all-trades artist, he is interested in physics and fostered my love for physics. He has always been supportive.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion

Response: I am majoring in mathematics and when looking into a minor, the physicscourses are so similar to those of math. And since I already have a hugefascination in physics I jumped on the opportunity to add physics as my minor.
I always loved astronomy and space. I was the kid who would watch the science channel all the time. Then when I started going towards that, I discovered astrophysics.

I`ve been interested in space since I was very young, and learned that astrophysics would give me a career studying space. I did research in high sschool that helped me explore my interests. Since college has began, I`ve continued to find things that interest me and I now work at the planetarium on campus. At times, being a physics major has been discouraging, but my goal of one day working at NASA has kept me motivated.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Cost (Emotional), Utility Value, Event Triggered

Response: When I first attended college, I was a mathematicsmajor. I also wanted to eventually become a philosophymajor, as well. However, I realized very quickly what my biggest flaw was: though I could readily accept pure mathematics and the principles they entail, I could not apply what I`ve learned to the "real world

I took my first physics class my junior year of high school on a bit of a whim, and within the first semester I was completely taken with the study, and felt as though I finally knew what I wanted to do with my life: I wanted to pursue a PhD in physics, and a career in teaching, ideally at the university level (although teaching high school physics and astronomy and having the chance to instill this same love of physics and astronomy in young students just as my teachers have done for me would also be very fulfilling). I have never enjoyed or so quickly connected with class material as I have with physics and astronomy, and will oftentimes find myself giving anyone who will listen a mini-lecture about something that I`ve learned and wish to share (physics brings me joy and fires my curiosity, and I try my best to use it to bring a similar feeling to others). There was a brief time as a freshman in college during which I was not on the STEM transfer track at the community college that I was attending, but this time lasted a brief two quarters before I found myself wandering the local library looking for physics and math books that might supply me with the practice problems for which I longed, and I began to realize that I couldn`t imagine my life without physics. I switched back to the STEM transfer track as soon as I could, and it felt as though my life had meaning once again. During my time at Cascadia Community College, I also took my first two astronomy classes, and was finally able to distinguish the kind of physics in which I am the most interested: astrophysics, and the related sub-fields of physics, like cosmology. At the end of my second year, I transferred to the University of Washington to complete my four-year degree, and was accepted into both the physics and astronomy majors. Now, being exposed to higher-level STEM classes, research, and other students who share my passion for the field, I am as sure as ever that this is the path I wish to pursue.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: In high school I excelled in math and science. Having played piano from the time I was 5 years old, however, I was torn between going to schools for engineering or music. I eventually decided to pursue an undergraduate degree in classical piano performance. Having completed all math and science requirements via AP credit, I was never required to take a math or science course again. After my sophomore year, I realized that I really missed learning science. While I love playing piano, it simply wasn`t enough. I had always loved physics and had an exceptional physics teacher in high school, but it wasn`t until I had the idea of changing my major that I seriously thought about pursuing physics further. After several months of thinking, preparing, and seeking guidance from the few physics professors I knew, I switched my major halfway through my junior year. Although the transition was quite difficult, within weeks of my first semester as a physics major, I knew it was what I should have been doing all along. I quickly began doing research in the soft complex materials lab at JMU, and now, a year and a half later, I am applying to PhD programs for physics.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: I chose physics before I ever took a physics class. I would do research on my own, and it always was related to physics. The reason I chose to study physics in particular, so I would have the skill set and knowledge to conduct the research I want to do. I also wanted a challenge; I did not want to take the easy route. Physics surely supplied me with a challenge.

I have a neuroscience degree and after graduation was tutoring high school students in math, chemistry, and physics. Upon revisiting physics through tutoring (I had taken two intro courses in my undergraduate education and some in high school), I realized I felt regret in not exploring different career paths, including physics and decided to take some courses to see if I wanted to follow this as a career path. I`m much more aware of racial and gender diversity in spaces I`m in, and it`s truly discouraging to see how few women (and even less women of color) are in my courses with me - but even more so to see how few women are on staff at most major institutions and in higher level leadership positions. It`s important to me to shift these power dynamics if I have the ability to do so. I`ve had the opportunity to engage in research at the undergraduate level - which I find engaging, interesting, and fun - this is a key component in my continuation and (near) completion of my physics undergraduate degree while working full-time in the philanthropic sector.
Codes: Cost (Emotional), Utility Value, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered

Response: I first considered physics when I was introduced to Experiment Presentations. I started doing science experiments and I figured out that I liked more about physics due to the topic that I graduated towards. After it happened for a while, I went to a physics class and I noticed that I liked that class more than majority of my other classes. That class, was in fact made for me. I knew this because in that class, I was always doing research ahead of time and so I became fairly knowledgeable before my classmates knew what they were doing. This helped me a lot in the class.
I`ve always loved science and with many physicists in my family, interest in the topic seemed natural. When I began to study astronomy and attend some star parties my interest took off.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered

Response: I became a physics major to supplement my understanding of the basis of my engineering classes. This occurred midway through my sophomore year, and was the first time I seriously considered majoring in physics (I considered it too theoretical to be of use previously).

I have always loved physics, and I decided my freshman year of high school that I was going to get my PhD in astrophysics after reading a book which featured an astrophysicist as a main character. My high school physics teacher and my physics professors in college have been very supportive of this goal. Since then, I have enjoyed studying physics and I love the community in the physics department at Geneseo.
Codes: Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: A natural love of science led me to want to be a science teacher. After taking an honors physics course in high school taught by a female, I decided that I still wanted to be a teacher, but narrowed down my field to wanting to teach Physics. I then took AP Physics my senior year and only changed my mind about teaching after my freshman year of college after taking a few education classes at WSU and not enjoying them as much as my Physics classes. All of my professors were incredibly caring and I consider myself quite close with most, if not all, of them. They have really pushed me towards a Physics degree as well.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: I became interested in physics as a high school student. I really wanted to learn more about how the world worked and, more specifically, about they physics of sound.

I grew up watching science shows with my dad and having his excitement rub off. He wanted to be a physicist but when he was a teenager his mother died and he ended up supporting his younger brother with no parents. I also want to find a way to help people through science and I love that physics relates and explains so many different phenomena`s and fields.
Codes: Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Utility Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: Physics was the first science class that I took in high school that I could really get into and understand without a problem. I didnÕt dread going to the class ever because it interested me so much and really challenged my thinking. I understood it and when I realized hat I could do much more with it than just teaching I knew I wanted to stay in physics.

I was heavily influenced by my high school physics teacher. He really made me enjoy the subject, and I couldn`t think of anything else I would rather major in going into college. Being a secondary education major came along in college. I never quite considered teaching high school beforehand, but good opportunities and a little more thinking lead me to pursue a career in teaching physics.

I had not taken any physics in high school, but when I took it in college, I realized that I really enjoy it. I have always loved math, so the two pair well. I have a deeply rooted desire to know HOW the universe works, and physics trues to understand some of that, so I am drawn to it. It was about this time last year, while I was in General Physics II that I realized I wanted to know more about it and changed my major from Biomedical Engineering to Physics. I have since taken Modern Physics, and am currently in Particle Physics and an Independent Physics Research class. I find these upper level classes to be difficult but fascinating, and I love the subject matter. It is amazing to me that the patterns that govern so much of nature are discoverable and understandable to people.

I first started college with the intention to study biology, but after one class, I decided that this was the wrong direction for my academic career. So I reevaluated my academic strengths and wanted to incorporate math into my academic studies. Before I could even consider engineering, physics stood outto me. What really persuaded me was the acceptance from students and faculty that convinced me that this was right for me.

I went to a college prep school that supported and encouraged young women to enter the sciences. Additionally I have very educated parents that always supported critical thinking and reasoning skills. I became a pilot which further reinforced my natural curiosity and love of learning.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: As a young person, I was inspired by my father, a PhD mathematician, to invest in my passion for math.  As a high schooler, hands-on experience with design led me toward mechanical engineering interests until I began reading about quantum physics and my interests shifted.  I have continued to enjoy and enthuse about physics since graduating from high school, seeking out exposure to and further engagement with my research interests through books, internships, and conversations with professors.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Physiological/Emotional

Response: my high school physics teacher encouraged me a lot and got me where i am today

My Junior year of high school, after a very long choir dress rehearsal, I was walking to my car (through the science hall) when I came across a room full of people doing various tasks. Some were programming, some were wiring, and some people were building. I didn`t know what was going on in that room,but I walked in anyway. It was my high school`s robotics team. After that day I fell in love with that team, and within a few months I was an officer. By the end of my Senior year I was very into all different kinds of science, but physics stuck out to me because I cannotthink of anything better to do than to learn, research, and discover how the world works.

I have always been a lover of science since I was a little girl. I constantly asked my parents detailed questions about how things worked. As I got older, my curiousity became more localized to geology and astronomy. When I was a youn teen, I was sure that I wanted to be a volcanologist. As I got older however, I began delving into physics and astronomy to the point that it became an obsessive hobby. I read, watched, and listened to everything I could on the subjects and even related subjects like chemistry, geology and biology. After I finished high school, I got married within a few years afterward and then had kids a few years on from that, so my academic career was put on hold to raise my kids while my husband worked. I thought that my academic career was over actually. All throughout my time as a stay-at-home mother, I continued to obssesively pursue astronomy and physics. Eventually, I decided that it was time to pursue a career in Physics. I had so much knowledge about the concepts of Physics but none of the math to back it up. Now I`m currently halfway through my academic career as an undergraduate in Physics. I have declared an Emphasis in Astronomy and a minor in Mathematics. So now I am able to really solidify my knowledge of Physics with the mathematics that so accurately describes it.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Attainment Value, Media Triggered

Response: I took an online class called Idaho Science and Aerospace Scholars in my Junior year of high school and attended the Summer academy. This gave me an idea of what it`s like to be a scientist.

I was first interested in physics and astronomy before first grade. My dad worked at NASA for seven years and I`ve always been interested in the "how" and the "why" and started trying to learn and understand from very early on.When I finally had my first physics class in my freshman year of high school, I learned that it was more fascinating than I had ever imagined possible. In my sophomore year of high school, I decided that I couldn`t wait until after high school graduation to continue with physics. So, I applied for college, got accepted, then dropped out of high school so I could start pursuing my education.
I enjoyed physics based classes and joined a physics based research lab.

I was introduced to physics just before entering high school, and there I was able to take challenging but very interesting courses and conduct research. I was attracted to physics first because of the fact that one concept or theorem could be used to explain countless phenomena, and then the fascination (after a lot of struggle) of devising a model to analyze a specific phenomenon. I am not sure about my abilities as a researcher yet, but I think I am going to focus on trying to learn and try out the basic tools of physics during my undergraduate years.

I discovered my interest in biophysics at the age of 15. At the time, I was volunteering in a Radiology lab and was interested in developing new contrast agents.I was specifically influenced by one of my close friends developing cancer and requiring the use of these novel contrast agents that had the potential of being useful to her.
1. Middle School Physics teacher: Wow you are so smart2. My parents being physicists3. When applying to college: "I don`t know what I want to do ut physics is something I`m familiar with."

I really enjoyed the AP physics courses I took in high school, and my high school physics teachers were excellent and passionate about the subject. This gave me the idea to pursue a minor in physics in college. Then I realized that I could major in both mathematics and physics. I enjoyed all of the physics courses I have taken in college, and my professors and other students helped me realize that I do belong in the physics community.

I didn`t start seriously considering physics until my senior year in high school. I love the mystery associated with it, since there is so much we don`t know.I`ve always loved the mystery of space, as well, and the combination really appealed to me. My parents have always been very supportive. The faculty atmy school are also very supportive to all the physics majors.
Before High school I was already very interested in physics concepts but it was my time in my honors and AP physics classes that grew that interest and made me want too major in physics.

I have always enjoyed math and sciences and from a young age found science in particular very captivating. Right out of high school I thought I wanted to own my own bakery but after some experience in the field I decided it wasn`t for me. While taking a few years off I did some critical thinking, and discovered that I wanted to be in a field where I felt like I`d make a difference, and for me that is physics. I still have a very long way to go in my journey to my higher education, but I feel that it meaningful work that I will hopefully be getting into and I can`t wait to be more involved.

It all started when I was offered the opportunity to apply to give a TEDx talk at my high school`s first TEDx event. Naturally, I couldn`t pass it up. The most interesting topic I could think to share was the concept behind black holes and time dilation`s role in the movie Interstellar. During the research process, I decided I wanted to dedicate a large chunk of my life to understanding and discovering physics phenomena. My dad`s endless enthusiasm for anything STEM-related emboldened my curiosity, and I grew to love math as well. A few years on, RIT provided me a strong support network in the Society for Physics Students and many ideas for research applications through our physics colloquia. I`m more certain than ever that physics is the discipline for me, even if I`m not entirely sure where it`ll lead.
Codes: Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Intrinsic (Social), Vicarious Experience

Response: I enjoy problem solving and really like taking on challenges. My physics classes at Brown offered that, and I am pretty interested in the material. I took the intro to astronomy class in my first college semester, and really enjoyed it. I knew I wanted to major in a non-biological science, and thought physics would be a better fit than chemistry. I do enjoy my classes and work, but am now considering work outside of physics after college.I have been encouraged by a few of the upperclassmen I know, especially some of the women in the year above me.

My high school calculus teacher saw potential in me from when I began taking a math class. He nurtured my natural curiosity for mathematics by encouraging me to strive toward goals that were both challenging and enriching. I started out as a mathematics major in college before I realized that I`d like to apply my abilities in math to the natural world, and to solve more than just logic problems and write proofs.My second year of college, I changed my major to a double major in astronomy and physics. I found my classes incredibly engaging and inspirational, and I thought of my professors and mentors as role models for someone I may like to become in the future. I have returned from my third consecutive summer internship interested more than ever in contributing real research and original thought to natural processes that occur. I really enjoyed working both in the laboratory on experiments and at the computer analyzing data. I feel that it is something I can see myself happily doing for the rest of my life because it is fulfilling, challenging, and simply fun.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered, Physiological/Emotional

Response: I always loved stem-type material and a grade schooler. In high school, I took my first physics class, and I really enjoyed that it was the first time that I was learning the most fundamental laws and rules of how science works. My teacher was very invested in the material and I just fell in love with physics. I applied to college as a physics major and developed a close group of peers that have encouraged my success in the major and excitement for the material.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: Around my junior year of high school I developed an interest in physics while I was taking my first AP physics course. I had an amazing teacher, and while I genuinely enjoyed almost every subject I had learned in school so far, this was the first time I thought about pursuing a subject further. When I was applying to colleges senior year, I was torn between physics and anthropology, but I ultimately decided to apply under physics, and I have stuck with it since.

In High School, I had to take Honors Physics under an amazing female physics teacher. Everyone treated the class as a joke, but I found it interesting and I was good at it. I was not aware of the gender inequality issues specific to the Physics field until I left her class and took AP under a male teacher. Without her, I would have never considered going into the Physics field.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Cost (Emotional)

Response: Cosmos aired when I was fourteen years old, and I never missed an episode. Six years later, despite feeling inadequate and behind and inferior to my peers, here I am, hoping to study the cosmos.

My uncle works for NASA and I have been interested in physics ever since I went down to see him at his workplace. I always knew I wanted to do science but was not sure what field exactly. Physics was something I have never tried before and thought I would give it a shot. I also did summer internship out at Dartmouth College this past summer which really got me interested in Space an Astrophysics.

I have always been really interested in Astronomy and Astrophysics. It all began when I was 4 years old and my father and grandfather took me to the science museum in Sao Paulo, Brazil to learn about the universe (especially the solar system). In high school, astronomy was my favorite subject. I met a young girl on a summer camp during my high school`s senior year, and when we were talking about our families, she told me her sister studied Astrophysics in the United States. Before that, I had never considered having a career in physics/astrophysics. But when I talked to a young woman who was pursuing that career, I realized that was possible and decided to apply to a Physics major at universities in the United States so I can study Physics and later Astrophysics. During this summer, I worked with professor Ben Mazin and his graduate student Isabel Lipartito on the Mazin lab, and that experience led me to learn more on what I believe is my favorite research topic in astrophysics: exoplanets.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I have always been highly interested in the planets, and galaxies, and the universe. This led me to do research on careers and and finding out what I need to do learn more. Because it is what interests me the most, I decided I wanted to become an astrophysicist.

I first encounter physics in high school and thought that the subject was really interesting. Getting into college that when I really got to know and struggle with physic but was fascinated with how physics can explain why many things that act the way they act and that physic is all around us and that what led me to go into a physics-related major.

In high school, I was very interested in physics and did very well in the class. When applying for college I wasn`t sure what major to choose because several of the majors seem interesting for different reasons. I chose physics at that time because it sounded like an interesting and broad major that could help me explore various areas in the future. I was sure about my choice after my first semester because I had talked to several of the physics professors and got a better idea on where physics could lead me in the future.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: From a young age I got bored by common phenomenon, and then became infatuated with the strange aspects of space. I`ve continued to look into Astronomy since than (3rd Grade.)

My sister was majoring in physics when I visited her, and I ended up attending a couple of her classes with her. I thought the subjects were fascinating, and it made me want to pursue a degree in physics as well.

When I was a kid, I definitely spent a lot of time looking at the stars and meteor showers, and I also did a lot of camping out in my front yard just to feel connected with the stars and sleep out underneath them. I watched a lot of PBS and NOVA type shows, and so a deep curiosity for the most unknown things in our universe was developed from an early age. From the moment that I learned of the word astrophysics, I became interested in becoming one, but there was not a big physics program at my old high school and so I did not see myself going down this path out of a lack of knowledge on the matter. However, I then went to a science and math boarding school, and while I was intimidated by the field, I also became more familiar with it, and I decided that I would try and become either a theoretical physicist or an astrophysicist and major in related fields in college. Yet, through my wide-reaching and deep curiosity, I also discovered the fields of psychology and psychology, and my interests in neuroscience as a combination of physics, psychology, and philosophy outweighed my interests in astrophysics, so I switched majors to physics and psychology. After researching black holes and simulating accretion disks around them for a summer, I found that astrophysics was not the career path for me, but I also came to have a deeper understanding and appreciation for the mysteries of our universe. I was heavily influenced by mentors who encouraged me to pursue physics, particularly philosophy professors, as well as the influence of the physics community on constantly sparking my imagination.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I did a project in middle school on elementary particles, which introduced me to physics, and then I had a very good calculus teacher in high school who encouraged me to pursue physics.

I never liked in physics at all until I took a Modern Physics course in high school. I hadn`t even considered the class, but a female friend of mine a year older than me said that she had taken it and loved it, and she wasn`t even interested in science at all. So I signed up for both Modern and AP Biology, thinking I would love Bio and learn some cool stuff in Modern. To my surprise, while Bio wasn???t bad, it didn???t grab me like it did other people. What grabbed me was physics ??? on our first day, we learned a rudimentary form of dimensional analysis, and I was blown away by how elegantly we could talk about things happening using math. (Incidentally, my interest in math blossomed here, too). After that, I ended up at a small liberal arts school taking Introductory Physics (but actually paying attention this time!). I was initially insecure about being the only girl in the class, and the cockiness of the guys made me worry that I wasn???t good enough to be a physics major, but the only female junior at the time took me under her wing and didn???t let me think that way for long. Now I???m the lone woman in the upper class, but we???ve got 2 sophomores and 5 or 6 freshmen ladies interested in the major, and seeing them really gives me hope on the hard days. My current goal is to finish my degrees in physics and French and to find a way to use physics to study language. But we???ll see!
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Emotional), Utility Value

Response: I`ve been very interested in astronomy for as long as I can remember. The summer prior to my first physics course (Junior year of high school), I knew that physics/astrophysics was the path for me. Have never doubted that since.
I enjoy and understand physics, which caused me to seriously consider it as my major.

One of the biggest factors is the fantastic teachers I`ve had. In my first physics class (junior year of high school), I found very quickly that (1) I loved the subject matter and (2) I very much enjoyed my time in class. My first teacher was someone I knew very well (my cross country coach), which meant that my first interactions with physics were in a fun and comfortable environment. As a result, I chose to take physics my senior year of high school (instead of chem or bio). The teacher of my senior physics class did a notably great job getting people excited about physics, which still sticks with me. Freshman year of college, I was lucky to end up in an engaging small class, where I was encouraged to go to events outside of class and get involved (with things like CUWiP!). I declared my major last year, and everything I`ve experienced thus far has made me even more confident in that decision!
Codes: Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience

Response: My first physics class was AP Physics B in high school. I had a great experience and a great teacher, so I took AP Physics C the following year. Because I enjoyed it and excelled in it, I decided to pursue a physics degree at Kenyon. I also found in high school that I was good at explaining physics concepts to other students, so I am currently considering careers in education, as well as engineering.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Utility Value, Physiological/Emotional

Response: I was always very good at science in school, but it all started in 7th grade when we first went over Newton???s three laws. We didn`t have enough time to really get in depth about the topic so only a week was spent on the subject, but I wanted to know more. I was also in this program called AVID which was supposed to be a college preparatory program, but that year I had A???s in all my classes except my AVID class which I was given a B. There were these things we had to do called tutorials held twice a week where we asked questions about our homework or things we didn???t understand. One week I kept asking about light; what makes light? Where do the colours come from? How do we know they are that colour other than from seeing? Until one of the teaching assistants pulled me to the side and told me that maybe I shouldn???t ask those kinds of questions yet. In High school it was all about Biology and Chemistry, both exceedingly tough classes with the most amazing teachers I owe my education to. At one time I was worried about my grades, I understood most of the material and worked hard to get everything done, but my grades never reflected that. My teacher pulled me aside, but this time rather than telling me to give up; she told me that it isn???t always about the grade you make in the class, but what you take away from the class. I could make straight A???s and never understand what I was taught, and I could make straight D???s, but surpass all my peers. Of course why not do both, make straight A???s and surpass the nay-sayers, but that day, that woman taught me not to doubt myself because of where I came from or what a piece of paper told me. I have made it my goal to better understand the world around me so that maybe one day I can help it, give back to it, make it better, and physics is where I find myself. I might not be the best physics student when it comes to getting perfect grades and reiterating what my professors write down, but I always strive to fully understand.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Event Triggered, Social Persuasion, Cost (Task Effort)

Response: Both my parents have technical degrees so I have had a strong influence of math and science in my household from early on. Once I got into school, math and science became my favorite subjects and I even joined robotics club in middle school for a bit. When deciding on a degree, it was evident to me that I wanted to pursue a degree in STEM and I chose physics in particular because it is limitless in my opinion and can be used in any field.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: I took physics during my senior year of high school and I believe my teacher mentioned quantum mechanics in class, so I went home and researched what it is. Then, that lead me to find out about astrophysics and I started reading books and watching documentaries about relativity and became obsessed with astrophysics.

In middle school, one of my best friends and I got really in to sci-fi, like Star Trek and Doctor Who, and one day we just kinda asked "why?". I eventually understood that physics is a big part of astronomy, so I decided to study physics and astronomy at NAU since I was so passionate about astronomy (and she`s studying Earth and space exploration at ASU).
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience

Response: My high school physics teacher had a profound effect on me pursuing physics in college. I grew to love physics as I took it in college, and even more so, I found a knack forcomputer science. I have always had a lot of support frommy family and professors to pursue and further my physicscareer.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: I initially got interested in astronomy in physics in 7th grade after reading a novel in which one of the main characters was an astrophysicist. The character`s passion inspired me to investigate the field, and I was hooked. Though my path to physics and astronomy wasn`t exactly direct (I spent two years at art school before realizing I would rather be in a STEM field), I`m glad to be studying it.

One of my choir teachers talked about one of her friends who was an astrophysicist. I thought about how cool it would be to study astronomy and math since I really enjoyed science and math. I have since changed my passion a little bit to a materials science focus, but still enjoy utilizing physics to make sense of physical phenomena.

Ever since I was a child I have always had a fascination with science, space, and math. I knew I wanted to do something in the math or science fields since I started thinking about life after school. I tried to take classes in different areas (biology, chemistry, etc.) until I realized I wasn`t enjoying the material. When I took my first physics class I was discouraged by how cruel the teacher was but realized I enjoyed doing the coursework more than any other science class I had taken at the time. It was my senior year of High School that I realized I wanted to major in Physics and initially minor in Astronomy, as I`ve always loved space. I spent my first semester of college at RIT and did not feel welcomed by anyone in my department. They were very hesitant around females and my male professors said some very rude and discouraging things to me. This made me feel like this wasn`t the major or University for me so I transferred to my local community college the next semester with the intentions of taking classes until I could transfer to the right University and make my primary major Astronomy. After three semesters I finally found my way to Umass. Here I took Physics 181 with Professor Jenny Ross my first semester, as an Astronomy major. She changed my feelings towards physics and I have decided to now double major in Astronomy and Physics. This one professor made me feel welcomed and like I deserved to be in the classroom when no one else did. I will forever appreciate her for that.
Codes: Attainment Value, Physiological/Emotional, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion

Response: I have always held a deep fascination with the night sky and it`s implications of our place in the universe. In high school, I became enthralled with books and interviews by physicists such as Stephen Hawking and Neil Degrasse Tyson. I was able to take my first physics class my senior year of high school which led to a pretty instantaneous declaration as a physics major in my college applications.

What led me to physics is astronomy. I`ve been interested in astronomy since Mr. Hudson`s science class in 4th grade. I was in awe of this notion that the universe was so very big, and I wanted to explore that. I remember asking for a telescope for Christmas that year, and I got an Easy-Bake Oven instead. I was constantly told I wasn`t smart enough to do math or science, and there were many factors throughout my childhood that reinforced this. So, when I finally got to college, I majored in English, because everything in my life was telling me that I wasn`t smart enough, and that I should pursue what came easy to me. I was depressed. I loved English, I loved words, and I loved writing papers, but I knew in my heart it wasn`t what I wanted to do. I knew I was on the wrong path, but the path I wanted seemed impossible. I gave up on that English degree and took a few years off from school. When I went back, I took an Intro to Astronomy class, just to see if that fire was still there. The fire was definitely there. I immediately switched majors. I know Physics and Astronomy go hand in hand. I have to work very, very hard at Physics for the material to click, it doesn`t come naturally at all, but the struggle is worth it, because I know I`m on the right path now.

Both of my parents were born in Los Alamos, and 3/4 of my grandparents worked for Los Alamos National Labs during the Manhattan Project. My first memory of anything physics-related was during the last years of the Cold War, standing in front of the replicas of the Fat Man and Little Boy casings. I was probably 7, and put together that these relatively tiny objects had all but leveled cities that were not significantly different from the one I was living in - I understood, all at once, the implication of E=mc^2, and knew that my family was somehow involved in carnage depicted in the photos of post-bomb Hiroshima and Nagasaki.For many years after that, I tried to not think about physics - I studied anything and everything, fairly seriously pursued art & music and read constantly on a wide variety of subjects.At some point in my early 20s it became clear that I needed, to whatever extent possible, to understand this thing my family had helped create. I started reading anything I could find that was related: the histories leading up to World War II, the complicated interplay of nationalism and fear that allowed the Nazis to come to power and anything else I could find that explored the stakes involved in the decision to attempt building a nuclear weapon. Then I needed to understand how the bomb was built; I started reading history and pop science books specifically about the Manhattan Project. A few years later, I realized it had been over two years since I`d read a book that wasn`t about physics. I also noticed that my focus had broadened - reading about the Manhattan Project had lead to reading about nuclear physics which had lead to reading about quantum mechanics and from there things were getting decidedly out of hand. The problem was that my pile of books was getting bigger and bigger, but the additional depth of understanding was decreasing with each one I read - these were pop science books, after all. That is: it was rapidly becoming clear that the level of understanding I wanted was not available between the covers of any pop science book. Within six months of this realization, I had enrolled at my local community college and started taking the math pre-reqs I needed for calculus-based physics courses. The more I learned, the more I needed to learn more. I all but stopped playing music and practicing art and I went to school full time, year round until I had completed the classes available at community college.By that time, I was nearly two years in, and nowhere near satiated, so I started looking in to transferring to a four year school. I discovered that the program at the local state school would likely be frustrating (I understand they`re primarily known for the engineering program) but that Reed (which is also local). Instead, I applied to Reed College, and started as a sophomore in fall 2013. At this point (midway through my junior year) I`m fairly certain that the next 1.5 years are not going to be enough either....
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Cost (Emotional), Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value

Response: I have wanted to become a physicist since the first grade. I was fascinated by learning how the universe worked. Throughout school, I took as many classes and read as many books as I could on the subject. In college, I am a physics major so I have taken many physics classes and my love for physics has only grown. I also have done research for the past two years in an experimental condensed matter lab and it is extremely fulfilling. Working in the lab has verified to me that I want to pursue a graduate degree in physics and continue working in academia.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered

Response: In middle school I started watching NOVA and decided that I was very interested in physics and astronomy. Therefore I decided to study physics.
My Grandfather was an electrical engineer and I have always had a passion for innovation and opportunities to learn.

I first considered physics in high school. In my community college, I became a NASA Aerospace Scholar and decided I wanted to pursue mechanical engineering, but I still have a love for physics and would like to minor or perhaps double major in physics.
Codes: Utility Value, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: I have always liked science and after taking high school level physics, I decided it held my interest the most. My dad was a physics major in college and encouraged me to pursue it. When I entered college I found other students who held the same enthusiasm as me, and I felt like I was in the right place. Since then, I have continued to take physics courses and on average enjoy them.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social), Physiological/Emotional

Response: I came to college as a music major, and I took a physics course to fulfill my requirement of a lab science. During my physics course, I got to know some of the physics majors in the study room, and was curious on the different classes they were taking. I knew that I wanted to pursue education, and saw that there was a program for physics education. I then changed my major to physics and explored more and realized how much I loved being in the lab and the community that is in the physics department at my university reinforced my decision of pursuing Physics.

I spent three semesters as a West Point cadet. My third semester was rough. I was very depressed, thousands of miles from home, and growing increasingly interested in a civilian guy who was not supportive of me staying in the Army. My grades were slipping and my desire to stay was waning. I tried to see an Army psychiatrist, but I realized quickly that she was assessing my fitness for the Army more than she was trying to help me. My introductory physics instructor was a major in the Air Force who was in the process of transitioning to civilian life. I had stopped turning in homework for his class. He knew I was intelligent and knew that I was more than capable of turning in my homework and doing well in his class. He eventually reported me to my TAC officer, and I received 5 walking hours as punishment. I resented him initially for doing this, but I am now extraordinarily thankful that he sent the negative report to my TAC officer. The walking hours were a wake up call, and I snapped back into doing my work and studying kinematics. I did eventually leave the Academy at the end of that third semester. At the very end, my physics instructor made me sit down and chat with him. I hadn`t told him half of what was going on, but he was intelligent enough to read the subtleties. He told me a story about another female cadet he and his family had grown close to who wanted to leave the Academy because of an unsupportive girlfriend. He inspired a great deal of confidence in me when I felt like I had none. When I decided to attend BSU last year, I thought about my physics instructor at West Point, and I just knew I could do physics long term. Now I am at the tail end of my third semester at Boise State, and I am thriving in my physics major. Side note: Below I indicated that I have completed Electromagnetism I and Linear Algebra. This is not entirely true since I am currently taking both classes, but I will have completed them by the time of the APS conference in January.

As far back as I can remember, I`ve been fascinated with and captivated by the cosmos and what lies beyond our own infinitesimal world. Alastair Reynolds, Isaac Asimov, Douglas Adams, Orson Scott Card, Arthur C. Clarke, Ray Bradbury, Anne McCaffrey, and the Killer B???s ??? Gregory Benford, Greg Bear and David Brin ??? have captured my imagination, fed my curiosity and expanded my vision, so much so that I knew, even in early elementary school, that I was going to be an astrophysicist. I decided that physics would be a strong foundation to lead to a career in astrophysics or astronomy.In high school, I took AP physics as a junior, and there I had my first real experience with sexism in physics. My teacher told the girls in my class not to be worried if the boys did better than we did because physics comes more naturally to boys. I have to say that, as awful as that was to hear, it has only strengthened my resolve.

I have loved the sciences, and after taking biology, chemistry, and then physics (in that order) I loved each one more than the last. My high school physics teacher in particular encouraged me to continue with physics and I highly valued his opinion and have stuck with it ever since.

I have always been passionate about astronomy and space, and people told me that physics was the way to get into these fields. I was lucky in high school to have a very inspiring and motivated teacher who believed I could learn concepts. That trend has continued in college, from astronomy to electromagnetism to astrodynamics. When I have interacted in a research capacity with members of the astronomy community, they have been welcoming.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I decided to major in physics my sophomore year of college because I liked the problem solving and the challenge of it and it seemed more applicable than math.

At the beginning of my high school career, I had never considered studying any subject in the STEM field. I completed a study abroad my junior year and this gave me a whole new perspective in general, especially science. I became fascinated with my science courses when I returned for my senior year, prompting me to pursue the study of Mechanical Engineering. After over a year of taking hard science and math courses, I continue to be fascinated by the application of physics in engineering.

I took 3 years of physics in high school, one year of honors and two years of IB. I chose that because after the mandatory first year of classes, I found I really enjoyed the challenges and problem solving skills. In college, I initially declared a Chem major, but after two weeks in my first college level physics course, I declared physics as a major. It wasn`t long after that I changed my Chemistry declaration to a minor because I found that I was much more fascinated--even by just the lectures--in physics and the idea of doing physics research sounded much more exciting to me. I honestly think I`ve put more thought into staying in physics, rather than when I made the decision to declare physics as a major.

When I decided to attend a residential public school for academically talented high school students, I was enrolled in my first physics course. I love the intricacies of the problems and the way we were given tools that can be applied to multiple problems. Since then, I have tried to continue my physics education, eventually leading to me loving it enough to pursue a career in one of its many subfields.

I didn`t have any good experiences with science in high school. When I got to college, my father suggested I take an astronomy course for a gen ed and said it would be fun. I loved the subject matter and read the book cover to cover and loved my professor. I liked that the subject challenged me as all other classes came easy to me. I took a=another class with this professor for fun in the winter term and decided to switch to physics to give it a trytelling myself if I failed, I could switch back majors. It`s been extremely difficult. I was always used to gettinggood grades and in some of my classes, nobody received an A. I also faced some harassment along the way due to my genderand particularly due to the way I express myself as very feminine with dresses, dyed hair, etc. I also received criticismor doubt from my peers because I have an English major and a minors in Spanish and Dance. As these areas are very differentfrom physics, I would experience jokes at the expense of my varied interests and that I couldn`t possibly be as good at physicsbecause I dance and excel at writing/reading.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Cost (Emotional)

Response: As a student at college I have always thought about a field in engineering. When I got to Central I then considered the duel degree of both physics and engineering. My mentors have convinced me that with physics will also open new opportunities as well as engineering. Overall I am working towards that goal of 2 Bachelors of Science in Physics and Mechanical Engineering from 2 different schools.

I was interested in math, taking BC Calculus my junior year of high school and enjoyed the physics-based questions, so I enrolled in AP Physics for my senior year. After enjoying the different problem-solving techniques I was taught, I decided that I wanted to major in it in college. My academic adviser was then very supportive of this decision, and I have enjoyed the classes and connections I have made with professors along the way.

I first considered physics as an option junior year of high school when I took my first physics class. Before the class, I considered becoming an accountant. After exceeding my expectations for myself in the class I decided to think about pursuing a career in physics. I found the material interesting and everything just made sense. This is also the time I was thinking about teaching. I started tutoring essentially my entire physics class. By the end of that year I decided on pursuing physics in college and perhaps teaching. While visiting schools that summer I became interested in Astrophysics. I am still interested in the field but after become the only physics tutor in the honor society at my school my senior year and some soul searching I decided that teaching is what I truly wanted to do. Today, I am interested in research, preferably focused in education, and still enjoy my physics and education classes.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value (PER), Physiological/Emotional

Response: During high school, I reached out to the closest university I could find, University of Washington, in search for some taste of physics.My high school physics class made me far too curious about physics to simply sit at a desk. My physics teacher was incredibly passionate and this drew me in to the subject even further. I wanted to experience it for myself. I ended up working at an observatory with a professor from the University of Washington and fell in love. This inspired me to become a physics major.This also caused me to desire a career in high school science education. In the long run,I would love to teach high school physics and show the amazing world of science to young explorative minds.Furthermore, this past summer, I came across a research opportunity with a professor in the physics department. I worked during the summer of 2014 on polymer based solar cells and realized that this was where I belonged. I love to learn and what better place than a lab. Because of this, I strive to seek out new opportunities in the lab and in the field. I want to explore as manytopics as possible while I am still discovering my identity in science.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: I was taking a physics course in high school but my teacher didnÕt have much faith in me and my abilities. I ended up talking AP Physics with this teacher and proving him wrong. Also, when I was a child, the physical sciences were the only thing I focused on.

When I was in high school I took classical mechanics.  During that time, I discovered lectures notes of a professor on General Relativity and I started asking my physics teacher questions about it .  Then I discovered the rest of the lecture notes for various topics in Physics such as Lasers< dark matter, etc. After a year of studying Physics and going through these lecture notes I was sure there was nothing else I would want to learn more about or contribute to than Physics. In my first year, we had to take Physics Colloquium, where we had to choose a topic and present it at the end of the semester.  I found the paper on the topological structure of the Borromean Rings and the Efimov state .  Ever since then IÕve been invested in the relationship between Math and Physics and how they influence one another.

In high school, I took AP Physics 1 and C. I didn`t do too well in the AP exams, but something had me coming back. Originally, I intended to go into Biology and go towards the pre-med track. However, when applying to Virginia Tech, a school known for engineering, I decided to apply for Physics. I ended up going to Virginia Tech and taking Physics. I really enjoyed the class and stuck through with it.

I grew up in an extremely religious family but did not believe in God the way they do. For me, there has never been anything more fulfilling than studying physics. When I am in physics and math class I feel closer to knowing God than I ever did in a church.

Since elementary school, I`ve been interested in the sciences. Some of my favorite shows were Planet Earth, Into the Universe with Stephen Hawking, and How the Earth Was Made. Throughout the rest of grade school, science and math came easier to me than English and history, so I naturally gravitated towards those subjects. When we briefly covered space science in eighth grade, I knew I wanted to go to college and study something about space. Everything we learned in that unit - from the formation of stars to the Big Bang - was fascinating to me, especially black holes. I went to a college preparatory high school with the intent of finding a college with a good physics degree program, a smaller student body, and professors who are experts in their fields.

I attended supplemental instruction (SI) sessions every day after class for my intro physics classes. I was taking these classes as a cognate to my math major and seemed easy enough to translate these classes into a minor, which is what I did. One of my physics SI leaders recommended I be an SI leader in physics as well so I became one and I am now the Senior SI Leader for physics, acting as a bridge between the other leaders and the SI coordinator for all departments. My first physics SI leader then became my lab instructor, he and several other students would be graduating and he recommended I look into his research group in which there would be several vacancies. I attended one of their meeting, and I became eager to change my major to Physics and join this gravitational wave group. Since my joining, I have attended several conference to share my projects and have also done an abroad research experience in Australia. The community I am a part of in the physics department has changed school from a chore to a community.

I have always had an interest in how things work mechanically. In high school, I struggled through math and physics, but I discovered that I truly had a passion for them. In college, I started out as a physics education major, but changed to strictly physics. The math and physics community at my university has always been a great source of support. The faculty and fellow physics majors are looking out for each other and always looking for ways to help each other. My decision to major in physics and pursue a PhD in astrophysics has been fostered by my family. The tremendous amount of support I have received has been amazing.

I originally wanted to go into Aerospace engineering, but UCSC does not have it as a major. I decided to pursue physics and get experience in aerospace. However, as I started doing research in Astrophysics I quickly realized that my true passions were in Astronomy and Astrophysics. Presently I am continuing research in astrophysics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Utility Value, Event Triggered

Response: I`ve always wanted to pursue astronomy, but I wasn`t sure about physics. Many of my high school classmates assumed that since I was passionate about astronomy, that I`d also do well in AP Physics. However, I consistently received low grades on exams, and would have to consistently retake them in order to do well. In the EM section of the course, I was almost failing and was given the option to have my grade be based on how well I do on my final. I didn`t know where to begin, or how to succeed in physics, but I decided to watch Neil DeGrasse Tyson`s Cosmos one night. The episode I watched focused on Michael Faraday and his contribution to electricity and magnetism, despite growing up poor and having little background in mathematics. Learning about Michael Faraday being one of the greatest minds of his time, in spite of his upbringing, made me realize I can also be a physicist. I started studying as much as possible the month before the exam. Although I kept getting questions wrong, I pushed through and wanted to learn the physics rather than get the question correct. I eventually took the exam, and received one of the height grades on it. I realized that I can also be a physicist.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience

Response: The person that influenced me to major in physics was my spouse.  He introduced me to the subject when I was undetermined when choosing a major. As an astrophysics major he had access to many lectures and labs at UCB and he would take me with him to sit in the lectures to get an idea on what physics is and what is the study behind it was like. Later on I declared my major to be physics because mostly all my interest, mainly math and science, came together in the material presented and I grew a passion for physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: I always wanted to be a mechanical engineer because I liked designing machines. My love for physics began when I took physics in high school. I was lucky to have a wonderful teacher named Mr. Houston at Indian River High School.
Codes: Utility Value, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: As a child, I really enjoyed school, especially my science and math classes. I also enjoyed reading the STEM books that my grandfather had and looking up at the night sky for hours at a time. By the time I got to high school, I was two years ahead in math and I knew that I wanted to go into a field relating to mathematics in some way. My grandfather took me to see the Palomar Observatory with the Hale telescope over the summer before high school, and I watched Dr. Neil DeGrasse Tyson`s COSMOS when it came out my sophomore year of high school. Those two events led me to look for degrees in Physics and Astronomy, and after I visited Embry-Riddle and found out about their Space Physics degree, I decided to go there to begin my career in Physics.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: I have 3 older siblings, and they all have succeeded in college and outside. My dad is a computer scientist and 2 of my siblings also studied this, with my eldest sister studying applied mathematics. I was always encouraged to do something with the sciences and math, and sophomore year I took physics and loved it. I went through IB Physics HL, and was utterly inspired by astrophysics and the complexity of it. My highschool physics teacher had attended MIT as a physicist, and I admired his knowledge of it. In addition, I talked to some women in Astrophysics about the field and after hearing about their experiences, was excited to major in it.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: Throughout middle and high school I excelled in areas of science and math. Physics was one of my favorite classes so I decided to major in it.
I became a physicist because I like to solve problems and my high school AP physics teacher told me I could never succeed as a physicist so I set out to prove him wrong.

I started undergrad as a double major with music and chemistry. Unfortunately (or fortunately), I wasn`t able to fit in any chemistry classes my first semester, and took physics instead. I fell in love with all the math that goes into physics as well as how it explains everyday things, and haven`t looked back at chemistry since.

I was always interested in science and had a fondness for the cosmos, along with an interest to explore becoming an astronaut or working within astronomy. As I grew older my innate curiosity continued and my philosophical view on life prompted me to further my studies in science in order to gain a more cosmic and universal perspective. After a series of different employments, such as analyst at an energy company and that of physics lab assistant, I was convinced that research, science, and working in a lab satisfied my personality and quest for knowledge. Moreover it fulfilled moral and ethical standards that my interests would make a difference with having little to no adverse effects.

I considered becoming a physics major when my high school physics teacher gave a presentation on why I should get an undergraduate degree in physics. He said that it would be challenging but would pay well and give me skills that would make it easy for me to get a job in another field if I didn`t end up liking it. I have always enjoyed physics so I figured I would give it a shot. I still enjoy physics and will continue to pursue it, but I don`t have any other specific influences on why physics.

Mostly from a lifelong interest in space and astronomy. It never really went away when the years went by. So when I started applying to different Universities, there was really only Physics that interested me.

I was first interested in Biology in high school. However, once I took AP Physics in my senior year of high school, I realized I might like physics more than biology. I also really enjoyed math and physics involved more math than biology did, so I felt it would be a better fit for me. I started off college already as a physics major, and taking classes has only strengthened my wish to major in physics and confirmed for me that this was what I wanted to study.

My high school physics teacher was very good at getting people interested in physics. There was one problem in class where we had to find Louis Lane`s terminal velocity when superman dropped her. That`s when I wanted to be a physics major.

I first took an intro to engineering and met few women who were enrolled in the class. Some guest speakers who visited the class made it a point to tell the females in the class to stick with the major. Then I had met a classmate in a chemistry class who was heavily involved in the physics/engineering department. She inspired me to keep pursuing this career and get more involved in the physics program.

I always loved space and science, ever since I was a very little kid. Luckily, my parents were very supportive and bought me a small telescope which I loved to take video from using an eyepiece camera. They bought me books like, "You Can Be A Woman Astronomer." I would study online in my free time. The stars sparked my curiosity and my desire to understand the world around me. I wanted to be an astronomer or an astronaut. However, I applied to the Extended Learning Program in fifth grade at my elementary school, and I did not qualify due to one test in math in second grade where I received a 75%. I felt like my dreams were shattered and I had no more confidence in math or science from that moment onward. I was ashamed and decided to focus on English instead. Through middle school I had a plethora of people, including close friends, telling me that my newfound dream to become a particle physicist and work at CERN was unrealistic and unattainable. There was a misconception that only geniuses like Einstein could do jobs like that. I decided to put science on the back burner through high school. I didn`t even take physics. I did take astronomy in my senior year though, and I loved it. When I entered university, I was initially working towards an International Relations major, studying at the University of British Columbia. Then, I had a stroke. I came back home and started attending the University of Utah while recovering. I realized that International Relations wasn`t my passion, and I reverted back to my original love, physics. I have stuck with it ever since, even though I have dealt with extremely misogynistic professors and a department in turmoil. I worked as a Dark Ranger in Bryce Canyon National Park and for Gemini Observatory in Hawaii which helped to light the fire under me to continue in physics, and also to teach.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Cost (Emotional), Media Triggered, Event Triggered

Response: My teachers influenced me, as well as news and internet resources that publish articles and videos on science and technology. Also, physics history has inspired me to pursue physics.

I first considered being a physics major after watching a movie about the high tensions and emotions involved in the development of the ideas of quantum leaping. After that I just stayed on this path because it is challenging and fun.

I discovered quantum mechanics and thought it was just ridiculously cool. That`s when I started to go to science-oriented summer camps...it was those experiences that really solidified my love of physics and encouraged me to pursue research outside of high school. I really think it helped having supportive parents that allowed me to explore whatever I wanted.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Social Persuasion

Response: I started considering physics my junior year of high school when I took my first physics class. My high school teacher was amazing and really pushedme to pursue physics based on my ability, high understanding, and obviousinterest. After taking AP physics and receiving a 5 on the AP exam, I knew physics was for me. In college, I have had some great opportunities, includingworking with my professor on optics research over the summer. My school also has a small but supportive physics community, which has greatly impacted my understanding and knowledge in many physics topics, many outside the scope of my classes.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: High school senior year I took Astronomy for fun, soon being involved in the wonder of the stars by an eccentric teacher. After his class, I wanted to major in that field and become someone who finds a way to use dark energy as a power source for space travel.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience, Utility Value

Response: Growing up I always had a mind similar to my dad`s, and when faced with the choice of physics or chemistry in high school, he suggested that I`d probably enjoy physics. I was good at it in high school, and decided I wanted to be a mechanical engineer in college. But after getting to college I realized I really just enjoyed the pure physics and I`ve been happy with it ever since.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Utility Value, Physiological/Emotional

Response: Through reading books about physics

I was in high school and took an engineering course and I loved it. I decided I wanted to be an Engineer and as the years progressed I took as many physics and engineering courses as possible in high school. In college I will have took the highest math and physics my school has to offer and want to expand my knowledge of both physics and engineering.
I really enjoyed physics in highschool which led me to pursue a Bachelor`s degree in Physics at UCCS.  Since starting my degree, I have come to enjoy this topic even more.
