I am a physics major because I would like to become an engineer in the future. I would like to create thing that will be a benefit to people who are disabled. I personally have family members and friends who are disabled that could really benefit from some new inventions. My main goal is to be able to help people have a better life.

I`ve always been really good in math, so when I took physics in high school and did well, and thought that the applications to astrophysics/cosmology were really interesting, I figured I should continue in college. I took two freshman seminars dealing with scales in the universe and cosmology related stuff (along with the standard physics 101 and 102 courses) and enjoyed and did very well in both, so I decided to ask the professor that I had if I could do research with him. I had an amazing experience the summer following my freshman year doing research, so then I declared my major in physics during my sophomore year, even though that had been my plan for a while by that point. I also declared my math major in the fall semester of my junior year to help out with the math side of things so that I have a better foundation for grad school.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I first became interested at an international leadership in Iceland regarding alternative energy. My goal has always been since then and is still to use a physics degree to research alternative energy, specifically green energy.

I started with a passion for medicine, which turned to an interest in biomedical physics just before starting my freshman year. Learning about a major that could have such a wide range of talents and ways to use the degree really interested me. From first hearing that I could help design devices that could be used to help people really pulled me in. I did a summer research program where we worked on a device that could be used like a sticker of sorts but would be able to take different vital readings and send them through the internet to both the patients phone but also to their doctor`s office. I am now continuing research with a different professor and hope to continue this research work as a career path.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Medical), Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: As a kid I loved astronomy and math, and really liked how physics combines the two. In high school I had the opportunity to take IB physics classes higher level for two years, which really showed me the breadth and scope of physics and the multitude of ways that it applies to life. I considered engineering, but did not want to have to specialize quickly but rather see how physics works in many ways.

I started out wanting to do health sciences and I was better at math in high school so I thought I would do physics. I have always been interested in astronomy and I wanted to learn more about physics.

It is something I have enjoyed since the basics of Physical science in 7th grade. My physics teacher in high school showed me all the different opportunities a physics degree brings, and I love the idea of being able to pursue so many different careers with a background of a subject I love so much. I have always loved math and excelled at it, and physics gave a purpose to that math as well.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion

Response: Growing up, I always had a passion for science (specifically astronomy) and I liked math, but I hadn`t really considered majoring in physics until the 9th grade. Previous to that year, I wanted to pursue an acting career. Everything changed when I saw the movies "Interstellar" and "The Theory of Everything" that came out on 2014. I was blown away by them. I suddenly remembered all of the astronomy talks I had had with my father growing up, and how much I enjoyed learning new things about space. I also thought about how I always wondered how things worked and moved in our universe. I was that kid with a million questions about why everything works the way it does, questioning everything. After seeing both movies, something clicked inside me; I realized I could turn that curiosity and love for the universe into a profession. I started researching exactly what and where did Stephen William Hawking studied. I kept researching different branches of cosmology and astronomy, until I found "Astrophysics." After reading about the profession for a couple of hours, I knew that that was the profession I was going to pursue. I also realized I`m interested in other branches of physics, which is why I went with a Physics major and not an astronomy one, just in case I decide to switch into a different branch in the future. I am, however, planning on doing a minor in astrophysics at my university starting next year.

I have always been in love with science. I`ve always wanted to know more, and had a passion for physics before I even knew what it was. I spent a lot of time as a child at museums because I had such a thirst to learn. My favorites were the Museum of Science in Boston and the New England Aquarium. At the Museum of Science I was free to explore concepts that were new to me in ways that were easy for me to understand. Even if I didn`t fully understand something, I was not discouraged. In high school, I fell in love with physics. I have always been strong in math, and was pleased to find a field that I could excel in. I find myself applying things that I learned in class to my every day activities and life. When my car has trouble in the snow, I think about the coefficient of friction that I would need in order to gain traction. I am very excited to study physics and can`t wait to see what I can do.

My physics teacher in high school did a very good job teaching the material in a hands-on way. I have always enjoyed the application of mathematics to real-world scenarios. In college, I have enjoyed (for the most part) the physics courses and found them to be challenging but rewarding.

What led me to be interested in physics was working in a physical oceanography modeling lab on campus. Initially I had thought I would do biological oceanography, but after working in the physical oceanography lab, I quickly realized that I was more interested in the physical aspects of the ocean.

I had a really good high school physics teacher, so I got a good background in basic physics. I loved seeing math in relation to the real world. It was so cool to be able to type some numbers into a calculator and figure out where a projectile was going to land! After my high school physics class, I knew I wanted to be a physics major. Taking physics classes in college led me to want to be a physicist.

In high school I took an intro to engineering/3D printing class as a freshman and really enjoyed that, and then when had the option to choose which science classes to take in junior and senior year, I chose to take the AP/IB HL physics class (no prior experience in an actual physics class) and had an exceptional teacher. I initially planned to pursue an engineering track in undergrad, but chose to go to Brandeis, which doesn`t have an engineering program, and switched to physics.

I first took a physics class in high school and it became my passion. I knew I wanted to study it in some capacity, and then I learned about the astrophysics program and I felt like I found what I wanted to study for college and the rest of my career.

Elementary school is when I started to take an interest in the sciences thanks to enthusiastic teachers. I developed an interest in astronomy on my own after watching space documentaries and science fiction shows. There is no astronomy major at my university, but I was told applied physics was a good foundation for it.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered

Response: Exposure to science magazines/documentaries/books growing up, and supportive, enthusiastic STEM teachers throughout my education.

Growing up with an immense interest in methods that govern our world not so surprisingly translated into a present passion for physics. I always have loved math, but as a student on the pre-medical track, I also wanted to see connections in science as well. This is what pulled me to physics initially. Once I declared the major, I absolutely loved the courses I took. This along with a friendly department is what kept me in the major.

I`ve always been in love for the quest of knowledge; curiosity is a powerful tool in any young mind.When I was a child, math and sciences were easy to learn and appreciate, --the love of learning I owe it to my mother--, and I grew it was a clear path of my future. Although my dreams were to become an astronaut, I wanted to see the world beyond Earth, and my high school research was indeed about astronomy. I oriented myself as to how could achieve this, later I found physics and physics captivated me. From there it was a bumpy road through my first college year, meeting people, changing ideals and desires. I started my undergraduate research in High Energy Physics, which led me where I`m standing here today, November 6th, at CERN, one of the most known physics research center in the world.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I was introduced to physics in high school through AP Physics I. The reason I picked physics as my major was because my physics teacher who was a man and had his PhD in physics was going to write my recommendation letter. He asked what I was thinking about majoring in and I said I didn`t know and he said "Well you`re good at physics, what do you think about majoring in it?" All it really took was one person who was important in my life and who I saw as someone important in the field to tell me I could do it, and then I did.

I was always vaguely interests in astronomy growing up, I think due to skimming Science News magazines, although didn`t have the opportunity to take any courses before college. When I got to UCSC, there were a few majors I was interested(astrophysics, math, archaeology, and creative writing), and I heard that the most course-intensive major and should be started right away, so I became a proposed physics major.

I became interested in physics after attending a science-based magnet high school. I knew that I wanted to do research and help increase the knowledge of the universe but I discovered that I love the way that math and physics work together and create a really cool description of the world through numerical analysis.

I got interested in light, which led me to find the Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation. That`s when I started to consider physics as a career. I got interested further from documentaries and decided to sign up for a physics class my senior year of high school, but my counselor made a mistake and placed me in the highest level physics class that I had zero qualifications for and the class I was supposed to take filled up resulting in me taking my first physics class freshmen year of college. I was lucky I didn`t suck at it and declared it as my major later that year. Through a research experience and classes, my interests narrowed to astroparticle physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Event Triggered

Response: My physics teacher in high school had a major influence on me. She was incredibly brilliant, and very encouraging. For a long time I was considering Architecture, but I go to a small college without an architecture program. I began double majoring in Physics and Studio Art with the intention of going to architecture grad school. However, after attenuating a CUWiP I decided to do summer research. I did an REU at Harvard this last summer, and that`s when I decided that I love research, and that I want to be a physicist.

My first exposure to physics was my freshman/sophomore year of college. I didnÕt think I was good at math or science until I took an algebra based physics course and precalculus. It was then that I realized where I wanted to take my education. Now IÕm working toward electrical and mechanical engineering.

In high school, I found physics to be enjoyable. I always loved math and I liked science, but the fact that physics can be seen in every day life just draws me to it. Also physics is challenging, and sometimes frustrating. Being able to work through that challenge and help others work through that challenge is really fun. My high school professor`s in physics sparked my interest, and now at Augustana through Augustana Physics and Engineering Society I`ve been able to be more hands on in physics and become more excited about the practicality of physics in life.

I signed up for AP Physics my junior year of high school because it seemed like a rigorous course that would be impressive to colleges. However, from the first unit on kinematics, I found the connections between physics and the calculus topics I was simultaneously learning - a connection across classes more apparent than I`d ever seen - and fell in love with the subject. My fascination hasn`t diminished since, and while I`m only a freshman taking my first university physics courses now, I plan to follow it to whichever (most likely physics-related) major it leads me.

I fell in love with physics during my senior year of high school, during which I took an electromagnetism course. I loved using my math and coding skills in physics, and I loved solving problems and learning the concepts. Working with my physics teacher definitely influenced me a lot as well. She always challenged me and encouraged me to think in a new way. I loved the mental task of trying to understand physics, and I still do! I feel that physics is somehow fundamentally aligned with who I am, which is not something easy to explain, but it is something that I can be sure that I feel.

I had started college as an engineer student with plans to pursuing chemical engineering.  During the first semester, I took a physics class and met a lot of the majors.  The physics department seemed a great community for more than just learning.  I switched to physics to join a very supportive community and genuinely enjoyed the classes more than the engineering.

I didn`t like science at all until I took physics in high school and really enjoyed it, especially after a circuits experiment. I chose physics as my major because I didn`t know what my major should be, and I ended up liking my classes in college. So far, I have enjoyed my courses, but I really like the faculty, peers, and community outreach in my physics department.

Ever since i was a child i always wanted to study physics and astronomy in order to become an astrophysicist, so starting in high school i began taking upper level math courses but it wasn`t until recently that i began taking classes towards my physics degree, and now i am on my way to graduating in the spring of 2012 as a physics major and immediately staring graduate school.

I first became seriously interested in physics during my introductory physics course in high school. I enjoyed the problem solving aspect of the course, and it was the first time that I felt intelligent. However, I decided to pursue physics further only because it was suggested of me. When I enrolled at my undergraduate institution I was an undecided major, and during my orientation the head of our physics department approached me and encouraged our program. For the first two years of my study, personal interest and determination had been the only factors influencing me to stay in the field. Going into my junior year of study I was very close to giving up as I felt like an inadequate student and an impostor in my community. Luckily, I gained further encouragement from faculty members in our department, and have since decided to continue my pursuit of a degree in physics.

I have always had a deep interest in both math and science. In my science classes, I was continually told that most of my questions were "beyond the scope of the class" or "too complicated for this grade level". Luckily, I also grew up with access to Google. By the time I reached my sophomore year of high school, I realized that the majority of my questions, regardless of the science from which they originated, led me to physics. Physics allows me to remain curious and to be perpetually fascinated by the world around me.

I first encountered physics as a high school senior. Over the course of the year, I fell in love with the challenging material. I tried other science fields like biology and chemistry, but didn`t feel the same way towards their curriculum. I was heavily influenced by reading books by well known physicists like Stephen Hawking and Carlo Rovelli. I see so much opportunity for discovery and critical thinking in many facets of physics. Overall, I think it is the challenge that keeps me attracted to physics.

I initially started college as a math major with a physics minor. After the completion of physics I and talking to my professor I decided that physics was something that I truly enjoyed learning about. Since then I could not be happier with my decision. I want to encourage young girls to explore science and not be intimidated by it.

My first physics class in high school as a senior really opened my eyes to the amount of impact that physics makes in the world.  Prior to that I had a very small understanding of this and I`m very glad I got to experience it with a great teacher who guided me through it.
I liked physics; physics liked me.

I had a really inspiring college physics professor that challenged me and believed in me. Since he always pushed me to be better, I found physics to be extremely rewarding since I wanted to study more and more to meet his expectations.

I always enjoyed math and science, and in high school I was first introduced to physics and it just made sense to me and I enjoyed it. I tried engineering for a bit in the beginning half of college, but came back to physics once I discovered Medical Physics from a guest Radiologist speaker discussing the use of physics in medicine. Becoming a medical physicist has been my goal and interest ever since.

I enjoyed many TV shows involving physics concepts as a child, such as Star Trek and Cosmos. In high school, taking AP Physics inspired me to pursue physics as a major in college. Specifically the teacher I had in that class was very enthusiastic and encouraged me to succeed in physics. In college I feel like physics is the topic I find most interesting, and the one I am most interested in pursuing.
Codes: Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: I returned to college 5 years after high school because I was bored with merely working for a living.  I wanted to explore my mind and what I was capable of so I began taking 2 classes at Cabrillo with my original interests centered around neuroscience.  I began by taking some pre-calculus math, and I realized that I wanted to explore its applications, so I went on to take Chemistry classes, and then Physics as I hadn`t even taken such courses in high school.  At first Physics made me angry; the challenges of the counter-intuitive nature of Physics was frustrating for me.  However, when I persevered and continued taking the calculus-based Physics series at Cabrillo, I realized I love the challenge.  During my course covering light from ray diagrams to the basics of the quantum properties of light, I changed my major from General Science to Physics. Physics has qualities of everything I am passionate about, and in my opinion is the closest thing to magic a human being can study. I have now tutored for 2 semesters in the Physics Learning Center, and love reviewing old course material with new students.  I feel like Physics is so vast that my lifetime will be well spent immersed in its depths.  I just have to figure out what to focus on first!

My fascination with problem solving and success with physics in high school encouraged me to become a physics major, as well as meeting another girl in the first few weeks of school who was also a physics major.

I am always interested in physics since I started learning it in middle school. My middle school and high school teachers were very encouraging, and they also had very high expectations for students. In addition, my physics classes were very challenging and every day, I spent at least 2 hours on physics study. As I spend more time on physics and delve more deeply in this area, I am more determined to be a physics major.

I took an algebra based physics course in high school, and it was cool but not very fulfilling. My first semester of college I took my first calculus-based physics course, and really enjoyed it. I spent a lot of time talking to faculty, and I decided to officially change my major after going to some Society of Physics Students meetings. I fell in love with physics very unexpectedly but I feel incredibly centered when I am studying and teaching it, and the tight-knit nature of my department makes it feel very easy to find guidance and resources. I always have upperclassmen willing to talk to me about classes, there is always a professor with an open door to give me further academic guidance.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social), Intrinsic Value

Response: I started physics in High school because it was a combination of math and science, and ended up loving it and continued for a second year in high school. I felt natural to continue with physics courses in college. I enjoyed these classes very much and the prospects for my future with this career path seemed very exciting and has pulled me further down this path. I am most excited to connect physics to the environment and do more applied physics.

My love for math is the reason I continued on to the second semester calculus as a Biology Major. My chemistry professor suggested that I take the calculus-based physics instead of algebra based. In my intro physics I met my mentor, who I went on to do research with and he helped rediscover my love for physics, and hence the major change.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: The first time when I seriously consider my career in the future, I chose physics.

I became a physics major mostly by chance, as physics was the most interesting high school course I had taken. But even then,I only took AP physics because it was one of the two science-related AP courses available at my high school at that time. In completing my major, I have realized that physics, or more specifically biophysics, is the most interestingfield and best fit for me. I have taken an assortment of biology, chemistry, mathematics, and some computer science courses as an undergraduate, and I can say without a doubt, my physics classes have always been the more interesting, challenging material. Comparing my statistical thermodynamiccourse with my physical chemistry course now, I find the physics material much more satisfying and fascinating to learn. I think I was lucky enough to take a chance with physics, which I believe many people do not or are not given the opportunity. I have found most people assume physics is`too hard` and do not give it a chance to find out how awesome it can be.I became interested in biophysics again by chance when researchingphysics major requirements. These interdisciplinaryalternatives were not advertised very well at my university, but are the next step up for physics-awesomeness. There is so much cool stuff you can do as a physicist that is not shown to high school students!
I liked it and I am good at it

I first discovered a live for Physics my junior year in school when I went to Africa. At first I was not very good at it but I later began to catch up with other students and I realized I loved to learn more and more about physics. Physics just seems to make more sense to me and can be used to explain a lot of things and answer a lot of questions of why things happen the way they do.

A friend introduced me to the book "The Black Hole War" by Leonard Susskind in my senior year of high school. I read it and although I didn`t fully understand everything, it made me realize how much I love to learn and want to understand how the universe works. After that I never doubted my decision and have loved Physics at every turn. I also credit my love of Star Trek with opening my mind to science and giving me the desire to contribute to the human race and the quality of life. Today I am inspired by my own professors and the physics majors around me.
Codes: Media Triggered, Utility Value, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: I am double majoring in Chemistry and Physics, and after taking Quantum Mechanics through our Chemistry department, I decided that I would like to learn more about Physics. Having many classes that overlapped between the two majors, I decided to declare my second major in Physics.

I was always interested in studying while in high school and I pursued Physics and Mathematics in order to continue a career becoming a research scientist. After joining University of Michigan-Flint, I joined many research projects on-campus and off-campus which also resulted in going to several conferences. All of these have also boosted my interest in Physics and plan to go to graduate school in Physics.

Taking up a physics course in high school really made me love science even more. I would always participate in class, and help tutor other student who were struggling in physics. When I got to college i decided to major in physics, so that i could go on to grad school and receive my PhD in Physics Education Research.
I really like math and science and physics pairs the two nicely.

When I was in high school, I had a fantastic female physics teacher. I would do better than all of the boys on my physics exams, even in the highest level of physics offered at my high school, which was IB physics. I sort of randomly decided my sophomore year of high school to therefore become a physicist and I`ve never looked back.

I was a music education major for 2 years when I started university. Through issues with myself and with my initial university I decided to leave the music major. I really like Star Trek and science and have always found it important and decided to try physics out, and if that didn`t work go into Cultural Anthropology. But physics worked out wonderfully. I became a member of the Learning Assistant (LA) program on campus and was able to cultivate my love of teaching and meet and build connections with other physics majors. It was also through the LA program that I met my research advisor/mentor Dr. Eleanor Close and began engaging in Physics Education Research. After getting through my intro classes and into the "heavy stuff" I finally found my love of pure physics content. Although it is immensely difficult it isn`t nearly as hard as being a music education major and I really love the content I`m learning, the friendships I`ve made, and the research I m doing.
Codes: Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (PER), Event Triggered

Response: I was always interested in science.  When I was 13/14 I read a book called Time Travel in Einstein`s Universe which got me interested in physics.  I was not able to take any physics classes or even calculus in high school because the school that I attended didn`t offer science or math classes.  I got to college and was amazed at how many different fields there were that I didn`t even know existed, and how much I could learn.  I spent my first year undeclared exploring different fields, and I wanted to learn as much as possible and gain broad and interdisciplinary knowledge and experience.  I ended up choosing Physics as a major because I thought it would help me build a good base of knowledge from which I could jump off to excel in anything else I wanted, and because I had always been interested in learning about how things work and the secrets and limits of the universe.  My very first physics course in my second year of college was tough.  I was dealing with a severe family issue at that time, had just left a three year romantic relationship, and was struggling with depression and anxiety (as I have been throughout college).  I nearly failed the course but managed to pass it with the help of an amazing TA, who ended up dropping out of graduate school to focus on his music but continued to encourage me to keep going in physics.  I didn`t really interact with any of my professors or other students at that time, so he was the first person in Physics I really talked to and he made me feel confident and capable, answering all my questions with enthusiasm and telling me I was smart and inquisitive and that he really hoped I decided to continue with physics.  When I joined SPS and started making friends in physics, I felt more like a part of the community and more excited about studying physics.  The previous CUWiP conferences I have been to have been invaluable in renewing both my passion for physics and my confidence that I can succeed in Physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Cost (Outside Effort), Social Persuasion, Event Triggered, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I heard about the discovery of Planet X (Now Eris) on NPR in elementary school and became fascinated with space. My family and friends were always supportive of my interests and I had easy access to documentaries and science magazines. In high school I took physics early to see if I liked it, and I did well and was supported by my teacher. As both the youngest in the class and one of only a few girls, I sometimes felt I had to be the best in the class in order to be taken seriously. In college I struggled through my introductory classes, but enjoyed the challenge enough to stay motivated.
Research experience and Physics club involvement
I enjoyed mathematics in high school and then I tried physics when in college. I enjoyed it extremely and considered to continue with it.
I did well in my college physics class and was intrigued by the concepts and the way of solving problems. My college physics teacher encouraged me. I liked the idea of engineering as well.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: In high school, I believed that my passion for math and science were indicators that I wanted to be an engineer. As I learned more about the profession, in particular its connection to math and science, I realized that most of the work done by engineers ignores the importance and implications of the theory that they put into practice. For the sake of my own education and in an effort to stay true to my passions, I wanted to study something that not only enabled me to put into practice these mathematical and scientific ideas, but also gave me the opportunity to appreciate the intuitive motivation, derivation, and robustness of these ideas. Physics and mathematics allow me to attain just that. Fortunately for me, it was not difficult for me to convince myself that physics was a viable path. My dad studied physics and eventually got a masters degree in the subject. In conjunction with my knowledge that undergraduate choices of study are not always binding to one`s future career, I was sure that, if anything, physics would provide me a base on which I could found skills relevant to any career path.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Utility Value

Response: In high school, I originally had no plan of following physics as a major, instead interested in the engineering route. However once in university, I learned I actually had no idea what I wanted to do. I switched majors a few times, however I still had no idea what I wanted to do, even as a junior in university. I ended up leaving UF with an associates degree, and took a year off so I could figure out what my goals were for education and possible professions.At some point, I became interested in maglev, projects such as hyperloop, the shinkansen, and the failed Florida high speed rail system.I didn`t know exactly what this field would be called, but I knew that a degree in math would at least set me up to work on a wild array of fields related to this topic. Eventually, through involvement with the Physics department at my current school, I learned that I`m interested in generally "electromagnetic propulsion." And then more specifically, advancements in ion propulsion for deep space travel. Around this time, I switched majors from mathematics to physics, as I knew that a degree in physics would foster the tools necessary to improve upon ideas in ion propulsion/related fields. At the same time, I began apprenticing at Florida Atlantic University`s observatory, where I`m being trained how to run the observatory. Because of this apprenticeship, I`m learning more than I ever thought I would, and at this moment I knew that I was in love with physics and astronomy.

I really enjoyed my introductory course in Mechanics because the questions were challenging but fun and doable. I`m also interested in engineering, so I started working in an experimental physics lab (there isn`t much engineering at my school), and I think my project is very interesting.

I had a very positive experience with a high school physics teacher I had for two full years and he changed my outlook on physics. I took all the courses he offered and I enjoyed everything we were doing. Once I realized how much I enjoyed physics, I looked into what I could do with physics and math and engineering was the way to go. My high school teacher originally went to school to be an engineer and the topics we talked about peaked my interest. Along the way, I just enjoyed physics courses and I hope I can use this one day to become an engineer.

I began to like Physics from the 8th grade. However, at that time it didn`t occur to me that women did not get enough recognition in many things including, Physics for the longest time. Even though my parents wanted me to study Medicine, I decided that I would major in Physics. In fact in would always make the most sense to me. I definitely people there should be more underrepresented people in the Physics field.
I took physics in high school, and had a very supportive physics teacher. It was the first class that really challenged me, and I really liked that. I never looked back after that moment.
I`ve always had an interest in physics related sciences. Because of this I felt that a bachelor`s of science in physics would be adequate for my interests.

I fell in love with physics in high school because I had avery enthusiastic teacher who made it enjoyable to work through difficult problems. Each challenge brought itsown sense of victory and I felt that it activated my criticalthinking beyond any other course I had taken. In college, however, I initially took on mechanical engineering as my major because I felt it would allow me to not only learn but applyall the concepts and theories I learn from class.After discovering that a professor of mine conducted particle physics research on campus, I asked to participate.I had exhausted all the physical science courses my high school had to offer (both AP and regular), and the physics I was takingduring my first year of college was review; I was excited because I knew that particle physics would give me room to expand my knowledge and experience instead of reteaching me what I already knew. Particle physics fascinates me because it rationalizes concepts and phenomenon that seem otherwiseinexplicable. I think of it as scientific madness, since manyseemingly outrageous theories (such as the Higgs Boson or darkmatter) have been proven through large-scale collaborative experiments, such as the ones at CERN! I would love to one day work atan institution for physics research because I know it is a job I would not grow bored of; it would immerse me in a dynamic and intellectually stimulating culture.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value (Particle), Utility Value

Response: I really loved science shows/magazines, and I wanted to do somethingthat would take advantage of the proclivity I had for math and science. I basically chose what I thought was the hardest science major because I thought I was smart enough to handle it. After I got into it, I fell in love with it. Not just the science of it, but the culture of it. And I also love howit affects other peoples` perceptions of me so positively. They are alwaysso impressed. However, I started realizing that the academic route was not what I wanted to take. The culture in acadamia seems very different than the undergraduate physics culture. I`ve heard stories and seen the difference in attitude.

The combination of Cosmos and Star Wars got me interested in space when I was younger, but I never really considered a career in physics until last year. For a very long time, I wanted to go to medical school to become a doctor, but I decided I was more interested in researching molecular biology. After attending a conference for women in science at Argonne Nation Lab and speaking with a woman about her career in astrophysics, my interest in space rekindled. As of right now I am a biology major, but I hope to double major in physics in preparation to research astrobiology.
Codes: Media Triggered, Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience, Utility Value

Response: I was originally a biology major, but I took an astronomy course as an elective. I decided then I wanted to go into astronomy/astrophysics. After that, I was selected for a pulsar research fellowship and sent to Puerto Rico for a conference. I have attended several conferences since, as well as completing a research experience abroad in Sardinia. The traveling and community-like aspects to physics have been important.
I really enjoyed taking physics and calculus in high school. I have also interned at a planetarium, which got me interested in astrophysics.

I was learning about nuclear chemistry and I kept thinking to myself that wish I could know more physics so that I could further explore the topic. Then I started to think back and I realized that I had always found my physics classes interesting and fun.
Found my love for physics in a physics course about renewable energy

I have always liked science and math but I originally considering studying chemistry because I wanted to understand the structure and workings of the universe. As I looked more into chemistry I realized that I would need to study physics for a more fundamental understanding so I decided to apply to college as a physics major after having considered chemistry. After entering college, I was sure I had picked the right major. After my first semester I decided to added math as a second major. I got into research early. In the spring of my freshman year, and a group of my peers and I went with our mentor to CERN in the early summer to work on test beam. Although it was a great experience doing experimental physics at CERN, it solidified my want to do theory. In the summer after my first year of college, I also did an internship at NIST as a science writer. In the summer after my second year of college, I started doing theoretical physics research in supersymmetry. The work led to me co-authoring a paper. The first half of last summer, I studied cosmology at the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics. In the latter part of the summer I continued my supersymmetry research. Although I have challenged myself in my undergraduate career I have not always felt like I belong hear or am capable of succeeding in the field. But my mentors and my parents (especially my father who is a physicist) have all been very supportive. I am also very involved in my physics community. I really love physics and think it is amazing to use math to understand the world in a way we cannot by just looking at it with our eyes. And I love sharing this love with others and helping people who love exploring the world through physics as well. I am very involved in my physics community. I have been the president of my SPS chapter since I was a sophomore and am founding member of my undergraduate WiP club. After attending my first CUWiP in my sophomore year, a peer and I convinced our department to apply to host a CUWiP. I also tutor. Interacting and helping people in my physics community also helps me feel more confidant about my place in the physics community.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: My high school physics classes were enjoyable, I liked math and was good at it so physics seemed viable. In college I got in with a great group of undergraduates in the physics department so i am sticking with this and still enjoying classes.

I had trouble with math in high school but I excelled in physics. I then went to college for digital media production and excelled at 3D modeling and visual effects. I enjoyed the `mimicking` physics aspect of my job as an animator/compositor. I did not like the sedentary aspect of the job though and switched careers to being a distiller since I had enjoyed that as a hobby. I was a spirits and essential oil distiller for 5 years and just wanted to understand more about the chemistry and physics behind the process while at the same time contribute to society in a meaningful way. My work as an animator and then spirits distiller did not satisfy those desires. I was also told many times that I wasn`t good enough at math to ever excel. I just didn`t want to believe that I couldn`t do it. So, I decided to go back to school to study biomedical physics, remembering that I enjoyed physics as a teenager. I enjoy visual/spatial problems since I find it easy to visualize 3D spaces and shapes. I`m finding that this talent is very useful for multivariable calculus and linear algebra (both of which I love so much). This gives me some confidence that I will be ok in physics. I enjoy the "troubleshooting" aspect of physics problems too.

I went to an all girls high school, and I was very involved in our science department. My senior year I was incredibly discouraged and didn`t know what I was going to do after school, but then I took physics. My high school physics teacher is really why I decided to go into physics. When I got to Wittenberg University, I wasn`t sure if I made the right choice. I felt inadequate compared to my peers and constantly felt like I wasn`t doing enough, then I started my plasma research. I currently work under Dr. Williams in the plasma physics lab, and he has been an amazing influence in my life. He has encouraged me to get involved in the physics community and continues to introduce me to others in the field that will help me improve. That`s really why I am interested in continuing on in physics, my professors at Wittenberg have helped me grow and learn more about myself, and have helped me set my sights on who I want to be in the future.

I was first introduced to physics in high school. I took AP Physics my senior year. I was actually not that interested when I was taking the course the first time. After high school in my first year of college I would watch videos and do my own research in astrophysics and engineering since both interest me. I still don`t know what career path I want to take. I definitely want to continue to learn about physics and get my PhD some day in the near future.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Utility Value

Response: I loved physics in high school and find myself always trying to figure out the concepts I see in the world. I also am interested in education and find physics an extremely important subject to get kids more interested in.

I think I was always a curios girl full of questions about the world and when I first came into a physics class everything started to make sense. It was like an explanation of things around me, and answer to questions I had always had and my high school teacher definitely saw my potential in that class. He started to push me to learn and question more and that lead to me having a passion for the subject and deciding to major in it. It also gave me the opportunity to switch easier to engineering if I ever felt like I needed it.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Attainment Value

Response: When I was in sixth grade, my father encouraged me to try reading a book titled Dance of the Photons, relating to quantum entanglement. This sincerely interested me, and I began to grow interested in physics as a field. However, it was not until I took AP Physics 1 in high school that I realized I truly enjoyed the subject. I loved the combination of math and science into a field, as well as the challenge this subject gave me. For much of my education, classes came easily and I did not have to work to understand things. However, with physics I was challenged to go further and not just plug numbers into equations, but to understand why I was using equations and how they related to specific concepts. My high school physics teacher had great faith in me and my abilities, and I was very pleased to have the opportunity to participate in class. I found my voice was heard and respected quite often. This encouraged me to become a physics major, as I believed it would give me a positive challenge and a great outlet for trying to challenge myself and expand my horizons.

MY whole life I`ve always been interested in space and stars, so astronomy or astrophysics was the career path in late high school. My university doesn`t have an astronomy program, so physics is the next best thing.As I became a physics tutor for my campus job, I realized how much I love tutoring and teaching, so now physics education research is a field I`m looking into.I`ve had a growing interest in social justice, so a science research field in physics isn`t something that appeals to me for its lack of immediate social aid - education is something more relevant.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Utility Value, Intrinsic Value (PER)

Response: I first found physics by looking at articles online about the newfound gravitational waves at LIGO and new binary star formations. I was almost done with a separate degree until I started doing this type of research on my own. I then changed my major. Honestly, this choice was completely self-driven and I didn`t even think about how difficult it would be in the beginning, but it has been completely worth it.

In high school I hated physics. Honors physics was the hardest class I had ever taken. I was accustomed to doing well in my courses with little to no effort. I initially went to community college to become a psychologist. When I found out I was about to have a child, I dropped out of school. I only realized I could be a scientist myself when I was explaining to my daughter that she could do so. So I went back to school in the College of Natural Sciences for chemical physics. It was the hardest thing I could think of and I wasn`t afraid to fail something impossible. The adviser for chemistry suggested I choose between physics and chemistry before graduation for a more marketable degree. So I looked at both programs, and then spoke with the physics adviser as well. The people I had met in the physics department were generally more dynamic, the jokes were funnier, and there were more fun things to play with. When I decided on physics, my adviser explained that I would get paid to attend graduate school instead of the other way around and said I should get connected to a research project. I landed in the Physics Education Research Lab at MSU working under Dr. Vashti Sawtelle and found that not only was my work incredibly rewarding, but I also developed an incredible support network in the process.
Codes: Cost (Task Effort), Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social), Event Triggered

Response: I was good at math and was from a poor home. I wanted money and I didn`t want a math degree and physics has to do with math so, I learned about physics and it has stuck.
I went for a space olympiad.

I`ve always had an avid interest in science, but I didn`t always consider it as a life path. I think the first time I seriously considered physics as a major came when I was taking chemistry in high school. I knew there was a lot of intertwining of the disciplines, and I wanted to know more about how the physics was brought into things. When I took my first physics course in high school a year later, I was disappointed in the way were taught. I felt that I didn`t learn what I needed to learn, and since I was a junior in a senior class, I also felt pushed to the side in my interests. I wanted to learn more about what I missed out on in high school, and I also wanted to focus more on the astronomical facet of the discipline since I have a deep interest in the cosmos. The solidification of physics as my major came the summer before I first attended college. One of the faculty members here at Wittenberg utterly changed that way I viewed the world and this discipline not only with his sheer enthusiasm, but also in that he made me believe in myself. He is no stranger to hardships himself, and since I am a perfectionist in my work, that showed me that not everyone needs to be a super genius to succeed in this field of science. They simply need to have a passion for physics and an ability to persevere through their hardships in their journey to understand the world. Even now, it is still difficult for me at times to grasp what I am trying to learn, but that doesn`t mean I won`t stop in my attempts to understand.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience

Response: My favorite TV show as a kid was called "Mr. Wizard`s World." It had been about an old man who let kids come to his house and he`d teach them science experiments. This was the beginning of everything for me. I often got into trouble at school for going `above and beyond` science experiments in labs-- and for asking my science teachers too many questions.I considered physics as a major back in the 1990s, when I was in high school, but I came from an abusive home and was kicked out of the house, barely able to graduate high school. I then put myself through community college and university, beginning as a science major (interest in the cross between biology and physics but the term `biophysics` hadn`t been born yet). I switched to social science when I learned my junior year that you could get paid to do genealogical research, a passion of mine. These last twenty years I worked as a professional genealogist but realized a couple of years ago I spent my time reading about mathematics and quantum biology, not history or genealogical research methodology. I called various graduate admissions advisers throughout the country. We lived in Maine at the time; my husband put in for transfers to three different cities that had good physics graduate programs at the universities. He was transferred to Tucson and now I am back in school, clearing up some math and science requirements so that I can attend the University of Arizona to obtain my PhD in physics. I have two teenagers who will thankfully be out of the house by the time I enter graduate school. In my current classes, I still tend to ask too many questions but the professors are delighted to answer some of them. Of the ones they don`t answer, it usually comes in the answer of, "Salena, this is a physics undergrad course. Why are you even asking about this?" They answer me after class, and these responses reaffirm to me that physics was my calling all along.
Codes: Media Triggered, Cost (Outside Effort), Intrinsic Value

Response: Astrophysics is something I have been deeply interested in since my time in high school. However, there were a number of academic fields I wanted to pursue in college and due to scheduling, I ended up double majoring in mathematics and economics.  It was only after I applied to graduate school in economics during my fourth year that I realized that not pursuing astrophysics meant sacrificing something that sparked my curiosity more than any research I had ever done. From the moment of that realization, graduate school in economics felt like a trap and something that I knew I did not want to waste 5 years doing. I chose to extend my undergraduate education by two years, of which I am now in the second, in order to pursue the one topic I know will keep me engaged and curious for the rest of my life.

I attended a Higgs boson particle lecture given by Dr. Neeti Parashar of FermiLab, during my junior year of high school (spring of 2014), and after discussions at length with my AP teachers, I decided to major in physics at Valpo. Attending previous CUWiPs and talking to colleagues over the years has solidified my love of the subject itself.

In my junior year of high school, I was enrolled in my firstphysics course. I did not have much experience and honestly expected that I was not going to like it. Turns out, I enjoyed the class very much. Physics was the first class in high school that challenged me, and I enjoyed the challenge.After getting an A in the class and the final, I decided that Physics was something that I could study in college. I took AP Physics my senior year and decided to go to South Dakota School of Mines and Technology to continue my studies. After taking different Physics courses, I decided that the main reason I enjoyed it was because of math. Math is a class that has always come easily to me, but I had never considered math as a career. Physics is the perfect choice for me, because it is truly applied math. With Physics, I am able to take something I love and make a career out of it. As our department head says, ???Physics is math with a soul.???

I originally started college as an anthropology major, because I find the subject fascinating. However, in my second semester I realized that it was too easy and I wasn`t being challenged. I thought of the hardest subject I could think of that I would still enjoy, which left me with physics. I love figuring out how the world works and I like to be challenged. The event that lead to this realization was my anthropology professor telling me that I didn`t have to show up to class anymore because I already earned my A. After I switched into physics I had a hell of a time adjusting to the rigorous courses and material, and even contemplated leaving the major to go back to anthropology. If it wasn`t for a very nice and incredibly thoughtful postdoc that was subbing in my astronomy course that I decided to talk to that day I would have.She told me that physics isn`t easy and that is incredibly competitive but if I enjoy learning about why things do what they do and being around smart people who share the same curiosity then I should stick it out and make up for my subpar grades by doing research, a lot of research.Sadly I didn`t know until very recently which branch of physics I wanted to do research in, so I have very little of that. But I will not let that stop me, because that postdoc really inspired me to strive for what I want.

I started to really consider physics in high school after taking an astronomy class. I was very interested in space and all the strange things that were out there as well as out place in the universe. I took an honors physics class my senior year and learned about more interesting things in quantum mechanics, and nuclear physics, energy, and generally how things worked and the technology that came from them. When I got to college, and the classes went more in depth, I started to follow my own curiosity to think about what kind of problems/fields I wanted to learn about. Right now my interests are cosmology and quantum physics and I hope to one day to research in these fields and perhaps develop useful technology to ease the world`s needs for energy, resources, and discovery.

The main influence as to why I am a physics major is the physics community at my school. I randomly took the introductory physics course freshman year, and was not sure if I wanted to continue until I met the other majors my sophomore year. I am mainly motivated by my peers and the professors in the department, and enjoy working together on quantitative, difficult problems. I am less motivated by the physics itself, and do not want to go go graduate school for physics, but I have found a home in the physics community at my school.

As a high school student, I always enjoyed math and science and could see myself doing well in a major that used both of these subjects. By my senior year, I knew was interested in engineering and physics, yet had not decided exactly what I wanted to study in college. I applied to many different colleges that fall, yet was still unsure of where I wanted to attend. I applied to Wheaton college with an intended major in engineering, however, as I researched scholarships, came upon one offered for physics students. I sent in an essay submission to the scholarship application and waited to see what would happen. Several months past, and I eventually heard back from the scholarship application reviewer, who notified me that I had won the scholarship. I am a Christian, and I believe that this occurrence was God`s hand directing me toward a physics major. As I have begun my undergraduate study this year, it has been difficult, but rewarding and exciting. It is clear that God has brought me to Wheaton and provided me with the opportunity to study physics; I am grateful for this gift and excited to see where He will lead me.

Being the first person in my family to graduate high school has always put a large amount of pressure on me. So when my mom wanted me to become a doctor. I felt an obligation to her and my family to be successful. However, I fell in love with physics my senior year of high school. My teacher was brilliant and really knew how to "wow" the class. I was always good at math as well but again felt like I had to please my family. I graduated high school and pursued biology/pre-med. After a year I knew it wasn`t for me. I had to take a year off to help my family with finances. Which was probably the best thing for me. In that time off I grew and learn so much about myself and what I truly wanted to do. I switched my major to physics and couldn`t wait to see where it led me. Physics is what makes me wake up excited to learn everyday. I couldn`t be happier with my decision.
Codes: Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience

Response: I`ve always loved math and science. The occupation that I`m most looking into is chemical engineering. I have always had an interest in the sciences and I have been good at math and that made me looking to the chemical engineering field.

A few weeks into my first physics course my junior year of high school, I knew I wanted to consider physics as a potential undergrad major because I really loved how physics modeled the world. However, I was not solidly decided on physics (vs biology) until I took my first college course, where I realized how much I appreciated the creativity required to do physics effectively, something that I did not see in biology. I loved the challenge of college level physics and how it made more complex mathematics tangible in the real world in a way that a mathematics course did not. The last factor that led me to physics has been the faculty and classmates, who are caring and funky folks that I identify with more on a personal level than in any other area of study.

I didn`t really know what physics was until I took a class my junior year of high school. My teacher was crazy and fun and tried to make physics something interesting that people should care about. I took a second physics class with him my senior year and decided that physics was what I wanted to major in. However, once I got to high schoolI knew I at least wanted to take a physics class. Growingup I knew that I wanted to smart, and Einstein is any8-year-old`s idea of Someone Smart. I didn`t know whatphysics was, but I knew that Einstein had done it and Iat least wanted to know if I could do it too.

I became interested in physics in highschool because I initially wanted to pursue astronomy and astrophysics. I had my first physics class my junior year, and I really enjoyed all of the content and labs of that class. My teacher was always very sure to emphasize the difficulty of physics, and that even though it might not come easily at first, that does not mean one can`t be good at it. This lead me to be more confident in the subject as a whole and to put in the work to understand the material. As a result, I really enjoyed the class, and took AP Physics (C) (Both Mechanics and E&M) the next year. I decided to become a physics major because I enjoy the content, prefer the application side of mathematics, and wanted a degree that could both be applied to many different fields and that also has many different concentrations within it.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Utility Value

Response: I attended a lecture on stellar evolution at Bryce Canyon National Park when I was in middle school.When I applied to UCSC, I applied as a theater major with a minor in astro--but once I started taking classes, I decided to stick with physics.

I`ve always been interested in physics and astronomy related subjects, so my grandfather (a retired astronomy professor and high school physics teacher) told me I should major in physics as a way to become an astronomer.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion

Response: The experiences that led me to becoming a physics-related major are the ones that piqued my curiosity for physics. I first considered studying physics after reading the book Hyperspace, by Michio Kaku, when I was in High School. As an undegraduate student, I got involved with research that heavily relied on physics, so I began to take upper-level coursework in physics.

I consider living a life without trying to have some profound impact on the world uneventful. I therefore aspire to be the first. The first in my family to pursue a college education overseas, the first to get a PHD, and to be the first female member of my family to pursue a career in the sciences; eventually earning this PHD in engineering . To achieve these goals I am currently a Jamaican international student, majoring in Physics with a minor in Anthropology at Mount Holyoke College.The first time I considered Physics as a major was when I took an A-level Physics course and was facinated by the way physics taught me to approach problems.

When I compared physics to the other science courses that I was taking in high school, none of them seemed as interesting and I wasn`t as good at any as in physics. My high school physics teacher always made it fun, and I had always had an interest in space and astronomy. I knew that the only way I would be able to study those things was with a background in physics.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: Honestly, I didn`t really know that physics could be a field I could go into until my senior year of high school, when my AP Physics 1 class went to a talk by a woman who did work with the Curiosity rover, that was the moment when I realized that I could be involved in physics. Before then, I knew I wanted to be in a science field but none of them really seemed to fit? But after that field trip I realized that this was something that was actually really cool, and I wanted to pursue it farther. Since then I managed to get into a good college, and have been studying physics since then (with no regrets).
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value

Response: I took a general physics course my junior year of high school. I realized that the math for physics was mostly easier for me to grasp and more interesting overall than any other math I had taken so far. At the time I was unsure of what major to pursue but after taking the physics class I came to the conclusion that physics was the best option for me since I had gained a deep interest for it and it is a general enough field that has many different areas of research, so I would have many different options to choose from.

I really enjoyed physics in high school, and I especially liked that I could apply math to scientific problems. I also liked that everything had rules it needed to follow. I picked physics because I knew it would be a good challenge for me and because I really enjoyed the classes I took in high school.

I was interested in astronomy and physics conceptually in high school, but struggled in math because of issues with depression in my teenage years. When I got to community college, my math abilities improved completely and it gave me confidence in actually pursuing physics academically.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Cost (Outside Effort), Mastery Experience

Response: I decided to take IB physics in highschool to avoid taking biology so I lept into it for two years. I struggled initially, but I enjoyed the type of thinking it required and I began to see how the world worked in simple ways around me. Really it is just incredibly cool, and has only gotten cooler. I struggled throughout university physics, but every time I leave office hours I am reaffirmed in my choice because of how fulfilling it is and the importance I think it can hold in the world.
I had a fantastic physics teacher in high school, and I enjoyed reading about physics in books and on Wikipedia for fun since 7th grade.
I am a chemistry major, but my General Physics professor was so inspirational that I thought physics was so interesting.

I took an honors physics class my junior year of high school and loved everything about it. Senior year I took the AP physics course with no intention of ever using physics after high school. My class went on a field trip to Fermie Lab and I fell even more in love with physics and knew that I needed to somehow incorporate it into what I wanted to do with my life after college. I changed my major that day from pre-med to physics and all of my experiences with the physics department in college so far have only increase my desire to be a part of this community.

When I was in third grade part of my science class was about Astronomy and I loved it. Any time after that I always loved it when we would cover anything related to space. Then I took a physics class in high school and I just knew that is what I wanted to go to school for. My current plan is to go into astrophysics.

I decided to study physics right before my first year of college because I knew I was I liked math and space, and the way to combine those was to do astrophysics. Since then, my perceptions of physics have certainly changed, as I`ve taken more classes and actually done astrophysics research, but my love for it has done nothing but grow. I`m happy to stay up literally all night in order to use the telescope, and can`t imagine doing something else.

IÕve always enjoyed math and the application of math to the real world, so it was just a matter of taking a physics class in college. Once I experienced the material, I realized it just clicked with me and I didnÕt want to stop learning physics.

I was in my junior year physics class when I first considered becoming a physics major. I over heard some other students talking about an advances physics topic that I was not familiar with and I realized that I really wanted to understand it. I then took physics again as a senior and was the only girl in my class aside from my teacher. She encouraged me to pursue physics further. I then went on to college as a physics major, and within the half year preceding my college entrance I began to realize I wanted to pursue a medical career in Ophthamology. I was able to reconcile this with my interest in physics through the shared topic of optics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Optics)

Response: I was initially an engineering major, but found physics concepts more exciting and the physics community more accepting. I have been offered more opportunities as a physics major, although the mathematics courses I`ve taken have been less fruitful in terms of advancement opportunities. Despite that, I am currently a general mathematics and physics double major.

In high school I excelled in my first physics class, but also for the first time met challenges that I had not yet faced.I found the subject exciting, and my high school physics teacher and some friends encouraged me to take AP Physics.When I entered college, I had not yet decided on what major I wanted to pursue. A friend had brought up physics, and I decided to try it.My intro physics professor was lively, impassioned, and made the subject very exciting. I found out more about the physics program and felt at home with the other physics students, so I decided to pursue the major.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I have always held interest in space, NASA, ect, but never saw myself as someone that could do science for a living. In high school, I was always encouraged to pursue arts or english a career choice, since I never excelled in mathematics. But after spending a year in college as an English major, I became aware that it was not the path for me. I decided to pursue my childhood dream of veterinary sciences and soon became involved in the research of a physics professor on campus. It only took three months of working with him for me to discover that my real passion laid in mathematics and physics. I recently was involved with a public outreach program that taught daily STEM classes for underrepresented youth in our area. It was an incredibly fulfilling experience and I now know that this is the kind of thing I would like to do as a career.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Cost (Emotional), Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: General interest in the aerodynamics of the cars in the childhood and experiments

My first exposure to physics was when I was about 10 years old and I saw the TV series Stargate SG1. One of the characters is a female physicist, Dr. Samantha Carter, who became my role model. I did not truly understand physics until I reached the course in high school. Physics did not come easy but I knew it was worth working for and pursuing for my undergraduate degree. Even without all the special effects and excitement of a science fiction show I found physics exhilarating. As I pursued my undergraduate degree, I had multiple research opportunities in which I was able to experience numerous different areas of physics. Of these different topics, I was most interested in statistical mechanics and applying it to modeling biological systems which gave it the most purpose for me.

After progressing from wanting to be an architect to a civil engineer, I discovered physics in my junior year of high school and finally felt like I had found what I loved.  I found that it was always the physics behind the engineering that interested me.  This led me to pursue a B.S. in physics in college.  I still wanted to target the applied side of physics however, so I have an Environmental Engineering minor.  I am interested in renewable energy and am interested in pursuing this either through physics research or in industry.

I was a stay at home mom for a few years.  I knew I needed to get back in the work place and decided that going to school was the best decision.  I started at Spokane Community College.  I have several supportive teachers there who encouraged me to use my logical thinking and critical analysis and pursue a STEM based degree.  This led me to Spokane Falls Community College.  I am very close to finishing a transfer degree in engineering.  This is because it was the closest physics related degree I could find.  A professor at SFCC, Asa Bradley, has motivated me to follow the degree and field that I truly enjoy.

In high school I was interested in physics but did not excel in my physics course. I think my B+ grade performance (not bad but not my best) in high school physics was attributable to two factors: one, I was deeply afraid of asking questions for fear of sounding dumb, and two, the course was algebra-based and glossed over proper derivation (derivation of key equations helps me to understand and accept equations).In college I didn`t consider physics until I became good friends with a physics major. They talked about physics in a way that completely changed my perception of the subject. This change in perception, along with newfound math skills, led me to realize that I deeply missed physics. But I didn`t switch my major to physics right away. Initially I changed my major from environmental science to geology, mostly because the geology major allowed me to take more math and physics courses. I was beginning to realize that physics was my true interest, but when I expressed my interests to family and friends, there was pushback. First of all, my friends couldn`t believe that I was suddenly so interested in physics, considering that I didn`t take to it so much in high school. I was warned against switching to physics. People said it would be too hard, or that I wouldn`t get a job. When I met with the undergraduate physics advisor, she warned me that sometimes students would come to her in tears. They were failing the courses they loved so much. But I knew already that I would not be fulfilled if I did not quickly and completely explore this strong pull towards physics.  There were some bumpy points in coursework in the beginning of my switch, but ultimately I learned how to change my study habits to study physics successfully. A few great teachers influenced me along the way. The same undergraduate advisor who warned me about the major also encouraged me once I made the switch.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: Every since I took my first science course (biology) in high school, I knew I loved science. I originally planned to major in biology, however I enjoy the math aspect of science and found my passion for physics.

I became interested in physics since senior year of high school when I took my first mechanics course. I went into college thinking about majoring in engineering, but I realized soon that my passion was in physics and I have stayed passionate ever since I made this realization.

As an undergraduate majoring in biology, I was discouraged from doing a double major in physics/biology because of the difficult course load. Unfortunately, I took this as fact and have decided to persue a minor in physics instead, but that minor is fueled by passion and commitment that I love. I found that my minor was not supplementary to my major, my desired career choice or really anything I wanted to do, but it was purely because I loved physics and gaining the expanse of knowledge. Slowly I learned the applicability of physics to biological systems and medicine, my desired field of study, and have fallen in love with it even more.
Codes: Cost (Task Effort), Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Biophysics)

Response: I took physics classes in high school and really enjoyed the experience. My teacher encouraged me to look into physics classes at Hamilton, and after my first semester, I continued on the major track and am now looking at a math and physics double major. The teachers and professors I have had definitely helped me find this path and encouraged me to continue since I had a strong interest and ability with the material.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience

Response: I initially didn`t consider physics as an option because I was behind in math in high school, but always found it interesting. I was encouraged and then decided to go into physics in college, got discouraged by the people I was surrounded by, and switched majors. I missed physics and decided to go back into it with different people and made myself at home and am happy with that decision.

I decided to major in physics my junior year in high school while taking my first physics course. I enjoyed working out the problems and explaining natural phenomena. Throughout my undergrad, I noticed there was not much of a physics community at my university. After attending CUWiP 2018, a fellow student and I decided to start Society of Physics Students as an offical organization at our university. Since, we have seen a community form with different people from all different backgrounds- mostly physics majors. We do feel that our physics community is small- 50 undergrads total- so we chose to start a club that included all genders. We are excited to see where the organization goes and I, personally, am excited to continue my studies and start applying for graduate schools.
I was always good at science, then I took physics and AP physics in high school. I attended an information session on the physics major for my college, and I was hooked.

I have always had an interest in the physics/astronomy field. This was cultivated by shared interest and support from my parents. The first time I really considered physics an option to study was during my first high school physics class. The class was very interesting and my teacher was supportive and encouraged me to learn as much as I could about physics.
I took physics in high school starting my junior year, and as soon as we started covering intro to modern physics I knew it was what I wanted to do.
reading philosophy books and realizing how physics can be related to fundamental questions about the origin of universe
I wanted to be challenged to the greatest extent and become a great physicist because a lot of people back home have doubted my ability to succeed in the physics major for years.

My chemistry teacher in high school had a degree in physics, and so he introduced me to many of the topics I am interested in now within physics. From there I took physics and AP physics and enjoyed both classes, which validated my choice in majoring in physics in college when the time came.
I liked and enjoyed physics. Don`t know what`s going on with me right now.

When I was 14, I was on a road trip in Southern California with my grandparents. I`d downloaded a bunch of podcasts to entertain myself on the trip, without paying much attention to what they were. One came on about Schrodinger`s cat, string theory, and the Copenhagan interpretation. I was fascinated, and throughout the rest of high school I checked out and read as many books as I could about modern physics at the non-expert level. I took AP Physics in high school, expecting to be able to finally learn about these topics in a classroom setting. Our teacher gave us a little bit of modern physics, but when it came to the curriculum we needed to know for the AP exam, she was essentially non-existent. She never lectured, and when she gave us quizzes, she would literally pick the questions on the spot, usually without having a clue how to do them herself.Most of the class failed the test, and the rest of us barely skated by.By the time I had taken the exam, I had attended PhysFest at Seattle University. Through the program, I had decided on the school, but due to my experience in my high school physics class, I was very skeptical about the major.
