My acceptance letter from Seattle University said that I was a declared physics major. I decided to go with it and at least try out the intro course. This quarter, the intro course reminded me of how passionate I am about the subject, and I`m very much looking forward to pursuing a career in physics.

I realized I liked physics in high school. In college freshman year, physics seemed so difficult and everyone seemed so much smarter than me, but as I made female friends in the department I became  a lot more confident.

My older brother was interested in engineering and went to school for civil engineering. This caused me to consider the STEM fields seriously when choosing a college major. I found physics to be the most interesting and chose it as my major; my passion and interst in physics has been growing exponentially ever since.

I always had an interest in studying nature: energy and matter, but my parents thought I had an interest in animals. Throughout high school and commencement of college, my advisors would suggest I avoid physics courses. My family has an obtusity for science, so they didn`t know how to encourage me to follow my desire in physics. Eventually, I stopped listening and took action by taking physics courses which I wasn`t properly prepared. I struggled to meet at the same level as my colleagues, but I enjoyed learning physics and eventually flourished. I am now deeply involved in the physics community. I`ve been conducting research for ~2years attended/presented at several conferences, and conducted an REU at a national Laboratory. I am thankful to have a mentor who has given me these opportunities and exceed my capabilities.
Codes: Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I began college pursuing an associates degree and took Intro to Astronomy. I did not think of myself as good at physics and I did not think I enjoyed math at all. I did well in the class and my teacher kept asking me if I was going to take physics the next semester. I said no at first, but decided I would take it as an elective just to see if I could do well and to see what the class was like. Much to my surprise, I did very well! I continued on to take the second general physics class at my college and once I finished that I got a job as a tutor for that class at my college. These first two physics classes I took were algebra based and not the calculus based engineering classes that physics majors need. Even so, after tutoring the class for about a year I realized that I really enjoyed what I was doing and I decided to take calculus to see if I did in fact like math as much as I had found I like physics. I did very well in calculus and continued on to take the engineering physics courses and change my major to Engineering.
Codes: Cost (Emotional), Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional

Response: I contribute my love of physics to watching Bill Nye, the Science Guy, as a child. I took every opportunity to learn mathematics and science before college and I think that helped me develop my understanding and appreciation for physics.

My love to Astronomy has pushed me towards loving physics. After I used to dislike physics in high school, my college experience with astronomy and physics classes in college have changed my thoughts. I now love physics just as I love Astronomy.
ive wanted to work with outer space ever since i was 5 year old

In fourth grade I did a science fair project and I`ve beenhooked on physics ever since. I did another experiment withsubmarines in 5th grade and air buoyancy in 6th grade. In 7thgrade I (with the help of my father) made a mini wind tunnelto measure lift. I`ve loved physics forever and my desire toperuse it has never faded.

It started with my high school physics teacher noting my ability to succeed in the class and suggesting I try it in college and consider persuing it further if I enjoyed it. My father has a Ph. D. in Geophysics, so it is not surprising I did enjoy it and plan on possibly going on to get a Master`s Degree in Geophysics.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Geophysics)

Response: I loved my high school AP physics class, which is what inspired me to study physics in college. All of the information sort of clicked for me, and I knew that I wanted to keep learning physics.

I think I started becoming partial to STEM in early high school. (Before that, I wanted to be a history teacher.) In general, I tend to be a practical thinker. I appreciate the complexities presented by literature and other humanities, but on the whole, they are ideas which I already possess to an extent. I am more interested in systems and how things work -- things like machinery and energy -- things that I have only barely scratched the surface of understanding. Anyone can read a book and give their opinion, but a much smaller amount of the population is proficient in higher math, physics, etc.
I began liking astrophysics in middle school when I watched shows about it and then started reading books on the topic. Because astrophysics is part of physics, I`m studying physics.

In high school I participated in debate and designed my plan around antimatter. From researching (the reading online articles type of researching not the scientific kind) the topic I developed a passion for both physics and alternative energy. I initially entered college as a mechanic engineering major, but hoped to change to a double major in physics as well. I talked with my general chemistry professor since he mentioned doing research in using hydrogen for energy. After hearing of my interest, he offered me a position in his lab working towards more efficient photovoltaics, if I became a chemistry major. At this opportunity, I dropped mechanical engineering altogether and went for a double major in physics and chemistry. After living this double life for a time, I found myself associating more and more with the physics side, eventually dropping the chemistry major. Quite luckily I was able to switch over to computational physics research of photovoltaics. Much to my surprise, I found I quite enjoyed theory over experiment. I plan to continue doing research and work towards a PhD.
Codes: Media Triggered, Event Triggered, Physiological/Emotional, Utility Value

Response: I first became interested in physics my junior year of high school when Itook Honors Physics at my high school. My teacher had a PhD in NuclearPhysics and worked in Russia disabling nuclear bombs for several years.He made the class extremely interesting, and I did well in it. Senior year,I took AP Physics with the same teacher and enjoyed it even more. Theconcepts were all interesting, I felt like I understood the material well,and my teacher incorporated what we were learning into real life issues.After arriving at UIUC as a physics major, I joined the Society of PhysicsStudents and Society for Women in Physics, and I felt right at home. Iloved the other students and the department as a whole. My classes werechallenging but interesting, but I received so much support. My secondyear I became a representative for the Physics Student Advisory Boardand got a job as one of the coordinators for the UIUC Physics Van, whichis a traveling science show for kids. I have enjoyed being a part of all ofthese things and how it has affected my college career. I think my decisionto become a physics major has benefited me greatly.

I began considering physics as a major after I took the required courses in high school. Before junior year I never even considered it a possibility, but when I transferred schools junior year physics was required. My teacher was amazing and inspiring and the material was so fun that I decided to pursue it. Although I did check with my teacher first to see if he thought I would be able to (reasonably) pursue it (he said of course I could). Although my parents are not in scientific careers, they have encouraged me to do it because I love it. I have always had their support, and the support of my teachers, and that`s what has led me to be able to be a physics Major. The support from professors and students at AU, and the general AU community had also made me able to keep going in it when things get difficult.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social), Physiological/Emotional

Response: I was just a chemistry major and physics minor and after discussing the addition of physics to be my second major, my advisor thought it would be a great idea. I also believe that being a woman in physics will be a great addition to my pursue in getting my PhD

My mother is a physics professor and so I`ve always known that Physics was an option I could pursue. It wasn`t until taking a Special Relativity intro Physics class in college however that I really found I enjoyed physics/astronomy and wanted to pursue it further.

How I got here is significant to understanding who I am. My whole life I wanted to be a scientist. However, I was strongly discouraged from a young age. Partially because I was not born into an environment that accepted the idea of women in science and because of my unusual performance in school. When I was a young I had extreme trouble in school but exhibited exceptional verbal communication skills for a child and an unusually strong talent for realistic drawing. When I was nine I was diagnosed with severe dyslexia, ADHD, and an anxiety disorder. The guidance counselor who informed my parents told them I wouldnÕt be able to graduate high school and should focus on art due to my aptitude in drawing. What no one understood at the time was that my aptitude for drawing was not the result of an interest in the arts, but rather an interest in geometry and the problem-solving aspect of finding the shapes within a more complex figure. I grew up trying to prove people wrong about my potential but also trying to compensate for my struggle in the classroom. Not believing I could go into science I tried to focus on design in high school. Despite what the counselor said, I did graduate high school and got accepted to a good architecture school. I attended for one year and realized no matter how hard I tried to believe I loved architecture, my passion would always be in science. So, a few days before I was supposed to go back for my second year, I gathered the courage to do what I had wanted to do for a long time: I withdrew from architecture school and registered at PCC to study physics and eventually transfer to a four-year university to complete a degree in astrophysics. IÕm much happier now.
Codes: Attainment Value, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Cost (Outside Effort)

Response: My dad is an engineer and we???ve always connected over our love for science so I grew up with a general interest in the sciences. In elementry school they started to divide the students based on mathematical aptitude, I was placed in the accelerated learning section. This made me feel capable and since then it has been a part of my identity. I can do math and do it well. This was reafirmed by the fact that my father was good at math too so I could see where it could take me because he has a very successful career. These were all impressions made on me before or during middle school. After that it was just claiming my place in every math and science course there, if I had any doubts about my abilities I don???t think I would have made it this far because I occasionally ran into sterotyping, which was a driving force in proving them wrong. That I belong here and that I???ll work harder and learn more than them. Because of this and my general aptitute (which I feel many women have, but the don???t identify with) I have always been at the top of my class. After completing the first 2 years of undergrad I took some time off of school because my competitive nature was unsustainable. I needed to be inspired by more to succeed and have an impact on the world as a scientist, so I traveled and explored who I wanted to be in this world in this one life I have. I came back to the same conclusion that I want to be a physicist, but this time it wasn???t to prove to people that their presumptions about me are wrong, but because I know I can make a contribution. I can???t wait to collaborate with the many brilliant scientific minds out there to make this world a better place.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Utility Value

Response: I remember from a very young (elementary student) age being very interested in science in general. I was always intrigued as to how things worked and asking `why`, much to my parents` annoyance. However, even at age thirteen I only had a vague idea of the field of Physics. I certainly didn`t know anyone who had studied physics, or even science. I thought science was mainly what I would now consider biology and I knew I didn`t want to study that long term. One day I saw an advert in my local newspaper for a series of public science talks, and suggested to my parents that I`d like to go. They dutifully took me and I sat enthralled as a physicist described both his work and how we could prove that man really had landed on the moon through physics. I felt that I had finally found the career I wanted (which I had no idea had existed before that evening), a field that used both my maths skills and my curiosity for how the universe worked.Over the next couple of years, I continued maths class with an excellent teacher in a small `gifted and talented` group of eight, which really pushed me mathematically, I struggled a lot with the rigorous curriculum and being in a class of high-achievers, but I believe it taught me to persevere with maths and problem solving. However, at age 16, and partly due to familial pressure to `get a degree that will lead to a job`, I was split between physics (which by then I knew was where my true interest lay) and engineering (which I liked less but lead to a more obvious career). Luckily I then was placed in a class with an excellent, interesting Physics teacher for the first time, and he encouraged me that I could study physics at university and that I had the ability. He also nominated me for an award from a scholarship trust in the UK, and that lead me to physics-based residentials and more public lectures. As is the UK system, I then applied for university as a physics student. I really believe that it was excellent teaching and, equally, encouragement that lead me to being a physics student. I found the mathematical treatment of the universe fascinating, but I doubt I would have ever gone on to study Physics at university without excellent maths and physics teaching and two teachers who explicitly told me I had the ability to.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience, Cost (Emotional), Social Persuasion

Response: When I was in High School the state of Texas offered a program for Juniors in High School. I completed additional homework assignments throughout the school year and atthe end of the school year was selected to do a week long seminar over the summer.The seminar consisted of being part of a team that designed a manned mission to Mars.This was the point that I knew I wanted to pursue a path in Physics.

I originally wanted to go into chemistry, but I found I had a talent for engineering/working with my hands in a high school applied physics course where we build things like small cars and model bridges. My teacher encouraged me to look into physics seriously. Once in college, I got accepted into an experimental physics elective lab where I got to work with vacuum chambers and different optic experiments. In doing the experiments and talking to the TAs about their research experience I realized the part of chemistry I loved the most was the physics end of it. I was fully "converted" to a physics major when a TA in the course told me there was an undergraduate opening in his lab (which was run by my professor in that same course) and urged I apply for it. This got me a job in an amazing condensed matter research lab in my second semester of college (which I still work at now) that has given me incredible experiences.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered

Response: I chose to major in physics because the subject was always interesting to me growing up. In high school, I was able to listen to presentations about the different jobs available in the science and engineering field. The presentation that stood out to me the most was the astronomy one, because I could see myself working and doing research in that field.My physics teacher was also a big reason why I chose to major in physics/astronomy. She was incredibly passionate about what she taught and she encouraged me to work hard and understand the subject. Another factor that influenced me was that seeing a successful woman teaching physics or presenting the researchthey`ve done encouraged me to choose physics. I know that a lot of women are discouraged from working in science fields, so seeing women succeed in this field motivated me even more.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience

Response: I was not an academic person, until I took my first ever classical mechanics class I was flattered by the depth and the subtlety of the subject. I felt like I was introduced to whole different world where things are a lot complicated and wonderful. I found myself staying awake all night trying to solve a physics problem. It just got my heart. I like theory, but I noticed that I am more like experimental person. I stay after school on fridays to work in lab and do whatever I like to do. I like using oscilloscope, and coming up with various circuit design. I think however old the classical mechanics might be, the modern physics hold onto the base. And that is the one of the things that intrigues my curiosity for physics.

My father was a big influence in my choosing to pursue a degree in physics as he also got a Masters in physics. However, he always encouraged whatever choice I wanted to make. I have always wanted to work in physics.
Had no idea I would wind up studying physics. I thought I was an artist because I was so creative. But the arts were not fulfilling. My Dad started watching the tv show "Through the Wormhole

My dad is an engineer, and he told me about physics from a very young age. I didn`t realize that physics was a field in and of itself until after I had graduated with a bachelors degree in Environmental Science. After teaching for 4 years, I went back to school to get my bachelors in physics with the intent of pursuing a graduate degree.

I was a Biology major who really liked NASA, until I decided that I didn`t want to do Biology any more, so I changed my major to Physics because I`ve always wanted to be an Astrophysicist. I wasn`t a physics major at first because I always considered being an astrophysicist a pipe dream; I thought I wasn`t smart enough, but now I know that if I dedicate myself to my studies I`m able to succeed.

I had an excellent class about stars and stellar evolution years ago from a teacher at UCSC that I think may have beenmy first exposure to the science of Astronomy. Currently, I have an acquaintance that is a Physics Professor at the University of Washington. We often run into each other ata coffee shop and he explains concepts that I inquire about.Last spring he suggested I take a lecture cosmology classhe was teaching, I found it fascinating. I was alreadyplanning on going back to school for physics but this definitely cemented the desire. The more physics I learn the more I want to know. Currently I`m working on my first physics classes, my teacher is a woman and she`s very supportive. She was the one that told me about this conference and I`m very excited to meet other female physicsmajors. Right now I`m the only one I know.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: My interest in phyics led me to become a physics major. It is what I like the most out of my interests and something I can see myself applying to other fields in the future.

I did this by looking back at my childhood and seeing that throughout all of my years, I held onto a passion for physics and space. I developed other passions that possibly tied into a future career in astronomy and eventually found my dream job that way. Overall, my high school pushed towards building a career and put me in a path to help me in a stem career.

I became interested in Astronomy as a nine year old living in Ghana, West Africa. I decided to pursue the sciences in high school and later on Physics and Astronomy in college because of my heightened interest in cosmology and particle physics.

I never thought I`d be interested in science at all until 8th grade earth science. We watched a video on the future of space travel. There was a bit about solar sails and how those would work. I was hooked. Space was officially my passion.This led me to believing I should be an astronaut. Instead of going the engineering route that most aspiring astronauts seem to take, I went with physics. I took AP physics as soon as I could in high school. My teacher there was amazing. He made everything fun and encouraged us to try more difficult material.From there it was a given that I`d major in physics. I`m not so set on being an astronaut anymore. I`ve experienced some now of what the research side of physics is and I love it. I would be 100% content just doing that for the rest of my life.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Utility Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: My parents, especially my mom, always encouraged my sister an I to pursue science and challenge ourselves in school. My sister was also a physics major and she is currently working on her PhD. I was attracted to physics because I liked math in high school and it came easily to me, but I didn`t like the fields that math majors went into. Physics is the application of math to the real world, and I love it more as I continue to learn more about it.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: Taking math and physics classes in high school, and seeing demonstrations and participating in physics experiments.

My high school physics teacher was always very encouraging to me and she helped motivate me to do well in my physics classes. I also naturally excelled at science and math classes, which helped me like my physics class even more. When I reached college, I went in thinking I was going to major in Chemistry, but I also took a physics lab class because I was possibly thinking about minoring in Physics. However, as I was comparing my physics lab and chem lab, I realized I enjoyed my physics lab so much better. I also noticed that outside of class I enjoyed keeping up to date on physics and astronomy related news rather than chemistry related news. Because of this, I switched my major to physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value

Response: I initially considered studying physics in 5th grade when I got a popular science book on quantum mechanics. I didn`t think I wanted to pursue the topic in high school, but the AP Physics C course I took was incredibly challenging. Wanting to continue challenging myself I enrolled in honors physics at my University and have never looked back.

My third grade teacher sang us a song about the solar system and the planet Jupiter blew my mind. I then wanted to become an astronaut. I was always bad at math and did not graduate high school so after many years of going in an out of community college, I decided to pursue a degree in physics because the internet said if I was interested in astronomy, I should major in physics. I overcame my mental math block and transferred to a local 4 year university and enjoy all of my classes(except classical mechanics) and could not see myself studying anything else.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: I used to build and launch rockets and was really interested in how they worked, so I researched more about it and really enjoyed it. I also took two physics classes in high school and found that I was pretty good at it and liked it. Then, and now, I want to know more and more about why things are the way they are in the universe, and specifically, how the atmosphere and space work. I am fascinated by everything I am learning, which is why I continue to major in it.

I have always been fascinated with Astronomy since I was a child and I wanted to pursue a career in it ever since then. UCSB doesn`t offer Astronomy as a major (only as a minor) but they have a great Physics department so I decided to choose Physics as my major. I don`t have a strong background in Physics but I`m more than willing to learn.

To begin with, I always knew that I was going to pursue science. I have always loved and been intrigued by all the sciences. In high school, I had a very good Honors and AP Physics Professor who spurred my interest in the field. My first physics course at Harvey Mudd College was a special relativity class that was part of the required core. I loved the class and the following mechanics class that I took. As an overall life goal, I want to pursue biomimicry and I discovered that physics would be an excellent way for me to get to that goal. Biophysics in combination with some biomaterials is what I am currently planning to set as my path. One major insight about picking physics as my major is that I don`t have to be the greatest physics student out there, as long as I enjoy the matter and feel passionately about what I am learning, then I am accomplishing my goal. I want to make a positive difference in the world, and I think I can achieve that through physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Attainment Value, Vicarious Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Utility Value

Response: I realized I liked and was good at math my freshman year of high school, which was the same year I read Carl SaganÕs Cosmos and fell in love with astronomy. My junior year I took a community college physics class, and discovered how exciting and exhilarating I found the process of problem solving in physics to be.  Since then I havenÕt looked back; using math to understand the universe is the most exciting, fulfilling thing I could be doing.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Media Triggered, Physiological/Emotional

Response: I took AP physics in high school with a teacher that had huge passion for the subject and was very responsive and open. We would stay after class and talk more about the subject, and he gave me the academic award for physics at the end of the year. I decided it was what i wanted to do, and i`ve never changed my mind. While the courseload has been difficult, i`ve been interested in every class i`ve since taken. it interests me hugely, and it`s very satisfying to have a concept click.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience

Response: I was initially influenced by the movie Interstellar when I was 12, then I randomly decided to do a research project over Special Relativity. This led me to take AP physics courses in high school as well as attend conferences with different speakers like Michio Kaku. I also have read many different physics books and have just found myself in love with the topic ever since I first was introduced to it.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered

Response: I wanted to go into engineering and physics was a required course. During the course, I realized that I had a natural inclination to finish my physics problem set than any other homework. I didn`t seriously consider physics as an option until I came to that realization.

My name is Brenda Fabela Enr??quez. Since I was in elementary school, I felt strongly attracted to science, enjoying experimenting at my school or house, and always wondering why and how the things worked. I used to do experiments that were written in my textbooks, read a lot about natural sciences and watch TV programs about science. During all my academic studies, I have obtained good grades. During the high school I have participated in many competitions of knowledge at state and national level, related to physics, chemistry and mathematics, and I`ve obtained first places in those contests. When I realized that I have the ability of understand and deal with problems linked with natural and exact sciences, and also, because all the new concepts and knowledge that I have acquired through the competition, I discovered that I have a passion for Physics and for the research, currently in the experimental field, I decided to study Physics as my bachelor. In addition, the teachers who have prepared me for the contests, encouraged me to study physics, showing me that is a beautiful and rewarding profession, that help to the humanity to understand our Universe, our nature.
Codes: Attainment Value, Media Triggered, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion

Response: When I was younger, I always enjoyed taking things apart to examine how they work. By the time I reached high school, I realized my interest in science and physics, but refused to take a physics class because I felt that being forced to study it and being graded on it would ruin it for me. I preferred to read up on various astrophysics and cosmology concepts on my own, outside of the classroom. After high school, I worked for five years before finally deciding to pursue a career path in physics. I began by enrolling in the local community college, and have since transferred to UNC Charlotte where I am a semester shy of receiving my Bachelor`s degree in physics. My experiences at the university, including various research internships and assistantships, have only strengthened my resolve in this path. Next stop, graduate school.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Event Triggered

Response: I discovered the field of physics by asking around after becoming interested in astronomy. I had to seek this out on my own; no one pushed me or encouraged me.

I was planning on majoring in Biology, but I happened to stumble upon Carl Sagan`s book, Pale Blue Dot. I wanted to learn more about our universe, and I felt as though the next best step was to major in Physics.
My passion for astronomy got me thinking into what majors would be helpful for me to pursue a career in the astronomy field.

I first considered physics as option when I started college as a chemical engineer. I felt like engineering wasnt right for me, and neither was chemistry. I did not enjoy neither biology nor computer science either. However, I felt that I always had a love for math, especially math that could be applied to real life phenomena-- and that was when I found out physics was the right field for me. I study both math and physics, one for the abstract end of it and the other for the application of mathematical concepts.

Working at LANL for a summer internship, I was privileged to be working with two other postdoctoral students. Mary and Olga both served to be positive female role models in the lab. While these two women first encouraged meto think of physics as a career, it was not until working with one of my professors on a project that I felt empowered to change majors into the physics department.
Codes: Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: The way that Physics is so involved in my life is because I am an Engineering major. Through becoming an Engineer student, I have been shown Physics and I very much enjoyed the classes I have taken, I have done well in them and felt like I have learned a lot.

When I was in elementary school I had a class project on hurricanes and from there I became interested in weather.After that I wanted to become a meteorologist and since I excelled at math I easily chose to pursue an atmospheric science degree.Once in college I realized atmospheric science in applied math and physics and realized how much I actually liked physics (my high school experience was not the best).
I really like solving physics problems. I also really enjoy being able to understand how the world works, and applying equations to solve actual problems.

IÕve always been enamored by space and the stars. As long as I can remember, I knew that I was going to go into the field of astronomy in some way. Thus, every class I have taken and every grade I have recieved has been for this aspiration.

For most of high school, I though that I was going to be an English major, but in junior year, I took a physics course with a really good teacher. After that, I decided that studying physics was what i wanted to do with my life.

My very first physics class was in my sophomore year of college. Initially I was intimidated by it, but I told myself that I had to get through it. My mindset changed once I learned about electromagtic fields because I could easily relate that to my chemistry major. I decided to minor in physics because I enjoyed learning about the mathematical relationships and how to derive equations. Now, I am a Conceptual, Principal, and General Physics tutor and I feel like I know the material better because I am teaching strategies to other students. Tutoring has also helped me in my upper level physics classes and acts as a refresher.

Taking AP Physics C, which was my favorite class in high school. In college, I became more interested in the mathematical theory behind physics, rather than the physics concepts themselves. This led me to major in math and minor in physics.

I`ve been fascinated by Physics as far back as I can remember but the first time I started considering it as a career is when my mother bought me a book on the universe. Currently I am pursuing Physics because of it`s ability to explain so many phenomenon around us and it`s wide scope.

I love learning so I figured I could be happy with any field I chose to study. When I was in high school, however, I went through a period of clinical depression and physics, my first exposer was calculus-based were I didn`t even know calculus, was so hard I didn`t have time to be sad, and it gave me confidence that I could master challenging problems. I`ve always loved math, and physics seemed to be a perfect application that could help me wherever I decided to pursue a career if that ended up being outside of physics. So I committed to learning as much as I can right now, and my peers are some of my most significant support in keeping that.

I originally didn`t even consider science as a career ormajor to complete in college. I wanted to be a musicianor a veterinarian. I wasn`t at all confident in math skillseven though I managed to get A`s and B`s in math coursesuntil I took trigonometry. I did very well in trig, andthen I did even better in calculus in high school. Thiscombined with watching science fiction films (specificallyContact and the CERN scenes in Angels & Demons) made meinterested in physics and engineering, however I had noidea how to actually get started in learning, or couldn`tfigure out the things I need to start doing. It was over-whelming, and I felt very inadequate at science. I wasgood at memorizing things in biology, but problem-solvingwas scary and new to me, especially since my high schooldidn`t even have a physics course when I was wanting to takeone. When applying to colleges they said that your choice ofmajor didn`t affect your acceptance (even though we all knowit does), so I put physics almost as a joke, with musicas a double major. After I decided to go to Fresno Statemainly to continue with the music program I was familiar withI started to love my intro physics courses more than mymusic courses. Learning the in-depth theory deconstructedthe emotional side of music and made it too roboticand formulaic for me to enjoy it. However, putting formulasand theory behind the physical world made me love learningabout physics more (what a weird paradox) because I couldquantify the world around me. I eventually decided to drop the music major and stickwith just physics. It seems like physics is one of the majors in college that are really worth the time and money.It`s hard to learn it by yourself, especially if youhave an inadequate background like myself. The average joedoesn`t really care about physics so a university is oneof the most accessible places I could think of to interact with people who cared about physics.I enjoy my professors and fellow students and departmentas a whole. We are a small department, which is welcomingin comparison to the giant, unfriendly biology and chemistrydepartments. The faculty know you by name, we have weeklybarbeques that everyone is invited to join in- even justrandom students walking by Mclane Hall. We have a physics undergrad study room that unites us all and creates a community and support system. I`m excited to continuebeing a physics student and learn more about how ouruniverse works.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I started by taking the low-level physics course in high school. I definitely interested me but I wasn`t sure if I wanted to go down the physics or chemistry path for college. I took calculus based physics my junior year and thought that I wasn`t too sure if I wanted to really study physics so senior year I took Calculus I and college level chemistry. Calculus showed me what I was missing from the Physics courses I had taken and from there I was hooked. I also had a friend tell me about astrophysics freshman year of high school and that really stuck with me. I had that in the back of my mind when trying to decide what I wanted to study in college and decided I couldn`t see myself studying anything other than that. There has to be something (or someone) else out there.

I became a physics major because I had an interest in astrophysics since I was young and realized that I could turn a mere interest into a career path. I also discovered that while I thought of myself as bad at math for a very long time, I was not at bad at it as I thought, especially once I applied myself to the topic. Once taking physics in my junior year I realized it was something I loved learning about and wanted to pursue further.

My first experience with physics was at a community college in high school. My high school still does not have physics as a course. My first love was mathematics, and I saw that physics was just practical mathematics and relating physical properties in a mathematical way. I enjoyed my professors in physics, and thought that they seemed excited about physics. I saw that there were even fewer women in physics than there were in mathematics, and I decided that I wanted to be a professor who could help women like me become physicists.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Utility Value

Response: I originally planned to be a pharmacist coming into college, however when I realized how much upper chemistry I had to complete, I decided to take my second choice of a major which was physics. This decision did not occur until my second year of college, therefore I have to stay an extra year at the university. When I first became interested in physics I was in 10th grade. My teacher pushed me into advanced learning and that was when I developed a strong attraction for physics.

Physics was the only class in high school I got a B in, so naturally I chose to major in it. I saw it as a challenge, to finally prove myself to others. I chose and continue in physics because of my public image.

I failed physics the first time I took it in high school but loved it even then. I retook it with the support of my physics teacher and did much better and have loved challenging myself with the subject ever since.
Physics has always been of interest to me. My family has been supportive of my decisions.

I took an elective course my senior year of high school called Honors Modern Physics and immediately fell in love. My high school teacher was very passionate and skilled at physics and has inspired most of my hand work and love for the subject. In this course I was constantly challenged and stumped by complicated subjects and problems but with my class was able to tackle each issue head on. We focused on varying subjects (calculating the speed of light, mechanics, astrophysics, relativity and more), going in depth on each and building our knowledge from the ground up as if rediscovery this topic for ourselves. This course taught me great skills in problem solving while introducing me to the subject of physics. When I came to Whitman college I began taking intro physics courses, but was unable to maintain the same wonder and drive for these subjects as I had in high school. With more lecture style teaching I found it difficult to grasp the importance and relevance of the information rather than just try to memorize equations, which I don`t believe physics is about. I believe physics is about understanding what an equation can tell you about the physical properties of something. I`ve found it hard to grasp conceptual concepts apart with and separate from mathematical aspects of physics. I have found a grounding to physics at Whitman through the astronomy department, as many of the concepts overlap and relate to astronomy. I am open minded about the upper level physics courses and believe that they will cover topics more in depth than the intro courses.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Cost (Task Effort), Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: I chose physics because I was good at spatial reasoning and was comfortable with math. I always had to try the hardest thing and understand the most about `why` something happened the way it did. When I first entered college, I was an engineering major and found that no professors ever answered `why`, so I switched and never looked back. Now I love seeing how one thing relates to something else that you wouldn`t have thought were ever related. I love being able to use my understanding of `why` things happen in new situations and for things that I am passionate about.

I became a double major in chemistry and math because I wanted to learn how to apply math to the sciences. I enjoyed how math can be used to explain science, so when I took an introductory physics course during my sophomore year, I loved it. That is when I added a minor in physics to my studies and started applying for research internships in physics. I participated in a biophysics REU at Texas Christian University. I am now a physics tutor and a supplemental instruction leader for a physics class. I genuinely enjoy helping other students understand concepts that explain the world we live in.

I was strongly influenced by my high school Physics teacher. He showed a genuine passion for teaching the material and wanted all his students to succeed. He taught my class so well, that I became very interested in Physics and decided that was what I wanted to major in. Physics has helped satisfy my own personal curiosity about how that world works. Throughout my undergraduate career, I found great satisfaction from working on experimental research duringa summer REU and labs and I would love to keep doing experimental research throughout graduate school.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered

Response: My high school physics teacher made the subject very interesting and fun. I liked the subject, and so I pursued it once in college. My family also has always been interested in the sciences, and so I have had a curiosity about the field all my life.

I started college as a Biology major and then switched to physics. I switched to physics because I had always enjoyed physics in High School. In High School, I took two years of AP Physics (AP Physics B and AP Physics C). My decision to attend grad school stemmed from my research experience that I did at Lehigh University last summer.

I`ve always been interested in astronomy, and how the universe works. I got sidetracked in high school because I was really good at biology, so I assumed that I should become a doctor. But I took a physics class during my senior year, and I started to doubt my career path. I stayed in the biology program for 2 years at my college before I switched. I was so much happier and more invested in the astronomy courses I took in college, and both my physics` high schools teacher`s enthusiasm and my professor`s enthusiasm encouraged me to switch to something that I knew would be much more difficult to understand, but something I could conceivably see myself being happy doing for the rest of my life.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: I first took physics in high school. I loved the application of math and had a great teacher who fostered interest in the the subject. The more I learned about physics the more I wanted to continue!

Throughout my educational career, the sciences weren`t really emphasized until I got to high school. My physics high school teacher saw potential in me and got me involved in popsicle stick bridge building competitions. Along with other students, we would stay after school to build out competing bridge along with learning and discussing the physics behind it all. Coming from South Central Los Angeles we didn`t think we had a chance against other schools. To our surprise we won 2nd place our first competing year and that encouraged me to look into Civil Engineering.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Event Triggered, Mastery Experience

Response: I have always done well in math and science classes and found a particular interest in astronomy while still attending high school. There is not really a specific experience that made me decided on astronomy; I simply enjoyed the subject. I assumed getting a bachelor`s degree in physics and moving on to a master`s degree in astrophysics would be a better route in terms of job opportunities. I have attended regional stargazes of which further increased my desire to become an astrophysicist. Attending this conference will be a wonderful experience and I look forward to meeting the people working in the field of physics.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Utility Value, Event Triggered

Response: There was a science museum in Tokyo that I really liked as an elementary-school child that got me into astronomy initially, and I later found passion for math in later years of my elementary school, middle school, and high school. In high school, these two passions coalesced in a brilliant field called physics, and I am currently especially interested in theoretical astrophysics. In college so far, I especially enjoyed the graduate-level astrophysics course I took last year, and the variable star astronomy research project I have been conducting for about two years now. Consequently, I would like to complete a Ph.D. in physics with an emphasis on astrophysics or astronomy. In terms of career, I am currently very much split between teaching and research, but the ultimate goal for me is to become a physics professor at a university.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Physiological/Emotional, Utility Value, Event Triggered

Response: I have always loved math and thought of myself as someone who would end up as a scientist. It wasn`t until I read a book about a doctor in Haiti, that I realized that there is a big issue with water quality in the world. That is when I decided that I wanted to become an engineer.I can use my skills in mathematics in a real life application in order to bring people a better quality of life.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Utility Value

Response: High school physics was by far my favorite class before I entered college.  I had not decided a major until my 3rd year of college, and became excited after watching different physics videos on youtube. I decided I would pursue a career in that direction. The classes that I take now that involve physics or engineering excite me greatly. I am most likely going to transfer from city college to a university within 2 years as a Mech. Engineer.

I have always shown an interest in science and how things work. I frequented science museums as a child and that was really the start of my interest in physics. In high school I had a physics teacher who was very passionate about the subject and encouraged me to pursue it as a career. Throughout college, I have continued my enjoyment of physics and despite some difficulties, have flourished in my physics career thus far. Now looking into the future, I know that I can use my passion for physics to help me find a suitable career.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: There were a few science museum exhibits and science-related activities that initially got me excited about physics in middle school, but I didn`t think about pursuing physics until high school.  Looking back, it was very much the gender dynamic that initially kept me from acknowledging my interest.  When I went to an all-girls high school, there wasn`t a gender norm associated with different subjects.  It became clear to me that I was not only interested in physics, but I could see myself in the role of a physics student.  I studied a lot of physics and physics-related topics on my own, and that just fueled my excitement and gave me confidence when I went to college and interacted with other physics students.
switched majors about 7 different times, knowing I always loved physics but it definitely intimidated me quite a bit. Finally plunged into it and haven`t regretted it since.

I really enjoyed my high school physics course because learning about how the world worked was so interesting. I really enjoyed teaching and imagined it would be fun to teach physics since its a subject I enjoyed a lot. I excelled my freshmen year and found that physics at TCNJ really brought out the best version of myself. I enjoy the challenge of physics and have always been able to overcome it and I feel like I`ve become a more intelligent person learning physics. I hope to inspire my future students as I`ve been inspired by physics.

I have always loved science; it is my favorite subject. At first, I wanted to be a surgeon, but in my senior year of high school, I decided I no longer wanted to pursue that career. I was taking physics at the time, and the labs and concepts were appealing. I was also taking human anatomy and physiology, which I love studying. When I had to apply for colleges, I wanted to do a major that combined both physics and human anatomy. After doing research on potential jobs, I decided to become a biomedical engineer.

I was first introduced to chemistry in middle school and loved it immediately. While doing some independent research on different topics in chemistry I learned about physics and have been very interested in it ever since. It was a lesson in atomic structure that got me into chemistry, so high energy physics is what has and still excites me most. I wasn`t able to take a physics class until my senior year of high school, but I really liked the big picture concepts I was learning on my own because they provided explanations for why things are the way they are, and it was that drive to understand the world around me that solidified my decision to study physics.

I came in as an astronomy major because I love Neil deGrasse Tyson. I found out that astronomy was very physics-heavy and decided to double-major. I stayed with physics because I believe it will bring me job opportunities.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Utility Value

Response: I`ve always excelled in math which eventually led me to physics.

I became interested in astronomy in the third grade, and from that point I continued to follow that path, until highschool, when I realized I wanted to do astrophysics specifically. Both of my parents along with my high school physics teacher were supporters of this decision and helped me to decide for sure on that path

I started college as a music major, and quickly felt unfulfilled in that environment.  I still love and am involved in music, but it is not my focus anymore.  I spent a semester considering different potential fields, and landed on physics since it was my favorite class in high school, and I enjoy learning about physics concepts and new research outside of class.  Since switching to a Physics major, I have never considered moving out of it.  I have found a community and a sense of home in the Physics department at my university.

I enjoyed physics in high school, and took many proto-engineering courses then as well.I happened to get placed in a Physics course my first semester in college, mostly by accident. I bonded well with the other engaged students in the course, and enjoyed the community enough to continue pursuing courses in the field.

I was originally an English major but I always had a fascination for science, originally anatomy, then chemistry. Then after switching from English to computer engineering, I heard about the CUWiP conference from my physics teacher and decided to go. I always knew I was into science and after talking to many attendees and the professors from the university, I decided to go to astrophysics.

I`ve always had an interest in space, and that has taken me through many different ideas of what I wanted to do. First it was more of an engineering approach, wanting to work on spacecraft. Then it became more of an interdisciplinary focus when I believed I couldn`t really succeed in engineering/physics because I didn`t have a strong math/calculus base. I gained some confidence in my math skills, and planned once again to go with a space physics and engineering path, with the intent to focus on developing spacecraft to send humans to Mars. I had a realization this semester while taking a stellar astronomy class that, while human spaceflight is still an interest, astrophysics and astronomy are greater interests.

When I came into college, I wasn`t even considering being a physics major. I didn`t enjoy my honors physics class in high school, and didn`t find it to be interesting. I took a freshman elective in physics at Harvey Mudd because the course sounded like it would be heavily based in chemistry. I had no idea that there was so much overlap, and I thought it was interesting to learn about what I knew from chemistry from a new, deeper perspective. I went through Harvey Mudd`s core classes, which includes Special Relativity, Newtonian Mechanics, and Electricity & Magnetism I. I did well, and I enjoyed interacting with the faculty. I always felt like the professors were fair and thoughtful, and I trusted the department and felt like I could learn a lot from working with them. However, I wasn`t interested in studying physics as a major until we talked about statistical mechanics in my physical chemistry course. The professor`s explanations of what a partition function was and how we could extract thermodynamic quantities from derivatives of its natural log went completely over my head, but I thought it was such a cool tool/description. After that week, I felt like I really wanted to understand where it came from and how it worked. Because of the extensive core program, I was still on track to be a physics major, so I declared myself as a physics major in the spring of my sophomore year. I`ve enjoyed my classes a lot (they`re hard!), but sometimes I doubt whether or not 1) I can be a successful physicist 2) I can find a job as easily as my CS/Engineering major friends will be able to.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic (Social), Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: When I was in my country Costa Rica, I had the opportunity to meet the director of a university project in a public university in Costa Rica, the project consisted in the creation of the first Central American satellite. This project, the opportunity to study physics in the United World College movement, and my high interest in science led me to make the decision to study physics-mathematics at College. I am extremely interested and excited to be part of activities in the area of physics, in projects and research, and learn from other experts in this field.
My parents always pushed me to explain things as I saw them growing up. It gave me a deep sense of curiosity and I see that same sense in the physics community.

As clich??d as it sounds, I was interested in astronomy from a very early age. My parents fed this interest with books and related materials, encouraging me to follow the things I???m interested in. In elementary school, I actually helped out all of my teachers during the astronomy lessons, as I already knew everything they were teaching us in class. I have always been fascinated by the strange wonders of the cosmos and I thought how amazing it would be to study these astronomical wonders for the rest of my life. I seriously considered pursuing astronomy and physics in middle school, where I began to take classes that I knew would prepare me for my future in this field. I also began reading more books on the subject and attending local talks and public observing sessions, which only succeeded in piquing my interest even more. In high school, I had more freedom to take classes pertaining to physics and astronomy. When it came time to apply for college, I looked into astronomy and physics programs, eventually settling on the University of Wisconsin at River Falls (UWRF) upon recommendation, where I would be majoring in physics with the ultimate goal in receiving a PhD in order to achieve a career in astrophysics. Now into my second year as an undergraduate, I have become even more involved and excited about physics. I help out in the intro physics classes and the public astronomy observing sessions here on campus and I became involved in the IceCube project as an intern studying neutrinos this past summer. As a result, I have attended many physics conferences where I have presented my undergraduate research. My work with IceCube has continued over the last part of this semester, with promise to continue even farther into the future. IceCube is exactly the kind of work I want to be doing as an astrophysicist and I am extremely enthusiastic about the project. I never knew that I was so interested in particle astrophysics, but I absolutely love it and I hope to continue the work.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: I first became interested in astrophysics upon realizing that the vast expanse of the universe was so far beyond me that I did not even realize how much I did not know until I started learning more. Entertaining the idea of studying astrophysics over the first year of my undergraduate career, I began taking physics classes to see if that was indeed the path I wanted to take. I enjoyed my physics and astronomy courses more than any others (such as life science and chemistry) because, simply put, they actually involved thinking. Learning physics and astronomy involves more than just memorization or learning tricks to get good grades. It involves thinking and truly seeking to understand the nature of the universe. I enjoy thinking beyond myself, and that is why I am studying astrophysics.

I loved reading Michio Kaku books in middle school, which got me very interested in physics as a field. Later in high school when I took physics classes and did some research, I decided that was what I wanted to do as a job because I loved it so much.

I chose to become a physics major to become a more well rounded scientist and better/quicker problem solver when it came to real world applications and issues. I am glad I chose this major because since deciding I have chosen to travel and attend many conferences of varying topics and types of people involved and it has really influenced me in positive way to see all the different options of how physics can be used in real world careers and what I was ultimately interested in.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: When I was in high school, one day, I decided to read a thick physics reference book,just because I didn`t understandhow certain formulas were derived. After I read the book for two consecutive days, I happened to fall in lovewith physics knowledge as it, somehow, managed to explain most of the events that people encounter in real life.I was then starting to realize how close physics to people`s life is. However, most people didn`t see physicsas interesting as I did. They often thought physics as a killer course due to its difficulty, which then led them tohave bad perception about physics and neglect the fact that physics was a fascinating field to explore. For this reason,I decided to pursue in physics so that I could change this stereotype by introducing physics in a different yet interesting way.

I aspired to be a journalist, but after interning at a broadcast news station, I felt that too much importance was placed on how the information was presented rather thanthe quality of the information. We only published what would sell, not what people needed to hear. Back at school I took Astronomy for my science requirement. I discovered that here, the most important thing wasn`t how you presented your topic, but rather what the topic meant. It also helped that during this time I had a marvelous Intro physics instructorthat really encouraged me to make the switch, even late in my college career. Never too late!
I first started physics as an option in my high school physics class. I like the way that how it seeks to explain the world around us.
Taking a physics course in high school where I basically taught myself how to do physics.

I wanted to be an architect in elementary school. What sparked my interest at first in physics was some science shows on the History channel.Then one day I saw the show The Universe on the History channel and fell in love with it. I noticed the scientistsfeature were all astronomers, physicists, and astrophysicists.I knew that that is what I wanted to study for the rest ofmy life: space. So from 7th grade on I`ve wanted to becomeand astrophysicists , and that is my goal in school - all theway to a PHD.

In high school, I wasn`t sure if I should pursue physics or if I should just study music, since physics was pretty hard for me. I expressed this to my dad in the car one time and he told me that he saw a light in my eyes when I talked about physics and that I should go for it. I hold that remark he made very dear to me. I never loved learning anything like I loved physics; physics was the only thing I didn`t actively dislike the work of learning (note: I love learning things, but the work of learning is hard to love). It has been very hard, but I am about to graduate and I am honestly amazed I made it this far, and that I am now applying to Ph.D. programs in physics. I never would have imagined that I would be here, back when I was sitting in that car with my dad.

I watched many science programs on TV as a child and quickly learned I loved to learn about astronomy and how our world works. In high school I did a lot of environmental research and learned the value of a hands-on, research approach to learning. In college, as I dive further into my upper level physics and astronomy courses, as well as my research, I decided that this is something I want to continue learning for as long as possible. Against the many barriers I have faced, both as a woman and a minority from a lower socioeconomic background, I firmly believe that obtaining my Ph.D. will be invaluable in achieving the future I see for myself.
Codes: Media Triggered, Event Triggered, Cost (Emotional), Utility Value

Response: This past summer I was giving an opportunity to do high altitude ballooning research. This definitely opened my eyes about physics and I choose that I would like to continue to achieve a physics minor.

I was never presented physics at my Christian Academy. I had no understanding of how everything around me worked, nor did I care. Once I graduated from my high school, I went on to go to community college- as that is what society has told me to do-not for my own knowledge. Upon  taking an earth and space science credit, I learned that Mars had two moons. This was the exact moment my life changed to craving the phenomena of the universe. Ever since that day, I have been deeply interested in learning what we do not see everyday.

Both of my parents were electrical engineers and highly encouraged me to focus on math and science in school, so in high school I took upper level math and sciences. When I took physics in high school my brother was graduating with a physics major at the same time so it really encouraged me to try hard in that class. I ended up really loving it so I thought I would like to continue in college. I had no idea what I wanted to major in while starting college, but the physics department really stood out so I gave it a shot and ended up loving it. While at Drake I have take many classes, attend countless seminars, done great research, and taken highly challenging and rewarding classes, and they all have really confirmed my ideas about majoring in physics and showed me that this is what I really want to do in the future.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic (Social), Event Triggered

Response: I was bored in 10th grade, and so I took physics. I loved it and just took more and more physics and didn`t want to study anything else. I`m not exactly sure why.

I STARTED LEARNING PHYSICS IN HIGH SCHOOL. iT WAS COMPULSORY AT FIRST,BUT I REALIZED I LOVED THE SCIENCES SO I CONTINUED TO STUDY IT. MY HIGHPROFESSORS WERE VERY DETAILED WITH THE WAY THEY EXPLAINED THE PHYSICSCONCEPTS TO ME AND MADE ME REALIZE I COULD DO PHYSICS IF I PUT MY MINDTO IT. IN COLLEGE, I DECLARED MYSELF AS A CHEMISTRY MAJOR AND WAS THINKING OF TAKING PHYSICS AS A SECOND MAJOR BECAUSE I REALIZED I DO LOVE PHYSICS NATURALLY.

I`ve always been interested in astronomy as a kid and coming into college I was going to be a astrophysics major but didn`t think I would enjoy the theoretical as much as the practical applications of physics. So instead,I went into Mechanical Engineering with an astronomy minor.I has been my dream for a long time to work with NASA, and it`s still something I strive for today. Ideally I want to go to graduate school for astronautical engineering and then work in space exploration.

I have always really enjoyed my physics courses. One of the coolest things is when you are feeling helpless in an exam and then are able to logically solve a problem simply based one one`s knowledge of the world around them. I have always had great experience with past physics professors both in high school and college. One of the things that really made me want to study physics is when we had taken stuff so as spin states for granted in earlier classed and then were able to mathematically explain why we had always learned what we did earlier.

I have always been interested in Astronomy for as long as I can remember. When I was young, I would ask plenty of books for Christmas or birthdays that only discussed about astronomy concepts. It wasn`t until I started college that I wanted to pursue a career as an astrophysicist seriously and immediately majored in physics. However, I had a long way to go before I could even begin my upper division courses. So I did what I could at the time, I would attend and participate at the Utah Valley University Physics club, this is where I met a friend of my sisters back when they were classmates in elementary school. She also so happens to want to become an astrophysicist as well! She was the first person to invite me to the CUWIP conference in Texas. That event truly opened my eyes and realized how fun and easy it was to meet  and converse with researchers from faraway places! Later in my second year that I decided to apply for a job as a planetarium presenter that my friend also worked at in my college. This is where I met the first astronomy professors that would support me in becoming a better astrophysicist. I even ended working for them as a research assistant as of right now!
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I came to college as a chemistry major. I had never thought of taking physics as my major before my physics professor said that I had talent in physics. At first, I did not quite believe what he said because there were too many Chinese students who were better at physicsthan me when I was in high school. I just did not have enough confidence in myself. Later, my professor encouraged me to have a try, and he said that I would figure out what I really want. I followed his advice.Actually right now I have a lot of fun studying physics.This semester, I am taking modern physics and statisticalphysics. I have gained lots of interesting experiences which I never expected before. Then I realize my professor was totally right. Lacking of confidence almostdeprived me of some important opportunities in my life. Now I am a chemical physics major which is a special interdisciplinary major involving both physics andchemistry. I really enjoy what I am doing now. I dobelieve physics will bring much fun to my life in the future.
I found that physics was my most challenging course in high school but that is why I enjoyed it so much! I was very fortunate to combine my degree with the other field I love which is engineering.

When I was gifted linguistically as a child and wanted to be a novelist. When I was in middle school, I was working on a story with hard magic and started researching particle physics to help make the magic in my story more realistic. I ended up getting more excited about learning quantum mechanics than actually writing the sorry, because it was like magic in real life. When I was in highschool, i became part of the Underwater Robotics team. Lots of people encouraged me to be an engineer. That was the first time I realized a STEM job might be interesting or available to me. I decided I was more interested in learning physics than engineering or writing. I decided I wanted to be a theoretical physicist and do research. (this received from doubts from my classmates and I suspect my teachers.) A lot has happened for me between highschool and university. I took a leave of 3 years and taught preschool and became a mental health coach. I also experienced much spiritual growth. What currently drives me to get the degree is a curiosity about how mathematics can be used to describe natural reality and what that implies philosophically. i also want to be able to communicate with those who have scientific mindsets and to develop my critical thinking skills. When I was in high school, my drive to study physics came from fear and ego. Now my drive comes from a desire to develop my natural abilities to their fullest potential so that I can serve the world the way I feel I am intended to do.
I really liked how difficult the concepts are, but how applicable they are once I understood them. As I have gone further, I just really like how interesting learning new things are.

I wanted to go into medicine, but a physics professor at my school showed me that in college it matters how you learn to think moreso than what you have learned. In this regard, there is nothing better than physics and I have stuck with it to learn problem solving skills rather than memorization.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: In high school, my best friend`s parents were both engineers. She and I always had a friendly competition for grades and especially in physics. I initially thought I wanted to be an engineer like she wanted to be and her parents were. I knew that I liked math and science, but in order to understand biology, it was more complete to understand the chemistry, but to understand chemistry it was more complete to understand the physics, which was the application of math that I really liked. So my friend Kristin was accepted to Princeton for engineering and I was accepted to Boston College, which doesn`t have an engineering program, so I chose to become a physics major because it was my best choice at the school.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value

Response: Both my parents are physicists, so I grew up very exposed to physics. When I was younger, I never thought I wanted to be a physics major, because I wanted to be different from my parents. However, after taking high school science, I realized physics appealed the most to me, and I liked the variety of careers open to physics majors. Since getting to college, physics has been my favorite (although hardest) course by far, and I always find myself interested in physics things beyond class.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: Started out as engineering because of suggestions by teachers and peers. Liked physics better because it is more fundamental.
discussing different topics with my high school science teachers, watching youtube videos and lectures

Before I changed my major in Applied Physics Analysis, I was a pre-med students. Due to the the medical school application has the requirement to take general physics. After I took physics course, I would like to spend more hours to work on it and I found physics is more interesting for me. Then, I researched with Dr. Soto and got a opportunity to present with a poster for undergraduate students. I never had so much passion before. I had a kind of feeling of success when someone is more interested in physics after my presentation.
I wanted more math in my classes but I didn`t have a math degree and didn`t know what engineering was, but now I`m leaning more towards engineering than physics.

My first physics course in Electromagnetism sparked my interest in the thinking processes involved in solving physics problems. I also loved how I can use concepts from courses and apply them to physics research.

For my entire life, I`ve loved math. It comes naturally to me and I just enjoy the feeling of solving problems. I love the patterns with numbers and how logical and beautiful math is. Since sixth grade, I knew I would major in mathematics. I took regular physics my junior year of high school and AP Physics 1 my senior year of high school. They were both decent classes, and I enjoyed the material we were learning in class, but what I was really interested in was the craziness of quantum mechanics and general relativity. Throughout those two years, I watched numerous videos on YouTube and did my own research. I found these topics super interesting. I enjoyed thinking about all of the mysteries about our universe and loved the connection to math. While my high school classes were cool, I wanted to take physics in college so I could learn more about the current questions in physics. I thought about majoring in math and minoring in physics. When I got to Hamilton College, I took an introductory physics course and was blown away by the amazing physics department. We really have an awesome community here, and I think this welcoming, collaborative, supportive atmosphere of our department really pulled me in and influenced my decisions to continue with physics. I am now double majoring in physics and math and am loving my classes. I really do think Hamilton`s physics department is special, and I feel like I`ve found my place. The course material is super interesting, and I enjoy both the applications of math and the philosophical conjectures about our universe that stem from physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Media Triggered, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: Freshman year of high school I had physical science. When I got to the chapter on physics and learned why we can observe rainbows, I was amazed. I never wanted to quit learning why the world works the way it does and within a week I had decided to major in physics. I chose to add an area of emphasis on applied physics when I was applying to college as I felt it would provide more job options than pure physics might.

I had never taken a physics class until college. I was planning on studying biochemical engineering and then going to law school. At the end of my first quarter of physics, I had to choose whether to take a physics class or a chemistry class and I chose physics. I had no idea what I wanted to do with it, but I knew I wanted to take it. Not taking chemistry meant that I wouldnÕt be able to complete the major IÕd intended so I thought IÕd do engineering. It wasnÕt until the middle of my third quarter of physics that I decided to become a physics major. Now there is nothing else I could imagine doing. I like the way I view the world after taking each new physics class. I like a challenge and nothing else has ever presented as much of one.

I took a course in middle school on nanotechnology, and I became interested in the fundamental nature of things. After going to a few physics camps and taking physics in high school, I kept enjoying learning more about how things work. I have really enjoyed my research experiences in college so far and would like to pursue physics research.

I had a great high school physics teacher, and a really good into physics professorwho made me decide to not just take a few intro courses but actually be a physics major.I have always been encouraged so it always seemed like a possibility, I just had to chooseto take advantage.

When I was in high school, I found myself really enjoying learning physics. After taking intro-level physics courses in college, I realized that I do not want to stop there, and I want to know more in physics.

I started out wanting to persue a career in medicine but decided that the many years of schooling weren`t quite worth that much effort. I have always been interested in physics so it was the natural path for me to follow at that point. However, after my experiences in physics I have decided I would much rather pursue a career in software development. Job security, income, and the ability to choose where I live rather than have my job dictate where I can live are well worth that exchange. I have also found that individuals in physics do not seem to have the same collaborative energy as computer scientists and I would like to live to see the effect my life`s work has.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Cost (Emotional)

Response: I have always wanted to major within math and science, but it took a few years to settle on physics specifically. I began with the desire to major in computer science. Over time, I leaned more toward engineering, but the engineering program at my university is a 3-2 program, where you transfer after 3 years. I did not want to leave without getting a full 4-year experience, so I chose a physics major since it was a 4-year program and was the most similar to engineering.

I first decided to major in something related to physics in high school, when my physics teacher began talking about the effects of special relativity and it really grabbed my attention. This made sense as I had always liked math, solving puzzles and analytical thinking.
