When applying to university, I initially enrolled in the engineering program at my school but realized almost immediately that it wasn`t for me, since I wanted to work in academia and had no interest in industry or in engineering/design work, so I decided ultimately to go for theoretical physics.
I took a physics course in high school that really sparked my interest in physics. Since then I have just fallen in love with all aspects of physics and engineering, especially electrical.

When I first learned about string theory, I knew that this stuff was far too interesting not to study. I honk I was in 10th grade when I decided I wanted to do Physics and I have learned so much mostly from personal physics books and of course from school too.

The main factor that influenced me to become a physics major is Astronomy. I have always been curious about how things worked, especially things relating the universe. As I grew older I became to read about science and physics and did well and enjoyed Physics at in High School. I was in Avid a program to help guide students to college and my advisor helped me analyze the many career options and Physics was what I felt that best work for me.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered, Social Persuasion

Response: My brother was a very big influence. He pursued physics out of his own volition. At the time he began, I hated physics. It turns out, I only hated it because my teacher hated me. In her own words (directly to my parents, who had me as an 8th grade boy), "I really don`t like 8th grade boys. I like to make things harder for them." This negativity from the teacher was projected onto the subject. Luckily, I had a brother to show me what really is interesting about physics. I tried out the basic course in my junior year in high school. I loved it, and needed more. I hopped in AP physics the next year, and my need to continue in this field was solidified.(I already finished this survey once before, but the email I just received shows that it is not complete. Sorry if you have to read this twice.)
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Emotional)

Response: My journey to becoming a physics major is actually quite unique. I never knew what the subject of physics entailed until my senior year in high school, and consequently up to that point, I had never considered choosing physics as my major in college. I have, however, always known that I wanted to teach and help to reconstruct the field of education. Specifically, my goal was to start schools in inner-city areas with a holistic approach to education. During my senior year, as I was talking with my guidance counselor, I was able to share this dream with her. From our discussion, she helped me to realize how much more effective I could be in the realm of education, if I had a degree in another field. In my case, that field was science, because I have always had a love and affinity for science. It was also in my senior year of high school that I first took a physics class, and I loved it! I loved the fact that I could begin to understand the fundamental dynamics of the everyday events I experienced. I also enjoyed how much physics caused me to think deeply and conceptually about all of these events. So, it was in my senior year of high school that I decided that I wanted to study physics in college. My dream to open schools in inner-city areas hasn`t suffered because of this choice; in fact, it has only caused the scope of my dream to broaden and deepen. Now, I am working towards opening up science and technology schools in inner-city areas. I hope to use my knowledge of physics to write curriculum and to introduce teaching methods that will take the sense of intimidation away from the field of science, and of course from the subject of physics.
Codes: Utility Value, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: I`m actually an applied math major w/an emphasis in physics. I have completed a minor in astronomy. I have made a Nobel prize worthy discovery on Exoplanets. I`m there to learn, and network to publish my work when ready. The male faculty in the math dept. At my school are not very supportive. I will get it published and dedicate my work to future generations of female astrophysics. I will do my post grad in astrophysics.
Codes: Event Triggered, Mastery Experience, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Utility Value

Response: If I had decided to major in what I was best at, I`d probably be a math major right now.  I chose physics because it simply seemed more interesting; physics homework was always the first homework I`d work on, and procrastinate on other work to finish my physics homework.  The faculty seemed welcoming and also overall the department that had the highest ratio of recommended professors.  I wanted to learn more about how the universe worked, and I believed that physics would open up the most paths to achieve that.

I started really developing an interest in science in 8th grade, when I wrote a (very bad) report about wormholes. In my high school biology and chemistry courses, I became more and more hopeful that I would like physics (since I didn`t love bio or chem, but I still liked science in general). In 11th grade, I had a phenomenal physics teacher. I am still on the fence between pursuing physics or aerospace engineering, but my experiences in the Georgia Tech physics dept are pushing me more towards physics, at least for my undergrad degree.
Codes: Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Intrinsic (Social)

Response: As a child, I always had a fascination with space. So, I believe I was always intended to wind up in astronomy (specifically, astrophysics). I only seriously began considering it around the time I finished my psychology degree (last year), as I was having a discussion with a friend about following our dreams and having faith in ourselves (instead of living a life of misery in a "tolerated" field). I realized that I was so melancholy because I wasn`t following my dream, because I had never believed I was "smart enough" to pursue physics, and a large part of it was lack of self-confidence stemming from the attitudes of male students growing up. I decided to give myself a chance, and I became determined to prove myself (and countless others) wrong - that no one is "geared" towards anything. You simply try, and try, and try until you get what you want out of life. And so, that`s why I`m here: because astrophysics is my dream.

The major event that led me to becoming a physics major is my love for the stars and the phenomena of the world around me.I have always been infatuated by various scientific fields, but it wasn`t until I started to learn about physics on my own and then in class that my passion for physics developed. My greatest influences were scientific programs on TVlike NOVA on PBS and The Universe on The History Channel that from an early age piqued my curiosity in the sciences.
I watched a t.v show where one of the main characters is a female astrophysicists. from there I studied the topic nonstop. watched documentaries, read books, and did online research.

My mentor, Dr. Diola Bagayoko, is the major reason why I am interested in physics. He explained to me how physics is the base of all sciences. This intrigued my interest. It was at the 2014 CUWiP that I was introduced to the field of medical physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Medical), Event Triggered

Response: Some of my high school teachers supported my decision on majoring in physics, and those were the people who directed me in the right path at the beginning. Throughout my college years, some of my professors guided me on how to become better at physics and how to get involved more on campus. I started working on the Orientation Team, where I met so many incoming students who are also majoring in physics as well. Meanwhile, I started to tutor physics 1 for engineers, and this opportunity has allowed me to become better at solving problems in physics, and thinking about the different ways to approach to physics concepts and problems. Guiding other students with physics also enabled me to become better at teaching, and understanding the needs of others.

My parents encouraged me to think independently andpursue my goals in life. My father is an engineer and mymother is very good at explaining difficult concepts. Mymom assisted me in learning the basics and encouraged meto follow my interests. While my dad would discuss hiswork and brainstorm ideas with me. Between the two ofthem I learned to love the complexity of solving problems.I have also been a competitive gymnast for most of mylife. Gymnastics enabled me to understand physics conceptsfirst hand and it is the main reason I am pursuing thisdegree. My coach would not only teach me new skills butexplain why these skills were even possible. When I wasyounger his way of teaching was confusing, but as I grewup I appreciated it because it gave me perspective Icouldn`t attain in a classroom. My parents and coachtreated me as an equal while teaching me many things.Their influence in my early education led me to choose achallenging field with real world applications.Regardless, trying to decide which field to go into wasvery difficult. My top choices were architecture andengineering. I eventually decided to pursue an engineeringcareer, but I couldn`t afford the colleges that had bothgymnastics and engineering. I also was unsure which fieldof engineering most interested me. Since all engineeringfields require a good physics background I decided topursue a physics degree instead. This route has been verychallenging, but also very beneficial. Physics was thecorrect choice for me because it is challenging,interesting, and prepares me for a wide variety ofopportunities.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I was really unhappy with the general education curriculum classes I had been taking and I wanted to take a class I knew I would enjoy, so I signed up for an algebra based physics class at Oakland Community College (OCC). My professor was incredibly passionate about teaching physics, and had this way of making hard concepts less intimidating. I ended up taking him for two more semesters of physics after that, and then transferred to LTU for biomedical engineering the year after. I became his supplemental instructor the year I transferred, and ran tutoring sessions with the students. My first semester at LTU I was more unhappy than I`d been in a long time, and figured it was just because I transferred to a new school and didn`t know anybody. My advisor for my physics minor suggested I get involved in our SPS chapter, so I started attending meetings and getting involved in the physics department at LTU. My second semester, I realized I was unhappy at LTU because I didn`t like BME and considered switching to mechanical engineering in order to take more physics classes. I discussed this with my professor at OCC and he said it sounded like what I wanted was to change to physics. I hadn`t considered this as a real option before, but after talking more about it, realized he was right. I switched my major, but didn`t start my physics curriculum until my third semester at LTU. That semester was the most intellectually challenging semester I`d had up until that point, but I was the happiest and most content with where I had been in a very long time. Ultimately, I think the physics communities at OCC and LTU helped me realize my passion lies in physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social), Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience

Response: I want to become a meteorologist and decided to pick up physics as a backup major.

My dad is an engineer and has always taken a special interest in encouraging me to go into a STEM field, because as a child I had shown a lot of interest in my math and science classes. Growing up, my dad and I have read a lot of physics books on car rides or on Saturday mornings, and my dad started telling me he thought I would be good at physics since it was something that was important to me. I told him physics was boring and that I had no interest in physics. I wanted to be an engineer, too, until my junior year of high school. In high school I had a fantastic physics teacher who changed my perception of what physics is-- it was no longer a boring study of balls rolling down hills (though we did plenty of that in his class!) but a dynamic learning experience that encompassed everything from the motion of water to the orbit of planets. Physics became bigger, and, consequently, more interesting to me.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value

Response: The majority of it had to do with my dad being an engineer and me always having a strong interest in what he was doing. Additionally, my high school physics teacher was very good and passionate about the subject which caused me to gain more interest.

I always did really well in my math courses growing up and enjoyed it, but once I took calculus in high school I decided that math was boring and there was no application to it. I could not get a degree in that field. I did enjoy my science classes though and once I got to AP physics my senior year of high school, I enjoyed the application of the calculus into the science of physics. Also, I am intrigued by how the world works and physics explains it pretty well. WIth that, I decided to pursue physics as a major. After two years in college, I am still a physics student and am enjoying everything about it! I have also gotten the chance to participate in undergraduate research at my university and through that have decided to pursue graduate school either in physics or biophysics, which is the field of study my research is in.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered

Response: I thought I wanted to be an engineer, but I hated the classes so much, so I researched careers, and stumbled across geophysics.  I read that students that are physics students succeed better than those that are just environmental science majors, so I decided to major in both.

I came into college thinking that I would be either a math or a physics major, and I like my introductory physics courses a lot and I think the physics department at my university is a lot better than the math department in terms of teaching, so I decided to become a physics major.

Well I decided during seventh grade that I wanted to build myself a spaceship and that my final journey, when I grew old, would be to board it and sail forever essentially - since I didn`t plan on returning I could get to places too far away for a two way trip. And I needed physics for that. I thought space was interesting, particularly as Earth made up a very small amount of the total universe. I thought it would be boring to stay here all my life. Before that, I knew I would be a scientist, so I could be able to find things out from myself instead of only reading about them and depending on the findings of others. With this in mind I decided as a child to be a scientist. Since I was attracted to the notion of studying animals in the jungle, and, later, watching the Teaching Company Great Courses lectures by Dr. Sapolsky on human behavioural biology, I thought of studying animal behaviour or neurobiology. But since Biology felt incomplete - it wouldn`t give you an understanding of the fundamentals of matter - I kept physics. To think about not studying physics feels like committing to a life of ignorance, even though I;m currently in a phase where I feel I have no real love of the subject, only a love for the idea of the subject, and for some of the things it can do for you. That begin said, I have only a fuzzy idea what the life of a researcher is like. It feels boring, in the fact that they seem mostly sedentary beasts, but interesting in that they are on a noble quest, and a hard one at that. Influences have included: my parents, who have always plied us with educational material and who homeschooled me for the first 11 years of my life, Carl Sagan and his captivating voice and dreams of other worlds -he spoke especially to the explorer in me; Neil DeGrasse Tyson; my best friend in High school now studying physics at Georgetown. I am very much a product of attempts to inspire popular interest in science. At current I am a physics major because I hope to develop a means of transportation sufficient to hop between galaxies, a la Star Trek, and because I want some engineering know how as well. The obstacles include my not begin overly fond of the work we`re doing in class now on mechanics, and being dubious about how much I`ll like further work. I am considering strongly a career as an Astronaut, and a doctorate in physics would help meet entry requirements.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Vicarious Experience, Utility Value

Response: I have wanted to obtain my Ph.D in physics since I was 11 years old. Before that, I knew I wanted to be a scientist, but I didn`t know what kind. At 11, though, I was browsing through my local bookstore and I found an introductory physics book. I started leafing through it and it explained spectral lines from the sun. I was hooked instantly. Though my interests in physics have changed a few times throughout the years and I still haven`t narrowed down which exact field I want my doctorate in, one thing has never changed: my love of physics.

Entering high school, Physics was the only science that truly appealed to me.It explained the world around me, and the space in the night sky.I didn`t excel at it at first, but my interest in the subject kept me going.My college Professor was highly supportive of his students and pushed them to succeed.This drove me to take on projects outside of class, and enjoy Physics more.I began with an interest in receiving a degree in an astronomy related field.The more physics I delved into, the more I wanted to gear my future towards that instead. Currently, I plan to major in Astrophysics, with the hope of being a teacher, so I can inspire others.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Utility Value

Response: I enjoyed my intro physics classes because they was graded on understanding the concept rather than memorization. Having physics demonstrations in class made intro physics interesting. I decided that I wanted to go into physics when I heard about the biophysics major at my college. It combined my two interests: the human body and physics. It is a physics major, but with extra classes in biology and chemistry. I also liked how the professors and teaching assistants are always willing to help and give a really good answers to my questions. I enjoy the conceptual aspect to it, and its applications to the real world. Also, I had a female professor in the second year of physics and that was nice because in a way convinced me to continue in the physics major. By participating in different networking events and conferences, I learned that biophysicist can work in a verity of areas, and I liked that.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value (Biophysics), Intrinsic (Social), Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered

Response: The thing that most led me to pursue a physics degree was that I have always had a love and a large understanding of mathematics especially in higher level courses. This love of math led me to understand that the application and use of mathematics in physics was exactly the kind of challenge, passion, and understanding I craved in my education. I have also always enjoyed the way that physics can convert simple topics into ideas that have literally changed the way society runs.
Participating in astronomy research in high school, doing problem sets with a group of close friends in college

I have always have curiosity of things around my world but never really got the chance of proving myself. I have always wanted to learn new things, I believe that physics is a field which is so much full of life. Everything, every concepts make sense in physics. As i discovered so many interesting things in my Modern Physics course, I have been wanting to know more about them. Hydrogen atom, the smallest charge has so many complicated things in it, I wonder how interesting could other things be. Physics is the path that always inspires me to quench my thirst of curiosity.

I am stilling just a novice in this opportunity. I have always had a passion for learning, an overly curious mind, and a love for the stars and whats beyond earth. when I discovered my enjoyment could be a career and it is called Astrophysics I was blown away. my desire grew stronger and my ambition enrolled me into school again.  I am still learning what this world of physic entails and how many opportunities there are but my mind is open to it all. there is no limit on this thing we call learning.

I grew up very interested in vehicles due to my older brother. I was fascinated with how they worked and wanted to know more. I also made little gadgets, again with my brother, that had me constantly wondering about the ways of everything in the world. I really didn`t know I wanted to pursue a degree in Physics until I realized how in awe I was of Astronomy. From there, I knew that no matter which career path I choose it will always revert back to Physics.

I initially decided I would major in physics after a teacher had told me I could never do it. Naively I thought this was an okay deciding factor in physics, but unfortunately I have spent a good portion of time on the major and I do not know of anything else I would be interested in pursuing as a career.

I have always been good at math and enjoyed science. My grandfather is a nuclear physics and gave me mini physics lessons when I was a kid, so I decided in high school that physics was the best application of my skills and interests. I love space, and I want to study astrophysics.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: I first considered physics as an option in high school. I did well and my teacher identified me as someone who would be good in this field. Since then, it has been hard to feel like I am truly a part of the community.

My interest in Physics began in high school, when I took my first Physics class. I was very intrigued by the labs and experiments. When I entered college, I majored in Mechanical Engineering. After a couple of years in school, I took a summer internship. The internship was with the Illinois Department of Transportation, working with Civil Engineers on bridge and roadway construction projects as an inspector. I loved the internship, and was offered a full-time job. I took the position, and worked for 10 years. I loved my duties, but could not perform them any longer. I returned to school to find a new career, that was close to what I appreciated in my engineering career. Physics was the obvious choice for me. After, years of tutoring, working as a TA, or LA, I decided to go into teaching (Physics/ secondary education). I`ve enjoyed several internships, and research opportunities, that have allowed me to experience different aspects of Physics. Eventually, I`d like to teach at the university level, or work in a museum/ planetarium or research facility.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: I`ve been interested in physics since I was young because I was always fascinated by space and loved the idea of being able to prove what is true of our universe through scientific experimentation. When I was in high school I took two years of physics which furthered my interest in the subject, leading me to become an astrophysics major in college.

I`ve always liked math and science and when I came to Pomona, I figured I should take an intro-major physics course since I wanted to keep the option of majoring open (I had just come from my second year of physics in high school and liked that quite a bit, as my prof was wonderful). I really liked the class so I kept taking physics classes, and for a while I wavered between physics and math but I`m happily settled on an astrophysics major right now.

I have always been interested to learn about how things work around us, which has drawn me towards science. I gravitated towards physics more after reading general science books and watching physics talk shows as a 12 year old. Physics answers the most fundamental questions about the universe, which I would consider spending my life working on. I always enjoyed studying physics and had a knack for it. Being comfortable, and hopefully good, with mathematics also made it easier to deal with physics. Being part of science clubs, attending various science events and always being surrounded by `physicsy` things made physics an essential part of my life. In college, I love the physics department and the wonderful resources we have. My faculty mentor has also been very helpful. I`m looking forward to advance further in learning physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I grew up with my grandfather who was an electronic engineer and amateur astronomer. growing up he inspired me and taught me about science. In school, it was the only thing that I truly loved and when I finally took my first physics class in high school I instantly fell in love and that is how I decided on a physics major. going through school loving science and not being able to develop that early I believe is detrimental especially at a young age especially when a gender gap is not something truly perceivable by the young students. As a woman who has found love in physics because of the science filled environment, I grew up in, I believe that we need to push for more science curriculum in elementary schools to promote more woman in STEM.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: It began in High School, ironically, when I was researching for my Chemistry Extended Essay. The library I was in is very small, so instead of finding anything useful I found pop science books on Physics, in this case a Brief History of Time by Stephen Hawking. I was enamoured, and while I didn`t have a chance to take Physics formally in High School due to the program I was in, I took it online and continued my studies into college as a Physics/Astronomy Major.

Through most of high school, I didn`t really consider a career in physics even though I took advanced math/science courses and found the topics interesting. At my parents` encouragement I took Physics II and Calculus II my first semester in college and decided (far more quickly than I expected) that I wanted to major in physics. I realized how much I enjoyed the challenge of physics and wanted to continue to study it.

I have always been interested in science. I wanted to learn how the world worked. When I began high school, I started watching the Weather Channel on television and that sparked my interest in weather. Then I took physics in high school and that confirmed to me that I wanted to get a career towards climate science.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Meteorology), Utility Value

Response: I chose physics as a major because I liked science and math ever since I was little and I wanted to be a scientist. Physics is a fundamental subject and I thought if I studied physics, I would be able to explain everything around me. I was also inspired by the broad applicability of physics in other sciences like biology and chemistry.

I was always interested in STEM fields, and when I applied to colleges, I was very interested in the Center for Relativistic Astrophysics. Since I wanted to take classes from those professors, I chose to be apply as a physics major at GT despite applying for engineering programs at other colleges. I am now finishing my degree as a physics major at GT.
my curiosity

I first started considering physics as an option for me around middle school because my parents got me a telescope. From there I was hooked on astronomy. After that I took an interest in every STEM related subject that I could get my hands on. I learned 3d modeling, physics, chemistry, rocketry, and astronomy all throughout high school. My parents then encouraged me to become a physics major in college, and I chose DU partially because it has a program for physics and astronomy. I also never felt much pressure to go into a different field other than physics for most of my life. The only time that I felt dissuaded from this career field was during and after my social gender transition. I have faced discouragement especially from my father over going into this field.

Going to the society of physics students get-togethers every friday afternoon, as well as really getting to know the other girls in the department at my school where occasionally we would have movie or dinner night together.

I have always loved learning anything I can get my hands on, so I knew for some time that science was important to me. I realized that what I wanted to learn was the laws of the universe and use those laws to build technology. Maybe if I am lucky, one day expand on our understanding of those laws. The best way to do this is to learn as much physics as I can, so I am pursuing a PhD in it.

My first encounter with physics was in college. It was a prerequisite and I loved the class, it was a class where the students taught eachother.I then began to see physics in everyday life from the movement of a wrench to leaning against a wall. After my first year I began to participate in our school`s physics club becoming an active member. I then worked my way into an officers position where I coordinated outreach.After the year was up I decided to run for president, and I won. From this year on I have dedicated myself to teaching theyoung minds of the Salinas Valley physics and how fun it can be.This semester alone our club has reached over 700 students.

I took AP Physics my senior year of high school. By this time, I knew that I was going to major on something in the sciences, but was unsure of what. We did an experiment involving springs that really pushed me into physics. We had to determine the amount of mass to add to a Buzzlightyear toy so that when he was attached to a spring and dropped from the top of the bleachers he would just tap the ground. We worked together as a class, and when we tested our calculated additional mass, it worked! That experience of collaboration and experimentation brought me into college knowing that I was going to major in physics.
I decided to be a physics major as a high school junior taking physics for the first time. I have not seriously considered anything else since then.

I started to become interested in Physics in my senior year of high school. I was always interested in both math and science, and physics seemed like a good combination of the two. However, I wasn`t sure whether or not Physics was for me until I actually took a Physics course my senior year. I enjoyed the class and found the concepts to be ones that I could apply in everyday life, regardless of whether or not I ended up pursuing a Physics major. This made me realize that Physics was the right field for me.

For most of my life, I thought I was going to study music and become a musician. However, in high school I took a physics class and was so interested in all the sections of physics. It was so fascinating to me that the world could be explained in such a way and that we could explore space and the unknown with these ideas. Physics ability to take me from my place in a classroom to space caused me to consider physics as a major option.

I chose physics as a major for several reasons. I loved the collaborative atmosphere in the Duke Physics Dept and appreciated the support from all of the professors and staff. In general, I enjoy that the study of physics yields deeper insight into the mechanical workings of the world. I feel that the types of thinking physics encourages have really helped me with success in other disciplines. I have thoroughly enjoyed the research I have so far participated in. It is also a great challenge for me that I have found to be incredibly rewarding. Additionally, another large appeal of physics is that it is a versatile major with a wide range of applications. I very much appreciate that it can translate into any future. And it is just really really cool, for lack of better words.
Codes: Intrinsic (Social), Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Physiological/Emotional, Utility Value

Response: A lot of my friends went to college as physics majors and they would talk to me about what they were doing in class and with research and it sounded very interesting. Then I participated in a Pre-College Experience in Physics camp at the University of Rochester, and also took physics in high school. The teachers and professors I met really inspired me and made me love physics and see how many different opportunities physics presented.
Codes: Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: When I came to college I was planning on being a politics major. After one semester I knew that I was better suited for math than I was social science. I felt more engaged and interested in my calculus class than I did my international politics class. In my second semester I took an intro physics course and excelled. I found that everything I had enjoyed about calculus (being able to quantitativly describe systems) is a major part of physics, even more so than higher math. I saw no major barriers standing between me and a physics major, so I ended up declaring my major in physics the following semester.

My father`s degree was in physics, so as a very small child I thought that physics must be interesting and exciting. However, it was not until the end of high school that I realized I enjoyed it; and I did not consider a degree in physics until last year, when I was almost finished with my bachelor`s degree in mathematics. I realized that, when given a choice, I would always choose physics electives over other science electives, and that I really enjoyed my physics classes. When I learned that I could fit in a double-major, I realized that I would really like to do so.

I was in my first intro class and I was doing very well in the class as well as enjoying the material. It was then that I started considering what I would do if I changed my major to Physics. The next semester I took an intro to nuclear science course which is where I fell in love with Medical Physics. It was then that I decided that my career was going to be in Medical Physics.
I enjoyed physics in high school and so decided to pursue it in college. After my first research project, I knew that I wanted to continue pursuing a career studying physics and astronomy.

I excelled in science and math, and thought I would be a good doctor one day. My mother was a nurse, so I figured I would be a doctor. I majored in chemistry when I started college. I soon discovered the portion of chemistry I liked was physics, which I took intro physics for my chemistry major. After taking organic chemistry and biology, I realized medicine was not for me, and I went with the physics route, as I loved my physics classes.

At five years old, I did not have a clear comprehension of life, the Earth and how the physical universe operated, but that never stopped me from trying to understand. I was always breaking objects like windows in my living room because I was curious about how pushing or pulling on an object made it break apart from its original form. ÒI mean, should it not stay the same?Ó, I wondered as a five year old.  Later in my life, during tenth grade, I was introduced to physics, and the questions my five year old self had were finally answered. Of course, I had learned the concept of forces intuitively before tenth grade, but my first physics class had given me a new perspective on forces and other physics topics such as energy. I was captivated by physics and over the next few years I took a lot more physics courses. Unfortunately, I was met with backlash and harsh criticism. Not a lot of people were convinced that I liked physics or even that I was good at physics. Being a black, Nigerian American female in physics is a rarity, so I was met with skepticism about my skills and knowledge. Physics is a tricky subject, so when I failed at times, I would sometimes give into my insecurities and think I was not good enough. Despite the adversity, in twelfth grade I decided that I did not care what others thought of the subject I was passionate about; I wanted to be a physicist no matter what.

Since the age of four, I loved the night sky. Before bedtime, my mother would tuck me in and let me choose a story. Each night my choice was my constellation book, filled with glow-in-the-dark stars and Greek mythological stories of their origins. My mind pictured Orion the hunter chasing Scorpios, the Scorpion, across the evening sky, the graceful swan, Cygnus, flying across the Milky Way and even the Great Bear, Ursa Major, strolling happily into the horizon. Before high school, I considered astronomy as the ancient lore and the patterns in the dark sky. I decided to rekindle my earlier fascination with astronomy when I was a freshman, and applied to attend the Astronomy Camp conducted for a week each summer through the University of Arizona; that first week at star camp, I fell in love with the physics and beauty of astronomy. Every year since, I have conducted research at this camp on Kitt Peak National Observatory???s 90-inch telescope.

I have always been interested in space as a child, and my parents never tried to pull me away from the sciences. If anything, the encouraged it. They dealt with watching Cosmos and other space-related shows that others might find boring. I have always wanted to have a career in physics. In my Earth - Space Science course in high school, my teacher was always very supportive and helpful in getting me to wear I am today.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: Strong interest as a middle schooler. Parental Support.Encouragement from high school teachers.Valuable mentors in college.Constant interaction with other women who have established successful careers in physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: I loved Physics class in high school, and my parents are engineers so they encouraged me.

Since arriving at UCSB, IÕve had the fortune of doing materials research in Germany through the Materials Research Lab and statistics research through the Statistics and Applied Probability department, for which I received a department award last year. I also have had the opportunity to mentor 28 first year students through a mentorship program that serves predominantly underserved and underrepresented communities in STEM. In addition, I had the opportunity to go to the Netherlands for a modern physics colloquia event and currently work at a local defense company where I conduct experiments on infrared systems.Being a woman in STEM is not without its own challenges. I have had literally countless encounters with- letÕs just be honest- men, which have made me feel uncomfortable or unsafe. I have had to change class times to avoid certain people who have made unwanted and unsolicited advances to me. I had to complete partner assignments by myself in computer science because my lab partner physically molested me while we were working on a lab together. IÕve taken many precautions that I know my male colleagues donÕt typically have to consider. And despite this, IÕve done well in my classes and beyond. I still have a long way to go, but if you asked Madeleine the political science major, she would never have believed she could make it this far.Being in physics has been a truly humbling experience. Even though I donÕt want to continue with physics into grad school, I will truly appreciate all of what I learned and how far it has taken me educationally and emotionally. ItÕs funny, though, because the universe has a strange way of making things work out.
I am more interested in astronomy and, more specifically, astrobiology. With a biology background, I am interested to see how cosmic radiation can affect eukaryotic cell viability.

My interest with physics started with a show called The Universe. After watching it in high school I became obsessed with space and wanted to study astronomy. From here I started taking physics courses and fell in love with the curriculum.
Working in a neuroscience lab clearly showed to me the importance of physics. Having a female physics professor who is always nice and especially encouraging also helped.
Codes: Event Triggered, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: Physics snuck up on me! I planned on majoring in Flute Performance until I went on a vacation to the western United States the summer before my senior year of high school. I saw the sky without light pollution for the first time and fell in love. I knew that I wanted to study space, and Astrophysics became a means of doing that. I became engrossed in Physics after I started my courses in college and later added an Optical Physics concentration to my major. Now here I am!

The main influence on me has been that my mother is a physicist and she is a great role model for me in life. I grew up hearing about all kinds of fascinating experiments happening at Jefferson Lab and she also helped link me with people at the Hampton University Proton Therapy Center so that I could to a research project through them for my senior project. That project was a big influence on me in that it made me feel like physics was slightly more accessible to me and also showed me that I could combine two passions - physics and helping others. Medical physics is a big interest of mine now.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Medical), Event Triggered

Response: The first time I decided I was interested in Physics was in middle school, when I found out that astronomy (which I had decided I was extremely interested in when I was in second grade, after seeing Saturn through a telescope) involved math and physics. I wasn`t sure I could do it, but I decided to give it a try. Because math had never come easily to me, I needed a lot of support from my family, and especially my older brother, who tutored me in all my math classes through high school. During that time, I had a unique experience that greatly influenced me at the Lick Observatory on Mt. Hamilton in San Jose, CA. I had the opportunity to visit during the Venus Transit of 2012. The astronomers and faculty were beyond kind, and when one astronomer saw my enthusiasm, he invited me to see the telescopes they had there that were actually taking data and therefore weren`t open to the public, as well as introducing me to one of the head researchers there! This whole experience further cemented my desire to work in astronomy research.During my first semester at UVU, I took a conceptual physics class, as I had never actually take physics before, and loved it. This also helped me believe that I could actually achieve the goal I`d had since second grade, and was the beginning of my academic study of physics.Since then, I`ve been surrounded by an amazingly supportive physics community - both the students and the faculty have been so helpful and kind in their instruction, tutoring, and help in general. The tight knit physics community at UVU has certainly encouraged me to continue study.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Event Triggered, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: High school physics class, especially practical physics (trebuchet and boat-building projects/ competitions)Interest and classes in the Natural Sciences

For years I felt suffocated by the fallacy that I wasn???t smart or driven enough to be more than an unemployed high school dropout. I grew up living with an abusive father and I was convinced that the claims he made about the person I would become were true. Academically, it was evident that my home life was impacting my confidence in my abilities. When I was 16, I found the courage to get the police involved. My mom allowed me to move in with her until I graduated from high school. That is when the long healing process commenced, and in my senior year of high school, I realized that I had aspirations to become someone that I could be proud of. I enrolled in SUNY Brockport, majoring in chemistry and eventually physics. Since I had been forced to take math-alternatives in high school, I had to self-teach myself every math concept up until pre-calculus. I didn???t even know what a square root was when I enrolled in college. Despite my incredibly lacking math background, I not only pushed my way through two math intensive degrees and a math minor, I excelled. I had a difficult time in high school with math and science, so when I decided to pursue a degree in chemistry at Brockport, I knew that it wouldn???t be easy. I was too headstrong to let a little pre-calculus class get the best of me. With a bit of persistence, I started to excel in math. Before long I was double majoring in chemistry and physics with a minor in mathematics, achieving Dean???s List status and being awarded scholarships for my academic efforts.

I was good at physics in high school. Most of the people I know don`t really want to do this, but I don`t think I hate it. Then I chose physics, hoping it would give me some peace and fun when learning.

Doing well in my high school physics course encouraged me to pursue it further in college. The student and faculty physics community also really encouraged me to declare a physics major and to keep going with it.

My first experience that led to me pursuing physics, was my physics class in high school. I had wanted to be an artist, but had decided that that was a hobby, and was therefore uncertain about what direction by life was going to take. Upon taking physics in high school, I felt that I was beginning to get answers to so many of my questions about how and why things worked the way they did in the world. I`ve always been a curious person, and I truly felt that being a physicist would allow me to explore the world. I didn`t take physics again until community college, where I took two engineering physics courses. That helped to cement that I didn`t want to be an engineer but a physicist. From there, I transferred to Michigan Technological University, where I am now pursuing my Bachelor`s in physics. Afterwards, I am planning to pursue my Master`s in physics as well.

The largest event that pushed me to become a physics major was the encouragement and support I received from my intro physics professor and now adviser. She helped me realize the passion I had for physics, which was stemming from the fact that it consistently challenged me.

The first time I considered pursuing a degree in Physics was my junior year of high school. I found myself very interested in everything being taught in physics, more interested than I was in any other subject. I ended the year with, not only, the highest grade in the class, but one of the highest physics grades in the department. I went on to take Astronomy my senior year and, again, got the highest grade in the class. I would stay after class/school and continue labs and research beyond the curriculum`s expectations. Ever since, I knew that physics is what motivates me. I knew that I had to pursue it, because this is a topic that truly interests me and I want to spend the rest of my career doing something I love.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Utility Value

Response: My father is an astrophysicist, so I`ve grown up seeing how much he enjoys doing what he`s doing. Because of that, I started seeking for opportunities in physics such as doing research in high school and it made me more certain about my career path.

I always considered physics an option. I had to declare a major freshman year because of a scholarship, and I did not take physics freshman year, so I chose chemistry. In my sophomore year I took intro physics as well as Electronics, and I seriously looked into completing a physics major as well as chemistry, but I was unsure whether schedule conflicts would rule that out. This year, as a junior, I talked to the heads of both departments and learned that the classes I will need to take next year do not conflict, so I declared my physics major.

I hadn???t considered physics as an option until well into senior year of high school. When I was little, I wanted to be a test pilot for the Air Force, but found out they don???t take people with underlying health problems. I continued loving aerospace and space and science fiction of all kinds through the long slow slog of elementary school, but a love for physics didn???t kick off until high school. My physics teachers there were really great and encouraged the lone girl in their classroom to continue on with STEM as a major choice. I???m not great at math but I???m working on that, and my passion has carried me through so far. My primary major is astrophysics, and it was easy to double major in physics and astrophysics at my home university. why is this form so weird what`s happening with this textbox.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Social Persuasion

Response: I have always wanted to be a teacher. However, I did not know which subject I wanted to teach. I wanted to do something that allowed my students to feel free to think outside the box, while still having control. My high school Physics teacher showed me that that was what Physics was all about. Senior year of high school, I decided that I was going to be a Physics Major in order to teach Physics to the next generation.
Codes: Utility Value, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion

Response: Ever since 6th grade I have loved math, when I was a senior in high school I took a conceptual physics class and I loved it, but I went to college as a music major. A few years later I realized that I missed math and really loved the course I took in high school so I changed my major.

While I was growing up, I was always encouraged to pursue any subject, sport, or interest that I was into at the time. I gravitated towards science and more specifically physics because I was always interested in how and why things worked they way they did. I mostly made this choice by myself, although my parents (with backgrounds in biology and engineering) provided many opportunities to explore science and would take me to the planetarium whenever I wanted, which happened to be at least once a month. I attended a local space camp in middle school called Project Salute. This camp challenged me to design and build a way for our "astronauts (other students) to get on and off of our "shuttle" (an old school bus that we painted to look like a shuttle). This experience furthered my interest in physics and engineering. I then took an online course my junior year of high school called VASTS
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered

Response: An adviser suggested I do Biophysics when I was a sophomore. Physics is hard and fulfilling, I never looked back.
I loved astronomy, so I began in the physics-astronomy program. I considered switching, but different experiments in my physics classes made me decide to continue.
Attended a workshop for high school girls to consider engineering/orthopedics (The Perry Institute) which made me first consider engineering/physics

Most of the influence came from my high school honors physics class and my teacher. All through school, I loved math and science and when i finally took physics during my junior year, I knew that was what I wanted to continue to study in college. Another major influence was being around my dad and talking about physics since his degree is in engineering physics.
It was challenging, I liked it, and I was relatively good at it.  I also admired people in my senior, and I gained respect for the field.

I was a competitive gymnast growing up and I found the manipulation of bodily motion to be very beautiful. My coach always made a point to help my teammates and I understand the basic mechanics of whatever skill we were performing or technique we were implementing for improvement, etc. Thinking in those parameters always came very naturally and once I had formal exposure to physics in high school which gave me the tools to quantify the systems my coach had presented as well as those presently around me I was hooked.
I was convinced by the accepted students day held by my department.

I had really great science and math teachers in high school, who were very inspiring to me. I originally started out as a chemistry major, but I found that I enjoyed the more math-heavy physics classes more than the chemistry classes. At this point, I enjoy taking physics classes,but I`m not sure what I want to do career-wise after college.
I took an Astronomy course in community college and talked to my professor about my interest. He recommended that if I wanted to pursue Astronomy that majoring in Physics would be ideal. Here I am!

I originally wanted to focus on art in high school because that is what I was always best at. I adored all of my science classes and excelled in them but none of my family has been through college so the academic world seemed so overwhelming and thought I`d never make it through any of the schooling to become a scientist. I continued to be fascinated with learning new things about the universe. In my junior year of high school I took AP Chemistry and my teacher was this amazing, spunky woman who was incredibly passionate about science but didn`t act or look like all of the scientists I`d ever seen. The only students/faculty at my school that were interested in physics were the classically nerdy guys in physics. I very much did not fit into that group since i loved art, fashion, make-up and had a bubbly personality. My high school`s physics teacher hated me since he thought I didn`t belong in his physics classes. It wasn`t until I had my AP Chemistry teacher who mentored me and taught me that I can be whoever I want to be and still be successful in a scientific career. She taught me how I could dedicate my life to learning about the universe by studying physics despite the discrimination I`d face.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Cost (Emotional)

Response: I first saw it as an option through my father, who is a physicist and really supported my interest.  My high school physics teacher, who I had for both physics and AP physics, was amazing and really supported me and helped me gain confidence in my work.  My mentors at Mount Holyoke College have largely been women, which has also been very influential.

-In 9th grade, I took a freshman physics course which I enjoyed but did not initially consider because I wanted to be a profession french horn player. -That spring, I broke my jaw, and I needed to fill the time no longer spent in music ensembles. I asked my physics teacher for more physics, and he directed me to a junior class physics b study group. I studied, did well, and decided that I enjoy physics and the accepting and encouraging physics culture that exists in the Morristown High School science department-When you tell people you like physics, they tell you to be an electrical engineer-I took AP Physics C junior year and really enjoyed it, and I tutored people in freshman and ap physics throughout high school. -senior year, I applied to CWRU under electrical engineering. When I was accepted, I told my ap physics c teacher that I didn`t really want to do engineering. He suggested I pursue physics research-As soon as I got to CWRU, I started emailing professors asking for research, per the advice of my older sister.The research I have worked on has only solidified my resolve to pursue physics, and it has provided me with strong role models and mentors to help me along the way
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I had always loved math, and then I had a great physics teacher in high school, prompting me to explore physics during my undergrad. I have been fascinated with physics and math, and the varied applications of these fields, since coming to college. I enjoy the biophysics research that I do, and I find the physics related career opportunities available to me to be exciting and lucrative.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Biophysics), Utility Value

Response: I began competing in science fairs in 6th grade and completed my first astronomy project in 8th grade. After that, I decided I wanted to eventually pursue my PhD in astrophysics. I continued with astronomy science fair projects throughout high school, worked with a mentor at a local university, and then majored in physics for my undergraduate degree.
Codes: Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: As a young child I did not understand the world around me. I was unaware that the world was far wider and larger than the small area that lied between my house and small school in Mexico. My mind first began to expand when I moved from Mexico to California. In my new school I first noticed a globe on my teacher`s desk. It was round and depicted many colors that represented different continents and countries. That help me rialize that the our Earth was very large and has many different places that were unknown to me. But then comparing the globe to poster of our solar system our Earth now appeared very small. I grew curious about what lied out side our Earth, and began taking a great interest in astronomy. Then over the years as my knowledge of math expanded, my curiosity continued to grow with astronomy and physics. The physics of our universe helps us predict so many events that happen outside our Earth. Now that curiosity of prediction of stellar events feeds my drive to study astrophysics.

I have always had a deep wonder for the workings of the universe. I came back to school after exploring the world for some years out of high school. I originally wanted to teach math and ended up following my passion deeper into the mathematical world. Both math and physics are deeply philosophical and learning to navigate through their layered worlds is becoming a great joy in my life.

When I was in seventh grade, I read a fiction book whose plot had been heavily influenced by certain mystical precepts of quantum mechanics. While the author took muchliberty with the underlying science, the idea of superposition and its implications for Schr??dinger???sfamous cat caught my imagination. I scoured the internetfor information, devouring articles on quantum mechanics and Schr??dinger???s cat to the best of my ability. In art class I would get in trouble for doodlingSchrodinger???s equation rather than landscapes, marveling over the strange characters. It was the fanciful tales fromStar Trek that convinced me that physics was something I wanted to spend my life pursuing; the wonders of the universe seem best captured through the lens of physics. Too many Star Trek: The Next Generation episodes later Iwalked onto Hendrix Campus my first day, declared a physics major without ever having taken a physics course.Luckily physics turned out to be just as exciting and intriguing as I had imagined. It was in Modern physics when I was recreating the famous Millikan oil drop experiment in lab, that I realized with some equations and knowledge I could measure a fundamental constant of the universe. That moment captured all that I love about physics.

As a child I always wanted to be a weather woman. When I first entered college I entered as a Chemistry major but shortly I found my passion in Physics and wanting to fulfill my childhood dream of becoming a meteorologist.

I first was introduced to physics through a CTE engineering program in high school. While taking AP Physics, however, I realized that I enjoy pure science far more than engineering. I am currently pursuing my degree in Physics with a minor in Mathematics. I originally declared a double major in Mathematics, but upon taking more theoretical math classes, I realized that I can appreciate math for its applications, but I prefer applications of math and I am hoping to attend graduate school in physics.

I was led to consider physics as a major because of my general chemistry course and love of mathematics. I began learning about quarks. I learned that physics applied more to quarks than chemistry. My brother, a physics major, encouraged me to look more into physics as a major.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: I became interested in physics in high school, however, I switched into the major my freshman year after my interest in astronomy led me to pursue a degree in physics. I enjoyed the amount of math involved in both majors and it was Astronomy 100 taught at my university that really persuaded me to continue on that path.

I absolutely loved my AP Physics C course in High School. There were only seven people in the class - three of which were women - and I really felt valued and appreciated by my peers and professor. Part of the course was working on a project for the science fair about particle physics / cosmic ray detection, which got me excited about research in high school to. However, for some reason I thought that since I loved physics, I should go into Engineering. I entered college as an Engineering Major, but after taking Intro Physics II during the spring of my first year realized that physics is what I wanted to do, not engineering. I didn`t love any of the engineering courses I took; I found them tedious and unexciting. The actual physics - specifically the theoretical side of physics - is what I`m interested in. I`m now over halfway through the physics major and I love it! I`ve also worked on multiple research projects during undergrad which has been a huge factor in realizing that I want to pursue physics research post-grad. Most formatively, I worked at the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) Lab at Caltech this past summer conducting research on the gravitational waves emitted by black holes. This was an extremely net positive experience for me, and confirmed that I want to study theoretical astrophysics.
Codes: Intrinsic (Social), Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered

Response: My father is a physicist and always encouraged me to study physics. When I was a junior in highschool I took an astronomy course and I really loved it.

When I was living in Brazil (before coming to college), I participated in a ton of physics olympiads. In the middle of all of the competitions in which I participated, I took part in the International Young Physicists` Tournament (IYPT). I was one of the five Brazilian representatives twice for the IYPT and I started doing pre-university research for this competition. Up to then, I thought I`d be an aerospace engineer. After IYPT, I decided to become a physics major. Besides, I was always encouraged by my parents and teachers to pursue math from a very young age, which helped me a lot.
Codes: Event Triggered, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience

Response: Always was interested in physics topics from books growing up, but didn`t know the topics were called physics until college. Began studying after I knew what field it even was that I was interested in.
I had a really good physics teacher in high school, but also I found physics to be my most difficult class in high school. I liked having a challenge, so I decided to become a physics major.

In High School, physics was the first subject I really found challenging. My teacher, though, was the best teacher I`ve ever had. He was very passionate and excited about physics, his excitement was infectious. I fell in love with the deeper understanding of the world around me that I found in physics. Coming to college I was deciding between chemistry and physics as possible majors, I didn???t quite have enough room in my schedule to take both with the other classes I wanted. I chose physics and when I was going to departmental info sessions, the chemistry department seemed surprised and told me I really had to take chemistry freshman year if I wanted to be a major. I found that somewhat off-putting and never ended up taking chemistry. As I took more physics classes and became a lab TA for intro physics I discovered that I especially enjoyed the hands-on lab nature of physics much more than the more theoretical classes, which brings me to my current direction. I think I would like engineering more than just straight physics, I am therefore now considering going into some engineering or logistics field in the future.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I was very interested in astronomy and was the president of my high school astronomy club junior and senior year. After taking an AP Physics class my senior year, I found an interest in physics as well.

A missions operation manager for NASA spoke at my school. I developed a love of space/astrophysics in highschool, participated in programs at NASA Langley, and in college I`ve interned with Dominion Energy at a Nuclear Power Station.

I had a wonderful teacher in high school that introduced physics in a way that proved physics is fun and someone can be enthusiastic about it. He gave me a very strong background that is still helping today. I first attempted an engineering major but that was too intense for me. Then I tried a Chemistry major and I liked that but missed physics. I attempted a Physics and Chemistry double major and found myself disliking Chemistry more and more. I was always looking forward to my physics courses. I became a physics tutor because I understood the concepts in the university physics courses better than my peers and thought I could help. I finally decided to drop my Chemistry major because I was no longer enjoying any of my courses, and am only a physics major.

Physics challenged my intellect more than anything in high school and my high school teacher always believed in me even when I never did and never thought I could learn physics in college. But I am challenging myself right now and enjoying myself more than anything.

In high school, I was enrolled in a 4-year engineering ???university program??? where I was placed in accelerated math and science classes. I struggled a lot with calculus until my junior year when my physics teacher explained the derivative and integral when lecturing about position, velocity, and acceleration. From that point on, physics became the method by which I understood math, and was the first subject I was learning in school that I felt could be applicable to real life. I took AP physics my junior and senior years and had a wonderful teacher who was an inspiration to me and mentored my senior year research project on touchscreens. In this project I analyzed resistive, surface acoustic wave, and capacitive touchscreens, and found I had a special interest in the applications of physics in technological systems. Outside of school, I was a devoted track and field member and I developed an interest in sports science. I started to analyze the components of my races, the 100-meter and 200-meter-dash, through physics and began to use my knowledge of mechanics to improve my running form and training regiments. Overall, physics makes sense to me, and I decided to pursue physics as a major because it???s the one subject that still fascinates me as it intrigues me.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I loved space as a child, when I was six I got my first telescope. As I went through high school I was told I would be better suited in medicine or biology, it was only men in my high school who were interested in physics. I decided I would major in pre-med in college and become a doctor because I was told I was good at that. My first semester of college, I took an astronomy class for fun. That class reminded me how much I loved space. The following semester, I did a research-based independent study on variable stars. I learned how to use a telescope, got hired to work in a physics lab prep-room, and changed my major. After changing my major, I was hired at the Delta College Planetarium as a student assistant. My passion for astronomy grew as I was able to tell people about all the wonders of our universe. I transferred in the Fall 2016 to Central Michigan University to pick up a physics major with astronomy concentration. Physics did not come as easy to me as astronomy, but I kept working at it. Dr. Aaron LaCluyze, the professor of my astronomy classes, offered me a research opportunity on RR-Lyrae stars. I have since learned to use the 16" telescope in the Brooks Astronomical Observatory, as well as many things about instrumentation and coding.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Cost (Emotional), Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: It has been my dream for a long time and I am finally making it my reality.

Starting in junior high school, I felt inspired to subscribe to DISCOVER magazine, which I immediately fell in love with. Reading articles about new developments in physics and astronomy excited me and made me realize that there are no bounds to the scientific world. In high school, I attended a Research camp at Kitt Peak National Observatory where we carried out a couple research projects and got hands-on experience using the telescopes there. It was an amazing, beautiful, and inspiring experience and what made me decide to apply to college as an Astronomy major. However, learning that being a double major in Physics and Astronomy would help me out a lot in the long run, I decided to do both. Then, learning in college all the research that happens in physics, I discovered that I may want to end up doing physics research.
Codes: Media Triggered, Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: We had to take it in high school and my teacher was amazing. She made me love every minute of it and started my passion in physics!

I chanced upon physics. I had always harbored an interest in science and mathematics, and had intended to study neurobiology or psychology in college. An impulse purchase of Kleppner and Kolenkow???s An Introduction to Mechanics led me to taking my first physics class at Cornell University. The honors course introduced me to more than just Newtonian mechanics and special relativity ??? it gave me my first taste of physical intuition. I was hooked. Everything that has followed since then has been a blur - I have taken many courses in physics and mathematics, but ultimately it was my undergraduate research experience that made me certain that I wanted to pursue a PhD in physics.

I wanted to dual major in electrical engineering and math.My advisor suggested physics instead- I`m glad now becauseI enjoy my physics classes. A very strong interest indigital logic, design, and computers are what drew me toelectrical engineering.

My father received his Bachelor`s degree in physics and has been reading Stephen Hawking books and watching science fiction movies for a while, so growing up in kind of environment has most definitely piqued my interest in physics. In my high school physics class, my teacher shared information outside of the required coursework, such as astronomy photos and information about the solar eclipse of that year. These factors, along with various podcasts, documentaries, and novels, made me question the world we live in and made me hunger for a deeper understanding of it through physics.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: Took high school AP Physics and loved it, have continued from there.
My high school teacher

The first time I knew I wanted to be a physics major was when I was in eighth grade and went to a talk given by Michio Kaku. I instantly fell in love with physics. From that moment on I have been doing everything in my power to accomplish my dream of receiving a physics degree.

I decided in my senior year of high school to major in physics. AP Physics was my favorite classand I liked solving physics problems the best, so I put physics on all of my college applications.Looking back, I`ve been interested vaguely in physics topics from reading science fiction and news.But I`ve always felt like I wasn`t good enough at physics to be a physics major. I set a series oftests for myself. If I could get a 5 on the AP physics exam, if I could get an A in my intromechanics course, if I scored above average on the final exam for electromagnetism, etc. then andonly then would I declare physics in my sophomore year of college, which I did. My main struggleas a physics major currently is keeping my shaky confidence in myself.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Media Triggered, Cost (Emotional), Mastery Experience

Response: I told my dad I liked science when I was little and he told me to stick with it, so I did. Later I found out that I really liked Physics by taking an AP Physics course in high school, and that`s how I ended up here.

I`ve known I`ve wanted to do astrophysics my entire life, since elementary school. I feel very fortunate that physics has always been a passion of mine, and I`ve always known without a doubt it`s what I wanted to dedicate my life to. Throughout high school math and physics were my favorite subjects, and although I struggle sometimes in my physics courses at Berkeley, I continue to love it.

My English isn`t very good and writing is worse so the easiest classes for me have been math and science. Out of all the science classes I found physics the most interesting and the teachers to be very nice. I am still not sure about my major but I am currently planning on getting a degree in applied physics.

To find what I should major in, in high school I took several online quizzes that said I should be an engineer. However, the more I thought about myself, the more I realized that I liked the physical concepts and ideas more than using STEM concepts to design and build things. I also realized that I was greatly interested in the universe and how things work, which made me go into astrophysics for an undergraduate degree.

I always had low expectations for myself and my abilities, so out of high school I initially pursued something that seemed "doable" for myself, such as personal training, because that depended more on physical ability and experience, rather than intelligence. The stronger I got in the gym, the more I was able to conceptualize what hard work really looked like, and the expectations I had for myself began to grow. I had decided to pursue firefighting, which required I take an EMS program. During the course of this program I noticed myself out performing many of the other classmates, and began to suspect that perhaps I had been severely underestimating myself. Ultimately I realized that my failures in the past were due to a misunderstanding of what hard work and ambition really looked like, so during the process of becoming a fire fighter I was forced to reconsider my future and determine my true limits. I decided to change directions entirely and pursue something science-related and to see where that would take me. After completing my first calculus course I realized that perhaps I could do more than I ever thought before. It`s been a long road, and I still have a long ways to go with respect to behavior modifications, but I am certain I`ve made the right choice with applied physics. There is so much to know about this world and I am thrilled to be spending my time learning about some of what feels like its most intimate and eloquent aspects.

I wrote about twice as much as needed. Here is a link to the entirety:https://docs.google.com/document/d/1IKI0TY-iGb2JUBTkg-jbcayYB37amoAJQ-xVf0emLo8/edit?usp=sharingWhen I was a Freshman in high school, I distinctly remember deciding that I wanted to take our Advanced Chemistry and Physics courses when I became a senior. My homeroom teacher taught it at the time so I talked with him about it and he told me that those courses were difficult and most people didn`t take them at the same time. It felt like he was trying to discourage me so I promised myself that I would take those courses no matter what. When the time came, I took both of them, loved them both, and ended up excelling. I could take pride in it since my homeroom teacher had also told me that I had great potential and I never used it. After those classes, I felt like I had finally accomplished something.When I actually started university, I came in as undecided. They automatically put you on a Mechanical Engineering track. My first day of class, it was like, what am I doing here? This is definitely not for me. So I ended up following a Math, Physics, and Chemistry-based track. I was still undecided but I had a better idea of what I wanted. As I followed along it for a year and a half, I realized that there was plenty of math in physics and chemistry. So now it was down to two. But how to choose? I liked how physics had a wide variety of applications but chemistry seemed like a crazy, mind-blowing field of its own. So I talked about it some more, and I mulled things over. I came to the conclusion that I was stuck. I had decided that I might prefer physics a bit more, but a part of me believed that I couldn`t get the skills, that I wasn`t good enough to figure it out, to understand. Then, I had someone who showed just enough confidence in me that I felt that I could. Because why not? I hadn`t had much trouble so far and I could work through any difficulties I had encountered.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Emotional), Social Persuasion

Response: The science curriculum for 3rd grade in my school district was astronomy. I developed a deep passion for understanding the mysteries of the universe. My university does not offer astronomy as a major, so I chose to get my B.S. in Physics. I am very happy with my choice.
After developing a general interest in physics in childhood, I got the chance to take IB physics in high school, loved it, and decided to major in it in college.

After taking college physics 1 and 2 in high school and really enjoying that class, I realized I wanted to study physics. I liked how physics explained how things worked. As soon as I got to college, I began my major in astrophysics. I started doing research in astrophysics this past summer. I am planning on going on to grad school for a Phd in astrophysics.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered

Response: I had no intention of being a physics major until I took Physics 1 my freshmen year on the path to applied math or engineering.  I enjoyed the challenge and the concepts and my professor really helped grow my interest in the subject.  I`ve been sold on physics ever since.
