Additionally, having opportunities it to do research through summer internships (REUs) really solidified my desire to continue onto graduate school.

I first considered physics when I was in high school. I took both the requires course and an independent study of AP physics. I eventually went on to continue in just the independent study, and found that I loved learned about physics and conducting experiments to apply our concepts to.  I didn`t declare my major until the second semester of my first yea at Umaine. I wasn`t sure I would be capable of doing it, and I had plenty of people tell me how hard physics is. I found out I was bored with out my intense calculus and physics classes. I wanted to be a scientist, and I figured because I love physics so much, I might as well be a physics major. I love most all sciences, but I believe that physics is the backbone of all science.

I start loving physics from my first physics class in my 8th grade middle school. I thought this subject is so brilliant and I will keep studying it. After that, as I learn more about physics, I have more love in physics.

Waves are cool and were not too difficult to wrap my mind around (initially). Physics gives me a way to quantify and understand how the world works. Physics is difficult, but once you understand it, it is euphoric.

I fell in love with particle physics in 6th grade, when I had some spare time at school and used it to write a research paper on the role the electron played in the structure of the periodic table. Since then, I`ve had the pleasure of interacting with physicists and other students, not to mention exposure to research. In college, I was torn between physics and computer science as a major, but ended up choosing physics, as it felt more like an area of study than a tool for investigation (like computer science).

I had always been really interested in math and science but didn`t know how to combine the two. My parents suggested in engineering, and I began to look into it. Then I took a physics class in high school. I loved my teacher and the content. I decided to make that my major to allow me to look into all of the options that physics and engineering have to offer.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: My interest in physics has grown gradually since I was very little, when I would incessantly ask how various things I interacted with or knew about worked.  I`ve also always loved problem solving questions from when I was little.  I made the formal decision to study it academically/for a career in middle school, when I learned that atoms in our body came from parts of the Universe.

I started in AP Physics in high school and really liked it so I found a mentor at the University of Colorado to do research with and loved that and so I decided that physics is what I wanted to major in.

I was always good at math and thought that was what I wantedto do. However, my physics course junior year of high schoolreally impacted me. My teacher was great and encouraged meto learn more about it independently. I read a lot of physicsbooks and decided to apply to college as an Applied Math major and Applied Physics minor. However, an intensive firstyear physics course I took freshman year made me realizeI should major in Applied Physics. It was a very challengingcourse that involved about 20 hours of work per week, but Irealized after all that time spent on it, I still loved physics.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: In high school I was the only female in my AP Physics class and was top of my class. My teacher talked with me in persueing a career with physics or engineering and I thought that it would be a good fit. I had always loved my physics class and thought that I could excel in that environment.

I first became seriously interested in physics in junior year when I took Honors Physics. My teacher saw that I had a lot of natural talent and encouraged me to do more physics. I also loved space and wanted to learn physics so I could learn more about the universe. I took AP Physics and became interested in majoring in Physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: During college applications I decided that I wanted to study astronomy, then I found that my department recommends double majoring in physics as well.

I have been interested in a career in medicine since I was eight years old. When I took my first physics class in college, Classical Mechanics, I immediately knew that physics was what I wanted to study during my undergraduate degree. This semester I am the Supplemental Instruction Leader for our Electricity and Magnetism class on campus and being involved in the transfer of knowledge and instruction in physics has motivated and inspired me even more to pursue physics research and instruction in some way. This year I attended the UC Davis Pre-Health Conference where I got to attend workshops about the MD/PhD programs available to students who wish to accomplish both educational goals at once. It is now my plan to complete my undergraduate degree in either physics or astrophysics and then do an MD/PhD in physics afterwards. This would allow me to be a practicing physician/surgeon and an instructor or researcher in physics!
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Medical), Utility Value, Event Triggered

Response: I considered physics as a major and a possible career thanks to my high school physics teacher. I was excited to attend every class and learn a bit more of how the universe works. I just wanted to learn as much as possible about the laws that govern everything. I had so many questions which my physics teacher was happy to answer. He also told me to consider teaching or engineering, as I love design and I spend so much of my time helping others understand physics but also appreciate it more. When I came to the College of William and Mary, I wasn`t sure if I wanted to major in chemistry or physics. It was the community of physics students here that really helped me choose physics. The society of physics was filled with the nicest of people doing amazing research, and they really made me feel excited to be a budding physicist.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: Was always interested in both math and science. Later became aware of physics in middle and high school. Was between pursuing physics and medical career, have compromised and plan on going into medical physics or bioengineering.

From a very young age, I aspired to be an engineer like my dad. Growing up I have always been good at math and physics. However, I was ushered away from my engineering career path by my family, friends and some teachers because of how dominated the engineering and physics fields are by men. Discouraged by this unfortunate reality, I decided to pursue a career in medicine and when I got to university I started majoring in biology. My calling for engineering still remained, however, and in my sophomore year, I enroled in a calculus-based general physics course; I received an A-. Furthermore, I took part in a bioengineering research program this past summer at the University of Pennsylvania where I worked on a bile duct-on-a-chip device. I enjoyed both of these experiences; so much so that they rekindled my fire for both engineering and physics. So, this fall I enroled in the second part of the calculus-based general physics course and I plan to switch to being a physics major from biology for the upcoming spring semester.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered, Cost (Emotional)

Response: I am actually an astrophysics major, which means I belong to the rather different astronomy community. I have wanted to be an astrophysicist since I was 10, likely a consequence of growing up near the astronomical powerhouse that is the University of Arizona. I grew up attending all manner of public outreach and Women in STEM conferences as a child which, along with the fortune of well-educated and supportive parents, being visibly white, and having access to good public schools made me never waver. Rolemodels: My high school physics teacher was a woman, who, despite not excelling as a physics teacher, was extremely supportive and whom I still visit to this day. My 2nd junior project adviser is young, but a full professor who is involved in all sorts of outreach and inclusions issues, runs marathons, and is a new mother. She treated me so collegialy, that I felt respected and validated, like I could contribute impactfully to a project. My adviser this past summer was a female astronomer at ALMA who treated me as an equal and competent researcher, talking to me, too, about life as a female astronomer. While I began to bloom throughout my other research experiences, I really blossomed as a researcher working with her. That experience assured me that I really could make it as graduate student. After my sophomore research project was so unenjoyable, I began to question whether or not I wanted to go on to grad school. It was a stressful time, but as a result, I became familiar with alternate careers (thanks to astrobites) & the grad school process early. I also talked to grad students at other schools, at our own, professors, department reps, older peers. As a result, I am headed strongly and confidently into the grad app process.Thanks to the astro community, I feel like I can excel at astro by being an A astro student and a sharp and driven researcher, even while being a B physics student.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Mastery Experience

Response: I had a very encouraging high school physics teacher my senior year. I started taking courses in physics my first semester and never looked back. Completing research through REU programs only strengthened my interest.

My curiosity since very young swayed me in the direction of more challenging subjects, science and math. Later I realized it was fulfilling to understand how the world around me worked and all while doing math which I also enjoy.

One of the main factors in my decision to pursue a physics-related major (Materials Engineering) is my childhood in the bay area. I grew up in the heart of silicon valley, innovations in tech and science and the people behind them surrounded me. Both of my parents and older brothers pursued science related fields, through the encouragement of my family I developed a healthy curiosity about science and engineering. In high school, I became very interested in science and mathematics, so choosing materials engineering as a major was a very natural fit. I think living in silicon valley showed me the power of science and technology, and female role models like my mother and my high school teachers allowed me to envision myself as an engineer and gave me the confidence to pursue that role. In college,I have found a positive community of people with a passion for STEM within my major and within the professors who teach courses, males and females included. This continuation of support has driven me to accomplish things I once didn`t think I would be able to do, like undergraduate research or getting on the Dean`s List.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic (Social), Event Triggered, Mastery Experience

Response: I`ve planned on pursing physics as a career since I was very small; I actually have no memory of ever making the decision, or wanting to be anything else. I`m synesthetic, and tend to sense mathematical systems as fractals or other patterns, so that probably contributed to my being drawn to mathematics and science generally. I graduated high school after tenth grade because I had exhausted the math and physics course offerings, and selected my undergraduate institution because of the reputation of its physics program and undergraduate research opportunities. I originally worked in an observatory and studied large-star binaries; this convinced me that I did not want to do observational astrophysics. I then worked in an experimental lab that studied ultra-high-energy neutrinos. The fundamental physics behind the particles interested me, and my PI suggested that I might do very well in a theory group, which is where I currently am.
Codes: Attainment Value, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: When I was a kid, about 8 or so, I always had a fascination with astronomy. Due to that fascination and progressive strength in my math skills, I felt compelled to pursue a future in Astrophysics. Over the years, I have read articles/research papers, attended colloquiums, and watched programs/segments on Astrophysics. Seeing how the field is growing and witnessing what researchers are doing has grown my passion to an extent of hoping to be in their shoes one day.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Event Triggered

Response: I have been interested in astronomy since I was seven years old. Growing up, I always said that I wanted to become an astronaut but the reactions of the people around me to my career choice was discouraging and I was told to aim for something more , "realistic". In high school I considered multiple career routes (all mainly in STEM) until I enrolled in an astronomy course and realized that I did not want to do anything else with my career. From there, I decided to major in physics so that I could eventually do astrophysics and astronomy as a profession.
my high school physics teacher was the greatest man I`ve ever known. His passion for physics and enthusiasm for teaching really made me realize that I was passionate about it too.

I never really understood what physics consisted of or even considered the possibility that I could major in physics until I took AP Physics B in high school. I really didn`t want to take the course in the first place, because I considered myself more of a humanities-type person than a math and science person. Math always came easily to me, but I never had a way to apply it or understand why I was doing it. A few weeks into my first physics course it hit me that this was the way I could take my skills in math and use them in the real world. The possibility to be able to explain everything in the the physical world attracted me beyond anything I could ever do with English or History. The complexity behind the fundamental laws of nature sparked an interest in me that I had never experienced. At first I didn`t think I had it in me to do physics for the rest of my life, because I thought that only the types of people you see on the television and in movies were the ones who made it in that field. I don`t know what the rest of my scholastic career will bring me, but I do know that the more I read, the more I study, the more courses I take, and the more people I meet, the more I want to do physics for the rest of my life. I love the math, I love the theory, and I love the unknowns. As of right now, I am the only freshman female at my college who has expressed an interest in majoring in physics, but it`s my hope that other girls who are interested aren`t discouraged because they think they aren`t good enough or because they think they`re outnumbered.Unfortunately, I can`t say that my first physics teacher was much of an inspiration, but that just goes to show that my dedication to the subject is deeper than what one teacher one year may throw at me. I got to college, and I was nervous that after my first college physics course I would be discouraged and fall out of love with the topic, but I didn`t. I did the exact opposite, because I found myself in the midst of a loving and accepting and supportive group of faculty and students who want nothing but to encourage me and push me forward, not regard me as competition and set me back. I`ve only had one semester in college, but I already have prospects of research at school this summer and my own plans for my future for the next four years are phenomenal.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I was originally going to attend art school to study fashion design, but a info session about the school I had won a scholarship to made me realize that building things was what I liked rather than art. This lead me to attend a school that has a 3-2 year plan to get a bachelors in both physics and engineering. Once I started attending college I realised I could graduate in three years with a Bachelors in physics so I decided to stay at my original university and not be a part of the 3-2 program. I know plan on graduating a year early and going on to graduate school for a master`s degree in mechanical engineering.
I am unsure if I have talent for upper level physics courses. I was forced to take physics as a biochemistry major and I`m now considering pursuing physics further.

In middle school I didn`t have the best physics teacher, so the first time I thought that I might seriously like physics was in high school when one of my friends started explaining special relativity to me. From there, I grew to like physics more and more. Now I like it most of all the sciences because it is the most "pure science. "

I have always liked mathematics and physics courses in my high school and then my junior year AP classes were starting to be offered in my high school and my physics professor told me that I should join the class because I was very good at physics. Since that moment I started considering physics as an option and finally I decided to be an electrical engineer because of my dad.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience

Response: I had never really considered anything physics related as a possible major/career until after my freshman year of college. While home for the summer, I saw a post about space on Facebook that sparked a conversation with my dad and to me thinking about how I have always found space fascinating but for some reason never considered it to be a possible career. I looked up different jobs within NASA and other astronomy based positions. I felt really excited about the idea of studying space so I looked at the available majors for my school and found Physics - Astronomy. I looked into the requirements and different classes and still felt really excited about it. Being a religious person, I also prayed about the decision and felt good about making the change (my previous major was Genetics and Biotechnology). I had a planned roughly 2 year break from my college education to perform a mission for my church. During that time, I continued to consider the change and never lost my excitement so when I returned I made the change. I contacted the faculty as well and found a position as a research assistant. I`m only in my first semester in the major but have been enjoying my time and what I am learning.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: ÒYour goal is simple: get the ball into the can.Ó That was easy enough for my physics teacher to say, but with the catapult on a desk, the can on the floor, and the physics equations on the board, it didnÕt seem like a straightforward task, especially when we only had three tries to accomplish the daunting feat. That first lab was like the first lesson in DriverÕs Education, when I learned how to trust the rearview mirror while driving in reverse. By swishing the ball into the can on the first try, I learned to trust physics. After that lab, my teacher lent me a book called Geometry, Relativity, and the Fourth Dimension, which made me understand how physics could not just be reliable and applicable, but theoretical and mind-blowing. Rudolf Rucker, the author, first explains how an object that exists in two dimensions would perceive a three-dimensional object. A sphere moving through a plane would look like a circle that is changing sizes from the planeÕs point of view. What really made me think is trying to take the insights from the second dimension and pushing it into the third dimension. What would a four-dimensional object look like as it moved through my perceived three-dimensional world? This book amplified my interest in pursuing higher-level physics courses, and eventually led to me working in a biophysics lab.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Media Triggered

Response: I began my study of physics in my sophomore year of high school. At the start, I was terrible at it. I did not understand how to turn a concept, say, an object ???just leaving the ground,??? into an equation: normal force = 0N. As simple as this conversion may seem to me now, it was incredibly hard to learn. I felt like I was being taught to think ??? really think ??? for the first time. It was no longer enough to simply state that something was happening. I was forced to consider why that event had occurred and what that information meant with respect to a whole situation: the ice melts, the block falls, the car makes the turn safely. After I learned to think in the way physics demands, I was free to enjoy the amazing discoveries it has to offer. I was, and am, absolutely fascinated with the ideas of electron tunneling, Heisenberg???s uncertainty principle, Schrodinger???s cat, and everything I have learned so far about quantum physics and general relativity. The day I learned about Young???s double slit experiment being done with a single photon, I knew I wanted to be a physics major. Out of everything I have learned in the past three years studying physics, the one subject that has been demonstrated repeatedly is that there is so much we have yet to learn. I want to be a part of future discoveries. I want to study physics because I think the universe is incredible and mysterious and I am excited to learn more about it. Every time one discovers an answer to a physics question, he/she unearths a dozen more questions about the subject. Physics is a continuous cycle of discovery and curiosity. They feed off each other ??? curiosity prompting discovery and discovery furthering curiosity. Some may find that cycle tiring, but I find it enthralling. When I learn something new, the questions that accompany that knowledge are not daunting, but inviting. The challenge of unearthing further answers is like a treasure hunt ??? at the end of the journey, I find the reward well worth the work done. Whether I pursue astrophysics, quantum mechanics, relativity, or another subfield I come to love, I look forward to contributing to our understanding of the world around us.

I took a physics class during my junior year of high school and realized that I preferred it to biology (I had been planning on studying microbiology with the intent of doing virology). I took another physics class my senior year, wasn`t that great at it, but attended college as an intended major. I fully anticipated doing one semester of physics before changing my major to economics, but I loved my into class and professor, so I kept doing it. I started doing research, which also kept me in the major.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I initially became interested in physics through high school AP Physics class, but I didn`t know of any physics careers that sounded interesting so went into nursing instead. After my sophomore year, I rediscovered physics through reading some books on cosmology by Stephen Hawking, and I decided to switch my major. My desire to go into physics research was solidified by my experience doing high-energy heavy-ion physics research at the University of California, Los Angeles as a part of the Research Experience for Undergraduates program. I am now applying to physics Ph.D. programs fornext fall. I am very excited for a career in physics research!
Codes: Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Media Triggered, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: The reason I took Physics as the career path of my choice was bexause it made sense. Things started to make sense the more I learned and then it got to a point where I got a drawn in by all the things I was learni g and getti g confused by I knew I had to go into the field. Some things did cause some major bumps in the road for examole not being able to paid for a year of school and having to take it off as well as my father getting sick and having a tumor on his kidney. All thses things have given me more drive opposed to when I started my journey in Higher Education.

Competing in Future City middle school engineering competition instilled in me a dream to become an engineer; personal experiences with cancer and an interest in medicine without medical school furthered that dream to be specifically a biomedical engineer; finally arriving to MHC there was no engineering so I chose physics and am now pursuing opportunities for a PhD in medical physics
Codes: Event Triggered, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value (Medical)

Response: I`ve always had a deep, innate interest in space and I realized that I would need physics to indulge in astronomy beyond the surface level. My father helped me improve at math and my teachers in high school all supported my goal of pursuing a physics degree even when I thought I would fail.

I loved my math and science courses in high school, but chose to pursue an art degree because it seemed more reasonable at the time because I enjoyed drawing and I think I subconsciously felt that I wasn`t actually supposed to like math and science. It turned out art school wasn`t for me, so I dropped out and worked in retail for 10 years. I was very unhappy with my life and was reaching a period where I had to completely change the direction my life was heading or I would lose my mind. I was inspired while watching Cosmos with Carl Sagan and wanted to understand the universe and how everything works. I decided to go back to school with a long-term goal of eventually becoming an astrophysicist in mind and started with applying to Massasoit, the closest community college.

In high school, physics was very difficult, but I really enjoyed the concepts and math behind it. I entered college as an engineer and quickly realized that while I was enjoying the math, I was not a fan of the building and design aspect. I chose to switch to physics because it interests me more and I really enjoy learning the concepts behind how the Earth works.

As a young child, I learned about Mae Jamison and wanted to become an astronaut. However, as I was growing up I learned more about the dangers of being in space and it discouraged me for awhile but led me to the decision to study the stars from Earth. I took physics classes in high school and decided to choose a physics major after realizing what my original dream career was, originally being a computer science major freshman year for hopes of being a video game programmer and realizing programming was not fun for me.

I loved physics before from when it was first introduced to me in middle school, and have wanted to study it since then. My second high school physics teacher showed me that physics is a field that I can excel in and encouraged me to pursue the field. I of course have had my doubts, but physics seems to be the field that all of my interests lead back to.

My high school physics teacher was the first to inspire me to pursue a degree in physics. Her passion for the subject lead me to continue taking physics courses my first semester of college. Once I completed the introductory courses, I took Quantum Physics and Relativity, which was the course that allowed me to fall in love with and be excited by the subject. It showed me the beauty of physicsÑ all the phenomenon in the universe can be explained in a mathematical way.
I realized that in my high school physics course I was doing better than other students. I took the introductory college physics course my first semester and really enjoyed it.

I was in high school and I wanted to take an AP science course. AP Physics was the only one that fit into my schedule so I signed up for it. However I did not have therequired math background to do the class. The teacher worked with me and said that I could try as long as I kepta grade above a C for every semester. His willingness to work with me on this and his engaging way of teaching really opened up the door to me for physics. I have beenin love with the subject ever since.

I took a really great AP Physics I class in high school with a teacher that made physics interesting. The next year I had a not-so-great physics teacher and was the only girl in a class of sixteen. I figured that if I could make it through that year I could major in physics, so I decided to.At the end of freshman year I really didn`t know whether to stick with physics, but I found the environmental physics option at my school and the classes fit my interests a lot better. I changed my minor to anthropology and have felt that that complements my choice of major quite well.This term I am abroad in Denmark taking a few classes on climate change, and that has only made my desire to graduate with this major stronger, as I want to do something to help the world if I can.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Environmental), Utility Value

Response: My high school physics teachers encouraged me and inspired me to become a physics major. In my first physics class in college I realized that there was only a few females in physics and I realized I want to change this.
I always loves math and science since i was a young girl. I considered physics as a major about a year ago, i used to want to be a chemist. I want to discover something new about the world.

My physics class as a junior in high school is what opened me math and science. Suddenly, math was no longer abstract, and had solid applications in life. I loved physics from day one, and I have loved it ever since.In college, I began as a mechanical engineering major, but when I realized that I was hanging out with all of the engineering physics majors, I found myself switching majors. After that, I have become more involved with physics: I took an REU at UIUC studying the physics of music, I am now a TA for a physics I class, and I am a member of SPS.The more I read and the more I investigate life through a physics lens, the more I remember how fascinating the world is to me, and how much sense it all makes when I think of it in terms of physics.

I visited Sudan, Minnesota where they had a particle accelerator and talked aboutsubatomic particles like neutrinos that move so fast and we don`t even realizeit. This fascinated me and got me interested in how large machines work with proton/atomic beams and collect data about the interactions. This sent me to Fermilab in Batavia that I did Saturday Morning Physics in the summer of my junior year for 9 weeks. I love to learn about particle physicsand how small particles react to electromagnetism and such.

IÕve always been interested in science since I was little,  but it wasnÕt until I entered college that I made the decision to pursue a degree in physics. It was my interest in space that triggered me to pursue the degree in physics.  IÕm extremely fascinated with our universe and the physical nature of the planets, stars and other celestial bodies. I want to learn how the laws of physics apply to the behavior of astronomical objects and a lot more.

My father is a software engineer with Lockheed Martin. He brought me to take-your-kid-to-work day when I was little, which really got me interested in science. When he asked me in like 7th grade what I wanted to study, it didn`t take me long to pick Astrophysics. I almost switched to BusinessManagement Economics my sophomore year because I didn`t feel like I was cut out to study physics,but my mom encouraged me to stay in the major a little while longer. Now, I couldn`t imagine doing anything else.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion

Response: When I was in about the 5th grade I decided I wanted to be a chemical engineer, then in high school I took a physics course and really enjoyed the topic so I decided to pursue physics and engineering in college! Being a physics major has been a really good experience and I enjoy the challenge that comes with it!

The main reason I became a major was due to the attentionof my Honors Physics Professor freshman year. I was kicking around the idea of doing a double major in Chemistry and physics (like my high school Chemistry teacher and good friend did when she was in undergraduate).So her presence in my life - as well as my physics teacher- really got me interested in science and gave me the support to see myself in the difficult realm of sciencethat neither of my parents ever were interested in.When I admitted this to him, he brought me to the head of the department and got me tosign the change of major forms. While the decision was really spur of the moment, I stayed because of the community; the professors and the students were all people I could relate to and most of them will probably be some of my best friends for the rest of my life.

I could do physics well in high school, my grandparents did physics research in Chinese Academy of Sciences till their retirement, and I was not allowed to do what I initially wanted to do in the US due to immigration policy. Thus, I choose physics.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: I took my first physics class during my last year of high school and had a good, enthusiastic teacher. He made the class a lot of fun and was very supportive of student success. I also found myself enjoying the subject matter, and that you can describe everyday things (mainly kinematics at that point) with math. I had only been in that class for a few months when I was applying for college, and applied as an undeclared physical sciences major. When I got to UC Davis I thought maybe once we get to non-classical mechanics courses I will enjoy it less and move toward another major, but the next thing I learned about was special relativity and with each new subject I ended up liking physics even more. Of course there are aspects which are not so fun, but overall this is a way of seeing the world that I enjoy.

I`ve wanted to study physics for about as long as I can remember having any academic plan at all. Both of my parents work in computer engineering, so I was introduced to STEM subjects early in life. My classes and academic tendencies only reinforced my preference towards physics. My major seemed like a logical choice based on my progression through my science classes and my interest in the subject.

I became interested in physics my senior year in high school. I actually did not take AP Physics, but instead took AP Chemistry. My teacher was amazing and very encouraging. I loved studying the quantum theory of the atom and found out that this was more physics than chemistry. Because of this my interests in physics have always been quantum mechanics and particle physics.

I liked the class in high school, even when everyone else hated it. I wanted to take more classes so I kept taking them. I enjoy problem solving and figuring out the answer to each question. I also like figuring out how things work.
I was inspired by my high school teachers. This ultimately lead to my own curiosity of the science. It was something I could be passionately about. Physics humbles me.

I did a research paper on the effect of radiation on the body that I really enjoyed doing so I shifted my focus from a biology major to a biophysics. Taking physics classes and math classes in college and university that I enjoyed and did well in also influenced my decision along the way.

I enjoy watching science documentaries (specifically those about the universe).  One series I enjoyed from the beginning was the "Cosmos" with Neil DeGrasse Tyson.  I remember watching the first episode in awe.  I always knew I liked Math and Science, but watching this series prompted me to continue reading about Astronomy on my own.  It even convinced me to take Astrochemistry as an elective my Junior year of high school. In school we were required to take one year of biology, one year of chemistry, and one year of physics.  As a Junior I took AP Chemistry after taking honors Chemistry my Sophomore year and doing relatively well.  As Junior year progressed I realized I did not really enjoy it aside from the lab portion.  Since I was involved in the STEM program, I had to take more science electives along with the core curriculum.  I took Astrochemistry.  I learned about different galaxies, celestial objects, and the conditions needed for life to survive on other planets.  From that point forward I knew that I wanted to do something Astronomy related.  My Astrochemistry class distracted me from AP Chemistry and allowed me to look forward to taking AP Physics my Senior year.  I knew the content within Physics could be related to more space/astronomy topics than Chemistry was.  Senior year I ended up loving my AP Physics class and applied to colleges as a Physics/Engineering major.  I entered North Park University as a Physics major (with the idea I could always change it to Math or Engineering down the line).  After taking my Intro classes I was sure I wanted to continue with the Theoretical side of Physics and Astronomy.  At this point in college I am trying to double major in Physics and Philosophy.  Both subjects rely heavily on each other and they each help me understand many topics on a deeper level.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional

Response: I first considered studying physics after an earth science class in high school that included a unit on astronomy. I also completed an independent study on the history of astrophysics in high school. As I started taking physics and math classes in high school, I realized that I liked both subjects, but I liked the more applied nature of physics over math. While I was initially interested in astrophysics, I realized that I also really liked other areas of physics, and I started doing research in experimental particle physics during my junior year of college. I have continued in this field (I am a senior now) and have learned to appreciate many different research areas, even though I intend to pursue experimental particle physics in my own career. Throughout my high school/college career, the factors that drew me to physics were all material-based -- I really enjoyed what I was learning in all of my physics classes, as well as all of the research talks I attended.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered

Response: It was partially the class in high school and also family members. There is not really a certain incidentthat sticks out in my mind. I really enjoyed the experiments in high school of building things with myhands and seeing how well they turned out.
I took honors physics (mechanics) and loved it.
I`ve always been interested in astrophysics and it was the natural thing for me to major in when I got to college.

Took AP Physics in high school. Last week of the year was a history of our universe, which I was extremely interested in and intrigued by. Took an Intro to Astronomy class at UC Davis (Astron 10G) and decided that I loved astronomy. I wanted to major in something more general to ensure that I had the ability to change my mind, so I decided upon Physics with an eventual specialty in Astrophysics.

I hated science in grade school, but after taking the Apologia "Exploring Creation with...[Physics/Chemistry/Bio...etc.] my interest and appreciation began to grow. (Courses and teachers have so much influence in a student`s interest. I`m so grateful for my high-school program.)I was home-educated all the way until graduating high school in May 2014. Every other week other home-schoolers in the area would meet at the home of a (well-scientifically-versed) woman who would facilitate our labs.Each science course was two grades ahead of me (since I took the class with my brother). Not yet having quite the math skills

My dad as a computer scientist was always interested intopics of all sciences, thanks to this I`ve been exposed to science all my life. Since I can remember I`ve always wanted to study Astrophysics. When the time to apply tocollege arrived I applied for a Bachelors Degree in Electrical Engineering. My two introductory physics courses were amazing. I hadthe opportunity of taking them with a professor who wasa specialist in physics education and made the perfectbalance of making the class both enjoyable and challenging.As I continued taking my engineering classes I also tookphysics courses as free electives. I enjoyed more the physics courses than the engineering ones and decided tochange majors. A great part of my success I owe it to some faculty members that have always been available and open to discussion of physics topics related and not related to curriculum courses. They have also providedcounseling related to graduate school. I have also reached out to faculty members of other universities and one letme do an REU at her university. I owe to her almost all my formation in the astrophysics field. As of now, I`m a senior looking forward to applying to graduate school in (Astro)Phyics.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: Towards the end of high school, I became extremely interested in the implications of different scientific issues on various philosophical concepts. I entered into my university originally as a philosophy major in hopes of one day further delve into, however I switched to physics in order to better understand the scientific concepts I sought to analyze. Despite traditionally having an issue with mathematics, I found after much hard work and persistence that I enjoyed physics and wanted to stay in the field as a career. I love now being ableto understand the technicalities of how the universe aroundme works and to have the ability to explore it throughnot only philosophical questioning but scientific experimentation.

When I was in the 5th grade, my Dad had gotten a telescope and together, we would look out of it at the night sky. It was during this time that I had decided I wanted to become an Astronomer. When I was in high school, I had been thinking about the practical way of becoming my childhood dream and, through research I learned that this would be made possible if I majored in physics. When I took my first physics class, I loved it and knew was for me.
I took my first Physics class my sophomore year and I loved it, so I decided to make it my major.

I wasn`t really interested in science until I went to the Illinois Math and Science Academy for high school and I was able to take a lot of physics electives.That sort of hands-on approach to learning really opened my eyes to how much physics really interested me.My dad is also a physicist, so becoming one myself never seemed like an unfeasible goal.I took a total of 7 physics courses in high school and realized that I liked the challenge of physics and I was good at it.I applied to colleges knowing that I wanted to major in physics, and started at the University of Chicago with the physics major curriculum and have stuck with it ever since.About a year ago I started working for the Cheng Chin Lab in ultracold atomic physics and that has strengthened my interest in research.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Exprience, Event Triggered

Response: I quite enjoyed Intro Physics as an engineering major and I switched to physics because I wanted to explore more than just the engineering applications. I wanted to explore Astrophysics, Quantum, and learn more about how the universe works.

I grew up always knowing I would go into a STeM related field, but physics really grew on me when I was in high school and would look up astrophysics for fun. I have always loved physics and now I get to do it and have fun.

When I was younger, I grew up on a ranch, and so learned to explore the world around me. My mom would also do science experiments when growing up--like swinging a bucket of water around to explain centrifugal/centripetal forces. I grew interested in space as a child, and that expanded into physics when I took physical science courses in high school. I decided to major in physics, and I`ve loved all of the opportunities I`ve had--great classes, undergraduate research, involvement in SPS, and an internship at a national lab.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: Last fall, I took an astronomy related freshman seminar and found a new appreciation for physics that I lacked when I took physics in high school. The next semester, I took an astronomy course (intro physics is fall-only at my school) and started learning more about physics on my own. I`m taking Physics I right now and loving it!

I took physics in high school and really enjoyed it and was really interested in learning as much as I can about the universe. I then, on a whim in high school, watched the movie "The Theory of Everything" and it amazed me. I immediately bought some of  Stephen Hawking`s books and really started to get interested in physics and astronomy. I had always been interested in space and the stars, but after watching that movie and reading some of his books I realized that physics is what I want to study.

I have always enjoyed math, but was turned off by physics in high school. I am an older student, getting a second BA degree. With my initial degree, I did a concentration in philosophy, which led me to desire a synthesis of philosophical enquiry grounded in objective reality. This desire coupled with my love of math led me to physics.

I started out as a music major. I knew that I loved science, but I wasn`t sure what I wanted to study. I never originally wanted to study physics, but now that I am taking the classes I realize how much I love this field.
Something clicked and I knew right away.
My professor and adviser encouraged me to be a physics major. I wanted to do engineering, but due to his encouragement I switched to physics. It has been difficult, but I have enjoyed it.

When I was younger, I had a pure fascination for space and NASA`s projects, though my true love for science would be kindled in my physical science. In this physical science course, we were introduced to many physics and chemistry concepts. My resolve in doing physics was finalized in my high school physics course. We were given an assignment to interview a physicists through "Adopt-a-Physicist" program to which we learn more about an individual`s journey to becoming a physicist. I became inspired after learning what it takes to become a physicist and decided to major in Physics once I went to college. I am now in my second semester of university currently enrolled as a Physics major.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value

Response: I choose to study physics because of my interest in Fusion research and particle physics. This was peaked by a tour of the Nuclear Fusion Lab at MIT.

In my high school physics class, I felt encouraged by the more I learned in the class. The more I learned, the more knowledgeable I felt about the world around me. I found this fulfilling, so naturally I pursued more. My family is full of engineers and STEM majors, but I never truly grasped how important it was or how interesting it could be until my later years of high school. I graduated high school a year early and immediately delved into my degree in physics at University of Colorado at Colorado Springs and am entirely grateful for everyone and everything that helped me get to this point.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: I`ve known that I wanted to be a scientist my whole life. My mom is a radiochemist, and I used to go into work at her lab with her, and I thought that science was the coolest thing ever. Most of the books my mom bought me were science books, and I used to watch Magic School Bus and Bill Nye the Science Guy with my mom. By the time I was in 7th grade I knew I wanted to be a physicist because I thought that Astrophysics and Quantum Mechanics were the most fascinating. I have not had many wonderful or inspiring math or science teachers throughout middle or high school, and nearly all of my inspiration has come from home. In addition to normal science, I have been incredibly influenced by science fiction. Star Trek and Contact in particular have helped shape the kind of person I want to be and the kind of future I want to create.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: I started seriously considering becoming a physics major after I participated in a summer physics program during high school and realizing I was having a lot of fun and enjoyed learning about the material that was presented. Later, as I started doing research that allowed me to learn things that weren`t necessarily being taught in classes yet, I became more excited about being involved in physics and talking with others in the physics community.

My dad is a physicist, and my mom is an engineer. I`ve always been interested in STEM and found math very easy. To me, physics seems like the most natural thing to do because I believe it to be the most an important job, figuring out the mysteries of the universe.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience

Response: I had a wonderful (female) high school math teacher that really made both math and pre-calculus fun and interesting. This lead me to pursue a science degree in math in hopes of becoming a high school math teacher. Since the university I attended was so small (University of Alberta, Augustana Campus) I was required to double up my major with physics. After a year of pursuing this I felt that teacher was not the career for me and instead I wanted to apply the interesting concepts I was learning to the world around me. This lead me to consider the world of engineering. I then chose engineering physics firstly because I wasn`t sure what type of engineering I wanted to do and engineering physics gives the most options, and secondly because I wanted to keep learning more about physics and see how it can be used.

When I was in high school, I started considering what degree I wanted to go into. I always knew I wanted to go into something math or science related, and Chemical Engineering really combines the two while allowing me many job opportunities when I graduate. Once I thought about it, Chemical Engineering just made sense because I`ve always been interested in puzzle and building games as a child (and my family members involved in science made sure to get me plenty of those), so that`s what I`ve been pursuing since then. I`ve continued to enjoy it more and more despite the hard work and dedication it takes to continue in this field.
Codes: Utility Value, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience

Response: I first considered physics an option back in high school, and I loved every minute. I didn`t know I wanted to do physics until I did physics related things and realized how much I loved it.

In 2nd grade, we had a science unit on astronomy. We learned about the solar system and phases of the moon, and I found myself actively engaged and interested in school for the first time. I decided to be an astronomer, watching documentaries on space in my free time. I started applying myself in school, reading unassigned chapters of our science textbooks, checking out books on science from the school library, and memorizing extraneous pieces of information on science topics. By middle school I recognized I was good at math, so I decided I would be an astrophysicist because it sounded more involved. My physical sciences teacher in 8th grade gave me a fuller understanding of what physics was. Space as a whole started to feel like it wasnÕt as relevant as other branches of science to understanding everything around us. I decided to be a physicist so I could understand everything, and have the flexibility to specialize in something later on.Unlike most of my classmates I went straight into honors physics my sophomore year. I was 1 of 5 sophomores taking that class, and thus felt isolated. I barely talked during lab and did every assignment without help from study groups. At the end of the year my teacher needed an idea of the number of AP physics books required for the oncoming year. Although terrified at the prospect of underperforming, I raised my hand. The next year, I was the only junior and the only female in the AP physics class. I didn`t know anyone, but they were engaging and non-competitive so I felt more comfortable than the year before. As a senior and only AP physics ÒveteranÓ at the school, I became a TA for my physics teacher. In college IÕve tried harder right off the bat to develop a sense of camaraderie with my classmates. Labs became fun and I learned how to come off as confident without appearing unapproachable. I know how it feels to be isolated, so I try to seem friendly to others who may need help.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Vicarious Experience, Cost (Emotional)

Response: My mom has her PhD in Chemistry, but as a typical teenage daughter, I wanted to be anything but like her. I rejected science as a viable life path. But, my freshman year of high school changed my view completely. I took an introductory physics class and I fell in love almost immediately. A whole course on why the world is the way it is and an explanation for every simple (or complicated) aspect of life; who could not love that? From there I dove in. I petitioned to get higher level courses available at my school, I started a Physics Club, and ultimately went to a Polytechnic Institute in order to further pursue my interests. Every step of the way has only served to reinforce my love for the subject and I couldn`t be more thankful to my high school Physics teacher for inspiring this passion in me.

My science interest started, like most, with Bill Nye and the Magic School Bus, but I eventually graduated to reading pop-science books by people like Brian Green and Brian Cox. During my second year of high school, I took a less-than-satisfactory high school physics course, and I found that the material itself was much more appealing than the class. The following year, I took a physics course at a local university called Life In The Universe. It was a really silly course, designed to be a fun gen-ed, and I loved it. Upon entering college at UT, I enrolled in the Intro Physics class and had a great experience. I was thoroughly challenged, but enjoyed (nearly) every moment of it. I continued my physics major bytaking Classical Mechanics and ended up starting to learn about my professor`s research in Heavy Ion Physics outside of class. That year I joined Relativistic Heavy Ion Physics Group doing research under Dr. Christine Nattrass and have continued that research for the past year and a half. I do data analysis for the ALICE detector group working at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN, and I adore it. I plan on going to grad school and continuing my research in the field.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered

Response: When I took my first physics class in high school, I did the worst that I have ever done in a class. That was when I knew I would study physics. I took the long way though and started in the art field, but then my math teacher told me about the properties of an ellipse and I was hooked. I switched majors to physics and am interested in particle collision.

My father and I have always bonded over the technology, electronics, and mechanics so by the time I entered my junior year in high school I acquired a natural enthusiasm from learning and understanding physics. Because I was so good at it and I enjoyed it over other subjects I decided to major in it and pursue career in the field.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: Ever since I watched my first space documentary as a child, I wanted to learn more about space. I realized over time that physics, astrophysics, and astronomy were tightly bound, so in a way my interest in physics has always been related to my curiosity and fascination with astronomy and astrophysics. For a period in high school, I considered focusing more on biology, since my school had a weak physics program, but a 3-week cosmology summer camp at Stanford reawaked my love for space and physics, and I???ve been determined to study astrophysics ever since.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered

Response: I first got interested in Physics after my Physics Teacher in High School recommended me a Brian Greene book on String Theory. Ever since then, I realized that Physics was so much more than balls rolling down hills and wanted to pursue it in my future. Both of my parents are Electrical Engineers, so they are extremely supportive of my future in STEM, and were influential in helping me realize my dreams of pursuing physics. In addition, that high school physics teacher really provided a lot of support in encouraging my physics education and even found me a summer research job working on the CERN particle accelerator in Geneva. From those experiences, I applied as a physics major to undergraduate studies at Columbia University where I am now studying physics.
Codes: Media Triggered, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I always wanted to do something challenging where I had to work hard in order to achieve success. Growing up, I was always very interested in science and became really interested in astronomy when I hit high school. Eventually I learned that in order to do astronomy, I needed a strong background in physics. When I started my physics major, I knew that this is where I wanted to be and if I ever wanted to branch out into astronomy or another sub-field, then I could.

I was very interested in astronomy. After taking a sequence of Astronomy classes I spoke with the professor on what my options were regarding a major in Astrophysics. He informed me that there was no such degree at the University of Oregon and told me that the best route would be a Physics Major. So I declared the next week. I have struggled through some of the classes but found others really interesting. At this point I am excited to get my degree and be working out in the world.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Utility Value, Cost (Task Effort), Social Persuasion

Response: I did not consider Physics as a viable career option formyself until October of my senior year. I was in the process of applying for a very competitive scholarship,and I was reading the BBC news app during my break. I read the article about the Nobel Prize in Physics thatyear, and it was for the discovery of the Higgs Boson. II always really enjoyed learning about physics, but I did not see it as a option for a career until that moment. The Higgs Boson was theoretically conceived andexperimentally "found by people who spent their wholelives doing physics. As in
Codes: Media Triggered, Physiological/Emotional, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: One of the professors I had is the reason why I chose to go into physics. I have never attended any physics events.

My high school physics class was the first class that challenged me. I found the emphasis on thinking as opposed to memorizing very stimulating and rewarding.When I talked to non-physics peers or people I had just met and it comes up that I am studying physics, many wereimpressed and said something along the lines of "you`re really brave or "I could never do that

Last summer, I participated in a research program where I worked in a nanotechnology facility doing photolithography. Learning how this process works got me interested in material science, so I added a physics minor to accompany my bioengineering degree.

I watch lots of sci-fi and liked the idea of explaining all of the mediocre and bad science. I was on an accelerated math track so it wasnÕt too far off. I had a rough start in the high school physics courses I did but it worked out in the end I guess. I feel really satisfied and fulfilled when i can walk through the motion and story of each word problem.

Una Contempladora de las estrellasÒKarla look at this!Ó yelled my twelve-year- old brother. He ran to show me an astronomical video, ÒTen Scary Yet Beautiful Facts about Space and Us,Ó which Immediately caught my attention and aroused my interest in astrophysics and physics. Ever since I have become extremely passionate about these subjects. It all seems bizarrely unbelievable. This curiosity forces me to transcend the temptation to put an end to all my questions. Questions such as, what would it feel like to be orbiting near a merging black hole, is terrifying but it is this kind of question that motivates me to become an astrophysicist and pursue what other astrophysicists have done and much more. I would like to make my own discoveries and work with theories to prove them right or wrong and thereby help fully explain them. I also would love to create my own theories that will depict the work I have done to satisfy these interests of mine. Such wonder drives me into an unknown and enchanted universe whose beauty illuminates my imagination. Research and discovery that I have done through online websites, books, documentaries, observatories, university seminars/events and with the Society of Physics Students have put me through sleepless nights because I have an unquenchable desire to learn more. This quest has allowed me to understand that everything in life has value and that is why I should cherish the earth I call home. Not only should I take care of it, but, furthermore, I should study and understand it as well as my immediate surroundings. Knowledge is infinite; not all can be known; but it can be further understood.

Ever since a National Geographic for Kids article on black holes, I`ve been fascinated by astronomy.I didn`t really consider physics as an option until a bit later, when I really enjoyed my high school math courses.Both of my parents are electrical engineers, so I had a lot of support from home when it came to math and science courses.Their dinner table conversations also sparked my interest from a young age.Since then, friends and a drive for answers have kept me going on this path.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: I attended the spring camp in high school and I had an opportunities to helping to build a camp and also participate in water rocket launching game. I think physics is very cool and practical.

In high school I enjoyed physics but my teaches wasn`t the best and so I didn`t see physics as a potential major. Also in high school guidance counselors continuously pushed me towards non-science topics because I excelled in those courses. It wasn`t until I spent a year out of high schoolthat I realized that I wanted to major in something that I was truly interested in. My first year in college I did not take any physics courses and was continuously discouraged when other students questioned my major choice and made comments about physics being hard. Currently being in my first college physics class I do find it hard, after all I am no genius, but I am willing to study because I am interested in physics.

I really enjoyed knowing how the world works, and how to apply math to see the world in a unique way. Along the way, I met students that I really connected with, and professors that I looked up to that convinced me that I could pursue this area of study and be successful.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: Despite my initial dislike of physics in high school, I grew to love it when I came to college. With my fascination with the topics within physics, the collaborative and supportive physics community, and an opportunity-filled field to enter, I have genuinely come to love physics.

My interest in physics increased through my participation in a club called Science Olympiad in high school where I began studying more outside the classroom. My parents, peers, and teachers high level of confidence in my math and science abilities, as well as my growing interest in the subject led my decision to major in physics.
Codes: Event Triggered, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: My father became an electrical engineer in his home country (Burma), and told me many stories about how he would fix old radios for older people. I always saw myself fixing things so I decided that physics would be the way to go.
The subject itself is really interesting to me and I love problem solving. I also think my parents were very encouraging in supporting my decision to study physics.

In second grade, I wanted to be an astronaut like everyone else did - the inspiration being the first Indian woman astronaut, Kalpana Chawla. I assumed thatastronauts needed to know astronomy and I asked myparents for books about it. I found I enjoyed astronomy and astrophysics and never missed a chance to learn more about the subjects. I decided I would pursue adegree in Physics as an undergraduate, and specializein astrophysics later on.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Utility Value

Response: Science was always interesting, and I thought in high school that extreme outer space conditions, such as black holes and absolute zero, were really interesting. I decided to study astronomy, and soon realized that it was part of physics and added it as a major.

My interest in physics initially began from my senior physics class in high school along side my interest in space and time. I would research topics and books about the many fields of physics. Then as a freshman in college I attended colloquiums and gained more insight and decided to participate in an REU. From there I remained active in research and presentations, including presenting my own research at several conferences, and continue to do so today.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Event Triggered

Response: I first became interested in physics in high school after taking it my senior year. Once I continued my physics journey in college I fell in love with the subject and the professor is absolutely incredible, so now I am continuing it.

My grandfather was a dean in physics in the Philippines. I took a physics course in high school and felt that it was interesting. I went on to take physics courses in college and decided to make physics my major.

Due to a general essence of gender rolls and expectations, I never considered the possibility of pursuing a science based education or career. However, over a year ago when the Mars One project was getting off the ground, I was faced with the reality of my passion for space exploration and the science of it. It was an epiphany of sorts that lead to me deciding on becoming a full time engineering student. I am now 4 semesters in to this journey, and so satisfied with this decision. Because I had an incredibly weak science and mathematics background, I had a play a lot of catch up, and so my first official physics course isn`t until next semester but I am deeply interested in and dedicated to the subject.

I was often pushed to excel by my high school physics teacher and upon coming to Fredoniamy professor for Physics II convinced me I would excel as a physics major. I hada lot of support by many different teachers and professors in my educational path.

Learning physics in high school was very interesting and seemingly easy for me compared to other students, which lead to where I am today. I began as a minor in physics as a freshman in college, and after my very first physics class I was hooked! I added on a physics major, and I am really enjoying my studies thus far.

I loved high school AP physics. I was really good at it, and my teacher really encouraged me. Now, as a biophysics major, I feel that I have the best of both worlds because I have resources in both physics and biology.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience

Response: Looking up into the sky with my dad and wondering why things work as they do. My dad is a plumber and taught me early on about how and why things happen in the world. I feel like it was meant to be since I was a child.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Attainment Value

Response: I have never considered studying anything but physics. My father always encouraged me and worked with me outside of regular school to cultivate this interest. I was initially good at math, but I was disinterested in numbers in the abstract. Physics explained phenomena I saw around me and therefore interested me immensely. I`ve always thought I`d be happiest if I were able to have a career in which I am constantly learning and using Physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional

Response: I have always been interested in the way things work, which eventually led me to biology. But with time I realized that more than anything I just wanted to take physics to learn about outer space, and the true mechanisms behind everything we do and see. I took a physics class at the Santa Rosa Junior College with Professor Lynda Williams, and that was when I realized that I was going to be a physics major.
I watched the Cosmos by Carl Sagan and read books about Elon Musk and Nikola Tesla. Because of these, I have been intrigued by physics and technology.
I really love space, and a physics degree will get me to be where I wanna be.

I have always been inclined towards mathematics and the sciences even from my elementary school days. I finally took my first physics class in my junior year of high school and developed such an interest towards the field that I decided I would major in physics once I get to university.

The main reason that I have become a physics major is because I am interested in becoming an astronomer,and I am pursuing a astronomy major, so it made sense to add a physics major to that, since it only required a few additional classes. I also enjoyed physics in high school so I thought I would continue it at a higher education.

When I was 10 and I picked up a book about astronomy. It was fascinating. Then in high school, I like Physics the most due to the fact that I can derive the equations and not memorize everything. But what sealed the deal for me was when my high school Physics teacher pushed me to continue in the Physics field.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion

Response: I took an introductory course with a wonderful professor and greatly enjoyed the topics more than any other course so I added physics as a minor after that I switched to a double major and realized I wanted to keep studying physics for the rest of my life.

The first time I realized I wanted to study physics I was inhigh school. I was a terrible student, skipping class all the time and always getting into trouble. That was until my junior year when I had my first physics class. I found it interestingand it was the first thing that actually challenged me in schoolI started going to class, paying attention, and doing homework. I got my first A ever in high school at the end of that year and I had finally found something that I wanted to do with my life. All of a sudden I wanted to go to college. I even begged and pleadedthe school to allow me to take the AP physics class my senior year, which was reserved for honors students (which I was not). They finally relented and allowed me to take it as an elective, not forAP credit. I was one of a few kids in the class who got an A.I went on a to community college in the hopes of improving my grades enough to go to a four year school andmajor in physics. My first semester there the professor told me he didn`t think I was bright enough to be a physics major (his words exactly) and so I left school, as it was the only thing I wanted to do. 13 years later I still regretted that and decided to try again. I went to a community college for a couple of years where I did take Physics I and II and that was I all I needed to remind me of why I had fallen inlove with it in the first place. When I graduated from there I moved on to a 4 year school where I finally became I physics major. I have loved every moment of it and every class I have taken has just increased my passion for the subject. In particular, Iwas offered the opportunity to do a summer research project after my first semester at the four year school and it was the the thing I needed to help me realize that I could survive beinga physics major. It was the boost to my confidence I needed.I have subsequently done another summer of research and someduring the semesters as well and it has been life changing.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience, Cost (Emotional), Event Triggered

Response: High school physics was when I learned that this topic interested me. I enjoyed the hands on activities and labs. I also loved how the physics applied to the real world.

I walked out of high school swearing to never take another physics course (even though I intended to be an engineer). Then I got into my college summer bridge program which every year teaches one science course. My year it happened to be physics that was the science. I had always loved astronomy. I grew up as a little kid obsessed with the stars wanting to one day go visit them (and then I learned how far is far).We had a physics professor and an astronomy professor as the professors co teaching the science course at the bridge program. Then we were asked to create poster presentations on anything that we had learned about during the summer. I chose planetary nebulae. I formed such a good connection with both science professors and thoroughly enjoyed the science course (a mash of astronomy and optics) that I decided to take the intro physics course (named: Spacetime and Quantum) along with the intro engineering course to see if maybe leaving engineering for physics what the right move. And it was. I found myself more engaged with physics than engineering, which combined with my love for astronomy made astrophysics the right move. However, materials physics has been increasingly on my radar.

In high school I wanted to go into aerospace engineering. Decided my senior year being a high school math teacher would be a better way to give back to my community.  I realized the math I loved is centered on physics and isn`t covered in most high school curriculums.  I Reflected on a phenomenal (and challenging) two years of AP physics in high school with a Top Tier teacher and decided I would find a way to give back to my community (or any community) through a physics base career path.  I am very interested in organizations like Astronomers and Engineers without borders which offer a chance to use physics and engineering as outreach to folks all over the world.  I switched majors from math-ed to a dual degree (3-2 program) in physics and mechanical engineering.  I`m in my last year of physics coursework and will begin my two years of engineering coursework next fall. I`m unsure of what exactly I`ll do after undergrad, but I`m leaning towards grad school, though I`m not opposed to industry.  Reflecting back, from the very beginning, once I got into my AP physics courses I was in the minority in two ways:  I was in a lower math class than most of my peers, secondly, I was female.  Instead of feeling inferior this made me proud and I worked even harder to prove I belonged there.  Fortunately, my teacher was a great mentor and helped me to understand that I didn`t need to compensate to prove I belonged in the class.  When I was off in college and faced with the option to pursue physics at a higher level, it was those lessons and the inspiration of my classmates who pursued similar academic paths that helped me to realize if the field was really something I wanted to study, the path was mine for the taking.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Utility Value, Vicarious Experience, Attainment Value

Response: I was always interested in the field of medicine, but after taking several chemistry and biology courses in university, I found that I did not enjoy that aspect of medicine as much as I thought I would. However, due to many amazing physics professors, my interest in physics increased dramatically, and I explored the options of physics in medicine, and I settled on nuclear medicine

When I was taking general physics, my professor (the chair of the Physics department) suggested that I consider switching my major to physics. After some consideration, I discovered that I was in factor more interested in physics than any of my other subjects, so I switched. Though interest in physics helped, I would not have gotten where I am without the encouragement of our wonderful physics department faculty.

I first considered becoming a physics major after doing well in my high school physics class. My student teacher was very enthusiastic and a good teacher, and his encouragement led me to consider becoming a physics major. My parents also pushed me to become a physics major.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: I took physics in high school and was terrible. I had no intentions of studyingit in college. But I loved math and it came so easily to me so I decided to givephysics another shot my freshman fall and couldn`t have asked for a betteroutcome. I fell in love with the topic, the physics faculty department, and the other students. I decided I wanted to continue taking courses and declared myphysics major my sophomore year. I really yearned for answers to my questions about understanding the world around me and physics was begin to brush the surface of the knowledge we have gathered. The teachers were one of the strongest pulls for me becoming a physics major: their enthusiasm and passion shows through every class. I would say that physics doesn`t come as intuitively to meas it does with with other students and I struggle to explain physics to non-majors. That being said, I work really hard at the subject and hope to go to graduateschool either in physics or in engineering.

Physics has been the only subject that has kept me interested while also challenging me. Also being accepted into a summer research program and continuing with multiple research and industry internships really gave me the push that I needed towards science research and physics that made me realize that I wanted to do this as a career.

When I was a kid I had a book about outer space, and I would read it all the time.
