From there I became interested in astronomy - which I found out was a branch of physics.Living near FermiLab allowed me to explore the world of physics in high school through their educaiton programs, and I realized that I was really interested in high energy and astro physics.Going into college, I wasn`t a physics major because I didn`t think that I had a large enough interest. But from the second I got on campus I realized that I already missed it and decided to add a physics major on my first day.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered

Response: Since i was a kid, i was very curious and my dad used to explain me all about physics and mechanics with books and encyclopedias to show me how everything worked. As i grew up, i was still curious and some appliances that dint worked out (relativity).
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Attainment Value

Response: As a child, I was always extremely curious. I asked my dad lots and lots of questions, and he encouraged my curiosity, answering my questions as best as he could. In middle school, I learned the physical basis of heat and temperature, and my mind was blown by the knowledge that everyday experiences could be understood as physical phenomena. This is when I became interested in physics in particular. I liked all of my science classes, but I particularly liked my first physics class in high school. I liked the idea of being able to explain anything in the universe, and I also really liked math. My high school (Brooklyn Technical High School) had majors, so I became a physics major. This naturally lead to becoming a math and physics major at Cornell.

I detested physics initially but became involved at a collegiate level from coming to college a month early for a research group called Summer Opportunities for Intellectual Achievement (SoFIA). SoFIA provided my first hands on real world experience with physics through using an arduino package I designed to explore the physics behind roller coasters. Seeing an experiment through from design to finish and seeing concepts I had previously learned about enacted in real life got me hooked not on phonics but "hooked on physics" and I have not looked back. Since then I have done research in areas of condensed matter physics, astrophysics, observational astronomy, and most recently nuclear agriculture. Mainly it has been the support of my faculty and research experiences that have motivated me to stick with the discipline.
Codes: Event Triggered, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: Primarily as a double major to the astronomy major, where my primary interest is focused.

My high school physics teacher inspired me to take AP Physics my senior year! I enjoyed and excelled in the class, despite there being only two girls, me being one of them. I decided to pursue physics in college.
I watched/read a lot of science fiction, participated in a lot of science fairs, and fell in love with math.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Event Triggered

Response: Physics has been a passions ever since my first research experience at The College of Wooster during the summer of 2013. I worked with my advisor on a experimental research project in the field of soft condensed matter. Ever since, my love for physics has increased and I am interested in pursuing it is a career. I worked at Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory last summer, and that experience gave me a well rounded view of physics and the states of women in Physics. I was amazed by the men and women ratio and I hope to be able to make a difference in the near future. Being an international student from India, I was not exposed to the culture of research before, and I am very keen on continuing in the direction I am in right now. What I love most about research is that is is not a nine to five job- It encompasses my thoughts and actions at all times- and this is what has drawn me to this field of science.

I began considering physics after the first reading of one of Stephen Hawkings popular science books in middle school, and as I learned more and faced more challenges I became even more invested in the field and determined to make a significant contribution.
I took a two-year IB Physics course which was my first exposure to that area of science and I immediately fell in love with it.

I`ve been fascinated astronomy since I was a young child and bought my first telescope at about 10-years-old. I`ve always excelled in my STEM classes, however, I was raised in a traditional home that discouraged these pursuits because I`m female. After a few years of taking social work college classes to please my mom, I finally had the courage to pursue a physics bachelors degree, despite it upsetting my parents. I feel completely comfortable in the physics community and genuinely enjoy my classes and reading research outside of class. I finally fit in with my peers and enjoy discussing physics related topics with my universities professors. I feel the most centered and grounded when I`m working on physics and calculus problems. I feel like physics encompasses the various fields I`m passionate about as well, including mathematics, geology, astronomy, and of course, physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Mastery Experience, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic (Social), Physiological/Emotional

Response: When I was five-years-old, my kindergarten teacher recommended me to take a series of cognitive tests so I could skip grades. My examiner told my parents I would make an excellent physicist. Apart from that, I`ve always found myself drawn to fundamental questions about our universe, and I found more answers in my physics courses rather than philosophy courses.

I took an introductory course that combined physics, chemistry, and biology, and I succeeded in physics more than the other two disciplines. I saw a talk about some research that applied physics to the study of fish behavior, which was something that I was previously interested in. Then I met a really great professor in my department who got me really excited about physics and helped me see the flexibility that would come with a degree in physics.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Event Triggered, Social Persuasion

Response: I began considering physics when I took AP Physics in High School. Physics helped me understand chemistry (which I had almost failed the semester before) which was very important to me because I can accept failure as long as I can redeem myself. What I mean by this is I was distraught when I first failed chemistry but now that I understand and grasp the materials I am quite glad that I failed, it gave me motivation to revisit the materials while taking AP Physics. I also find the contents on physics and have developed my way of thinking through that of a physicists mindset.

I was in 5th grade and I had to bring a robot-like to class. My grandfather is an engineer and sat with me to develop my own instead of buying a remote robot. He thought me how torque through a rubber band could make an object move in a circular matter with enough tension. we build a dog robot with things that you could find anywhere. I was really motivated and impressed by the creating. Later on I got really into knowing how things work. I started taking things apart and trying to put them back together. The support from my grandfather, and the care and knowledge he has towards his career made me want to understand things in a different level.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: I have known for a long time that I wanted to be a scientist; my constantly watching "Bill Nye the Science Guy, "Cosmos

Intended to major in astronomy/astrophysics since middle school/preteen. I watched a lot of the science channel and discovery channel, saw myself through Dr. Michelle Thaller on How the Universe Works. Had a negative experience in HS physics due to the teacher, who told me I was wasting my time looking into astronomy, and that I was getting into college because of my gender, as if I was some diversity requirement. Decided to just major in astronomy because I was told all people in physics would treat me the same way. Convinced quickly during my first year of college that UMD physics department was not as bad as I thought it would be, and that a double major would help me in my future, and would not put me in uncomfortable situations the way that my high school experience did.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic (Social), Vicarious Experience

Response: I`ve always been interested in Physics, but have always been intimidated by it. First quarter did not go very well, I thought I was not smart enough to pursue physics. I often felt that I needed more time and explanation for topics, but when I asked other students, many of whom had seen a lot of what we were doing in high school, I felt inferior. I did the second quarter to finish the sequence and I really, really liked electromagnetism. I finished the intro sequence and continued with it this year. Even though I did not feel smart enough I wanted to give myself a fighting chance. The first week of classes this quarter I was panicked about the level of difficulty of classes. I felt very lost and inadequate when trying to work on the problem sets. I finally talked to others and found that many people were as lost as I was. We all came together and the sense of community and support was what convinced me to commit to the physics major.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Task Effort), Intrinsic (Social), Social Persuasion

Response: I`ve always loved and been good at science. In middle school I thought I wanted to go into veterinary medicine but then I shadowed a vet and was kinda bored. I went to physics after school programs at MIT and Harvard during high school and got really interested in Black Holes and dark matter and relativity etc. I took an intro physics class in high school and loved it. It was exactly the type of puzzles that I loved, it was mental puzzle not the hands on puzzles people tried to throw at me and had the right amount of math (to say a lot but not for the sake of math, for the sake of understanding the world around me). It also just made the rules of the world much more apparent.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered

Response: I really enjoyed physics classes in high school and my mom has always encouraged me to do physics because she got her masters in physics

My first main interest was in astronomy, I used to watch documentaries on space travel when I was younger and watched more as I entered high school. Around high school, I noticed a lot of the speakers on the documentaries held the title `Astrophysics`. After looking up the occupation, I decided that was the one for me, and took AP Physics I my third year of high school to see if I really did like physics. I enjoyed the class, and when I went to college I selected my major to be astrophysics. Now I`m here.
I took a few astronomy courses at community college and one of my professors encouraged me to pursue physics. I want to challenge myself and hopefully turn my interest in the subject into a career.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: I took AP Physics and AP Calculus in my senior year of high school. Both of my teacherswere very good and inspired me and believed in me. I fell in love with math and physicsand with my teachers` support, I decided to pursue a degree in Physics and Math.I also met two astrophysicists at a physics event my senior year, heard about what theydid for a living, and decided that that is what I wanted to do. I never had the highest grade in my classes, but I always enjoyed them, and that stood out to my teachers and professors,and that is why I have been successful and stuck with this difficult degree.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional

Response: I started become interested in astronomy, so I started reading some books. Then, I read a page on black holes and became fascinated by it, so I decided to go into astrophysics. I think I have always been curious about how nature works.

Applied Associates of Science in Integrated Systems Technology. Will pursue Bachelor`s in Engineering Technology with a minor in Physics. Physics is the foundation of my discipline and it is imperative that I comprehend it.

The events that led to me becoming a physics major occurred long before I ever considered physics as an option. It began with my love of language, instilled within me at an early age by my grandmother. When I was first introduced to physics in high school, it was fun, and I saw it more as a puzzle than anything else. That was enough reason for me to pursue physics as an option, since while I could delve into my other interests of literature and art independently, physics required more tutelage. In my second summer of research following my sophomore year of undergrad, I learned to see mathematics as a language for communicating the ideas of physics. This initiated a paradigm shift in how I approached physics as a discipline. In achieving the status of an aesthetic subject, my relation to physics was transformed. It was no longer simply an option for the types of puzzles with which to occupy my time. Instead, I knew I had become Tantalus, standing in the pool of the universe, forever reaching in a futile attempt to assuage my hunger for knowledge with the fruits of physics.

I always enjoyed math and science, and loved space as a child. It wasn`t until around middle school that I realized I could pursue astrophysics as a career and the idea of studying space thrilled me. I set my sights on top universities early on in high school. While opportunities to learn astrophysics in high school were limited, I took them where I could. I`m now a first-year at Yale and a perspective astrophysics and religious studies double major. As much as I love STEM, I can`t imagine my education without the humanities as well. In the future, I hope to do research regarding dark matter or black holes, one day I hope to study the intersections of religion and our desire to study space, and I`m still debating whether I want to pursue my PhD or a law degree to do international space policy.

I`m an astrophysics major and I seriously started considering it in high school. I can`t think of one main experience or event that led to me choosing to study that. I have loved Astronomy ever since I was young. At around 6 years old, I had cheap, plastic telescope that I would stare at the moon with on clear nights. Then on my sixteenth birthday I graduated to a Celestron telescope.

I first considered physics entering as a freshman into college. I spent much time with my grandfather, who was a retired mathematician was a fascination for physics. After his death, maybe in order to reconnect or out of curiosity I majored in physics. I had always exceled at math, and indeed in intro physics the concepts were manageable and fun to learn. I wanted to do something hard, and physics was what I came up with. As well sophomore year I bonded with fellow physics students forming a good support network.
I was always really interested in how things worked. Physics for a long time just always made sense, both intellectually and as a good plan for the future.

My family really encouraged me from a young age to go into science, my parents bought me books on constellations and a telescope and I really enjoyed it. When I got older, I wanted to be an artist and didn`t becoming a scientist again until I was at an art program my junior year of high school and didn`t feel like I was doing what I wanted. My physics teacher in high school when I told him I wanted to go into physics told me that he could really see me doing that and my math teacher described me as a star in math. When I got to college a big factor why I stayed in physics was my job in research.

I used to feel inadequate and incapable in science courses, but my high school physics teacher made physics understandable. Then, I joined the astronomy club and read article after article, determined to learn more about physics. I never would have imagined myself pursuing a degree in physics, but here I am!
Codes: Cost (Emotional), Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic (Social), Media Triggered

Response: My interest in physics started in my high school physics class. I then started my freshman year of college as an Engineering Physics major. As I took more physics courses, such as modern physics, classical mechanics and thermodynamics, I realized that there was a lot in physics that I did not know about. The transition from classical physics to modern physics was a bit tough for me, so I began to focus more on Engineering courses. However, after taking some Electrical Engineering courses, I realized the importance of physics in the engineering field. This drew me more back to the physics courses. I have now decided to complete my bachelors degree in Physics and Electrical Engineering.

I just really thought physics seemed like the most worth while thing fir me to study if I could indeed study anything I wanted to. I honestly thought that I would be :weeded out" so to speak but the first year of my physics courses was surprisingly encouraging. I have since had many struggles in my physics classes, with my mental health, etc.. which have deterred me more from pursuing the physics PhD I used to dream of. Nowadays I`m interested in what else I can do with my physics education and passion for learning and teaching other physics. As well as the skills I`ve picked up in taking classes for my neuroscience concentration. I could see myself analyzing data, doing something w/ medical physics, teching physics at a college level, or some other interdisciplinary work involving any set of my interests.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Outside Effort), Utility Value

Response: I thought that I wanted to complete a 3-2 engineering program when I first came to college so I took the required physics courses and became very interested in the topic. At the time, the department seemed very welcoming and since I had a newfound passion for the subject, I decided to major in physics (and math) which I thought would keep my options open for physics or engineering grad school.

I had first been exposed to physics in a meaningful way through my AP physics classes and developed an interest from there, and have read some books and attended programs that have furthered my passion for physics.

I began my college experience with diving into pre-med studies, which introduced me to physics and I fell in love with the study and all of its wondrous applications, such as astronomy. I have since gone on to write a peer reviewed research paper on double star observations of a system near Leo. I am currently writing two more papers on systems near Hercules and Fornax. I still get lost in self doubt though and am constantly pondering whether it`s imposter syndrome or if I`m just bad at it.

I did well in my physics classes while in the engineering major, was disillusioned by engineering, and decided to switch to physics. My grades improved and I met a lot of people that have become very good friends of mine.

When I was a little girl, I wanted to be an astronaut. I have always been fascinated with the Moon and stars, and nature in general. In middle school, I got very interested in my Biology and Physics courses. I loved them both. When I came to an orientation on Campus, I was introduced to Biophysics, and I really thought this was a great opportunity to learn and get involved in what I wanted. No that I am a Physics student, I can say that this is the most beautiful, challenging, excited and mysterious, wise decision I have ever taken.
Codes: Utility Value, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Intrnsic Value (Biophysics)

Response: Father got his master`s in physics and sister got her bachelor`s in physics. Science exposure at a young age.

I really liked the small amout of physics I did during AP Calc my junior year. From that I took physics my senior year and really ejoyed seeing the relationship between math and physics. That caused me to consider a double math and physics major. I will continue down that path of a math and physics double major.

I liked physics in high school, but I was not the best at it. I saw myself getting better at it if I studied it further; the subject was very interesting to me as a whole. When I got to college I completely fell in love with the subject.

I always knew I wanted to pursue science but was never sure of the direction until I took high school physics my junior year. I really enjoyed the math application and I`d always really loved astronomy so I grabbed that and ran with it.

I have had a talent for math since grade school and have always loved the maths and sciences. I worked as a medical assistant for about five years, but wanted more for a career path. I decided to strive towards an associates degree in pre-engineering and continue towards a bachelors in either biochemical or bio-medical engineering with possibilities for furthering to masters and doctoral degrees.

Growing up I always loved watching shows about space, the universe, etc. I am in love with the idea of being able to take these concepts to explore things bigger than ourselves, it is all so interesting and beautiful. Another reason I would choose to go with something so hard is that I really don`t want to be like my family. I love them, but they did nothing with their lives. My mom didn`t even graduate high school, and she hates her job. Its hard on her, and she struggles to pay bills. I don`t want to be 45 years old and in her spot, I want to do something that I love, and physics is exactly that.
Codes: Media Triggered, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value

Response: I`ve always wanted to be an astronaut.

Astronomy has always interested me, but it wasnt until I took physics in high school that I actually considered majoring in it. I think I liked that physics explained how the world works, and can be applied to so many aspects of life.

My first experience with physics was when I was around the age of eight and I would stay after school for a science club where we would do physics related experiments, such as experiments with buoyancy and pressure and what would happen when you squeeze a bottle with a tiny object inside. It was fun to see an introduction application of how science is involved in our world, and that is what sparked my first interest. Over the years I would have teachers give me tons of science books about geology, biology, physics, and so on that I ended up loving everything. During my final year of 5th grade, I had a math teacher who would always encourage me seek out what NASA was doing and encouraged me to look into careers in physics and engineering. From her encouragement, I ended up obsessing about the curiosity rover, engineering, math, and the idea of being able to figure out plans and inventions to help us learn more about the universe we live in. What finally inspired to pursue a specific career in Aerospace Engineering was when I attended an air show where old World War II planes were being shown and flown. Watching these huge pieces of metal fly in the air so effortlessly and talking to a few of the engineers is what convinced me to follow Aerospace as my future because not only did it involve planes, but it had a combination of physics, chemistry, astronomy, and other subjects I loved.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Media Triggered

Response: When I started college, I didn`t consider physics even though I enjoyed it in high school. I hadn`t let myself consider the option because I thought it would be too hard for me. But I am friends with a female physics major who was a senior when I was a first year, and we went on a run together and as I listened to her talk with such enthusiasm about her physics classes and research, I remembered how much I enjoyed it in high school. I allowed myself to consider the possibility, and now I am on this path! It is tough but worth it, and I feel supported by the sense of community in the physics department of my university.

I never considered the possibility of a career in physics until my second semester in college when my counselor sat me down to talk about my future. The conversation started out with Òwhat do you want to be in the futureÓ and of course I did not have an answer. My counselor began to ask me questions about what my hobbies were and my interests and I found myself talking about the universe which has always been a major topic of interest for me. After a while my counselor urged me to consider a career in physics which could later lead to a job in astrophysics. This was the first time I had ever considered pursuing a degree in physics. I decided to take an introduction class into the field and immediately fell in love with the subject. Where Astrophysics had drawn my attention to the field, the vast career options held my interest. I still hope to obtain a Ph.D in astrophysics but I am more open to other opportunities in physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: My modern physics professor was really encouraging about thepossibilities of a career in physics research, and I had always been interested in physics, but before thought that being a physicist was like becoming the president, a dream too unrealistic to be true.

I changed from being a biology major to a physics one my second week of college because I thought it would be more helpful for when I take the MCAT. As time went by I realized the concepts involving physics were very intriguing and decided to change concentrations from pre-med to pure physics to pursue the path of astrophysics.

By the time I got to high school I somehow knew I was going to study science in college. It wasn`t until I took my first physics course as a junior in high school that I was exposed to physics and immediately decided that pursuing physics was the path for me. My parents both have degrees in science: chemistry and materials science. It is with their encouragement, particularly from my father, that I began studying physics in college.My high school physics teacher also firmly believed that I could contribute to physics and said so in writing to me when I left my (very white, privileged, public) high school.My first semester of physics was quite discouraging- I had no idea that I would feel so uncomfortable in my classroom. I happen to be very stubborn as well as passionate about physics however, and so I was determined to not be a female attrition statistic.Since then I have gotten to know all of my classmates, found a fantastic undergrad mentor, been elected the leader of our undergraduate group at Brown, and overcome many fears of interacting with professors, and so I feel more comfortable pursuing physics as an undergrad. I still struggle to find my voice in my lecture classes at times, and am still figuring out which areas of physics I am best suited to, but I am firmly committed to getting my PhD in physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Cost (Emotional), Attainment Value, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: In high school I was really intrigued by physics topicsoutside of the classroom curriculum, and that led me todevelop a passion for physics that continues today.

The first time I considered physics was when I was a Sophomore in college and I took my first course in physics. I had always loved astronomy, but I never realized how curious I was about physics. I then decided to minor in physics, and transferred to a school where I could be an astronomy major. However, after speaking to the Chair of the Physics Department, I decided to get a degree in Physics and a degree in Astronomy. This is my second year as a physics major and I have had support from the entire department my entire time in New Paltz.

I first took physics my junior year of high school and loved it - I realized I had the mindset for such calculations and excelled in the class.In my senior year physics class, we watched a video on string theory and I fell in love with the theoretical side of physics.I originally entered college intending to major in nursing because I didn`t think I could get a job with a physics major, but that changed when my advisor told me I was too smart to be a nurse. Consequently, that advisor was a physics professor.I changed my major to Physics and Mathematics my second semester of college, even though the introductory levels of physics classes were boring to me.During "May Term - an extra term in which physics majors can learn research techniques - I learned about particle physics for the first time
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Social Persuasion

Response: I became a physics major to my continued interest in mathematics throughout my education. I always felt comfortable with equations and numbers and my interest in astronomy, as well as the encouragement of my mother, drew me to pursue physics. I think my continued interest in physics can be attributed to the continued encouragement of the faculty in the astronomy department.

I first decided I wanted to do physics in high school. I took a physics course my senior year and loved it! When I went off to college, I originally wanted to do Astrophysics. After taking my first Astronomy class, I decided it wasn`t for me. I was so worried that I would not find an area of physics that I would love. I did, and it was through a Physics Colloquium class that I learned about Medical Physics. I researched it more than any other career option and found it was a perfect fit with me.    I struggled in my last few years of physics though. I took a physics class at my university that, for the first time in my life, I failed. That started the feelings of not being good enough in physics. That doubt made me struggle with the rest of my physics classes. It wasn`t until this past year, when I founded our women in physics club and took one of the best classes that I started to think I could do it again. Being involved in the physic community and learning how to teach physics has helped me so much. I won`t graduate with a great GPA. But my experiences have made me a better student and even physicist. This doesn`t mean I won`t struggle any more though, as I have run across countless hindrances in the past few months. But at least I know I can get through it!
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value (Medical), Cost (Task Effort), Intrinsic (Social)

Response: The first time I took physics was my senior year in high school. I did not have any understanding of what physics was. I ended up doing very well in the class and really enjoyed the material that I learned. I did not decide to major in physics until the second semester of my freshman year in college. I originally was going to do business because I was a little intimidated by majoring in physics and I was not really sure what options there were for careers with a degree in physics. I started doing some research on options for physics careers once I realized I would have to take accounting classes. I found some things that seemed interesting enough that made me want to change my major to Physics. I am still very happy with my decision, but I am still not completely sure of what path I may take for a career when I am done with school.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: Research experiences in physics influenced my desire to pursue physics
My desire to understand the fundamentals of nature and reality with the intentions to dig deeper and be surrounded by people who thing about the world.

I first considered physics as a career path in high school due to the influence and support of my physics teacher. When I first entered college, however, I was not yet sure that I wanted to do pure academic physics, and I took several classes that were physics related (physics of music, acoustics, etc) in order to see if I liked the material. The deciding factor for me came in my sophomore year when I joined the research project of a professor in the astronomy department. Working on the project in combination with his influence helped me decide to combine my enjoyment of physics with another area that I find very interesting -astronomy- and pursue an astrophysics degree.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: I started my collegiate career as a political science major - I originally had little to noinclination to study any math-heavy major, let alone physics. About a year in to my degree program, however,I realized I was beginning to miss calculus (which I had taken as an elective in high school), and I was continually frustrated by what I saw as a lack of clarity or usefulness in any of the theoremswe were being taught in public policy and other political science classes. Our school hadjust hired a new physics professor, so - following my sister, who was a history major and also missingmath - I switched majors, I and have been thoroughly pleased with my decision. Nothing is more thrillingthan learning about the major underlying mechanics of the universe, and I am happy to know that there are a number of fields of applied physics that will allow me to put my education to good use. I will admit,the switch from no physics and math to days packed full of it were difficult, but the continual supportof my professors and classmates has helped me along the way towards becoming a better student and, hopefully,an accomplished physicist someday.

I came to Wellesley wanting to major in Environmental Engineering. This is not an option so I thought my next best option was to get knowledge in physics and chemistry. I spoke to the faculty in the major and they all seem really welcoming. I participated in research last summer that had to do with chemistry, physics, and environmental science and it really cemented my decision.
Codes: Utility Value, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I have always been interested in physics, but I really became involved in it and considered the possibility of majoring in it during the spring semester of 2014. I was an electrical engineering major, and due to this interest and opportunity, I was able to add a physics major. I always enjoyed my physics courses, but it was the outside reading that really sparked my desire to major in physics. I have a decent collection of books on different physics topics and the history of development of different theories and discoveries. This collection keeps growing, and this outside reading fuels my love for physics.
I was always interested in science, and developed a more academic interest during my high school physics class.

Applying to Sonoma State University I declared as a Physics Major coming into my first year. I had enjoyed Math in high school and saw the applications in my AP Physics class. I loved learning the Physics material. However I had a terrible experience in my HS Physics class due to the other students, teacher and the structure of favoritism that I felt other students were receiving.I was not receiving adequate help and did not even attempt the AP test. It is my goal to become a High School Physics teacher so that our future generations of Physics Majors feel prepared and ready to take Physics college courses and pursue Careers in STEM fields.

Had a bad physics teacher in high school but still did well and really understood the material. That experience started me down the path. When I got further into the topic, the thought process and problem solving approach was something that I really connected with.

I have always been interested in physics. I found it fascinating because it deals with the largest and smallest things in the universe. To me, physics was all about learning how the world works and that is why I love it.

My first approach to science and the most important for me was a book about rocks and minerals that was in English that my aunt gave me when I was a kid. I rememberthe weeks that I spent trying to translate every detail that I could and then writing what I discovered on a notebook. I started to collect minerals and classify them depending on their characteristics. Those days werevery important to me.I have always liked to learn new things. I had many questions that I thought that school would answer me: The meaning of gravity, the origin of the stars and the universe. As time passed and I grew older, I became fascinated not only with the structures of rocks and minerals, but with particle physics and theories of multiple dimensions.

I did well in physics in high school. I love the applications of physics in daily life.My country, Malaysia, just started to work on space science seriously. I feel excited about it, so I wanted to learn more & contribute to my country.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I first became interested in physics after attending the United States Space Camp in Huntsville, Alabama right before starting high school. After having that amazing experience, I knew in high school that I wanted to focus heavily on different sciences and math to help me find the right path for me. After taking AP Physics my senior year, I knew that was what I wanted to study in college.  During my sophomore year of college, I started getting interested in different fields and was discouraged that I wasn`t doing as well in my physics class that I had hoped. My professor for that class brought me to the side and told me that he knew what I was capable of and gave me the confidence I needed to be able to strive in physics. After that talk, I knew that physics was the field for me but that it would take hard work and determination to get to where I want to be.
Codes: Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Cost (Task Effort)

Response: I was lucky to have had incredibly supportive Physics teachers through high school. The support they provided encouraged me and I decided to pursue Physics in college in beyond. I am currently enrolled to do a double major in Physics and Astronomy which, I am confident, will help lay a strong foundation to take up a career in Astrophysics.I like collaborative learning environments and passionately believe in promoting more women to take up careers in Science. Since my sophomore year, I have been a mentor to in-coming freshman class and have also been an outreach officer for UWIP (Undergraduate Women in Physics) organization. Both these experiences further enhanced my belief in sharing and learning and I do look forward to staying engaged and attracting more women to take up Sciences.
I wanted to study physics because I found it interesting in school and I wanted to do something that not everyone can or dares to do. It is hard and I like it.

My dad is a materials scientist so IÕve always been in the physics world. He would always take my sister and me to work where we would see what he was working on and get to fiddle with non-harmful experiments. He always made me feel like I could do anything and he really got me interested in science and itÕs powerful effects.

I was initially driven towards physics when I watched space-related shows on TV when I was young. I always had an interest in space, and loved to read about our galaxy in the universe. My parents encouraged me to pursue physics, and told me that I should aim to pursue what I am most interested in. In high school, I found physics exceedingly difficult and struggled to maintain self-esteem in the course. I was meeting with my teacher one day, and expressed my concern that I would not be able to study physics in college. My teacher told me that he had flunked his way through undergraduate physics, and advised me that as long as I wanted to study physics, I could do it, regardless of my grades. His advice was extremely influential, and I went on to study physics in college.
Codes: Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Cost (Task Effort)

Response: I`ve always been interested in astronomy and space travel. I did well in physics in high school, and really enjoyed it. Sci-fi books and movies made me interested in how we could achieve similar concepts in our world.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Media Triggered, Mastery Experience

Response: I first became interested in physics while taking a course in high school. At the time, I didn`t consider it a field that I wanted to study in college. After taking an introductory astronomy class in college, I realized that I had a passion for astronomy and decided to take an introductory physics class. I realized that my interest in physics was growing, and after taking another astronomy class I decided to pursuit a physics major.

My first physics class in high school was taught by a woman who was very enthusiastic about the subject. I had already been interested in some sort of STEM major, but I found that physics was a subject that really clicked. Now I find the constant academic challenge fulfilling.

I have considered studying physics since elementary school because I had a strong interest in space and astronomy. However, as I grew older I shied away from it since I perceive physics as being a very difficult field that few people can succeed in. I entered college undecided between Computer Science and Physics, initially intending to try out both and even going so far as to declare a major in computer science during my freshman year. The first semester of my sophomore there was a conflict between the required classes for Physics and CS, forcing me to choose. At the time I was enjoying my physics classes a lot more and felt far more supported and welcome in the Physics department than in CS, which became the deciding factor for me to switch definitively to a Physics major.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic (Social), Cost (Task Effort)

Response: Growing up my father was always interested in astronomy and physics, reading books and sharing the interesting things he found.  We would spent many nights outside with his scope.  I was considered an accelerated learner in school and therefore was always given unique opportunities to be involved in hands on science.  I was lucky to have this foundation. After high school I was a bit overwhelmed by all the pressure placed on me to succeed in the science field, and therefore chose another route my first time in college.  As my children began to no longer require my constant attention, I realized I wanted to do something in my life that was fulfilling and enjoyable.  My true desire was always physics research, and I made the choice to return to it again.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Cost (Task Effort), Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: After my first Physics class, I realized I really enjoyed the material (which was a new feeling for me) and that it was something I could see myself doing for the rest of my life.
My high school physics teacher made it awesome.

I took my first intro to physics class in 10th grade of high school, and fell in love at first sight with Newton`s Laws of motion. Though now I know they weren`t quite right, I still think it`s really amazing and mind-boggling that puny humans such as ourselves could find mathematical relationships to describe the UNIVERSE! I found it all to be very elegant, so my mind was set from that point forward.
physics is really tough but I like the community of women in phys on campus and also physics is a stepping stone to a plethora of other fields and jobs

I have always wanted to be a scientist. Community college was a great experience for me to try on `different hats` of science disciplines. It wasn`t until my last semester before receiving my AA that I took my first physics course. I loved every minute of that class. For the first time I had challenging classwork. The lab that accompanied the class made the material from the lecture so clear, and it was fun! My teacher was a great influence as well; through him I was able to see into a community of like minded people who also strived to test limits and explore our world, from a macro and microscopic point of view. I love physics, down to the last detail. Now, as an undergraduate, I try to soak in as much knowledge as possible from every class, every poster presentation, and every intelligent conversation. Presently, I am involved in an experimental research lab at my school. This lab influences me to continue to develop skills and learn new methods (and software) to be able to contribute more as a lab mechanic.
Codes: Attainment Value, Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I took an introduction to physics course at my college and found it intensely interesting. Two of the physics professors encouraged me to continue to pursue physics because of my natural abilities in calculus and physics. I switched my major and have not regretted it.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience

Response: I first considered physics in high school. I had wanted to pursue science from a young age, and was always strongest in my math courses. I loved that physics is a way to mathematically model the physical world.

I saw all the cool things that other physics majors were doing my first semester of college. I asked one of the guys helping out in my first semester physics class about the stuff he was doing in his research, and when he explained it to me I really realized how cool it is. Then I ended up changing my major to electrical engineering and was super inspired by Tesla. From there, I realized that the only parts of Electrical Engineering that I liked were the physics parts. So then I decided to major in it.

My older brother has always been into science related topics and he always talked about these topic as we grewup. I had a great Physics teacher in high school and that`s when I knew I wanted to study Physics in college.

My passion for physics stems from the fact that both my parents are Physics majors. I love learning about physics, and feel as if everyone should have the equal opportunity to study something that they are truly passionate about. I want to be able to create a community where everyone can share their experiences, and love for physics in a supportive and positive environment.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I took physics in high school and really enjoyed it. Both my parents and my older sister are (non-science) writers, and I latched onto physics because it was a way that I could be different from them, and not follow down the same paths that they did. I was also a part of starting my high school`s robotics team, which showed me how physics could be fun. I went into college knowing that I either wanted to do physics or engineering. I don`t mind being a woman in physics because I`ve been lucky enough to not face any serious adversity along the way, and I`ve found that people are always pleasantly surprised when they find out that I`m a physics major and they think better of me knowing that.

I first took AP Bio and honors chemistry and found that I didn`t really like doing labs in those classes. Because physics can be a lot more theoretical, I took AP Physics C hoping that I would enjoy it enough to major in it. I didn`t hate the class, and I liked how collaborative working through problem sets was. I like math, too, but careers in math didn`t interest me much, and there is so much you can do with a physics degree. When I took my first college physics class, I loved the sense community we built by working together, and I liked the gender diversity of our department.

Growing up I had incredible science teachers who encouraged me to continue to feed my curiosity. Eventually in high school I found that I really enjoyed aspects of Chemistry that related to Quantum Mechanics, and so I felt that I would want to pursue Physics. I felt a very strong sense of purpose once I learned about topics in Physics such as Special Relativity. It wasn`t until this current semester of my third year that I finally feel committed to being a Physics major. I think this is because I`ve built a strong foundation of knowledge that has allowed me to be more comfortable with the class material, and I`ve made more friends I can relate to in the department.

I participated in a physics class in High School and remembered doing well even though I was not impressed by the teaching method of the teacher at the time. I re-entered the physics world after realizing that I wasn`t interested in other majors I explored and immediately felt a passion for the topics. They were fascinating to me and I started looking into physics topics even when they weren`t related to the topics being discussed in class.

I became interested in physics as a junior in high school. I had two great physics teachers in high school that encouraged my interest. I took the 101 honors as a freshman at my college, and loved it even more, so I became a physics major! I also started working in a lab my sophomore year. I am now a senior and have had a wonderful experience in my university`s department, and intend on pursuing a PhD in physics.

I was never very into physics until a very influential teacher showed me I could be involved in high school. She showed me how great it was and that I could do it too. During college I decided that I would like to add onto my Applied Mathematics Degree and take physics classes. They interested me so much I decided to double major.
I grew interest to physics in high school and kept this interest throughout college.I have always loved physics and how we can use it to describe the world

I always liked to be challenged, whether in the sports I participated or on a project in school. My sophomore year of high school I took Tech Ed. This class was all about graphics on a computer and building things. Every project my teacher presented to the class I was more than happy to per-take in. I built towers, structure, designs, parachutes, hovercrafts, and much more. Not only did I enjoy these projects but I strived with them.I managed to beat everyone in my class in every project. This led me to take my first physics class my senior year of high school. I enjoyed all the experiments and lectures that course had to offer, and it led me to pursue a major in physics in college. My first semester I took physics 221. This course led me deeper in to the material I covered in high school, expanding my knowledge and love for everything about it. My major is sill physics and engineering,and I look forward to everything I still have to learn, and all the projects I still have to take on.

I`ve always loved math and science. For a long time, I wanted to do something that involved the medical field. Some family of mine suggested that I look into the field of pharmacy because it involved some medicine and somemath. So I began to look into that field very seriously. That lead me to do some college vists for pharamceuticalprograms. Then as I visited colleges and learned about other programs, I began to do some more research on differentfields. I found a page online describing what a biomedical engineer was and I was convinced that that was the job for me. I loved medicine, physics, engineering, and math! It seemed perfect! So I went to college as a biomedicalengineering major. It was great, I was in a 3-2 program so I was taking mainly physics classes. When I first startedthose classes I was convinced that I wasn`t doing well and I thought that maybe I was inthe wrong field. However, I was actually doing just fine. Then I suddenly started to really like it. My mom was diagnosed with stage 0 breast cancer the summer before my sophomore year of college. When she was going throughher radiation treatments, she told me about the field of medical physics. She suggested that I look into it becauseit was something that might interest me. When I came in for a break I was able to go with her to her radiation treatmentand I got to talk to the medical physicists that worked at the hospital and they told me everything that was involved inthe field and how to get into the field. After this, I knew what I wanted to do. I`ve never been so sure of anything.So I switched out of biomedical engineering to physics while taking some extra science classes in biology and chemistry.I am planning on going to graduate school in two years to study medical physics and I plan on earning my PhD. I am veryexcited about it. The more I am studying physics the more I am falling in love with it. I am so excited to see whatthe future will bring.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Medical), Vicarious Experience, Utility Value

Response: Math led me to physics. <3
high school teacher

Learning about space in first grade was the first experience with astronomy that made me interested in it. Taking my first physics class was a challenge and interesting which really shocked me because I haven`t had a challenge in school before and it was in a topic that interested me. I remember my parents telling me that what I love is supposed to be hard because it wouldn???t be worth it otherwise. I was encouraged by my physics professor and mom to pursue my interests in astronomy. Being able to look at a telescope and see galaxies light years away and planets in our solar system was very fascinating to me. Doing research presently on Southern Galaxy Compact Groups is really fascinating because I get to take the images of the galaxies and analyze them. Being able to take pictures with telescopes that professionals use is still mind-blowing.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: Interested in astrophysics since I was a child as I grew up in Puerto Rico and visited the Arecibo radio telescope as well as a solar observatory in my hometown.However, I never considered it for college or as a career until I met an astrophysicist at a local conference for women in science (San Diego). She was a community college professor who was incredibly excited to meet me and told me to be her student. I then signed up for her astronomy class and have been pursuing this ever since!
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: I took a few Project Lead the Way engineering courses in high school as well as AP Physics, which all piqued my interest in the physical world and how it works. I found a program that would allow me to study and receive two undergraduate degrees within 6 years in physics and engineering, and I applied to the school that hosted the program because I toured the campus and it felt like home.
I went to a science conference the summer before my senior year of high school. Then, in my senior year, I took an AP Physics course and I really enjoyed it. This led me to want to be a physicist.

I was debating between math and physics when I came to college. I chose physics because the WiPs group and the professors. They reached out, were welcoming and supportive, and generally the people I wanted to be around.
reading books by Carl Sagan and Neil DeGrasse Tyson

My parents both did high level studies of mathematics and physics, and so in a sense I always wanted to pursue physics, or at the very least science. However it wasn`t until the ninth grade, when I started looking into astronomy and astrophysics thanks to my teacher, that I had fully decided on my path. From that point on I choose to be a physics major. Once in college my professors kept me hooked on it, and in my second year I began to work with Dr. James Webb, helping him with his research, using a telescope to make observations of quasars and blazars. I still do this work, and will continue to pursue physics into graduate school.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered

Response: My dad and I would watch the science channel all the time. He told me that if he wasn`t a software engineer, he would be a scientist doing something with astronomy. We bought a telescope, and we would look at the moon and the occasional planet depending on the time of year. In my junior year of high school I took physics, which prompted me to consider majoring in the area in college for the first time. I didn`t realize that I could major in physics and have a career in the subject I found so interesting. After that, I changed my mind a couple of times due to outside influences telling me to major in engineering or biology so I could go into the medical field. I eventually went back to considering physics when I was applying to colleges. I remembered watching shows with my dad about the theories on black holes, the Hubble telescope, dark matter, etc... I realized that the subject really interested me and that I should major in a discipline that I was generally interested in learning more about.
Codes: Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: I really enjoy learning about Physics ideas and topics. I have my private pilots certificate and my instrument rating and I want to continue in that field. The science behind flying is fascinating and I love the idea of doing research in that area! I have also always wanted to go into space or do research about space and I think that Physics is a good degree for that path.

I took a high school physics course with a teacher who didn`t care very much but in an attempt to do well in the class, I read the textbook on my own. I ended up having alot of fun reading the textbook which I found quite notable. I then took another course in high school and the same thing happened. I couldn`t help but read my textbook as much as I could. In college I have continued to take physics courses to my parents confusion and now i sit here and loving classes I am taking specifically how I can use computers and physics concepts to analyze real world interactions.

Around the age of 7 or 8 I developed an interest in astronomy, by 10 I decided I wanted to pursue astrophysics because I was fascinated by the universe and discovered that I had a real natural talent for math and science. In middle school I was placed into an accelerated program for math and eventually worked my way up to taking multivariate calculus on my own as a senior in high school. By that point, I simply couldn`t see myself doing anything other than mastering as much high-level math and physics as I can, and I`m still fascinated by the origin and nature of the universe.

I was inspired by the PBS series Cosmos by Neil Degrasse Tyson in 8th grade. I was captivated by the idea that the universe could be explained through logical laws and theorems. From then on, I researched physics-related topics on my on time. I also took a couple years of physics in high school and was lucky to have an amazing and inspirational physics teacher.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: I dropped physics in high school; it seemed too abstract and difficult for me at the time, and my teacher had a voice that put me to sleep. He seemed to care less than I did about physics. I began college coursework as a biochemistry major, which required first-year physics. Dr. Monika Lynker, my professor for physics 1 & 2, is an excellent educator. Her obvious love of the material inspired me, and I came to love physics too. I switched my major to physics after that first year.

I took my first undergraduate physics course because it was required as part of a chemistry degree, which was what I was orginally in. I had taken physics in high school, and really liked it but feared that I would struggle too much and not be able to complete a degree in it. From that first intro course in college though, I spent most of my time trying to understand the topics and concepts. I spent a lot of my time with the learning assistants working through problems and trying to understand the material. I realized instead of wanting to study other topics, I actually spent most of my time studying physics, and not because I had to but because I wanted to. Then I asked the professor if I could become a learning assistant and had talked with her multiple times about whether I could actually manage being a physics major instead. Her belief gave me the courage to pursue physics instead of chemistry. From there, research opportunities as well as the classes I have taken have only motivated me to stay within physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Task Effort), Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I have wanted to study outer space ever since I was a small child, and in middle school I realized that my proficiency in math and science may someday provide me with the opportunity to research space as an adult. I started college intending to major in engineering, but was drawn to the physics courses and eventually decided that physics was the path that I wanted to pursue.

I was always interested in astronomy and was lucky enough to have two parents who are both very encouraging of scientific pursuits. My AP Physics C teacher my senior year of high school was very dedicated to providing the students with opportunities to learn, so I really took to his class. Once I reached college, I realized that a double major in astronomy and physics was achievable and decided to declare. My academic adviser took an interest in me and started a research group with me, so now I`m conducting research alongside all my classes.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: A nearly failed Physics 1 when I returned to school after taking about 6 years off.  It had been a six years since I had taken any math courses and 10 since I had really taken a science course like Physics.  I struggled to wrap my head around calculus based physics and passed.  I promised myself I would work to become a better physics student and I finished Physics 2 with a 105.  I learned how to approach problems, and the subject overall, differently and discovered I was actually interested in the subject.
Codes: Cost (Task Effort), Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: Science had been my favorite subject for a long time when I applied to college,so I planned to major in a scientific field. At that time, I was consideringbiology, which I`d really liked in high school, or astrophysics, since I`d beeninterested in astronomy ever since I was a little kid, but I was open to seeing how I likedmy college classes. I hadn`t really liked my high school physics class ??? I`dthought it was easy but boring ??? and thought of physics as a means to an endfor studying cool things like planets and galaxies. My first semester of collegephysics (mechanics) I also thought boring, but I did well. In my second semesterof college physics (introduction to modern physics) I found both of my preexistingbeliefs about physics upended ??? physics, I found, could be incrediblyinteresting and really freaking difficult (both of these aspects were enhancedby the professor who taught the class). Over the summer I got to take part in an astronomy REU; not every minute was thrilling, but it was a very good learningexperience and I enjoyed it overall. This fall, although my class (electricity and magnetism) has been neither as exciting nor extremely challenging as modernphysics, something has clicked ??? I just like physics. I can`t even say exactly why,but it`s probably something about the way it combines mathematical structurewith all sorts of physical (and generally interesting) phenomena. I`ve also reallyenjoyed the camaraderie large segments of my physics class has developed aswe face our common enemy, The Problem Set. I plan now to major either in astrophysics or in physics itself.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value

Response: Throughout high school I was not challenged much with course work.My junior year of high school I took CP physics and fell in love with the course material, the challenge it presented and how it helped me view the world. I then again took AP physics my senior year, both of my teachers went to LVC for physics so they had a huge influence on me as well. Physics helped me becomemore confident in my viewpoints of the world, how things worked, and just helpedme become who I am today. I knew going into college I wanted to pursue physicsafter my senior year of high school.

I can`t really place the exact event that made me want to major in physics since I have always been interested in science ever since I was little. I did get more interested in Astronomy in middle school when my science teacher played a portion of Brian Green`s "The Elegant Universe" in class. I ended up watching all of those videos on my own later. Astronomy is the biggest reason I am majoring in physics since that is the field I want to be in.

I have always been interested in physics. I thoroughly enjoyed taking the intro level series of physics courses. I was considering double majoring in physics and education to be able to get my high school certification for Illinois. I am currently a tutor for Physics 110 and think the experience has been valuable for me. Because I am from Oregon I have decided to major in physics, minor in education, and continue on to grad school to get my Masters in Education.

I came to college as an undecided freshman, on the sole purpose of cheerleading. I always thought I would be a business major due to my liking of money. However, after taking an economics course, I knew it was not for me. I took an intro level course to physics with the department chair and soon fell in love with physics. I was "good at it and had interest in learning more. Therefore

I got into astronomy junior year of high school and took physics senior year of high school and loved it. I have been pushing through my physics and math courses since freshman year of college and seeing myself improve greatly in my work. Currently, I feel fairly confident in my physics course, but still am getting used to my astrophysics course.

My high school physics teacher was great and really influenced me to consider physics as a career path. I have always been fascinated with space and when I found out these the two strongly related, I knew this is what I wanted to do.

I took two introductory physics classes my sophomore year because they were required for the environmental science major. Both of these classes were in the SCALE-UP format, which meant a lot of team activity and experiential learning with minimal lecture. These were two of my favorite classes in college, and they also challenged me in a way I hadn`t felt challenged by my other classes. The summer after my sophomore year, I was considering changing my major to either math or physics. I eventually chose physics because it seemed most relevant to renewable energy, I had loved my intro physics classes, and I knew that it would challenge me.

I first became fascinated with Physics and Astronomy as a young child when I went on a field trip to a planetarium. From there, I pursued physics-related activities and groups whenever I could. I was very lucky to have a family, teachers, and support system that encouraged me to pursue whatever I wanted. I knew from a young age that I wanted to do research in physics and to maybe go to space one day.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: Ever since I was little I loved space and wanted to learn everything about it. I always had the science channel on watching documentaries on growing up, though most of the time I had no idea what was going on. It was the idea of that one day I would understand it kept me watching them (and to see beautiful images of space). But, In high school I did not have a good experience with my physics teacher. He only taught us projectile motion. So physics never was an option I considered at as a choice for my major. I entered college undeclared my freshman year, and tried a little bit of everything. Sadly nothing stuck or kept my interest. UntilI put on a space documentary one day and thought, why can`t i just study space?Then the lights went off in my head saying be a physics major, and the rest ishistory!

I`ve always been interested in space. I attended space camp in the 5th grade and decided I wanted to become an astronaut. Now, I just want to further the our space exploration program and encourage manned spaceflights to the moon and Mars.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: During my senior year of high school, I took BC Calculus (calculus I and II each in a semester). My favorite parts of the class were the applied sections, so I decided to go into college as a physics major even though I had never taken a physics class before. Fortunately, I loved my intro physics class, so I stuck with the major.

Currently, I am still unsure if physics is for me, but throughout my education physics teachers have always been the best teachers. In high school, my physics teacher was amazing, and in first year university the trend continued. I enjoyed being taught by these fascinating people and began to enjoy physics more and more as the years progressed.

It was my senior year in high school and we were required to take a physics class. It was very challenging, but the mechanics of the class itself were very eye-opening. When I decided to pursue a Biomedical Engineering degree, I realized that physics was the major that would help me out the most in expanding my mind. Hence, it led me to become involved in physics.
I first became curious about science when I was 5 years old after watching a show called "Sliders
Was always interested in astronomy. I had a really influential woman mentor in astronomy before I attended college and that led me to pursue astrophysics up to this day.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: I took my first physics class my senior year of high school.  I absolutely loved it, and I knew it could be my possible major in college.  When I got to college I fell in love with the physics department at Kenyon College, and now I am a major and starting research.

I had a female lab TA in intro physics course who helped my see myself as a future physicist. I also had a helpful female professor in my sophomore year. I`ve always been interested in a challenge and physics is one of the more challenging majors at my school. I became a physics major when I realized I didn`t want to have any semesters in college without physics, math, or computer science classes.

I had excellent middle school and high school teachers that got me interested in science and science research.They taught me a love of science and research in general, but my high school physics teacher was the first to introduce me to physics and astronomy.I loved the challenge of physics and how it described how the world works.

I have always been intrigued by the stars and as my interest for astronomy grew, so did my interest for astrophysics. I have also always been encouraged to pursue a STEM career since I was in Elementary School, so becoming an astrophysics major just made sense to me.
I wanted to be a mechanical engineering major and Lewis has a dual-degree program with IIT for Physics and Mechanical Engineering and that`s where I chose to go to school.

I first considered becoming a physics major when I took AP Calculus in high school and really enjoyed it. I knew I wanted to do science in college, but I didn`t like anything like biology. Then I took a physics course and really liked it, so I became a physics major. In college I started to like math more too, and now I also have a Math major.

I was taking an introductory class in the physical sciences with a really awesome female teacher and she showed the movie Contact based off the novel by Carl Sagan and the way she expressed the curiosity of the universe using both fantasy/science fiction and actual formulae and physics laws blew my mind and I`ve been hooked ever since. Since then, I`ve sought the mentorship and guidance of those who used their power and voice for the goal of inclusivity in our field and that has been my rock to be able to navigate such a challenging field as astrophysics.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: I first became interested in physics and astronomy as a possible major during high school in a creative writing class. We were working on a project where we had to create a sort of story using different genres of writing, but we were allowed to choose our own topic. In trying to decide on my topic, I remembered an experience I had a long long time ago where I reada kid`s magazine on the subject of dark matter, and I remember being fascinated by it, so I decided to do some research on that for my project.For the next year, I read almost every book I could get my hands on concerning astronomy and space exploration history, and I found myself trying to solve physics problems with characters in movies. When I finally got to college I took my first astronomy class and absolutely loved it, and soon after that I became a TA for that class. Teaching other students about astronomy was probably one of my most favorite things to do at that point, but I still couldn`t decide between a physics/astronomy major or mechanical engineering. So, I took an intro class for mechanical engineering, and after a semester-long debate I finally got tired of trying to decide and chose astronomy, partly because I didn`t look forward to the work involved in learning engineering at a university, and partly because I realized I loved learning about astronomy specifically more than learning about engineering and physics in general, and I didn`t want to give that up for engineering experience. I would love to get some engineering experience, but I figure I can do that through internships and engineering-related jobs, and for the past year I`ve been taking classes to help me gain enough course experience to hopefully get an internship like that.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Physiological/Emotional, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: I disliked AP Physics in high school due to the teacher, but watched lots of Discovery Channel documentaries (and the like) on quantum phenomena and cosmology the summer before undergrad. I decided physics deserved anotherchance, so I took the intro courses and felt very at home in the departmentat Wooster. I also had my sights on theory since deciding to take that firstphysics course. Since then, I have made a home in the Wooster physicsdepartment and have participated in a total of 5 research opportunitiesthat have proved to me that I am passionate about physics research. I am currently applying to graduate programs for high energy.
Codes: Media Triggered, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic (Social), Event Triggered

Response: I loved physics due to continuous encouragement from those around me. But I got into physics especially due to my professors at Muhlenberg College. Whenever I was going through difficulties in terms of physics, I was encouraged to move on and continue forward. The concept of physics just made sense to me compared to other majors.

I liked studying physics in high school. I had positive interactions with physics professors that made me feel good about myself. I like thinking about things carefully and understanding them. I liked the physics department atmosphere in college. I wanted to challenge myself in a particular way - being an international student and a slow reader, I felt that no matter how many reading-intensive courses I took, my inability to do the readings on time and get enough sleep was really constraining me. Studying physics isn`t necessarily easy, but it felt like a challenge that was sort of within my comfort zone and that if I put in hard work, I could get somewhere. Writing a lab report is time-consuming and requires a lot of thought, but I wasn`t as stressed about it because I knew better about what I was doing and writing about than writing for a humanities course. I just stress too much when it comes to articulating and developing my own thoughts and referencing class materials by a certain deadline because I feel like there`s always more to think about, organize it better, make sure there`s no contradictions, and find connections with course material. It`s not that lab reports don`t have those aspects but at least I can get a sense of what can go into intro, what goes into the results section, methods, and so on. Even though I still take reading, writing intensive, I feel like taking STEM courses balance things out - there`s at least something where I feel like I know what I am doing.

I actually became interested in physics as a byproduct of being interested in astronomy. I was very interested in what LIGO was doing when I was in high school, so I thought astronomy would be a good path for me. Along the way i learned to like physics considering they`re so similar. I joined the Undergraduate Women in Physics group my first year at UT and am now the president of the organization. UWiP was a big factor in my physics experience the influenced me and helped me keep going.

-My high school physics teacher making thinking of me as the exemplary student and the amount of confidence he had in me. -My dad is an engineer so I`ve always been interested in that realm, but from my physics course in high school and realizing that I was actually good at physics made me very interested-I then thought that I`d go into engineering, since there is major overlap between engineering and physics, but then I found out about clinical medical physicists     -That combined my dream of a career with physics, engineering/technology, and healthcare all into one and I decided to change my major and declare physics. The only reason I found out about his niche in physics though is just because my school just-so-happened to have a major called biomedical physics. Otherwise, I still wouldn`t have known.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Medical)

Response: When I was young my mother was the one in the family who held the highest form of educational degree, having a masters in computer science. I always wanted to be like her, and especially when she passed away due to breast cancer when I was 14 years old. After her passing I found a strong interest in physics and astrophysics, and felt an immediate strive to learn more about it, and eventually went into college knowing I wanted to be a physics major.

I took a physics course in high school and loved learning about the different concepts. I considered physics going into college but did not choose it as my original major. I decided this year to do physics as i always walked down the department hall and finally talked to the head of the department.

In gradeschool and high school I was usually one of the to students in math and science, and I truly enjoyed both subjects,Going into high school, I took the usual progression of science courses for advances students. I took chemistry, then AP physics.I enjoyed both classes and felt very encouraged by my teachers.
