My father also expresses a great love for physics.My junior year, my math teacher, who would later become my physics teacher, assigned a project where we were to choose a college and a major and research what it would be like to do that major at that college.I decided that I would choose physics since I liked both chemistry and physics, and chemistry was a part of the physics curriculum at most schools.After doing this project, I though more about it and decided that would be a good idea for real life.I took my high school physics course and did very well. I enjoyed the subject very much.In college, I have found that I still enjoy physics. I have egun doing research at my school and I had a research internship last summer, which was a great experience.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered

Response: I wanted to study Physics in high school but have loved physics and astronomy as a young child. My father worked on the comptel (a part of the gamma ray observatory) and taught me so much. However after high school I spent six months in Uganda and became convinced that I needed to do something that was more productive for the world. Yet after attempting to be an International Studies major my freshman year I realized that this was all that I wanted to do. I read articles on exoplanet discoveries, on titan and europa and I couldnt ignore my calling anymore. Its one of the best decisions I`ve ever made.There are so many influences but a huge one was with the help of teachers, and my family that science was also an important way to help the world, this helped my let go of the guilt that I was not in politics fighting for progress. My father, my teachers, the beautiful sky in New Hampshire and science fiction movies like Contact were huge influences.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Media Triggered

Response: I decided to major in astrophysics during my junior year of high school. Prior to this, I became fascinated with astronomy when I received a telescope from the local astronomical society as a reward for an essay contest. Throughout middle school and high school, its members mentored me as an amateur astronomer and pointed me towards resources and literature with which I could use to supplement my learning. Then, in high school, I took my first physics course. People had told me that I needed to know physics to do astronomy, but until that class I was unsure if I could do it. The support from my high school physics teacher and her teaching methodology of a student-led learning environment taught me that not only could I do physics, but I liked physics. With that knowledge, I committed to majoring in astrophysics in college and pursued all the physics classes available to me at high school. In short, I chose a physics-related field because of my passion for astronomy.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Mastery Experience, Intrinsic (Social), Social Persuasion

Response: I took a physics class and a lot of math classes in high school and really enjoyed them. I knew I wanted to go into a math/science related field, and physics sounded fun. My older sister also studied physics, and I was always interested in what she was working on.

I went to college thinking that I was going to be a math major, and I just ended up liking physics a lot more than I expected. When I took AP Physics in high school it wasn`t really learning motivated, and there were only four people in class: myself and three other boys. My opinion wasn`t really respected so I just took a back seat in every lab. I only took physics because I wanted to do engineering and the college picks your first semester classes for you. I feel like if I went to a bigger school I`d still be a math major and not a physics major because a majority of physics majors at my college are female. If I hadn`t had the professors and friends that I have I definitely wouldn`t love physics as much as I do now.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Emotional), Utility Value, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: When I was a very young child, I wanted to be a scientist.Physics, as a field, had not truly been introduced to me bythat time of my life. (My grandparents were literary folk, aswas my mother. The field of science, though interesting to all of them, wasn`t really a part of their lives. So, to encourage me in the scientific field, they allowed me to experiment with kits that they found at Hobby Lobby, or similar places.) Learning, more than anything, was the majordriving force in my life from an early age. I soaked up information. Bill Nye and Mrs. Frizzle were my best friends on the television, when I stopped long enough to watch them.Going into middle school, the school counselor recognizedme as an intelligent child. She attempted to get me into theschools` Gifted/Talented program, but I was not able to pass the entrance test for the program. (Our school only offered an artistically talented program, and I am partially colorblind. The portion of the test requiring the student to recognize patterns in blocks that were similarly coloredwas the only portion of the test that I did poorly on, butit was enough to keep me from getting into the program.)So, I began to read, avidly. Forgoing classes (I stayed ina seat in the back of the classroom, and kept my nose firmly in a book), I began to work my way through the library. My grades were decent. I didn`t fail any classes.But, I did read. I read through the library. History, geography, astronomy, fiction, science fiction, non fiction,there was not a single subject left unexplored. I couldn`tsoak up information fast enough! After high school, I wenton to college, starting with a junior college near home.Looking through the various majors, I settled on nanotechnology. It looked interesting.Though I did marvelously well in nanotechnology, my classin Physics did not go so well. To be honest, I just got scared.I felt like I couldn`t understand the subject, and that maybe I wasn`t as intelligent as everyone told me I was my wholelife. So, I looked back through the majors and changed over to Information Technology. I could be a librarian! I likedbooks, so that must be perfect for me! After a semester going in that direction, my mother reminded me that, as anintrovert, I do not like dealing with people. Perhaps I should reconsider a scientific field again. After some cogitation, I agreed with her, and researched one last time.As I scanned through the list of fields that I was interested in (most of which were scientific fields, go figure.), my gaze caught on the words `Nuclear Astrophysics`. I`mnot completely certain, but I think fireworks went off.This was what I was supposed to do. After some more researchinto the field, I knew that this was the right choice for me.And I have been extremely happy with this choice ever since.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Attainment Value

Response: I have been interested in astronomy for as long as I can remember, and at age two told my family that I was going to become an astronaut.  Even though it`s cheesy, since then, I have known that I want to pursue an astronomy career.  I have enjoyed math classes throughout my life, and also enjoyed the two physics classes that I took in high school.  I realized that I could combine astronomy with physics, and decided to become a physics major and astronomy minor.

Physics was my favorite class in high school, and it was a major I had considered, but my parents convinced me to study aerospace engineering instead. About a year later, I realized that engineering wasn`t right for me, and I switched to studying physics instead.

My grandpa was a physicist and we would talk about physics since I was a little kid. I always enjoyed science classes throughout grade school, and I really started liking math in high school. I just think physics is really interesting and fun.

Most recently, I have been enjoying taking physics and math courses in high school and college. I also have a lot of family support, especially from my father and brother.My earliest memories of enjoying math are being challenged by my dad (who is a math professor) with higher level logic problems. I think my enjoyment of physics is an extension of that.

I have been interested in math since elementary school, and really enjoyed my middle school physics class because it felt like applying the math I liked to more relevant concepts. I didn`t take another physics class until my senior year of high school, but I considered it a likely major during all of high school. My experience in college solidified my interest, as I found I was good at the kinds of thinking required and that I really enjoyed being a part of the community of physics at Carleton, which is very supportive and geeky and fun while still being incredibly challenging.
My high school teacher brought the subject alive and I have loved it ever since.
I had a very interesting physics class that I loved. Then in ABQ freshmen physics convinced me.

My love for science/physics began when I saw my first meteorshower in elementary school. I became obsessed with studying,despite a severe learning disability. My desire for physics gave me a driving force to first learn how to achieve higher grades and then start taking harder courses, such as Chemistry Honors. In my junior year, I successfully completed the national, competitive 2013 Women in STEM HighSchool Aerospace Scholars Project, and earned a trip to theJohnson Space Center. A strong friendship with my high school physics teacher also helped me to persevere in physics, as my professors and friends are now.
Codes: Event Triggered, Cost (Outside Effort), Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: The start of my interest in astrophysics is likely similar to that of many other students, faculty, and researchers in the field.  I think a curiosity towards the universe is shared by everyone.  To an uninformed observer, the night sky is beautiful, with its twinkling flecks of light, our glowing moon, the occasional asteroid, perhaps, on rare occasion, a supernova near enough to be seen with the naked eye.  To an informed observer, however, the night sky is sublime, terrifying, unimaginably complex, unbelievably enormous, and hardly understood.  It`s not hard to fall in love with astronomy, and I too fell victim to it`s compelling, mysterious pull.  With this passion for the universe, I began taking as many classes as I could in astronomy.  I had an excellent astronomy teacher in high school, who happened to also be my physics teacher.  Every other weekend, he would host star parties in the hills of Santa Cruz.  He would use his telescope to show us planets, nebulae, and other interesting celestial objects.  He was the final push I needed to pursue astrophysics in college.  My love for physics blossomed in college, as I quickly learned that everything I see and feel is governed by a set of all-powerful laws.  My love for research and spectroscopy blossomed when I was introduced to the three spectroscopists I`m lucky enough to call my mentors.  Working alongside these incredible, humble, and ever-curious gentlemen has truly transformed my academic life.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: Traveling and road-tripping around the country opened my eyes to the nature around me, which made me want to learn more about how the world works and the laws that govern it.

I`m wildly fascinated by mathematics and astrophysics. I plan to get my masters in mathematics and then hopefully continue on with a doctorate in planetary sciences. Growing up near Kennedy Space Center as the daughter of a navy pilot was probably the initial spark.  My father has his masters in mechanical engineering and aviation, so it was a a part of my whole life. After earning my bachelors in psychology, and working for a few years, I decided to move on and into math. It felt more in line with my love for discovering the mysteries of our universe. With math, I feel privileged to have the opportunity to learn the language that describes this vast universe. Physics uses math to unlock the answers I`m always searching to find. I was discouraged by teachers growing up. Attending high school in the early 90`s, the general thought was that math wasn`t for girls and definitely not physics. It wasn`t until I shed the insecurities of youth, and with the supportive encouragement of my daughter and husband did I feel confident just going for it. I intended to only return to school for math and take the few lacking prerequisite courses needed to get into the graduate program. Because some courses are taught as a series, I had some availability in my schedule. So, I decided to take some physics courses. I fell in love. I do feel that it is a bit more challenging to learn this all so late in life but I am determined.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Emotional), Cost (Task Effort)

Response: I first realized my interest in physics as a sophomore in high school, where I had been one of the smartest students in my introductory course on physics. It was not AP or calculus based, but I found I enjoyed doing the problems and they made logical sense to me.As a senior, I took AP Physics, and was still able to earn good grades with minimal studying, which made me feel like it came intuitively to me.I placed regionally in my science fairs, for physics related research and experiments.In college, I decided to major in physics because it seemed intuitive and logical to me and I remembered my first physics class as my favorite class, and I felt that it would give me many options after graduating to pursue physics research, engineering, business, law, or medicine.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: Before entering college I was never interested or encouraged to study STEM. In fact before entering college, I had never taken a calculus class and only had one basic algebra based physics course. In high school I did like math, and I really enjoyed the one physics class I took. So finally after 2 quarters I decided to take a calculus class and shortly after decided to take the calculus based physics course - mechanics. I ended up performing much better than I thought, seeing as I was the only one in my calculus class that didn`t hadn`t taken calculus before. I realized that math and physics was not only something I enjoyed, but were topics that challenged me the most. I decided to become a math and physics major, and started doing undergraduate research for the Axion Dark Matter experiment.

I have been interested in astronomy since I was a child. I was fairly good at math in middle school and high school and enjoyed taking lots of science classes in high school, where I especially enjoyed my physics, astronomy, and chemistry courses. I decided to continue studying physics and astronomy in college because I find the subjects very interesting.

I have always had an interest in astronomy since I was a little girl. I always knew I wanted to be some sort of a scientist, but I was not sure what kind of science I liked best. I was unsure up until I took a high school physics course my junior year of high school. Physics was the first subject I was able to keep asking questions without feeling like I`d ever hit a wall. I always wanted to know "why?" in a deeper way, so I decided to continue to study physics in college and my passion for physics will always continue to burn!
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Attainment Value, Intrinsic Value

Response: I have always felt drawn to space and to celestial bodies, and I took high school physics, but it wasn`t until after graduation that I began to consider mathematics and physics as a way to pursue my interest.
It is the most related route I can take to study astrophysics in grad school. I began considering physics as an option during my senior year of high school.

I was homeless and pregnant and very far from family. My mother had been going back to college and had then graduated with her law degree. Seeing her journey, I decided I needed to create more family security for myself and decided to go back to school. I wanted to do something I did not think I could learn on my own so I chose physics. I began without a background in algebra (failed algebra twice in high school). Along the way, working minimum wage, raising my young child and building a relationship with their father, I was discouraged in doing well in my work (due to time commitments). The friendships I made, going to CUWiP in 2016, communicating with my faculty weekly (about time challenges, possible make up work and extending due dates) and being offered a teacher assistant position on campus made me work with more intent and accuracy. I found healthy boundaries between work/school/family through faculty mentorship and now I am ready to graduate. I have built confidence in my ability and want to delay entrance into graduate school to spend time with family and study for the GRE.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Cost (Outside Effort), Event Triggered, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: In high school I knew I wanted to be in the sciences it was a matter of what field. I had thought about chemistry because my high school chemistry teacher was really good at it. However when I took physics I really enjoyed it and understood the concepts even though the teacher wasn`t very good at her job.Another experience that lead me to becoming a physics would be Mythbusters even though they were silly and like to make fires and explosions they did show how they did apply concepts that I am learning in collage. they had made science fun.
I just enjoyed doing physics and felt like it would really open up options later in life!

I was raised in a religious household, and while I did find some appeal in the morals that the organization promoted, I never accepted the way the facts of life were explained. Consequently, I began to question the organization`s views with little to no success at home, but my curiosity kept growing to the point where I began to seek the truth, and I would not settle for any vague explanations. Once i started school, I was introduced to the field of physics. Finally, a field of study that aims to answer the mysteries of this and possibly other universes, a field that isn`t afraid to admit that there is uncertainty,a field where I can let my imagination run rampant. Since that day, I`ve accepted that many of my curiosities will not be satisfied, and that`s okay. If anything, I wouldn`t have it any other way; the hunt for answers will keep us busy for generations to come.

There are many engineers in my family and I have always had a strong affinity for math and the sciences. I declined going to an engineering university in favor of a liberal arts school in order to explore my options but ended up falling in love with my school`s physics faculty and courses and ended up declaring a major in the fall of my sophomore year. RIght now, I am torn between going to graduate school for physics and going to one for engineering.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic (Social), Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I went to High Technology High in Tinton Falls, New Jersey. HTHS has been the #1 STEM school in the country for several years. The physics and engineering teachers atHT were inspirational and engendered a strong desire to continue study in physics. While in grammar school I attended summer science camps atHT. The summer before entering my freshman year of high school I completed a college course in precalculus, whichincorporated problems from a variety of physics topics.I have taken two physics courses at Smith College, including an advanced math methods in physics course. My professor in those classes extends my great fortune of having challenging and inspirational teachers.

In High School physics was just the third year science class to take if you were good in school. But, once I took it, it became more than that. I started seeing the world around me different and relating the classroom to my life around me. This began my love affair with physics and led me ultimately choose physics over any other major.
I wanted to be an astronomy major and my advisor said I should also major in physics because grad schools might be concerned about my level of physics with just an astronomy degree.

My high school physics teacher was phenomenal and really started me on the path. I loved physics from the start because it was one of the few subjects in school that I couldn`t stop thinking about when I got home. It felt like I had always wanted to do it, I just never knew what it was until I took my first class, and then I honestly didn`t feel like I had any other choice; my interest in other classes paled in comparison with my immediate love of physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: I started out as a psychology major, but after taking calculus I realized how much I really enjoyed math. After taking multiple math classes, I started reading a lot about cosmology and astrophysics, mainly by Carl Sagan. It was just a few months later that I decided to declare physics as my major.

My dad has always been interested in sciences, so him and my mom would take me to Oregon Museum of Science and Industry (OMSI) in Portland, and  we would watch science channels on television; we`ve been doing this for as long as I can remember, and I think this had a huge impact in my decision for studying physics. In the sixth grade, I wanted to be a chemist, but then changed my mind to physics after begging my parents to buy me a huge book that described how the universe we know, works (with pictures). They bought me this book after watching a presentation about nebula and super nova`s at OMSI, and that initial interest in astronomy brought me to physics. Now that I am college, I have never been so interested, and confused over a topic, and I look forward to attaining my career goals while studying physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Utility Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: In middle school, our science teacher showed our class theTV series based on The Elegant Universe, and I wasfascinated by the idea of being able to understand how the universe works on the most fundamental level. When I took high school physics, I really enjoyed it, and I wanted to learn more, so I decided to study it in depth in college, and I absolutely love it.

It`s hard to remember, but I think it would be in high school, Honor`s Physics, when it was the only class I sat in and felt happy. Even in classes where I didn`t have to work hard to get good grades, I felt some sort of clarity and happiness with physics I have yet to find elsewhere. Even though I am not the best physics student, I cannot see myself doing anything other than physics. Everything else would end up boring me. When I took my internship at a national lab, I discovered the one thing better than learning physics - exploring physics. Even if I`m not the best at it in class, I know that I will always work hard to do physics.
I became a physics major because of an interest in gaining a understanding of the basics of the universe. I was intrigued by the complex nature of seemingly basic concepts such as mass and charge.

I didn`t even know what physics was until my junior year of high school, when I took my first physics course. I enjoyed the material in the class immensely, and soon enough my teacher was meeting with me weekly to discuss more concepts and recommending physics books and articles to me. Even after the year ended, her and I continued meeting and working on projects together for another year. She made me want to become a physicist.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: My mother`s interest in physics sparked mine. I used to enjoy watching the science channel, and I loved learning about black holes. I decided that I would go into a field that coincided with my interests; that field was physics and astronomy.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value

Response: Recently I discovered that Physics was a way for me to further expand my knowledge about the world and universe which we live in. For as long as I can remember, I found myself looking upward at the night sky wondering about the "great purpose of humanity. In part

I took a physics course in high school and I loved every aspect of it. I wanted to study it thoroughly so I decided to major it. When people found out I was going to major in it, the majority of them told me I would end up switching to something easier and felt the need to explain to me how physics it very difficult. I have always been an A/B student so it confused me to that they didn`t think I could do it. Before I felt for college someone said to me, "prove them all wrong girl", which is now a quote I have hanging in my room. Its been difficult but I always remind myself that I`ve made it this far, what is keeping me from going farther?

I knew that I wanted to become a physicist when I was helping my brother with his astronomy homework one day.He was working on the topic of supernovae. When he described the phenomena to me I became intrigued with space and astronomy. One thing led to another and I decided that I wanted to become knowledgeable in all areas of Physics. Initial classes were hard but I studied all topics at hand and succeeded in understanding most concepts. However I still did not know what I wanted to do after I graduated from the college of new jersey. It wasn`t until I received a job at TCNJ`s observatory as a technician that I fell in love with my major. My thirst for knowledge grows every day and I wish to go to grad school after I graduate from TCNJ.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: I really enjoyed my introductory physics courses and I really proficient in math so I thought Physics would be a good field for me.

I did not take a physics class in high school and only was introduced to it during my first year of undergraduate (last year). I came into school as a declared geology major and joined the Physics Club to socialize, see cool demonstrations, and hopefully learn a bit about the subject. I ended up really enjoying the community and the content we learned and decided to pursue physics further as I moved into my second and third semesters.

Influence from my family members strongly encouraged me to pursue physics. My grandmother was especially significant in pushing me in the direction of physics since she wanted to study physics into graduate study, but did not have the financial ability to stay out of the job market for so long (she was a refugee) and was restricted by her institution from pursuing any science or engineering during her undergraduate study. She encouraged a lot of scientific interest for me, and I am motivated by her story to advance the scientific background of the women in our family. Additionally, my father as some of my aunts and uncles have studied in STEM fields, at either the PhD or bachelors level, and talking with them was a consistent encouragement toward a career in STEM of some kind. Personally, I chose physics since I have always been drawn to the big questions that physics seeks to answer, and I saw condensed matter in particular as a way to combine my love of chemistry lab work and physics based problem solving. As I got older much of my motivation to go into physics came from good education in high school in physics and chemistry. My chemistry teacher was a woman who worked in the chemical engineering industry, and my physics teacher was a woman with a bachelors in physics. This was really encouraging for me as a woman who was seeking to enter STEM since I had several examples of women who had succeeded in STEM.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: I took Honors Physics in Junior year in High School and that was my first official physics class. I`m just really amazed at how physics is able to describe the world around us. I continued with it in Senior year of High School, taking the AP course offered and gaining a calculus background. I chose a physics major thinking I might go into astronomy and astrophysics, but I have shifted away from that and into a more Sustainability concentration.

During high school AP Physics, I felt like I excelled at physics, and that it was an interesting topic. During first couple years of college, I wanted to major in Electrical Engineering because I liked physics but didn`t know how I could build a career out of it other than engineering. But my Electricity and Magnetism grade didn`t reflect my want to be an engineer. I felt that I understood the concepts very well, but it did not reflect in my overall course grade. Since I had completed the pre-reqs for the Physics major, I decided to apply to Physics as well. Since I`ve been in the program, I`ve had a better outlook on classes, and have been doing much better in classes than I was when I had engineering in mind. I think it is because now I am able to simply enjoy physics without worrying about the grades, and thus am actually able to learn and retain information a lot better. It is also a huge confidence boost when you have previously learned things and are able to show others how to solve a problem.

In high school I competed at the International Science and Engineering Fair for a biophysics project, and I loved understanding how physics is in all facets of science. In my senior year of high school I won a NASA award to job shadow at the Kennedy Space Center, and I received first place in Physics and Astronomy. Since then, I`ve known physics and astrobiology is where I belong. I LOVE research. This is what I want to do with my life.
Codes: Event Triggered, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: I really enjoyed my physics course in high school and continued to enjoy the classes that I took in college. I found the department to be really welcoming and supportive and there to be a few really inspirational female professors that I see as role models.

I enjoyed my physics class in high school, which is when I started to consider physics as a minor. After attending a college-level class on a tour of Syracuse, I started to think about it as a major. I declared my major after starting my introductory physics courses at college and joining my research group, both of which I enjoyed.

I am one of those kids who always wanted to be a physicist. I`ve been reading books about space since I can remember. When I was in junior high and high school, I started reading those pop-physics books. Brian Greene, Lee Smolin, Hawking, etc. When I read Smolin`s "Three Roads to Quantum Gravity and "The Trouble with Physics" I was hooked. I sent him fan mail telling him how he inspired me
Codes: Attainment Value, Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: I was first exposed to physics my senior year of high school in AP Physics B. I really enjoyed the class, and began to consider a physics major. Making my schedule for freshmen year classes, I signed up for the introductory physics class just to try it out. I absolutely fell in love with physics, and immediately knew that I was no longer a mathematics major, but a physics major. However, I still really loved biology and chemistry and took courses in those areas too. Later on in my freshmen year, I discovered biophysics, and then decided to concentrate on that because I loved how it combined all the sciences.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Intrinsic Value (Biophysics)

Response: I have always been quick with math, and so when I started studying physics in high school, it came rather easily to me. My physics teacher was encouraging of me and he motivated me to continue studying physics. In college I decided to major in physics and math because I couldn`t imagine going for a whole semester without taking a math class, and I wanted to also have the challenge that physics presented. Now as a senior I am faced with the decision of what to study in graduate school; I am not sure yet but will be spending the next few months thinking about that and trying to decide. I think that I will study physics or math, or maybe some overlap between the two.
In high school, it was nice to see math come to life. When I took robotics classes it was fun to see physics come to life. In college, I realized math is boring and physics is cool.

Every since my physic class in high school, I fell in love with physics. Even more so when it was an important material in my dream career of a Biomedical Engineer. I want to pursue my physics minor and advance more into the sciences that will help me be very well equipped for the career I am pursuing. I am eager to participate in any and all the physics group if possible.

I grew up fascinated with space and the exploration of it, so I wanted nothing more than to explore it. Science Fiction made that dream seem completely possible, and now i want to make that possible for others.

My first year of college I had a wonderful College Algebra professor who was very supportive and pushed all her to students to go far in the STEM field. She is the one who ultimately convinced me to pursue my dreams in physics. I always knew that I had a desire to study within the STEM field, however I did not know that I had a passion for physics until I began watching documentaries by renowned physicists did I realized that this is what I wanted to do.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Media Triggered

Response: I`ve always love science, especially outer space, when I was in elementary school, and wanted to become an astronaut after learning about Mae C. Jemison. My high school physics teacher convinced me to consider getting a Physics degree after sharing my interests and goals.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion

Response: Starting in middle school, around sixth grade I started reading books on astrophysics, including old college books. I also watched science fiction shows such as Star Trek, and Stargate, which though fictional increased my interest in being a scientist. As a Freshman in High School I took a physics class and really enjoyed it. I also read Brian Greene"s book The Fabric of the Cosmos" around this time. Most of it was above my head

I enjoyed physics and AP chemistry in high school, and those teachers encouraged me to study science in college. However, I had not had exposure to other branches of science and engineering, and my varied interests in arts and social sciences led me to attend a liberal arts college.I initially intended to major in chemistry and was considering pre-med or biochemistry. My advisor did not inform me that freshmen should not skip intro chemistry even if AP credits technically exempted them, so I did organic chemistry my freshman year. The professor did not explain concepts very well, and was unsympathetic to the fact that I had no knowledge or experience of how to handle college-level courses. It was a very time-consuming and negative experience.I decided to branch out and try intro biology and physics classes my sophomore year. I was drawn to physics because I enjoy being logical. My physics classes required applying fundamental laws to different situations, whereas biology leaned much more towards memorization and facts without deep understanding of the mechanisms behind biological processes.In addition, the physics department was very encouraging and felt like a positive, tight-knit community. I started doing research the second semester of sophomore year, despite only having taken one introductory class. I conducted research in a polymer physics lab under the mentorship of Peggy Cebe, a strong female role model in an otherwise male department.I also took Professor Cebe`s biophysics course. Being able to use my biology and chemistry knowledge while applying the rigor and logic of physics greatly excited me. I found that every time I asked a "why question about a biological phenomenon
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic (Social), Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience

Response: I can honestly say that next to engineering, physics is one of the most exciting for me in life. I first learned physics around 5 or 6 years of age when my mother brought me a physics kit for ToysRUs. Back then, I hardly knew the basics, just that stuff moved and did things and that always seemed pretty cool, but I was dying to learn more. It wasnÕt until I was older and I got to study Newtonian physics and the basics that I truly fell in love with physics. The ability to understand and describe the world around me in way that that I could quantify amazed me and left me craving even more answers to some of lifeÕs biggest questions. When I met my high school physics teacher, he inspired me even more. He noticed a potential in me that I couldnÕt see and even though I wasnÕt the best at math (just good enough to pass with high marks), he believed and encouraged me to keep seeking answers to those burning questions that my family or friends cared nothing about. As far as inspiration, I would say my physics teacher coupled with my momÕs support in all my endeavors motivated me along with my natural curiosity and stubbornness for answers. I hope to go onto medical school after undergrad or a graduate program and do research in medical physics or biophysics, particularly with cancer research or something trauma related, but my main goal is to get an M.D and Ph.D so I can treat patients and conduct research. If I donÕt get a chance to get an M.D, I want to pursue medical physics so that I can still contribute to both the physics and medical communities.  Additionally, I would love to learn more about experimental and theoretical physics as my knowledge of those subjects are not highly extensive. Overall, physics is still fairly new to me (despite being a physics major for 3 semesters) and IÕm just taking my first steps in a long journey to find something that I would be more than happy to do with the rest of my life.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value (Medical)

Response: I enjoyed High School physics and Science Olympiad.
I saw a video on YouTube the summer before college and it has inspired me since.

I first considered physics when I was in seventh grade and excelling at math. I knew I enjoyed math, but didn`t want to become a mathematician. My dad is an engineer and recommended that I think of engineering as a possible career. As I continued through high school, I was excelling in my math classes still and were my favorite classes until I started taking chemistry. I found out that chemical engineering was a possible career. Once I got to college though, I took a basic physics class to prep me for engineering. Since I did so well in my intro physics, I decided to continue in physics. So far I have loved physics and am still taking courses for. I still haven`t decided if I would like to major in physics, but it is such an interesting major and I would like to see if it is what I would like to do for a career.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: When I was younger I used to watch all of the TV shows that involved physics. I then was given a science book for younger kids and I read it cover to cover. I then received Stephen Hawking`s The Universe in a Nutshell. When I was in high school, I took two physics courses and found I really loved it by my senior year which convinced me to become a physics major rather than a theater major. After that, I found that Towson was the best fit for me. The physics department here has done nothing but support me and help me every step of the way. It is no easy major.

I`ve always been good at math, but never wanted to be any sort of math major. I happened to take a physics course while I was trying to figure out what I wanted my major to be and I fell in love with it. My professor and an upper class man that worked as my tutor were influencing factors in my decision to enter the field of physics. Now that I`m into my junior year, I`m starting to get burnt out, and I`m rethinking what I want to do after I graduate. I`m honestly a little scared of physics if its just going to be like this forever.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Cost (Emotional)

Response: I have always been interested in science and mathematics, in how everything works. My passion and path was truly illuminated when I saw Neil DeGrasse Tyson in the television show Cosmos and then read his books. He inspired me to put my curiosity to use and apply my knowledge in the astronomy and astrophysics fields.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: My family friends who are medical physicists introduced me to the field of  medical physics when I was in high school. I realized that I am interested in this field  and I started my observation learning  in their hospital. Now, I help sometimes in the hospital to gain more experiences.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Medical), Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: I was slightly better at physics and math than other people in my school. I also happened to watch a Michio Kaku tv show about physics of the future and thought the applications of physics were cool. A combination of these things caused me to pay more attention in physics class and I found it interesting enough to want to learn more.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value

Response: Curiosity and interest in high school classes Fun physics research job over the summerInteresting classes in college

I started as a neuroscience student my freshman year, but my physical chemistry class peaked my interest. The photoelectric effect and the quantization of light excited me more than any other science I had learned before. I enjoyed the challenge and how my intuition alone could not predict the outcome of the experiment. I switched to physics my second semester upon a lot of hesitation. However, I realized that the primary source of doubt originated from thinking I was not smart enough. I realized that this was probably a gendered doubt and so decided to ignore it and go for my interests.

I previously wanted to attend medical school. A requirement is Principles of Physics I. When I took this class, I was so amazed by every concept introduced as well as how beautiful the math behind it all is. The enthusiasm my professor had about the topic also influenced me quite a bit. I decided to add Physics as a second degree and haven`t looked back. I cannot wait for what physics has in store for me for the future.

I am fascinated by the notion that the same macroscopic physical and mathematical principles governing the universe can elucidate the inner workings of microscopic biochemical systems. My laboratory science exposure and undergraduate education at The Macaulay Honors College at Hunter College has provided me with a depth of knowledge and an appreciation for the scientific process and its application to clinical work. I would like to understand the interface between tissue engineering, theoretical physics, and computational biology, and specifically how this relates to the characterization and simulation of disease. I am intrigued by the intersection of scientific disciplines, which has led to my major in biophysics, and desire to obtain an MD/PhD in a physics related field. My experience as a research assistant at The Rockefeller University for the past two years has cultivated my fascination with mechanisms of disease, synthetic tissue and 3D bio-printing, and optics. Through my current work applying machine learning techniques to melanoma detection, I am learning about the optical properties of skin tissue, how to optimally image and evaluate tissue samples on different confocal microscopes, and to critically analyze features that are characteristic of a particular disease for quantifiable metrics to then translate into computer code (imaging biomarkers).
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Medical), Event Triggered

Response: I didn`t really like high school physics, but I realized first semester my freshman year that I didn`t like the major I was in, I just didn`t know what I wanted to do. Astronomy was the only major I was interested in pursuing, but it was only offered in the Physics and Astronomy major, so I changed my major! I fell in love with physics once I got into my higher level and more challenging classes and now want to study astrophysics.
I had a strong interest in math and science. Therefore I wanted to try studying Physics to see if it would be the right fit in the STEM field for me.

I had enjoyed science and math in high school and originally intended to pursue biochemistry. My mom suggested that I should try physics, so I became a physics major. After taking several classes, I really liked the subject so I stuck with it.

I first considered physic as a major in my junior year of high school. I attended a women in engineering camp at University of Wisconsin Maddison the summer after my junior year. I was interested in biochemical engineering at the time and thought I might like to go in to medicinal research. But in attending the lectures about mechanical engineering, I fell in love with it. I went and talked to people and shadowed some engineers and decided that I wnted to do something with physics instead of biology or chemistry. I still enjoy those subjects I just enjoy pysics more. Its a lot more challenging to me but I have more fun studying it.
Codes: Event Triggered, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion

Response: I struggled a lot with physics in high school but I found it so intriguing that I was willing to try it again in college. I had been considering studying a science for a while so moving into the department felt natural. I continue to be amazed by studying the foundation of the way to universe works and I think that STEM fields need even more attention than they have now because they contribute to all of our modern technological advances. Thanks to the welcoming and supportive environment of my physics department at a women`s college I was encouraged to work through my hardships with physics and pursue my education

I really enjoyed the physical applications from my early mathematics courses and felt more comfortable taking on physics as a major. I was first exposed to physics in college and I just jumped in and hoped for the best, and I tried my best not to doubt my abilities.
I took an Astronomy class in 10th grade. It quickly became my favorite class. It felt like learning real life magic and I have pursued Astronomy/ Physics since.

I have always had deep interest in astronomy, so I decided that I will major in phyiscs in college and minor in astronomy to pursue my dream. When I entered the phyiscs community I started realizing the gender issue which I was not very aware of before then, that when I became very involved in events that pertain to women in phyiscs and STEM in general.

I became interested in physics through my high school advisor, a physics teacher but a philosopher at heart. He encouraged me to pursue physics and philosophy in my effort to understand the world from its most interesting, confusing questions. I continued to pursue physics when I arrived at university and found a supportive community ready to take me in. Not to say I haven`t had doubts about where specifically I want to end up, or if that support is universally held, so far I`ve encountered incredible mentors and peers who motivate me to keep going and trying to find answers to all my questions

The first time I considered Physics, was in the 7th grade when I visited the Christie McAuliffe Science Center on a class field trip, and wanted to work with NASA, and become an astronaut. As I took Physics in High School, I then realized that the best way to learn about these types of things was through physics, and having done well in AP Physics I decided to pursue that faculty in college. While my Physics teacher in high school did not give me the best background for college level physics, I worked to catch up to the rest of the students in my classes, and eventually became one of the top students in my classes in college. Finally, when I joined the Biophysics lab I am currently a part of, I realized that I wanted to pursue research, possibly in Biophysics, or possibly more along the lines of Modern Physics, at the graduate level. I have had a very positive experience in college that has encouraged me to go further along my track in Physics.
Codes: Event Triggered, Utility Value, Mastery Experience

Response: Enjoyed physics courses, got to do research with a really supportive professor.
I enjoyed astronomy as a kid and as I learned more math I enjoyed physics and astronomy more.
I decided to minor in Physics because I want to go to Graduate School in Applied Mathematics. I took an honors physics class at CSULB.

In 11th grade, I took physics and college algebra and loved them a lot more than I expected. I decided to do physics as I was applying for college. Physics stood out to me. It made me very excited and curious. When I got into college, I joined SPS and WIMSE (Women in Math, Science, and Engineering). I was very active and met a lot of students and professors in the department. I ended up failing trigonometry due to mental health issues. I sought the attention that I needed and retook it. I have made an A in every math/science course since then. I am the president of my SPS chapter, and I have made it a priority to ensure that freshmen get the help that they need.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic (Social), Cost (Outside Effort), Mastery Experience

Response: Taking a physics course in High School was the start of my interest in physics. I then began reading pop physics and watching documentaries and my interest in physics kept growing, enough to lead me to pursue a physics degree starting in community college up to now.

I was taking three general science classes that all tied back into Physics - Intro to Robotics, Energy in the 21 Century, and one about how the world works. They were all super interesting and I had never taken a Physics class before. I loved learning about how the world works and why it works that way and so I started considering majoring in Physics. It was the first time that had been able to see a path in, even though I knew it wouldn`t be easy.

I have always enjoyed science classes in school.I took a break in college and fell in love with the original cosmos series and decided to go back to become a mechanical engineer.My mom was a big influence in encouraging me to go back to school for some type technical degree. When it came time to certify in mechanical engineering I had second thoughts about limiting myself because my ultimate goal is to work in the space industry preferably research.That is when I made the official switch to physics because I had always been interested in the introductory physics classes and wanted to dive deeper into the concepts and theories.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Media Triggered, Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: I always liked science, and as I went through high schoolI realized that I could combine my interest in math and mycuriosity to be successful in physics. It was the subject thatmost caught my attention and now I have no idea what else I would do.

I am a Physics and Mechanical Engineering double major. I always knew I wanted to be an engineer and in high school I knew for sure I wanted to take a physics class. I fell in love with it and to me, it was a reassurance that this was the field I wanted to go into. I learned of the 3 + 2 program between North Carolina Central University and North Carolina State Univerisity and jumped at the opportunity to go into both Physics and Mechanical Engineering.

I decided to become a physics major because I really love astronomy and I knew that the only way I would be able to understand the physical workings of the cosmos would be by understanding the physics behind it. I had never taken any physics courses prior to deciding to be a physics major, but I had read a lot of astrophysics books. These books highlighted the marvels of physics and convinced me to pursue the field.

I have always been interested in the STEM field, I never considered physics due to not really knowing it was an option to pursue. I really enjoy math and science and because physics is a mixture of the two, I figured it was worth looking into. I am not 100% decided on the field, but I would like to learn more about it to see if this is a possibility in my future.
My high school physics teacher was absolutely phenomenal and we were fortunate enough to have access to a telescope. I fell in love with all things astro, and haven`t looked back.

I am always interested in inventing products that may help to tackle problems: from small improvements in current products or large problem-solving gadgets like something that can help to solve climate change. To actually create those products, Physics is a critical subject that helps me to understand how daily objects are working and how things can be worked. It acts as a dictionary that teaches me the definitions of how things work and the possibilities that can be done base on the current knowledge, inspiring me furthermore for more ideas.

Physics was something that scared me in high school. It didn`t come to me as quickly as other subjects did but there was some driving force within me that pushed me to continue pushing my limits with physics. Going into my third year of university, I have no regrets in my decision to study physics.

I took a conceptual physics course in high school and loved it. I wanted to understand how math and physics work together. I also attended my older cousin`s college physics course and loved it. I started studying physics when I came to college and have had ups and downs, but have had a great experience overall. I started research a couple years ago and have found it to be great hands on experience and I have learned a lot.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered

Response: Perhaps the most defining moment of my undergraduate career was on my first day freshman year in a sophomore-level physics course, when the boy in front of me turned to me and asked, ÒAre you sure youÕre in the right class?Ó In that moment, my goal in that class shifted from a simple completion of my last quantitative course to proving that I did belong in that class. Though perhaps petty, my internal knowledge that I was capable and my desire to prove it were what motivated me through all the ups and downs of a class that was using math two semesters ahead of what I had been taught. I used that drive until I found a new motivator: that undeniable, unmatchable satisfaction of understanding something that was conceptually very difficult for me. Even though my freshman self was intent on attending law school, I decided to major in physics. Up until this spring, I proceeded through undergrad on the idea that I would eventually become an immigration lawyer with a non-traditional background in physics. When I was asked why I did not want to become a physicist, I would mumble something while thinking to myself that I was not good enough to do it as a career. A funny thing happened, though, when I took my first astrophysics class with my first female physics professor. Her class showed me a facet of physics that interested me much more than any other subject in physics had. More importantly, though, I found a professor who believed in me and who I could talk to when the ugly monster that is the Imposter Syndrome reared its head. When I reflected on my future plans last spring, I realized that my reasons for not being a physicist was nullified: upon recalling my grades and the amount I had learned while achieving them, I was good at physics. After serious consideration, I decided to pursue a career in astrophysics.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: For most of my life, I thought I was bad at math and science. My parents had encouraged my brother to engage in physics related activities, but did not do the same for me. However, when I got to high school, I took a course with an incredibly encouraging and enthusiastic physics teacher. He spent so much time helping me, and I really felt at ease in his class, both answering and asking questions.Now, I still love physics. Even though I don`t always feel that I`m as intelligent as the other physics majors, I work as hard as I possibly can, because I wouldn`t give it up for anything!
Codes: Cost (Emotional), Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value

Response: I have always understood and enjoyed math classes and because of this, my parents suggested engineering. I took advanced physics classes the last 2 years of high school and always enjoyed them but I didn`t know that physics was a viable option for a major and career until talking with the head of the engineering department at a college I was touring. He could tell I was more interested in the concepts and mathematics requited in engineering than I was in the engineering itself. After this I started talking with physics professors from several colleges and my interest grew for the field. I was excited at the prospect of expanding my understanding of the world and using it to help people.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I first properly considered physics in high school when I was thinking about applying as a Mechanical Engineering major for college, up until fairly close to actual application season. I was working on my personal statement for my application essays, and something I realized about myself was that at my most basic, I`m driven by curiousity. I had thought that Mechanical Engineering was what I wanted because I liked making new things, but I had realized that it was in fact that I liked learning new things. When I was taking AP Physics C, my teacher talked about what he did during his undergrad and masters and I realized that that was what I wanted to do for the rest of my life.I am currently a physics and mathematics concurrent degree student, and I am involved with the Magnetized Plasma Research Laboratory at Auburn University. I am having the time of my life, and I am very excited for what is to come.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered

Response: Curiosity about Astronomy, was origninally on a aero-e plan but had to leave school for medical/family reasons. When I was ready to come back I met with aero-e and physics departments, and I felt more welcomed and accepted with the physics department. It was a choice that I have never since regretted.

I always enjoyed watching NOVA specials about the physics,but as an adolescent I spent a lot of my time focused onengineering, and what kind of enginnering I wanted to do.Eventually I realized that what I really enjoyed was physics,and gave up on engineering.

I took a geology course and realized that I loved geology and some geophysics. My college, however, does not have a geology degree so I pursued what I thought was the next best thing-- Physics. Since then, I have discovered that I really enjoy geophysics.

I am studying physics because I have a deep appreciation and fascination for how and why the natural world works. I feel that by studying physics, I am living to my fullest academic and mental potential. My mother, who is an experimental physicist at the Panama City Naval Base in Panama City Beach, FL, was and still is my inspiration to become a physics major. However, the path I am on now was not always so clear. Until my first year in high school, I had no clue as to what I wanted to pursue for my future major or even career. I was also struggling with a lot of emotional distress and self-doubt due to the degradation from a few of my peers. I didnÕt feel like I fit in, nor did I feel like I was intelligent in comparison to others. During that year, however, I took a Physical Science class, which became the best and most influential class I had ever taken up to that point. My fellow classmates were all struggling so much with the material and tests, but I was finding the material to be fascinating and enjoyable. For the first time, physics allowed me to feel intelligent, which was an unfamiliar concept to me at the time. I realized that physics, not only helped me feel more in touch with myself, but it also allowed me to bond with my mother. She would lend me some of her physics books to reference while I completed my Physical Science homework assignments, and we would talk about the interesting concepts and mathematical techniques involved in each type of problem. It almost felt like we were talking to each other in our own language. It was in that same year that I decided to become a physics major.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Cost (Emotional), Mastery Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion

Response: When I was maybe 13 or 14, I started reading pop science books about physics (stuff like Michio Kaku`s Parallel Worlds). I decided I wanted to be a theoretical physicist. So from that point on, I was thinking I was going to study physics in college. I went to a math and science high school, and there I was fortunate enough to be exposed to physics research and concepts very early on. I was still interested in physics when I went to college, so it became my major. My interests have obviously shifted a lot over the years. I no longer want to work on string theory; in fact I think I`ll end up in some kind of optical engineering. However, thanks to good professors and opportunities to contribute to research, I have stuck with and continued to enjoy physics throughout my undergraduate career.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Optics), Event Triggered, Vicarious Experience

Response: My interest in science and research started since I was little girl, I was always trying to make things work, and if they didn???t, I made new things with them. In Elementary School, I participated in a Science Fair with a Biology project, and even when it was a simple one, the experience increased my interest in science. Also, in Middle School I participated and won the 1st place in Yabucoa`s Science Fair in a study of heavy metal concentrations in potable water. In 10th grade I realized that Physics could be an option after I participated in a Nanotechnology program (Experimenta con PREM). After that, in 2013 and 2014, I was a member of the Petra Mercado High School???s Moon-buggy team and represented my school in the NASA competitions in Humacao, Puerto Rico and Huntsville, Alabama where our team won several prizes. As a high school student, I continued participating in the Science Fairs with various projects in the areas of Enviromental Chemistry and Nanotechnology and represented Puerto Rico in the 2013???s Intel ISEF Science Fair in Phoenix, Arizona. In June 2013, I started a new research studying the properties of activated carbon and carbon nanotubes to create electrodes for super-capacitors. I have presented the results of my work in several scientific conferences: 10th PREM Annual Meeting (Nov 2013, Humacao, PR), National Conference on Undergraduate Research (NCUR, April 2014, Lexington, KY), NSF-PREM Symposium (May 2014, Humacao, PR) and 11th PREM Annual Meeting (Nov 2014, Humacao, PR). Also, my research of super-capacitors won the first place in the 2014 Regional Science Fair. In summer 2014 I participated in the Penn Summer Science Initiative Course in Materials Science for High School Students at the University of Pennsylvania, USA; all this research experience motivated me to select the Physics Applied to Electronics Program for undergraduate studies.

I applied to college as an International Relations major,because those were the classes in which my inputs wereminimized for a given output. The summer before college,however, I decided to change my major to what I reallywanted to study -- astrophysics and quantitative economics.It turns out that I had not studied my total revenue curves well enough; at high effort, my profit* is maximized not in the realm of writing essays on nuclearnon-proliferation, but in analyzing spectra from distantgalaxies.I believe that the largest influence on my original choiceof major was cultural. I was raised with the idea that oneshould never claim to be above average at anything, andthat you will most likely fail if attempting a difficulttask or profession. Whether the cultural aspect is alsocorrelated with gender is unclear due to the sample size.The largest influence on my change of major was winninga championship in Thai Boxing, odd as that sounds. I`m extremely short (around 5` 1") with a very strong build,so I was consistently at a range (arm/leg length) disadvantage in bouts. When I won the championship against a person who had that natural advantage, I decided that an increase in effortcould offset my perceived disadvantage in natural intellect. I have found that I am on at least equal footing withmy peers. However, it is still unclear whether the ideals I grew up with are false, or if the effort hypothesis I formed is true.*Not profit in the conventional sense, but the differencebetween my intellectual product" (a term which I made upand has no ground in economics) and my input effort"

Short version (it is difficult to be brief):My first college physics professor saw a lot of potential in me, he insisted I would be bored pursuing a non-science major. I was so intrigued by the subject matter that I had to take more classes. By the third physics course, I decided to change my major. Fast forward several challenging years, and today I???m certain I will find a niche in the physics world. With many avenues of pursuit still available, I am elated to see what all is in store. At present, I hope to continue to grad school to study to become a nuclear physicist.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I had already completed a degree and was working in entertainment. I was still interested in physics and missed the challenge of academic work. I decided to quit my job and come back to school to try physics, but I wasn`t confident I would succeed. It wasn`t until a few months into my courses that I finally started to feel like I might know what I was doing. Since then, I`ve found more and more topics in physics that I love and want to pursue.

I have always wanted to be a physicist. Ever since I first found out what physics was, it has appealed to me. The women IÕve met and have bonded with in my major have just reaffirmed my interest, have helped me see that physics is the field for me.

I first became interested in physics while tutoring the subject in high schools rge request of my wonderful physics teacher at the time. I would hold lessons in the physics room during the hour lunch we had to provide other students with the extra help they needed. I loved seeing that moment when a difficult concept finally clicked with a student and they could say the words ÒI completely understand it now.Ó I wanted to change the way my classmates viewed physics. They thought it to be an awful beast, but I wanted to show them how to understand and even grow to appreciate it. I am still as passionate now as I was then.

I started thinking about going into the Physics area in Third Grade after doing a project on Mars.After that, I expressed to my parents that I wanted a telescope to further understand that which we could only see with the naked eye.As I kept growing, I realized that I didn`t like any other subjects except Physics. My father found an Astronomy Summer Program for High School students at Alfred University and I said I wanted to participate in it.Convinced that I would find it boring, my parents sent me there, only to be surprised over my insistence that I wanted to keep going into Astronomy.It was only a matter of time when I started researching schools with good Physics and Astronomy programs, that eventually led me to be a Physics major at Iowa State University.

I always had an interest in the hard sciences but only contemplated becoming a physics major my senior year of high school; partly because I enjoyed the courseand partly due to my teacher`s encouragement to pursue a degree in physics. I was torn between a major in chemistry or physics but ultimately chose physicsbecause I enjoyed seeing complex phenomena explained and felt I morebelonged in the physics community.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I received the physics award at my high school graduation above all the boys in my class which really inspired me to pursue it in college. Once I got to college, the department at my school really pushed me in the right direction and always made me feel valued and excited to learn more about physics.

I never considered majoring in physics (or any STEM subject in general) until my senior year of high school, when I had fantastic calculus and physics teachers at the same time. Since then, I`ve been taking physics classes in college, where the close-knit community in the physics department has helped motivate me to continue in physics.

The only physics class prior to college was one I took was in high school and it was very easy because we had an English teacher substituting for a majority of the semester. I was interested in the subject and wanted to know more, and with a couple of my friends as physics majors, I decided that I wanted to know more about this subject too.

I first considered becoming a physics major in high school when I had a fantastic AP Physics teacher who really encouraged me to pursue it. I didn`t know for sure until I came to college and took an introductory physics course, when I decided for sure that I liked physics and wanted to continue doing physics. My parents have been supportive of my decision from the beginning when I was hesitant to now where I`m sure. Sometimes, I have my doubts about whether I can really do it because of the difficulty of the upper level physics courses, but I still love physics and know I can do it.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Cost (Task Effort)

Response: The first time I encountered physics was in my 5th grade science class. My teacher taught us about torque in rockets and I really became interested in astronomy because of our involvement with the planets at the time. From this, I competed in the astronomy event for Science Olympiad and specialized in astronomy for my Science Bowl team. I even started my school`s astrophysics club and I love melding two of my favorite science topics together.

I was a drop-out psychology major when I started working at a small restaurant. I loved the job, was promoted quickly, but hit a ceiling when they couldn`t promote me to management because I did not have a degree. I went back to school not knowing what I wanted, but knowing that I love physics and chemistry, and that Ineeded to finish my bachelor program. I knew my love for physics would motivate me to complete school instead of dropping out again. Although I love physics greatly, it never occurred to me that I could actually work in the field of physics. Iam still not sure what the best path is for me.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: My dad always put on nova growing up so astronomy and physics has always been part of my life.

My love for science led me to physics, biology, and chemistry. Taking all of those classes, I slowly was able to single out physics as my desired field because I found it the most challenging and stimulating for me.
Started with deep love for astronomy which morphed into physics in high school, did physics research in high school and liked it, continuing now
I have always liked science and physics especially. I like learning how things work and my physics classes that I have had have been very fun and engaging.

I first considered becoming a physics major when I took an introductory physics class at the beginning of my freshman year. My major was originally landscape architecture because I`ve always been interested in both math and art. But that quarter I realized I was falling asleep in my landscape architecture class and fascinated in physics. I planned my class schedule out myself, since I didn`t like asking for help, and only went to advising appointments when necessary. This set me back a year because of scheduling issues. After that I realized I had to get over my fear and laziness about asking for help. I was set back another year when I failed almost all my courses fall of 2017 because of major events happening in my personal life. Now I am in my 5th year and will finish after my 6th. This quarter, fall 2018, I am making up the classes from last fall and am in a much better place. I`m excited about learning the material and I`m completing all of the assignments and studying that I need, and attending all classes unless there`s an emergency. I`m still deciding what to do with my physics degree but looking forward to whatever adventure is to come.

My journey to become a physicist started when I was in seventh grade.  My friend brought in a book about elementary particles, and we started reading about quarks.  The charges for the quarks were not listed, but we knew that three quarks composed a proton and a neutron, so we set out to derive the charges ourselves.  Unknowingly, we had just derived the charges of the up quark and the down quark, just as Murray Gell-Mann had done nearly 60 years ago.  From there, I got involved in local science fairs and started going to lectures at Fermilab, and I continued to fall in love with physics.  I`ve had a lot of support from my professors, parents, and family members, and they`ve all pushed me to believe in myself and pursue my passions.  I was able to research on the Muon g-2 experiment at Fermilab for the past two years, and currently, I am working in a condensed matter lab on terahertz scanning tunneling microscopy.  My studies and my research have made me realize how amazing and elegant physics can be but also how frustrating it can be at the same time.  Still, throughout my years studying physics, I am still continually amazed, but how cool awe-inspiring physics is, and that is the main reason why I want to pursue a career in physics.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Social Persuasion, Mastery Experience

Response: I really enjoyed physics in high school - I took it because I thought it would be a cool senior science class. I did not end up going to college immediately, and when I did, after a few years, I chose to major in electrical engineering because I was worried about finances and having a career with which I could support a family. One of the first classes I took at university was freshman physics, which I loved and excelled in. I wished I could take classes more like that and less like my engineering courses. I did not feel especially welcome in the engineering department at my school, and after about a year I became depressed and withdrew for a semester. Upon return, I hesitantly switched to a math major, because I already had a math minor and liked the courses. I took a physics elective for fun with the professor who had taught my freshman course, and again did very well and enjoyed it, and he talked me into adding a physics major. That was fall of my junior year, and everything physics-related that I have done since has only reinforced my awareness that this is my passion.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion

Response: I am an engineering major because of the support of my proffessors in college. I am president of a club called Support-Network for Women in Engineering and have been pursuing my degree since taking introductory physics and engineering.

In high school, I took the basic, but "honors" level physics course offered. I really enjoyed the class and had an especially good relationship with my teacher. I had also always enjoyed mathematics and loved how physics bound the real world with beautiful computational theory. When it came time to register for college courses, I knew I wanted to take a science course, but was very unsure of what specifically interested me. I decided to take the intro course in classical mechanics. I really enjoyed the class, and especially connected with Professor, Katharine Jensen, and decided to continue on the progression. I have another parallel interest in music, which I have started to connect to my path in physics, which was made my study of this subject even more compelling. I am excited to continue exploring this connection, which is driving my passion for physics going forwards.

My love for physics originated from the professor that taught my introductory physics class. He was so in love with physics, that his joy of doing physics rubbed off on me. I was lucky enough for be allowed to do research with the same professor a year later, which helped teach me many valuable things that will allow me to be a better physicist.
I really enjoyed my intro physics classes, so I decided to add a double major in physics.

My father is physics teacher so I`ve had exposure since I was a little kid.I competed in various physics based competitions in Science Olympiad.I took several physics classes in high school and had really amazing teachers who I enjoyed talking with.

Since I was little girl, I have always liked gazing at the sky and looking at the stars at night, and I wondered a lot of questions about them in my mind. Then there was the moon that surprised me even more, how on a few nights it was different every night. Little by little I realized how much I liked everything that was outside of our planet, like galaxies, more planets, black holes, constellations, everything that has to do with space. My researches experiences began in Spring of 2017 at the Arecibo Observatory Space Academy in Arecibo, PR.  Here, I developed an investigation in Theoretical Physics area called "The other side of singularityÓ, where it was proposed to calculate theoretically what is beyond the black holes and its singularity. Actually IÕm part of with two undergraduate investigations,both in astronomy at the UPRH. One of them is in Astrometry with a binary Stars investigation with Prof. Cotto where I traveled to work with the NURO Observatory to take pictures and gather data with its 31ÕÕ telescope. Then we calculate the separation and angle between the stars and check it with ÒThe Washington Double Star CatalogÓ of USNO.
