The other investigation is in planetary astronomy with Prof. Ruiz about cratersÕ impacts (age and areas) in the nearside of the moon in latitude 15¡ to -15¡ and longitude -120¡-120¡ using the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter Camera (LROC Quickmap).  Also, I participated as a mechanic along with the UPRH in the ÒThe Human Exploration Rover ChallengeÓ at NASA in Huntsville, AL. Last summer I had the opportunity to participate in a Plasma Physics Workshop at PPPL. Presently IÕm participating in the NASAÕs Lucy Student Pipeline Accelerator and Competency Enabler  Virtual Academy which is designed to engage a diverse population of university science and engineering students in rigorous, project based to gain skills, knowledge, and competency in NASA mission protocols and procedures.

I started going to school again because I wanted to finish a degree, and I started with PreCalc I thinking that whatever I did, math would be important. I found that I really enjoyed it, and I was good at it. I kept taking math, and physics questions would come up in application work. I got curious, and since I was hoping to go into a scientific field, I decided to give it a try. It turns out, I actually really love physics, and I`m pretty good at it too! I have taken several physics classes since then, and I intend to keep taking more.

In high school I was very influenced by my physics professor to work in the physics field. He always explained physical principles and concepts as a way of understanding the universe. As a naturally curious person, I loved learning why things worked the way they did. It was also very fulfilling to finish a problem or understand a concept, more so than other courses. My high school class made me think I could do something with physics later on, whether it was teaching or research. When I declared my major in college, all of the professors and faculty were surprised and congratulated me since I was a girl trying to pursue physics. I believe the fact that so many people around me have praised and believed in me is the reason I stayed in physics. Currently I am very influenced by my female physics faculty mentor who has helped me in multiple ways with being a female physics student. She has been a strong and supportive mentor all along the way. She has helped me get into a REU program over the summer and helped me realize what I like most about the field. Because of her, I will be pursuing astrophysics as a career.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Event Triggered

Response: I have always loved math and thought I wanted to pursue a career in that area. However, when I went to college, I found that I loved physics much more than math. I also can specialize in geophysics, which combines two of my top interests: geology and physics. I am passionate about topics in that area, and look forward to representing my school as the first female physics graduate.

My high school physics class was the hardest class I had taken up to that point, and was really the first course I had to work to get a good grade in. I enjoyed the challenge, though, and my (female) teacher was a big role model for me. At university, I fell in love with the physics faculty and made a lot of great friends who are also studying physics, which has encouraged me to continue pursuing it.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Intrinsic (Social)

Response: I began college as a math major, but I soon realized that most of the applications and examples that I was interested in were physical. I then decided to take my first ever physics course, as I hadn`t taken anything outside of very basic physical science in high school. I ended up loving it! Now that I have almost completed my degree, I am interested in finding out how to combine my love of music to the physics I have learned. I have been surrounded by an amazing, passionate, and supportive department at my college who have supported every decision I have made in regards to my studies. My professors and fellow students are the best!
My parents encouraged my interest in astronomy back in high school and when I got to college I chose a specific path in astronomy (astrophysics) based on my interest in the field.

I didn`t like high school physics and thought I hated the entire subject. When I took a college astronomy course designed for nonscientist, I discovered found I was most interested in the astrophysics information. I have since majored in physics, minored in math, dropped out to start a family. To help support my family, I started working as a substitute teacher. Realizing the pay for substitutes is minimal, I decided to go back to school and finish my degree so that I could become a full-time teacher. Now I am currently looking at what else might be possible with physics as I have rekindled my interest in learning. (The text box in this survey needs to be reformatted.)
Codes: Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Cost (Outside Effort), Utility Value

Response: I didn`t consider a physics major until I took physics my senior year in high school. I knew at that time I was going to college but I didn`t know what for. It wasn`t until I had a physics class that I decided that`s what I wanted to explore in college.

I first considered physics as an option after 6th grade when I was introduced to pure science as a concept and field. I had always been extremely interested in science as a young child, so seeing a direction for my life that was purely based on my curiosity and the progression of human knowledge was incredible to me. As I grew older, I went back and forth as to whether it was truly the path for me. I mainly think that was due to having very little encouragement from my schools. Physics was severely underfunded at my high school and the student population really did not understand or like the subject. I was certainly the odd one out and, on top of that, had no challenge in any of my physics courses. By sophomore year I decided I should pursue something more like a "real job." My junior year of high school, I studied abroad in Finland. There I had access to challenging and engaging physics and math courses, as well as incredible teachers who were passionate about the subject at a higher level than I had experienced before. Being challenged in the subjects I loved the most really sparked the passion in me for pure science as a career again. By the end of the year, I knew physics was my path. Since then I have been pursuing that goal.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Emotional), Vicarious Experience, Event Triggered, Physiological/Emotional

Response: I am more astronomy oriented, which has a lot of physics embedded with it, so my experiences are more astronomy related. When I was in 5th grade, I had the opportunity to participate in a science competition, which I won, and the prize was a science summer program. In this program, astronomers from the Arecibo Observatory came, and I had the opportunity to look at the planets, moon, etc., which was what first exposed me to the field. Throughout the years I discovered that basically the way I could do astronomy was through the world of physics. After that, I started to involve myself in research in high school, ending in doing research in the Arecibo Observatory, which was finally helped me decide that it was what I wanted to do for the rest of my life.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered, Mastery Experience

Response: I`ve always had an interest in science and technology, and physics always peaked my interest the most. I knew from a young age that I would pursue a physics degree/job.

I`ve always been interested in astronomy and physics, having gone to science camps every summer and having been encouraged to explore the world around me as a child. But back then (and even now) because the majority of my free time was spent drawing, I considered myself more of an artist than a scientist (my middle school math grades reflected that). I used to believe the left-right-sided-brain idea that people either tend either to be artsy/emotional/creative or cold/calculative/scientific depending on which side of their brain they use most. I therefore dismissed my ability to be "good at science/math" throughout childhood, even though those subjects always seemed interesting from a distance. But in high school, when had I gotten interested in programming because of my "artsy" hobbies (ie. game development/web design), I was offered the opportunity to astrophysics research at a university as part of a partnership they had with my school. It was there that my preconceived notions of what doing science meant were changed: I realized that coming up with experiments to answer questions about the universe was a very creative process, and that the problem solving skills used in research were very similar to those I use as an artist. This experience was one of the things that inspired me to reconsider my ability to do and enjoy science. Though in college I still feel like I`m a more capable artist than scientist, unlike the other physics students around me, I`m working to overcome imposter syndrome and show that you can succeed at learning anything you`re interested in.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives), Cost (Emotional)

Response: mainly professors and research talks that have interested me within the field

During my school days, I thought physics was the hardest subject until I had this teacher who explained everything so clearly and sparked my interest in physics and also in teaching physics. That is the reason why I want to pursue teaching physics so that I can make it easier for the students and somehow change their thinking that physics is too hard and they cannot do it. I want to encourage more young girls and women to join physics.

In high school I had no idea what I wanted to do. Then my senior year I took IB Physics and it was extremely interesting. I looked forward to going to this class everyday. Being able to take what we learned in class and then apply it to a real life experiment was phenomenal. I was also finally able to apply the math that I learned to real world examples. All of it made sense to me with hard work. My teacher at the time noticed I was excelling and suggested that I continue with physics. I then decided to go to college for physics and am enjoying it.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: My father was the navigator of a warship in Vietnam, and he introduced me to astronomy. Then, I had a bad freshman science teacher, and I went to thepublic library a lot to satisfy my curiosity. I started with basic astronomy, then to cosmology, then relativity, quantum mechanics, and so on.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Media Triggered

Response: My father is an astrophysicist and he used to run the Air Force Academy Observatory. I would often go with him to the observatory to do research and give star talks. I remember him looking up at the sky and telling me stories about star formation and the wonders of the galaxy. I wanted to understand, and I wanted to be able to speak and understand the language of the stars and be like my father. I also used to sit in on his classes he taught and I would try to prepare ahead of time so that I would know all of the answers. I love puzzle solving and physics provides me with puzzles, along with the tools to tackle the mysteries of the universe.

When I was little, I really liked rocks and geology. Then when I was about 8, I saw the National Geographic magazine with the pictures from the Mars Rover. I realized there were a lot of rocks on Mars and that I`d really like to study them. I started reading more about the development of the planets, stars, and universe. Since I was in the physics section at the library, I also picked up some books on quantum physics. The more I delved into any particular topic, the more questions I had, and I started to really delight in the more general theories and solutions. By the time I got to high school I knew I wanted to be a physicist, possibly with a focus in astrophysics.My high school teachers were amazing. They helped me apply for scholarships, and I even got an internship in the High Energy Physics Department at University of Oregon (UO) when I was 15. I started college at UO two years later, but I ended up dropping out due to poor health, financial instability, and mental health issues. I`m now 29, and this is my first term back at UO in about 8 years. One of my academic advisors asked what made me decide to come back now? To which I replied, "I`ve been trying this whole time." I just had to get to a point where it was possible.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Cost (Outside Effort), Social Persuasion, Event Triggered, Attainment Value

Response: I just loved science and I thought that physics was the most interesting and the one I wanted to pursue. I still love it and really want to continue with it.

Since I was young, my mission has been to approach life, and itÕs many, varied obstacles, with innovation and a firm belief in trial-and-error experimentation Ð approaches are center to a physics toolkit. My motivation for majoring in the sciences stems both from academic interest as well as a childhood obstacle. When I was 14, I nearly died from electrocution due an exposed wire in a pool.  Luckily, I was resuscitated and in the following weeks had to learn to perform basic tasks againÑwalking, eating, even talking. This experience taught me not only resilience but sharpened my interest in physicsÑ instead of fearing electricity, I wondered, could I understand, even study, these phenomena that almost killed me?At Cal-Poly, I immersed myself in scientific study. IÕve taken a strong curriculum in basic biology, chemistry and physics as well as upper-division courses like Organic Chemistry and Optics, typical of juniors or seniors. Over the years, my grades have improved as I found my understanding of a topic was aided best by hands-on learning. In sophomore year, I became part of the MBRS-RISE program where I attended workshops about cutting-edge research in the field, prepared grant applications, and even participated in research internships. In my first research internship with Dr. Salik, I worked on tapered fiber optic biosensors and learned not only basic bench skills but also conducted systematic trials on parameters such as heat to better sensor performance. In my second experience with the Fordyce lab at Stanford, I applied my knowledge of optics, physics, and chemistry to fabricate new microfluidic devices to generate complex droplets for biological micro-reactions. I planned my own experiments for the first time and even built a device-operation setup, which resulted in co-authorship on a publication. These hands-on experiences deepened my coursework and invigorated my commitment to the STEM field.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered, Mastery Experience

Response: I liked learning and was really good at math so I figured physics was a good option. Then encouraging physics teachers in high school who taught very well set my path to physics.

I hated physics in high school, and in fact, I was horrible.  This discouraged me from taking an advanced, integrated intro course which combined Introductory Biology, Chemistry, and Physics.  Thankfully, the professor convinced me to take the course because the computational programming aspect was appealing to me.  From there, I was able to understand and appreciate physics and its applications to biological systems, which is my main interest.
Codes: Cost (Emotional), Cost (Task Effort), Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Biophysics)

Response: In high school, I really enjoyed my physics classes, and considered applying to physics programs for college.  My parents encouraged me to pursue engineering, which is the major I started in at TCNJ.  However, after taking different science/engineering classes freshman year, I decided that I would rather focus on physics, so I changed my major to Physics & Secondary education.

I have always greatly enjoyed science, but I was originally going to be a music major until my high school physics teacher told me that I should major in physics. After talking to my parents, I realized that physics is what I wanted to do.

I knew I wanted to be a physics major in High School. I knew that I wanted to do science or a technical major, and physics was the only science that I truly liked throughout my courses in High School. My true interest was Astronomy & Astrophysics, but after a year in college I decided that a physics major and astronomy minor was a better choice for my career. I was nervous about taking advanced physics courses, but I was encouraged when I did well in the honors introductory sequence and started working on research during my sophomore year in college. Now, as a senior, I have decided against starting a physics graduate degree immediately after my bachelors, but through networking and advice of many others, I have realized that a PhD is not the only end goal a physics major should have their eye on (which is what the pressure often feels like). Sometimes I feel as if I have disappointed people around me by pursuing industry after a physics bachelors, but I have realized that it is more common than people think, and it is the right choice for me. Plus, a physics graduate degree will remain an option for me throughout my life. I think physics has given me a unique skill set that was very marketable during my job search, so I do not regret choosing this major.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Utility Value, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Event Triggered

Response: - research as a freshman- optics research lab- ISR research lab- REU- dinner with 2017 Nobel Laureate in physics

I have gone through several business ventures, academics, and apprenticeships in my 54 years. When I decided to go back to my higher education, I wanted it to be something I`m extremely passionate about. I am gearing toward Astrobiology, but am double majoring in Biochemistry and Astrophysics, due to the lack of an astrobiology major at my institution. Currently being established, but a bit late for my study plan, I am excited to contribute to this new major while I can and am still here.

I wouldn`t say that there were many specific events or experiences that led to my becoming a physics major; rather, I have always had an interest in and greatly enjoyed mathematics and physics classes that I took in high school and college. I suppose one major aspect that pushed me to become a physicists was being inspired by another physicist/musician who I really look up to. Their talk of and passion for physics really helped me in my decision to become a physics major.

I initially started college premed and a neuroscience major. I really enjoyed astrophysics and it was my back up plan coming into college. I took electromagnetism the first time and liked it so much that I believed physics was too amazing to not major in. I got very interested in specific topics regarding hydrodynamics in space, and I plan on pursuing a PhD, hopefully focusing a thesis on something involving astrophysical hydrodynamics.

My mom is a radiologist that specialized in ultrasound. So she introduced me to some basic physics of sound when I was younger. Out of all my teachers in high school, the physics teachers were the most enthusiastic of their subject material and the most knowledgeable. At college I tested out physics and math my freshman year. I really liked the physics department and decided to major in physics.
Working at NASA, getting a job at a uPlanetarium and going to a astronomy conference.

My mom is a high school physics teacher and my brother studied physics in college so I have always heard about physics as a major. However, when I entered college, although I took an AP physics course in high school, I did not consider studying physics at all because I found it averagely interesting and I wanted to do something completely different from my family members. After taking courses in other sciences on campus and then took Physics 122 (Electromagnetism) I realized that it was the right fit for me as a major because it answered questions that I`ve always thought about growing up - how the world works. Now I think it`s still a very interesting major and it definitely gets much harder with each level of class.
I had a love for astronomy at a young age but never believed I could pursue it until I took physics in community college and received an internship at NASA JPL.

I had an outstanding high school physics teacher and really enjoyed creating projects that we tested such as life size trebuchets, toothpick bridges, and mousetrap cars. I enjoyed the challenge and the exhilarating feeling when it finally worked. I also have this curiosity with the world and always want to know more and to teach others what I know so I felt that majoring in physics accomplished both goals well.

In middle school and high school I knew that I liked science and math, but it wasn`t until college that I decided that I wanted to go into physics. I had agreat high school physics teacher and great physics professors during myfirst year of college, which helped me develop a passion for the subject andencouraged me to major in physics. I found that I enjoyed my physics coursesmore and more as I took more advanced courses beyond intro physics.

My mother was a physics professor at a community college and my father was also specialized in science education. My parents really encouraged me to learn about math and science, which has led me to major in physics.

When I first got to college I was an engineering major, although I wasn`t decided on what kind specifically. I wasn`t really passionate about it at all, I was primarily doing it because I had always loved my math courses, but wasn`t confident enough to major in math (I was mostly uncertain on job propsects upon graduating), so I wanted to have a mathematically challenging major.I saved my physics courses until the end of my two-year degree due to a bad experience in high school. I managed to get a professor whose teaching style I really enjoyed and helped me come to love the topic. It was in physics II where I noticed that I really enjoyed the classes more than any other class I had ever taken; at the time I was an electrical engineering major, but again, it was never something I was particularly interested in.I decided to switch that semester and have been incredibly happy about that decision ever since. The courses are challenging and interesting and I have been able to secure some amazing opportunities since then, which all started with the first CUWiP I atteneded last year. Since then I have attended an REU at the National High Magnetic Field Lab at FSU and also been invited as a guest speaker to talk about my research more recently.
Codes: Cost (Emotional), Vicarious Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered

Response: After high school, I took a gap year and planned on majoring in math. I read A Brief History of Time and Einstein`s book on Special and General Relativity as well as some other general books on physics and astronomy, and this is what influenced me to major in physics. I feel that physics is the best place I can put my mind to use in order to contribute to the world. I have struggled as a non-traditional student in school but have always persevered and have never reconsidered my major.

My father has a bachelors degree in engineering, so I have always been around physics. In high school, I took a few engineering courses, but it was not until my junior year when I took my first honors physics course and immediately fell in love. My teacher even pulled me aside towards the end of the course and told me he saw something in me that he didn`t see in many students and he encouraged me to seek a career in physics. The following year I took AP Physics. Although I only got a 3 on the exam, I feel as though I learned a lot and it really prepared me for college. Now in my current classes, I am doing very well. I received a 98% on the most recent exam and every grade before that was around the same scores. Even my professor said that she is impressed with how well I am understanding the material so quickly.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience

Response: I took an amazing intro science class where bio, chem, and physics were team taught. I felt like I could do physics, and its applications to other sciences were apparent and interesting. I was on track for a Biophysics major until I decided I wasn`t interested in cellular level stuff and became interested in Earth and climate science. That`s where I am now; I`m planning to pursue research in applied physics in Earth/environmental/climate sciences.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic Value (Geophysics), Utility Value

Response: My first introduction was during my high school physics course. I fell in love with the subject, and decided topursue it as a career. The aspect of physics which reallypeaks my interest is the ability to learn more about God`screation. The more I learn in physics the more I am amazedat the incredible world around us and want to learn more.

I was a Chemistry major for 3 years before I decided to major in physics. I transferred from Mississippi Valley State University to Arkansas State University in the Fall of 2011.I had already taken 2 semesters of physics classes at MVSU, but decided to take them over at Arkansas State University, even though I had already passed the classes with an A. My physics professor at ASU spoke with me after class one day and asked me if I`d like to major in physics because of the questions that I asked in his class. He was impressed withhow much I wanted to know and the questions that I thought to ask. It took me a whole month before I decided to go ahead and change my major from my beloved chemistry to physics. I even worked in a laser lab with my professor--who ended up being my academic adviser for physics as well. In that lab, I helped build programs that collected data for a government-fundedresearch project titled ArClas (Arkansas Center for Laser Applications and Sciences). Being in that lab gave me a sense of not who I was, but who I could be. Classes were difficult, but working in that lab for 2 years gave me the sense that I belonged in that department filled with men who had years and years of research experience under their belts, and male students who already had a clear sense of where they were taking their careers in the field of physics. In the end, I am very happy with the decision that I made. And I am proud to be a woman in the field of physics!
Codes: Social Persuasion, Event Triggered, Attainment Value

Response: I was never interested in physics until I got to college. The high school physics teacher at my school had a bad reputation, so I stayed clear of that class. I took "The Science of Space and Time" which focuses on spacetime geometry and special relativity and was immediately hooked on theoretical physics.

I enjoyed physics since high school because we had a great physic teacher. Computers were like a mystery to me so I wanted to learn more about them. When I was in grade 8, we bought a computer (Pentium 4). I always played aroundwith the hardware part of the computer. Doing so, my initial thought was to do computer science at college. However, after few programming classesI realized I liked computers because I was interested in electronics and the physics behind it. Though, I found programmingskill extremely useful, taking class like Electronics for Scientists was something that I enjoyed the most. Going from the classical physicsto modern physics, I have learned physics in quantum world thatthat makes me feel know some fundamental experiment based factsabout the nature. The feeling to know and explore this nature is great. Also, the willingness to help and teach that I seein my professors at Middlebury has always encouraged me to do more physics.

Was influenced to pursue a hard science after showing interest in the scientific method as a child- chose physics. I also took advantage of the research opportunities presented to undergraduates at my university. In fact, it was the reason I chose to attend my university.

I loved physics in 8th grade, especially the way we had to think through each problem and had the ability to reason out our own answers and explain them. I was excited to take it in high school and decided to major in physics after doing a radio astronomy program the summer after my first year.

I had no experience with physics in high school. I began college considering elementary education or english as my field of study. My freshman year, I took and introductory physics course for elementary teachers and was introduced to physics for the first time. I regularly stayed after class to continue discussions with my professor. The following quarter I worked with that professor assisting in her physics for non-science majors course. This confirmed my interest in the material, and I switched majors to physics at the start of my sophomore year. I continued working in physics classrooms, taking consecutive classes on pedagogical methods for science. I am currently completing my final year for a physics degree with a math minor.
my dad said i couldn`t and now i`m getting a degree out of sheer spite

My father`s background is in astronomy (he holds a Ph.D in Astrophysics), though he now currently works in finance. Starting from a young age, I learned how to appreciate space through my dad`s lessons on constellations, planets, galaxies, and meteor showers.For some time, when I was little, he owned a few telescopes. Every once in a while, on a particularly clear night, he would take out the telescopes and show me the stars. When I was seven or eight, I watched the movie "Contact, based off of the book by Carl Sagan. To a young girl interested in science
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Media Triggered

Response: I first became aware of physics as an option when I took physics in my senior year of high school and became interested in the subject. This interest led me to choose biophysics as my major when applying for some schools, since I was interested in both physics and biology.

I was always interested in science (reading books, watching documentaries, etc.).Most of the encouragement to major in physics came from my parents, with support from fellow physics majors and faculty increasing as I become more involved with the department.

Well, I`m actually not a Physics major; I`m a Culture, Literature and the Arts major with a minor in Consciousness Studies. However, I`ve been deeply passionate about cosmology and astrophysics for many, many years, and while I`m not majoring in Physics (never got around to the requisite math classes) I`ve been quite determined to pursue this interest. I`ve worked as a TA for a cosmology class and am a member of my university`s gravitational wave astronomy research group. (Please note - for the GPA questions below I`ve used my overall GPA, since I haven`t completed any of the listed courses at the college/university level.)
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Cosmology), Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered

Response: I decided to pursue physics as a sophomore in high school. This is right after I had completed my first physics class. I had always been fascinated by space and decided to pursue physics as a path to astronomy. I took more physics and astronomy courses in high school and decided that this was really the path for me. I looked for colleges that would let me get started with research early and choose Missouri State University. I applied to work with faculty on exoplanet research and started researching the spring of my freshman year. I researched over the summer and it was a great experience.

When deciding what degree I wanted to pursue in college, I knew that it would be some sort of science, having excelled in my science courses throughout high school.  However, after playing violin for 8 years, I was not willing to give up my musical studies.  After much thought, research, and discussion with mentors, I decided on what I view as an intriguing compromise between the two fields.  I would become an acoustical engineer.  This career path is not really something I could just get a major in, I would somehow have to specialize in acoustics.  For me, I decided to get my bachelor`s degree in physics and then go to graduate school and specialize in acoustics to finally achieve my goal.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Utility Value, Intrinsic Value

Response: I`ve always had an interest in science, and I felt that physics was the most fundamental form of any science. My parents are both biologists, and so they`ve lent a type of curiosity towards the world to me.

I wasn`t sure physics was the right fit until I actually started my undergraduate work. The physics community at my school is very uplifting and helpful, and I felt as though I fit in. I also joined the Learning Assistant program during my second year and that really helped me to feel involved in the community.

I realized that I wanted to be a physics major in high school when I found that physics was the guiding principle underlying the mysterious structure of the periodic table. This feeling was later confirmed as, in college, I gained an appreciation for the elegance of describing the natural world with mathematical structures. The relationship between the math we use to describe physics and the physics itself is now the area that I am most interested in.

I have always loved science and problem solving, so when very young, I took time and did research with my mom and maternal grandfather and decided what kind of science I actually enjoyed. Then I had narrowed it down to Neurology and Physics (generally). By the time I was about half way through middle school, I decided the biology track was not for me, then I chose physics.

I became interested in science in my sophomore year of high school, though I wasn`t as specifically interested in astronomy as I am now. I was attending a different school for my sophomore year and it gave me an opportunity to explore a lot of different subjects - which first brought me to the sciences.

My AP Physics 1 course sparked my love of physics. The next year in AP Physics C I surprised myself when I excelled in electricity and magnetism as well as mechanics. I was the only girl in my class and consistently set the curve on exams. I love learning about physics in the classroom and in outside reading. I decided to pursue physics in college because it makes me so excited.

I first became a Physics major because I realized that doing Engineering at my school would not prepare me for a job as an engineer. I figured that Physics would give me a solid foundation to get into a good engineering graduate school and then I could work as an engineer, as I have always wanted to do.

I took Physics in high school and thought it was very interesting and fun. It made me think deeper about things than I have ever thought before. I liked the classand decided to try being a Physics major in addition to my planned Mathematics major in college. On the regent Itook at the end of Physics, I got a 100, which furtherpushed me to be a Physics major along with the supportof my teacher, friends, and family. In addition, I havealways loved thinking about the mechanics of everydaylife and why everything works the way they do.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: I was originally an engineering major, and I realized I preferred researching and learning about concepts and different phenomenon rather than building. I want to enter more of the policy side and specifically do things with nuclear weapons and later nuclear energy. I wanted to do physics because at my school, it is a hard major but the department is very supportive and there are many opportunities.

I am dyslexic, therefore, classes with heavily reading and writing have always been a challenge for me.  Surprisingly, I found math to be my strong suit.  Sciences have grabbed my attention and physics seemed like the logical choice.  Having struggled for so long in school, I found physics just clicked. Physics made sense to me and it is exhilarating learning how the world around me works.
I got to know physics since secondary school and that`s the most interesting subject in school to me.

I am a part of the Society of Physics students at my University. I am one of five officers. The people in my department are really helpful and encouraging. I usually don`t even realize that i am one of 3 participating female undergraduate students in the department. Everyone is willing to explain physics concepts but it is competitive, which can be intimidating. I do wish that there were more women to talk to and to explain things in a different way.

For the longest I had intended to study veterinary medicine. With that as theplan I worked hard in school and took the most challenging academic coursesoffered at my high school (I attended an Arts Magnet High School). I took physics my junior year of high school. Senior year we lost a litter of puppies and in that moment I knew that studyingveterinary medicine was not for me. From that point I shifted my focus to science, specifically physics. Physics had been the most challenging course I had taken, but also I had learned more there than any of the other courses. Iloved the applications of math and the way it challenged me to think differently to solve problems.Currently I am pursuing a physics major at WPI and seriously considering a nanoscience minor. I am still debating where I want my education to lead, but Iam enjoying the journey.

In high school I thought I would not enjoy physics. In reality, I loved it. It was a class that actually had me think through problems logically. While I felt challenged by it, I also felt perfectly capable of completing the work. My teacher in high school was also excellent and inspiring. In college, I have often felt that I am inadequate or incapable of being a physics major. I spoke with a professor in the physics department here at UNC and she encouraged me to continue. I felt much better after talking to her and am motivated for the future.
Codes: Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience, Cost (Emotional), Social Persuasion

Response: From a young age, I was very interested in astronomy. I had a telescope and would read astronomy-related literature, and dreamed of being an astrophysicist. In high school, I learned more and more of environmental issues and my aptitude towards chemistry, so I decided to mainly apply for environmental chemistry undergraduate programs and abandon my interest in studying physics. However, my freshman year college-adjustment class was a history of physics class taught by my school`s head of the physics department, and he convinced me into majoring in physics. I haven`t regretted my decision to major in physics as well as chemistry because there is a lot of overlap between the disciplines, and I believe I am very well-prepared for a materials science program in graduate school from studying both fields.
My dad is a high school physics teacher at the high school I went to. I decided to become a physics major as soon as I took physics in high school because it gave math a purpose.

As a kid, I was interested in astronomy, but never considered it as a practical option for me. I took an astronomy course in my first year of college, and since I was undeclared, was looking into my options. A friend of mine told me to look into majoring in Astrophysics, since he knew how much I loved astronomy. It took me a while to decide, but I jumped into my current major, Astrophysics, and have been falling in love with it ever since. I found that I enjoyed math, astronomy, and physics. I also enjoy a challenge, and my majors definitely challenges me.

I`ve always taken in interest in the sciences. I was fortunate enough to have a wonderful biology teacher in high school who encouraged me to pursue the AP courses available in my school. I took all that were available but unfortunately physics was not among them. Through the years I`ve done a fair amount of research on my own and have taught myself some things. The amount of free courseware available online greatly contributed to my interest in physics. I wanted to know more about space and how the universe works. I downloaded a lot of educational apps on my phone and began watching lectures from other universities until I decided to take a chance and take a class on cosmology and I fell in love. I switched my major and am now pursuing a degree in physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Intrinsic Value

Response: My physics highschool teacher encourage me to pursue a degree in physics. After that on my first year as an undergrad I started doing research in Astronomy and I fell in love with physics and astronomy specifictly. On my third year I started working with my current mentor working on Planetary Science and that made me decide that I will pursue my career in Planetary Science.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered, Utility Value

Response: I have always been adept at science and have loved it. I thought strongly about engineering, but knew at the time that I had no chance of successfully doing the work required. I went into physics originally because I felt God wanted me there, and stayed because I loved it.

I wanted to be a physics major because space always interested me and I was always good at math. Physics is so cool because you can describe and predict how the universe is going to act around you, it`s like an ultimate power. You can see the past and the future down to the tiniest of numbers. I first got interested in Physics when I spend the night at the Johnson Space Center with girl scouts. My interest got reignited when I started watching "Cosmos" for fun in the 10th grade. Since then, it`s like something I can`t shake and I really want to make it a career.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered, Media Triggered, Mastery Experience

Response: I think I was influenced by the enthusiasm of the physics department in my high schooland encouraged by my parents to pursue the sciences.I came to Harvey Mudd College and found I had never worked harder on anythingin my life than on physics and although it was hard work I felt very rewarded by my introductorymechanics course. This is satisfaction I had when I gained understanding in phsyicsis what propelled me to want to major in it.

I don`t know - I`ve been interested in STEM fields since before I could talk, and I guess I started to consider physics in middle school when I was in Science Olympiad and competed in astronomy related events. However, when I took my first formal physics class in my sophomore year of high school - AP Physics 1 - that`s when I really learned I had a passion for physics in particular.

I initially chose physics because I liked math and science a lot and it was the best subject that combines those. I had a really good high school physics teacher that played a key role in realizing I loved physics. I love the problem solving aspects and the logical and critical thinking that is required to be a physicist. Talking to other people in the physics major as a freshman in college also helped me realize it was what I wanted to do.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Physiological/Emotional, Vicarious Experience

Response: I studied Physics during my two years of International Baccalaureate. I have always looked forward to using the theoretical knowledge I have gained in my home country (Haiti) in a more advanced setting, a setting that includes scientific experiment. In High School I always enjoyed solving Physics problems.I knew a Physics major in college would not be easy but I knew it was important for my career goals. I want to become a Civil Engineer. Since I attend a liberal arts college, a Physics major (with a Math major)seemed to be the right path. Besides, Physics is fun, especially when the concepts are well understood. As a student, I always enjoy seeing how what I study in the classroom is applied outside of the classroom setting.Physics gives me that feeling. As a Physics major, I knowI have gained the significant knowledge I will need for my graduate studies. I look forward to using this knowledge, mostly theoretical at this point,on a more concrete level.

I always knew I wanted to pursue something in STEM but I wasn`t sure what exactly. The summer before senior year of high school I took a physics class at my local city college. The class showed me how fun physics could be. My CCS physics class in college cemented my love for physics, struggling through problems as a group, and using math to describe the world.

I wanted to attend a small school with intent to study engineering but still have access to other courses of study. The school I chose to attend had said major within the Physics department. The professors are enthusiastic about physics and encourage further exploration as I later did so in a course on nano-fabrication.

I have always been very STEM-minded, and I discovered that physics was my favorite topic within STEM. I just love how physics describes the world in mathematical/quantitative ways. I first considered physics to be an option as a major when taking AP Physics 1 my junior year of high school. By the time I completed AP Physics 2, I was set on being a physics major.

I was inspired by the work done by Ms.Chiaki Mukai, a first woman Japanese astronaut, 10 years ago. That made me want to learn physics, so I first learned English for 10 years and then finally made it to the US, where I think is one of the most advanced place in science.

When I first came to UO I had no idea what I wanted to do. I spent my first year as an undeclared freshman with no clue on what I wanted my future to look like. In my first month, I looked at the campus job search site for students with work study and interviewed for a job working in the Materials Science Institute on campus and was offered it later in the day. Working with professors, program directors, and other staff within the Physics and Chemistry Department and institute, changed my academic path and goals. I decided to take a physics course taught by a professor I met while working and declared physics as my major two months later. I`ve now have two physics professor who I`ve known prior to class and my mentor at the university is an MSI staff member, and associate director of a physics graduate program.

When i first started at my community college I was a nursing major and I soon realized that was not for me. I talked to my sister`s fiancee who has a PHD in aerospace engineering and decided that engineering sounded right to me. I am now almost done at my community college to transfer as a mechanical engineer and I love what I am studying.

I`ve known since high school that I was interested in a career in a STEM field. I enjoyed physics in high school, and I got along well with my physics teacher, which is part of the reason that I chose to take physics classes in college. My school has a tight-knit physics program, and I have always felt supported by both professors and classmates within the department. This is a lot of what encouraged me to continue in physics and complete the major despite the difficulty of classes. I also started research with a physics professor in my first year, which
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion, Intrinsic (Social), Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered

Response: My former high school physics teacher was a positive influence. When I returned to college, years later, I thought I wanted to be a math teacher. I soon realized that I still loved science. More aptly, I liked the application of physics in earth science based classes. I have been involved in research since entering Roanoke College and I find it rewarding.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Event Triggered

Response: I`ve always liked space so I took a physics class in high school (it was the closest thing I could find to astronomy) and have loved physics since.

I wanted to do mechanical engineering in high school but I was always told that I wouldn`t be able to get anywhere with it since it was male dominated. Then in sophomore I took Physics and I knew that`s what I wantedto do. My teacher really helped me decided by the time college came around the corner since I wanted to go intoart instead. I graduated and went into physics have yet to regret it.

My mom graduated at Ole Miss with a Masters in Physics and went to study acoustics at the core of engineers. My dad is an educator and he taught methe importance of our education system. I always wanted to teach, and my mom made physics fun, interesting, and applicable. Then I saw how many people were intimidated by the subject. So, I decided I wanted to break down the barrier that often stands between students who are too intimidated by the subject. I want to prepare students for college by teaching them not only how things work, but how to problem solve too. I hope that I can invest in students individual lives to encourage them to become their best.

At a young age, I always knew I wanted to be a scientist; the question was what kind and if I had the abilities to be one. In high school, I had a science teacher that I looked up to and was a mentor to me. He helped me see the potential that I had and the strength within in my passion for physics. I knew that over time especially in college I will hit the challenges that come with majoring in physics, but I remind myself of my goals. The main goal is to be a physicist, but at the same time, I`m working on commissioning into the Air Force as an officer and hopefully do research for them.
Codes: Attainment Value, Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: I started college originally doing an engineering major. I took an astronomy class as part of my general education and fell in love with the class and the major. So i decided to study physics with an enfaces in astronomy because i found it fascinating  the mystery and wonders that outer space provides.

When I was younger, I would watch documentaries on cosmology and quantum mechanics. Every single year from preschool through elementary school, I studied space; it was my favorite topic without a doubt. My first Physics course was my junior year of high school; this is when I realized all of my interests are all part of the same subject. My father holds a Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering and shares my passion for all things science, which allowed me to continue my education beyond the classroom. Though I probably would have pursued Physics anyways, quickly noticing the lack of diversity in the field inspired me all the more to further my Physics education and break the mold.
Codes: Media Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience

Response: Before my third year of college, I was debating between two programs: One that had physics, calculus, and chemistry, and another that included biology, chemistry, and geology. My friends had taken the physics program the year previous and recommended it to me. When I took it the next year, I was surrounded by the subject for a year and learned that it was something that I enjoyed learning. Since then, I have moved onto more chemistry intensive things but continue to tutor physics and utilize its theories when learning chemistry.

I attended my cousins wedding when I was 17 and had a long conversation with my cousin who explained her physics research she was doing with nanotechnology and I was fascinated with the idea.In high school I found myself really enjoying math classes and doing better than many other kids so I realized I would want to do something math related when I grew up.Lastly, I wanted to do something that challenged me but was also important and new physics would qualify for both of those.

I first thought of becoming a physicist when I was 8 years old, but as I continued through school, I though physics would be too hard so I changed my mind. My senior year of high school, I actually took a physics class and decided that I liked it, it was doable, and that I would do it. Then in college pure determination and a little bit of spite kept me going though the classes.

My grandmother liked to teach me basic physics when I visited her on holidays.In high school, I did not like my physics class because I did not think the teacher explained the concepts clearly. However, I had always been interested in physics and astronomy and my high school astronomy class influenced me to pursue astronomy in college as a physics major.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Social Persuasion

Response: It is the most interesting thing in the world to me. I noticed that the topics that just blew my mind and made me want to know more all the time had to do with astrophysics.

I have always loved the puzzle solving involved in mathematics and so, when I began taking classes again I focused mainly on math courses, and, because math and science are so related I began taking chemistry, then physics courses. I found my chemistry courses to be extremely interesting, however I did not enjoy my labs. I struggled more with the concepts in my first physics course, however I very much enjoyed the labs. The physics material became much more interesting when we began talking about wave functions and oscillations. I am excited to continue my studies in this field.

Around the dinner table, starting in about 8th grade,my father and I would talk about physics. This is what really sparked my interest. Then, when choosing a major,I was also attracted to physics for how versatile a BS inphysics can be when deciding on what to go to graduate school for. When I got to college, my physics professorswould talk about their research or interesting physics concepts, and my fellow physics majors would talk aboutthe current news in physics, and these things renewed andinflamed the interest and passion I already had for physics.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Utility Value, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: I love mathematics and science and plan to major in both math and either Physics or Chemistry. I have had a lot more experience in chemistry in high school but I am leaning more towards physics since taking the intro physics course. I love how much of it is math based and I can`t wait to take physics courses with higher level math concepts.

I had an amazing high school physics teacher, who really got me interested in physics.  Although I was a biomedical engineering major and my academic adviser discouraged me, this led me to take physics classes aimed at physics majors when I entered college.  In the physics department, I found a thriving community where the undergrads would help each other with homework, and an intoxicating freedom of thought.  I thought I had the opportunity to learn how to think, and acquire new understanding of the world, instead of just learning how to make products that sell.  I continually felt disadvantaged and embarrassed of my meager background in math and physics, but the more abstraction I was exposed to, the more I loved it.  My sophomore year I switched into the physics major.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic (Social), Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: From the moment I was introduced to a telescope and the dark night sky to the moment I learned that I could research more into the cosmos; IÕve always loved astronomy and astrophysics. In high school I was finally able to take classes specific to physics and I enjoyed the times when the lessons would be specifically on astronomy. Around the same time I had to start preparing for college and though I could declare my major as unknown I decided to choose physics/astronomy because now my life long hobby is turning into an education and job. My dad was also a huge factor as he always encouraged me to pursue a physics degree in college and then get a job rather than having a traditional job without college.

My grandfather was a chemistry professor, and the only relative I have who has a science background. I applied to a lot of colleges as a chemistry major, but also chose physics because of the similarity. Once I started learning physics (and also more math), my physics major decision was cemented.

At the very beginning I want to be a physics major simply because I work very well in my middle school and high school physics courses. I realize that I don`t need to spend too many time on it, instead I understand and remember concepts quickly. At that moment, I think maybe I should try to become a physics major and I should be able to do it well.

I was first excited about physics in high school when my class participated in the Rube Goldberg competitions. My teacher initially thought I was clueless in class because I performed poorly on the first exam. By the end of the year I had changed his mind significantly, but it was frustrating to have such a bad first impression. In college I have enjoyed my physics classes so far and will likely continue my major in this area.

I have always loved physics....not necessarily math.  My brothers all love physics and have studied it.  I always have a popular physics book by my bed to read.  I consider myself foremost a spiritual entity, and I find more spirituality in physics books than in standard spiritual books.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience, Media Triggered

Response: I am focusing my studies on pre-medical school subjects.

I knew I was always drawn to science, so when I was in middle school I decided to apply to the California Academy of Mathematics and Science. I got in and attended for the next four years, and it became my high school experience. There I learned a lot about engineering and biotechnology, I then took a class that was about physics in robotics that was offered for those in First Robotics, however only I signed up. The professor at CSUDH felt bad so he continued the class for me and I brought my friend along and he decided to teach me whatever I wanted to learn. I then began to learn more about physics and fell in love with the subject, so I then chose to become a physics major in college.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience

Response: When I was in elementary school, my eldest brothers constantly emphasized the importance of science in the world. I was exposed to science programs such as NOVA Science , and became deeply enamored with the broad range of STEM fields, from biology to astrophysics. From a very young age, I dreamt of working in labs where I could spend my days performing all kinds of experiments. As I grew older, I deviated from the sciences because I felt that I was not intelligent enough to be a part of that world. I never mentioned it to anyone because I genuinely believed  I would be laughed at. I did not believe in my abilities and I thought others felt the same. I spent most of my adolescence and early twenties focusing on the performing arts. I danced for many years and even ventured into fashion design. Although I had deep admiration for the arts, I  felt dissatisfied with how I was spending my time. I yearned for a better understanding of the world and I knew that I had to return to school to find it. When I was 23, I returned to school to earn a degree in the physics; the field that had both left me baffled and in awe.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Media Triggered, Cost (Emotional), Intrinsic Value

Response: In high school I enjoyed physics as it was one of the things that I actually needed to work to understand, however, I would always understand at some point (maybe even after a test), how the problems worked. Physics deals with everyone`s lives on a daily basis and I wanted to understand why things happen the way that they do.

I`ve had a love for Astronomy since childhood, the event that lead  me to pursue a major in the field was watching a comet soar right above us in my hometown in Mexico.  My parents would spend evenings watching space and alien documentaries, and as I got older I came across astrophysics and astrophysicists like Michio Kaku and Neil D. Tyson.  As of now I have only completed college Physics 1, and will take Physics 2 this Spring semester, and although I plan to switch majors, for aerospace engineering, due to my financial, situation, I feel like this conference will be good for me to have more involvement in the STEM community over all, especially as a Hispanic female.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered, Media Triggered, Cost (Outside Effort), Social Persuasion

Response: I had a great high school physics teacher, and the subject was by far the most interesting to me. In college the subject still remained the most interesting to me, although the professors were not as engaging as the one I had in high school. I also made a lot of good friends as a physics major and I enjoyed the problem solving aspects of physics and finally learning how to properly do experiments, code, and build things.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value, Intrinsic (Social), Physiological/Emotional

Response: that is what i consider a tric question there was many factor that push me into physics the first was the chalenge and my cusriosity abouth the nature of the universe.
Reading Michio Kaku`s books.

I decided I wanted to be a physics major in high school, as a combination of an amazing computer science teacher of mine helping me realize I wanted to do something involving coding, and my physics teacher helping me realize I could be good at physics. However, I`ve been interested in physics since I was really young, and that`s probably the main factor.
I`m a non- traditional student and previously worked in marketing. I decided to go back to school to pursue a career in physics after taking some time off to travel and reflect on career goals.

I first took Physics in junior year of high school and liked how hard it was for me. Usually classes were not hard for me and I had to work very hard to stay on top in this class. I wanted to show that I could do it. And the satisfaction of doing good on something challenging made me feel good. I didnÕt consider it as a major until my best guy friend in senior year told me he wanted to study physics and decided to go to RPI. I didnÕt even think about studying physics even though I had liked it. I felt like I was smart enough to study physics too so I started applying to some engineering programs and put physics as a potential major. Since then it was something I leaned toward. Once I got here,calculus was finally integrated into the physics course material. I really liked it cause I liked Calculus and was good at it. I could do it and I felt smart and everyone kept telling me how I was the smartest person they knew cause I was studying physics. Even though I didnÕt get good grades all through college, I am now in the hardest classes and finally feel like I am smart enough to maybe pursue physics.

My dad has always been a bit of an engineer, whether or not he went to school for it. Ever since I can remember, he???s been designing and building his own speakers for surround sound systems. His enthusiasm in his work and his excitement in explaining it all to me has been inspirational. I enlisted him to help with a middle school science project in which I compared different types of insulation on their soundproofing abilities. He helped me build a model house and supplied the different insulation and decibel meter. We made a good team and I could tell he really enjoyed teaching me everything he knew.I loved AP physics in high school. The class was much smaller than the CP physics class that I had taken the year before and we had access to the more expensive equipment. I had the same teacher for both years of physics, but during my second year, I was the only girl in my class. My teacher recognized that it was important to make sure the guys didn???t make me feel left out. I never did. I believe I excelled due to her encouragement.Before I graduated, I had trouble deciding whether to major in music or physics, since I had built families in both departments. However, my music theory teacher approached me and said I could utilize both with acoustics. I didn???t take him seriously at first, but now I am considering finding a way to combine my interdisciplinary experiences.

When I was in high school, I hated physics and vowed to never take more classes than I needed to in order to fill my biomedical science requirements. After taking physics at my college, I learned to love and enjoy the subject as I was able to apply physics and its thought processes to my other areas of study. I hope to be able to study physics not as a way to go into the field, but to develop my critical thinking skills in STEM.

When I entered college, I only knew I wanted to be in a STEM major.My family background and the fundamental canons of NSPE made Engineering my first choice.I took introductory classes to narrow the list and chose Mechanical Engineering.Great people in physics and overlapping courses lead me to take Physics as a 2nd Major.

I grew up adoring math, but upon entering high school and taking more science courses, I became more intrigued with the concept of combining the sciences and math. I completed my first physics course junior year of high school and fell in love with it and took a second, non-required class my senior year. My declared major when I entered college was physics, but since I am more interested in the mathematical and hands-on aspect of it, I decided to pursue a major in Biomedical Engineering with a minor in Physics to continue my desire to learn it.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: When I first got to college, I did not consider physics as a major - I thought it was too hard and well above my head. At the time, I wanted to do law, though it was not my passion. However, when I took an astronomy class and fell in love with it, I decided to change my life course and become an astronomer. So, I decided to double-major in physics and astronomy, to have enough background for graduate school in astronomy. I have never regretted my decision, as physics has always been challenging but incredibly stimulating and fascinating to me.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Intrinsic Value, Cost (Task Effort)

Response: My parents encouraged me to take physics in high school, but I did not enjoy it at all, due to the pre-calculus curriculum and poor teaching. I`m not sure why I decided to take physics in my first year of college, but I felt that I had to catch up in it.I thoroughly enjoyed and did well in my freshman year physics classes. I also joined a wonderful community of physics majors, mostly from the Women and Gender Minorities in Physics group. The older female physics students I met were able to give me advice on a path through the major, and formed a welcoming friend group for me. The physics department definitely had a stronger community than any other department I was involved in. I enjoyed the spirit of collaboration among my peers, and was always encouraged by my professors when I went to ask for help. I enjoyed my success in the challenging subject.I also enjoyed chemistry at the time, but after taking organic chemistry I realized that I had most enjoyed the physics parts of chemistry. After the end of my freshman year I had to decide, due to scheduling reasons, whether to continue in chemistry or physics and I chose physics.
Codes: Cost (Emotional), Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience, Intrinsic (Social), Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: My junior year of high school I was introduced to the subject of physics. There was something different about physics, something that just really drew in my attention: it made sense. Physics seemed to explain everything, all the questions I had seemed to have a physics-related, logical explanation. Most people fear the subject of physics, and wince at the very mention of the topic, but I embrace the knowledge and understand its importance. My teacher, Mr. Austen, made the class fun and understandable. I enjoyed his class so much that I took physics two years in a row with him.

I don`t have a clear story here like many students. Physics, specifically astrophysics, was the subject that consistently intrigued me, prompting me to learn more about related topics. Essentially, astro/physics is the subject that I enjoy the highest percentage of my time spent studying and learning (problem sets, tests, classes, reading, or "edutainment") about it.

Since middle school, I always had an inclination towards maths, maybe mostly because my dad used to always make me solve math problems, and I started understanding it. Gradually, I started enjoying doing math, and physics since it did not require any large amount of memorization, which I was not really good at. By end of high school, I realized I wanted to do physics, and not math, since I had so many questions which physics could answer, and not just math.

I have always been good at math, but never really knew what I wanted to do. My junior year of high school, I took a physics class as a required course and I loved it. I took AP physics my junior year and I knew I wanted to pursue a career in physics

Coming from a family that focuses on professional careers like doctors, lawyers, engineers and businessman, I realise that I don`t want to follow the career path of any of my family because I`m sick of chasing after money, fame and social status. I wanted to do something that I love. When I first encountered Physics, I hated it the most because I didn`t understand it at all. However, as I put in more effort to understand physics and make sense out of it, it becomes really interesting. I could spend days and nights just learning physics for fun. And when I say learn Physics, I am not talking about popular science, but actually going through wikipedia to learn about it in addition to college coursework. At the same time, I met a couple physics enthusiasts and passionate physics teachers who helped me to nurture my passion and be persistent in doing physics. I encountered strong objection from my family when I decided to do physics. At the same time, I was aware that I wasn`t the brightest kid in science. However, I still continue to pursue Physics because I am passionate about understanding the laws that govern the universe.

I first discovered my love for physics in my first high school physics course. I then interned at UCSC to study in the Institute for Particle Physics, and realized this is something I really wanted to study.

When I was in high school, my extremely low self esteem, especially in the sciences and math, led me to never even consider majoring in something like physics. When I got to college, I took a series of physics and math courses with women professors who immensely influenced my views of what I (and other women) could do in the physics field. Armed with this new self confidence, I discovered an immense joy and love for solving problems, and learning science.

I have always had an interest in science based fields. I would take classes in junior high and high school to explore different topics and the most interesting classes I took were my math classes, engineering classes and physics class. I wanted to be a math major and double major in mechanical engineering before I took my physics class. One of the reasons why I enjoyed it was because of the beauty in being able to explain the small actions that happen every day such as dropping a pencil. I thought is was beautiful how the light refracted and then explain the measurements of something I am unable to see but is there. I wanted to go into math and mechanical engineering for the reason that I could create and understand what I was creating but with physics I could understand the world around me.

I have always had a deep desire to learn and explore the fundamental nature of the universe and it just so happens that physics is pretty much that. I loved watching the science channel when I was younger; I was always watching educational films on space and the stars. One of the biggest influences has been Carl Sagan, I grew up watching the "Cosmos. For a long time I just had a deep urge to learn science

I have always loved science as a kid and knew I would major in STEM. Then junior year of high school I had my first physics class with my favorite teacher and he told me I was a natural. I absolutely loved the subject and went on to take AP physics and declare it as my major.

I was applying to colleges and my mother wanted me to pursue microbiology.  I did not really care but the more I thought about it, the more I thought about how much I would miss physics and how I cannot see my life without it.  It became such a huge part of my life in high school and I felt that I learned so much about the world and myself when I was in class.  I found that I liked the person that I had become when I did physics.  After discovering this, I knew that there was no other option for me.

My high school strongly encouraged participation in research through summer internships and my 9th grade physics class led me to pursuing an internship in a physics lab. That experienced motivated me by introducing me to the realm of physics beyond the classroom. Everyone I met that summer was very encouraging and helpful in the lab regarding technical work and surrounding opportunities regarding a physics major in college. I learned so much about a field of physics ignored in introductory physics classes (soft matter) and I even had the opportunity to attend a conference and meet/listen to many leading researchers in the field.
courses and general enthusiasm of people in the dept.

I have been obsessed with the study of the universe since I was a small child. Since I was bright and curious no one ever discouraged me and I always assumed I would be able to attend college and become a scientist as I was growing up, but that dream quickly fell away once I reached High School. My family life was very unstable, and in order to ensure my security, I dropped out of school in order to get a job. Though I was unable to pursue an education for many years, astronomy remained a passion and a great source of comfort in my life. No matter how bad things seemed, staring up into a sky full of stars always put my mind at ease. Still, it saddened me to celebrate scientific discoveries from the sidelines, especially since I was painfully aware that my lack of mathematical fluency excluded me even further as an observer. After finally creating my own stable home life, I was able to begin school at my local community college. I quickly found that my determination and curiosity quickly outpaced even my natural aptitude, and for once my dream seemed within reach. My goal is to take my education as far as I can. I want to go to grad school because I feel it will test the limits of my capacity for knowledge. I want to do research not so much for the discovery, but for the process of problem solving and the experience of working on a team of like minded people. Ultimately I want to teach. I know there are other young women (and young men) out there for whom science is a life raft like it was for me. With the promise of my education comes the responsibility to make sure the same opportunities are extended to future generations, and this is a responsibility I do not take lightly.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Cost (Outside Effort), Utility Value

Response: -loved tinkering as a kid-fantastic high school physics teacher-wanted to be a missionary and loved math/science so engineering seemed like a good option and physics was a natural major choice-fantastic first year professor who became my advisor; he recru
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value, Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: I was inspired to become a physics major after taking Honors Mechanics my freshman year in college.My inspiration stems mostly from engineers who used physics to improve other people`s lives, from innovations in clean waterto discoveries about asteroid impact detection, to biomechanics inventions. In another way of speaking, I always like a challenge and physics is both an intellectuallyinvigorating endeavor, as well as one that women are still not encouraged to pursue. Even as a twenty first century student,I have sometimes received discouragement from male peers and even teachers about wanting to pursue a technical career.This just makes me more motivated to succeed, but I am lucky to have a supportive family and friends cheering me on. I worryabout other young women who are not as lucky in this regard. My goal is to use physics to solve energy issues, particularly by making renewable resources more viable for use. I thinka fundamental understanding of physics is crucial to achieving this, and that along with a love of fundamental mathematics and fascination with the universe, inspire me to be a physicist.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Cost (Emotional), Social Persuasion, Utility Value

Response: I have known that I wanted to study Physics since I was ten years old. During that time in my life, I constantly watched shows about physics on the discovery Science channel. I have always had a special interest in science and I began to see it as a plausible career in high school.
I began to love physics in college. In High School it was never an important topic.

I became a physicist because I knew that I was good at it in high school, and I knew that I enjoyed it. My high school physics teacher and parents encouraged me to pursue physics, but now that I`m in my second year I have some doubts. I still very much enjoy my classes, but I hate my research lab and the environment surrounding labs. If I could feel confident that I would like career options outside of pure research, then I would feel much better.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Social Persuasion, Cost (Emotional), Physiological/Emotional, Cost (Loss of Valued Alternatives)

Response: I always enjoyed the sciences, and making discoveries outdoors. I began with a fascination in geology, then earth sciences. Eventually I began to look further into everything, wondering how the laws of physics could explain what cannot be seen.

In junior high I was very small and skinny and scrawny but I asked the band director if I could switch from playing the three pound trumpet to the thirty pound tuba. He looked at me like I was crazy then said,"Sure why not." I ended up doing a two mile parade that year carrying the huge thing on my shoulder. I don`t know why I desperately wanted to play the tuba, I think the challenge was attractive to me and no one would`ve expected my skinny and girly self to do it and they would think that I`d quit because it was too hard and I wanted to prove them wrong for no other reason than I could prove them wrong.
