I also thought the visual of me being so tiny carrying the largest instrument was hilarious.I think my drive to pursue a physics degree is similar to my drive to be a hardcore tuba player that runs across the football field with thirty pounds on her (now well-muscled) shoulders blasting the bassline loudly without losing her breath. It`s widely accepted that physics is difficult and a lot of people quit halfway because it`s too hard. There is a small segment of the population that dominates the field and as a Filipino-Mexican girl who is pretty stupid I`m not exactly part of that demographic. I don`t have a clear-cut reason why I want to do this and I don`t have a life-altering story that led me to physics I just know that this is a challenge and maybe I`ll prove more people wrong. I also don`t know exactly what I want to do with my life and with a physics degree there are a lot of career paths I can take.

I have always been a very curious person; so as a kid, I always dreamed on studying something related to astronomy or geology (as both of them were my passions). In the city where I grew up in Mexico, there is no support for anything related to science, so I always saw anything related to physics more as a hobby. The first time I considered physics as an option was during high school, where I learned that I could pursue physics and follow my dream if I studied at the city next to my hometown *since I grew up in the mexican side of the border).

I initially wanted to be a US Air Force pilot. I was very active in JROTC in high school and ended up earning a college ROTC scholarship, which would guarantee me a career as an Air Force officer after my college graduation. However, due to medical issues, I lost my scholarship and was forced to reevaluate my future. I decided to drop a potential engineering major and focus on physics instead. This interest in physics was enhanced by a trip to England, where I toured the acoustics facilities at University of Salford. It was at that point that I decided I wanted to dedicate my studies to the physics of sound.

I had a very good physics teacher in high school that made me interested in the subject. After high school I was going to becomes jeweler, but after working in a jewelry store for two years I started to hate sales. When I came back to school I decided to major what I had been interested in before, and that was physics. Now as a junior I still feelconfident that I will continue to enjoy science and physicsas a career.

I first encountered physics in my junior year during a summer internship at KAIST. I was involved in particle physics research regarding using microwave cavities to conduct experiments in search of a particle called the axion -- a candidate for dark matter. I realized that physics research was very interesting to me and decided to apply to college with a physics major. Although my first semester I decided to try out becoming an economics major, I realized that I enjoyed doing physics and decided to continue to study it.

I have always been interested in the way the universe worked and had an affinity for math. In my junior year in high school I was given the choice of taking either an honors physics course or an art course; since I preferred science courses and had already taken many art classes, I decided to take physics. At this point, I did not know what being a physicist truly entailed. As the course went on, I realized that learning physics meant learning about how the universe worked, therefore, being a physicist meant being able to ask questions about the bigger picture. Ever since I was younger I seemed to ask too many questions about things most people didn???t think or care about; that physics class gave me the chance to ask those questions and seek answers. When I arrived in college, due to scheduling issues, I was not able to participate in a normal Introduction to Physics lecture. Instead, I was enrolled in a modeling physics course. This is very different from a normal lecture. In a modeling class, the professor does not lecture, and does not provide information to the students; instead, the professor sets up a basic problem and lets the students think for themselves until they come up with a logical explanation to natural phenomena. The professor is merely there to guide the students and stop them from venturing too far from the solution. After the students come up with a viable solution, they also had to come up with an experiment to test said solution. This went on until the students reached the best possible solution. This course made it possible for me to see what physics is all about, and also fed my curiosity and interest in physics.

I have always been interested in science and experimenting with things to create different results. But I fell in love with physics from the first time I set foot in the Hayden Planetarium and saw the infinite possibilities of the universe outside of ours. After that day I have always loved learning more about the natural world and how it works. When my friends wrote their last research paper in physics about kinematics, I wanted to know more about Schrodinger`s cat. After discovering the whole branch of quantum mechanics, it opened my eyes and curiosity to how the world works past what the eye and mind can even fathom.

Winter 2018 I spontaneously took a pre-calculus, algebra-based physics, and learning psychology program at the Evergreen State College. I fell in love with the way it changed the way I saw the world, and also found great enjoyment in problem solving. I also started building a relationship with my physics professor. I continued on with conceptual physics in Spring 2018 in a course focusing on biophysics and holistic health. It was an exploration of practices like acupuncture and the physics of how it works, which was truly fascinating and a combination of my interests. The physics portion was taught by the same professor and she is now more like a mentor to me! This fall I am unfortunately on medical leave because I have a concussion and brain work is very difficult. However, I plan on taking a year-long physics, calculus, and chemistry program next year so I can have access to upper division sciences. I am passionate and excited about my future in physics.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Physiological/Emotional, Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Cost (Outside Effort)

Response: I have taken an interest in Physics since in High School. I love conducting physics experiments, getting to understand the concepts and applying to real life situations.

Both of my parents studied physics, and my father is currently a professor at the local university, so I have been surrounded by physics since an early age. I`ve always enjoyed science and math in school, but it wasn`t until I took my high school physics class that I seriously considered studying physics. Between being genuinely interested in the material, having understanding it all come very easily, and having an incredible teacher, along with really great hands on labs, physics became one of my favorite classes. Possibly the only indicator before then was that I had gone to a workshop once as a kid about nanotechnology and had been incredibly excited about it since. Once in college, I started off looking in chemistry (another class I really loved in high school), mostly just checking out all of the sciences, and even seriously looking into engineering. Only knowing that I did not want to pursue medicine or business, I just wanted a program that fit all of my interests and learning/investigatory style. After two semesters of taking the generally required intro physics courses, I was hooked. Especially after learning about the research my professors were doing, both of which were involved with CERN, I knew I wanted to continue learning physics and to be able to explore everything my curious mind ever wanted to.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Physiological/Emotional, Mastery Experience, Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value

Response: I first was introduced to the idea of being a physics major in high school through my high school physics teacher. He made me aware about the growing opportunities in astrophysics and encouraged me to pursue it for a degree. That goal led me to RIT where I had a lot of flexibility in research opportunities along with good physics program. Since joining RIT I`ve had the opportunity to be involved with both observational astronomy research and computational astrophysics research, which is helping me develop a more solid idea of where I want to take my future.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Event Triggered

Response: My interest in physics came from having an amazing high school physics teacher. He made physics fun by exploring its applications and connecting it to film. I took three courses with that teacher and just enjoyed getting to learn about astrophysics, nuclear physics, and quantum physics. For a long time, I wanted to be a doctor, and I was considering a degree in biophysics. I hope that my physics education will allow me to find the intersections between physics and other fields like biology. I think I appreciate physics because of the constant discovery it involves, and I decided to pursue physics, so I could participate in research and help find solutions to the fundamental questions of the universe.
Codes: Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value (Biophysics), Intrinsic Value, Utility Value

Response: I initially began at an Engineering University and I found myself becoming bored with the curriculum. I did not see a purpose of the type of coursework I was doing, although it is similar to lower level physics work, and I was frustrated the mindsets of many engineering students/professionals I interacted with. I wondered more of why the answer was that way instead of what the answer was, which in my mind was an indication that I should not be in a field that searches to make the most money out of an answer they are not focused on understanding. After working for a summer at an engineering firm, my fears were confirmed that I would not get to satisfy my thirst for learning, and so I transferred into physics.
I felt challenged by Physics. When looking for majors to choose from I found that I would have the greatest faculty support in Physics, rather than other majors.

My dad received his PhD in solid state physics, so I was naturally drawn to it. He would quiz me every day about physics concepts, so I knew a lot before even taking a physics course.When I went to college, I knew I wanted an applied science route, but I wasn`t confident of which one. So I picked engineering undecided. Once I found out about engineering physics, I chose that as my major and never looked back.

I decided to study physics because it was the hardest class for me in High School. Since then, I decided that I was going to obtain a bachelor`s degree in physics no matter how hard it seems. Now I can assure that I made the right decision when I decided to study physics instead of Industrial Chemistry or other area in science. I have accomplished and learned so much as a student and as a person during my bachelor`s degree in physics that I don`t have any regret about the decision I took 4 years ago.

I was always good at math and science. I took AP Physics C my senior year and saw how math was applied to solve physics problems and thought that that was very cool. I also have experience working in the national laboratory setting and grew up in a very academic environment.
Codes: Mastery Experience, Intrinsic Value, Vicarious Experience

Response: I decided to study physics because I had had interest in topics related to physics since I was a kid and because I believed that I could do it and wanted to do something very challenging. I didn`t take the possibility seriously until part way though my sophomore year in college, which was my first year studying physics, because I just hadn`t pictured myself as a scientist before, but my faculty, parents, and classmates were all very encouraging and so I decided to give it a shot because I was enjoying it so much.

I have always had a love of math and science, and I became very interested in my high school physics class when the two were put together. I was interested in pursuing engineering, but decided to major in physics after not enjoying an engineering job shadowing program.

As a high school student, I absolutely hated physics. Something about drawing arrows on an imaginary elevator really dissuaded me. However, my dad, who was (and still is) a professor, saw a style of thinking in me that he imagined would be most ideal in a field like physics. Hence, during junior year of high school, he forced me to take AP Physics and try it out. By the end of the course, I fell in love with the course (thanks to an amazingly inspiring teacher in high school) and decided I wanted to continue my journey in the field.
Codes: Social Persuasion, Vicarious Experience, Intrinsic Value

Response: I`m an intended chemistry major, but some major influencing factors along the way have been some incredible chemistry and physics teachers/professors, two summers of experience TAing for chemistry, and doing a summer of research in organic synthesis.

I was an RN for many years and I left nursing and tried to figure out what I wanted to do and decided to go back to school to study BioChemical Engineering.  I started at a community college because the cost was less and took an Astronomy Class in the summer and my instructor suggested I take the next course Astronomy II which had more physics in it and I fell in love with it to the point of not  being able to think of other things.  One thing that really made an impact on my personally was the fact that the book we used in those classes often used pronouns like she and her and not he and him exclusively.  I was surprised at how much that made an impact on me.  The book also had a section on women`s contributions to Astrophysics and that also was impactful to me.  I have a great mentor at the University of Wyoming and she has had a big impact on me as well in supporting me and my research ideas.
Codes: Intrinsic Value (Astronomy), Vicarious Experience, Social Persuasion

Response: Every since high school, I was always really strong in mathematics. So in college, I have decided to pursue that subject and physics was a recommended course to take. I took it and was interested in the applications of calculus and trigonometry in real world problems.
I like space and learning how things work, so I want to go into astrophysics

All through my education (before college) i had been looking for a challenge, school was too easy, and i was always ahead of my class in math and science. When i got to college and took my first college level Physics course i loved it. I loved understanding how things work and how to apply math to the real world and how it all just made sense. I also loved the challenge it posed. I decided then that i wanted to become a Physicist. I have not decided my field yet, although i know a field or two i do not wish to go into.

I have always had a strong interest in the natural sciences. From early on, dfferent topics in biology, physics and chemistry interested me; during high school, I wanted to go more into the applied side of physics. During college, I have been able to incorporate this into my other interests on the social sciences side.

I was a stay at home mom for over ten years. I decided I wanted to go back to school when both of my kids were in school full time. I knew I wanted to study astronomy, but I didn`t realize how intertwined astronomy and physics are and I had never taken a physics course before. I wanted to study space though, so I applied to Rutgers to study astrophysics. That was a little over four years ago. I`ve been a student at Rutgers for nearly four years now, and because I attend part-time, I will graduate in the spring of 2020.

I grew up in the middle of the woods in northern Michigan. I first knew I was interested in the natural sciences through my constant questioning and interest at the land around me and stars above me. Before I went back to school to earn my GED, I was always in between my geo and astro interest. I knew Physics was a happy middle ground, that is why I decided it was the best goal to set my sights on during my indecisive times. After getting research experience at Northwestern Uni I realized getting a Physics degree is smart also because it looks and sounds good, this might be egotistical but it`s a nice backfall to know. This semester I soon realized just how segregated the field is by gender and race: I notice department pages at four-year universities I was interested in and observed the four women, including me, in my first physics class with 34 students. With this realization came a new motivation to become part of the change. My time at Northwestern studying gravitational waves was amazing, I never knew I would become so engrossed in a new idea like that so fast and so passionately. But I am not sure that is the right astrophysics discipline for me, although astrophysics has been and still is the way to go. I keep trying to gain these experiences like research at Northwestern and a funded trip to the Johnson Space Center with the hopes that I narrow my options but I just realized more and more I want to be a part of and contribute to this community because of the topic and the people. The topic is hard, but the take away is an understanding of the world around me - which I could never overlook. I can`t say where my path will lead exactly but I know that I`m happy with the path I am on right now.
Codes: Intrinsic Value, Utility Value, Event Triggered, Intrinsic Value (Astronomy)

Response: I liked physics, math and chemistry in high school, so I started exploring in those areas. I liked the creative problem-solving of physics and the application of math that physics provides, so I chose to be a physics major.
